Title: Partner plank band row
Desc: The partner plank band row is an abdominal exercise where two partners perform single-arm planks while pulling on the opposite ends of an exercise band. This technique can be done for time or reps in any ab-focused workout.
HowTo: 1. Start in a plank position with your partner facing you. 2. Each partner holds one end of the exercise band. 3. While maintaining a single-arm plank, pull the band towards you while your partner pulls the opposite end.

Title: Banded crunch isometric hold
Desc: The banded crunch isometric hold is an exercise targeting the abdominal muscles, particularly the rectus abdominis or "six-pack" muscles. The band adds resistance and continuous tension to this popular exercise.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back with your knees bent and feet flat on the floor. 2. Hold the band behind your head, keeping tension. 3. Crunch your torso up towards your knees while keeping your lower back pressed into the ground.

Title: FYR Banded Plank Jack
Desc: The banded plank jack is a variation on the plank that involves moving the legs in and out for repetitions. Having a band around the thighs forces the lower body to work harder, particularly the hips and glutes. The plank jack is commonly performed as part of a bodyweight circuit, or as part of a dynamic warm-up.
HowTo: 1. Start in a plank position with a resistance band around your thighs. 2. Jump your feet in towards your hands and then back out to the starting position. 3. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Banded crunch
Desc: The banded crunch is an exercise targeting the abdominal muscles, particularly the rectus abdominis or "six-pack" muscles. The band adds resistance and continuous tension to this popular exercise.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back with your knees bent and feet flat on the floor. 2. Hold the band behind your head, keeping tension. 3. Crunch your torso up towards your knees while keeping your lower back pressed into the ground.

Title: Crunch
Desc: The crunch is a popular core exercise targeting the rectus abdominis, or "six-pack" muscles, as well as the obliques. It has been the centerpiece of many ab-focused workouts, due to both its simplicity and the intense burn and mind-muscle connection it produces. It can be performed for time or reps as part of the ab-focused portion of any workout.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back with your knees bent and feet flat on the floor. 2. Place your hands behind your head. 3. Lift your shoulders off the ground by engaging your core, then lower back down.

Title: Decline band press sit-up
Desc: The decline band press sit-up is a weighted core exercise that works the rectus abdominis or "six pack" muscles, as well as the deep core muscles. It also taxes the muscles of the shoulders and upper back. Sit-up variations with added resistance are usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of the core-focused portion of a workout.
Muscles: rectus abdominis, deep core, shoulders, upper back
HowTo: 1. Lie on a decline bench with your feet secured. 2. Hold a resistance band or weight at chest level. 3. Perform a sit-up by lifting your upper body towards your knees while pressing the band forward. 4. Lower back down with control.

Title: FYR2 Banded Frog Pump
Desc: The FYR2 Banded Frog Pump is a glute activation exercise that targets the glutes and hamstrings. It is performed using a resistance band to add extra tension.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back with your feet together and knees bent out to the sides. 2. Place a resistance band around your thighs just above your knees. 3. Press your feet together and lift your hips towards the ceiling. 4. Squeeze your glutes at the top and lower back down.

Title: Band low-to-high twist
Desc: The band low-to-high twist is a core exercise targeting the upper abdominals and the obliques. Take care to perform it with control, as rapid, uncontrolled twisting can injure the spine. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps, at least 8-15 per side, as part of the core-focused portion of a workout.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and hold a resistance band anchored at a low point. 2. Pull the band diagonally across your body while twisting your torso. 3. Return to the starting position and repeat on the other side.

Title: Barbell roll-out
Desc: The barbell roll-out is an abdominal exercise that utilizes a barbell in the place of an ab roller. It is best performed with a barbell that has rotating collars, and is considered more difficult than other ab roller variations. Many lifters may not be able to perform a single rep at first, but once they can perform these for reps, they'll be rewarded with a seriously strong core.
HowTo: 1. Kneel on the floor with a barbell in front of you. 2. Grip the barbell with both hands and roll it forward while keeping your core tight. 3. Roll out as far as you can while maintaining control, then roll back to the starting position.

Title: Barbell Ab Rollout - On Knees
Desc: The barbell roll-out is an abdominal exercise that utilizes a barbell in the place of an ab roller. It is best performed with a barbell that has rotating collars, and is considered more difficult than other ab roller variations. Many lifters may not be able to perform a single rep at first, but once they can perform these for reps, they'll be rewarded with a seriously strong core.
HowTo: 1. Kneel on the floor with a barbell in front of you. 2. Grip the barbell with both hands and roll it forward while keeping your core tight. 3. Roll out as far as you can while maintaining control, then roll back to the starting position.

Title: Decline bar press sit-up
Desc: The decline bar press sit-up is a weighted core exercise targeting the abdominal muscles, particularly the lower abs. It also challenges the shoulders and upper back to move the weight. Weighted sit-up variations are usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of the core-focused portion of a workout.
Muscles: Rectus Abdominis, Obliques, Shoulders, Upper Back
HowTo: 1. Lie on a decline bench with your feet secured. 2. Hold a barbell above your chest with arms extended. 3. Engage your core and lift your torso towards your knees, then lower back down.

Title: Bench barbell roll-out
Desc: The bench barbell roll-out is a challenging exercise targeting the abdominals. It is similar to using an ab roller, but using a barbell allows for a wider grip. Placing the knees on a bench rather than the floor makes the move more difficult by increasing the challenge to the upper body.
HowTo: 1. Kneel on a bench with a barbell in front of you. 2. Grip the barbell and roll it forward while keeping your core tight. 3. Roll back to the starting position.

Title: Barbell Side Bend
Desc: The Barbell Side Bend is an exercise that targets the obliques and helps improve lateral core strength.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart holding a barbell across your shoulders. 2. Slowly bend to one side, keeping your back straight. 3. Return to the starting position and repeat on the other side.

Title: Seated bar twist
Desc: The seated bar twist is a core exercise meant to strengthen the obliques. It is often performed for high reps with relatively light weight, such as an empty barbell, a lightweight fixed-weight bar, or even a PVC pipe. It can be performed during a workout, at the end of a workout, or outside of the gym to build core strength and resiliency.
HowTo: 1. Sit on a bench with a barbell held across your shoulders. 2. Rotate your torso to one side, then return to the center. 3. Repeat on the other side.

Title: Single-arm landmine pull and press
Desc: The single-arm landmine pull and press is an explosive rotational movement using a barbell anchored in a landmine device. It combines a pull off the floor with rotation and finishes with a press. It is usually performed for low reps per set with an emphasis on speed and form, not moving heavy weight.
HowTo: 1. Stand with a barbell anchored in a landmine device. 2. Pull the barbell towards your body while rotating your torso. 3. Press the barbell overhead with one arm, then return to the starting position.

Title: Barbell Ab Roll Out - Gethin Variation
Desc: The barbell roll-out is an abdominal exercise that utilizes a barbell in the place of an ab roller. It is best performed with a barbell that has rotating collars, and is considered more difficult than other ab roller variations. Many lifters may not be able to perform a single rep at first, but once they can perform these for reps, they'll be rewarded with a seriously strong core.
HowTo: 1. Start in a kneeling position with the barbell in front of you. 2. Grip the barbell with both hands and roll it forward while keeping your core tight. 3. Roll the barbell out until your body is extended, then pull it back to the starting position.

Title: 30 Barbell Floor Wiper
Desc: The barbell floor wiper is a core exercise in which the barbell is held in the locked-out position of a floor press, and the hips and legs are rotated side to side. It targets the oblique muscles of the lateral abdomen, but is also seriously challenging to the deep core and rectus abdominis or "six-pack" muscles.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back with a barbell held above you in the locked-out position. 2. Rotate your hips and legs side to side while keeping the barbell stable above you. 3. Return to the center and repeat.

Title: 30 Barbell Roll-Out
Desc: The barbell roll-out is an abdominal exercise that utilizes a barbell in the place of an ab roller. It is best performed with a barbell that has rotating collars, and is considered more difficult than other ab roller variations. Many lifters may not be able to perform a single rep at first, but once they can perform these for reps, they'll be rewarded with a seriously strong core.
HowTo: 1. Start in a kneeling position with the barbell in front of you. 2. Grip the barbell with both hands and roll it forward while keeping your core tight. 3. Roll the barbell out until your body is extended, then pull it back to the starting position.

Title: Decline plate sit-up
Desc: The decline plate sit-up is a weighted core exercise that works the rectus abdominis or "six pack" muscles, as well as the deep core muscles. Weighted sit-up variations are usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of the core-focused portion of a workout.
HowTo: 1. Lie on a decline bench with your feet secured. 2. Hold a weight plate against your chest and perform a sit-up by curling your torso up towards your knees. 3. Lower back down and repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: KV Barbell Hip Thrust
Desc: The KV Barbell Hip Thrust is an exercise that primarily targets the glutes and hamstrings. It is performed by thrusting the hips upward while resting the upper back on a bench.
HowTo: 1. Sit on the ground with your upper back against a bench and a barbell over your hips. 2. Roll the barbell over your hips and secure it with your hands. 3. Drive through your heels and thrust your hips upward until your body is in a straight line from shoulders to knees. 4. Lower back down and repeat.

Title: Advanced Kettlebell Windmill
Desc: The Advanced Kettlebell Windmill is a challenging exercise that enhances core stability and improves shoulder and hip mobility. It requires balance and control, making it suitable for those looking to advance their kettlebell skills.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a kettlebell in one hand overhead. 2. Rotate your torso and hinge at the hips, lowering your free hand towards the ground while keeping your eyes on the kettlebell. 3. Return to the starting position and repeat for reps before switching sides.

Title: Kettlebell Windmill
Desc: The single-kettlebell windmill is a dynamic kettlebell exercise emphasizing core strength and shoulder and hip mobility and stability. It is often used as a functional warm-up or for multi-directional strength work. It doesn't work as well in a metcon or conditioning setting, and shouldn't be performed under intense fatigue.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a kettlebell in one hand overhead. 2. Rotate your torso and hinge at the hips, lowering your free hand towards the ground while keeping your eyes on the kettlebell. 3. Return to the starting position and repeat for reps before switching sides.

Title: Kettlebell Pass Between The Legs
Desc: The Kettlebell Pass Between The Legs is a dynamic exercise that targets the lower body and core. It enhances coordination and stability while engaging multiple muscle groups.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and hold a kettlebell with both hands. 2. Bend at the hips and knees, passing the kettlebell between your legs. 3. Stand up straight while bringing the kettlebell back up to the starting position. 4. Repeat for desired reps.

Title: Kettlebell 3-point leg extension
Desc: The kettlebell 3-point leg extension is a dynamic core exercise performed around and over a kettlebell or other short, stationary object. It is similar in some ways to a V-up or reverse crunch, but targets both the obliques and the rectus abdominis or "six-pack" muscles. It can be performed for reps or for time, usually in dedicated ab training or as part of a kettlebell and bodyweight circuit workout.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back with a kettlebell positioned near your feet. 2. Lift your legs and upper body simultaneously, reaching for the kettlebell while engaging your core. 3. Lower back down and repeat for desired reps.

Title: Double Kettlebell Swing
Desc: The Double Kettlebell Swing is an explosive exercise that targets the posterior chain and builds overall strength. It requires coordination and power to perform effectively.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a kettlebell in each hand. 2. Hinge at the hips and swing the kettlebells back between your legs. 3. Drive your hips forward, swinging the kettlebells up to shoulder height. 4. Repeat for desired reps.

Title: Burpee over kettlebell
Desc: The burpee over kettlebell is a more advanced version of a popular conditioning exercise. If you're performing a circuit that already has both burpees and kettlebell movements, it's a simple way to provide a novel stimulus to the muscles of the lower body and create a more athletic style of training.
HowTo: 1. Start in a standing position. 2. Drop into a squat and place your hands on the ground. 3. Jump your feet back into a plank position. 4. Perform a push-up. 5. Jump your feet back towards your hands. 6. Jump over the kettlebell and land softly.

Title: Kettlebell toe-touch
Desc: The kettlebell toe-touch is a more difficult version of a highly popular abdominal movement usually done for high reps. The simple addition of a weight makes the toe-touch far more difficult, providing a different stimulus to the core during training.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back with your legs extended and hold a kettlebell above your chest. 2. Engage your core and lift your upper body while reaching for your toes with the kettlebell. 3. Lower back down and repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Kettlebell swing
Desc: The kettlebell swing is a popular lower-body exercise emphasizing the hamstrings, glutes, and back muscles. It is often used to train explosive power, for aerobic or cardiovascular conditioning, in circuit training, or as an accessory movement for the deadlift.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a kettlebell with both hands. 2. Hinge at your hips and swing the kettlebell back between your legs. 3. Drive through your heels and thrust your hips forward to swing the kettlebell to shoulder height. 4. Let the kettlebell swing back down and repeat.

Title: Two-way swing
Desc: The two-way kettlebell swing is an exercise that alternates a chest-height kettlebell swing (sometimes called a "Russian" or "hardstyle" swing) with an overhead kettlebell swing (sometimes called an "American" swing). Both swing variations work many of the same muscles, such as the hamstrings, glutes, and core, but because the weight must travel farther in the overhead swing, it's slightly more metabolically demanding and works the upper back and shoulders more. This combo can be performed for time or reps and works especially well in circuit-style or full-body training. If you can't perform the overhead swing without lower back or shoulder pain, just perform the chest-height swing.
Muscles: hamstrings, glutes, core, shoulders, upper back
HowTo: 1. Start with the kettlebell at chest height. 2. Perform a chest-height swing, then transition to an overhead swing. 3. Alternate between the two swings for the desired duration or number of reps.

Title: Kettlebell crab reach
Desc: The kettlebell crab reach is a kettlebell pressing exercise in which the lifter presses a kettlebell overhead while in a modified single-arm bridge position. The simple addition of a weight makes the reach far more difficult, challenging the muscles of the back, shoulders, glutes, and core.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back with your knees bent and feet flat on the ground. 2. Press a kettlebell overhead with one arm while lifting your hips into a bridge position. 3. Hold the position briefly, then lower your hips and the kettlebell back down. 4. Repeat on the other side.

Title: Taylor Single-Arm Kettlebell Swing
Desc: The Taylor Single-Arm Kettlebell Swing is a dynamic exercise that targets multiple muscle groups while improving grip strength and coordination. It emphasizes the posterior chain and core stability.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a kettlebell in one hand. 2. Hinge at your hips and swing the kettlebell between your legs. 3. Drive through your hips to swing the kettlebell up to shoulder height, keeping your arm straight. 4. Allow the kettlebell to swing back down and repeat.

Title: Holman Kettlebell Up to Elbow Down
Desc: The Holman Kettlebell Up to Elbow Down is an exercise that focuses on the upper body, particularly the arms and shoulders. It helps in building strength and stability in the shoulder joint.
HowTo: 1. Start by holding a kettlebell in one hand at shoulder height. 2. Lower the kettlebell to elbow height while maintaining control. 3. Raise it back to shoulder height and repeat. 4. Switch arms after completing the set.

Title: FYR2 Double-Kettlebell Ski
Desc: The FYR2 Double-Kettlebell Ski is a high-intensity exercise that engages the entire body while improving cardiovascular fitness. It mimics the motion of skiing, providing a fun and effective workout.
HowTo: 1. Hold a kettlebell in each hand and stand with your feet hip-width apart. 2. Bend your knees slightly and hinge at your hips. 3. Swing both kettlebells back between your legs and then explosively swing them forward as you stand up. 4. Repeat in a rhythmic motion.

Title: FYR2 Kettlebell Hike
Desc: The FYR2 Kettlebell Hike is a lower body exercise that strengthens the legs and glutes while enhancing hip mobility. It is great for developing explosive power.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a kettlebell with both hands. 2. Hinge at your hips and lower the kettlebell between your legs. 3. Drive through your heels to stand up and swing the kettlebell forward. 4. Repeat the motion while maintaining control.

Title: FYR2 Kettlebell Cross-Body Catch
Desc: The FYR2 Kettlebell Cross-Body Catch is an exercise that enhances coordination and mobility while engaging multiple muscle groups. It is particularly effective for improving functional movement patterns.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a kettlebell in one hand. 2. Swing the kettlebell across your body to the opposite side. 3. Catch the kettlebell with the other hand as it swings back. 4. Repeat the motion, alternating hands.

Title: FYR2 Kettlebell Duck Walk
Desc: The FYR2 Kettlebell Duck Walk is a dynamic exercise that targets the lower body while improving balance and coordination. It involves walking in a squat position while holding a kettlebell.
HowTo: 1. Start in a squat position with your feet shoulder-width apart. 2. Hold a kettlebell in front of you with both hands. 3. Keep your chest up and back straight as you walk forward in the squat position, taking small steps. 4. Continue walking for a set distance or time.

Title: FYR2 Kettlebell Get-Up Reach
Desc: The FYR2 Kettlebell Get-Up Reach is a full-body exercise that enhances stability and strength. It combines a kettlebell get-up with an overhead reach to engage multiple muscle groups.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back with a kettlebell in one hand, arm extended. 2. Roll to your side and push up onto your elbow. 3. Move to a seated position, then rise to standing while keeping the kettlebell overhead. 4. Reverse the movement to return to the starting position.

Title: FYR2 Kettlebell Juggle
Desc: The FYR2 Kettlebell Juggle is a dynamic exercise that improves coordination and mobility. It involves juggling a kettlebell between hands while maintaining balance and control.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a kettlebell in one hand. 2. Swing the kettlebell up and catch it with the opposite hand. 3. Continue alternating hands in a controlled manner. 4. Focus on maintaining a stable core and good posture.

Title: FYR2 Squat-Clean-Alternating-Press Complex
Desc: The FYR2 Squat-Clean-Alternating-Press Complex is a compound exercise that builds strength and muscle mass. It combines a squat, clean, and press into one fluid movement.
HowTo: 1. Start with a kettlebell in each hand at your sides. 2. Perform a squat, lowering your body while keeping the kettlebells close. 3. As you rise, clean the kettlebells to shoulder height. 4. Press the kettlebells overhead, then lower them back to your sides and repeat.

Title: Dumbbell V-Sit Cross Jab
Desc: The dumbbell V-sit cross jab is a hybrid movement that trains the abdominal and shoulder muscles simultaneously. It can address multiple muscle groups in a time-efficient muscle-building or circuit-style workout, while also providing a cardiovascular challenge.
HowTo: 1. Sit on the floor with your legs extended in a V position. 2. Hold a dumbbell in each hand and lean back slightly. 3. Alternate jabbing the dumbbells across your body while engaging your core. 4. Keep your movements controlled and maintain balance.

Title: Dumbbell spell caster
Desc: The dumbbell spell caster is an exercise that primarily targets the abdominal muscles such as the obliques. However, it also works shoulders, back, hips, and legs, and demands all of those muscles work together in a coordinated motion. It is usually performed with relatively light weights for moderate to high reps, at least 8-12 reps per side. Make sure to only use a weight you can control.
HowTo: 1. Stand with a dumbbell in one hand, feet shoulder-width apart. 2. Slowly lean to the side, bringing the dumbbell down toward your knee, then return to the starting position.

Title: Dumbbell side bend
Desc: The dumbbell side bend is a popular exercise for targeting the oblique muscles of the abdomen. It is usually performed for relatively high reps, at least 8-12 reps per set or more. It can be performed one side at a time or alternating sides.
HowTo: 1. Stand with a dumbbell in one hand, feet shoulder-width apart. 2. Bend sideways at the waist, lowering the dumbbell toward the floor, then return to the starting position.

Title: Dumbbell crunch
Desc: The dumbbell crunch is a more difficult version of a highly popular abdominal movement. The simple addition of a weight makes the crunch far more difficult, providing a different stimulus to the core during training.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back with your knees bent and hold a dumbbell against your chest. 2. Crunch up by lifting your shoulders off the ground, then lower back down.

Title: Dumbbell Fix Dumbbell Sprawl
Desc: The Dumbbell Sprawl is a dynamic exercise that combines a push-up with a jump. It engages multiple muscle groups for a full-body workout.
HowTo: 1. Start in a standing position with a dumbbell in each hand. 2. Drop into a squat, place the dumbbells on the ground, and kick your feet back into a push-up position. 3. Perform a push-up, then jump your feet back toward your hands and stand up.

Title: Dumbbell Fix Alternating Renegade Row
Desc: The Alternating Renegade Row is an effective exercise for building strength in the back and arms while engaging the core. It requires stability and coordination as you lift one dumbbell at a time.
HowTo: 1. Start in a plank position with a dumbbell in each hand. 2. Row one dumbbell toward your hip while stabilizing your body with the other arm, then alternate sides.

Title: Dumbbell Fix Dumbbell Mountain Climber
Desc: The Dumbbell Mountain Climber is a dynamic exercise that engages multiple muscle groups while improving cardiovascular endurance. It combines strength and cardio for a full-body workout.
HowTo: 1. Start in a plank position with your hands on dumbbells. 2. Drive one knee towards your chest while keeping the other leg extended. 3. Quickly switch legs, bringing the opposite knee towards your chest. 4. Continue alternating legs at a rapid pace.

Title: Dumbbell Fix Dumbbell Russian Twist
Desc: The Dumbbell Russian Twist is an effective exercise for targeting the core, particularly the obliques. It helps improve rotational strength and stability.
HowTo: 1. Sit on the floor with your knees bent and feet flat. 2. Hold a dumbbell with both hands and lean back slightly. 3. Rotate your torso to one side, bringing the dumbbell beside your hip. 4. Return to the center and rotate to the other side. 5. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Dumbbell Fix Dumbbell Pull-Over
Desc: The Dumbbell Pull-Over is a great exercise for expanding the rib cage and strengthening the upper body. It targets the chest and back muscles effectively.
HowTo: 1. Lie on a bench with your upper back supported and feet flat on the ground. 2. Hold a dumbbell with both hands above your chest, arms slightly bent. 3. Slowly lower the dumbbell behind your head while keeping your arms straight. 4. Pull the dumbbell back to the starting position using your chest and lats.

Title: Dumbbell Fix Dumbbell Sit-Up
Desc: The Dumbbell Sit-Up is a classic exercise that targets the abdominal muscles. It helps build core strength and stability.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back with your knees bent and feet flat on the floor. 2. Hold a dumbbell against your chest or extend it above your head. 3. Engage your core and lift your torso towards your knees. 4. Lower back down with control and repeat.

Title: Dumbbell Fix Dumbbell Front Squat
Desc: The Dumbbell Front Squat is a powerful lower body exercise that targets the legs and glutes. It also engages the core for stability.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a dumbbell in each hand at shoulder height. 2. Lower your body into a squat by bending your knees and pushing your hips back. 3. Keep your chest up and back straight. 4. Return to the starting position by pushing through your heels.

Title: Dumbbell Fix Full Man Maker
Desc: The Dumbbell Fix Full Man Maker is a full-body exercise that combines multiple movements to build strength and endurance. It typically involves a combination of a push-up, a row, a squat, and a press.
HowTo: 1. Start in a standing position holding dumbbells. 2. Drop into a squat and place the dumbbells on the floor. 3. Kick your feet back into a push-up position. 4. Perform a push-up. 5. Row one dumbbell to your side, then the other. 6. Jump your feet back to the squat position. 7. Stand up and press the dumbbells overhead.

Title: Dumbbell T-hold
Desc: The dumbbell T-hold is a static exercise that primarily targets the obliques, although it also works the shoulders and upper back. It involves holding a dumbbell in the air while in a side plank position. It is usually performed for timed holds, although it can be performed dynamically for reps as a plank with dumbbell rotation.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your side and stack your feet. 2. Place one hand on the ground for support and hold a dumbbell in the other hand. 3. Lift your hips off the ground into a side plank. 4. Extend the dumbbell above your shoulder, keeping your arm straight. 5. Hold this position for the desired time.

Title: Dumbbell hollow-body floor press
Desc: The dumbbell hollow-body floor press combines upper-body strength and core work in one move.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back with your legs elevated and straight. 2. Hold dumbbells in each hand at chest level. 3. Press the dumbbells up until your arms are fully extended. 4. Lower the dumbbells back to your chest while maintaining the hollow-body position.

Title: Dumbbell crusher
Desc: The dumbbell crusher is a dumbbell complex that combines a squat with a dumbbell curl, followed by a triceps press. It targets the legs, glutes, biceps, shoulders, and triceps in a single sequence, making it a great way to burn serious calories and hit a lot of muscles in a short period of time. The upper-body movements will determine the amount of weight you can effectively use.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart holding dumbbells. 2. Perform a squat while holding the dumbbells. 3. As you rise, curl the dumbbells to your shoulders. 4. Press the dumbbells overhead. 5. Lower the dumbbells back to your sides and repeat.

Title: Dumbbell Crunch - Gethin Variation
Desc: The dumbbell crunch is a more difficult version of a highly popular abdominal movement. The simple addition of a weight makes the crunch far more difficult, providing a different stimulus to the core during training.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back with your knees bent and feet flat on the ground. 2. Hold a dumbbell against your chest with both hands. 3. Engage your core and lift your shoulders off the ground, crunching towards your knees. 4. Lower back down and repeat.

Title: Single-arm dumbbell crunch
Desc: The single-arm dumbbell crunch is a more difficult version of a highly popular abdominal movement. Adding a weight to one side makes the crunch far more difficult to your rectus abdominis or "six-pack" muscles, as well as the obliques and deep core muscles.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back with your knees bent and feet flat on the floor. 2. Hold a dumbbell in one hand and perform a crunch by lifting your shoulders off the ground while keeping the other arm extended to the side.

Title: HM Alternating Dumbbell Plank Row
Desc: The HM Alternating Dumbbell Plank Row is an effective exercise that targets the back and core while improving stability.
HowTo: 1. Start in a plank position with a dumbbell in each hand. 2. Row one dumbbell towards your hip while stabilizing your body with the other arm, alternating sides.

Title: Dumbbell straight-legged hip raise
Desc: The dumbbell straight-legged hip raise works the hips and glutes. It requires and teaches body control and coordination.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back with your legs straight and hold a dumbbell in your hands. 2. Lift your hips towards the ceiling while keeping your legs straight, squeezing your glutes at the top.

Title: Seated leg tuck with dumbbell
Desc: The seated leg tuck with dumbbell is an ab exercise requiring only a bench and a dumbbell. It's commonly performed for high reps as a burnout at the end of a core workout.
HowTo: 1. Sit on a bench with your feet off the ground and hold a dumbbell in both hands. 2. Tuck your knees towards your chest while leaning back slightly, then return to the starting position.

Title: Dumbbell V-sit cross jab-
Desc: The dumbbell V-sit cross jab is a hybrid movement that trains the abdominal and shoulder muscles simultaneously. It can address multiple muscle groups in a time-efficient muscle-building or circuit-style workout, while also providing a cardiovascular challenge.
HowTo: 1. Sit on the floor with your legs in a V position and hold a dumbbell in both hands. 2. Rotate your torso to one side while extending your arms and then alternate to the other side in a controlled manner.

Title: 30 Hanging Leg Raise With Dumbbell
Desc: The Hanging Leg Raise is an effective exercise for strengthening the core and hip flexors. It involves hanging from a bar and raising your legs to engage the abdominal muscles.
HowTo: 1. Hang from a pull-up bar with your arms fully extended. 2. Keeping your legs straight, raise them towards your chest while engaging your core. 3. Lower your legs back to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Dumbbell Get-Up Sit-Up
Desc: The Dumbbell Get-Up Sit-Up combines a sit-up with a dumbbell for added resistance, targeting the core and improving overall strength. This exercise also enhances stability and coordination.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back holding a dumbbell in one hand. 2. Perform a sit-up while keeping the dumbbell extended above your chest. 3. Return to the starting position and repeat, switching sides.

Title: Holman Right Side Plank with Left Triceps Press
Desc: The Holman Right Side Plank with Left Triceps Press is a variation of the side plank that engages the obliques and shoulders. It combines stability with upper body strength.
HowTo: 1. Start in a side plank position on your right side, with your right elbow under your shoulder. 2. Hold a dumbbell in your left hand and press it overhead while maintaining the plank. 3. Lower the dumbbell back to your shoulder and repeat.

Title: Holman Left Side Plank with Right Triceps Press
Desc: The Holman Left Side Plank with Right Triceps Press is similar to the right side variation, focusing on the left side of the body. It builds core stability and shoulder strength.
HowTo: 1. Start in a side plank position on your left side, with your left elbow under your shoulder. 2. Hold a dumbbell in your right hand and press it overhead while maintaining the plank. 3. Lower the dumbbell back to your shoulder and repeat.

Title: Holman Boat with Feet Push-Out and Overhead Press
Desc: The Holman Boat with Feet Push-Out and Overhead Press is a challenging exercise that targets the core while also working the shoulders. It combines balance with strength training.
HowTo: 1. Sit on the floor with your knees bent and feet flat. 2. Lean back slightly and lift your feet off the ground, balancing on your sit bones. 3. Push your feet out while pressing a dumbbell overhead, then return to the starting position.

Title: Holman Hovering Plank Row
Desc: The Holman Hovering Plank Row is a core-strengthening exercise that combines a plank position with a rowing motion. It targets the abdominal muscles and the back while improving stability and strength.
HowTo: 1. Start in a plank position with your hands directly under your shoulders. 2. Hold a dumbbell in one hand and row it towards your hip while stabilizing your body with the other arm. 3. Alternate sides while maintaining a strong plank position.

Title: Holman Weighted Seated Killer Abs to Russian Twist
Desc: The Holman Weighted Seated Killer Abs to Russian Twist is an effective exercise for targeting the core and oblique muscles. It combines seated ab work with rotational movements to enhance core strength and stability.
HowTo: 1. Sit on the floor with your knees bent and feet flat, holding a weight in both hands. 2. Lean back slightly and twist your torso to one side, then to the other, while keeping your core engaged. 3. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Holman Straight Plank Dumbbell Reach-Under
Desc: The Holman Straight Plank Dumbbell Reach-Under is a challenging exercise that engages the core and shoulders. It requires balance and coordination while strengthening the upper body and core.
HowTo: 1. Start in a plank position with a dumbbell in one hand. 2. Reach the dumbbell under your body towards the opposite side while maintaining a stable plank. 3. Return to the starting position and repeat on the other side.

Title: Holman Straight-Arm Side Plank Overhead Press to Chest Press
Desc: The Holman Straight-Arm Side Plank Overhead Press to Chest Press is a dynamic exercise that targets the core and shoulders. It combines a side plank with pressing movements to enhance strength and stability.
HowTo: 1. Start in a side plank position with a dumbbell in your top hand. 2. Press the dumbbell overhead, then bring it down to your chest. 3. Repeat the pressing motion while maintaining the side plank position.

Title: Holman Weighted Burpee to Pike
Desc: The Holman Weighted Burpee to Pike is a high-intensity exercise that works the entire body. It combines a burpee with a pike position to enhance cardiovascular fitness and strength.
HowTo: 1. Start standing, then drop into a squat and place your hands on the floor. 2. Jump your feet back into a plank position, perform a push-up, then jump your feet back to your hands. 3. From the squat position, jump into a pike position, then return to standing.

Title: Holman Straight-Legged Boat Chest Press
Desc: The Holman Straight-Legged Boat Chest Press is a strength exercise targeting the chest and triceps. It combines a boat position with a pressing motion to engage the upper body while stabilizing the core.
HowTo: 1. Sit in a boat position with your legs extended and feet off the ground. 2. Hold dumbbells at chest level with elbows bent. 3. Press the weights upward until your arms are fully extended, then lower back to the starting position.

Title: Holman Weighted Burpee to Side Delt Raise
Desc: The Holman Weighted Burpee to Side Delt Raise is a dynamic exercise that combines cardio with strength training. It engages multiple muscle groups while improving cardiovascular fitness.
HowTo: 1. Start standing with weights in hand. 2. Drop into a squat and place weights on the ground. 3. Kick your feet back into a plank position. 4. Perform a push-up, then jump your feet back to your hands. 5. Stand up and raise the weights to the side for a side delt raise.

Title: Holman Heavy Double Pike
Desc: The Holman Heavy Double Pike is a power exercise that focuses on explosive movements. It enhances overall strength and coordination through dynamic pike movements.
HowTo: 1. Start in a standing position. 2. Bend at the hips and lower your torso while keeping your legs straight. 3. Jump explosively while bringing your legs up into a pike position. 4. Land softly and repeat.

Title: Holman Heavy Double Split Pike
Desc: The Holman Heavy Double Split Pike is a challenging power exercise designed to build strength and agility. It focuses on explosive leg movements and core stability.
HowTo: 1. Start in a standing position. 2. Bend at the hips and lower your torso while keeping your legs straight. 3. Jump explosively into a split position, alternating legs. 4. Land softly and repeat.

Title: MetaBurn Alternating Dumbbell Sit-Through
Desc: The MetaBurn Alternating Dumbbell Sit-Through is a mobility exercise that enhances core strength and flexibility. It focuses on controlled movements to engage the abdominal muscles.
HowTo: 1. Start in a plank position with a dumbbell in each hand. 2. Shift your weight to one side and lift the opposite hand while rotating your torso. 3. Sit through with the lifted leg, bringing it under your body. 4. Return to plank and repeat on the other side.

Title: MetaBurn Alternating Plank Row With Dumbbell Pull-Through
Desc: The MetaBurn Alternating Plank Row with Dumbbell Pull-Through is a full-body exercise that engages multiple muscle groups. It combines elements of stability and strength training to enhance core stability and upper body strength.
HowTo: 1. Start in a plank position with a dumbbell in one hand. 2. Row the dumbbell towards your hip while stabilizing your body. 3. Place the dumbbell on the ground and pull it through to the other side. 4. Repeat on the opposite side.

Title: MetaBurn Alternating Plank Row With Push-Up
Desc: The MetaBurn Alternating Plank Row with Push-Up is a challenging exercise that targets the upper body and core. It combines a push-up with a rowing motion to build strength and stability.
HowTo: 1. Begin in a plank position. 2. Perform a push-up. 3. After the push-up, row one dumbbell towards your hip. 4. Alternate sides and repeat.

Title: MetaBurn Dumbbell Russian Twist
Desc: The MetaBurn Dumbbell Russian Twist is an effective exercise for strengthening the core and improving rotational movement. It targets the obliques and helps enhance overall core stability.
HowTo: 1. Sit on the ground with your knees bent and feet flat. 2. Hold a dumbbell with both hands and lean back slightly. 3. Rotate your torso to one side, bringing the dumbbell beside your hip. 4. Return to the center and rotate to the other side.

Title: MetaBurn Dumbbell Toe-Touch
Desc: The MetaBurn Dumbbell Toe-Touch is a mobility exercise that focuses on stretching the hamstrings and lower back. It helps improve flexibility and range of motion.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a dumbbell in each hand. 2. Hinge at the hips and lower the dumbbells towards your toes while keeping your back straight. 3. Reach as far as comfortable, then return to standing.

Title: MetaBurn Plank To Alternating Row
Desc: The MetaBurn Plank to Alternating Row is a dynamic exercise that engages the entire body, focusing on strength and stability. It enhances core strength while working the upper body.
HowTo: 1. Start in a plank position with a dumbbell in each hand. 2. Row one dumbbell towards your hip while maintaining plank form. 3. Lower the dumbbell back down and repeat on the opposite side.

Title: Standing dumbbell knee crunch-
Desc: The standing dumbbell knee crunch is a great way to train the abs while standing up. Additionally, the deltoids are worked because the lifter holds a pair of dumbbells overhead throughout.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a dumbbell in each hand overhead. 2. Lift one knee towards your chest while engaging your core, then lower it back down and repeat on the other side.

Title: MetaBurn Plank With Dumbbell Rotation
Desc: The MetaBurn Plank with Dumbbell Rotation is an effective core exercise that also targets the shoulders. It combines stability and strength training.
HowTo: 1. Start in a plank position with a dumbbell in each hand. 2. Rotate your body to one side, lifting the dumbbell towards the ceiling, then return to plank and repeat on the other side.

Title: FYR2 Dumbbell Crab Reach
Desc: The FYR2 Dumbbell Crab Reach is a dynamic movement that enhances mobility and core stability. It engages multiple muscle groups while improving flexibility.
HowTo: 1. Start in a crab position with your hands and feet on the ground, holding a dumbbell in one hand. 2. Reach the dumbbell towards the ceiling while rotating your torso, then return to the starting position and switch sides.

Title: FYR2 Dumbbell Man-Maker
Desc: The FYR2 Dumbbell Man-Maker is a compound exercise that works multiple muscle groups for a full-body workout. It combines a push-up, row, and squat into one movement.
HowTo: 1. Start in a push-up position with a dumbbell in each hand. 2. Perform a push-up, then row one dumbbell to your side, followed by a squat and overhead press with both dumbbells.

Title: FYR2 Dumbbell Sit-Up Reach
Desc: The FYR2 Dumbbell Sit-Up Reach is designed to strengthen the core while incorporating a reach for added difficulty. It targets the abdominal muscles effectively.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back with your knees bent and hold a dumbbell at your chest. 2. Perform a sit-up while reaching the dumbbell towards the ceiling, then lower back down.

Title: FYR2 Loaded Beast Sprawl
Desc: The FYR2 Loaded Beast Sprawl is a dynamic movement that combines elements of mobility and strength. It helps improve flexibility and strength throughout the entire body.
HowTo: Start in a beast position with hands under shoulders and knees under hips. Shift your weight forward, then kick your legs back into a sprawl position, and return to the beast position.

Title: FYR2 Loaded to Unloaded Beast
Desc: The FYR2 Loaded to Unloaded Beast is a transitional exercise that enhances mobility and strength. It focuses on fluid movement patterns that engage multiple muscle groups.
HowTo: Begin in a loaded beast position, then shift your weight to transition smoothly into an unloaded position, maintaining control throughout the movement.

Title: Lying Leg Pullover
Desc: The Lying Leg Pullover is an exercise that targets the lower body and core. It helps in building strength and stability in the legs.
HowTo: Lie on your back with your legs extended. Hold a weight above your chest, then lower your legs and arms simultaneously before returning to the starting position.

Title: Landmine twist
Desc: The landmine twist is a rotational abdominal movement performed using an angled barbell anchored at floor level in a landmine device. It can also be performed by sticking a barbell in the corner of a room, preferably in a towel to protect the walls. It targets the deep muscles of the core, including both the obliques and the transversus abdominis. It can be done fast or slow, for time or reps, either in traditional muscle-focused rep ranges such as 8-12 reps per side or for higher rep ranges.
HowTo: Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, holding the end of a barbell anchored in a landmine. Rotate your torso to one side, then return to the center and repeat on the other side.

Title: Suspended ab fall-out
Desc: The suspended ab fall-out is a dynamic abdominal exercise utilizing a suspension strap system or gymnastic rings. It is similar in form to an ab roller, but can more easily be scaled to be more or less difficult. It targets the muscles of the rectus abdominis or "six-pack" muscles, as well as the deep core muscles. It can be trained for low reps for strength or higher reps for muscle definition.
HowTo: Start in a kneeling position with suspension straps or gymnastic rings. Hold the straps and lean forward, extending your body while keeping your core engaged, then pull back to the starting position.

Title: Decline reverse crunch
Desc: The decline reverse crunch is a popular bodyweight exercise targeting the abdominal muscles, particularly the lower abs. It is usually performed for high reps, such as 10-15 reps per set or more, as part of the ab-focused portion of a workout.
HowTo: 1. Lie on a decline bench with your legs secured. 2. Curl your hips and knees towards your chest while contracting your abs, then slowly return to the starting position.

Title: Plate Twist
Desc: The Plate Twist is an exercise that targets the core, particularly the obliques, by incorporating a twisting motion with a weight plate.
HowTo: 1. Sit on the floor with your knees bent and feet flat. 2. Hold a weight plate with both hands, lean back slightly, and twist your torso to one side, then to the other.

Title: Weighted Crunches
Desc: The weighted suitcase crunch is a weighted version of a popular abdominal training exercise. The simple addition of a weight makes the suitcase crunch far more difficult, helping build the "six pack" muscles and providing a different stimulus to the core during training.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back with your knees bent and hold a weight against your chest. 2. Crunch your upper body towards your knees, lifting the weight, then lower back down.

Title: Ab Roller
Desc: The ab wheel roll-out is an exercise targeting the abdominals, often with an inexpensive wheel device with a handle on either side. Many trainers and strength coaches claim it's one of, if no the best exercise for developing strength in the midsection. Beginners may have to start with a limited range of motion or just wheel planks.
HowTo: 1. Kneel on the floor and grip the handles of the ab wheel. 2. Roll the wheel forward while keeping your core tight, then pull back to the starting position.

Title: Otis-Up
Desc: The Otis-up is a weighted exercise focusing on the abdominal muscles, as well as the shoulders to a lesser degree. It primarily targets the rectus abdominus or six-pack muscles, but also involves the obliques and deep core muscles. It is normally performed on a decline bench holding a weight plate, but can also be performed with a dumbbell, kettlebell, or other weight.
HowTo: 1. Lie on a decline bench holding a weight plate at your chest. 2. Lift your upper body towards your knees while keeping your core engaged, then lower back down.

Title: Captain's chair knee raise
Desc: The captain's chair knee raise is a bodyweight exercise that targets the abs. It is performed on an apparatus that allows the forearms to rest on pads and the upright torso to hang freely. Knee raises are often performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps or more, as part of ab-focused training.
HowTo: 1. Position yourself on the captain's chair with your forearms resting on the pads. 2. Hang your legs down and then raise your knees towards your chest while keeping your back straight.

Title: Sledgehammer swing
Desc: The sledgehammer swing is an exercise working the abdominals and numerous other muscles. The sledgehammer is slammed from overhead onto a tire which absorbs the impact and causes the hammer to bounce back up. It can be performed for time or reps as part of a functional fitness or athleticism-focused workout.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a sledgehammer with both hands. 2. Raise the sledgehammer overhead and swing it down onto a tire, using your core and legs to generate power.

Title: Decline bar press sit-up
Desc: The decline bar press sit-up is a weighted core exercise targeting the abdominal muscles, particularly the lower abs. It also challenges the shoulders and upper back to move the weight. Weighted sit-up variations are usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of the core-focused portion of a workout.
HowTo: 1. Lie on a decline bench with a barbell held above your chest. 2. Perform a sit-up by lifting your torso towards your knees while pressing the barbell upwards.

Title: Pallof press
Desc: The Pallof press is an isometric exercise that trains core stability. It involves resisting rotation from a cable or band, developing what is sometimes called "anti-rotation" core strength. It is most often seen in programs for athletes who compete in sports that test strength, power, and functional movements. It can be trained in timed holds or for reps by pressing the cable or band away from the body.
HowTo: 1. Stand with a cable or resistance band attached to your side. 2. Press the cable or band away from your body while resisting rotation, keeping your core tight.

Title: Weighted Sit-Ups - With Bands
Desc: The weighted sit-up is a more difficult version of a highly popular abdominal movement. The simple addition of a weight makes the sit-up far more difficult, providing a different stimulus to the core during training and helping build strong abs.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back with your knees bent and hold a weight above your chest. 2. Perform a sit-up by lifting your torso towards your knees while keeping the weight steady.

Title: Suitcase crunch
Desc: The suitcase crunch is a bodyweight movement that targets the muscles of the abs, the rectus abdominis or "six-pack" muscles in particular. It is similar to a V-up, but the lower back stays flat against the ground. It can be performed for time or reps in the ab-focused portion of any workout.
HowTo: Lie on your back with your knees bent and feet flat on the ground. Lift your shoulders off the ground while bringing your knees towards your chest, then lower back down.

Title: FYR Rope Jumping
Desc: Jumping rope is classic conditioning exercise that is popular with everyone from children to boxers to CrossFit athletes. It targets many different muscles, including the calves, glutes, shoulders, and upper back, and is great for everything from fat loss to improving overall athletic performance.
HowTo: Stand with your feet together and hold the handles of the jump rope. Swing the rope overhead and jump as it comes down, landing softly on the balls of your feet.

Title: Barbell press sit-up
Desc: The barbell press sit-up is a weighted exercise focusing on the abdominal muscles, as well as the shoulders to a lesser degree. It primarily targets the rectus abdominis or "six-pack" muscles, but also involves the obliques and deep core muscles. It can be performed on the floor with the feet anchored or unanchored, or on a decline or other bench. It is similar to the Otis-up, which is performed with a weight plate.
HowTo: Lie on your back with your knees bent and feet anchored. Hold a barbell above your chest, then perform a sit-up while pressing the barbell upwards.

Title: Single-arm bent-over rear delt fly
Desc: The single-arm bent-over rear delt fly is a popular upper-body exercise that targets the muscles on the back of the shoulder joint, specifically the rear head of the deltoid. Since pressing movements build the front and (to a lesser degree) side deltoid heads, this move is often done to promote balanced shoulder development. It is usually performed for high reps, such as 10-15 reps per set or more, as part of a shoulder or upper-body workout.
HowTo: Stand bent over with one arm hanging down holding a dumbbell. Raise the dumbbell out to the side, keeping your elbow slightly bent, and squeeze your shoulder blade at the top.

Title: Captain's chair leg raise
Desc: The captain's chair leg raise is a bodyweight exercise that targets the abs. It is performed on an apparatus that allows the forearms to rest on pads and the upright torso to hang freely. Leg raise variations are often performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps or more, as part of ab-focused training.
HowTo: Position yourself on the captain's chair with your forearms resting on the pads. Raise your legs by flexing at the hips and knees, then lower them back down slowly.

Title: Shoulder-Elevated One-Leg Hip Thrusts
Desc: Shoulder-elevated one-leg hip thrusts are a variation of the hip thrust that targets the glutes and hamstrings while also engaging the core. This exercise helps improve hip extension strength and stability.
HowTo: 1. Sit on the ground with your upper back against a bench and one foot flat on the floor. 2. Extend the other leg straight out in front of you. 3. Drive through the heel of the foot on the ground, lifting your hips towards the ceiling while keeping the extended leg straight. 4. Lower your hips back down and repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Ab Twist - Gethin Variation
Desc: The cross-body sit-up is a bodyweight exercise targeting the ab muscles, the obliques and rectus abdominis or "six-pack" muscles in particular. It involves bringing the opposite-side knee and elbow together, usually alternating sides with each rep. It can be performed for time or reps as part of the ab-focused portion of any workout.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back with your knees bent and feet flat on the floor. 2. Place your hands behind your head. 3. As you sit up, twist your torso to bring your right elbow towards your left knee while extending your right leg. 4. Lower back down and repeat on the other side.

Title: Weighted Crunch - Gethin Variation
Desc: The weighted sit-up is a more difficult version of a highly popular abdominal movement. The simple addition of a weight makes the sit-up far more difficult, providing a different stimulus to the core during training and helping build strong abs.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back with your knees bent and hold a weight plate or dumbbell against your chest. 2. Engage your core and sit up, lifting your upper body towards your knees. 3. Slowly lower back down to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Ab Wheel Roll-Out - Gethin Variation
Desc: The ab wheel roll-out is an exercise targeting the abdominals, often with an inexpensive wheel device with a handle on either side. Many trainers and strength coaches claim it's one of, if no the best exercise for developing strength in the midsection. Beginners may have to start with a limited range of motion or just wheel planks.
HowTo: 1. Kneel on the floor and hold the ab wheel with both hands. 2. Roll the wheel forward, extending your body while keeping your core engaged. 3. Roll back to the starting position by pulling with your arms and engaging your abs.

Title: Bench crunch
Desc: The bench crunch is a popular ab exercise performed lying on a bench. It is largely similar to the same exercise performed on the floor, but being able to press the lower back into the bench pad can help reinforce proper form and increase the burn in the abs. Like most crunch variations, it is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more.
HowTo: 1. Lie on a bench with your lower back pressed against the pad and your feet flat on the floor. 2. Place your hands behind your head or across your chest. 3. Engage your core and lift your upper body towards your knees. 4. Lower back down slowly and repeat.

Title: Decline plate sit-up twist
Desc: The decline plate sit-up twist is a weighted core exercise that works the obliques and rectus abdominis or "six pack" muscles, as well as the deep core muscles. Weighted sit-up variations are usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of the core-focused portion of a workout.
Muscles: obliques, rectus abdominis, deep core muscles
HowTo: 1. Lie on a decline bench with a weight plate held against your chest. 2. Perform a sit-up while twisting your torso to one side, then return to the starting position and repeat on the other side.

Title: Reverse ab roll-out
Desc: The reverse ab roll-out is an exercise targeting the abdominals. It's a twist on the ab wheel roll-out, and is similar to a body saw exercise, only performed on a foam roller. Instead of your arms moving and your lower body remaining stationary, your lower body moves and your arms remain stationary. Beginners may need to use a limited range of motion.
HowTo: 1. Start in a kneeling position with your feet on a foam roller. 2. Roll your body back while keeping your arms stationary, then return to the starting position.

Title: 30 Seated Twist With PVC Pipe
Desc: The seated bar twist is a core exercise aiming to strengthen the obliques.
HowTo: 1. Sit on the ground with your legs extended and a PVC pipe held across your shoulders. 2. Twist your torso to one side, then return to the center and twist to the other side.

Title: Suspended crunch-
Desc: The suspended crunch is an abdominal exercise performed with the feet in the stirrups of a suspension strap system. It targets the muscles of the core, most prominently the rectus abdominis or "six-pack" muscles, but also taxes the shoulders and deep core muscles.
Muscles: rectus abdominis, shoulders, deep core muscles
HowTo: 1. Adjust the suspension straps so your feet can fit into the stirrups. 2. Hang from the straps and perform a crunch by bringing your knees towards your chest while engaging your core.

Title: Suspended oblique crunch
Desc: The suspended oblique crunch is an abdominal exercise performed with the feet in the stirrups of a suspension strap system. It targets the muscles of the core, most prominently the obliques, but also the rectus abdominis or "six-pack" muscles, the shoulders, and deep core muscles.
Muscles: obliques, rectus abdominis, shoulders, deep core muscles
HowTo: 1. Secure your feet in the stirrups of the suspension strap system. 2. Perform a crunch while twisting your torso to one side, then return to the center and twist to the other side.

Title: Weighted sit-up
Desc: The weighted sit-up is a more difficult version of a highly popular abdominal movement. The simple addition of a weight makes the sit-up far more difficult, providing a different stimulus to the core during training and helping build strong abs.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back with your knees bent and feet flat on the floor. 2. Hold a weight against your chest or extend it above your head, then lift your upper body towards your knees, engaging your core throughout the movement.

Title: 30 Decline Press Sit-Up
Desc: The decline bar press sit-up is a core and upper body exercise targeting the lower abdominals and shoulders.
HowTo: 1. Lie on a decline bench with your feet secured. 2. Perform a sit-up while pressing a barbell or weight plate above your chest, focusing on engaging your core and shoulders.

Title: Holman Towel Reverse Plank Alternating Heel Pull-in
Desc: The Holman Towel Reverse Plank Alternating Heel Pull-in is an exercise that enhances core stability and shoulder strength while promoting flexibility.
HowTo: 1. Start in a reverse plank position with your feet on a towel. 2. Pull one heel towards your glutes while keeping your hips elevated, then alternate sides.

Title: Holman Boat with Weighted Cross Punch
Desc: The Holman Boat with Weighted Cross Punch is a dynamic core exercise that combines stability with upper body strength.
HowTo: 1. Sit in a boat position with your legs lifted and knees bent. 2. Hold a weight in one hand and punch across your body while maintaining balance, alternating sides.

Title: Holman Weighted Hook Punch
Desc: The Holman Weighted Hook Punch is an exercise that targets the upper body while enhancing punching power and coordination.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, holding a weight in one hand. 2. Rotate your hips and shoulders as you throw a hook punch, engaging your core and maintaining control.

Title: Holman Weighted Traveling Punch
Desc: The Holman Weighted Traveling Punch is a dynamic exercise that targets the upper body, focusing on arm strength and coordination. It involves performing punches while maintaining a stable core and engaging the shoulder muscles.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, holding weights in both hands. 2. Engage your core and keep your elbows slightly bent. 3. Step forward with one foot and punch forward with the opposite arm. 4. Alternate arms and continue moving forward.

Title: Holman Weighted Uppercut Punch
Desc: The Holman Weighted Uppercut Punch is designed to build strength in the arms and shoulders while improving punching technique. This exercise emphasizes upward punching motion, engaging the core for stability.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, holding weights in both hands. 2. Bend your knees slightly and engage your core. 3. Perform an uppercut motion with one arm while keeping the other arm in a guard position. 4. Alternate arms and repeat.

Title: Holman Slow Weighted Double Pike
Desc: The Holman Slow Weighted Double Pike is an advanced core exercise that challenges stability and strength. It focuses on controlled movements to engage the abdominal muscles effectively.
HowTo: 1. Start in a plank position with weights in your hands. 2. Slowly lift your hips towards the ceiling while bringing your knees towards your chest. 3. Hold for a moment, then return to the plank position. 4. Repeat the movement with control.

Title: Holman Plate Straight Plank Reach
Desc: The Holman Plate Straight Plank Reach is a stability exercise that enhances core strength and shoulder mobility. It involves reaching forward while maintaining a plank position to engage multiple muscle groups.
HowTo: 1. Start in a plank position with a weight plate under one hand. 2. Reach forward with the opposite hand towards the plate. 3. Return to the plank position and alternate sides. 4. Keep your core engaged throughout the movement.

Title: Holman Plate Elbow Plank Jack to Straight Plank Jack
Desc: The Holman Plate Elbow Plank Jack to Straight Plank Jack is a compound exercise that targets the core and shoulders while improving stability. It combines plank variations with dynamic movements.
HowTo: 1. Start in an elbow plank position with a weight plate nearby. 2. Jump your feet out to the sides and back together (plank jack). 3. Transition to a straight-arm plank and repeat the jumping motion. 4. Maintain a tight core throughout the exercise.

Title: Holman Plate Hill Climber
Desc: The Holman Plate Hill Climber is a dynamic exercise that engages multiple muscle groups while improving cardiovascular endurance. It involves a plank position with alternating knee drives towards the chest.
HowTo: 1. Start in a plank position with your hands on a plate. 2. Drive your right knee towards your chest. 3. Return to plank and switch legs, driving your left knee towards your chest. 4. Continue alternating legs at a quick pace.

Title: Holman Plate Reverse Plank Hill Climber
Desc: The Holman Plate Reverse Plank Hill Climber targets the core and upper body while also engaging the glutes. This exercise combines the benefits of a reverse plank with dynamic knee movements.
HowTo: 1. Begin in a reverse plank position with your hands on a plate. 2. Engage your core and lift your hips. 3. Drive your right knee towards your chest. 4. Return to the starting position and switch legs, driving your left knee towards your chest.

Title: Holman Plate Straight Plank Pike to Jack
Desc: The Holman Plate Straight Plank Pike to Jack is a challenging exercise that improves core stability and flexibility. It combines a pike movement with a jumping jack motion.
HowTo: 1. Start in a straight plank position with your hands on a plate. 2. Engage your core and lift your hips into a pike position. 3. Jump your feet out to the sides like a jumping jack. 4. Return to the plank position and repeat.

Title: Holman Plate In-and-Out Push-Up
Desc: The Holman Plate In-and-Out Push-Up is a variation of the traditional push-up that adds a dynamic element to target the chest and triceps. It also engages the core for stability.
HowTo: 1. Start in a push-up position with your hands on a plate. 2. Lower your body into a push-up. 3. As you push back up, jump your feet in towards your hands. 4. Jump your feet back out and repeat the push-up.

Title: Holman Plate Burpee
Desc: The Holman Plate Burpee is a full-body exercise that combines strength and cardio for an effective workout. It involves a squat, plank, and jump to maximize calorie burn.
HowTo: 1. Start standing with a plate in your hands. 2. Squat down and place the plate on the ground. 3. Jump your feet back into a plank position. 4. Perform a push-up, then jump your feet back to your hands. 5. Jump up explosively with the plate.

Title: Holman Plate Elbow Plank Reach
Desc: The Holman Plate Elbow Plank Reach is an isometric exercise that targets the core and shoulders. It helps improve stability and strength in the abdominal area.
HowTo: 1. Start in a plank position on your elbows with your body in a straight line. 2. Reach one arm forward while maintaining your balance, then return to the starting position and alternate arms.

Title: Holman Elbow Plank to Renegade Row
Desc: The Holman Elbow Plank to Renegade Row combines a plank and rowing motion to engage the core and upper body. It enhances stability and strength in multiple muscle groups.
HowTo: 1. Begin in a plank position on your elbows. 2. Row one arm up towards your hip while stabilizing your body, then return to plank and repeat with the other arm.

Title: Holman Straight Plank Weighted Hand Hill Climber
Desc: The Holman Straight Plank Weighted Hand Hill Climber is a dynamic exercise that targets the core and improves cardiovascular endurance. It incorporates a climbing motion to engage the legs and arms.
HowTo: 1. Start in a straight-arm plank position with a weight in one hand. 2. Alternate bringing your knees towards your chest while maintaining a strong plank position.

Title: Holman Weighted Left Side Diagonal Pike
Desc: The Holman Weighted Left Side Diagonal Pike focuses on the obliques and core strength. It helps improve balance and coordination while engaging the entire core.
HowTo: 1. Start in a plank position with a weight in one hand. 2. Lift your hips up and bring your weighted arm towards your opposite foot, then return to plank.

Title: Holman Weighted Right Side Diagonal Pike
Desc: The Holman Weighted Right Side Diagonal Pike is similar to the left side version, targeting the obliques and enhancing core stability. It challenges your balance and coordination.
HowTo: 1. Begin in a plank position with a weight in one hand. 2. Lift your hips and reach your weighted arm towards your opposite foot, then return to the starting position.

Title: Holman Weighted W-Boat to Overhead Press
Desc: The Holman Weighted W-Boat to Overhead Press is an exercise that targets the shoulders and core while incorporating a dynamic movement pattern. It combines a boat position with an overhead press to enhance stability and strength.
HowTo: 1. Start in a seated position with your legs bent and feet off the ground, holding weights in each hand. 2. Lean back slightly to engage your core, then press the weights overhead while maintaining your balance. 3. Lower the weights back to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Holman Weighted Kneeling Lift
Desc: The Holman Weighted Kneeling Lift is designed to strengthen the core and upper body while promoting stability. This exercise involves lifting weights from a kneeling position, engaging multiple muscle groups.
HowTo: 1. Begin in a kneeling position with a weight in each hand at shoulder height. 2. Engage your core and lift the weights overhead while keeping your back straight. 3. Lower the weights back to shoulder height and repeat.

Title: Holman Hips-Up Weighted Pull-Over
Desc: The Holman Hips-Up Weighted Pull-Over focuses on the back and core while enhancing flexibility and strength. This exercise involves pulling a weight from an overhead position down towards your hips.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back with your knees bent and feet flat on the ground, holding a weight above your chest. 2. Engage your core and lift your hips off the ground while lowering the weight behind your head. 3. Pull the weight back to the starting position while lowering your hips back down.

Title: Holman Weighted Cross Punch
Desc: The Holman Weighted Cross Punch is a dynamic exercise that combines cardio and strength training. It involves punching across the body while engaging the core and upper body muscles.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding weights in each hand at shoulder height. 2. Rotate your torso and punch one arm across your body while pivoting on the opposite foot. 3. Alternate sides in a controlled manner to maintain balance and engage your core.

Title: Holman Straight-Leg Boat Hover Chest Press
Desc: The Holman Straight-Leg Boat Hover Chest Press targets the chest and core while improving stability. This exercise combines a chest press with a boat position to challenge the upper body and core strength.
HowTo: 1. Sit in a boat position with your legs straight and feet off the ground, holding weights at chest level. 2. Press the weights straight up while maintaining your balance. 3. Lower the weights back to chest level and repeat.

Title: Holman Weighted Pike
Desc: The Holman Weighted Pike is an effective exercise for targeting the core muscles, particularly the abdominals. It involves lifting the legs while maintaining a pike position to engage the core.
HowTo: 1. Start in a pike position with your hands on the ground and feet elevated. 2. Hold a weight in your hands and lift your legs towards your chest while keeping your core tight. 3. Lower your legs back to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Holman Feet-Elevated Wax-On Wax-Off
Desc: The Holman Feet-Elevated Wax-On Wax-Off is designed to enhance upper body strength while engaging the core. Elevating the feet increases the difficulty and targets the chest effectively.
HowTo: 1. Begin in a push-up position with your feet elevated on a surface. 2. Perform a push-up while rotating your body to one side, extending one arm upward. 3. Return to the starting position and repeat on the other side.

Title: Holman Elbow Plank to Towel Pike
Desc: The Holman Elbow Plank to Towel Pike is a core-focused exercise that challenges stability and strength. It combines a plank position with a pike movement to engage the entire abdominal region.
HowTo: 1. Start in an elbow plank position with your feet on a towel. 2. Engage your core and slide your feet towards your hands, lifting your hips into a pike position. 3. Return to the plank position and repeat.

Title: Holman Seated Killer Abs Overhead Press
Desc: The Holman Seated Killer Abs Overhead Press targets the core while also working the shoulders. This exercise combines a seated position with an overhead press to engage multiple muscle groups.
HowTo: 1. Sit on the ground with your legs extended and hold a weight overhead. 2. Engage your core and lean back slightly while maintaining a straight back. 3. Press the weight overhead and return to the starting position.

Title: Holman Straight Plank Alternating Weighted Open
Desc: The Holman Straight Plank Alternating Weighted Open is a challenging exercise for the core and shoulders. It requires stability and strength as you alternate lifting weights while in a plank position.
HowTo: 1. Start in a straight plank position with a weight in each hand. 2. Lift one weight towards your shoulder while stabilizing your body with the other arm. 3. Lower the weight and repeat on the other side.

Title: Holman Weighted Killer Abs with Overhead Press
Desc: The Holman Weighted Killer Abs with Overhead Press is an intense core exercise that combines abdominal work with an overhead press. It targets the core while also engaging the shoulders and arms.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, holding a weight overhead. 2. Engage your core and lower your body into a squat while maintaining the weight overhead. 3. Return to standing while pressing the weight overhead. 4. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Holman Weighted Split-Leg Pike
Desc: The Holman Weighted Split-Leg Pike is a challenging lower body exercise that emphasizes balance and strength. It targets the legs while also engaging the core for stability.
HowTo: 1. Start in a split stance with one foot forward and the other back. 2. Lower your hips into a pike position while keeping your back straight. 3. Push through the front heel to return to standing. 4. Switch legs and repeat.

Title: Holman Towel Reverse Plank Heel Pull-in
Desc: The Holman Towel Reverse Plank Heel Pull-in is a dynamic exercise that enhances mobility and core strength. It challenges the entire body while improving flexibility.
HowTo: 1. Sit on the floor with your legs extended and a towel under your feet. 2. Lean back on your hands and lift your hips off the ground into a reverse plank. 3. Pull your knees towards your chest while maintaining the plank position. 4. Extend your legs back out and repeat.

Title: Stick Twist
Desc: The Stick Twist is a rotational exercise that improves spinal mobility and core strength. It helps in enhancing flexibility and stability in the back.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, holding a stick or broomstick across your shoulders. 2. Rotate your torso to one side while keeping your hips facing forward. 3. Return to the center and rotate to the other side. 4. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Roc Everest
Desc: The Roc Everest is a high-intensity cardio exercise that engages multiple muscle groups. It is great for building endurance and burning calories.
HowTo: 1. Start in a plank position with your hands under your shoulders. 2. Quickly bring one knee towards your chest, then switch legs in a running motion. 3. Keep your core tight and maintain a steady pace. 4. Continue for the desired duration.

Title: Standing cable low-to-high twist
Desc: The standing cable low-to-high twist is a core exercise targeting the upper abdominals and the obliques. Take care to perform it with control, as opposed to violent twisting which can injure the back. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps, at least 8-15 per side, as part of the core-focused portion of a workout.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding the cable handle with both hands. 2. Rotate your torso upwards and across your body, engaging your core, then return to the starting position.

Title: Single-arm high-cable side bend
Desc: The single-arm high-cable side bend is an exercise targeting the obliques using a cable stack machine.
HowTo: 1. Stand next to the cable machine, grasping the handle with one hand. 2. Bend sideways at the waist, bringing the handle down towards your knee, then return to the starting position.

Title: Kneeling cable oblique crunch
Desc: The kneeling cable oblique crunch is a popular core isolation exercise using a rope attachment and cable stack while kneeling on the floor. It primarily targets the obliques and rectus abdominis or "six-pack" muscles, but also strengthens the deep core muscles. It is most commonly performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or higher.
Muscles: Rectus Abdominis, Obliques, Deep Core Muscles
HowTo: 1. Kneel in front of the cable machine and attach a rope to the high pulley. 2. Grasp the rope and pull it down while crunching your torso towards your knees, then return to the starting position.

Title: Kneeling cable crunch
Desc: The kneeling cable crunch is a popular core isolation exercise using a rope attachment and cable stack while kneeling on the floor. It primarily targets the rectus abdominis or "six-pack" muscles, but also strengthens the deep core muscles. It is most commonly performed early in an ab workout, usually in moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or higher.
HowTo: 1. Kneel in front of the cable machine and attach a rope to the high pulley. 2. Grasp the rope and pull it down while crunching your torso towards your knees, then return to the starting position.

Title: Rope Crunch
Desc: The kneeling cable crunch is a popular core isolation exercise using a rope attachment and cable stack while kneeling on the floor. It primarily targets the rectus abdominus or "six-pack" muscles, but also strengthens the deep core muscles. It is most commonly performed early in an ab workout, usually in moderate to high reps like 8-12 reps per set or higher.
HowTo: 1. Kneel in front of the cable machine and attach a rope to the high pulley. 2. Grasp the rope and pull it down while crunching your torso towards your knees, then return to the starting position.

Title: Standing cable crunch
Desc: The standing cable crunch is a popular core isolation exercise using a rope attachment. It primarily targets the rectus abdominis or "six-pack" muscles, but also strengthens the deep core muscles. It is most commonly performed early in an ab workout, usually in moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or higher.
Muscles: Rectus Abdominis, Obliques, Deep Core Muscles
HowTo: 1. Attach a rope to a high pulley on a cable machine. 2. Stand facing the machine and grasp the rope with both hands. 3. Pull the rope down while bending at the waist, engaging your core. 4. Return to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Bosu Ball Cable Crunch With Side Bends
Desc: The Bosu Ball Cable Crunch with Side Bends is an effective exercise for targeting the core while also incorporating lateral movement to engage the obliques.
HowTo: 1. Set up a cable machine with a rope attachment. 2. Stand on a Bosu ball with your feet shoulder-width apart. 3. Hold the rope above your head and crunch down while twisting to one side. 4. Return to the starting position and repeat on the other side.

Title: Standing Cable Wood Chop
Desc: The standing cable high-to-low twist is a core exercise targeting the lower abdominals and the obliques.
