HowTo: 1. Attach a handle to a high pulley on a cable machine. 2. Stand with your side to the machine and grasp the handle with both hands. 3. Pull the handle down and across your body while twisting your torso. 4. Return to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Cable reverse crunch
Desc: The cable reverse crunch is performed on the ground facing away from a high pulley, which helps target the lower abdominals specifically.
HowTo: 1. Attach a rope to a high pulley on a cable machine. 2. Lie on your back on the floor facing away from the machine. 3. Grasp the rope with both hands and pull your knees towards your chest while curling your hips off the ground. 4. Lower back down and repeat.

Title: Cable Russian Twists
Desc: Cable Russian Twists are a great exercise for targeting the obliques and improving core stability.
HowTo: 1. Attach a handle to a low pulley on a cable machine. 2. Sit on the floor with your legs bent and feet flat. 3. Hold the handle with both hands and lean back slightly. 4. Rotate your torso to one side, then to the other, while keeping your core engaged.

Title: Pallof press with rotation
Desc: The Pallof press with rotation is a dynamic variation of the Pallof press that incorporates weighted rotation away from the torso using resistance from a cable pulley. It is intended to build abdominal strength and teach proper bracing. It can be performed for time or for reps in the core-focused portion of any workout.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your side to the cable pulley. 2. Grasp the handle with both hands at chest level. 3. Step away from the pulley to create tension. 4. Press the handle straight out in front of you, then rotate your torso away from the pulley. 5. Return to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Cable Seated Crunch
Desc: The Cable Seated Crunch is an effective exercise for targeting the abdominal muscles. It allows for a controlled contraction and can be adjusted for resistance.
HowTo: 1. Sit on a bench with your back to the cable machine. 2. Attach the rope handle to the high pulley and grasp it with both hands. 3. Pull the rope down towards your chest while curling your torso forward. 4. Slowly return to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Cable Judo Flip
Desc: The Cable Judo Flip is a dynamic exercise that mimics the movement of a judo flip, engaging multiple muscle groups. It focuses on explosive power and coordination.
HowTo: 1. Stand facing the cable machine with the handle at the lowest setting. 2. Grasp the handle with both hands and step back to create tension. 3. Squat down and then explosively pull the handle up while rotating your body. 4. Land softly and repeat the movement.

Title: Exercise Ball Cable Crunch - Gethin Variation
Desc: The exercise ball crunch is a popular gym exercise targeting the abdominals. Unlike crunches on the floor or a bench, by using a ball, you can increase the range of motion and both stretch and contract the abs on every rep. The ball crunch can be performed for low reps with a slower tempo, focusing on a hard contraction, or for higher reps.
HowTo: 1. Sit on an exercise ball with your feet flat on the floor. 2. Walk your feet forward until your lower back is supported by the ball. 3. Place your hands behind your head and crunch your torso forward. 4. Lower back down and repeat.

Title: Standing cable high-to-low twist
Desc: The standing cable high-to-low twist is a core exercise targeting the lower abdominals and the obliques. Take care to perform it with control, as opposed to violent twisting which can injure the back. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps, at least 8-15 per side, as part of the core-focused portion of a workout.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your side to the cable machine and grasp the handle with both hands. 2. Pull the handle down and twist your torso away from the machine. 3. Return to the starting position and repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Bent-Over Reverse Cable Fly
Desc: The Bent-Over Reverse Cable Fly is an isolation exercise that targets the rear deltoids and upper back muscles. It helps in developing shoulder stability and strength.
HowTo: 1. Stand facing the cable machine with feet shoulder-width apart. 2. Grab the cables with both hands and bend slightly at the hips. 3. With a slight bend in your elbows, pull the cables out to the sides until your arms are parallel to the ground. 4. Slowly return to the starting position.

Title: Standing Cable Crunch - Gethin Variation
Desc: The standing cable crunch is a popular core isolation exercise using a rope attachment. It primarily targets the rectus abdominus or "six-pack" muscles, but also strengthens the deep core muscles. It is most commonly performed early in an ab workout, usually in moderate to high reps like 8-12 reps per set or higher.
HowTo: 1. Stand facing the cable machine with a rope attachment at the top. 2. Grab the rope with both hands and step back to create tension. 3. Bend at the waist, pulling the rope down towards your knees while keeping your elbows stationary. 4. Slowly return to the starting position.

Title: AM Cable Crunch
Desc: The kneeling cable crunch is a popular core isolation exercise using a rope attachment and cable stack while kneeling on the floor. It primarily targets the rectus abdominus or "six-pack" muscles, but also strengthens the deep core muscles. It is most commonly performed early in an ab workout, usually in moderate to high reps like 8-12 reps per set or higher.
HowTo: 1. Kneel in front of a cable machine with a rope attachment at the top. 2. Grab the rope with both hands and pull it down to your forehead. 3. Crunch down by bending at the waist, bringing your elbows towards your knees. 4. Slowly return to the starting position.

Title: Tyler Holt Weighted Knee-To-Chest Crunch
Desc: The Tyler Holt Weighted Knee-To-Chest Crunch is an effective exercise for targeting the abdominal muscles. It also engages the hip flexors for added strength.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back with your knees bent and feet flat on the floor, holding a weight plate above your chest. 2. Lift your knees towards your chest while simultaneously lifting your upper body off the ground. 3. Squeeze your abs at the top, then lower back down slowly.

Title: Standing cable twist
Desc: The standing cable twist is a core exercise that targets the abdominals, particularly the obliques. Take care to perform it with control, as opposed to violent twisting which can injure the back. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps, at least 8-15 per side, as part of the core-focused portion of a workout.
HowTo: 1. Stand sideways to the cable machine with the cable at waist height. 2. Grab the handle with both hands and pull it across your body. 3. Rotate your torso while keeping your hips stable, then return to the starting position. 4. Repeat on the other side.

Title: 30 Cable Rope Crunch
Desc: The kneeling cable crunch is a popular core isolation exercise using a rope attachment and cable stack while kneeling on the floor. It primarily targets the rectus abdominus or "six-pack" muscles, but also strengthens the deep core muscles. It is most commonly performed early in an ab workout, usually in moderate to high reps like 8-12 reps per set or higher.
HowTo: Kneel in front of a cable machine with a rope attachment. Grasp the rope with both hands, pull it down, and crunch your torso towards your knees while keeping your elbows stationary.

Title: 30 Cable Rope Oblique Crunch
Desc: The kneeling cable oblique crunch is a popular core isolation exercise using a rope attachment and cable stack while kneeling on the floor. It primarily targets the obliques and rectus abdominus or "six-pack" muscles, but also strengthens the deep core muscles. It is most commonly performed for moderate to high reps like 8-12 reps per set or higher.
Muscles: obliques, rectus abdominus, deep core muscles
HowTo: Kneel in front of a cable machine with a rope attachment. Pull the rope down and twist your torso to the side, engaging your obliques as you crunch towards your knees.

Title: Cable lying twist on ball
Desc: The cable lying twist on ball is an exercise targeting the core and obliques with the added challenge of stability to keep from losing position on the unstable surface.
HowTo: Lie on a stability ball with your back supported and feet on the ground. Hold the cable with both hands and twist your torso side to side while maintaining balance.

Title: 30 Cable Pallof Press
Desc: The pallof press is an anti-rotation, isometric exercise that trains core stability. It is most often seen in programs for athletes who compete in sports that test strength, power, and functional movements.
HowTo: Stand with your side to the cable machine and grasp the handle with both hands. Step away from the machine to create tension, then press the handle away from your chest and hold for a few seconds before returning.

Title: 30 Cable Reverse Crunch On Ball
Desc: The cable reverse crunch on a BOSU is performed on top of a BOSU ball between two cable pulleys, which helps target the lower abdominals specifically and is more proprioceptively challenging than a cable reverse crunch on the floor.
HowTo: Lie on a BOSU ball with your head towards the floor and feet in the air holding onto the cable handles. Pull your knees towards your chest while engaging your lower abs, then lower back down.

Title: 30 Cable Reverse Crunch
Desc: The cable reverse crunch is performed on the ground facing away from a high pulley, which helps target the lower abdominals specifically.
HowTo: 1. Attach a rope or handle to a high pulley on a cable machine. 2. Lie on your back on the floor facing away from the machine, holding the cable with both hands. 3. Pull your knees towards your chest while simultaneously curling your upper body off the ground. 4. Slowly return to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Tyler Holt Cable Torso Twist
Desc: The Tyler Holt Cable Torso Twist is an exercise that targets the core and oblique muscles.
HowTo: 1. Stand next to a cable machine with the pulley set at waist height. 2. Grasp the handle with both hands and step away from the machine. 3. Rotate your torso away from the machine, keeping your arms extended. 4. Return to the starting position and repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Single-Arm Cable Outward-Facing Biceps Curl
Desc: The single-arm cable outward-facing biceps curl is a cable exercise that targets the biceps. It is performed standing in front of a cable machine facing away from the cable stack to increase the range of motion by fully extending the elbows. This movement is usually performed for moderate to high reps for a burn and pump as part of an arm-focused workout.
HowTo: 1. Stand in front of a cable machine with the pulley set at the lowest position. 2. Grasp the handle with one hand, palm facing up. 3. Curl the handle towards your shoulder while keeping your elbow stationary. 4. Slowly lower back to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Biceps Rope Curl
Desc: The biceps rope curl is a cable exercise that targets the biceps using a rope attachment.
HowTo: 1. Attach a rope to a low pulley on a cable machine. 2. Stand facing the machine and grasp the rope with both hands, palms facing each other. 3. Curl the rope towards your shoulders while keeping your elbows close to your body. 4. Lower the rope back to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Kneeling Cable Crunches
Desc: Kneeling cable crunches are an effective exercise for targeting the abdominal muscles.
HowTo: 1. Attach a rope to a high pulley on a cable machine. 2. Kneel in front of the machine and grasp the rope with both hands. 3. Pull the rope down while crunching your torso towards your knees. 4. Slowly return to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Ab Crunch Machine
Desc: The machine crunch is a machine-based exercise targeting the abdominal muscles. It involves sitting upright in the machine and curling the torso down toward the chest against some pre-set level of resistance. On some machines, the knees also curl up torward the torso. Crunch machines usually use extra resistance in the form of selectorized weight stacks or plate loading, and are often performed for moderate to high reps, like 8-12 reps per set or higher, as part of the ab-focused portion of a workout.
HowTo: 1. Sit upright in the machine with your back against the pad. 2. Curl your torso down toward your chest against the resistance, then return to the starting position.

Title: Smith machine straight-legged hip raise
Desc: The Smith machine straight-legged hip raise is an exercise targeting the abdominal muscles. Because of the potential awkwardness of getting into position, it is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more. If your Smith machine has safety bars, set them at a height that allows you a full range of motion while giving adequate protection from the weight potentially falling.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back on the Smith machine bench with your legs straight. 2. Raise your hips while keeping your legs straight, then lower back down.

Title: Machine crunch
Desc: The machine crunch is a machine-based exercise targeting the abdominal muscles. It involves sitting upright in the machine and curling the torso down against a pre-set level of resistance. On some machines, the knees also curl up toward the torso. Crunch machines usually use extra resistance in the form of selectorized weight stacks or plate loading, and are often performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of the ab-focused portion of a workout.
HowTo: 1. Sit upright in the machine with your back against the pad. 2. Curl your torso down against the resistance, then return to the starting position.

Title: AM Ab Machine
Desc: The AM Ab Machine is designed to target the abdominal muscles effectively. It typically involves a seated position where you perform crunching movements against resistance.
HowTo: 1. Sit in the machine with your back against the pad. 2. Engage your core and curl your torso forward against the resistance.

Title: Smith machine V-up
Desc: The smith machine V-up is a weighted abdominal exercise that involves pressing a weighted bar upward while performing a V-up. Performing it in a Smith machine eliminates the balance challenge of a free weight. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps in the ab-focused portion of a workout.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back on the bench of the Smith machine with your legs extended. 2. Perform a V-up by raising your legs and upper body simultaneously while pressing the weighted bar upward.

Title: Elbow plank
Desc: The elbow plank is a popular isometric abdominal exercise. It is common in all types of exercise programs, as well as in group fitness and yoga classes. It targets the muscles of the core, the deep core or transversus abdominis in particular. It is also often prescribed for time to help back pain or to teach proper bracing.
HowTo: 1. Start in a forearm plank position with your elbows directly under your shoulders. 2. Keep your body in a straight line from head to heels, engaging your core and glutes.

Title: Bottoms Up
Desc: The lying leg lift is a popular bodyweight exercise targeting the muscles of the abs, the rectus abdominis or six-pack muscles in particular. It can be performed for time or reps in the core-focused portion of any workout.
HowTo: 1. Lie flat on your back with your legs extended. 2. Lift your legs towards the ceiling while keeping your arms at your sides or overhead, then lower them back down without touching the ground.

Title: Spider crawl
Desc: The spider crawl is a bodyweight exercise that involves crawling on the floor with the knees outside of the elbows. It is different from a leopard crawl in that the hips are higher, and it's different from a bear crawl because the knees are wider. It can be done as a full-body warm-up, in short bursts for power or circuit training, or for longer durations as cardiovascular conditioning.
HowTo: 1. Start in a high plank position. 2. Move your right knee towards your right elbow, then switch legs, crawling forward in a controlled manner.

Title: Cocoons
Desc: The cocoon crunch is a bodyweight exercise targeting the ab muscles, the rectus abdominis or "six-pack" muscles in particular. It involves bringing your knees to your chest and your arms from overhead to center. It can be performed for time or reps as part of the ab-focused portion of any workout.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back with your arms extended overhead and knees bent. 2. Simultaneously bring your knees towards your chest and your arms towards your knees, then return to the starting position.

Title: Cross-Body Crunch
Desc: The elbow-to-knee crunch is a bodyweight exercise targeting the ab muscles, the obliques and rectus abdominis or "six-pack" muscles in particular. It can be performed for time or reps as part of the ab-focused portion of any workout.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back with your knees bent and feet flat on the floor. 2. Bring your right elbow towards your left knee while extending your right leg, then switch sides.

Title: Elbow-to-knee crunch
Desc: The elbow-to-knee crunch is a bodyweight exercise targeting the ab muscles, the obliques and rectus abdominis or "six-pack" muscles in particular. It can be performed for time or reps as part of the ab-focused portion of any workout.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back with your knees bent and feet flat on the floor. 2. Bring your right elbow towards your left knee while extending your right leg. 3. Switch sides and repeat the movement.

Title: Decline Crunch
Desc: The decline crunch is an effective core exercise targeting the rectus abdominis.
HowTo: 1. Lie on a decline bench with your feet secured. 2. Cross your arms over your chest or place them behind your head. 3. Curl your torso up towards your knees, then lower back down.

Title: Hanging toes-to-bar
Desc: The hanging toes-to-bar is an advanced abdominal exercise in which the lifter touches their feet to a pull-up bar. There are many ways to perform this movement (strict or swinging, arms completely straight or slightly bent, legs straight or bent) each providing unique benefits and challenges. Initially, it may be a difficult move to do for a single rep, but once you build the requisite core, lat, and shoulder strength, it can be performed for higher reps.
HowTo: 1. Hang from a pull-up bar with your arms fully extended. 2. Engage your core and lift your legs towards the bar, aiming to touch your toes to it. 3. Lower your legs back down and repeat.

Title: Hanging Oblique Knee Raise
Desc: The hanging oblique crunch an abdominal exercise that targets both the rectus abdominus or six-pack muscles, and the oblique muscles. It can be performed hanging from a bar, or if grip strength is a limitation, by placing the elbows in ab straps. If hanging from a straight bar is uncomfortable to the wrists or shoulder, you can also perform them hanging with a neutral grip (palms facing one another)
HowTo: 1. Hang from a pull-up bar with your arms straight. 2. Raise your knees towards your chest while twisting to one side to engage the obliques. 3. Lower your legs back down and repeat on the other side.

Title: Gorilla Chin/Crunch
Desc: The Gorilla Chin/Crunch is a hybrid exercise that combines elements of a chin-up and a crunch. It targets the core and upper body muscles.
HowTo: 1. Hang from a pull-up bar with an underhand grip. 2. Pull your body up while simultaneously bringing your knees towards your chest. 3. Lower back down to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Hanging leg raise
Desc: The hanging leg raise is an exercise targeting the abs, but which also works the lats and hip flexors. Instead of resting your forearms on the pads of a captain's chair, you perform these hanging from a bar. Experienced lifters make these look easy, but beginners may need time to build up to sets of 8-12 reps.
HowTo: 1. Hang from a pull-up bar with your legs straight. 2. Raise your legs towards your chest while keeping them straight, then lower them back down.

Title: Mountain climber
Desc: The mountain climber is a popular bodyweight exercise targeting the muscles of the core, as well as the shoulders, hips, and cardiovascular system. It involves lifting one knee to the chest at a time from a straight-arm plank position. It can be performed for time or reps as part of a dynamic warm-up, for bodyweight cardio or conditioning, or as no-equipment dynamic core training.
HowTo: 1. Start in a straight-arm plank position. 2. Alternate bringing one knee to your chest while keeping your core engaged and back straight.

Title: Ab bicycle
Desc: The ab bicycle is a bodyweight movement that targets the muscles of the abs, the obliques and rectus abdominis or "six-pack" muscles in particular. It can be performed for time or reps in the ab-focused portion of any workout.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back with your hands behind your head and legs lifted. 2. Bring your opposite elbow to your knee while extending the other leg, then switch sides.

Title: 3/4 sit-up
Desc: The 3/4 sit-up is a bodyweight exercise focused on the muscles of the core. It is similar to a sit-up, but stops short of the top position. This keeps constant tension on the abs, making it more difficult than traditional sit-ups. It can be performed for time or for reps, with the feet anchored or free, as part of the ab-focused portion of any workout.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back with your knees bent and feet flat on the floor. 2. Engage your core and lift your upper body towards your knees, stopping short of a full sit-up.

Title: Reverse crunch
Desc: The reverse crunch is a popular exercise targeting the abdominals, particularly the lower half. Its easy to perform on either the floor or a flat bench. Many lifters think of this as a companion to the crunch, which targets the upper abdominals more than the lower.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back with your knees bent and feet off the ground. 2. Curl your hips off the floor, bringing your knees towards your chest, then lower back down.

Title: Crunches
Desc: The crunch is a popular core exercise targeting the rectus abdominis, or "six-pack" muscles, as well as the obliques. It has been the centerpiece of many ab-focused workouts, due to both its simplicity and the intense burn and mind-muscle connection it produces. It can be performed for time or reps as part of the ab-focused portion of any workout.
HowTo: Lie on your back with your knees bent and feet flat on the floor. Place your hands behind your head, lift your shoulders off the ground, and curl your torso towards your knees while contracting your abs.

Title: Dead bug reach
Desc: The dead bug reach is an exercise for strengthening the core in which you alternate lowering your opposing arm and leg simultaneously, controlling the movement with the abdominal muscles. It can be part of a dynamic warm-up to activate the core for other athletics or lifting, or be performed in a circuit or on its own in the ab-focused portion of any workout.
HowTo: Lie on your back with your arms extended towards the ceiling and your knees bent at 90 degrees. Lower your right arm and left leg simultaneously towards the ground while keeping your core engaged, then return to the starting position and alternate sides.

Title: Crunch - Hands Overhead
Desc: The Crunch - Hands Overhead is a variation of the traditional crunch that emphasizes the upper abs. It involves raising your arms overhead while performing the crunch to increase the difficulty.
HowTo: Lie on your back with your arms extended overhead. Engage your core and lift your shoulders off the ground, bringing your torso towards your knees while keeping your arms extended.

Title: V-up
Desc: The V-up is a bodyweight movement that targets the muscles of the abs, the rectus abdominis or "six-pack" muscles in particular. It is similar to a suitcase crunch, but the lower back lifts off the ground at the top of each rep. It can be performed for time or reps in the ab-focused portion of any workout.
HowTo: Lie flat on your back with your arms extended above your head and legs straight. Simultaneously lift your legs and upper body off the ground, reaching your hands towards your feet to form a 'V' shape.

Title: Stomach Vacuum
Desc: The Stomach Vacuum is an isometric exercise that targets the transverse abdominis, helping to strengthen the core and improve posture. It involves pulling the belly button towards the spine while maintaining a neutral spine position.
HowTo: Stand or kneel with a straight back, exhale fully, and pull your belly button in towards your spine as hard as you can. Hold this position for several seconds while breathing normally, then release.

Title: Russian twist
Desc: The Russian twist is an exercise targeting the abdominals and the obliques. Beginning from a position that resembles stopping midway through a sit-up, it involves twisting side to side. It can be performed with body weight alone or while holding a weight plate or other object. It is performed by alternating sides with each rep and can be done for time or for a specific number of reps as part of the ab-focused portion of any workout.
HowTo: 1. Sit on the floor with your knees bent and feet flat. 2. Lean back slightly while keeping your back straight, then twist your torso to one side, then the other.

Title: Flat Bench Lying Leg Raise
Desc: The lying leg lift is a popular bodyweight exercise targeting the muscles of the abs, the rectus abdominis or six-pack muscles in particular. It can be performed for time or reps in the core-focused portion of any workout.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back with your legs extended. 2. Lift your legs towards the ceiling while keeping them straight, then lower them back down without touching the ground.

Title: Knees tucked crunch
Desc: The knees tucked crunch is a core exercise that involves performing a crunch while keeping the knees bent in a 90-degree position. It primarily targets the rectus abdominis or "six-pack" muscles. It can be performed for time or reps as part of any abs-focused circuit or workout.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back with your knees bent at a 90-degree angle. 2. Perform a crunch by lifting your upper body towards your knees while keeping your lower back on the ground.

Title: Butt-Ups
Desc: Butt-Ups are a core exercise that targets the abdominal muscles. They involve lifting the hips off the ground while engaging the core.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back with your knees bent and feet flat on the floor. 2. Lift your hips towards the ceiling by engaging your core, then lower back down.

Title: Feet-elevated oblique crunch
Desc: The feet-elevated oblique crunch is a variation on the crunch exercise that targets the obliques as well as the rectus abdominis or "six-pack" muscles. Resting the feet on a bench takes some of the hip flexor activation out of the movement, focusing the stress more on the abs.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back with your feet elevated on a bench. 2. Perform a crunch by lifting your upper body towards your knees while focusing on your obliques.

Title: Bent-knee reverse crunch
Desc: The bent-knee reverse crunch is a popular bodyweight core exercise. It targets the lower portion of the rectus abdominis or "six-pack" muscles. It can be performed for time or reps as part of any ab-focused workout.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back with your knees bent and feet flat on the floor. 2. Lift your legs so your thighs are perpendicular to the floor. 3. Curl your hips off the floor, bringing your knees towards your chest. 4. Slowly lower back to the starting position.

Title: Alternating heel-touch
Desc: The alternating heel-touch is a popular bodyweight exercise that targets the obliques, as well as the rectus abdominis, or "six-pack" muscles. It can be performed for time or reps as part of any abs-focused circuit or workout.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back with your knees bent and feet flat on the floor. 2. Lift your shoulders off the ground and reach your right hand towards your right heel. 3. Return to the starting position and repeat on the left side. 4. Continue alternating sides.

Title: Suspended Reverse Crunch
Desc: The suspended reverse crunch is a core exercise that targets the abdominal muscles, particularly the lower abs.
HowTo: 1. Hang from a pull-up bar with an overhand grip. 2. Bend your knees and pull them towards your chest while curling your hips up. 3. Slowly lower your legs back to the starting position.

Title: Lying bench reverse crunch
Desc: The lying bench reverse crunch is a popular ab exercise performed by bringing the knees toward the chest while lying on a bench. It is largely similar to the same exercise performed on the floor, but being able to press the lower back into the bench pad can help reinforce proper form and increase the burn in the abs. Like most crunch variations, it is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more.
HowTo: 1. Lie on a bench with your head at one end and your legs hanging off the other. 2. Hold onto the bench for support. 3. Bring your knees towards your chest while curling your hips up. 4. Lower your legs back to the starting position.

Title: Sit-up
Desc: The sit-up is a popular bodyweight exercise focused on the abdominal muscles. It has also been used as part of military, tactical, and scholastic fitness tests for many years. It can be performed for time or reps, with the feet anchored or free, on flat ground or a bench.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back with your knees bent and feet flat on the floor. 2. Cross your arms over your chest or place your hands behind your head. 3. Curl your torso up towards your knees, lifting your shoulders off the ground. 4. Lower back down to the starting position.

Title: Side Bridge
Desc: The side plank is a popular isometric abdominal exercise focusing on the oblique muscles, as well as the transversus abdominis or deep core muscles. It is sometimes paired with the curl up and bird dog as the McGill big three for core strength and stability. It is performed for time and can work in a warm-up or in the core-focused portion of any workout.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your side with your legs straight and stacked on top of each other. 2. Prop yourself up on your elbow, keeping your body in a straight line from head to heels. 3. Hold the position for a set amount of time, ensuring your hips do not sag.

Title: Lying oblique crunch
Desc: The lying oblique crunch is a bodyweight exercise targeting the oblique muscles. It can be performed for a specific number of reps or to fatigue or failure as part of the ab-focused portion of any workout.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back with your knees bent and feet flat on the floor. 2. Place your hands behind your head and lift your shoulders off the ground while bringing one elbow towards the opposite knee. 3. Alternate sides for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Janda Sit-Up
Desc: The Janda Sit-Up is an effective exercise for engaging the core while minimizing hip flexor involvement.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back with your knees bent and feet flat on the ground. 2. Cross your arms over your chest or place your hands behind your head. 3. Engage your core and lift your upper body off the ground while keeping your lower back pressed into the floor.

Title: Leg Pull-In
Desc: The reverse crunch is a popular exercise targeting the abdominals, particularly the lower half. Its easy to perform on either the floor or a flat bench. Many lifters think of this as a companion to the crunch, which targets the upper abdominals more than the lower.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back with your knees bent at 90 degrees and feet off the ground. 2. Use your core to lift your hips off the floor, bringing your knees towards your chest. 3. Slowly lower back to the starting position without letting your feet touch the ground.

Title: Side Jackknife
Desc: The Side Jackknife is an effective exercise for targeting the obliques and improving core stability.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your side with your legs straight and stacked, and your bottom arm extended for support. 2. Simultaneously lift your legs and upper body off the ground, bringing your elbow towards your knees. 3. Lower back down and repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Scissor Kick
Desc: The scissor kick is an effective exercise for targeting the abdominal muscles, particularly the lower abs. It involves alternating leg movements while lying on your back, engaging the core throughout.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back with your legs extended and arms at your sides. 2. Lift your legs off the ground a few inches. 3. Alternate raising one leg up while lowering the other leg down, keeping your core engaged.

Title: Toe Touchers
Desc: The toe-touch is a bodyweight movement that targets the muscles of the abs, the rectus abdominis or "six-pack" muscles in particular. It can be performed for time or reps in the ab-focused portion of any workout.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back with your legs straight up in the air. 2. Reach your hands towards your toes, lifting your shoulder blades off the ground. 3. Lower back down and repeat.

Title: Lower Back Curl
Desc: The lower back curl is an exercise that strengthens the lower back muscles and improves spinal stability. It involves curling the lower back while lying on your stomach.
HowTo: 1. Lie face down on a mat with your arms at your sides. 2. Engage your lower back and lift your chest off the ground slightly. 3. Hold for a moment and lower back down.

Title: Exercise ball torso rotation
Desc: The exercise ball torso rotation is a rotational abdominal exercise performed while holding a yoga or exercise ball between the hands. It focuses on the rotational muscles of the core, including the obliques, glutes, and hip muscles. It can be performed one side at a time or alternating, either for time or reps. To make it more difficult, wrap a light exercise band around the ball and anchor it to a solid object.
HowTo: 1. Sit on an exercise ball with your feet flat on the ground. 2. Hold the ball with both hands and rotate your torso to one side, then to the other. 3. Keep your core engaged throughout the movement.

Title: Seated Overhead Stretch
Desc: The seated overhead stretch is an excellent exercise for improving shoulder flexibility and relieving tension. It involves reaching your arms overhead while seated.
HowTo: 1. Sit comfortably with your back straight. 2. Raise both arms overhead, interlocking your fingers. 3. Lean slightly to one side, then the other, to stretch the shoulders.

Title: Overhead Stretch
Desc: The overhead stretch helps improve flexibility and mobility in the shoulders and upper back. It is beneficial for relieving tension and enhancing range of motion.
HowTo: 1. Stand or sit up straight. 2. Raise both arms overhead, interlocking your fingers. 3. Gently lean to one side, feeling the stretch in the opposite side of your body. 4. Hold for a few seconds, then switch sides.

Title: Seated Scissor Kick
Desc: The seated scissor kick is a dynamic exercise that improves flexibility and mobility in the legs. It also engages the core for stability.
HowTo: 1. Sit on the floor with your legs extended in front of you. 2. Lean back slightly, keeping your back straight. 3. Lift one leg off the ground and alternate it with the other in a scissor motion. 4. Keep your core engaged and maintain a steady rhythm.

Title: Partner resistance standing twist
Desc: The partner resistance standing twist is a bodyweight exercise in which one partner performs bodyweight twists while the other provides manual resistance. It targets the muscles of the core, and the obliques in particular. It can be performed in the core-focused part of any workout.
HowTo: 1. Stand facing your partner, feet shoulder-width apart. 2. One partner twists their torso while the other provides resistance by holding their hands against the twisting partner's side. 3. Alternate roles after a set number of repetitions.

Title: Cross Crunch
Desc: The cross crunch is a core exercise that targets the abdominal muscles, particularly the obliques. It helps improve core strength and stability.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back with your knees bent and feet flat on the floor. 2. Place your hands behind your head. 3. Lift your right shoulder towards your left knee while extending your right leg. 4. Alternate sides, bringing your left shoulder towards your right knee.

Title: Full Moon
Desc: The Full Moon is a stretching exercise that promotes overall flexibility and relaxation in the body. It can be performed as part of a cool-down routine.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. 2. Raise your arms overhead, palms facing each other. 3. Slowly lean back, arching your back and looking up towards the ceiling. 4. Hold the position for a few seconds before returning to the starting position.

Title: Hanging knee raise with manual resistance
Desc: The hanging knee raise with manual resistance is a more advanced version of the hanging knee raise that utilizes a partner. The partner applies enough resistance to make the movement more difficult, while still allowing the lifter to perform multiple reps.
HowTo: 1. Hang from a pull-up bar with your arms extended. 2. Engage your core and raise your knees towards your chest while your partner provides resistance.

Title: Straight-Legged Hip Raise
Desc: The Straight-Legged Hip Raise is an exercise that targets the glutes and hamstrings while also engaging the core.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back with your legs straight and feet together. 2. Lift your hips off the ground while keeping your legs straight, then lower back down.

Title: Wall mountain climber
Desc: The wall mountain climber is a challenging exercise targeting the shoulders and abdominals. It's most common in bodyweight circuit training because it targets a lot of muscles as well as the cardiovascular system all at once. It can be performed for time or reps.
HowTo: 1. Start in a plank position with your hands on the wall. 2. Quickly alternate bringing your knees towards your chest in a running motion.

Title: Skin The Cat To Push-Up
Desc: Skin The Cat To Push-Up is a dynamic exercise that combines a skin the cat movement with a push-up, engaging multiple muscle groups.
HowTo: 1. Hang from a bar and rotate your body through your shoulders until your legs come up and over. 2. Transition into a push-up position and perform a push-up.

Title: Partner lying leg raise with lateral throw down
Desc: The partner lying leg raise with lateral throw down is a core exercise in which one partner performs a leg raise while the other partner pushes their legs back down at a lateral angle. The partner performing the exercise has to use core strength and stability to keep their legs from falling to the ground.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back with your legs straight and your partner positioned at your feet. 2. Raise your legs towards your partner while they push them back down at a lateral angle.

Title: Hanging leg raise with throw down
Desc: The hanging leg raise with throw down is a more advanced version of the hanging knee raise that utilizes a partner to make the movement more difficult. The partner pushes down at the top of each rep, forcing the lifter to "fight back" with their abs.
HowTo: 1. Hang from a pull-up bar with your legs straight. 2. Raise your legs towards your chest while your partner pushes down on your legs at the top of the movement. 3. Lower your legs back to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Partner sit-up with high-five
Desc: The partner sit-up with high-five is a full-body exercise targeting the core. Partners each perform a sit-up and high-five each other mid rep.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back with your knees bent and feet flat on the floor. 2. Perform a sit-up while your partner does the same, reaching for a high-five at the top of the movement. 3. Lower back down and repeat.

Title: Exercise ball knee roll-in
Desc: The exercise ball knee roll-in is an abdominal exercise that involves supporting yourself with your hands in a plank or push-up position and drawing the knees in toward the chest. This is a fairly advanced abdominal move requiring a fair amount of core strength.
HowTo: 1. Start in a plank position with your feet on an exercise ball. 2. Roll the ball towards your chest by bending your knees. 3. Extend your legs back to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Partner lying leg raise with throw down
Desc: The partner lying leg raise with throw down is a core exercise in which one partner performs a leg raise while the other partner pushes their legs back down. The partner performing the exercise has to use core strength and stability to keep their legs from falling to the ground.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back with your legs straight and your partner standing at your feet. 2. Raise your legs towards the ceiling while your partner pushes them down. 3. Control the movement and lower your legs back to the starting position.

Title: Crab toe-touch
Desc: The crab toe-touch is a full-body exercise targeting the glutes, hamstrings, quads, and core. It is a challenging move that trains balance, core strength, and many muscle groups, making it work well in a time-efficient bodyweight circuit workout.
HowTo: 1. Start in a crab position with your hands and feet on the ground, hips lifted. 2. Reach one hand towards the opposite foot, touching it while keeping your hips elevated. 3. Alternate sides and repeat.

Title: Side kick-through
Desc: The side kick-through is a full-body movement that involves isometric holds and moving the body through different ranges of motion, beginning in a bear crawl position. The difference between a side kick-through and a sit-through is that your butt stays off the ground throughout the entire rep. It is commonly performed in bodyweight circuits and animal-style flows, but can also work for reps on its own or as part of a dynamic warm-up or mobility sequence.
HowTo: 1. Start in a bear crawl position with your hands under your shoulders and knees under your hips. 2. Shift your weight to one side, extend the opposite leg out to the side, and then return to the starting position, alternating sides.

Title: Partner target sit-up
Desc: The partner target sit-up is a core exercise where one partner performs sit-ups, while the other uses his or her hands to create a target for them to reach for. This increases the challenge of each rep. It can be performed for time or reps in the ab-focused portion of any workout.
HowTo: 1. One partner lies on their back with knees bent, while the other partner sits at their feet. 2. The partner on the ground performs a sit-up, reaching for the target created by the other partner's hands.

Title: Suspended Crunch
Desc: The suspended crunch is performed while hanging from a bar, engaging the core muscles to lift the legs towards the chest. This exercise primarily targets the abdominal muscles and improves core strength.
HowTo: 1. Hang from a pull-up bar with your arms extended. 2. Engage your core and lift your knees towards your chest, then lower them back down.

Title: Jump Lunge
Desc: The alternating lunge jump is an explosive bodyweight exercise that targets the lower-body muscles, including the quads, glutes, and hamstrings. It can be performed for time or reps in power training, and is also effective in any fat-loss or athleticism-focused workout.
HowTo: 1. Start in a standing position with feet hip-width apart. 2. Step one foot back into a lunge, then explosively jump and switch legs in mid-air, landing in a lunge with the opposite leg forward.

Title: Side plank hip dip
Desc: The side plank hip dip is a dynamic version of the side plank exercise focusing on the oblique muscles, as well as the transversus abdominis or deep core muscles. It can be performed for time or reps and can work in a warm-up or in the core-focused portion of any workout.
HowTo: 1. Start in a side plank position with your elbow under your shoulder. 2. Lower your hip towards the ground and then lift it back up to the starting position, engaging your core throughout.

Title: Elbow plank jack
Desc: The elbow plank jack is an isometric abdominal exercise with a dynamic lower-body component. It targets the muscles of the core, the deep core or transversus abdominis in particular. It can be performed for time or reps in the ab-focused portion of any workout.
HowTo: 1. Start in an elbow plank position with your forearms on the ground and your body in a straight line. 2. Jump your feet out to the sides and then back together while maintaining the plank position.

Title: Exercise ball V-up
Desc: The exercise ball V-up is a popular movement to target the abdominal muscles, particularly the rectus abdominis or "six-pack" muscles. It involves passing an exercise ball or yoga ball back and forth between the hands and feet while performing V-ups. It can be performed for reps or time as part of any ab-focused workout or bodyweight circuit.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back with an exercise ball between your feet and hands. 2. Lift your legs and arms simultaneously to pass the ball from your feet to your hands and back.

Title: Standing torso twist stretch
Desc: The standing torso twist stretch is a stretching exercise targeting the lats and core, particularly the obliques. Its great before a workout or any sporting event that involves a lot of twisting of the upper body.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. 2. Rotate your torso to one side while keeping your hips facing forward, then return to the center and rotate to the other side.

Title: Slalom jumps
Desc: The slalom jump is an explosive bodyweight exercise that targets the lower body, including the quads, glutes, and hamstrings. Performed for reps, it also provides a serious cardiovascular challenge. It can be performed for time or reps and is especially effective in a fat-loss or athleticism-focused circuit or workout.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet together and jump to one side, landing on one foot. 2. Immediately jump to the other side, repeating the motion in a slalom pattern.

Title: Bear crawl
Desc: The bear crawl is a popular bodyweight crawling exercise. While it looks simple, the bear crawl is an intense full-body movement that targets the cardiovascular system as well as a wide range of muscle groups, the shoulders, core, and legs in particular. It can be done as a full-body warm-up, in short bursts for power or circuit training, or for longer durations as cardiovascular conditioning.
HowTo: 1. Start on all fours with your hands under your shoulders and knees under your hips. 2. Move your right hand and left foot forward simultaneously, followed by your left hand and right foot, crawling forward in a controlled manner.

Title: Crab single-arm reach
Desc: The crab single-arm reach is a full-body exercise that requires maintaining a tabletop position while alternating arm raises. It is an excellent movement to include in a dynamic warm-up, a bodyweight circuit, or for muscle activation or mobility anytime.
HowTo: 1. Start in a tabletop position with hands under shoulders and knees under hips. 2. Raise one arm towards the ceiling while keeping your hips stable. 3. Alternate arms while maintaining the tabletop position.

Title: Side lunge cross-body heel-touch
Desc: The side lunge cross-body heel-touch is a lower-body exercise targeting the quads, glutes, and hamstrings. The heel-touch adds a slight rotational challenge.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart. 2. Step to the side into a lunge while reaching across your body to touch the opposite heel. 3. Return to the starting position and repeat on the other side.

Title: Alligator Crawl
Desc: The spider crawl is a bodyweight exercise that involves crawling on the floor with the knees outside of the elbows. It is different from a leopard crawl in that the hips are higher, and it's different from a bear crawl because the knees are wider. It can be done as a full-body warm-up, in short bursts for power or circuit training, or for longer durations as cardiovascular conditioning.
HowTo: 1. Start in a plank position with hands under shoulders. 2. Crawl forward by moving your right hand and left foot simultaneously, then your left hand and right foot. 3. Keep your knees wide and hips elevated as you crawl.

Title: Lying cross-over lower back stretch
Desc: The lying cross-over lower back stretch is a simple bodyweight stretch targeting the lower back, hips, and torso. It involves rotating the legs while lying flat on the back. It is commonly included in dynamic warm-ups, but can also be performed as full-body mobility work anytime.
HowTo: 1. Lie flat on your back with arms extended out to the sides. 2. Bend your knees and rotate them to one side while keeping your shoulders on the ground. 3. Hold the stretch and then switch to the other side.

Title: Half bird dog
Desc: The half bird dog is a core exercise designed to strengthen the posterior chain. In the half bird dog, you will raise one arm or one leg at a time, rather than both at once as you would for a regular bird dog.
HowTo: 1. Start on all fours with hands under shoulders and knees under hips. 2. Extend one arm forward while keeping the opposite leg extended back. 3. Hold briefly, then return to the starting position and switch sides.

Title: Shoulder tap
Desc: The shoulder tap is an exercise targeting the abdominals and core. The basic stance matches the top of a push-up position. From there, one hand is raised to tap its opposing shoulder. A tap with each hand to each opposing shoulder equals one rep.
HowTo: Start in a push-up position. Raise one hand to tap the opposite shoulder, alternating sides.

Title: Double crunch
Desc: The double crunch is a bodyweight exercise focused on the muscles of the core, the rectus abdominis or "six-pack" muscles in particular. It's a very simple exercise that involves "crunching" the knees and elbows toward each other using the abdominal muscles, while keeping the back flat against the ground.
HowTo: Lie on your back with your knees bent. Simultaneously lift your knees and shoulders towards each other, crunching your body.

Title: Flutter kick
Desc: The flutter kick is a core exercise where the legs are held off the ground as you flutter your feet over and under each other in small motions. It targets multiple muscles of the core, but particularly the rectus abdominis or "six-pack" muscles. It can be performed for time or reps in the ab-focused portion of any workout.
HowTo: Lie on your back and lift your legs off the ground. Flutter your feet up and down in a controlled motion.

Title: Sprawl
Desc: The sprawl is an explosive bodyweight exercise that targets the core, upper body, and lower body. It is similar to a burpee, but without a jump at the top and with a plank instead of a push-up at the bottom. It can be performed for time or reps in any fat-loss or athleticism-focused circuit or workout.
HowTo: Begin in a standing position, drop into a plank position, then return to standing without a jump. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Spider plank jack
Desc: The spider plank jack is a bodyweight core exercise that begins in a straight-arm plank, then combines a spider crunch and a plank jack into a single sequence. It can be performed as bodyweight core training or for conditioning in a fat-loss or athleticism-focused circuit.
HowTo: Start in a straight-arm plank position. Bring one knee towards the elbow while jumping your feet out and back in, alternating sides.

Title: Pillar-To-Plank
Desc: The Pillar-To-Plank is an exercise that engages the core and stabilizes the shoulders. It transitions from a plank position to a side plank, enhancing core strength and stability.
HowTo: 1. Start in a plank position with your hands under your shoulders and body in a straight line. 2. Rotate your body to one side, stacking your feet and raising your arm towards the ceiling. 3. Hold for a moment, then return to the plank position and repeat on the other side.

Title: Alternating High Knee Raise
Desc: The Alternating High Knee Raise is a dynamic exercise that elevates the heart rate while engaging the lower body. It improves coordination and strengthens the hip flexors and legs.
HowTo: 1. Stand tall with your feet hip-width apart. 2. Quickly lift your right knee towards your chest while raising your left arm. 3. Lower your right leg and repeat with the left knee and right arm, alternating quickly.

Title: Sumo Squat Pulse
Desc: The Sumo Squat Pulse targets the lower body, particularly the inner thighs and glutes. It emphasizes muscle engagement through a pulsing motion at the bottom of the squat.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet wider than shoulder-width apart and toes pointed out. 2. Lower into a squat until your thighs are parallel to the ground. 3. Pulse up and down slightly while maintaining the squat position, then rise back up.

Title: Line-Drill Foot Work
Desc: Line-Drill Foot Work is an agility exercise that enhances foot speed and coordination. It is often used in sports training to improve overall athletic performance.
HowTo: 1. Set up a line on the ground or use cones. 2. Stand at one end and quickly step forward, back, and side to side along the line, focusing on speed and precision. 3. Repeat the drill, varying your foot patterns.

Title: Plank Fire Hydrants
Desc: Plank Fire Hydrants are a core stability exercise that targets the glutes and hip flexors. They help improve balance and strengthen the core while engaging the lower body.
HowTo: 1. Start in a plank position with your hands under your shoulders. 2. Lift one leg out to the side, keeping it bent at 90 degrees, then lower it back down. 3. Alternate legs while maintaining a stable plank position.

Title: Banded jumping jack
Desc: The banded jumping jack takes a classic plyometric exercise and adds an extra degree of difficulty in the form of a band surrounding the thighs, just above the knees. It can be performed for time or reps and is a great way to warm up for athletics or lower-body lifting.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet together and the resistance band around your thighs. 2. Jump out to the side while raising your arms overhead, then jump back to the starting position.

Title: Shin hug
Desc: The shin hug is a bodyweight exercise focused on the muscles of the core. It shares characteristics with V-ups and crunches, but finishes with the ribs touching the thighs. It can be performed for time or for reps as part of the ab-focused portion of any workout.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back and pull your knees towards your chest. 2. Hug your shins and lift your head and shoulders off the ground, bringing your ribs towards your thighs.

Title: FYR Bear Crawl Fire Feet
Desc: Bear crawl fire feet is a variation of the bear crawl that involves running in place while in a static bear crawl hold. It adds an extra coordination and full-body challenge to an already intense full-body movement that targets the cardiovascular system as well as a wide range of muscle groups. It can be done as a full-body warm-up, or as part of a bodyweight circuit or flow.
HowTo: 1. Start in a bear crawl position with your hands and feet on the ground. 2. While maintaining the bear crawl position, run in place by alternating your knees towards your chest.

Title: Bear crawl up-down
Desc: The bear crawl up-down is a variation of the bear crawl that involves lowering the forearms to the ground in an alternating rhythm while in a static bear crawl hold. It adds an extra coordination and upper-body challenge to an already intense full-body movement that targets the cardiovascular system as well as a wide range of muscle groups. It can be done as a full-body warm-up, or as part of a bodyweight circuit or flow.
HowTo: 1. Begin in a bear crawl position with your hands and feet on the ground. 2. Lower one forearm to the ground, then alternate lowering the other forearm while maintaining the bear crawl position.

Title: FYR Crab Kick
Desc: The crab toe-touch is a full-body exercise targeting the glutes, hamstrings, quads, and core.
HowTo: 1. Start in a seated position with your hands behind you and your feet flat on the ground. 2. Lift your hips off the ground and kick one leg out while reaching for your toes with the opposite hand.

Title: Bear crawl hold
Desc: The bear crawl hold is a static variation of the bear crawl exercise performed for time. It looks simple, but it demands full-body tension and is taxing to the shoulders, core, and legs. It can be done as a full-body warm-up, as part of a bodyweight circuit or flow, or as a build-up to the traditional bear crawl.
HowTo: Start in a bear crawl position with your hands under your shoulders and knees under your hips. Hold the position while engaging your core and maintaining tension throughout your body.

Title: Traveling bear crawl
Desc: The traveling bear crawl is a more advanced version of the bear crawl exercise that moves side to side rather than front to back. While it looks simple, the traveling bear crawl is an intense full-body movement that targets the cardiovascular system as well as a wide range of muscle groups, the shoulders, core, and legs in particular. It can be done as a full-body warm-up, in short bursts for power or circuit training, or for longer durations as cardiovascular conditioning.
HowTo: Begin in a bear crawl position, then move sideways by shifting your weight from one hand to the other while keeping your knees off the ground. Maintain a strong core and controlled movement throughout.

Title: Single-leg V-up
Desc: The single-leg V-up is a bodyweight exercise that targets the abdominals and the hip flexors, working one side of the body at a time. It can be performed for time or reps in the ab-focused portion of any workout.
HowTo: Lie on your back with one leg extended and the other leg bent. Lift your upper body and the extended leg simultaneously to form a V shape, then lower back down and repeat.

Title: FYR Bear Crawl Shoulder Tap
Desc: The bear crawl shoulder tap is a variation of the bear crawl that involves touching the opposing shoulder while in a static bear crawl hold. It adds an extra coordination and core challenge to an already intense full-body movement that targets the cardiovascular system as well as a wide range of muscle groups. It can be done as a full-body warm-up, or as part of a bodyweight circuit or flow.
HowTo: Start in a bear crawl position, then lift one hand to touch the opposite shoulder while maintaining balance. Alternate sides while keeping your core engaged and hips stable.

Title: Alternating single-leg sprawl
Desc: The alternating single-leg sprawl is an explosive bodyweight exercise that targets the core, upper body, and lower body. It differs from a standard sprawl by including a single-leg plank instead of a regular plank at the bottom. It can be performed for time or reps in any fat-loss or athleticism-focused circuit or workout.
HowTo: Begin in a standing position, then drop into a sprawl by placing your hands on the ground and kicking your legs back into a plank position. From there, perform a single-leg plank by lifting one leg while maintaining the plank, then return to standing and repeat on the other side.

Title: Wide mountain climber
Desc: The wide mountain climber is a popular bodyweight exercise targeting the muscles of the core, as well as the shoulders, hips, and cardiovascular system. It is different from a traditional mountain climber because you bring the knee to the outside of the elbow rather than the inside. It can be performed for time or reps as part of a dynamic warm-up, for bodyweight cardio or conditioning, or as no-equipment dynamic core training.
HowTo: 1. Start in a high plank position with your hands under your shoulders. 2. Bring your right knee to the outside of your right elbow, then return to plank. 3. Alternate legs, bringing the left knee to the outside of the left elbow. 4. Continue alternating for the desired time or reps.

Title: Plank leg raise
Desc: The plank leg raise is an isometric abdominal exercise that targets the muscles of the core, the deep core or transversus abdominis in particular. It also targets the muscles of the glutes and hips. It can be performed for time or reps in the ab-focused portion of any workout.
HowTo: 1. Start in a plank position with your body in a straight line. 2. Raise one leg towards the ceiling while keeping your core tight. 3. Lower the leg back to the starting position and repeat with the other leg. 4. Continue alternating legs for the desired time or reps.

Title: Glute bridge step-out
Desc: The glute bridge step-out is a lower-body bodyweight exercise that targets the glutes and hamstrings. It differs from a glute bridge by the addition of a step-out, which increases stress on the hamstrings. It can be performed for time or reps and works perfectly in a dynamic warm-up for lower-body training, but can also be performed for glute activation anytime.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back with your knees bent and feet flat on the floor. 2. Lift your hips towards the ceiling into a glute bridge position. 3. Step one foot out to the side while maintaining the bridge position. 4. Return the foot to the starting position and repeat with the other foot. 5. Continue alternating for the desired time or reps.

Title: Knee up-down
Desc: The knee up-down is a bodyweight exercise that mimics getting up and down from a kneeling position on the floor. It combines the low position of a squat with lunges, bringing some of the benefits of both. It can be done for time or reps as part of a dynamic warm-up or as part of a bodyweight circuit or workout.
HowTo: 1. Start in a kneeling position on the floor. 2. Shift your weight to one side and bring your foot forward to stand up. 3. Reverse the movement to return to the kneeling position. 4. Alternate sides for the desired time or reps.

Title: FYR Sprawl
Desc: The sprawl is an explosive bodyweight exercise that targets the core, upper body, and lower body. It is similar to a burpee, but without a jump at the top and with a plank instead of a push-up at the bottom. It can be performed for time or reps in any fat-loss or athleticism-focused circuit or workout.
HowTo: 1. Start in a standing position. 2. Drop into a squat and place your hands on the ground. 3. Jump your feet back into a plank position. 4. Perform a plank hold, then jump your feet back towards your hands. 5. Stand up and repeat for the desired time or reps.

Title: Reach crunch
Desc: The reach crunch is a bodyweight core exercise that involves keeping the arms raised toward the ceiling while performing a crunch. It can be performed for time or reps as part of any abs-focused circuit or workout.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back with your knees bent and feet flat on the floor. 2. Raise your arms toward the ceiling, then lift your shoulders off the ground while engaging your core, bringing your torso towards your knees.

Title: FYR Push-Up Plank Hold
Desc: The straight-arm plank is an exercise targeting the core muscles. It is basically the top of a push-up position, with elbows fully extended and palms on the floor. The position is held for time to target the muscles of the core, as well as the shoulders.
HowTo: 1. Start in a push-up position with your arms straight and your body in a straight line. 2. Hold this position for a set amount of time, keeping your core tight and avoiding sagging or arching your back.

Title: FYR Hollow-Body Rock
Desc: The hollow-body rock is a bodyweight abdominal exercise performed on the floor. It starts with a hollow-body hold and adds a back-and-forth rock that challenges core stability and increases the difficulty of the movement. It can be performed for time or for reps, either in an ab-focused portion of a workout or as part of a circuit workout.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back and lift your legs and shoulders off the ground into a hollow-body hold. 2. Rock back and forth while maintaining the hollow position, ensuring your lower back stays pressed into the floor.

Title: V-up plus knee-to-chest combo
Desc: The V-up plus knee-to-chest combo is a core exercise that targets the abdominals and hip flexors by combining two movements into a single sequence. It can be performed for time or reps in the ab-focused portion of any workout.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back with your arms extended overhead and legs straight. 2. Simultaneously lift your legs and upper body to form a 'V' shape, then pull your knees towards your chest before returning to the starting position.

Title: Side plank lateral raise
Desc: The side plank lateral raise is an exercise that combines an isometric side plank hold with a dumbbell raise to target both the core and the shoulders. You probably won't be able to use much weight without disrupting your balance, but even at light weight, this is a movement that can help address multiple muscle groups in a time-efficient workout.
HowTo: 1. Start in a side plank position, balancing on one forearm and the side of your foot. 2. Hold the side plank while lifting a dumbbell with your top arm, raising it to shoulder height, then lower it back down.

Title: Superhero burpee
Desc: The superhero burpee is an advanced variation of the burpee exercise. The main difference between this and the standard burpee is that while on the floor, the hands are extended in front of the body like Superman taking flight. This increases the challenge to the upper back and shoulders. These can be performed for time or reps as part of any fat-loss or athleticism-focused workout or circuit.
HowTo: 1. Start in a standing position. 2. Drop into a squat and place your hands on the floor. 3. Jump your feet back into a plank position. 4. Perform a push-up. 5. Jump your feet back towards your hands. 6. Extend your arms in front of you and jump up, mimicking Superman's flight.

Title: Hollow-body abduction
Desc: The hollow-body abduction is an isometric core exercise that includes leg abductions for an added challenge to the core and abductors. It targets multiple muscles of the core, but particularly the rectus abdominis or "six-pack" muscles. It can be performed for time or reps in the ab-focused portion of any workout.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back with your arms extended overhead and legs straight. 2. Lift your legs off the ground while simultaneously raising your arms to meet them. 3. Hold the position, engaging your core and keeping your back flat against the floor.

Title: FYR Hollow Hold
Desc: The FYR Hollow Hold is an isometric core exercise that focuses on maintaining a hollow position to engage the core muscles effectively.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back with your arms extended overhead and legs straight. 2. Lift your shoulders and legs off the ground, keeping your lower back pressed into the floor. 3. Hold this position, ensuring your body forms a 'hollow' shape.

Title: Tip-toe crunch
Desc: The tip-toe crunch is a variation on the crunch exercise that involves placing the toes on or near the ground. This can help isolate the abs from the hip flexors. The tip-toe crunch can be performed for time or for reps as part of the core-focused component of any workout.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back with your knees bent and feet flat on the floor. 2. Lift your shoulders off the ground and reach towards your toes. 3. Hold the position briefly, then lower back down and repeat.

Title: Knee-to-nose pulse
Desc: The knee-to-nose pulse is a bodyweight exercise that targets the core by pulsing your knee toward your nose. It starts in a straight-arm plank position, and is similar to a mountain climber, but with a hold or pause in the bent-knee position.
HowTo: 1. Start in a straight-arm plank position with your body in a straight line. 2. Bring one knee towards your nose while keeping the other leg extended. 3. Pulse your knee towards your nose, then return to the plank position and repeat on the other side.

Title: Plank walk-out
Desc: The plank walk-out is an advanced plank variation targeting the core and shoulders. From a standing position, the lifter descends into a plank-type position but walks the hands forward until they are out in front of the head. This is far more challenging to the core than having the arms directly under the shoulders. Beginners will need to progress to this exercise.
HowTo: 1. Start in a standing position. 2. Bend at the waist and walk your hands forward into a plank position. 3. Keep your core engaged and walk your hands out as far as you can. 4. Walk your hands back to return to the starting position.

Title: FYR V-Up
Desc: The V-up is a bodyweight movement that targets the muscles of the abs, the rectus abdominis or "six-pack" muscles in particular. It is similar to a suitcase crunch, but the lower back lifts off the ground at the top of each rep. It can be performed for time or reps in the ab-focused portion of any workout.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back with your arms extended overhead and legs straight. 2. Simultaneously lift your legs and upper body to form a V shape. 3. Lower back down with control and repeat.

Title: Long sit-up
Desc: The long sit-up is an advanced version of the sit-up exercise that is performed with the hands reaching over the head. This lengthens the torso, making it harder for the abs to contract and lift the upper body. Long sit-ups can be performed for time or for reps, with the feet anchored or free.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back with your arms extended overhead. 2. Engage your core and lift your upper body while keeping your hands over your head. 3. Lower back down with control and repeat.

Title: FYR Breakdancer
Desc: The side kick-through is a full-body movement that involves isometric holds and moving the body through different ranges of motion, beginning in a bear crawl position. The difference between a side kick-through and a sit-through is that your butt stays off the ground throughout the entire rep. It is commonly performed in bodyweight circuits and animal-style flows, but can also work for reps on its own or as part of a dynamic warm-up or mobility sequence.
HowTo: 1. Start in a bear crawl position with hands under shoulders and knees under hips. 2. Shift your weight to one side and kick your opposite leg through while rotating your torso. 3. Return to the starting position and repeat on the other side.

Title: Seated leg lift
Desc: The seated leg lift is a bodyweight exercise targeting the muscles of the core and hip flexors. It can be performed for time or reps in the core-focused portion of any workout.
HowTo: 1. Sit on the ground with your legs extended in front of you. 2. Lean back slightly and lift your legs off the ground while keeping them straight. 3. Hold for a moment, then lower back down and repeat.

Title: Gorilla burpee
Desc: The gorilla burpee is a variation of the burpee exercise that consists of a reverse lunge on each leg, a full squat, then a standard burpee. It is extra challenging for the lower body, including the quads, glutes, and hamstrings. It can be performed for time or reps in any fat-loss or athleticism-focused circuit or workout.
HowTo: 1. Start in a standing position. 2. Step back into a reverse lunge with your right leg, then return to standing. 3. Step back into a reverse lunge with your left leg, then return to standing. 4. Perform a full squat. 5. Jump into a standard burpee position, perform a push-up, and jump back to standing.

Title: Knee-in to V-out
Desc: The knee-in to V-out is a bodyweight abdominal exercise performed on the floor. It is similar to both the reverse crunch and the V-up exercise, but combines elements of both. It primarily targets the muscles of the rectus abdominis, or six-pack muscles. It can be performed for reps or time, either as part of an ab-focused workout or as a component of a circuit workout.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back with your arms extended overhead and legs straight. 2. Pull your knees toward your chest while simultaneously lifting your upper body off the ground. 3. Extend your legs out to form a 'V' shape while reaching your arms forward. 4. Return to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Bear crawl push-up
Desc: The bear crawl push-up is a variation of the bear crawl hold with a push-up added. It adds an extra coordination and shoulder challenge to an already intense full-body movement that targets the cardiovascular system as well as a wide range of muscle groups, the shoulders, core, and legs in particular. It can be done as a full-body warm-up, or as part of a bodyweight circuit or flow.
HowTo: 1. Start in a bear crawl position on all fours. 2. Lower your body into a push-up while maintaining the bear crawl position. 3. Push back up and return to the bear crawl. 4. Repeat the push-up while moving forward in the bear crawl.

Title: FYR Front Step
Desc: The FYR Front Step is a leg exercise that involves stepping forward with one leg and returning to the starting position. It targets the major muscle groups in the legs.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet hip-width apart. 2. Step forward with your right leg, lowering your body into a lunge. 3. Push back to the starting position. 4. Repeat with the left leg.

Title: Plank reach
Desc: The plank reach is an exercise targeting the entire core, particularly the oblique muscles. It resembles a plank exercise, but the primary difference is that the lifter extends their arms forward, one at time. The core, especially the obliques, must work hard to maintain stability. It can be performed for time, with holds in the reaching position, or for reps.
HowTo: 1. Start in a plank position with your arms straight and body in a straight line. 2. Extend your right arm forward while maintaining balance. 3. Return to the plank position and repeat with the left arm. 4. Continue alternating arms.

Title: Eiffel Tower leg raise
Desc: The Eiffel Tower leg raise is a bodyweight exercise targeting the muscles of the abs, the rectus abdominis or six-pack muscles in particular. It is similar to a V-up, but with the added challenge of drawing a pyramid shape in the air with the legs during each rep. It can be performed for time or reps in the core-focused portion of any workout.
HowTo: Lie on your back with your legs extended. Raise your legs while keeping them straight, drawing a pyramid shape in the air with your legs as you lift your torso off the ground.

Title: Straight-arm plank
Desc: The straight-arm plank is an exercise targeting the core muscles. It is basically the top of a push-up position, with elbows fully extended and palms on the floor. The position is held for time to target the muscles of the core, as well as the shoulders.
HowTo: Start in a push-up position with your arms straight. Hold this position for time, engaging your core and keeping your body in a straight line.

Title: Plank up-down
Desc: The plank up-down is a variation of the plank push-up that ends in an elbow plank rather than with the chest on the ground. It involves transitioning between the two positions one arm at a time, rather than two. It puts more stress on the triceps and core than traditional planks. It can be performed for time or reps in any bodyweight workout or during the core-focused portion of any workout.
HowTo: Begin in a high plank position. Lower one arm to the elbow to transition into an elbow plank, then push back up to the high plank, alternating arms.

Title: Frog kick
Desc: The frog kick is an explosive bodyweight movement that involves hopping the rear legs up and forward from a straight-arm plank position. It targets the legs, core, and shoulders, but is also a high-intensity conditioning movement that will raise core body temperature and burn serious calories. It can be performed for time or reps as part of any athleticism-focused or fat-loss circuit or workout.
HowTo: Start in a straight-arm plank position. Jump your legs forward and up, then return to the plank position, repeating for time or reps.

Title: FYR Knees to Chest
Desc: The hollow-body alternating knee-to-chest is a core exercise that involves bending the legs while holding the hips and shoulder blades off the ground. It targets the rectus abdominis or "six-pack" muscles. It can be performed for time or reps in the ab-focused portion of any workout.
HowTo: Lie on your back with your arms extended overhead and legs straight. Bend your knees and bring them towards your chest while lifting your shoulder blades off the ground, then return to the starting position.

Title: Front kick-through
Desc: The front kick-through is a full-body movement that involves moving the legs from a bear crawl position to a balanced one-legged stance. It is commonly performed for reps or time in bodyweight circuits and animal-style flows, but can also work on its own or as part of a dynamic warm-up or mobility sequence.
HowTo: Start in a bear crawl position with hands and feet on the ground. Shift your weight onto one leg while kicking the other leg through to a balanced one-legged stance, then return to the starting position.

Title: FYR Sit-Up
Desc: The sit-up is a popular bodyweight exercise focused on the abdominal muscles. It has also been used as part of military, tactical, and scholastic fitness tests for many years. It can be performed for time or reps, with the feet anchored or free, on flat ground or a bench.
HowTo: Lie on your back with your knees bent and feet flat on the ground. Engage your core and lift your upper body towards your knees, then lower back down with control.

Title: FYR Leg Lift
Desc: The seated leg lift is a bodyweight exercise targeting the muscles of the core and hip flexors. It can be performed for time or reps in the core-focused portion of any workout.
HowTo: Sit on the ground with your legs extended in front of you. Lean back slightly and lift your legs off the ground while engaging your core, then lower them back down without touching the ground.

Title: TBS Toes-to-bar
Desc: The hanging toes-to-bar is an advanced abdominal exercise in which the lifter touches their feet to a pull-up bar. There are many ways to perform this movement: strict or swinging, arms completely straight or slightly bent, legs straight or bent, each providing unique benefits and challenges. Initially, it may be a difficult move to do for a single rep, but once you build the requisite core, lat, and shoulder strength, it can be performed for higher reps.
HowTo: Hang from a pull-up bar with your arms straight. Engage your core and lift your legs to touch the bar with your toes, then lower back down with control.

Title: FYR Mountain Climber
Desc: The mountain climber is a popular bodyweight exercise targeting the muscles of the core, as well as the shoulders, hips, and cardiovascular system. It involves lifting one knee to the chest at a time from a straight-arm plank position. It can be performed for time or reps as part of a dynamic warm-up, for bodyweight cardio or conditioning, or as no-equipment dynamic core training.
HowTo: Start in a straight-arm plank position. Alternate bringing your knees to your chest in a quick, controlled manner, as if running in place.

Title: Roman Chair Side Ups
Desc: The Roman Chair Side Ups is a core exercise that targets the obliques and the rectus abdominis. It involves using a Roman chair apparatus to perform side raises.
HowTo: 1. Sit on the Roman chair with your back against the pad. 2. Secure your legs under the pads. 3. Lean to one side, lifting your torso while keeping your legs secured. 4. Return to the starting position and repeat on the other side.

Title: Push-Up Roll Out - Gethin Variation
Desc: The Push-Up Roll Out - Gethin Variation is an advanced bodyweight exercise that combines push-ups with a roll-out movement. It targets the chest, triceps, and shoulders while also engaging the core.
