HowTo: 1. Start in a push-up position with your hands on a stability ball. 2. Perform a push-up, lowering your body toward the ground. 3. As you push back up, roll the ball forward, extending your arms. 4. Roll the ball back and repeat.

Title: Cross-Body Crunch - Gethin Variation
Desc: The cross-body sit-up is a bodyweight exercise targeting the ab muscles, the obliques and rectus abdominis or "six-pack" muscles in particular. It involves bringing the opposite-side knee and elbow together, usually alternating sides with each rep. It can be performed for time or reps as part of the ab-focused portion of any workout.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back with your knees bent and feet flat on the floor. 2. Place your hands behind your head. 3. Lift your shoulder blades off the ground and bring your right elbow to your left knee. 4. Alternate sides with each rep.

Title: Decline leg lift with twist
Desc: The decline leg lift with twist is a bodyweight core exercise targeting the obliques and rectus abdominis or "six-pack" muscles, particularly the lower abs. It can be performed for time or for reps as part of the core-focused portion of any workout or circuit.
HowTo: 1. Lie on a decline bench with your head lower than your feet. 2. Hold onto the bench for support. 3. Lift your legs towards the ceiling while twisting your hips to one side. 4. Lower your legs back down and repeat on the other side.

Title: Hanging Leg Raise - Variation Gethin
Desc: The hanging leg raise is an exercise targeting the abs and hip flexors. Instead of resting the forearms on the pads of apparatus, hang from a bar. It can be performed for time or reps in the ab-focused portion of any workout.
HowTo: 1. Hang from a pull-up bar with your arms fully extended. 2. Keep your legs straight and engage your core. 3. Raise your legs towards your chest while keeping them together. 4. Lower your legs back to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Butterfly crunch
Desc: The butterfly crunch is a popular bodyweight exercise that targets the rectus abdominis, or "six-pack" muscles. It gets its name from the position of the elbows and knees, both of which are bent out like wings. It can be performed for time or reps as part of any abs-focused circuit or workout.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back with the soles of your feet together and knees bent out to the sides. 2. Engage your core and lift your upper body towards your feet, then lower back down.

Title: Cross-body mountain climber
Desc: The cross-body mountain climber is a popular bodyweight exercise targeting the muscles of the core, as well as the shoulders, hips, and cardiovascular system. It is different from a traditional mountain climber because you bring the knee to the opposite side of the body rather than simply to the chest. It can be performed for time or reps as part of a dynamic warm-up, for bodyweight cardio or conditioning, or as no-equipment dynamic core training.
HowTo: 1. Start in a plank position with your hands under your shoulders. 2. Drive your right knee towards your left elbow, then return to plank and switch sides.

Title: Flat Bench Lying Leg Raise - Gethin Variation
Desc: The lying leg lift is a popular bodyweight exercise targeting the muscles of the abs, the rectus abdominis or six-pack muscles in particular. It can be performed for time or reps in the core-focused portion of any workout.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back with your legs extended and hands under your glutes. 2. Lift your legs towards the ceiling while keeping them straight, then lower them back down without touching the ground.

Title: Lying leg lift
Desc: The lying leg lift is a popular bodyweight exercise targeting the muscles of the abs, the rectus abdominis or six-pack muscles in particular. It can be performed for time or reps in the core-focused portion of any workout.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back with your legs extended and hands under your glutes. 2. Lift your legs towards the ceiling while keeping them straight, then lower them back down without touching the ground.

Title: Hanging alternating single-leg raise
Desc: The hanging alternating single-leg raise is an exercise targeting the abs, but which also works the lats and hip flexors. Rather than performing both legs at a time, you lift one and alternate with each rep. Leg raises are often performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps or more, as part of ab-focused training. However, this difficult variation may require some time to build up to those rep ranges.
HowTo: 1. Hang from a pull-up bar with your arms extended. 2. Lift one leg towards your chest while keeping the other leg hanging, then alternate legs.

Title: Plank Walk
Desc: The plank walk is an isometric exercise that engages the core while challenging stability. It helps improve overall core strength and endurance.
HowTo: 1. Start in a high plank position with your hands directly under your shoulders. 2. Step your right hand and right foot out to the side, followed by your left hand and left foot, maintaining a straight line from head to heels. 3. Repeat the movement, alternating sides.

Title: Sit-Up - Gethin Variation
Desc: The sit-up is a popular bodyweight exercise focused on the abdominal muscles. It has also been used as part of military, tactical, and scholastic fitness tests for many years. It can be performed for time or reps, with the feet anchored or free, on flat ground or a bench.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back with your knees bent and feet flat on the floor. 2. Cross your arms over your chest or place your hands behind your head. 3. Engage your core and lift your upper body towards your knees, then lower back down.

Title: Plank Push-Up
Desc: The plank up-down is a variation of the plank push-up that ends in an elbow plank rather than with the chest on the ground. It involves transitioning between the two positions one arm at a time, rather than two. It puts more stress on the triceps and core than traditional planks. It can be performed for time or reps in any bodyweight workout or during the core-focused portion of any workout.
HowTo: 1. Start in a high plank position with your hands under your shoulders. 2. Lower your body into a push-up, then return to the plank position by lowering one arm at a time. 3. Alternate arms with each repetition.

Title: Decline crunch-
Desc: The decline crunch is a popular bodyweight exercise targeting the rectus abdominis or "six-pack" muscles, particular the upper abs. It is usually performed for high reps, such as 10-15 reps per set or more, as part of the ab-focused portion of a workout.
HowTo: 1. Lie on a decline bench with your feet secured. 2. Cross your arms over your chest or place your hands behind your head. 3. Curl your upper body towards your knees, then lower back down.

Title: Alternating lying leg raise
Desc: The alternating lying leg lift is a popular bodyweight exercise targeting the muscles of the abs, the rectus abdominis or six-pack muscles in particular. It can be performed for time or reps in the core-focused portion of any workout.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back with your legs extended and arms at your sides. 2. Lift one leg towards the ceiling while keeping the other leg hovering above the ground. 3. Alternate legs with each repetition.

Title: Decline leg lift
Desc: The decline leg lift is a popular bodyweight core exercise targeting the rectus abdominis or "six-pack" muscles, particularly the lower abs. It can be performed for time or for reps as part of the core-focused portion of any workout or circuit.
HowTo: 1. Lie on a decline bench with your legs secured. 2. Lift your legs towards your chest while engaging your core, then lower them back down.

Title: Crunch - Gethin Variation
Desc: The crunch is a popular core exercise targeting the rectus abdominis, or "six-pack" muscles, as well as the obliques. It has been the centerpiece of many ab-focused workouts, due to both its simplicity and the intense burn and mind-muscle connection it produces. It can be performed for time or reps as part of the ab-focused portion of any workout.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back with your knees bent and feet flat on the floor. 2. Curl your shoulders off the ground towards your knees, engaging your core, then lower back down.

Title: Plank - Gethin Variation
Desc: The elbow plank is a popular isometric abdominal exercise. It is common in all types of exercise programs, as well as in group fitness and yoga classes. It targets the muscles of the core, the deep core or transversus abdominis in particular. It is also often prescribed for time to help back pain or to teach proper bracing.
HowTo: 1. Start in a plank position with your elbows directly under your shoulders. 2. Keep your body in a straight line from head to heels, engaging your core and holding the position.

Title: Barbell floor wiper
Desc: The barbell floor wiper is a core exercise in which the barbell is held in the locked-out position of a floor press, and the hips and legs are rotated side to side. It targets the oblique muscles of the lateral abdomen, but is also seriously challenging to the deep core and rectus abdominis or "six-pack" muscles.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back with a barbell held above your chest in a locked position. 2. Rotate your hips and legs side to side while keeping the barbell stable above you.

Title: Prison Push-Up
Desc: The Prison Push-Up is a bodyweight exercise that targets multiple muscle groups, including the chest, triceps, and shoulders. It is performed without equipment, making it accessible for anyone.
HowTo: 1. Start in a push-up position with your hands shoulder-width apart. 2. Lower your body until your chest nearly touches the ground, then push back up to the starting position.

Title: McGill Modified Curl-Up
Desc: The McGill Modified Curl-Up is designed to strengthen the core while minimizing stress on the spine. It focuses on engaging the abdominal muscles without excessive flexion.
Muscles: Rectus Abdominis, Transverse Abdominis, Hip Flexors
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back with one knee bent and the other leg straight. 2. Place your hands under your lower back for support. 3. Engage your core and lift your head and shoulders off the ground while keeping one leg straight. 4. Hold for a moment before lowering back down.

Title: Cross-body toe-touch
Desc: The cross-body toe-touch is a version of the toe-touch stretch where instead of both hands reaching down toward both feet, one hand at a time reaches for the opposing foot. It's a common component in dynamic warm-ups for training or sports, but can also be performed for simple flexibility work anytime.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. 2. Lift your right leg and reach your left hand to touch your right foot. 3. Return to standing and repeat on the other side. 4. Continue alternating sides.

Title: Toy soldier
Desc: The toy soldier is a calisthenics exercise targeting the hip flexors and legs, which are kicked up one at a time. When each leg is at the top of the kick, the opposing hand touches that foot. It's a common warm-up exercise before athletics, but can also help raise core temperature and mobilize a wide range of muscles and joints prior to training.
HowTo: 1. Stand tall with your legs straight. 2. Kick your right leg up while reaching down with your left hand to touch your right foot. 3. Alternate legs and arms in a controlled manner. 4. Continue for a set duration or number of repetitions.

Title: Natural Glute Ham Raise with Stability Ball
Desc: The Natural Glute Ham Raise with Stability Ball is an exercise that targets the posterior chain, particularly the hamstrings and glutes. It requires stability and strength to perform correctly.
HowTo: 1. Kneel on the floor with your feet secured under a stability ball. 2. Slowly lower your upper body towards the ground while keeping your hips extended. 3. Engage your hamstrings and glutes to pull your body back up to the starting position. 4. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Lateral ape
Desc: The lateral ape is an exercise focused on the lower body that involves staying in a low squat position as you hop laterally. It can be performed as part of a dynamic warm-up, to improve hip mobility, or as part of a fat-loss or athleticism-focused circuit workout.
HowTo: 1. Start in a low squat position with your feet shoulder-width apart. 2. Push off with your feet and hop laterally to the right. 3. Land softly and immediately hop back to the left. 4. Continue alternating sides for a set duration or number of repetitions.

Title: Hollow-body knee tuck
Desc: The hollow-body knee tuck is a bodyweight abdominal exercise performed on the floor. It is similar to both the hollow-body hold and the knee tuck or reverse crunch, combining elements of both. It primarily targets the muscles of the rectus abdominis, or six-pack muscles. It can be performed for reps or time, either as part of an ab-focused workout or as a component of a circuit workout.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back with your arms extended overhead and legs straight. 2. Lift your shoulders and legs off the ground, creating a 'hollow' position. 3. Tuck your knees towards your chest while maintaining the hollow position. 4. Extend your legs back out and repeat.

Title: HM Air Jumping Rope
Desc: The HM Air Jumping Rope is a high-intensity cardio exercise that mimics the action of jumping rope without the equipment. It engages multiple muscle groups and improves cardiovascular endurance.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet together and arms at your sides. 2. Jump off the ground while swinging your arms in a circular motion as if you are turning a jump rope. 3. Land softly on the balls of your feet and repeat for the desired duration.

Title: HM Alternating Lunge Reach
Desc: The HM Alternating Lunge Reach is a lower-body exercise that targets the legs while also incorporating balance and flexibility. It involves lunging forward and reaching with the opposite arm.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet hip-width apart. 2. Step forward with your right leg into a lunge position, lowering your hips until both knees are bent at about a 90-degree angle. 3. Reach forward with your left arm towards your right foot. 4. Push back to the starting position and repeat on the other side.

Title: HM Alternating Side Plank Reach
Desc: The HM Alternating Side Plank Reach is a core stability exercise that targets the obliques and shoulders. It involves holding a side plank while reaching with the top arm.
HowTo: 1. Start in a side plank position with your elbow directly under your shoulder and feet stacked. 2. Extend your top arm straight up towards the ceiling. 3. Reach your top arm under your body while rotating your torso. 4. Return to the starting position and repeat on the other side.

Title: HM Superman Plank
Desc: The HM Superman Plank is a full-body exercise that engages the core, back, and glutes while improving stability. It combines a plank position with an extension of the arms and legs.
HowTo: 1. Start in a plank position with your hands under your shoulders and body in a straight line. 2. Extend your right arm forward and your left leg back simultaneously. 3. Hold for a moment, then return to the plank position. 4. Repeat on the opposite side.

Title: HM Table Pose
Desc: The HM Table Pose is a foundational exercise that helps improve core stability and flexibility. It engages the abdominal muscles while promoting proper alignment.
HowTo: 1. Start on all fours with your hands under your shoulders and knees under your hips. 2. Engage your core and maintain a neutral spine, holding the position for a set duration.

Title: HM Toe Touch
Desc: The HM Toe Touch is a simple stretch that targets the hamstrings and lower back. It promotes flexibility and helps alleviate tension in the posterior chain.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. 2. Bend at the hips and reach towards your toes, keeping your knees slightly bent if necessary. 3. Hold the stretch for a few seconds before returning to standing.

Title: HM Right Side Bird-Dog
Desc: The HM Right Side Bird-Dog is an effective exercise for improving balance and stability while engaging the core and back muscles. It helps enhance coordination and strength.
HowTo: 1. Start on all fours with your hands under your shoulders and knees under your hips. 2. Extend your right arm forward and your left leg back, keeping your body stable. 3. Hold for a moment, then return to the starting position and switch sides.

Title: HM Right Side Crunch
Desc: The HM Right Side Crunch targets the oblique muscles and helps strengthen the core. It is a great exercise for building abdominal strength and definition.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back with your knees bent and feet flat on the floor. 2. Place your right hand behind your head and lift your right shoulder towards your right knee, engaging your obliques. 3. Lower back down and repeat for the desired number of reps before switching sides.

Title: HM Bicycle
Desc: The HM Bicycle is a dynamic exercise that targets the entire core, including the obliques. It helps improve core strength and coordination.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back with your hands behind your head and legs lifted in a tabletop position. 2. Bring your right elbow towards your left knee while extending your right leg. 3. Switch sides in a pedaling motion, alternating between left and right.

Title: HM Bird-Dog Plank
Desc: The Bird-Dog Plank is an excellent exercise for improving core stability and balance. It engages multiple muscle groups while promoting coordination.
HowTo: 1. Start in a plank position with your hands directly under your shoulders and your body in a straight line. 2. Extend your right arm forward and your left leg back, keeping your hips level. 3. Hold for a moment, then return to the starting position and switch sides.

Title: HM Boat Pose
Desc: The Boat Pose is a yoga posture that strengthens the core and improves balance. It requires engagement of the abdominal muscles to maintain the position.
HowTo: 1. Sit on the floor with your knees bent and feet flat. 2. Lean back slightly and lift your feet off the ground, balancing on your sit bones. 3. Extend your arms forward and straighten your legs to form a 'V' shape with your body. 4. Hold the position while keeping your core engaged.

Title: HM Bottoms Up
Desc: Bottoms Up is a dynamic exercise that challenges your stability and strength. It engages the core and upper body while improving coordination.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and hold a kettlebell upside down by the handle. 2. Engage your core and press the kettlebell overhead while keeping it stable. 3. Lower the kettlebell back to the starting position and repeat.

Title: HM Bridge
Desc: The Bridge is a fundamental exercise that strengthens the glutes and lower back. It helps improve hip mobility and stability.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back with your knees bent and feet flat on the floor, hip-width apart. 2. Press through your heels and lift your hips towards the ceiling, squeezing your glutes at the top. 3. Hold for a moment, then lower your hips back to the ground.

Title: HM Running Man Crunch
Desc: The Running Man Crunch is a dynamic exercise that engages the core while mimicking a running motion. It helps improve cardiovascular fitness and core strength.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back with your knees bent and feet lifted off the ground. 2. Simultaneously bring your right elbow towards your left knee while extending your right leg. 3. Switch sides in a controlled manner, alternating the movement.

Title: HM Seated Twist
Desc: The HM Seated Twist is a great exercise for improving spinal mobility and stretching the obliques. It helps in enhancing core stability and flexibility.
HowTo: 1. Sit on the floor with your legs extended in front of you. 2. Bend one knee and place the foot on the outside of the opposite thigh. 3. Twist your torso towards the bent knee, using your opposite arm to deepen the stretch. 4. Hold for a few breaths and switch sides.

Title: HM Side-Bend Pose
Desc: The HM Side-Bend Pose focuses on lateral stretching and strengthening of the obliques. It enhances flexibility and core strength.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. 2. Raise one arm overhead and lean to the opposite side, feeling the stretch along your side. 3. Hold for a few breaths and switch sides.

Title: HM Side-Plank Arm Wrap
Desc: The HM Side-Plank Arm Wrap is an excellent exercise for building core strength and stability. It targets the obliques and improves balance.
HowTo: 1. Start in a side plank position with your elbow directly under your shoulder. 2. Extend your top arm towards the ceiling. 3. Reach your top arm under your body, wrapping it around your waist, then return to the starting position. 4. Repeat for several reps before switching sides.

Title: HM Side-Plank with Hip Touch
Desc: The HM Side-Plank with Hip Touch enhances core strength and stability while targeting the obliques. It is effective for improving balance and coordination.
HowTo: 1. Begin in a side plank position with your elbow under your shoulder. 2. Lower your hip towards the ground without touching it, then lift back to the starting position. 3. Repeat for several reps before switching sides.

Title: HM Side-Plank with Kick
Desc: The HM Side-Plank with Kick is a dynamic exercise that targets the obliques and improves core stability. It also engages the hip muscles for added strength.
HowTo: 1. Start in a side plank position with your elbow under your shoulder. 2. Lift your top leg and kick it forward while maintaining the side plank. 3. Return to the starting position and repeat for several reps before switching sides.

Title: HM Side V-Up
Desc: The HM Side V-Up is an effective exercise for targeting the obliques and improving core stability. It involves a lateral movement that engages the abdominal muscles.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your side with your legs stacked and extended. 2. Place your bottom arm under your head for support. 3. Engage your core and lift your legs and upper body simultaneously, reaching your top arm towards your feet. 4. Lower back down and repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: HM Crab Crunch
Desc: The HM Crab Crunch is a dynamic exercise that targets the core while also engaging the shoulders and legs. It combines a crunch with a bridge position for a full-body workout.
HowTo: 1. Start in a seated position with your hands behind you and feet flat on the ground. 2. Lift your hips off the ground into a bridge position. 3. Bring your knees towards your chest while crunching your torso forward. 4. Return to the starting position and repeat.

Title: HM Cross-Over Crunch
Desc: The HM Cross-Over Crunch is an effective exercise for targeting the upper and lower abs as well as the obliques. It involves a twisting motion that enhances core strength.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back with your knees bent and feet flat on the floor. 2. Place your hands behind your head. 3. Lift your shoulders off the ground and twist your torso to bring your elbow towards the opposite knee. 4. Alternate sides with each repetition.

Title: HM Crunch Pulse
Desc: The HM Crunch Pulse is a variation of the traditional crunch that focuses on the upper abs. It involves small, controlled movements to maximize muscle engagement.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back with your knees bent and feet flat on the floor. 2. Place your hands behind your head and lift your shoulders off the ground. 3. Perform small pulses by lifting your shoulders slightly higher without fully lowering back down. 4. Continue pulsing for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: HM Dead Bug
Desc: The HM Dead Bug is a core stabilization exercise that promotes coordination and control. It engages the entire core while minimizing strain on the lower back.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back with your arms extended towards the ceiling and knees bent at 90 degrees. 2. Slowly lower your right arm and left leg towards the floor while keeping your back flat. 3. Return to the starting position and repeat on the opposite side. 4. Continue alternating sides for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: HM Single-Leg Inchworm
Desc: The HM Single-Leg Inchworm is a dynamic stretch that focuses on improving flexibility and mobility in the legs. It engages the core while also enhancing balance and stability.
HowTo: 1. Stand on one leg and bend forward, reaching towards the ground with your hands. 2. Walk your hands forward into a plank position while keeping the standing leg straight. 3. Walk your hands back towards your feet and return to the starting position.

Title: HM Floor Jack
Desc: The HM Floor Jack is a high-intensity exercise that combines a jumping jack with a plank position. It elevates the heart rate while engaging multiple muscle groups.
HowTo: 1. Start in a plank position with your hands under your shoulders. 2. Jump your feet out to the sides like a jumping jack, then jump them back together. 3. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: HM Floor Wiper
Desc: The HM Floor Wiper is an effective core exercise that targets the abdominals and obliques. It helps improve core stability and strength.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back with your arms extended out to the sides for support. 2. Lift your legs to a 90-degree angle. 3. Lower your legs to one side while keeping your shoulders on the ground, then return to the center and repeat on the other side.

Title: HM Floor Kick
Desc: The HM Floor Kick is a lower body exercise that targets the glutes and legs. It helps improve strength and stability in the lower body.
HowTo: 1. Start on all fours with your hands under your shoulders and knees under your hips. 2. Extend one leg straight back, keeping it in line with your body. 3. Lift the leg towards the ceiling, then lower it back to the starting position. Repeat on the other leg.

Title: HM Sit-Up
Desc: The HM Sit-Up is a classic exercise that strengthens the abdominal muscles. It is essential for building core strength and improving overall stability.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back with your knees bent and feet flat on the floor. 2. Place your hands behind your head or crossed over your chest. 3. Engage your core and lift your upper body towards your knees, then lower back down.

Title: HM Slow Mountain Climber
Desc: The Slow Mountain Climber is a dynamic exercise that engages multiple muscle groups while improving cardiovascular endurance. It mimics the motion of climbing a mountain, making it effective for building strength and stamina.
HowTo: 1. Start in a high plank position with your hands under your shoulders. 2. Slowly bring one knee towards your chest while keeping the other leg extended. 3. Alternate legs in a controlled manner, maintaining a steady pace.

Title: HM Slow Sit-Up
Desc: The Slow Sit-Up is a core exercise that targets the abdominal muscles by promoting controlled movement. It helps build strength and stability in the core region.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back with your knees bent and feet flat on the floor. 2. Slowly lift your upper body towards your knees while engaging your core. 3. Lower back down with control and repeat.

Title: HM Half-Up
Desc: The Half-Up is an effective exercise for targeting the upper section of the abdominal muscles. It helps in building core strength and improving posture.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back with your knees bent and feet flat. 2. Engage your core and lift your upper body halfway up towards your knees. 3. Hold for a moment, then lower back down.

Title: HM Hollow-Body Pulse
Desc: The Hollow-Body Pulse is a challenging core exercise that focuses on maintaining a hollow position while pulsing the legs. It enhances core stability and strength.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back and lift your legs and shoulders off the ground, creating a 'hollow' position. 2. Pulse your legs up and down slightly while keeping your core engaged. 3. Hold the position and continue pulsing for the desired duration.

Title: HM Hollow Hold
Desc: The Hollow Hold is a core-strengthening exercise that requires maintaining a hollow position for stability. It effectively targets the abdominal muscles.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back and lift your legs and shoulders off the ground, keeping your lower back pressed into the floor. 2. Hold this position while keeping your arms extended alongside your ears. 3. Maintain the hold for the desired time, engaging your core throughout.

Title: HM Inchworm
Desc: The Inchworm is a dynamic stretch that helps improve flexibility and mobility throughout the body. It engages multiple muscle groups while also warming up the core and legs.
HowTo: 1. Stand tall with your feet hip-width apart. 2. Bend at the waist and place your hands on the ground. 3. Walk your hands forward to a plank position. 4. Hold for a moment, then walk your feet towards your hands. 5. Stand up and repeat.

Title: HM Right Side Hollow Hold with Pulse
Desc: The Right Side Hollow Hold with Pulse targets the core and oblique muscles, enhancing stability and strength. It is an effective isometric exercise that challenges your balance.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back and lift your legs off the ground, keeping them straight. 2. Raise your shoulders off the ground and twist to the right side. 3. Hold this position while pulsing your upper body up and down. 4. Keep your core engaged throughout the movement.

Title: HM Reverse Crunch with Frisbee
Desc: The Reverse Crunch with Frisbee is an engaging exercise that targets the lower abdominal muscles. It also helps improve coordination and control.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back with your arms at your sides and hold a frisbee above your head. 2. Lift your legs so your knees are bent at 90 degrees. 3. Engage your core and lift your hips off the ground while bringing your knees towards your chest. 4. Slowly lower back down and repeat.

Title: HM Left Side Bird-Dog
Desc: The Left Side Bird-Dog is a stability exercise that works multiple muscle groups while improving balance and coordination. It engages the core and promotes proper body alignment.
HowTo: 1. Start on all fours with your hands under your shoulders and knees under your hips. 2. Extend your left arm forward and your right leg back, keeping your body straight. 3. Hold for a moment, then return to the starting position. 4. Repeat on the opposite side.

Title: HM Left Side Crunch
Desc: The Left Side Crunch is an effective exercise for targeting the oblique muscles. It helps build strength and definition in the sides of the abdomen.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your left side with your legs stacked and your left arm extended out for support. 2. Place your right hand behind your head. 3. Engage your core and lift your upper body towards your hips. 4. Lower back down and repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: HM Left Side Hollow Hold With Pulse
Desc: The Left Side Hollow Hold with Pulse is an isometric core exercise that targets the abdominal muscles. It helps improve core stability and strength while engaging the obliques.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your left side with your legs extended and stacked. 2. Lift your legs and torso off the ground, keeping your core tight. 3. Pulse your legs up and down while maintaining the hold.

Title: HM Reverse Crunch
Desc: The Reverse Crunch is an effective exercise for targeting the lower abdominal muscles. It helps in building core strength and stability.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back with your knees bent and feet flat on the floor. 2. Lift your legs, bringing your knees towards your chest. 3. Curl your hips off the ground and squeeze your abs at the top before lowering back down.

Title: HM Low Lunge With External Twist And Arm Reach
Desc: The Low Lunge with External Twist and Arm Reach is a dynamic stretch that improves flexibility in the hips and spine. It also engages the core and enhances balance.
HowTo: 1. Start in a lunge position with your right foot forward and left knee on the ground. 2. Twist your torso to the right and reach your right arm up towards the ceiling. 3. Hold the position and breathe deeply before switching sides.

Title: HM Mountain Climber
Desc: The Mountain Climber is a high-intensity exercise that works multiple muscle groups while providing a cardiovascular workout. It helps improve agility and core strength.
HowTo: 1. Start in a plank position with your hands under your shoulders. 2. Drive your right knee towards your chest, then quickly switch legs. 3. Continue alternating legs at a fast pace.

Title: HM Prison Sit-Up
Desc: The Prison Sit-Up is a bodyweight exercise that targets the abdominal muscles effectively. It helps in building core strength and stability.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back with your hands behind your head and legs bent. 2. Engage your core and lift your upper body towards your knees. 3. Lower back down with control and repeat.

Title: HM Plank Alternating Hip-Dip
Desc: The HM Plank Alternating Hip-Dip is an effective core exercise that targets the abdominal muscles while enhancing stability. It involves alternating hip dips while maintaining a plank position.
HowTo: 1. Start in a plank position with your forearms on the ground. 2. Keep your body in a straight line from head to heels. 3. Slowly dip your right hip towards the ground, then return to the plank position. 4. Repeat on the left side. 5. Continue alternating sides for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: HM Tuck-Up Get-Up
Desc: The HM Tuck-Up Get-Up is a dynamic exercise that engages the core and improves overall body coordination. It combines a tuck-up motion with a get-up from a lying position.
HowTo: 1. Start lying on your back with your arms extended overhead. 2. Engage your core and simultaneously lift your legs and upper body, tucking your knees towards your chest. 3. Roll forward to a seated position. 4. Reverse the motion to return to the starting position. 5. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: HM Flutter Kick
Desc: The HM Flutter Kick is a core exercise that targets the lower abdominal muscles and improves core stability. It involves a fluttering motion of the legs while lying on your back.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back with your hands under your hips for support. 2. Lift your legs off the ground a few inches. 3. Alternate kicking your legs up and down in a fluttering motion while keeping your core engaged. 4. Continue for the desired duration.

Title: HM Plank
Desc: The HM Plank is a fundamental core exercise that strengthens the entire abdominal region and improves stability. It requires maintaining a plank position for a set duration.
HowTo: 1. Start in a forearm plank position with your elbows directly under your shoulders. 2. Keep your body in a straight line from head to heels. 3. Engage your core and hold the position for the desired duration. 4. Avoid sagging your hips or raising them too high.

Title: McGill Pull-Up
Desc: The McGill Pull-Up is a variation of the traditional pull-up that emphasizes back strength and muscle engagement. It targets the upper body while promoting good posture.
HowTo: 1. Hang from a pull-up bar with an overhand grip, hands shoulder-width apart. 2. Engage your core and pull your body up towards the bar, focusing on using your back muscles. 3. Lower yourself back down with control. 4. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: AM Leg Lift
Desc: The captain's chair leg raise is an exercise that targets the abs and hip flexors. It involves an apparatus that allows the forearms to rest on pads and the upright torso to hang freely. Unlike the Captains chair knee raise, the legs are straight here.
HowTo: 1. Position yourself on the captain's chair with your forearms resting on the pads. 2. Keep your legs straight and raise them until your body forms a straight line from your shoulders to your feet, then lower them back down.

Title: AM Decline Abs
Desc: The decline sit-up is a core exercise that works the iliopsoas, quads, hip flexors, and adductors. The rectus abdominis and obliques are the stabilizers in this movement.
Muscles: rectus abdominis, iliopsoas, quads, hip flexors, adductors
HowTo: 1. Lie on a decline bench with your feet secured. 2. With your hands behind your head, curl your torso up towards your knees, then lower back down.

Title: Hanging crunch
Desc: The hanging crunch an abdominal exercise that targets the rectus abdominis or "six-pack" muscles. It can be performed hanging from a bar, on a dip station or parallel bars, or if grip strength is a limitation, by placing the elbows in ab straps. If hanging from a straight bar is uncomfortable to the wrists or shoulders, you can also perform them hanging with a neutral grip (palms facing one another). It is similar to a hanging knee raise, but with more spinal curling and a more pronounced "crunch" at the top.
HowTo: 1. Hang from a pull-up bar or dip station with your arms fully extended. 2. Curl your knees or legs towards your chest while contracting your abs, then lower back to the starting position.

Title: Tyler Holt Hanging Toes-To-Bar
Desc: The Tyler Holt Hanging Toes-To-Bar is an exercise that targets the core and hip flexors. It involves hanging from a bar and raising your toes to touch the bar.
HowTo: 1. Hang from a pull-up bar with a grip slightly wider than shoulder-width. 2. Engage your core and lift your legs, bringing your toes up to touch the bar, then lower back down.

Title: Side plank
Desc: The side plank is a popular isometric abdominal exercise focusing on the oblique muscles, as well as the transversus abdominis or deep core muscles. It is sometimes paired with the curl up and bird dog as the McGill big three for core strength and stability. It is performed for time and can work in a warm-up or in the core-focused portion of any workout.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your side with your legs straight and stacked on top of each other. 2. Prop yourself up on your elbow, lift your hips off the ground, and hold your body in a straight line for the desired time.

Title: Bird dog-
Desc: The bird dog is a core exercise designed to help strengthen and stabilize the posterior chain. It involves lifting an opposite-side arm and leg while in a bent-leg tabletop position. It is most commonly performed as part of a dynamic warm-up, or for mobility and muscle activation anytime.
HowTo: 1. Start in a tabletop position on your hands and knees. 2. Engage your core and lift your right arm and left leg simultaneously, keeping your hips level. 3. Hold for a moment, then return to the starting position and switch sides.

Title: Single-leg curl up
Desc: The single-leg curl up is a bodyweight abdominal movement that teaches and reinforces abdominal bracing for strength training. It is usually performed along with variations of the bird dog and side plank as the McGill big three. The curl up can be performed for time or for reps, with or without pauses at the top position, as part of a warm-up or the core-focused component of any workout.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back with one knee bent and the other leg straight. 2. Place your hands under your lower back for support. 3. Engage your core and lift your head and shoulders off the ground while keeping the other leg straight. 4. Hold briefly, then lower back down.

Title: Single-kettlebell windmill
Desc: The single-kettlebell windmill is a dynamic kettlebell exercise emphasizing core strength and shoulder and hip mobility and stability. It is often used as a functional warm-up or for multi-directional strength work. It doesn't work as well in a metcon or conditioning setting, and shouldn't be performed under intense fatigue.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a kettlebell in one hand overhead. 2. Keep your arm straight and hinge at your hips, lowering your torso towards the ground while keeping your eyes on the kettlebell. 3. Return to the starting position by engaging your core and driving through your hips.

Title: UNS Foam Roll Thigh
Desc: The UNS Foam Roll Thigh exercise involves using a foam roller to release tension in the thigh muscles. It is commonly used for recovery and improving flexibility.
HowTo: 1. Sit on the floor and place the foam roller under your thigh. 2. Roll back and forth slowly, applying pressure to tight areas. 3. Adjust your body position to target different parts of the thigh.

Title: UNS Inverted row
Desc: The UNS Inverted Row is a bodyweight exercise that targets the upper back and biceps. It is effective for building strength in the pulling muscles.
HowTo: 1. Set a barbell on a squat rack or use TRX straps at waist height. 2. Lie underneath the bar and grasp it with an overhand grip. 3. Pull your chest towards the bar while keeping your body straight. 4. Lower back down with control.

Title: UNS T-spine rotation with reach
Desc: The T-spine rotation with reach helps improve thoracic spine mobility and shoulder flexibility. It is beneficial for maintaining good posture and reducing back tension.
HowTo: 1. Start in a seated or quadruped position. 2. Place one hand behind your head and rotate your upper body towards the opposite side while reaching your other arm forward. 3. Hold the stretch for a few seconds, then return to the starting position and repeat on the other side.

Title: UNS Quadruped thoracic rotation
Desc: The quadruped thoracic rotation is an excellent exercise for enhancing spinal mobility and improving shoulder function. It can help alleviate tension in the upper back and improve overall movement quality.
HowTo: 1. Start on all fours in a quadruped position. 2. Place one hand behind your head and rotate your upper body towards the ceiling while keeping your hips stable. 3. Return to the starting position and repeat on the other side.

Title: UNS Pec stretch
Desc: The pec stretch is designed to open up the chest and improve flexibility in the pectoral muscles. This exercise is particularly useful for those who spend long hours sitting or working at a desk.
HowTo: 1. Stand in a doorway or next to a wall. 2. Place your forearm against the wall or doorframe at a 90-degree angle. 3. Step forward gently until you feel a stretch in your chest. Hold for 15-30 seconds, then switch sides.

Title: UNS Lat stretch
Desc: The lat stretch helps to elongate the latissimus dorsi muscles and improve upper body flexibility. It is particularly beneficial for athletes and individuals who perform overhead movements.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. 2. Reach one arm overhead and lean to the opposite side until you feel a stretch along your side. 3. Hold for 15-30 seconds, then switch sides.

Title: UNS Foam Roll
Desc: Foam rolling is a self-myofascial release technique that helps to relieve muscle tightness and improve flexibility. It can be used on various muscle groups to enhance recovery and performance.
HowTo: 1. Choose a foam roller and sit on the floor with it under your target muscle group. 2. Roll slowly over the foam roller, pausing on tight spots for 20-30 seconds. 3. Continue rolling until you have covered the desired area.

Title: UNS Foam Roll Lats
Desc: The UNS Foam Roll Lats is a mobility exercise aimed at releasing tension in the lat muscles. It involves using a foam roller to massage the back and improve flexibility.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your side with the foam roller positioned under your armpit. 2. Slowly roll your body over the foam roller, moving from your armpit down to your hip. 3. Pause on any tight spots for a few seconds to release tension.

Title: UNS Rocking Adductor Stretch
Desc: The UNS Rocking Adductor Stretch is a mobility exercise that helps to stretch the inner thigh muscles. It promotes flexibility and prepares the legs for activity.
HowTo: 1. Start in a kneeling position with one leg extended out to the side. 2. Shift your weight towards the extended leg, rocking back and forth gently. 3. Hold the stretch for 20-30 seconds before switching sides.

Title: UNS Bird Dog
Desc: The UNS Bird Dog is a strength exercise that targets the core and improves balance and stability. It engages multiple muscle groups while promoting coordination.
HowTo: 1. Start on all fours with your hands under your shoulders and knees under your hips. 2. Extend your right arm forward and your left leg back simultaneously, keeping your body stable. 3. Hold for a moment, then return to the starting position and switch sides.

Title: UNS Jumping Jack
Desc: The UNS Jumping Jack is a cardio exercise that increases heart rate and improves overall fitness. It engages multiple muscle groups and is great for warm-ups.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet together and arms at your sides. 2. Jump up while spreading your legs shoulder-width apart and raising your arms overhead. 3. Jump back to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Ab wheel roll-out
Desc: The ab wheel roll-out is an exercise targeting the abdominals using an inexpensive wheel device with a handle on either side. Many trainers and strength coaches claim it's one of the best exercises for developing strength in the midsection. Beginners may have to start with a limited range of motion or just wheel planks.
HowTo: 1. Kneel on the floor and hold the ab wheel with both hands. 2. Roll the wheel forward while keeping your back straight and core engaged. 3. Roll out as far as you can while maintaining control, then pull back to the starting position.

Title: Bench mountain climber
Desc: The bench mountain climber is a bodyweight exercise that works the core, shoulders, and lower body while burning a lot of calories. Placing the hands on an elevated surface such as a bench decreases the challenge to the shoulders, allowing lifters to focus their work on the other body parts. Mountain climber variations are usually performed at a fast pace for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per leg or more.
HowTo: 1. Place your hands on a bench with your body in a plank position. 2. Drive one knee towards your chest while keeping the other leg extended, alternating legs at a fast pace.

Title: Feet-elevated bench side plank
Desc: The feet-elevated bench side plank is an advanced version of the side plank performed with the feet elevated on a bench. It targets the same muscles as the side plank, including the obliques, shoulders, and lateral hips, but the body angle makes it more difficult than side planks on the floor. Most lifters will need to progress to this version after mastering the basic side plank first.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your side with your feet elevated on a bench. 2. Lift your hips off the ground, keeping your body in a straight line, and hold the position.

Title: Cross-body sit-up
Desc: The cross-body sit-up is a bodyweight exercise targeting the ab muscles, the obliques and rectus abdominis or "six-pack" muscles in particular. It involves bringing the opposite-side knee and elbow together, usually alternating sides with each rep. It can be performed for time or reps as part of the ab-focused portion of any workout.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back with your knees bent. 2. Bring your opposite knee and elbow together while lifting your upper body off the ground, alternating sides.

Title: Decline kayak
Desc: The decline kayak is a core exercise targeting the obliques. It involves making a paddling motion on a decline bench with the feet anchored, using a bar or pipe for weight. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps, at least 8-12 reps per side, as part of the ab-focused portion of a workout or circuit.
HowTo: 1. Lie on a decline bench with your feet anchored. 2. Perform a paddling motion while keeping your core engaged, using a bar or pipe for added weight.

Title: 30 Decline Reverse Crunch
Desc: The decline reverse crunch is a core exercise targeting the lower abdominals.
HowTo: 1. Lie on a decline bench with your legs hanging off the end. 2. Curl your hips and knees towards your chest, engaging your lower abs, and then lower back down.

Title: Decline sit-up twist
Desc: The decline sit-up twist is a bodyweight core exercise that targets the obliques, as well as the rectus abdominis or "six pack" muscles. Sit-up variations are usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 10-15 reps per set or more, as part of the core-focused portion of a workout.
HowTo: 1. Lie on a decline bench with your feet secured. 2. Perform a sit-up while twisting your torso to one side, then return to the starting position and repeat on the other side.

Title: 30 Flat Bench Leg Raise
Desc: The lying leg lift is a popular bodyweight exercise targeting the muscles of the abs, the rectus abdominis or six-pack muscles in particular. It can be performed for time or reps in the core-focused portion of any workout.
HowTo: 1. Lie flat on your back with your legs straight. 2. Lift your legs towards the ceiling while keeping them straight, then lower them back down without touching the ground.

Title: 30 Flutter Kick
Desc: The flutter kick is a core exercise where the legs are held off the ground as you flutter your feet over and under each other in small motions. It targets multiple muscles of the core, but particularly the rectus abdominis or "six-pack" muscles. It can be performed for time or reps in the ab-focused portion of any workout.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back with your legs extended and hands under your hips. 2. Lift your legs slightly off the ground and alternate kicking them up and down in a fluttering motion.

Title: Chin-up crunch
Desc: The chin-up crunch is an exercise targeting the core and overall upper-body strength. It combines a chin-up with a knee raise or crunch to give extra emphasis to the core.
HowTo: 1. Hang from a pull-up bar with an underhand grip. 2. Pull yourself up while simultaneously bringing your knees towards your chest, then lower back down.

Title: 30 Gorilla Chin Oblique Crunch
Desc: The 30 Gorilla Chin Oblique Crunch is an exercise that targets the obliques and rectus abdominis through a dynamic movement.
HowTo: 1. Start in a chin-up position. 2. As you pull up, twist your body to one side and bring your knees towards your chest, then return to the starting position.

Title: Half Turkish get-up
Desc: The half Turkish get-up is a kettlebell movement that focuses on the first portion of the Turkish get-up exercise. It is often taught as a precursor to the full Turkish get-up, but is also a valuable abdominal and shoulder exercise in its own right. It can be performed for reps or time, either in lower rep ranges for strength or higher rep ranges for technique practice or conditioning.
HowTo: 1. Start lying on your back with one kettlebell in one hand, arm extended overhead. 2. Roll onto your side, prop yourself up on your elbow, and then push up onto your hand while keeping the kettlebell overhead.

Title: 30 Hanging Oblique Crunch
Desc: The hanging oblique crunch an abdominal exercise that targets both the rectus abdominus or six-pack muscles, and the oblique muscles. It can be performed hanging from a bar, or if grip strength is a limitation, by placing the elbows in ab straps. If hanging from a straight bar is uncomfortable to the wrists or shoulder, you can also perform them hanging with a neutral grip (palms facing one another)
HowTo: 1. Hang from a pull-up bar with your grip shoulder-width apart. 2. Engage your core and lift your knees towards your chest while keeping your upper body stable.

Title: 30 Hollow-Body Hold
Desc: The hollow-body hold is an isometric exercise that increases strength and stability in the core muscles. It is common in gymnastics training, CrossFit training, and as a core tension and bracing drill for lifters and athletes of all types. It is performed for time and can be performed as an activation drill prior to lifting, as part of a circuit, or as equipment-free core training anytime.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back and lift your arms and legs off the ground, creating a hollow position. 2. Hold this position by engaging your core and keeping your lower back pressed into the ground.

Title: Parallel bars knee raise
Desc: The parallel bars knee raise is a bodyweight exercise that targets the abs. It is performed on parallel bars, starting in the top position of a dip. Knee raises are often performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps or more, as part of ab-focused training.
HowTo: 1. Start in a dip position on parallel bars with your arms straight. 2. Bend your knees and raise them towards your chest while keeping your upper body stable.

Title: 30 Landmine Twist
Desc: The landmine twist is a rotational abdominal movement performed utilizing an angled barbell anchored at floor level in a landmine device. It can also be performed by sticking a barbell in the corner of a room, preferably in a towel to protect the walls. It targets the deep muscles of the core, including both the obliques and the transversus abdominus. It can be done fast or slow, for time or reps, either in traditional muscle-focused rep ranges such as 8-12 reps per side.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and hold the barbell with both hands at chest level. 2. Rotate your torso to one side, then return to the center and rotate to the other side, keeping your core engaged throughout.

Title: Parallel bars leg raise
Desc: The parallel bars leg raise is a bodyweight exercise that targets the abs. It is performed on parallel bars, starting in the top position of a dip. Leg raises are often performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps or more, as part of ab-focused training. However, this difficult variation may require some time to build up to those rep ranges.
HowTo: 1. Begin in the top position of a dip on parallel bars. 2. Raise your legs straight up while keeping your core engaged, then lower them back down.

Title: Otis-up-
Desc: The Otis-up is a weighted exercise focusing on the abdominal muscles and the shoulders to a lesser degree. It primarily targets the rectus abdominis or "six-pack" muscles, but also involves the obliques and deep core muscles. It is normally performed on a decline bench holding a weight plate, but can also be performed with a dumbbell, kettlebell, or other weight.
HowTo: 1. Lie on a decline bench holding a weight plate or dumbbell. 2. Perform a crunch by lifting your torso towards your knees while engaging your core.

Title: 30 Shoulder Tap
Desc: The shoulder tap is an exercise targeting the abdominals and core. The basic stance matches the top of a push-up position. From there, one hand is raised to tap its opposing shoulder. A tap with each hand to each opposing shoulder equals one rep.
HowTo: 1. Start in a push-up position with your body straight. 2. Lift one hand to tap the opposite shoulder, alternating sides.

Title: 30 Spider Crawl
Desc: The spider crawl is a bodyweight exercise that involves crawling on the floor with the knees outside of the elbows. It is different from a leopard crawl in that the hips are higher, and it's different from a bear crawl because the knees are wider. It can be done as a full-body warm-up, in short bursts for power or circuit training, or for longer durations as cardiovascular conditioning.
HowTo: 1. Start in a high plank position with your hands under your shoulders. 2. Crawl forward by moving your right hand and left foot simultaneously, then switch sides.

Title: Spider crunch
Desc: The spider crunch is a core exercise that begins in a straight-arm plank position and involves raising one knee toward your same-side elbow to target the obliques. It is similar to a mountain climber, but with the knees out wider. It can be performed for time or reps as bodyweight ab training or conditioning.
HowTo: 1. Begin in a straight-arm plank position. 2. Raise your right knee towards your right elbow, then return to plank and switch sides.

Title: Toe-touch
Desc: The toe-touch is a bodyweight movement that targets the muscles of the abs, the rectus abdominis or "six-pack" muscles in particular. It can be performed for time or reps in the ab-focused portion of any workout.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back with your legs extended and arms overhead. 2. Reach your hands towards your toes while lifting your upper body and legs off the ground, then return to the starting position.

Title: 30 Hanging Toes-To-Bar
Desc: The hanging toes-to-bar is an advanced abdominal exercise in which the lifter touches their feet to a pull-up bar. There are many ways to perform this movement: strict or swinging, arms completely straight or slightly bent, legs straight or bent, each providing unique benefits and challenges. Initially, it may be a difficult move to do for a single rep, but once you build the requisite core, lat, and shoulder strength, it can be performed for higher reps.
HowTo: 1. Hang from a pull-up bar with arms fully extended. 2. Engage your core and lift your legs to touch the bar with your toes, then lower back down.

Title: 30 V-Up
Desc: The V-up is a bodyweight movement that targets the muscles of the abs, the rectus abdominis or "six-pack" muscles in particular. It is similar to a suitcase crunch, but the lower back lifts off the ground at the top of each rep. It can be performed for time or reps in the ab-focused portion of any workout.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back with your legs extended and arms overhead. 2. Simultaneously lift your legs and upper body to form a 'V' shape, then lower back down.

Title: Cocoon crunch
Desc: The cocoon crunch is a bodyweight exercise targeting the ab muscles, the rectus abdominis or "six-pack" muscles in particular. It involves bringing your knees to your chest and your arms from overhead to center. It can be performed for time or reps as part of the ab-focused portion of any workout.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back with your arms extended overhead and knees bent. 2. Bring your knees to your chest while lifting your upper body towards your knees, then return to the starting position.

Title: Bench oblique crunch
Desc: The bench oblique crunch is an exercise that targets the obliques, the muscles running alongside the rectus abdominis. The range of motion is fairly small, but it still does a great job of working these hard-to-isolate muscles. Like most crunch variations, it is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more.
HowTo: 1. Lie on a bench with your feet secured and your back flat. 2. Crunch your upper body towards your knees while twisting to engage the obliques, then lower back down.

Title: Full moon-
Desc: The full moon is a bodyweight exercise targeting the muscles of the abs. It is similar to a V-up, but with the added challenge of drawing a circle shape in the air during each rep. It can be performed for time or reps in the core-focused portion of any workout.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back with your legs extended and arms overhead. 2. Lift your legs and upper body simultaneously, reaching your arms towards your feet while drawing a circle in the air. 3. Lower back down and repeat for the desired number of reps or time.

Title: Push-up to side plank
Desc: The push-up to side plank is an upper-body and core-focused exercise combining two popular bodyweight movements. It targets the chest, triceps, and shoulders with the push-up, and the obliques and hip external rotator muscles with the side plank. It can be performed as part of a dynamic warm-up or any bodyweight strength-training workout.
HowTo: 1. Start in a push-up position. 2. Perform a push-up. 3. After the push-up, rotate your body to the side into a side plank position, stacking your feet and raising your arm towards the ceiling. 4. Return to the push-up position and repeat.

Title: Tyler Holt V-Up
Desc: The Tyler Holt V-Up is a challenging core exercise that targets the abdominal muscles. It involves lifting both the upper and lower body simultaneously to form a 'V' shape.
HowTo: 1. Lie flat on your back with your arms extended overhead and legs straight. 2. Simultaneously lift your legs and upper body off the ground, reaching your hands towards your feet to form a 'V' shape. 3. Lower back down and repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Tyler Holt Plank
Desc: The Tyler Holt Plank is a stability exercise that focuses on strengthening the core muscles. It requires maintaining a plank position to engage the entire core.
HowTo: 1. Start in a forearm plank position with your elbows directly under your shoulders and your body in a straight line. 2. Engage your core and hold the position for as long as possible while maintaining proper form.

Title: Tyler Holt Hip-Dip
Desc: The Tyler Holt Hip-Dip is an exercise that targets the obliques and core stability. It involves lowering the hips towards the ground while in a side plank position.
HowTo: 1. Start in a side plank position with your elbow under your shoulder and your body in a straight line. 2. Lower your hips towards the ground and then lift them back up to the starting position. 3. Repeat for the desired number of reps before switching sides.

Title: Suicides
Desc: Suicides are a high-intensity cardio exercise that involves sprinting back and forth between markers. They improve agility, speed, and cardiovascular endurance.
HowTo: 1. Set up two markers about 10-20 yards apart. 2. Start at one marker and sprint to the other. 3. Touch the ground at the far marker and sprint back. 4. Repeat for multiple rounds.

Title: Holman Towel Straight Plank Jack
Desc: The Holman Towel Straight Plank Jack is a core exercise that engages the entire body while focusing on stability. It helps build strength in the core and shoulders.
HowTo: 1. Start in a plank position with a towel under your feet. 2. Jump your feet out to the sides and then back together while maintaining a plank. 3. Keep your core tight and back straight throughout the movement.

Title: Holman Towel Hill Climber
Desc: The Holman Towel Hill Climber is a dynamic exercise that targets the core and improves cardiovascular fitness. It mimics a climbing motion while engaging multiple muscle groups.
HowTo: 1. Start in a plank position with a towel under your feet. 2. Drive one knee towards your chest while keeping the other leg extended. 3. Alternate legs quickly, simulating a running motion.

Title: Holman Towel Elbow Plank Jack
Desc: The Holman Towel Elbow Plank Jack is a variation of the plank that incorporates movement to increase difficulty. It strengthens the core while also engaging the shoulders.
HowTo: 1. Start in an elbow plank position with a towel under your feet. 2. Jump your feet out to the sides and back together while maintaining the plank. 3. Keep your elbows under your shoulders and core tight.

Title: Holman Towel Elbow Plank Pike
Desc: The Holman Towel Elbow Plank Pike is an advanced core exercise that challenges stability and strength. It engages the entire core and improves overall body control.
HowTo: 1. Start in an elbow plank position with a towel under your feet. 2. Lift your hips towards the ceiling, bringing your feet towards your hands. 3. Return to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Holman Towel Straight Plank Hand Reach
Desc: The Holman Towel Straight Plank Hand Reach is an isometric exercise that engages the core while improving stability and balance. It challenges your abdominal muscles and enhances overall body control.
HowTo: 1. Start in a plank position with your forearms on the ground and your body in a straight line. 2. Reach one arm forward while maintaining a stable core, then return to the starting position. 3. Alternate arms for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Holman Towel Wax-On Wax-Off
Desc: The Holman Towel Wax-On Wax-Off exercise focuses on shoulder mobility and flexibility. It helps in improving the range of motion and strengthening the shoulder muscles.
HowTo: 1. Stand or sit with a towel in both hands. 2. Move your arms in a circular motion as if waxing a car, alternating directions. 3. Keep your core engaged and maintain a steady posture throughout the movement.

Title: Holman Towel Wide Hill Climber
Desc: The Holman Towel Wide Hill Climber is a dynamic exercise that elevates your heart rate while engaging multiple muscle groups. It combines cardio with strength training to enhance endurance and core stability.
HowTo: 1. Start in a high plank position with your hands on the ground and feet together. 2. Quickly bring one knee towards your chest, then switch legs in a running motion. 3. Continue alternating legs at a fast pace for the desired duration.

Title: Holman Towel Dirty Dog
Desc: The Holman Towel Dirty Dog is an effective exercise for targeting the glutes and improving hip stability. It also engages the core muscles for better overall strength.
HowTo: 1. Start on all fours with your hands under your shoulders and knees under your hips. 2. Keeping your knee bent, lift one leg out to the side, squeezing your glutes at the top. 3. Lower back down and repeat for the desired number of repetitions before switching sides.

Title: Holman Straight Plank Shoulder Tap
Desc: The Holman Straight Plank Shoulder Tap is a core stabilization exercise that also targets the shoulders and triceps. It helps improve balance and coordination while strengthening the upper body.
HowTo: 1. Begin in a high plank position with your body in a straight line. 2. Lift one hand to tap the opposite shoulder while keeping your hips stable. 3. Alternate sides for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Holman Killer Abs
Desc: The Holman Killer Abs exercise focuses on strengthening the core muscles, particularly the abdominals. It involves various movements that engage the core for stability and strength.
HowTo: 1. Start in a lying position with your legs extended. 2. Engage your core and lift your upper body while keeping your legs on the ground. 3. Hold the position for a few seconds and lower back down. 4. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Holman Straight Plank Split Jack
Desc: The Holman Straight Plank Split Jack is an exercise that targets the core while also incorporating a dynamic movement. It helps improve core stability and coordination.
HowTo: 1. Start in a plank position with your hands under your shoulders. 2. Jump your feet out to the sides and back together while maintaining the plank position. 3. Keep your core engaged throughout the movement. 4. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Holman Elbow Plank Swim
Desc: The Holman Elbow Plank Swim is designed to enhance core strength and stability while also working the shoulders. This exercise mimics a swimming motion while in a plank position.
HowTo: 1. Begin in an elbow plank position with your body in a straight line. 2. Alternate lifting your arms in a swimming motion while keeping your hips stable. 3. Focus on engaging your core and maintaining balance. 4. Continue for the desired duration.

Title: Holman Elbow Plank Saw
Desc: The Holman Elbow Plank Saw is a challenging exercise that targets the core and shoulders. It involves a sawing motion that enhances stability and strength.
HowTo: 1. Start in an elbow plank position with your body straight. 2. Shift your body forward and backward in a sawing motion. 3. Keep your core tight and avoid sagging your hips. 4. Perform for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Holman Feet-Elevated Straight Plank Toe-Tap Series
Desc: The Holman Feet-Elevated Straight Plank Toe-Tap Series is an advanced exercise that challenges the core and shoulder stability. Elevating the feet increases the difficulty of the plank position.
HowTo: 1. Begin in a straight plank position with your feet elevated on a surface. 2. Alternate tapping your toes out to the sides while maintaining the plank. 3. Keep your body straight and core engaged throughout. 4. Continue for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Holman Elbow Plank Pike Pull
Desc: The Holman Elbow Plank Pike Pull is an effective core exercise that engages the abdominal muscles while improving stability. It combines a plank position with a pike movement to enhance strength and coordination.
HowTo: 1. Start in an elbow plank position with your body in a straight line. 2. Engage your core and lift your hips towards the ceiling, forming a pike position. 3. Return to the plank position and repeat.

Title: Holman Hand-Elevated Walk-Over Push-Up
Desc: The Holman Hand-Elevated Walk-Over Push-Up is a variation of the traditional push-up that targets the chest and triceps while incorporating stability and balance. Elevating the hands increases the range of motion and engages the core.
HowTo: 1. Place your hands on an elevated surface and get into a push-up position. 2. Lower your body towards the surface while keeping your elbows close to your body. 3. Push back up to the starting position and repeat, alternating sides.

Title: Holman Hands-Elevated Hill Climber
Desc: The Holman Hands-Elevated Hill Climber is a dynamic exercise that combines cardio with core strengthening. It mimics a climbing motion, engaging multiple muscle groups while elevating the heart rate.
HowTo: 1. Start in a plank position with your hands on an elevated surface. 2. Drive one knee towards your chest while keeping the other leg extended. 3. Alternate legs quickly, simulating a climbing motion.

Title: Holman Seated Pike
Desc: The Holman Seated Pike is a flexibility exercise that stretches the hamstrings and hip flexors while promoting overall mobility. It helps improve range of motion in the hips and lower back.
HowTo: 1. Sit on the floor with your legs extended in front of you. 2. Reach forward towards your toes while keeping your back straight. 3. Hold the stretch for a few seconds, then relax and repeat.

Title: Holman Feet-Elevated Up-Down Plank
Desc: The Holman Feet-Elevated Up-Down Plank is a challenging core exercise that enhances stability and strength in the abdominal region. Elevating the feet increases the difficulty and engages the shoulders as well.
HowTo: 1. Start in a plank position with your feet elevated on a surface. 2. Lower your body to your elbows one at a time, then push back up to your hands. 3. Alternate the leading arm and repeat.

Title: Holman Feet-Elevated Hand Tap
Desc: The Holman Feet-Elevated Hand Tap is an exercise that engages multiple muscle groups while improving stability and coordination. It primarily targets the core and shoulders while also working the legs.
HowTo: 1. Start in a plank position with your feet elevated on a bench or step. 2. Tap your right hand to your left shoulder while maintaining your balance. 3. Return your hand to the floor and repeat with the left hand to the right shoulder. 4. Continue alternating sides for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Holman Reverse Straight Plank with Alternating Heel Pull-In
Desc: The Holman Reverse Straight Plank with Alternating Heel Pull-In targets the core and glutes while enhancing stability. It is an effective exercise for building strength in the posterior chain.
HowTo: 1. Begin in a reverse plank position with your body straight and your hands behind you. 2. Pull your right heel towards your glutes while keeping your hips elevated. 3. Return to the starting position and repeat with the left heel. 4. Continue alternating for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Holman Elbow Plank
Desc: The Holman Elbow Plank is a foundational core exercise that strengthens the abdominal muscles and improves overall stability. It is essential for building a strong core.
HowTo: 1. Start in an elbow plank position with your forearms on the ground and your body in a straight line. 2. Engage your core and hold the position for the desired duration. 3. Ensure your hips are not sagging or elevated.

Title: Holman Straight Plank Squat Thrust
Desc: The Holman Straight Plank Squat Thrust combines a plank with a squat thrust to engage multiple muscle groups. It is great for building strength and endurance.
HowTo: 1. Begin in a plank position with your hands under your shoulders. 2. Jump your feet towards your hands into a squat position. 3. Jump back to the plank position. 4. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Holman Alternating Single-Leg Pike
Desc: The Holman Alternating Single-Leg Pike is an advanced exercise that targets the core and improves balance. It also engages the hamstrings and glutes.
HowTo: 1. Start in a plank position with your body straight. 2. Lift your right leg towards the ceiling while piking your hips up. 3. Return to the plank position and repeat with the left leg. 4. Continue alternating legs for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Holman Knee Pull-In Crunch
Desc: The Holman Knee Pull-In Crunch targets the core muscles, specifically the abdominals. It helps improve core strength and stability.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back with your knees bent and feet flat on the floor. 2. Engage your core and pull your knees towards your chest while lifting your shoulders off the ground. 3. Hold for a moment, then lower back to the starting position.

Title: Holman Straight Plank with Hand Tap
Desc: The Holman Straight Plank with Hand Tap is an effective exercise for building core stability and shoulder strength. It challenges your balance while engaging multiple muscle groups.
HowTo: 1. Start in a plank position with your hands directly under your shoulders. 2. While maintaining a straight line from head to heels, lift one hand off the ground to tap the opposite shoulder. 3. Alternate sides while keeping your core engaged.

Title: Holman Straight Plank with Dirty Dog
Desc: The Holman Straight Plank with Dirty Dog is a dynamic exercise that targets the core and glutes while enhancing shoulder stability. It also improves overall body coordination.
HowTo: 1. Begin in a plank position with your hands under your shoulders. 2. Lift one leg and bend the knee, bringing it towards your side while maintaining the plank position. 3. Return to the starting position and repeat on the other side.

Title: Holman Elbow Plank Roll
Desc: The Holman Elbow Plank Roll is a challenging exercise that works the core and shoulders. It enhances stability and strength through rotational movement.
HowTo: 1. Start in an elbow plank position with your body in a straight line. 2. Rotate your body to one side, extending your arm towards the ceiling. 3. Return to the plank position and repeat on the other side.

Title: Holman Froggy Push-Up
Desc: The Holman Froggy Push-Up is a variation of the traditional push-up that targets the chest and triceps while engaging the core. It adds a unique challenge to your upper body workout.
HowTo: 1. Start in a push-up position with your feet wider than shoulder-width apart. 2. Lower your body towards the ground while keeping your elbows close to your sides. 3. Push back up to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Holman Straight Plank Hand Tap to Shoulder Tap
Desc: The Holman Straight Plank Hand Tap to Shoulder Tap is an effective core stability exercise that challenges your balance and engages multiple muscle groups. This exercise helps improve core strength and shoulder stability.
HowTo: 1. Start in a straight plank position with your hands directly under your shoulders. 2. Engage your core and lift your right hand to tap your left shoulder. 3. Return your hand to the ground and repeat with the left hand tapping the right shoulder. 4. Keep your hips stable and avoid rotating your body.

Title: Holman In-Out Straight Plank
Desc: The Holman In-Out Straight Plank is a dynamic exercise that targets the core while also improving coordination and stability. It involves moving in and out of a plank position, engaging various muscle groups.
HowTo: 1. Begin in a straight plank position with your feet together. 2. Jump your feet out wider than shoulder-width apart. 3. Jump your feet back together to the starting position. 4. Maintain a strong plank position throughout the movement.

Title: Holman Bicycle
Desc: The Holman Bicycle is a core exercise that focuses on the abdominal muscles and improves rotational strength. It mimics the motion of pedaling a bicycle while lying on your back.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back with your hands behind your head and legs raised at a 90-degree angle. 2. Bring your right elbow towards your left knee while extending your right leg. 3. Switch sides, bringing your left elbow to your right knee. 4. Continue alternating sides in a controlled manner.

Title: Holman Alternating Diagonal Knee Pull-in
Desc: The Holman Alternating Diagonal Knee Pull-in is a core exercise that enhances stability and engages the lower body. It focuses on pulling the knees towards the chest while maintaining a plank position.
HowTo: 1. Start in a plank position with your hands under your shoulders. 2. Bring your right knee towards your left elbow in a diagonal motion. 3. Return to the plank position and repeat with your left knee towards your right elbow. 4. Keep your core engaged and hips stable throughout the exercise.

Title: Holman Elbow Plank with Step-Out
Desc: The Holman Elbow Plank with Step-Out is a challenging exercise that targets the core and improves shoulder stability. It involves stepping out from a plank position to engage the muscles effectively.
HowTo: 1. Begin in an elbow plank position with your forearms on the ground. 2. Step your right foot out to the side, followed by your left foot. 3. Step back to the starting position one foot at a time. 4. Keep your core tight and maintain a straight line from head to heels.

Title: Holman Alternating Slow L-Raise
Desc: The Holman Alternating Slow L-Raise focuses on shoulder stability and strength. It involves lifting weights slowly to enhance muscle control and endurance.
HowTo: 1. Stand with a dumbbell in each hand at your sides. 2. Raise one arm out to the side slowly while keeping the other arm down. 3. Lower the raised arm and repeat with the other arm. 4. Continue alternating arms for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Holman Feet-Elevated Plank with Shoulder Tap
Desc: The Holman Feet-Elevated Plank with Shoulder Tap engages the core and improves stability. It combines a plank position with shoulder taps to challenge balance and strength.
HowTo: 1. Start in a plank position with your feet elevated on a bench. 2. Keep your body straight and engage your core. 3. Lift one hand to tap the opposite shoulder, then return it to the ground. 4. Alternate sides for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Holman Feet-Elevated Inchworm Pike to Straight Plank Push-Up
Desc: The Holman Feet-Elevated Inchworm Pike to Straight Plank Push-Up is a full-body exercise that enhances strength and flexibility. It combines an inchworm movement with a push-up to target multiple muscle groups.
HowTo: 1. Start standing, then bend at the waist to place your hands on the ground. 2. Walk your hands forward to a plank position. 3. Perform a push-up. 4. Walk your hands back towards your feet and return to standing. 5. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Holman Feet-Elevated Up-Down Elbow Plank
Desc: The Holman Feet-Elevated Up-Down Elbow Plank targets the core and shoulder stability. It involves transitioning between a plank on your hands and elbows.
HowTo: 1. Start in a high plank position with your feet elevated. 2. Lower one elbow to the ground, then the other, to get into an elbow plank. 3. Push back up to a high plank one hand at a time. 4. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Holman Feet-Elevated Plank Pike Pull
Desc: The Holman Feet-Elevated Plank Pike Pull is an advanced core exercise that challenges stability and strength. It requires pulling the hips up while maintaining a plank position.
HowTo: 1. Begin in a plank position with your feet elevated. 2. Engage your core and lift your hips towards the ceiling, forming a pike position. 3. Return to the plank position. 4. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Holman Feet-Elevated Alternating Single-Leg Hip Raise
