HowTo: 1. Lie on a decline bench with your feet secured. 2. Place your hands behind your head. 3. Engage your core and lift your upper body towards your knees, twisting to one side to target the obliques. 4. Lower back down and repeat on the other side.

Title: Decline sit-up
Desc: The decline sit-up is a bodyweight core exercise that works the rectus abdominis or "six pack" muscles. Sit-up variations are usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 10-15 reps per set or more, as part of the core-focused portion of a workout.
HowTo: 1. Lie on a decline bench with your feet secured. 2. Cross your arms over your chest or place your hands behind your head. 3. Engage your core and lift your upper body towards your knees. 4. Lower back down and repeat.

Title: Hanging Windshield Wiper
Desc: The hanging windshield wiper is an advanced abdominal training exercise that is also extremely challenging to other muscles of the upper body, including the lats (latissimus dorsi), biceps, and grip. It requiresand buildsgreat strength in the rectus abdominis or "six-pack" muscles, as well as the obliques and deep core muscles. If you can't perform it hanging from a bar, the lying windshield wiper on the floor provides some of the same benefits.
HowTo: 1. Hang from a pull-up bar with your arms fully extended. 2. Engage your core and lift your legs towards the bar. 3. Rotate your legs to one side, then to the other, mimicking a windshield wiper motion. 4. Keep your movements controlled and repeat.

Title: Exercise Ball Pull-In
Desc: The exercise ball knee roll-in is an abdominal exercise that involves supporting yourself with your hands in a plank or push-up position and drawing the knees in toward the chest. This is a fairly advanced abdominal move requiring core strength.
HowTo: 1. Start in a plank position with your hands on the floor and your feet on an exercise ball. 2. Draw your knees toward your chest while keeping your core engaged, then roll back to the starting position.

Title: Exercise ball crunch
Desc: The exercise ball crunch is a popular gym exercise targeting the abdominals. Unlike crunches on the floor or a bench, by using a ball you can increase the range of motion and both stretch and contract the abs on every rep. The ball crunch can be performed for low reps with a slower tempo focusing on a hard contraction, or for higher reps.
HowTo: 1. Sit on an exercise ball with your feet flat on the floor. 2. Lean back slightly, then contract your abs to lift your upper body off the ball, and return to the starting position.

Title: Feet-elevated crunch
Desc: The feet-elevated crunch is a variation on the basic crunch, a very popular ab move. Resting the feet on a bench takes some of the hip flexor activation out of the movement, focusing the stress more on the abs. It may have a small range of motion, but this movement produces a major burn.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back with your feet elevated on a bench. 2. Contract your abs to lift your shoulders off the ground, then lower back down.

Title: Weighted Ball Side Bend
Desc: The weighted ball side bend is an exercise that targets the obliques and helps in strengthening the sides of your abdomen. It involves bending sideways while holding a weight, which increases resistance and effectiveness.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart while holding a weight in one hand. 2. Slowly bend to the side, bringing the weight down toward your knee, then return to the starting position.

Title: Swiss Ball Ab Roll-Out
Desc: The exercise ball roll-out is an exercise that strengthens the core, shoulders and upper- back muscles. It starts in a plank-style position, with the arms resting on a ball. Then, you roll the ball out in front of you as far as you can while maintaining a strong, neutral spinal position. The lack of stability from the ball increases the degree of difficulty. This is a difficult movement, and beginners may need to use a limited range of motion.
HowTo: 1. Start in a plank position with your arms resting on an exercise ball. 2. Roll the ball out in front of you while maintaining a neutral spine, then roll it back to the starting position.

Title: Exercise Ball Cable Crunch - Gethin Variation
Desc: The exercise ball crunch is a popular gym exercise targeting the abdominals. Unlike crunches on the floor or a bench, by using a ball, you can increase the range of motion and both stretch and contract the abs on every rep. The ball crunch can be performed for low reps with a slower tempo, focusing on a hard contraction, or for higher reps.
HowTo: 1. Sit on an exercise ball with your feet flat on the floor. 2. Lean back slightly, allowing your lower back to rest on the ball. 3. Contract your abs and lift your torso towards your knees. 4. Lower back down and repeat.

Title: Exercise ball squat and twist
Desc: The exercise ball squat and twist is a combination exercise targeting the quads, but also the obliques because of the twisting motion with each repetition. The exercise ball is held close to the chest throughout. Because it is a lightweight movement, it is usually performed for high reps or for time, and can be a great part of a bodyweight and exercise ball circuit.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding an exercise ball at chest level. 2. Perform a squat by bending your knees and lowering your hips. 3. As you rise, twist your torso to one side. 4. Repeat for the desired number of reps, alternating sides.

Title: Swiss Ball V-Up With Foot Pass
Desc: The exercise ball V-up is a popular movement to target the abdominal muscles, particularly the rectus abdominis or "six-pack" muscles. It involves passing an exercise ball or yoga ball back and forth between the hands and feet while performing V-ups. It can be performed for reps or time as part of any ab-focused workout or bodyweight circuit.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back with the exercise ball between your feet. 2. Lift your legs and upper body off the ground, reaching for the ball with your hands. 3. Pass the ball from your feet to your hands. 4. Lower back down and repeat.

Title: Exercise ball pike
Desc: The exercise ball pike is a challenging move that targets the core. It involves thrusting the hips into full flexion over a ball, then extending out to a foot-elevated plank with the feet on the ball. It's a challenging move from a strength perspective, but also for balance. It can be the centerpiece of an ab workout or go along with other body weight or ball movements in an ab circuit.
HowTo: 1. Start in a plank position with your feet on an exercise ball. 2. Engage your core and lift your hips towards the ceiling, rolling the ball towards your hands. 3. Lower back to the plank position and repeat.

Title: Exercise ball bird dog
Desc: The exercise ball bird dog is a dynamic movement focusing on the glutes and the postural muscles of the upper back. When performing it, use an exercise ball that is tall enough to support your chest and core, but short enough to allow your hands and knees to reach the ground. It is slightly easier than a bodyweight bird dog and can work as a regression for that movement. It can be done for time or reps as part of a warm-up, paired with movements in a workout, or as a mobility or recovery exercise.
HowTo: 1. Start on your hands and knees with your chest supported on an exercise ball. 2. Extend one arm forward and the opposite leg back. 3. Hold for a moment, then return to the starting position. 4. Alternate sides and repeat.

Title: Exercise ball superman
Desc: The exercise ball superman is a slightly more advanced variation of the bodyweight superman exercise. It targets many muscles along the posterior or backside of the body, including the rear deltoids, trapezius, spinal erectors, glutes, and hamstrings. It can be done for time or reps as part of a warm-up, paired with movements in a workout, or as a mobility or recovery exercise.
Muscles: rear deltoids, trapezius, spinal erectors, glutes, hamstrings
HowTo: 1. Lie face down on an exercise ball with your feet anchored on the ground. 2. Extend your arms and legs, lifting them off the ground simultaneously while engaging your back muscles.

Title: BOSU cross-body crunch
Desc: The BOSU cross-body crunch is a dynamic abdominal exercise performed on a BOSU ball or other stability training device. It targets several of the muscles in the core, including the obliques and the rectus abdominis or "six-pack" muscles. It is usually performed in alternating reps, either for time or a number of reps, as part of an ab-focused workout or a circuit involving body weight or the BOSU ball.
HowTo: 1. Sit on a BOSU ball with your feet flat on the ground. 2. Lean back slightly and perform a crunch by bringing your torso towards your knees, alternating sides to engage the obliques.

Title: Exercise Ball Knee Tuck - Gethin Varation
Desc: The exercise ball knee roll-in is an abdominal exercise that involves supporting yourself with your hands in a plank or push-up position and drawing the knees in toward the chest. This is a fairly advanced abdominal move requiring core strength.
HowTo: 1. Start in a plank position with your hands on the ground and your feet on an exercise ball. 2. Draw your knees towards your chest, engaging your core, then return to the starting position.

Title: Alternating Exercise Ball Knee Tucks - Gethin Variation
Desc: The exercise ball knee roll-in is an abdominal exercise that involves supporting yourself with your hands in a plank or push-up position and drawing the knees in toward the chest. This is a fairly advanced abdominal move requiring core strength.
HowTo: 1. Begin in a plank position with your hands on the ground and your feet on an exercise ball. 2. Alternate drawing each knee towards your chest while maintaining a stable upper body.

Title: AM Ball Crunch
Desc: The exercise ball crunch is a popular gym exercise targeting the abdominals. Unlike crunches on the floor or a bench, by using a ball, you can increase the range of motion and both stretch and contract the abs on every rep. The ball crunch can be performed for low reps with a slower tempo, focusing on a hard contraction, or for higher reps.
HowTo: 1. Sit on an exercise ball with your feet flat on the ground. 2. Lean back slightly and perform a crunch by contracting your abs and lifting your torso towards your knees.

Title: 30 Bosu Cable Reverse Crunch
Desc: The 30 Bosu Cable Reverse Crunch is designed to target the core muscles, particularly the abs. It involves using a BOSU ball to enhance stability and engagement during the crunch.
HowTo: 1. Lie on a BOSU ball with your back supported and feet on the ground. 2. Hold a cable or resistance band above your head. 3. Engage your core and lift your legs towards your chest while pulling the cable down, then lower back down.

Title: BOSU knee tuck
Desc: The BOSU knee tuck is a dynamic abdominal movement performed on a BOSU ball or other stability training device. It primarily targets the rectus abdominis or "six-pack" muscles of the core. It can be performed for time or reps as part of an ab-focused workout or a circuit involving body weight or the BOSU ball.
HowTo: 1. Start in a plank position with your feet on the BOSU ball. 2. Tuck your knees towards your chest while keeping your core engaged. 3. Extend your legs back to the starting position and repeat.

Title: 30 Side Plank On Ball
Desc: The feet-elevated side plank on ball is a more advanced version of a traditional bodyweight side plank. The feet are balanced on an exercise ball, providing a balance challenge but also increasing the load placed upon the obliques and shoulder muscles. It is usually performed for timed holds, either one side at a time or alternating sides. If a ball is unavailable, some of the benefits of the movement can be obtained by performing side planks with the feet elevated on a couch, chair, bench, or other stable object.
HowTo: 1. Place your feet on an exercise ball and lie on your side. 2. Prop yourself up on your forearm, keeping your body in a straight line. 3. Hold the position for a set time, then switch sides.

Title: Hanging exercise ball leg raise
Desc: The hanging exercise ball leg raise is an exercise targeting the abs and hip flexors. Instead of resting the forearms on the pads of an apparatus, it's performed hanging from a bar with an exercise ball held between the legs.
HowTo: 1. Hang from a pull-up bar with an exercise ball held between your legs. 2. Engage your core and lift the ball towards your chest while raising your legs. 3. Lower back down and repeat.

Title: Taylor Exercise Ball Stir-The-Pot
Desc: The Taylor Exercise Ball Stir-The-Pot is a core exercise that also engages the shoulders. It involves circular movements to challenge stability and strength.
HowTo: 1. Start in a plank position with your forearms on an exercise ball. 2. Move your forearms in a circular motion, stirring the ball while keeping your body straight. 3. Alternate directions after a set time.

Title: FYR2 Air Ball
Desc: The FYR2 Air Ball is a stability exercise that engages multiple muscle groups while improving balance and coordination. It is often used in warm-up routines or as part of a functional training program.
HowTo: 1. Start by sitting on the air ball with your feet flat on the floor. 2. Slowly walk your feet forward, rolling the ball under your body until your back is supported by the ball. 3. Engage your core and hold the position, maintaining balance.

Title: Feet-elevated plank on ball
Desc: The feet-elevated plank is a variation on the straight-arm plank, a bodyweight standard. The feet are elevated on a ball to align the body parallel to the floor and provide a greater stabilization challenge. This makes it more difficult than straight-arm planks on the floor, but also puts more emphasis on the shoulder muscles. It is often used as a shoulder and core warm-up, or as a burnout movement for a chest or shoulder workout.
HowTo: 1. Start in a plank position with your hands on the floor and your feet elevated on a stability ball. 2. Keep your body in a straight line from head to heels. 3. Hold the position, engaging your core and shoulders.

Title: Band Hip Adductions
Desc: Band Hip Adductions are effective for targeting the inner thigh muscles and improving hip stability. This exercise is often included in lower body workouts to enhance strength and balance.
HowTo: 1. Stand with a resistance band around your ankles. 2. Shift your weight to one leg and lift the other leg out to the side, keeping it straight. 3. Return to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Lateral Band Walk
Desc: Lateral Band Walks are designed to strengthen the hip abductors and improve lateral movement. This exercise is commonly used in rehabilitation and strength training programs.
HowTo: 1. Place a resistance band around your thighs, just above your knees. 2. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and squat slightly. 3. Step sideways with one foot, then bring the other foot to meet it, maintaining tension in the band.

Title: FYR2 Standing Banded Leg Abduction
Desc: The FYR2 Standing Banded Leg Abduction is a targeted exercise for the glutes and outer thighs. It helps improve hip strength and stability, making it beneficial for various athletic activities.
HowTo: 1. Stand with a resistance band around your ankles. 2. Shift your weight to one leg and lift the other leg straight out to the side. 3. Lower the leg back down and repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Iliotibial band SMR
Desc: Iliotibial band self-myofascial release (SMR) is a self-administered soft-tissue treatment for the lower body, usually using a foam roller or other "trigger point" massage tool. By applying pressure strategically to the IT band along the side of the upper leg, some people find they can cause this often painful and tight area to relax or "release." IT band SMR is often accompanied by SMR on the glute or quad muscles, or by stretches that target the glutes or quads.
HowTo: 1. Sit on the floor with the foam roller positioned under your hip. 2. Roll your body over the foam roller, applying pressure to the IT band along the side of your thigh.

Title: Adductor SMR
Desc: Adductor self-myofascial release (SMR) is a self-administered soft-tissue treatment for the lower body, usually using a foam roller, lacrosse ball, or other "trigger point" massage tool. By applying pressure strategically to the adductor muscles in the inner thigh region, some people find they can cause this often painful and tight muscle to relax or "release." Adductor SMR is often accompanied by SMR on the iliotibial (IT) band or glutes (TFL muscles), or by stretches that target the adductors.
HowTo: 1. Sit on the floor with a foam roller or lacrosse ball under your inner thigh. 2. Slowly roll over the area, applying pressure to the adductor muscles.

Title: Lying Bent Leg Groin
Desc: The Lying Bent Leg Groin exercise targets the inner thigh muscles. It is typically performed lying on your back with your legs bent and feet flat on the ground.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back with your knees bent and feet flat on the ground. 2. Allow your knees to fall out to the sides, feeling a stretch in your inner thighs.

Title: Lateral box jump
Desc: The lateral box jump is a plyometric exercise targeting lateral agility and lower-body strength. It's a great move for athletes in many sports, including basketball, skiing, and tennis.
HowTo: 1. Stand next to a sturdy box or platform. 2. Bend your knees and jump laterally onto the box, landing softly with your knees slightly bent.

Title: Thigh adductor
Desc: The thigh adductor machine is a lower-body exercise that targets the muscles of the inner thighs. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of lower-body training.
HowTo: 1. Sit on the thigh adductor machine with your back against the pad. 2. Place your legs on the pads and squeeze them together, then slowly return to the starting position.

Title: Thigh abductor
Desc: The thigh abductor is a lower-body exercise that targets the muscles of the outer hips and glutes. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of lower-body training.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet hip-width apart. 2. Lift one leg out to the side while keeping your body straight. 3. Lower the leg back down and repeat for the desired number of reps. 4. Switch to the other leg.

Title: Standing Hip Circles
Desc: Standing Hip Circles improve hip mobility and flexibility. This exercise involves moving the hip joint in a circular motion to enhance range of motion.
HowTo: 1. Stand on one leg, lifting the other leg slightly off the ground. 2. Move the lifted leg in a circular motion, making small circles. 3. Perform for 10-15 circles in one direction, then switch directions. 4. Repeat on the other leg.

Title: Groiners
Desc: Groiners are a dynamic exercise that helps improve flexibility and mobility in the hips and legs. They also engage the core for stability.
HowTo: 1. Start in a plank position with your hands under your shoulders. 2. Bring your right foot forward to the outside of your right hand. 3. Return to the plank position and repeat on the left side. 4. Continue alternating sides for the desired number of reps.

Title: Fire Hydrant
Desc: The Fire Hydrant exercise targets the glutes and outer hips while also engaging the core. It mimics the motion of a dog lifting its leg to urinate.
HowTo: 1. Start on all fours with your hands under your shoulders and knees under your hips. 2. Keeping your knee bent, lift one leg out to the side. 3. Lower the leg back down without touching the floor. 4. Repeat for the desired number of reps, then switch legs.

Title: Windmills
Desc: Windmills are a dynamic stretching exercise that targets the hamstrings, glutes, and lower back. They improve flexibility and mobility throughout the body.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet wider than shoulder-width apart. 2. Raise one arm overhead and reach towards the opposite foot with the other hand. 3. Rotate your torso as you reach down, keeping your legs straight. 4. Return to standing and repeat on the other side.

Title: Side Leg Raises
Desc: Side leg raises are a great exercise for targeting the outer thighs and glutes. They can be performed standing or lying down to enhance hip stability and strength.
HowTo: 1. Stand straight or lie on your side. 2. Raise your top leg towards the ceiling while keeping it straight. 3. Lower it back down without touching the bottom leg. 4. Repeat for reps.

Title: Lateral hop
Desc: The lateral hop is an explosive bodyweight exercise that consists of a two-legged hop to the side. It targets the lower body, including the quads, glutes, and hamstrings. Performed for reps, it also provides a serious cardiovascular challenge. It can be performed for time or reps and is especially effective in a fat-loss or athleticism-focused circuit or workout.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. 2. Bend your knees slightly and jump to the side, landing softly on both feet. 3. Immediately jump back to the starting position. 4. Repeat for desired reps or time.

Title: Monster Walk
Desc: The monster walk is a dynamic warm-up exercise that enhances hip mobility and strengthens the glutes. It is often used in rehabilitation and athletic training.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and a resistance band around your thighs. 2. Bend your knees slightly and lower into a squat position. 3. Step sideways while maintaining tension in the band. 4. Continue stepping sideways for a set distance or number of steps.

Title: Side Lying Groin Stretch
Desc: The side lying groin stretch targets the inner thigh and hip area, promoting flexibility and mobility. It is beneficial for improving range of motion.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your side with your legs stacked. 2. Bend your top knee and place your foot on the ground in front of your bottom leg. 3. Gently push your bottom leg towards the ground to feel a stretch in your inner thigh. 4. Hold the stretch for 20-30 seconds and switch sides.

Title: IT Band and Glute Stretch
Desc: The IT band and glute stretch helps alleviate tension in the hips and outer thighs. It is important for maintaining flexibility and preventing injuries.
HowTo: 1. Sit on the ground with one leg extended and the other bent, placing the foot on the outside of the extended leg. 2. Twist your torso towards the bent knee and gently pull it towards you. 3. Hold the stretch for 20-30 seconds. 4. Switch sides and repeat.

Title: Single-leg lying cross-over stretch
Desc: The single-leg lying cross-over stretch is a simple bodyweight stretch targeting the lower back, hips, and glutes. It involves rotating a single leg over the body while lying flat on the back. It is commonly included in dynamic warm-ups, but can also be performed as full-body mobility work anytime.
HowTo: Lie flat on your back with one leg extended. Bend the other knee and rotate it across your body towards the ground, keeping your shoulders flat.

Title: Carioca quick step
Desc: The carioca quick step is a lateral bodyweight exercise targeting the adductors but also promoting agility and overall conditioning. Its a favorite of football players, particularly defensive backs, because it mimics the way they have to track wide receivers downfield. It can also help mobilize the hips for athletes and lifters of all ability levels.
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. Step laterally with one foot, crossing the other foot behind it, and then step back to the starting position, alternating sides.

Title: Standing hip circle
Desc: The standing hip circle is a bodyweight exercise targeting the hips and abductor muscles. It is a classic way to "limber up" after sitting for a long period or before a lower-body workout or sports. It requires no equipment and can be helpful for everyone from beginners to advanced fitness enthusiasts.
HowTo: Stand on one leg and lift the other leg out to the side in a circular motion. Repeat in both directions for a set number of repetitions.

Title: Lateral cone hop
Desc: The lateral cone hop is an agility drill that involves jumping over cones or other short hurdles side to side rather than front to back. It can be performed for reps or for time and can be beneficial for track athletes, basketball players, or any other athletes who need explosive lateral power.
HowTo: Stand next to a cone, then jump laterally over the cone, landing softly on the other side. Immediately jump back to the starting position and repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Side-To-Side Adductor Stretch
Desc: The Side-To-Side Adductor Stretch is a mobility exercise that targets the inner thigh muscles. It helps improve flexibility and range of motion in the legs.
HowTo: Stand with your feet wide apart and lean to one side, bending the knee while keeping the other leg straight. Hold the stretch and then switch to the other side.

Title: Dynamic pigeon stretch
Desc: The dynamic pigeon stretch is a lower-body stretch targeting the glutes, hips, and piriformis. It is influenced by the pigeon pose from yoga, but involves moving in and out of the pose. It can be part of a dynamic warm-up or mobility work performed anytime.
HowTo: Begin in a standing position. Step one leg forward and bend it at the knee while extending the other leg straight back. Transition smoothly between the two positions, focusing on stretching the hip of the bent leg.

Title: Cross-over jack
Desc: The cross-over jack is a variation on the jumping jack, a popular calisthenics exercise used to improve overall conditioning. The difference between the jumping jack and the cross-over jack is that with the latter, the feet don't just come together each rep, they cross over each other. It's a great way to add variety to your warm-up or conditioning work.
HowTo: Stand with your feet together. Jump up while crossing your feet over each other and raising your arms overhead. Return to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Traveling thigh killa
Desc: The traveling thigh killa is a challenging lower-body bodyweight exercise that builds muscular endurance with a series of hops forward and backward, as well as bodyweight squats. It can be performed for time or reps, usually in a circuit workout or as a lower-body finisher.
HowTo: Start in a standing position. Perform a hop forward, landing softly, then immediately hop backward. Alternate between hopping and performing bodyweight squats in between hops.

Title: FYR Thigh Killa
Desc: The thigh killa is a challenging lower-body bodyweight exercise that builds muscular endurance with a series of hops and bodyweight squats. It can be performed for time or reps, usually in a circuit workout or as a lower-body finisher.
HowTo: Begin in a standing position. Perform a series of hops forward followed by bodyweight squats, then repeat the hops backward. Continue this pattern for the desired duration or number of reps.

Title: HM Straddle Stretch
Desc: The HM Straddle Stretch is a lower-body stretching exercise that targets the hamstrings and hip flexors. It helps improve flexibility and mobility in the legs.
HowTo: Sit on the floor with your legs spread wide apart. Lean forward gently, reaching towards your toes while keeping your back straight. Hold the stretch for 15-30 seconds.

Title: HM Right Leg Swing
Desc: The Right Leg Swing is a dynamic stretching exercise that helps improve flexibility and mobility in the hip joint. It involves swinging the leg forward and backward to loosen up the muscles and joints.
HowTo: 1. Stand next to a wall or support for balance. 2. Swing your right leg forward and backward in a controlled manner. 3. Keep your upper body straight and avoid leaning. 4. Perform 10-15 swings before switching to the left leg.

Title: HM Right Side-Kick
Desc: The Right Side-Kick is a dynamic exercise that enhances hip mobility and strength. It involves kicking the leg out to the side to engage the hip muscles.
HowTo: 1. Stand upright with feet shoulder-width apart. 2. Lift your right leg and kick it out to the side while keeping your body straight. 3. Return to the starting position and repeat for 10-15 reps before switching sides.

Title: HM Frog Stretch
Desc: The Frog Stretch is a flexibility exercise that targets the inner thighs and hips. It helps to open up the hips and improve overall leg mobility.
HowTo: 1. Start on all fours with your hands under your shoulders and knees under your hips. 2. Slowly spread your knees apart while keeping your feet in line with your knees. 3. Lower your hips back towards your heels and hold the stretch for 20-30 seconds.

Title: HM Kick-Out
Desc: The Kick-Out exercise is designed to improve hip mobility and strength. It involves extending the leg out in front of the body to engage the hip muscles.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet hip-width apart. 2. Lift your right leg and extend it straight out in front of you while keeping your back straight. 3. Return to the starting position and repeat for 10-15 reps before switching legs.

Title: HM Left Leg Swing
Desc: The Left Leg Swing is a dynamic exercise that enhances hip mobility and flexibility. It involves swinging the leg forward and backward to loosen up the muscles.
HowTo: 1. Stand next to a wall or support for balance. 2. Swing your left leg forward and backward in a controlled manner. 3. Keep your upper body straight and avoid leaning. 4. Perform 10-15 swings before switching to the right leg.

Title: UNS Foam Roll Adductor
Desc: The UNS Foam Roll Adductor is designed to release tension in the adductor muscles of the inner thigh. It helps improve flexibility and mobility in the hip region.
HowTo: 1. Sit on the floor with your legs extended. 2. Place the foam roller under your inner thigh. 3. Roll back and forth slowly, applying pressure to the adductor muscles.

Title: MetaBurn Groiner
Desc: The MetaBurn Groiner is a dynamic exercise that combines a lunge with a plank position, engaging multiple muscle groups. It is effective for improving cardiovascular fitness and strength.
HowTo: 1. Start in a plank position with your hands under your shoulders. 2. Jump your right foot forward to the outside of your right hand. 3. Return to plank and repeat on the left side.

Title: Side-lying leg adduction scissor
Desc: The side-lying leg adduction scissor is a dynamic core exercise that combines the isometric hold of a side-lying leg lift with leg adductions to further challenge the core and adductors. It targets multiple muscles of the core, primarily the rectus abdominis or "six-pack" muscles. It can be performed for time or reps in the ab-focused portion of any workout.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your side with your legs stacked. 2. Lift your top leg while keeping your bottom leg on the ground. 3. Lower the top leg and repeat for reps.

Title: Groin and Back Stretch
Desc: The Groin and Back Stretch is aimed at improving flexibility in the groin and lower back areas. It helps alleviate tension and enhance mobility.
HowTo: 1. Sit on the floor with your legs spread wide. 2. Lean forward gently, reaching towards your toes while keeping your back straight. 3. Hold the stretch for 20-30 seconds.

Title: Adductor/Groin
Desc: The Adductor/Groin exercise focuses on stretching and strengthening the inner thigh muscles. It is essential for improving overall leg mobility.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet wider than shoulder-width apart. 2. Shift your weight to one side, bending that knee while keeping the other leg straight. 3. Hold for a few seconds and switch sides.

Title: Incline dumbbell biceps curl
Desc: The incline dumbbell biceps curl is an exercise targeting the biceps and performed face up on an incline bench. This creates a vertical arm angle, which helps to isolate the biceps and limit involvement of the shoulder muscles. This curl variation is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of upper-body or arm-focused training.
HowTo: 1. Sit back on an incline bench with a dumbbell in each hand. 2. Curl the weights up towards your shoulders while keeping your elbows close to your body, then lower them back down.

Title: Banded biceps curl in squat position
Desc: The banded biceps curl in squat position is an exercise targeting the biceps, although it also works the core and lower body.
HowTo: 1. Stand in a squat position with a resistance band under your feet and holding the handles. 2. Perform a biceps curl while maintaining the squat position.

Title: Banded Hammer Press - Gethin Variation
Desc: The machine chest press is an upper body exercise targeting the pectoral muscles.
HowTo: 1. Sit on the machine with your back against the pad and feet flat on the ground. 2. Push the handles forward until your arms are fully extended, then return to the starting position.

Title: Band standing concentration curl
Desc: The band standing concentration curl is a variation of a popular biceps-focused exercise utilizing a band instead of a dumbbell. It allows you to focus on one biceps at a time and really squeeze out intense peak contractions. Band concentration curls are usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of an upper-body or arm-focused workout.
HowTo: 1. Stand with a resistance band anchored at your feet and hold one end in your hand. 2. Curl the band towards your shoulder while keeping your elbow stationary, then lower it back down.

Title: Brachialis SMR
Desc: Brachialis self-myofascial release (SMR) is a self-administered soft-tissue treatment for the upper body, usually using a foam roller, lacrosse ball, or other "trigger point" massage tool. By applying pressure strategically to the biceps or brachialis muscles of the upper arm, some people find they can cause this often painful and tight muscle to relax or "release." Brachialis SMR is often accompanied by SMR on the triceps muscles or pectorals, or by stretches that target the biceps or pecs.
HowTo: 1. Sit or lie down with a foam roller or lacrosse ball on the area of the biceps or brachialis. 2. Apply pressure and roll slowly over the muscle to release tension.

Title: Wide-grip barbell curl
Desc: The wide-grip barbell curl is a variation of the classic barbell curl with the grip wider than shoulder width. It is thought that this helps build the inner or "short" head of the biceps muscles. This movement is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set.
HowTo: 1. Stand with a barbell in your hands, grip wider than shoulder-width. 2. Curl the barbell up towards your chest while keeping your elbows close to your body, then lower it back down.

Title: EZ-bar spider curl
Desc: The EZ-bar spider curl is an exercise targeting the biceps and performed face down on either an incline bench or on the flat side of a preacher bench. The EZ-bar makes for a more comfortable wrist position, while the angle helps to isolate the biceps and limit involvement of the shoulder muscles. This curl variation is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of upper-body or arm-focused training.
HowTo: 1. Sit on an incline bench or preacher bench with an EZ-bar. 2. With your arms hanging down, curl the bar towards your chest while keeping your elbows stationary.

Title: Barbell Curl
Desc: The barbell curl is an arm exercise that is also one of the most recognizable movements in all of bodybuilding and fitness. It helps build sleeve-popping biceps and allows heavier loading than many other curl variations. It is usually performed in moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set, as part of the arm-focused portion of any workout.
HowTo: 1. Stand with a barbell in your hands at arm's length. 2. Curl the barbell up towards your shoulders while keeping your elbows close to your body, then lower it back down.

Title: Close-grip EZ-bar curl
Desc: The close-grip EZ-bar curl is an exercise targeting the biceps, particularly the long head. The main difference between this exercise and standard EZ-bar curls is that the hands are positioned closer together on the bar. It is thought that this helps build the outer biceps head and the peak. This curl variation is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set.
HowTo: 1. Stand with an EZ-bar, hands positioned close together. 2. Curl the bar towards your shoulders, focusing on squeezing the biceps at the top of the movement.

Title: Preacher Curl
Desc: The EZ-bar preacher curl is a classic exercise for building bigger biceps. This move is all about isolation. With the back of the upper arms against the pad, its next to impossible to cheat. Go light, get a great pump, and build that peak!
HowTo: 1. Sit at a preacher bench with an EZ-bar. 2. With your upper arms resting on the pad, curl the bar towards you, then lower it back down slowly.

Title: Barbell Curls Lying Against An Incline
Desc: Barbell curls lying against an incline target the biceps while minimizing the use of other muscle groups. This position helps isolate the biceps for a more effective workout.
HowTo: 1. Lie back on an incline bench with a barbell in hand. 2. Keep your elbows close to your body and curl the barbell towards your shoulders. 3. Lower the barbell back to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Seated Close-Grip Concentration Barbell Curl
Desc: The seated close-grip concentration barbell curl is designed to isolate the biceps for maximum contraction. This exercise helps in building strength and size in the biceps.
HowTo: 1. Sit on a bench with your feet flat on the floor and hold a barbell with a close grip. 2. Rest your elbows against your inner thighs and curl the barbell towards your chest. 3. Slowly lower the barbell back to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Close-grip barbell curl
Desc: The close-grip barbell curl is a curl variation where the hands are closer than shoulder width. It is thought that this helps build the outer biceps head and the peak. This curl variation is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and hold a barbell with a close grip. 2. Curl the barbell towards your shoulders while keeping your elbows stationary. 3. Lower the barbell back down and repeat.

Title: Drag curl
Desc: The drag curl is a biceps exercise that attempts to remove the influence of the front deltoids on the classic curl. With the elbows kept back, the barbell "drags" up the torso. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-15 reps per set, as part of an upper-body or arms-focused workout.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and hold a barbell with an underhand grip. 2. Keep your elbows back and curl the barbell up along your torso. 3. Lower the barbell back down and repeat.

Title: Reverse-grip barbell curl
Desc: The reverse-grip barbell curl is a variation on the biceps curl where the palms face downward. The switch from an underhand to an overhand grip brings the forearm and brachialis muscles more into the exercise. If it is uncomfortable to the wrists, try performing it on the angles of an EZ-curl bar.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and hold a barbell with an overhand grip. 2. Curl the barbell towards your shoulders while keeping your elbows close to your body. 3. Lower the barbell back down and repeat.

Title: Lying High Bench Barbell Curl
Desc: The Lying High Bench Barbell Curl is an effective exercise for isolating the biceps. It is performed while lying on a bench, which helps to minimize cheating and focus on the muscle contraction.
HowTo: 1. Lie back on a high bench with a barbell in your hands. 2. Curl the barbell towards your forehead, keeping your elbows stationary. 3. Lower the barbell back to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Seated wide-grip curl to close-grip curl
Desc: The seated wide-grip curl to close-grip curl is a variation on the classic seated dumbbell curl. It is thought that wide-grip curls target the inner head of the biceps more, while close-grip curls target the outer head or peak. This variation allows you to get the benefits of both.
HowTo: 1. Sit on a bench with a dumbbell in each hand. 2. Start with a wide grip and curl the weights up towards your shoulders. 3. Lower the weights and switch to a close grip, repeating the curl.

Title: Seated Straigh-Bar Curl Superset
Desc: The seated wide-grip curl to close-grip curl is a variation on the classic seated dumbbell curl. The variation is that the range of motion changes in alternating fashionone more traditional, one where youre bringing the weight in more from the side.
HowTo: 1. Sit on a bench with a straight barbell. 2. Perform a traditional curl by bringing the barbell to your shoulders. 3. Then, switch to a side-angled curl, bringing the barbell from the side towards your shoulders.

Title: Dave Draper Forehead Curl
Desc: The Dave Draper Forehead Curl is a unique bicep exercise that emphasizes the contraction of the biceps. It is performed in a seated position to ensure stability and focus on the muscle.
HowTo: 1. Sit on a bench with a barbell or dumbbells. 2. Curl the weights towards your forehead while keeping your elbows stationary. 3. Lower the weights back down and repeat.

Title: Reverse-grip EZ-bar curl
Desc: The reverse-grip EZ-bar curl is an exercise targeting the biceps and forearms. Because grip strength is a limitation with this move, it is often performed for moderate to high reps as part of an upper-body or arm-focused workout.
HowTo: 1. Stand holding an EZ-bar with an underhand grip. 2. Curl the bar towards your shoulders while keeping your elbows close to your body. 3. Lower the bar back down and repeat.

Title: EZ-Bar Spider Curl - Gethin Variation
Desc: The EZ-bar spider curl is an isolation exercise targeting the biceps and performed face-down on an incline bench. The EZ-bar makes for a more comfortable wrist position.
HowTo: 1. Set an incline bench to a comfortable angle. 2. Lie face down on the bench with an EZ-bar in hand. 3. Curl the bar towards your forehead while keeping your elbows stationary. 4. Lower the bar back down to the starting position.

Title: Barbell curl-
Desc: The barbell curl is an arm exercise that is also one of the most recognizable movements in all of bodybuilding and fitness. It helps build sleeve-popping biceps and allows heavier loading than many other curl variations. It is usually performed in moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set, as part of the arm-focused portion of any workout.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a barbell with both hands. 2. Keep your elbows close to your torso and curl the barbell up towards your chest. 3. Squeeze your biceps at the top of the movement. 4. Lower the barbell back to the starting position.

Title: Paul Carter Barbell Curl
Desc: The barbell curl is an arm exercise that is also one of the most recognizable movements in all of bodybuilding and fitness. It helps build sleeve-popping biceps and allows heavier loading than many other curl variations. It is usually performed in moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set, as part of the arm-focused portion of any workout.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a barbell with both hands. 2. Keep your elbows close to your torso and curl the barbell up towards your chest. 3. Squeeze your biceps at the top of the movement. 4. Lower the barbell back to the starting position.

Title: Standing band biceps curl
Desc: The standing band biceps curl is an arm-focused exercise using a band for resistance. This variation is usually performed for moderate to high reps as part of an arms-focused or upper-body workout.
HowTo: 1. Stand upright with a resistance band under your feet. 2. Hold the handles of the band with your palms facing up. 3. Curl your hands towards your shoulders while keeping your elbows close to your body. 4. Slowly lower your hands back to the starting position.

Title: Close-Grip EZ-Bar Curl - Gethin Variation
Desc: The close-grip EZ-bar curl is an exercise targeting the biceps, particularly the long head. The main difference between this exercise and standard barbell curls is that the hands are positioned closer together on the bar. It is thought that this helps build the outer biceps head and the peak. This curl variation is usually performed for moderate to high reps, like at least 8-12 reps per set.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding an EZ-bar with a close grip. 2. Keep your elbows close to your torso and curl the barbell up towards your chest. 3. Squeeze your biceps at the top of the movement. 4. Lower the barbell back to the starting position.

Title: Seated Barbell Curl
Desc: The Seated Barbell Curl is an effective exercise for targeting the biceps while minimizing the use of momentum. It is performed while seated, which helps to isolate the biceps more effectively.
HowTo: 1. Sit on a bench with your back straight and feet flat on the ground. 2. Hold a barbell with an underhand grip, arms fully extended. 3. Curl the barbell towards your shoulders while keeping your elbows close to your body. 4. Slowly lower the barbell back to the starting position.

Title: AM Standing Barbell Curl
Desc: The standing EZ-bar curl is an immenselyp popular exercise targeting the biceps. It is commonly performed for moderate to high reps as part of an upper body or arms-focused workout. Many gyms even have EZ-bars at fixed weights, allowing for easy weight changes.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding an EZ-bar with an underhand grip. 2. Keep your elbows close to your body and curl the bar towards your chest. 3. Squeeze your biceps at the top of the movement, then lower the bar back down slowly.

Title: EZ-bar preacher curl
Desc: The EZ-bar preacher curl is a classic exercise for building bigger biceps. This move is all about isolation. With the back of the upper arms against the pad, it's next to impossible to use momentum which forces the muscles to work harder.
HowTo: 1. Sit at a preacher bench and rest your upper arms on the pad. 2. Hold an EZ-bar with an underhand grip and let it hang down. 3. Curl the bar towards your shoulders, keeping your upper arms against the pad. 4. Lower the bar back down slowly to the starting position.

Title: 30 Arms Standing Barbell Curl
Desc: The 30 Arms Standing Barbell Curl is a variation of the traditional barbell curl that focuses on the biceps. It is performed standing to engage core stability as well.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a barbell with an underhand grip. 2. Keep your elbows close to your body and curl the barbell towards your chest. 3. Squeeze your biceps at the top and lower the bar back down slowly.

Title: 30 Arms Incline Biceps Curl
Desc: The 30 Arms Incline Biceps Curl is designed to target the biceps with an incline position that enhances the stretch. This exercise helps in building muscle size and strength.
HowTo: 1. Sit on an incline bench with a dumbbell in each hand, arms hanging down. 2. Curl the dumbbells towards your shoulders while keeping your elbows stationary. 3. Squeeze at the top, then lower the weights back to the starting position.

Title: Bicep Curls "21s"
Desc: Bicep Curls '21s' is a variation of bicep curls that targets the biceps through a specific rep scheme. This exercise is performed in three segments: seven reps in the lower half of the range, seven in the upper half, and seven full-range reps.
HowTo: 1. Stand with a dumbbell in each hand, arms fully extended. 2. Curl the weights up to shoulder height, keeping your elbows close to your body. 3. Perform seven reps in the lower half of the range, then seven in the upper half, and finish with seven full-range curls.

Title: Incline Hammer Curls
Desc: Incline Hammer Curls are performed on an incline bench to target the biceps and forearms effectively. This position allows for a greater stretch and contraction of the muscles.
HowTo: 1. Sit back on an incline bench with a dumbbell in each hand, arms hanging down. 2. Keeping your palms facing each other, curl the weights up towards your shoulders. 3. Lower the weights back to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Hammer Curls
Desc: This curl is performed simultaneously with dumbbells but without wrist supination. Throughout each rep, the wrists remain neutral, like a carpenter hammering a nail.
HowTo: 1. Stand with a dumbbell in each hand, arms at your sides with palms facing your body. 2. Curl the weights up while keeping your wrists neutral. 3. Lower the weights back down and repeat.

Title: Biceps curl to shoulder press
Desc: The biceps curl to shoulder press is a dumbbell complex that combines two exercises that build and strengthen the biceps and shoulders or deltoids. It is usually performed one rep of each movement at a time, although you could perform more reps of each, or increase the reps in successive rounds (e.g., 1 rep in round 1, 2 reps in round 2, etc.). No matter how you structure the sets and reps, it is a time-efficient way to hit two crucial upper-body muscles in any workout.
HowTo: 1. Start with a dumbbell in each hand at shoulder height, palms facing forward. 2. Perform a bicep curl, then transition into a shoulder press by pushing the weights overhead. 3. Lower the weights back to shoulder height and repeat.

Title: Concentration curl
Desc: The concentration curl is a classic exercise for building the biceps one arm at a time. It can be performed bent over or kneeling, but is more often performed seated on a bench. It's great for emphasizing the biceps peak and is often used to finish a biceps workout. Like most curl variations, these are usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more.
HowTo: 1. Sit on a bench with your legs spread, holding a dumbbell in one hand. 2. Rest your elbow against your inner thigh and curl the weight towards your shoulder. 3. Lower the weight back down and repeat before switching arms.

Title: Flexor Incline Dumbbell Curls
Desc: Flexor Incline Dumbbell Curls primarily target the biceps while also engaging the forearms. This exercise is performed on an incline bench to enhance the stretch and contraction of the biceps.
HowTo: 1. Sit on an incline bench with a dumbbell in each hand. 2. Allow your arms to hang down fully extended. 3. Curl the dumbbells up towards your shoulders while keeping your elbows close to your body. 4. Slowly lower the weights back to the starting position.

Title: Dumbbell Bicep Curl
Desc: The dumbbell biceps curl is a single-joint exercise for building bigger and stronger biceps. Popular among gym goers of all experience levels, this move can be done seated or standing. It is generally performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps or higher, as part of the arm-focused portion of a workout.
HowTo: 1. Stand or sit with a dumbbell in each hand, arms fully extended. 2. Curl the weights up towards your shoulders while keeping your elbows stationary. 3. Squeeze at the top, then lower the weights back down slowly.

Title: Cross-body hammer curl
Desc: The cross-body hammer curl is a dumbbell exercise that targets the biceps, brachialis, and forearm muscles. Rather than lifting the weights directly in front of the body, you lift them across the torso. Throughout each rep, the wrists remain neutral, like a carpenter hammering a nail. This helps isolate the brachialis muscles on each arm. It is generally performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps or more, as part of the arm-focused portion of a workout.
HowTo: 1. Stand with a dumbbell in each hand, arms at your sides. 2. Curl one dumbbell across your body towards the opposite shoulder. 3. Lower it back down and repeat on the other side.

Title: Dumbbell Alternate Bicep Curl
Desc: The alternating biceps curl is a single-joint exercise for building bigger and stronger biceps one arm at a time. Popular among gym goers of all experience levels, this move can be done seated or standing. It is generally performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps or higher, as part of the arm-focused portion of a workout.
HowTo: 1. Stand or sit with a dumbbell in each hand, arms fully extended. 2. Curl one dumbbell up towards your shoulder while keeping the other arm stationary. 3. Lower the weight and switch to the other arm.

Title: Single-arm dumbbell preacher curl
Desc: The single-arm dumbbell preacher curl is an exercise that focuses on building the biceps, particularly the biceps peak. Most people will go light on this movement, performing it for moderate to high reps as part of an upper-body or arms-focused workout.
HowTo: 1. Sit on a preacher bench with a dumbbell in one hand. 2. Rest your arm on the bench with your elbow at the edge. 3. Curl the dumbbell up towards your shoulder, then lower it back down slowly.

Title: Alternate Incline Dumbbell Curl
Desc: The alternating incline dumbbell biceps curl is an exercise targeting the biceps and performed face up on an incline bench. This creates a vertical arm angle which helps to isolate the biceps and limit involvement of the shoulder muscles. This curl variation is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 rep per arm or more, as part of upper-body or arm-focused training.
HowTo: 1. Sit back on an incline bench with a dumbbell in each hand. 2. Curl the dumbbells up while keeping your elbows close to your body and your wrists neutral.

Title: Standing concentration curl
Desc: The standing concentration curl is a variation on the more common seated concentration curl, which is a staple of bodybuilding arm routines. It can serve as a substitute for preacher curl variations if a preacher bench is unavailable and is also a classic way to focus in on the biceps peak. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-10 reps per set, with a focus on strict form and controlled tempo.
HowTo: 1. Stand with a dumbbell in each hand, arms fully extended. 2. Curl the dumbbells towards your shoulders while keeping your elbows stationary.

Title: Alternating incline dumbbell biceps curl
Desc: The alternating incline dumbbell biceps curl is an exercise targeting the biceps and performed face up on an incline bench. This creates a vertical arm angle which helps to isolate the biceps and limit involvement of the shoulder muscles. This curl variation is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 rep per arm or more, as part of upper-body or arm-focused training.
HowTo: 1. Sit back on an incline bench with a dumbbell in each hand. 2. Curl the dumbbells up while keeping your elbows close to your body and your wrists neutral.

Title: Alternate Hammer Curl
Desc: The alternating hammer curl is performed with dumbbells but without wrist supination. Throughout each rep, the wrists remain neutral, like a carpenter hammering a nail.
HowTo: 1. Stand with a dumbbell in each hand at your sides. 2. Curl the dumbbells up with a neutral grip, keeping your elbows close to your body.

Title: Seated dumbbell biceps curl
Desc: The seated dumbbell biceps curl is a popular exercise for building bigger biceps. While curls can effectively be performed standing as well, performing them seated can enforce strict form and perhaps boost the mind-muscle connection. Like most curl variations, these are usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more.
HowTo: 1. Sit on a bench with a dumbbell in each hand, arms at your sides. 2. Curl the dumbbells towards your shoulders while keeping your back straight and elbows stationary.

Title: Preacher Hammer Dumbbell Curl
Desc: The Preacher Hammer Dumbbell Curl is an exercise that targets the biceps, particularly the brachialis and brachioradialis. It is performed on a preacher bench to isolate the biceps and minimize cheating.
HowTo: 1. Sit on a preacher bench with your upper arms resting on the pad. 2. Hold a dumbbell in each hand with a neutral grip (palms facing each other). 3. Curl the dumbbells up towards your shoulders while keeping your upper arms stationary. 4. Lower the dumbbells back to the starting position in a controlled manner.

Title: Dumbbell preacher curl
Desc: The dumbbell preacher curl is an exercise that focuses on building the biceps, particularly the biceps peak. All you need is a pair of dumbbells and a preacher bench. It's usually performed for moderate to high reps as part of an upper-body or arms-focused workout.
HowTo: 1. Sit on a preacher bench with your arms resting on the pad. 2. Hold a dumbbell in each hand with an underhand grip. 3. Curl the weights towards your shoulders while keeping your elbows stationary. 4. Lower the weights back to the starting position.

Title: Lying Supine Dumbbell Curl
Desc: The Lying Supine Dumbbell Curl is an exercise that targets the biceps while lying on your back. This position helps to isolate the biceps and reduce momentum during the curl.
HowTo: 1. Lie on a flat bench with a dumbbell in each hand, arms extended above your chest. 2. Curl the dumbbells towards your shoulders while keeping your elbows stationary. 3. Squeeze at the top of the movement, then lower the weights back to the starting position.

Title: Standing Dumbbell Reverse Curl
Desc: With the reverse-grip dumbbell curl, the palms face down, not up. This unorthodox wrist position simultaneously targets the biceps while also building forearm and grip strength. The move can performed standing or seated.
HowTo: 1. Stand with a dumbbell in each hand, arms at your sides, palms facing down. 2. Curl the dumbbells up towards your shoulders while keeping your elbows close to your body. 3. Lower the weights back down in a controlled manner.

Title: Palms-out incline biceps curl
Desc: The palms-out incline biceps curl is an exercise targeting the biceps. It is largely similar to the incline dumbbell curl, but the palms-out position targets the long head of the biceps, which is responsible for the biceps "peak." This curl variation is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of upper-body or arm-focused training.
HowTo: 1. Sit on an incline bench with a dumbbell in each hand, arms hanging down at your sides, palms facing away from you. 2. Curl the dumbbells towards your shoulders while keeping your elbows stationary. 3. Squeeze at the top, then lower the weights back to the starting position.

Title: Straight-arm plank with biceps curl
Desc: The straight-arm plank with biceps curl is a hybrid movement that trains the abdominal and biceps muscles simultaneously. It can address multiple muscle groups in a time-efficient muscle-building or circuit-style workout, while also providing an additional cardiovascular challenge.
HowTo: 1. Start in a straight-arm plank position with your body in a straight line. 2. Hold a dumbbell in one hand, and while maintaining the plank, curl the dumbbell towards your shoulder. 3. Lower the dumbbell back to the starting position and repeat with the other arm.

Title: Face-down incline dumbbell biceps curl
Desc: The face-down incline dumbbell biceps curl is an exercise targeting the biceps and performed face down on an incline bench. This creates a vertical arm angle, which helps to isolate the biceps and limit involvement of the shoulder muscles. This curl variation is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of upper-body or arm-focused training.
HowTo: 1. Lie face down on an incline bench with a dumbbell in each hand. 2. Let your arms hang straight down, then curl the dumbbells towards your shoulders. 3. Lower the dumbbells back to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Seated Dumbbell Inner Biceps Curl
Desc: The seated dumbbell inner biceps curl is an effective exercise for isolating the inner part of the biceps. It is performed while seated to ensure stability and focus on the biceps contraction.
HowTo: 1. Sit on a bench with a dumbbell in each hand, arms at your sides. 2. Rotate your wrists so that your palms face each other, then curl the dumbbells towards your shoulders. 3. Lower the dumbbells back to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Standing Inner-Biceps Curl
Desc: The standing inner-biceps curl is a variation that targets the inner biceps muscle. This exercise can be performed standing to engage core stability while isolating the biceps.
HowTo: 1. Stand with a dumbbell in each hand, arms at your sides. 2. Rotate your wrists so that your palms face each other, then curl the dumbbells towards your shoulders. 3. Lower the dumbbells back to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Seated hammer curl
Desc: The seated hammer curl is a popular exercise for building bigger biceps and forearms. The movement resembles hammering a nailhence the name. While curls can effectively be performed standing as well, performing them seated can enforce strict form and perhaps boost the mind-muscle connection. Like most curl variations, these are usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more.
HowTo: 1. Sit on a bench with a dumbbell in each hand, arms at your sides and palms facing your body. 2. Curl the dumbbells up towards your shoulders while keeping your palms facing each other. 3. Lower the dumbbells back to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Paul Carter Incline Dumbbell Biceps Curl
Desc: The incline dumbbell biceps curl is an isolation exercise targeting the biceps. This variation targets the long head of the biceps more than a traditional curl and there is more overall tension to this muscle.
HowTo: 1. Sit on an incline bench with a dumbbell in each hand. 2. Curl the dumbbells up towards your shoulders while keeping your elbows close to your body.

Title: Paul Carter Concentration Curl
Desc: The concentration curl is a classic exercise for building the biceps one arm at a time. It can be performed bent over or kneeling, but is more often performed seated on a bench. It's great for emphasizing the biceps peak and is often used to finish a biceps workout. Like most curl variations, these are usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more.
HowTo: 1. Sit on a bench with your legs spread and a dumbbell in one hand. 2. Rest your elbow on your inner thigh and curl the dumbbell towards your shoulder.

Title: FYR Dumbbell Curl
Desc: The dumbbell biceps curl is a single-joint exercise for building bigger and stronger biceps. Popular among gym goers of all experience levels, this move can be done seated or standing. It is generally performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps or higher, as part of the arm-focused portion of a workout.
HowTo: 1. Stand or sit with a dumbbell in each hand at your sides. 2. Curl the dumbbells up towards your shoulders while keeping your elbows stationary.

Title: Dumbbell biceps curl to upright row
Desc: The dumbbell biceps curl to upright row is a dumbbell complex that combines two exercises that build and strengthen the biceps, traps, and the middle head of the deltoids. It is usually performed one rep of each movement at a time, although you could perform more reps of each, or increase the reps in successive rounds (e.g., 1 rep in round 1, 2 reps in round 2, etc.). No matter how you structure the sets and reps, it is a time-efficient way to hit multiple upper-body muscles in any workout.
HowTo: 1. Start with a dumbbell in each hand at your sides. 2. Perform a biceps curl, then transition into an upright row by lifting the dumbbells to your chin.

Title: FYR Dumbbell Hammer Curl
Desc: This curl is performed simultaneously with dumbbells but without wrist supination. Throughout each rep, the wrists remain neutral, like a carpenter hammering a nail.
HowTo: 1. Stand with a dumbbell in each hand, palms facing each other. 2. Curl the dumbbells up while keeping your palms facing each other throughout the movement.

Title: Dumbbell overhead hold with single-arm curl
Desc: The dumbbell overhead hold with single-arm curl combines an isometric overhead hold with a curl for the other arm. The two movements collectively target the muscles of the shoulders and arms, while providing a surprising core challenge. Expect to be challenged, even with light weight.
HowTo: 1. Stand or sit with a dumbbell in one hand and raise it overhead. 2. With the other arm, perform a bicep curl while maintaining the overhead position.

Title: FYR Kneeling Biceps
Desc: The kneeling concentration curl allows you to target the biceps without having the ability to use momentum from the rest of your body to move the weight.
HowTo: 1. Kneel on one knee with the other foot in front, holding a dumbbell in one hand. 2. Curl the dumbbell towards your shoulder, focusing on isolating the bicep.

Title: Lunge hold dumbbell curl
Desc: The lunge hold dumbbell curl is a challenging complex that combines an isometric hold at the bottom of a lunge with a dumbbell biceps curl. The two exercises combine to target the legs, core, and biceps. The curl will determine the amount of weight you can use, but even a light weight will make the lunge hold seriously challenging.
HowTo: 1. Start in a lunge position with one leg forward and the other knee close to the ground. 2. Hold the lunge position while performing a bicep curl with the opposite arm.

Title: FYR Dumbbell Biceps Curl
Desc: The dumbbell biceps curl is a single-joint exercise for building bigger and stronger biceps. Popular among gym goers of all experience levels, this move can be done seated or standing. It is generally performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps or higher, as part of the arm-focused portion of a workout.
HowTo: 1. Stand or sit with a dumbbell in each hand, arms at your sides. 2. Curl the dumbbells up towards your shoulders while keeping your elbows close to your body.

Title: Alternating dumbbell snatch
Desc: The alternating dumbbell snatch is an explosive exercise that builds full-body power and targets the muscles of the hips, back, and shoulders. Performing it by alternating arms gives each arm the chance to recover, allowing you to do a greater amount of quality work. It can be performed for low reps with a focus on power and speed, or for higher reps to build muscle or as part of a metabolic conditioning circuit.
HowTo: 1. Start with a dumbbell on the ground between your feet. 2. Squat down, grasp the dumbbell, and explosively lift it overhead while standing up, alternating arms.

Title: TBS Incline Dumbbell Curl
Desc: The incline dumbbell biceps curl is an isolation exercise targeting the biceps. This variation targets the long head of the biceps more than a traditional curl and there is more overall tension to this muscle.
HowTo: 1. Sit on an incline bench with a dumbbell in each hand. 2. Curl the dumbbells up towards your shoulders while keeping your elbows close to your body.

Title: TBS Hammer Curl
Desc: The alternating hammer curl is performed with dumbbells but without wrist supination. Throughout each rep, the wrists remain neutral, like a carpenter hammering a nail.
HowTo: 1. Stand with a dumbbell in each hand, arms at your sides. 2. Curl the dumbbells up while keeping your wrists neutral.

Title: Reverse-grip dumbbell curl
Desc: With the reverse-grip dumbbell curl, the palms face down, not up. This unorthodox wrist position simultaneously targets the biceps while also building forearm and grip strength. The move can be performed standing or seated. Because grip is a limiting factor, it is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-10 reps per set.
HowTo: 1. Stand or sit with a dumbbell in each hand, palms facing down. 2. Curl the dumbbells up towards your shoulders while maintaining the reverse grip.

Title: Incline Dumbbell Curl - Gethin Variation
Desc: The incline dumbbell biceps curl is an isolation exercise targeting the biceps. This variation targets the long head of the biceps more than a traditional curl and there is more overall tension to this muscle.
HowTo: 1. Sit on an incline bench with a dumbbell in each hand. 2. Curl the dumbbells up towards your shoulders while keeping your elbows close to your body.

Title: Hammer curl
Desc: The hammer curl is a dumbbell movement that focuses on the biceps, brachialis, and forearm muscles. Throughout each rep, the wrists remain neutral, like a carpenter hammering a nail. It is generally performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps or more, as part of the arm-focused portion of a workout.
HowTo: 1. Stand with a dumbbell in each hand, arms at your sides. 2. Curl the dumbbells up while keeping your wrists neutral.

Title: Seated Dumbbell Curl - Gethin Variation
Desc: The seated dumbbell biceps curl is a standard exercise for building bigger biceps. While dumbbell biceps curls can be performed standing, this version involves sitting on a bench.
HowTo: 1. Sit on a bench with a dumbbell in each hand, arms fully extended down. 2. Curl the dumbbells up towards your shoulders while keeping your elbows close to your body, then lower them back down.

Title: Dumbbell Hammer Curl - Gethin Variation
Desc: This curl is performed simultaneously with dumbbells but without wrist supination. Throughout each rep, the wrists remain neutral, like a carpenter hammering a nail.
HowTo: 1. Stand or sit with a dumbbell in each hand, palms facing each other. 2. Curl the dumbbells up while keeping your wrists neutral, then lower them back down.

Title: Single-arm seated dumbbell curl
Desc: The single-arm seated dumbbell curl is a popular exercise for building bigger biceps. Performing it one arm at a time may allow you to use slightly heavier weight, while focusing on really feeling the mind-muscle connection in the working arm. Like most curl variations, these are usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more.
HowTo: 1. Sit on a bench with a dumbbell in one hand, arm extended down. 2. Curl the dumbbell up towards your shoulder, focusing on the contraction, then lower it back down.

Title: Lying Cable Curl - Gethin Variation
Desc: The lying cable biceps curl is an isolation exercise that eliminates the possibility of using momentum from the lower body to raise the weight.
HowTo: 1. Lie on a bench with your back flat and a cable attached to the pulley. 2. Curl the cable towards your forehead while keeping your elbows stationary, then lower it back down.

Title: Dumbbell biceps curl
Desc: The dumbbell biceps curl is a single-joint exercise for building bigger and stronger biceps. Popular among gym goers of all experience levels, this move can be done seated or standing. It is generally performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps or higher, as part of the arm-focused portion of a workout.
HowTo: 1. Stand or sit with a dumbbell in each hand, arms fully extended at your sides. 2. Curl the dumbbells up towards your shoulders, then lower them back down.

Title: Seated Biceps Hammer Curl
Desc: The seated biceps hammer curl is a great exercise for targeting the biceps. It is performed while sitting, which helps to stabilize the body.
HowTo: 1. Sit on a bench with a dumbbell in each hand, arms at your sides. 2. Keeping your elbows close to your body, curl the weights up while maintaining a neutral wrist position. 3. Lower the weights back to the starting position and repeat.

Title: HM Alternating Reverse Lunge With Biceps Curl
Desc: The HM Alternating Reverse Lunge with Biceps Curl combines a lower body lunge with an upper body biceps curl. This exercise targets multiple muscle groups simultaneously.
HowTo: 1. Stand with a dumbbell in each hand at your sides. 2. Step back with one leg into a lunge while simultaneously curling the weights up to your shoulders. 3. Return to standing and alternate legs.

Title: AM Hammer Curls
Desc: This curl is performed simultaneously with dumbbells but without wrist supination. Throughout each rep, the wrists remain neutral, like a carpenter hammering a nail.
HowTo: 1. Stand with a dumbbell in each hand, arms at your sides, palms facing each other. 2. Curl the weights up while keeping your wrists neutral. 3. Lower the weights back down and repeat.

Title: AM Seated Hammer Curls
Desc: The seated hammer curl is a popular exercise for building bigger biceps. The movement resembles hammering a nailhence the name. While hammer can be performed standing, this version involves sitting on a bench.
HowTo: 1. Sit on a bench with a dumbbell in each hand, arms at your sides. 2. Curl the weights up while keeping your wrists neutral. 3. Lower the weights back down and repeat.

Title: Seated alternating biceps curl
Desc: The seated alternating biceps curl is an exercise that builds bigger and stronger biceps. The alternating technique allows one arm to rest briefly while the other arm lifts. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps or more, as part of the upper-body or arm-focused portion of a workout.
HowTo: 1. Sit on a bench with a dumbbell in each hand, arms at your sides. 2. Curl one dumbbell up while keeping the other arm at rest. 3. Lower the weight and alternate arms.

Title: Alternating hammer curl
Desc: The alternating hammer curl is performed with dumbbells but without wrist supination. Throughout each rep, the wrists remain neutral, like a carpenter hammering a nail. It is generally performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps or more, as part of the arm-focused portion of a workout.
HowTo: 1. Stand or sit with a dumbbell in each hand, arms at your sides. 2. Keeping your elbows close to your body, curl the weights up towards your shoulders while keeping your wrists neutral.

Title: Alternating biceps curl
Desc: The alternating biceps curl is a single-joint exercise for building bigger and stronger biceps one arm at a time. Popular among gym goers of all experience levels, this move can be done seated or standing. It is generally performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps or higher, as part of the arm-focused portion of a workout.
HowTo: 1. Stand or sit with a dumbbell in each hand, arms at your sides. 2. Curl one dumbbell up towards your shoulder while keeping the other arm stationary, then alternate arms.

Title: Holman Slow Biceps Curl
Desc: The Holman Slow Biceps Curl focuses on controlled movements to enhance muscle engagement.
HowTo: 1. Stand with a dumbbell in each hand at your sides. 2. Slowly curl the weights up to your shoulders, taking 3-4 seconds to complete the upward motion, then lower them back down slowly.

Title: Holman Biceps Curl to Chest Punch
Desc: The Holman Biceps Curl to Chest Punch combines a bicep curl with a punch to engage the shoulders.
HowTo: 1. Start with a dumbbell in each hand at your sides. 2. Curl the weights up to your shoulders, then punch forward with both arms, extending them fully before returning to the starting position.

Title: Holman Right Arm Heavy Biceps Curl
Desc: The Holman Right Arm Heavy Biceps Curl emphasizes strength in the right arm.
HowTo: 1. Stand with a heavy dumbbell in your right hand, arm at your side. 2. Curl the weight up towards your shoulder, focusing on controlling the movement, then lower it back down.

Title: Holman Left Arm Heavy Biceps Curl
Desc: The Holman Left Arm Heavy Biceps Curl focuses on building strength in the biceps of the left arm. It is an isolation exercise that targets the bicep muscle specifically.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a dumbbell in your left hand. 2. Keep your elbow close to your torso and curl the dumbbell towards your shoulder. 3. Squeeze at the top of the movement, then lower the dumbbell back to the starting position.

Title: Holman Alternating Front Lunge Biceps Curl
Desc: The Holman Alternating Front Lunge Biceps Curl combines a lunge with a bicep curl to work both the legs and arms. This compound exercise enhances strength and coordination.
HowTo: 1. Stand upright with a dumbbell in each hand. 2. Step forward with your right leg into a lunge while curling the dumbbells towards your shoulders. 3. Push back to the starting position and repeat with the left leg.

Title: Holman Weighted Double-Time Biceps Curl
Desc: The Holman Weighted Double-Time Biceps Curl is designed to increase bicep strength and endurance. This exercise involves performing curls at a faster pace with weights.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a dumbbell in each hand. 2. Curl both dumbbells simultaneously towards your shoulders at a quick pace. 3. Lower the dumbbells back down and repeat.

Title: Holman Heavy Right Arm Biceps Curl
Desc: The Holman Heavy Right Arm Biceps Curl targets the biceps of the right arm for strength development. It is an effective isolation exercise.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a dumbbell in your right hand. 2. Keep your elbow close to your torso and curl the dumbbell towards your shoulder. 3. Squeeze at the top, then lower the dumbbell back down.

Title: Holman Heavy Left Arm Biceps Curl
Desc: The Holman Heavy Left Arm Biceps Curl is aimed at strengthening the left bicep. This exercise isolates the bicep muscle for targeted development.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a dumbbell in your left hand. 2. Curl the dumbbell towards your shoulder while keeping your elbow stationary. 3. Lower the dumbbell back to the starting position and repeat.

Title: MetaBurn Dumbbell Drag Curl
Desc: The MetaBurn Dumbbell Drag Curl is an effective exercise to target the biceps while also engaging the forearms. It emphasizes the contraction of the biceps throughout the movement.
HowTo: 1. Stand with a dumbbell in each hand, arms at your sides. 2. Curl the weights up while keeping your elbows close to your body, dragging the dumbbells up along your torso. 3. Squeeze at the top, then lower the weights back down with control.

Title: MetaBurn Hammer Curl to Overhead Press
Desc: The MetaBurn Hammer Curl to Overhead Press combines two effective movements to build strength in the biceps and shoulders. This exercise helps in developing overall upper body strength.
HowTo: 1. Stand with a dumbbell in each hand, arms at your sides, palms facing in. 2. Perform a hammer curl by lifting the dumbbells to shoulder height. 3. Rotate your palms forward and press the dumbbells overhead. 4. Lower the weights back to the starting position.

Title: MetaBurn Biceps Curl To Lateral Raise
Desc: The MetaBurn Biceps Curl To Lateral Raise targets both the biceps and the shoulders in one fluid motion. This exercise promotes muscle growth and coordination.
HowTo: 1. Stand with a dumbbell in each hand, arms at your sides. 2. Perform a bicep curl to bring the weights to shoulder height. 3. From this position, lift the dumbbells out to the sides for a lateral raise. 4. Lower the weights back down and repeat.

Title: FYR2 Alternating Dumbbell Curl
Desc: The FYR2 Alternating Dumbbell Curl is a classic exercise for building bicep strength and size. It allows for a full range of motion and isolates each arm.
HowTo: 1. Stand with a dumbbell in each hand, arms at your sides. 2. Curl one dumbbell up towards your shoulder while keeping the other arm stationary. 3. Lower the dumbbell back down and repeat with the other arm.

Title: FYR2 Pulse Biceps Curl
Desc: The FYR2 Pulse Biceps Curl focuses on the biceps by using a pulsing motion to enhance muscle engagement. This technique helps in maximizing the contraction of the biceps.
