Desc: The 30-Degree Incline Dumbbell Press is an effective exercise for building upper chest strength. It targets the pectorals while also engaging the triceps and shoulders.
HowTo: 1. Set an adjustable bench to a 30-degree incline. 2. Sit on the bench with a dumbbell in each hand at shoulder height. 3. Press the dumbbells upward until your arms are fully extended. 4. Lower the dumbbells back to shoulder height.

Title: Spoto press
Desc: The Spoto press is a variation of the popular barbell exercise the bench press that builds strength and muscle in the chest, triceps, and shoulders. It differs from the bench press in that the lifter pauses for a few seconds at the bottom of the movement before pressing the bar back up. This pause removes all momentum and increases the time under tension for the chest and shoulder muscles to help develop upper-body musculature and strength.
HowTo: 1. Lie on a flat bench and grip the barbell with hands slightly wider than shoulder-width. 2. Lower the barbell to your chest and pause for a few seconds. 3. Press the barbell back up to the starting position.

Title: Kettlebell plyo push-up
Desc: The kettlebell plyo push-up is an explosive upper-body movement that uses a kettlebell primarily as a platform for the hands. A short step, dumbbell, or other stationary object could also be used in place of the kettlebell. It can be performed for reps or time, either for low reps to build explosive power or for higher reps for conditioning.
HowTo: 1. Start in a push-up position with your hands on kettlebells. 2. Lower your body into a push-up. 3. Explosively push up and lift your hands off the kettlebells. 4. Land back on the kettlebells and repeat.

Title: Extended Range One-Arm Kettlebell Floor Press
Desc: The Extended Range One-Arm Kettlebell Floor Press is a unilateral exercise that targets the chest and triceps while improving stability. It allows for a greater range of motion compared to traditional presses.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back on the floor with a kettlebell in one hand. 2. Press the kettlebell up while keeping your elbow close to your body. 3. Lower the kettlebell until your upper arm touches the floor. 4. Press back up to the starting position.

Title: Kettlebell alternating floor press
Desc: The kettlebell alternating floor press limits the range of motion you would achieve with a dumbbell or kettlebell bench press, but still targets the chest, triceps, and anterior delts. This allows you to build strength in the top portion of the lift, overload the triceps, and work on strengthening the shoulder stabilizers.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back on the floor with a kettlebell in one hand. 2. Press the kettlebell up towards the ceiling while keeping your elbow close to your body. 3. Lower the kettlebell back to the floor and alternate arms.

Title: One-Arm Kettlebell Floor Press
Desc: The One-Arm Kettlebell Floor Press is a unilateral exercise that targets the chest and triceps while also engaging the core for stability.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back on the floor with a kettlebell in one hand. 2. Press the kettlebell up towards the ceiling while keeping your elbow close to your body. 3. Lower the kettlebell back to the floor and repeat.

Title: Leg-Over Floor Press
Desc: The Leg-Over Floor Press is a variation of the floor press that adds a leg movement to engage the core and lower body.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back on the floor with a kettlebell in each hand. 2. Press the kettlebells up towards the ceiling while keeping your legs elevated. 3. Lower the kettlebells back to the floor and repeat.

Title: Band-suspended kettlebell bench press
Desc: The band-suspended kettlebell bench press is a bench press variation where kettlebells or weight plates are hung from the ends of a barbell by looped bands. The suspended weights can be in addition to normally loaded weight plates, or in the place of them. Because the instability of the weights makes the lift difficult, this bench press variety is a popular accessory movement for building the traditional bench press in powerlifting training.
HowTo: 1. Set up a barbell on a bench with bands attached to the ends. 2. Lie on the bench and grip the barbell with both hands. 3. Lower the barbell towards your chest and press it back up while controlling the suspended weights.

Title: FYR2 Push-Up to Kettlebell Hike Combo
Desc: The FYR2 Push-Up to Kettlebell Hike Combo is a dynamic exercise that combines a push-up with a kettlebell hike, engaging multiple muscle groups.
HowTo: 1. Start in a push-up position with a kettlebell placed beside you. 2. Perform a push-up, then reach for the kettlebell and hike it back between your legs. 3. Return to the push-up position and repeat.

Title: Pushups
Desc: The push-up is a popular bodyweight exercise that is commonly used in military and tactical physical fitness tests. Its a classic movement to build upper-body muscle and strength, emphasizing the chest, triceps, and shoulders, but also working the upper back and core.
Muscles: Chest, Triceps, Shoulders, Upper Back, Core
HowTo: 1. Start in a plank position with your hands slightly wider than shoulder-width apart. 2. Lower your body until your chest nearly touches the floor, then push back up to the starting position.

Title: Incline Push-Up
Desc: The hands-elevated push-up is a variation on the push-up, a body-weight standard. The hands are elevated, so that your body is aligned at an angle to the floor rather than parallel.
HowTo: 1. Place your hands on an elevated surface, such as a bench. 2. Keep your body straight and lower your chest towards the surface, then push back up.

Title: Hands-elevated push-up
Desc: The hands-elevated push-up is a variation on the classic push-up where the hands are placed on a bench or other elevated surface. Having the hands higher than the feet makes it easier than push-ups on the floor, but also puts the emphasis more on the triceps. It can be used as a substitute for floor push-ups or as a mechanical dropset after maxing out on floor push-ups.
HowTo: 1. Position your hands on a bench or elevated surface, keeping your feet on the ground. 2. Lower your body towards the bench, keeping your elbows close to your body, then push back up.

Title: Decline Push-Up
Desc: The feet-elevated push-up is a variation on the push-up, a body-weight standard. The feet are elevated, so that your body is aligned at an angle to the floor rather than parallel.
HowTo: 1. Place your feet on an elevated surface and hands on the ground in a plank position. 2. Lower your body towards the ground, then push back up to the starting position.

Title: Single-Arm Push-Up
Desc: The single-arm push-up is a challenging variation of the traditional push-up that requires significant strength and stability. It targets the chest, triceps, and shoulders while also engaging the core.
HowTo: 1. Start in a plank position with one arm behind your back. 2. Lower your body towards the ground with the other arm, then push back up to the starting position.

Title: Close push-up to wide push-up
Desc: The close push-up to wide push-up combines two variations of a push-up to emphasize the strengthening of different muscles. The close push-up emphasizes the triceps, while the wide push-up emphasizes the chest and shoulders.
HowTo: 1. Start in a close push-up position with your hands close together. 2. Lower your body towards the ground, then push back up and transition to a wide push-up position by moving your hands wider apart. 3. Lower your body again and push back up to complete the repetition.

Title: Wide-grip hands-elevated push-up
Desc: The wide-grip hands-elevated push-up is a variation on the elevated push-up performed with the hands farther apart than with a standard push-up. Having the hands higher than the feet makes it easier than wide-grip push-ups on the floor, but the extra width also puts more emphasis on the chest muscles. It can be used as a substitute for wide-grip floor push-ups, or as a mechanical dropset after maxing out on floor push-ups.
HowTo: 1. Begin in a plank position with your hands elevated and wider than shoulder-width apart. 2. Lower your chest towards the elevated surface, keeping your body straight. 3. Push back up to the starting position.

Title: Push-Ups With Feet On An Exercise Ball
Desc: Push-Ups With Feet On An Exercise Ball are a challenging variation that engages the core and stabilizing muscles while targeting the chest and shoulders.
HowTo: 1. Start in a push-up position with your feet resting on an exercise ball. 2. Lower your body towards the ground while keeping your core tight. 3. Push back up to the starting position, maintaining balance on the ball.

Title: Feet-elevated push-up
Desc: The feet-elevated push-up is a variation on the push-up, a bodyweight standard. The feet are elevated so that your body is aligned at an angle to the floor rather than parallel. This makes it more difficult than push-ups on the floor, but also puts more emphasis on the shoulder muscles. It is often used as a bodyweight substitute for incline presses, or as a burnout movement for a chest or shoulder workout.
HowTo: 1. Start in a push-up position with your feet elevated on a bench or platform. 2. Lower your body towards the ground while keeping your core engaged. 3. Push back up to the starting position.

Title: Isometric Wipers
Desc: The typewriter push-up is an advanced push-up variation where the hands are extra wide and you lower toward each hand in alternating reps. It is more challenging to each working arm than traditional push-ups and also stretches and challenges the chest.
HowTo: 1. Begin in a wide push-up position. 2. Lower your body towards one hand while keeping the other arm straight. 3. Push back up and alternate to the other side.

Title: Clock push-up
Desc: The clock push-up is a series of regular push-ups performed one at a time, moving your hands one step to the side between each one until you've completed a full circle. It targets the same muscles as traditional push-ups, such as the chest, triceps, and shoulders, but adds an endurance and core challenge to traditional push-ups.
HowTo: 1. Start in a push-up position with your hands shoulder-width apart. 2. Perform a push-up, then move your hands one step to the side and repeat until you complete a full circle.

Title: Incline Push-Up Depth Jump
Desc: The incline push-up depth jump is a dynamic exercise that combines an incline push-up with a jump, targeting upper body strength and explosiveness.
HowTo: 1. Start in an incline push-up position with your hands on an elevated surface. 2. Perform a push-up, then explosively push off the surface and jump, landing back in the push-up position.

Title: Push-Up Wide
Desc: The wide push-up is a variation of the push-up with the hands wider than shoulder-width apart. It targets upper-body muscle groups including the chest, shoulders, and triceps, but has more of a chest emphasis than narrower-grip push-up variations. If wide push-ups lead to pain in the front of your shoulder, opt for a narrower version.
HowTo: 1. Begin in a push-up position with your hands wider than shoulder-width apart. 2. Lower your body until your chest nearly touches the ground, then push back up to the starting position.

Title: Sphinx push-up
Desc: The sphinx push-up is a difficult variation of the push-up that ends with the forearms on the ground in front of the body, rather than with the chest on the ground. It puts more stress on the triceps than traditional push-ups. It can be performed for time or reps in any bodyweight workout or during any arms-focused portion of a workout.
HowTo: 1. Start in a push-up position, but lower your body until your forearms are on the ground. 2. Push back up to the starting position while keeping your core engaged.

Title: Close-Hands Push-Up
Desc: The close push-up is an upper-body exercise that targets the chest, triceps, and shoulders. The close hand position places more emphasis on the triceps.
HowTo: 1. Begin in a push-up position with your hands close together. 2. Lower your body until your chest nearly touches your hands, then push back up to the starting position.

Title: Tiger-bend push-up
Desc: The tiger-bend push-up is an advanced push-up variation where you shift onto your forearms at the bottom position and then back onto your hands and up again. It targets the triceps far more than regular push-ups.
HowTo: 1. Start in a push-up position. 2. Lower yourself down until your chest is close to the ground, then shift onto your forearms. 3. Push back up onto your hands to return to the starting position.

Title: Plyo push-up
Desc: The plyo push-up is a bodyweight exercise aimed at increasing upper-body power and strength. It targets the muscles of the chest, triceps, and shoulders, and can be trained in low reps for power and strength, or higher reps for conditioning.
HowTo: 1. Start in a standard push-up position. 2. Lower your body down, then explosively push up off the ground, allowing your hands to leave the floor. 3. Land softly and go directly into the next rep.

Title: Close-grip hands-elevated push-up
Desc: The close-grip hands-elevated push-up is a variation on the classic push-up where the hands are placed on a bench or other elevated surface. Having the hands higher than the feet makes it easier than close-grip push-ups on the floor, but also puts the emphasis more on the triceps. It can be used as a substitute for floor push-ups or close-grip push-ups, or as a mechanical dropset after maxing out on floor push-ups.
HowTo: 1. Place your hands on an elevated surface, shoulder-width apart. 2. Lower your body towards the elevated surface, keeping your elbows close to your body. 3. Push back up to the starting position.

Title: Suspended push-up
Desc: The suspended push-up is a bodyweight pushing exercise performed on a suspension strap system or gymnastic rings. It targets the chest, shoulders, and triceps, but is also challenging to the core and upper back. It can work in traditional strength and muscle-building rep ranges or for higher reps.
Muscles: chest, shoulders, triceps, core, upper back
HowTo: 1. Adjust the suspension straps to a suitable length. 2. Grab the handles and lean back, keeping your body straight. 3. Lower your chest towards your hands and then push back up to the starting position.

Title: Push Up to Side Plank
Desc: The push-up to side plank is an upper-body and core-focused exercise combining two popular bodyweight movements. It targets the chest, triceps, and shoulders with the push-up, and the obliques and hip external rotator muscles with the side plank. It can be performed as part of a dynamic warm-up or any bodyweight strength-training workout.
Muscles: chest, triceps, shoulders, obliques, hip external rotators
HowTo: 1. Start in a push-up position. 2. Perform a push-up, and as you rise, rotate your body to one side into a side plank position. 3. Return to the push-up position and repeat on the other side.

Title: Isometric Chest Squeezes
Desc: Isometric chest squeezes are performed by pressing the palms of your hands together in front of your chest. This exercise helps to engage and strengthen the chest muscles without movement.
HowTo: 1. Stand or sit comfortably. 2. Place your palms together in front of your chest. 3. Press your palms together as hard as you can for a set duration. 4. Release and repeat.

Title: Side-to-side push-up
Desc: The side-to-side push-up is a variation of the push-up exercise where you side-step the opposite hand and foot and perform a push-up.
HowTo: 1. Start in a push-up position. 2. Move your right hand and right foot to the right side. 3. Perform a push-up. 4. Return to the starting position and repeat on the left side.

Title: Typewriter push-up
Desc: The typewriter push-up is an advanced push-up variation where the hands are extra wide and you lower toward each hand in alternating reps. It is more challenging to each working arm than traditional push-ups and also stretches and challenges the chest.
HowTo: 1. Start in a wide push-up position. 2. Lower your body toward your right hand while keeping your left hand straight. 3. Push back up and lower toward your left hand. 4. Alternate sides for the desired number of reps.

Title: Diamond push-up
Desc: The diamond push-up is an advanced variation of the push-up exercise performed with the hands in a diamond shape. It increases the challenge to the triceps, but also targets the chest and shoulders.
HowTo: 1. Start in a push-up position with your hands forming a diamond shape under your chest. 2. Lower your body toward the diamond. 3. Push back up to the starting position. 4. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Judo push-up
Desc: The judo push-up is an advanced push-up variation that blends elements of the yoga poses downward- and upward-facing dog. This movement increases the demands on the shoulders, but also has mobility benefits. It can work in a dynamic warm-up or mobility-focused workout, but also in bodyweight strength training.
HowTo: 1. Start in a downward dog position. 2. Shift your weight forward into a push-up position. 3. Lower your body to the ground. 4. Push back up and return to downward dog. 5. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Superman Push-Up
Desc: The Superman Push-Up is a bodyweight exercise that combines a push-up with a superman movement, engaging the upper body and core. It enhances strength and stability while targeting the chest and triceps.
HowTo: 1. Start in a push-up position. 2. As you lower your body, extend your arms forward and lift your legs off the ground. 3. Push back up while keeping your arms extended. 4. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Wide push-up
Desc: The wide push-up is a variation of the push-up with the hands wider than shoulder-width apart. It targets upper-body muscle groups including the chest, shoulders, and triceps, but has more of a chest emphasis than narrower-grip push-up variations. If wide push-ups lead to pain in the front of your shoulder, opt for a narrower version.
HowTo: 1. Start in a plank position with your hands placed wider than shoulder-width apart. 2. Lower your body until your chest nearly touches the ground. 3. Push back up to the starting position. 4. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: One-Arm Push-Up
Desc: The One-Arm Push-Up is an advanced variation of the traditional push-up that requires significant strength and balance. It primarily targets the chest, triceps, and shoulders while engaging the core for stability.
HowTo: 1. Start in a push-up position with one hand behind your back. 2. Lower your body while keeping the other arm straight. 3. Push back up to the starting position. 4. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions, then switch arms.

Title: Clapping Push-Up
Desc: Also known as a plyo push-up, the clapping push-up is a bodyweight exercise aimed at increasing upper-body power and strength. It targets the muscles of the chest, triceps, and shoulders, and can be trained in low reps for power and strength, or higher reps for conditioning.
HowTo: 1. Start in a push-up position. 2. Lower your body towards the ground. 3. Push up explosively and clap your hands together before landing back in the push-up position. 4. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Staggered push-up
Desc: The staggered push-up is a variation of the push-up exercise where your hand position is staggered, with one hand forward and one back. It targets the same muscles as a traditional push-up, including the chest, triceps, and shoulders, but is more difficult to the rear arm and core.
HowTo: 1. Start in a push-up position with one hand positioned forward and the other hand back. 2. Lower your body until your chest nearly touches the ground. 3. Push back up to the starting position. 4. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions, then switch hand positions.

Title: Reverse-grip hands-elevated push-up
Desc: The reverse-grip hands-elevated push-up is a bodyweight exercise performed on a Smith machine or other elevated surface. It targets the chest, triceps, and shoulders. It can work as a regression of floor reverse-grip push-ups, or in a progressive mechanical dropset moving the bar up once you reach failure at a lower height.
HowTo: 1. Set the bar on a Smith machine at an elevated height. 2. Grip the bar with a reverse grip (palms facing you). 3. Lower your body towards the bar while keeping your elbows close to your body. 4. Push back up to the starting position.

Title: Triple Clap Push-Up
Desc: The Triple Clap Push-Up is a dynamic variation of the traditional push-up that incorporates explosive movements.
HowTo: 1. Start in a standard push-up position. 2. Lower your body to the ground. 3. Push up explosively, clapping your hands three times before landing back in the push-up position. 4. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Side kick-through push-up
Desc: The side kick-through push-up is a full-body movement that begins in a bear crawl position and ends with a leg kicked out to the side, with a push-up performed between kick-throughs. It is commonly performed for reps or timed bodyweight circuits and animal-style flows, but can also work on its own or as part of a dynamic warm-up or mobility sequence.
HowTo: 1. Start in a bear crawl position with your hands under your shoulders and knees under your hips. 2. Perform a push-up. 3. As you push up, kick one leg out to the side. 4. Return to the starting position and repeat on the other side.

Title: Swimming
Desc: Swimming is a full-body exercise that engages multiple muscle groups and improves cardiovascular fitness.
HowTo: 1. Enter the water and choose your preferred stroke (freestyle, breaststroke, etc.). 2. Use your arms and legs to propel yourself through the water. 3. Focus on maintaining a steady rhythm and breathing technique. 4. Swim for a set distance or time.

Title: FYR Push-Up
Desc: The push-up is a popular bodyweight exercise that is commonly used in military and tactical physical fitness tests. Its a classic movement to build upper-body muscle and strength, emphasizing the chest, triceps, and shoulders, but also working the upper back and core.
Muscles: Chest, Triceps, Shoulders, Upper Back, Core
HowTo: 1. Start in a plank position with your hands slightly wider than shoulder-width apart. 2. Lower your body until your chest nearly touches the ground. 3. Push back up to the starting position. 4. Keep your body in a straight line throughout the movement.

Title: Frog push-up
Desc: The frog push-up is an advanced push-up variation that is performed with the legs bent and butt in the air. It heavily targets the triceps and shoulders, but is also quite challenging to the core.
HowTo: 1. Start in a push-up position with your legs bent and feet off the ground. 2. Lower your body towards the ground while keeping your elbows close to your sides, then push back up to the starting position.

Title: Wide push-up plank hold
Desc: The wide push-up plank hold is a full-body exercise targeting the core. Because the arms aren't directly under the body, it can be more difficult than traditional push-up planks, especially for the upper back and chest, but also for the core.
HowTo: 1. Start in a plank position with your hands wider than shoulder-width apart. 2. Hold the position, engaging your core and keeping your body in a straight line.

Title: Close push-up
Desc: The close push-up is an upper-body exercise that targets the chest, triceps, and shoulders. The close hand position places more emphasis on the triceps.
HowTo: 1. Start in a push-up position with your hands close together, directly under your shoulders. 2. Lower your body towards the ground, keeping your elbows close to your sides, then push back up to the starting position.

Title: Push-Up - Gethin Variation
Desc: The push-up is a popular bodyweight exercise that is commonly used in military and tactical physical fitness tests. Its a classic movement to build upper-body muscle and strength, emphasizing the chest, triceps, and shoulders, but also working the upper back and core.
Muscles: chest, triceps, shoulders, upper back, core
HowTo: 1. Start in a plank position with your hands shoulder-width apart. 2. Lower your body until your chest nearly touches the floor, then push back up to the starting position.

Title: HM Incline Push-Up On Chair
Desc: The HM Incline Push-Up On Chair is a variation of the standard push-up that targets the upper body while being easier on the shoulders. It is performed with hands elevated on a chair, making it suitable for various fitness levels.
HowTo: 1. Place your hands on the edge of a chair, shoulder-width apart. 2. Lower your body towards the chair, keeping your elbows close to your sides, then push back up to the starting position.

Title: HM Push-Up
Desc: The HM Push-Up is a variation of the traditional push-up that focuses on building upper body strength. It primarily targets the chest, triceps, and shoulders.
Muscles: Chest, Triceps, Shoulders, Upper Back, Core
HowTo: 1. Start in a plank position with your hands slightly wider than shoulder-width apart. 2. Lower your body until your chest nearly touches the ground, keeping your elbows at a 45-degree angle. 3. Push back up to the starting position.

Title: HM Push-Plank
Desc: The HM Push-Plank is a core-strengthening exercise that also engages the shoulders and arms. It enhances stability and endurance in the upper body.
HowTo: 1. Start in a push-up position with your hands directly under your shoulders. 2. Engage your core and hold the position, keeping your body in a straight line from head to heels. 3. Hold for as long as possible while maintaining form.

Title: AM Chest Dips
Desc: The chest dip is a chest-building exercise in which the lifter hangs between two parallel handles. Leaning the torso slightly forward shifts the emphasis from the triceps to the chest.
HowTo: 1. Grasp the parallel bars with your palms facing inward and arms straight. 2. Lower your body by bending your elbows until your upper arms are parallel to the ground. 3. Push yourself back up to the starting position.

Title: Push-up
Desc: The push-up is a popular bodyweight exercise that is commonly used in military and tactical physical fitness tests. Its a classic movement to build upper-body muscle and strength, emphasizing the chest, triceps, and shoulders, but also working the upper back and core.
Muscles: Chest, Triceps, Shoulders, Upper Back, Core
HowTo: 1. Start in a plank position with your hands slightly wider than shoulder-width apart. 2. Lower your body until your chest nearly touches the ground, keeping your elbows at a 45-degree angle. 3. Push back up to the starting position.

Title: UP Push-up
Desc: The push-up is a popular bodyweight exercise that is commonly used in military and tactical physical fitness tests. Its a classic movement to build upper-body muscle and strength, emphasizing the chest, triceps, and shoulders, but also working the upper back and core.
Muscles: Chest, Triceps, Shoulders, Upper Back, Core
HowTo: 1. Start in a plank position with your hands slightly wider than shoulder-width apart. 2. Lower your body until your chest nearly touches the ground, keeping your elbows at a 45-degree angle. 3. Push back up to the starting position.

Title: UN Push-Up
Desc: The UN Push-Up is a variation of the traditional push-up that targets the chest and arms. It helps build upper body strength and stability.
HowTo: 1. Start in a plank position with your hands slightly wider than shoulder-width apart. 2. Lower your body until your chest nearly touches the floor. 3. Push back up to the starting position.

Title: UNS Foam Roll Pecs
Desc: The UNS Foam Roll Pecs exercise is designed to release tension in the chest muscles. It improves flexibility and mobility in the upper body.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your stomach with a foam roller positioned under your chest. 2. Roll back and forth gently, focusing on tight areas. 3. Adjust your body position to target different parts of the chest.

Title: UN Hands Elevated Push-Up
Desc: The UN Hands Elevated Push-Up is a variation that reduces the difficulty of a standard push-up. It is effective for building upper body strength.
HowTo: 1. Place your hands on an elevated surface like a bench. 2. Keep your body straight and lower your chest towards the surface. 3. Push back up to the starting position.

Title: Holman Seal Drag to Push-Up
Desc: The Holman Seal Drag to Push-Up combines a dragging motion with a push-up to engage multiple muscle groups. It enhances strength and coordination.
HowTo: 1. Start in a plank position with your feet on a towel or slider. 2. Drag your feet towards your hands while maintaining a plank. 3. Perform a push-up, then return to the starting position.

Title: Holman Hand-Elevated Push-Up with Hand Row
Desc: The Holman Hand-Elevated Push-Up with Hand Row is an advanced variation that incorporates a rowing motion. It targets the chest, arms, and back.
HowTo: 1. Start in a plank position with one hand elevated on a surface and the other on the ground. 2. Perform a push-up. 3. After the push-up, row the elevated hand towards your torso. 4. Alternate sides.

Title: Holman Push-Up
Desc: The Holman Push-Up is a variation of the traditional push-up that emphasizes upper body strength. It targets the chest, shoulders, and triceps while also engaging the core.
HowTo: 1. Start in a plank position with your hands shoulder-width apart. 2. Lower your body until your chest nearly touches the floor. 3. Push back up to the starting position.

Title: Holman Slow Hips-Up Chest Press
Desc: The Holman Slow Hips-Up Chest Press is a controlled exercise that focuses on the chest and triceps. It helps build strength and stability in the upper body.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back with your knees bent and feet flat on the ground. 2. Hold weights in each hand above your chest. 3. Slowly lower the weights while lifting your hips off the ground, then press back up.

Title: Holman Jump-Out Push-Up with Hand Hop Back
Desc: The Holman Jump-Out Push-Up with Hand Hop Back is a dynamic push-up variation that combines strength and agility. It engages the chest, triceps, and core while improving coordination.
HowTo: 1. Start in a push-up position. 2. Perform a push-up, then jump your feet out wide. 3. Jump your hands back towards your feet and return to the push-up position.

Title: Holman Froggy Push-Up to Donkey Kick
Desc: The Holman Froggy Push-Up to Donkey Kick is a unique exercise that targets the chest and engages the glutes. It combines upper body strength with lower body activation.
HowTo: 1. Start in a push-up position. 2. Lower your body into a push-up, then as you push up, kick one leg back into a donkey kick. 3. Alternate legs with each repetition.

Title: Holman Push-Up to Sit Back
Desc: The Holman Push-Up to Sit Back is a compound movement that strengthens the chest and engages the core. It also improves flexibility and balance.
HowTo: 1. Start in a push-up position. 2. Perform a push-up, then sit back on your heels while extending your arms forward. 3. Return to the push-up position and repeat.

Title: Holman Sit Back Push-Up
Desc: The Holman Sit Back Push-Up is a variation of the traditional push-up that emphasizes strength in the upper body. It engages the chest, triceps, and shoulders effectively.
HowTo: 1. Start in a push-up position with your hands shoulder-width apart. 2. Sit back on your heels while lowering your chest towards the ground. 3. Push back up to the starting position.

Title: Holman Alternating Staggered Push-Up
Desc: The Holman Alternating Staggered Push-Up challenges your stability and strength by alternating hand positions. This variation targets the chest, triceps, and shoulders while engaging the core.
HowTo: 1. Start in a push-up position with one hand forward and the other back. 2. Lower your body towards the ground, then push back up. 3. Switch hand positions and repeat.

Title: Holman Foot-Up Diving Push-Up
Desc: The Holman Foot-Up Diving Push-Up is an advanced push-up variation that increases the challenge on the upper body. It requires strength and stability while targeting the chest and triceps.
HowTo: 1. Start in a push-up position with your feet elevated on a surface. 2. Lower your chest towards the ground while diving forward. 3. Push back up to the starting position.

Title: Holman Narrow Push-Up
Desc: The Holman Narrow Push-Up focuses on the triceps and inner chest by using a narrower hand placement. This variation is effective for building upper body strength.
HowTo: 1. Start in a push-up position with your hands close together under your chest. 2. Lower your body towards the ground, keeping your elbows close to your sides. 3. Push back up to the starting position.

Title: Holman Dynamo Push-Up
Desc: The Holman Dynamo Push-Up is a dynamic push-up variation that incorporates explosive movement. It is designed to build strength and power in the upper body.
HowTo: 1. Start in a push-up position. 2. Lower your body and then push up explosively, lifting your hands off the ground. 3. Land softly and repeat.

Title: Holman Jump to Push-Up
Desc: The Holman Jump to Push-Up is a dynamic exercise that combines a jump with a push-up to enhance upper body power and explosiveness. It is ideal for athletes looking to improve their performance.
HowTo: Start in a standing position, jump forward into a plank position, perform a push-up, then jump back to the starting position.

Title: Holman Foot-Elevated Push-Up
Desc: The Holman Foot-Elevated Push-Up is a variation of the standard push-up that increases the intensity by elevating the feet. This exercise targets the upper chest and shoulders more effectively.
HowTo: Place your feet on an elevated surface, keep your body straight, lower yourself into a push-up, and push back up to the starting position.

Title: Holman Feet-Elevated Push-Up
Desc: The Holman Feet-Elevated Push-Up is similar to the foot-elevated push-up, focusing on the upper chest and shoulder muscles. It is a challenging variation that builds strength and stability.
HowTo: With your feet elevated, maintain a straight line from head to heels, lower your body to the ground in a push-up, and return to the starting position.

Title: Total Fitness Plyo Push-Up
Desc: The plyo push-up is a bodyweight exercise aimed at increasing upper-body power and strength. It targets the muscles of the chest, triceps, and shoulders, and can be trained in low reps for power and strength, or higher reps for conditioning.
HowTo: Start in a push-up position, lower your body, then push explosively off the ground, allowing your hands to leave the floor before landing back into the push-up position.

Title: Scapular push-up
Desc: The scapular push-up is an upper-body exercise aimed at increasing the stability of the scapulae and mobility in the shoulders. It is often performed as part of a dynamic warm-up before an upper-body workout, or as part of a mobility session.
HowTo: Start in a plank position, keep your arms straight, and retract and protract your shoulder blades without bending your elbows.

Title: King Maker Push-up
Desc: The push-up is a popular bodyweight exercise that is commonly used in military and tactical physical fitness tests. Its a classic movement to build upper-body muscle and strength, emphasizing the chest, triceps, and shoulders, but also working the upper back and core.
Muscles: Chest, Triceps, Shoulders, Upper Back, Core
HowTo: 1. Start in a plank position with your hands slightly wider than shoulder-width apart. 2. Lower your body until your chest nearly touches the floor, then push back up to the starting position.

Title: Warrior push-up
Desc: The warrior push-up is a series of push-up and plank variations combined into a single sequence. They include a Judo push-up, plank, side plank, mountain climber, diamond push-up, and regular push-up. Done together, they tax the upper-body muscles from different angles and increase time under tension for the entire body.
HowTo: 1. Begin in a push-up position. 2. Perform a Judo push-up, followed by a plank, then transition to a side plank, mountain climber, diamond push-up, and finish with a regular push-up.

Title: Taylor Roll-Over Push-Up
Desc: The Taylor Roll-Over Push-Up is a variation of the standard push-up that incorporates a rolling motion. It challenges stability and engages multiple muscle groups.
HowTo: 1. Start in a push-up position. 2. Lower your body to the floor, then as you push up, roll to one side and extend your arm overhead. 3. Return to the push-up position and repeat on the other side.

Title: Taylor One-Arm Push-Up Slow Negative
Desc: The Taylor One-Arm Push-Up Slow Negative focuses on strength and control. It emphasizes the chest and triceps while requiring significant core stability.
HowTo: 1. Start in a push-up position with one arm behind your back. 2. Slowly lower your body to the ground with the working arm, then push back up.

Title: 30 Chest Push-Up To Isometric Hold
Desc: The 30 Chest Push-Up To Isometric Hold is a challenging exercise that builds endurance and strength in the chest and triceps. It combines push-ups with an isometric hold for added intensity.
HowTo: 1. Perform 30 standard push-ups. 2. After the last push-up, hold the push-up position with your chest just above the ground for as long as possible.

Title: 30 Chest Push-Up
Desc: The Chest Push-Up is a bodyweight exercise that primarily targets the chest muscles. It also engages the triceps and shoulders, making it an effective upper body workout.
HowTo: 1. Start in a plank position with your hands slightly wider than shoulder-width apart. 2. Lower your body until your chest nearly touches the floor. 3. Push back up to the starting position.

Title: 30 Chest Bench Push-Up
Desc: The Chest Bench Push-Up is a variation of the standard push-up that involves a bench for added stability. It targets the chest and arms while improving upper body strength.
HowTo: 1. Place your hands on a bench, slightly wider than shoulder-width. 2. Lower your chest towards the bench, keeping your body straight. 3. Push back up to the starting position.

Title: MetaBurn 3-Phase Push-Up
Desc: The MetaBurn 3-Phase Push-Up is a dynamic exercise that targets the chest and improves overall upper body strength. It involves three distinct phases to enhance muscle engagement.
HowTo: 1. Begin in a standard push-up position. 2. Lower your body, then push up and bring one hand to your shoulder, alternating sides. 3. Return to the push-up position and repeat.

Title: MetaBurn Fast Feet To Push-Up
Desc: The MetaBurn Fast Feet To Push-Up combines cardio and strength training, targeting the chest while also elevating your heart rate. This exercise enhances agility and upper body strength.
HowTo: 1. Start in a standing position. 2. Quickly shuffle your feet in place for a few seconds, then drop into a push-up. 3. Push back up and return to the shuffling position.

Title: MetaBurn Judo Push-Up To Pike Push-Up
Desc: The MetaBurn Judo Push-Up To Pike Push-Up is a challenging exercise that targets the chest and shoulders while improving flexibility. It incorporates two different push-up styles for a comprehensive workout.
HowTo: 1. Start in a push-up position. 2. Perform a judo push-up by lowering your body and shifting your weight forward, then push back up. 3. Transition into a pike position and perform a pike push-up.

Title: MetaBurn Pike Push-Up
Desc: The Pike Push-Up is a variation of the traditional push-up that emphasizes the shoulders. It helps build upper body strength and stability.
HowTo: 1. Start in a downward dog position with your hips raised and your hands shoulder-width apart. 2. Lower your head towards the ground by bending your elbows, keeping your body straight. 3. Push back up to the starting position.

Title: MetaBurn Push-Up To Frogger
Desc: The Push-Up To Frogger combines upper body strength with a dynamic movement to engage the legs and core. It's a great exercise for improving overall fitness and endurance.
HowTo: 1. Start in a push-up position. 2. Perform a push-up, then jump your feet towards your hands, landing in a squat position. 3. Jump back to the push-up position and repeat.

Title: MetaBurn Push-Up With Hand Side-Step
Desc: The Push-Up With Hand Side-Step adds a lateral movement to the traditional push-up, increasing the challenge for the upper body and core. This exercise enhances stability and coordination.
HowTo: 1. Start in a push-up position. 2. Perform a push-up, then step your right hand and foot to the right side. 3. Repeat the push-up and step to the left side.

Title: MetaBurn Push-Up With Hand-Up Rotation
Desc: The Push-Up With Hand-Up Rotation targets the chest and shoulders while improving rotational strength. This exercise is excellent for enhancing upper body mobility.
HowTo: 1. Start in a push-up position. 2. Perform a push-up, then rotate your body to one side, raising the corresponding hand towards the ceiling. 3. Return to the push-up position and repeat on the other side.

Title: MetaBurn Sphinx Push-Up
Desc: The Sphinx Push-Up is a unique variation that focuses on the triceps and chest while maintaining a plank position. It helps build strength and stability in the upper body.
HowTo: 1. Start in a forearm plank position. 2. Push up onto your hands one at a time, then lower back down to your forearms. 3. Repeat the movement while keeping your core engaged.

Title: MetaBurn Spiderman Push-Up
Desc: The MetaBurn Spiderman Push-Up is a dynamic variation of the traditional push-up that incorporates a leg movement. It targets the upper body while also engaging the core and improving overall stability.
Muscles: Chest, Triceps, Shoulders, Core, Upper Back
HowTo: 1. Start in a push-up position. 2. As you lower your body, bring your right knee towards your right elbow. 3. Push back up to the starting position and repeat on the left side. 4. Continue alternating sides.

Title: Roberston Push-up to Down Dog
Desc: The Robertson Push-up to Down Dog combines a push-up with a yoga pose, enhancing both strength and flexibility. This exercise engages multiple muscle groups while promoting a full range of motion.
Muscles: Chest, Triceps, Shoulders, Core, Upper Back
HowTo: 1. Begin in a push-up position. 2. Perform a push-up. 3. After pushing up, shift your hips back and up into the Down Dog position. 4. Hold for a moment, then return to the push-up position and repeat.

Title: FYR2 Push-Up-Breakdancer-Shoulder-Tap Complex
Desc: The FYR2 Push-Up-Breakdancer-Shoulder-Tap Complex is a challenging exercise that combines strength and coordination. It targets the upper body and core while improving balance and stability.
Muscles: Chest, Triceps, Shoulders, Core, Upper Back
HowTo: 1. Start in a push-up position. 2. Perform a push-up. 3. After the push-up, rotate your body to one side and lift your leg, tapping your shoulder with the opposite hand. 4. Return to the push-up position and repeat on the other side.

Title: ACFT Hand-release push-up
Desc: The hand-release push-up is a variation of the push-up, a popular bodyweight exercise commonly used in military and tactical physical fitness tests. Its a movement to build upper-body strength and endurance, emphasizing the chest, triceps, and shoulders, but also working the upper back and core. This specific exercise is part of the new Army Combat Fitness Test or ACFT.
Muscles: Chest, Triceps, Shoulders, Core, Upper Back
HowTo: 1. Start in a push-up position. 2. Lower your body to the ground, releasing your hands from the floor at the bottom. 3. Place your hands back on the ground and push up to the starting position. 4. Repeat.

Title: 1.5-rep push-up
Desc: The 1.5-rep push-up is a more difficult variation of the push-up, commonly used to train for military and tactical physical fitness tests. It builds upper-body muscle and strength, emphasizing the chest, core, upper back, triceps, and shoulders.
Muscles: Chest, Triceps, Shoulders, Core, Upper Back
HowTo: 1. Begin in a push-up position. 2. Lower your body to the ground. 3. Push halfway up, then lower back down. 4. Push all the way up to the starting position. 5. Repeat.

Title: ACFT Triple-clap push-up
Desc: The triple-clap push-up is an explosive bodyweight exercise aimed at increasing upper-body power and strength. It is an advanced exercise targeting the muscles of the chest, triceps, core, and shoulders.
HowTo: 1. Start in a push-up position. 2. Lower your body to the ground. 3. Push up explosively while clapping your hands together before returning to the starting position.

Title: ACFT Superman push-up
Desc: The Superman push-up is an explosive bodyweight exercise aimed at increasing upper-body power and strength. It is an advanced exercise targeting the muscles of the chest, triceps, shoulders, and core that involves pressing up off the floor and lifting the hands and feet off the ground simultaneously at the top of the movement.
HowTo: 1. Begin in a push-up position. 2. Lower your body to the ground. 3. As you push up, lift your hands and feet off the ground simultaneously, then return to the starting position.

Title: Cross-over push-up
Desc: The cross-over push-up is a variation of the push-up that adds a degree of difficulty by stepping over a small box or step between repetitions. It can be performed for time or for reps and creates a greater core stabilization challenge by forcing the core muscles to maintain the a neutral spine throughout the movement.
HowTo: 1. Start in a push-up position with your feet on a small box or step. 2. Perform a push-up while stepping over the box with one hand and then the other, maintaining a neutral spine.

Title: Leverage Incline Chest Press
Desc: The Leverage Incline Chest Press is a strength exercise targeting the upper chest muscles. It is performed on a machine that allows for a controlled pressing motion.
HowTo: 1. Sit on the incline chest press machine with your back against the pad. 2. Grasp the handles and press them forward until your arms are fully extended. 3. Slowly return to the starting position.

Title: Butterfly
Desc: The machine chest fly is an exercise targeting the chest. The motion is often compared to bear-hugging a tree trunk. In chest workouts, this exercise often follows compound moves such as the bench press.
HowTo: 1. Sit on the machine with your back against the pad. 2. Grasp the handles and open your arms wide. 3. Bring the handles together in front of your chest, then return to the starting position.

Title: Leverage Chest Press
Desc: The machine chest press is an upper body exercise targeting the pectoral muscles.
HowTo: 1. Sit on the machine with your back against the pad. 2. Grasp the handles and push them forward until your arms are fully extended. 3. Slowly return to the starting position.

Title: Decline Smith Press
Desc: The Smith machine decline bench press is a machine-based exercise targeting the chest muscles, particularly the lower pectoral muscles. The Smith machine mimics a barbell but provides more stability. This movement is often performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of a chest or upper-body workout.
HowTo: 1. Lie on the decline bench and grasp the barbell with a grip slightly wider than shoulder-width. 2. Lower the barbell to your chest, keeping your elbows at a 45-degree angle. 3. Push the barbell back to the starting position.

Title: Smith machine bench press
Desc: The Smith machine bench press is a machine-based movement targeting the chest. The Smith machine mimics a barbell but provides more stability. This movement can be programmed in low reps for strength or higher reps for muscle and strength endurance. It is often performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of a chest or upper-body focused workout.
HowTo: 1. Lie on the bench with your feet flat on the ground. 2. Grasp the barbell with a grip slightly wider than shoulder-width and lower it to your chest. 3. Push the barbell back up to the starting position.

Title: Leverage Decline Chest Press
Desc: The Leverage Decline Chest Press is a machine-based exercise targeting the chest muscles. It is performed on a decline bench to emphasize the lower pectorals.
HowTo: 1. Adjust the seat height and sit on the machine with your back against the pad. 2. Grasp the handles and press them forward until your arms are fully extended. 3. Slowly return to the starting position.

Title: Machine chest press
Desc: The machine chest press is a machine-based exercise targeting the chest. It approximates the motion of a bench press but is usually performed facing forward and seated upright. Many machines offer multiple grip options, such as overhand, neutral (palms facing), or underhand. The chest press is often performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of a pre-exhaust or muscle-building upper-body workout.
HowTo: 1. Sit on the machine and adjust the seat if necessary. 2. Grasp the handles and push them forward until your arms are fully extended. 3. Slowly return to the starting position.

Title: Smith Machine Incline Bench Press
Desc: The Smith machine incline bench press is a machine-based movement targeting the chest, particularly the upper chest. The Smith machine mimics a barbell but provides more stability. This movement can be programmed in low reps for strength or higher reps for muscle and strength endurance. It is often performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of a chest or upper-body focused workout.
HowTo: 1. Set the Smith machine bar to the appropriate height. 2. Lie back on the incline bench and grasp the bar with a grip slightly wider than shoulder-width. 3. Lower the bar to your upper chest, then press it back up to the starting position.

Title: Smith Machine Close-Grip Bench Press
Desc: The Smith machine close-grip bench press is a machine-based movement targeting the chest and triceps. The Smith machine mimics a barbell but provides more stability. This movement can be programmed in low reps for strength or higher reps for muscle and strength endurance. It is often performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of a chest, arms, or upper-body focused workout.
HowTo: 1. Set the Smith machine bar to the appropriate height. 2. Lie back on the bench with your hands in a close grip. 3. Lower the bar to your chest, then press it back up to the starting position.

Title: Smith Machine Decline Press
Desc: The Smith machine decline bench press is a machine-based exercise targeting the chest muscles, particularly the lower pectoral muscles. The Smith machine mimics a barbell but provides more stability. This movement is often performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of a chest or upper-body workout.
HowTo: 1. Set the Smith machine bar to the appropriate height. 2. Lie back on the decline bench and grasp the bar with a grip slightly wider than shoulder-width. 3. Lower the bar to your lower chest, then press it back up to the starting position.

Title: Smith machine bench press throw
Desc: The Smith machine bench press throw is an exercise that helps develop pushing power that carries over to the traditional bench press. It involves pushing a relatively light weight (such as 30-50 percent of your 1RM) explosively and actually letting go at the top of the rep. It can work as power or speed-style training in a strength or athleticism-focused workout plan.
HowTo: 1. Set the Smith machine bar to the appropriate height with light weights. 2. Lie back on the bench and grasp the bar with a grip slightly wider than shoulder-width. 3. Lower the bar to your chest, then explosively push it up and release it at the top of the movement.

Title: Machine chest fly
Desc: The machine chest fly is a machine-based exercise targeting the chest. It approximates the motion of a dumbbell fly or cable fly, but is usually performed facing forward and seated upright. The motion is often compared to bear-hugging a tree trunk. The chest fly is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of a pre-exhaust or muscle-building upper-body workout.
HowTo: 1. Adjust the machine to your height and sit down facing forward. 2. Grasp the handles and keep your elbows slightly bent. 3. Bring the handles together in front of your chest, then slowly return to the starting position.

Title: Machine bench press
Desc: The machine bench press is a machine-based exercise targeting the chest and upper body. It approximates the motion of a bench press, but uses a selectorized weight-stack or plate-loaded machine. Many such machines also allow you to choose between different grips and grip widths. Machine-based presses are often done for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of the upper-body or chest-focused portion of a workout.
HowTo: 1. Sit on the machine with your back against the pad. 2. Grasp the handles and push them forward until your arms are fully extended. 3. Slowly return to the starting position.

Title: Machine Seated Chest Press - Gethin Variation
Desc: The machine chest press is an upper body exercise targeting the pectoral muscles.
HowTo: 1. Adjust the seat height so that the handles are at chest level. 2. Sit down and grasp the handles. 3. Push the handles forward until your arms are fully extended. 4. Return to the starting position.

Title: Smith machine weighted push-up
Desc: The Smith machine weighted push-up is a pushing movement performed with a plate resting on the back or shoulders. It is performed most safely with a foot or so of space at the bottom to minimize the risk of getting "pinned" under the bar. It targets all the same muscles as a push-up, including the chest, triceps, and shoulders.
HowTo: 1. Set the Smith machine bar to the appropriate height. 2. Place a weight plate on your back or shoulders. 3. Position yourself in a push-up stance with your feet on the ground. 4. Lower your body towards the ground and push back up.

Title: Smith machine incline bench press-
Desc: The Smith machine incline bench press is a machine-based movement targeting the chest, particularly the upper chest. The Smith machine mimics a barbell but provides more stability. This movement can be programmed in low reps for strength or higher reps for muscle and strength endurance. It is often performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of a chest or upper-body focused workout.
HowTo: 1. Set the Smith machine bar to an incline position. 2. Lie on the bench and grasp the bar. 3. Lower the bar to your upper chest and then press it back up to the starting position.

Title: Smith machine decline bench press
Desc: The Smith machine decline bench press is a machine-based exercise targeting the chest muscles, particularly the lower pectoral muscles. The Smith machine mimics a barbell but provides more stability. This movement is often performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of a chest or upper-body workout.
HowTo: 1. Set the Smith machine bar to a decline position. 2. Lie on the bench and grasp the bar. 3. Lower the bar to your lower chest and then press it back up to the starting position.

Title: AM Pec Dec
Desc: The pec deck is a machine-based exercise targeting the chest. It approximates the motion of a dumbbell fly or cable fly, but is usually performed facing forward and seated upright. The motion is often compared to bear-hugging a tree trunk. The chest fly is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of a pre-exhaust or muscle-building upper-body workout.
HowTo: 1. Sit on the pec deck machine with your back against the pad. 2. Grasp the handles and bring them together in front of your chest, squeezing your pectoral muscles, then return to the starting position.

Title: 30 Chest Machine Flat Chest Press
Desc: The 30 Chest Machine Flat Chest Press is a machine-based exercise that targets the chest muscles effectively.
HowTo: 1. Sit on the flat chest press machine and adjust the seat height. 2. Grasp the handles and press them forward until your arms are fully extended, then return to the starting position.

Title: Smith machine push-up
Desc: The Smith machine push-up is an upper-body exercise targeting the chest, shoulders, and triceps. It is similar in form to bodyweight push-ups, but with the hands on the bar of the Smith machine. This allows you to vary the height to increase or decrease difficulty, or to perform a mechanical dropset by raising the bar after hitting failure at a certain height.
HowTo: 1. Position yourself under the Smith machine bar at chest height. 2. Lower your body into a push-up position, keeping your body straight, then push back up to the starting position.

Title: 30 Chest Smith Machine Incline Chest Press
Desc: The 30 Chest Smith Machine Incline Chest Press is a variation that targets the upper part of the chest.
HowTo: 1. Set the Smith machine bar to an incline position. 2. Lie on the bench and press the bar upward until your arms are fully extended, then lower it back to your chest.

Title: 30 Chest Smith Machine Chest Press
Desc: The 30 Chest Smith Machine Chest Press is a standard exercise for building chest strength.
HowTo: 1. Adjust the Smith machine bar to the appropriate height. 2. Lie on the bench, grasp the bar, and press it upward until your arms are straight, then lower it back down to your chest.

Title: 30 Chest Machine Incline Chest Press
Desc: The 30 Chest Machine Incline Chest Press is designed to target the upper chest muscles. It is commonly used in strength training routines to build muscle mass and strength in the chest area.
HowTo: 1. Adjust the seat height so that the handles are at chest level. 2. Sit down and grasp the handles with both hands. 3. Push the handles forward until your arms are fully extended. 4. Slowly return to the starting position.

Title: 30 Chest Machine Fly
Desc: The 30 Chest Machine Fly is an isolation exercise that focuses on the chest muscles. It helps in developing the pectoral muscles and improving overall upper body strength.
HowTo: 1. Adjust the seat height so that the handles are at shoulder level. 2. Sit down and grasp the handles with both hands. 3. With a slight bend in your elbows, open your arms wide to the sides. 4. Bring the handles back together in front of you, squeezing your chest.

Title: 30 Chest 30-Degree Incline Smith Machine Press
Desc: The 30 Chest 30-Degree Incline Smith Machine Press targets the upper chest and shoulders. It is an effective exercise for building strength and mass in the upper body.
HowTo: 1. Set the Smith machine bar to a 30-degree incline. 2. Lie back on the bench and grasp the bar with both hands. 3. Lower the bar to your chest, then press it back up to the starting position.

Title: Low-cable cross-over
Desc: The low-cable cross-over is an isolation movement that uses a cable stack to target the upper portion of the pectoral muscles. It is common in upper-body and chest-focused muscle-building workouts, often in combination with presses or flyes from other angles to target all portions of the chest.
HowTo: 1. Stand in the center of a cable machine with pulleys set at the lowest position. 2. Grasp the handles with both hands. 3. Pull the cables upward and together in front of your chest. 4. Slowly return to the starting position.

Title: Incline cable chest fly
Desc: The incline cable chest fly is an isolation movement that uses a cable stack and an incline bench to target the upper portion of the pectoral muscles. It is common in upper-body and chest-focused muscle-building workouts, often after pressing movements like the barbell or dumbbell bench press or as a finishing movement at the end of the workout. It is often used in combination with other flyes to target the chest from different angles.
HowTo: 1. Set an incline bench and adjust the cable pulleys to the lowest position. 2. Lie back on the bench and grasp the cable handles. 3. With a slight bend in your elbows, open your arms wide. 4. Bring the handles together above your chest, squeezing your pectorals.

Title: Cable Crossover
Desc: The cable cross-over is an isolation movement that uses a cable stack to build bigger and stronger pectoral muscles. Since it's done using adjustable pulleys, you can target different parts of your chest by setting the pulleys at different levels. It is common in upper body and chest-focused muscle-building workouts, often as a pre-exhaust at the beginning of a workout, or a finishing movement at the end. It is often in combination with other presses or flyes to target the chest from different angles.
HowTo: 1. Stand in the center of a cable machine with the pulleys set at shoulder height. 2. Grab the handles with both hands and step forward slightly. 3. With a slight bend in your elbows, pull the cables together in front of you, squeezing your chest muscles. 4. Slowly return to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Incline cable chest press
Desc: The incline cable chest press is a pressing movement that uses a cable stack and an incline bench to target the upper portion of the pectoral muscles, similar to an incline dumbbell press. It is common in upper-body and chest-focused muscle-building workouts, where it can be effective as a primary movement in classic hypertrophy rep ranges, as a pre-exhaust, or as a high-rep finisher. It is often used in combination with other presses or flyes to target the chest from different angles.
HowTo: 1. Set an incline bench in the cable machine and adjust the pulleys to the lowest position. 2. Lie back on the bench and grab the handles with both hands. 3. Press the cables upward, focusing on the upper chest, then lower them back down slowly. 4. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Cable Chest Press
Desc: The cable chest press is a pressing movement that targets the pectoral muscles using a cable stack.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your back to the cable machine and grab the handles at shoulder height. 2. Step forward slightly to create tension in the cables. 3. Press the handles forward until your arms are extended, then slowly return to the starting position. 4. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Single-arm cable cross-over
Desc: The single-arm cable cross-over is an isolation movement that uses a cable stack to build bigger and stronger pectoral muscles. Working the chest one side at a time allows you to focus on the balance between the sides of your chest and really feel the chest muscles contracting. It is common in upper-body and chest-focused muscle-building workouts, often in combination with other presses or flyes to target the chest from different angles.
HowTo: 1. Stand in the center of a cable machine and set the pulleys at shoulder height. 2. Grab the handle with one hand and step slightly forward. 3. Pull the cable across your body, focusing on the contraction of the chest muscles. 4. Slowly return to the starting position and repeat, then switch sides.

Since it's done using adjustable pulleys, you can target different parts of your chest by setting the pulleys at different levels. With a slight bend in your elbows, pull the cables together in front of you, squeezing your chest muscles. 4. Slowly return to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Standing Cable Chest Press
Desc: The Standing Cable Chest Press is a strength exercise that targets the chest muscles using a cable machine. It helps in building strength and size in the pectoral region.
HowTo: 1. Stand facing away from the cable machine with feet shoulder-width apart. 2. Grasp the handles with both hands at chest level. 3. Push the handles forward until your arms are fully extended. 4. Slowly return to the starting position.

Title: Lying cable chest fly
Desc: The lying cable chest fly is an isolation movement that uses a cable stack and a flat bench to build bigger and stronger pectoral muscles. It is common in upper-body and chest-focused muscle-building workouts, often as a pre-exhaust at the beginning of a workout or as a finishing movement at the end. It is often used in combination with other presses or flyes to target the chest from different angles.
HowTo: 1. Lie on a flat bench with a cable in each hand. 2. Start with your arms extended above your chest. 3. Lower your arms out to the sides while maintaining a slight bend in the elbows. 4. Bring your arms back together above your chest.

Title: Paul Carter Cable Cross-Over
Desc: The cable cross-over is an isolation movement that uses a cable stack to build bigger and stronger pectoral muscles. Since it's done using adjustable pulleys, you can target different parts of your chest by setting the pulleys at different levels. It is common in upper body and chest-focused muscle-building workouts, often as a pre-exhaust at the beginning of a workout, or a finishing movement at the end. It is often in combination with other presses or flyes to target the chest from different angles.
HowTo: 1. Stand in the center of a cable machine with pulleys set at a high position. 2. Grasp the handles with both hands. 3. Pull the handles down and across your body in a hugging motion. 4. Return to the starting position with control.

Title: One-Arm Cable Crossover - Gethin Variation
Desc: The single-arm cable cross-over is an isolation movement that uses a cable stack to build bigger and stronger pectoral muscles. Working the chest one side at a time allows you to focus on balance between sides of your chest, and really feel the chest muscles contracting. It is common in upper body and chest-focused muscle-building workouts, often in combination with other presses or flyes to target the chest from different angles.
HowTo: 1. Stand next to a cable machine with the pulley set at a high position. 2. Grasp the handle with one hand. 3. Pull the handle down and across your body. 4. Return to the starting position and repeat on the other side.

Title: Incline Cable Fly - Gethin Variation
Desc: The incline cable chest fly is an isolation movement that uses a cable stack and an incline bench to target the upper portion of the pectoral muscles. It is common in upper-body and chest-focused muscle-building workouts, often after pressing movements like the barbell or dumbbell bench press or as a finishing movement at the end of the workout. It is often used in combination with other flyes to target the chest from different angles.
HowTo: 1. Lie on an incline bench with cables in each hand. 2. Start with your arms extended above your chest. 3. Lower your arms out to the sides while keeping a slight bend in the elbows. 4. Bring your arms back together above your chest.

Title: Cable Cross-Over - Gethin Variation

Since it's done using adjustable pulleys, you can target different parts of your chest by setting the pulleys at different levels. It is common in upper body and chest-focused muscle-building workouts, often as a pre-exhaust at the beginning of a workout, or a finishing movement at the end. It is often in combination with other presses or flyes to target the chest from different angles.
HowTo: 1. Adjust the pulleys to the desired height. 2. Stand in the center of the cable machine and grab the handles with both hands. 3. Step forward slightly and lean slightly forward. 4. Pull the handles together in front of you while keeping a slight bend in your elbows. 5. Slowly return to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Seated cable chest fly
Desc: The seated cable chest fly is an isolation movement that uses a cable stack and an upright bench to target the pectoral muscles. Being able to brace against a seat can help you stabilize your torso and focus on isolating the pecs, feeling them stretch and contract. It is usually used in combination with other presses or flyes to target the chest from different angles.
HowTo: 1. Sit on the bench with the cable machine on either side. 2. Grab the handles with your arms extended to the sides. 3. Pull the handles together in front of your chest while keeping your elbows slightly bent. 4. Slowly return to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Single-arm incline cable cross-over-
Desc: The single-arm incline cable cross-over is an isolation movement that uses a cable stack and a bench to target the upper part of the pectoral muscles. Working the chest one side at a time allows you to focus on balance between the sides of your chest and really feel the chest muscles contracting. It is common in upper-body and chest-focused muscle-building workouts, often in combination with other presses or flyes to target the chest from different angles.
HowTo: 1. Set the cable pulleys to a low position and lie on an incline bench. 2. Grab the handle with one hand and extend your arm out to the side. 3. Pull the handle across your body towards the opposite shoulder. 4. Slowly return to the starting position and repeat on the other side.

Title: High-to-low cable chest fly
Desc: The high-to-low cable chest fly is an isolation movement that uses a cable stack to target the lower portion of the pectoral muscles. It is common in upper-body and chest-focused muscle-building workouts, often after pressing movements like the barbell or dumbbell bench press or as a finishing movement at the end of the workout. It is often used in combination with other flyes to target the chest from different angles.
HowTo: 1. Adjust the cables to a high position. 2. Stand in the center of the cable machine and grab the handles. 3. Pull the handles down and together in front of you, focusing on the lower chest. 4. Slowly return to the starting position and repeat.

Title: UP Cable Cross-Over
Desc: The cable cross-over is an isolation movement that uses a cable stack to build bigger and stronger pectoral muscles. Since it's done using adjustable pulleys, you can target different parts of your chest by setting the pulleys at different levels. It is common in upper body and chest-focused muscle-building workouts, often as a pre-exhaust at the beginning of a workout, or a finishing movement at the end. It is often in combination with other presses or flyes to target the chest from different angles.
HowTo: 1. Adjust the pulleys to the desired height. 2. Stand in the center of the cable machine and grab the handles with both hands. 3. Step forward slightly and lean slightly forward. 4. Pull the handles together in front of you while keeping a slight bend in your elbows. 5. Slowly return to the starting position and repeat.

Title: UP Cable Fly
Desc: The UP Cable Fly is an isolation exercise targeting the upper chest muscles. It involves using a cable machine to perform a fly motion, which helps in building muscle size and definition.
HowTo: 1. Set the cables at a low position. 2. Stand in the center, grab the handles with both hands. 3. With a slight bend in your elbows, pull the handles up and together in an arc until your hands meet above your chest. 4. Slowly return to the starting position.

Title: 30 Chest Low-To-High Cable Fly
Desc: The 30 Chest Low-To-High Cable Fly focuses on the lower to upper chest transition. This exercise enhances muscle growth and definition in the chest area.
HowTo: 1. Set the cables at a low position. 2. Stand in the center, grab the handles. 3. With a slight bend in your elbows, pull the handles up and outward in an arc until your arms are extended. 4. Slowly return to the starting position.

Title: 30 Chest Incline Cable Fly
Desc: The 30 Chest Incline Cable Fly targets the upper chest and shoulders. It is effective for building muscle mass and improving upper body strength.
HowTo: 1. Set the cables at a low position and adjust the bench to an incline. 2. Lie back on the bench and grab the handles. 3. With a slight bend in your elbows, pull the handles together above your chest. 4. Slowly return to the starting position.

Title: 30 Chest Incline Cable Chest Press
Desc: The 30 Chest Incline Cable Chest Press is a compound exercise that works the upper chest and triceps. It is great for building strength and size in the upper body.
HowTo: 1. Set the cables at a low position and adjust the bench to an incline. 2. Lie back on the bench and grab the handles. 3. Press the handles upward until your arms are fully extended. 4. Slowly lower the handles back to the starting position.

Title: 30 Chest High-To-Low Cable Press
Desc: The 30 Chest High-To-Low Cable Press focuses on the upper chest and helps in muscle development. This exercise is effective for increasing strength and size in the chest area.
HowTo: 1. Set the cables at a high position. 2. Stand in the center and grab the handles. 3. Press the handles down and together in front of your body. 4. Slowly return to the starting position.

Title: 30 Chest High-To-Low Cable Fly
Desc: The 30 Chest High-To-Low Cable Fly targets the chest muscles through a controlled cable movement. It helps in building strength and definition in the upper body.
HowTo: 1. Stand in the center of a cable machine with the cables set at a high position. 2. Grasp the handles with both hands, arms outstretched. 3. Pull the cables down and together in front of your chest, keeping a slight bend in your elbows. 4. Slowly return to the starting position and repeat.

Title: 30 Chest Shoulder-Height Cable Fly
Desc: The 30 Chest Shoulder-Height Cable Fly is designed to enhance chest muscle activation. It focuses on the middle part of the pectorals for balanced development.
HowTo: 1. Adjust the cable machine to shoulder height. 2. Stand in the center and grasp the handles. 3. With a slight bend in your elbows, pull the cables out to the sides and then bring them together in front of your chest. 4. Control the movement back to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Cable Pec Fly
Desc: The Cable Pec Fly is an effective exercise for isolating the chest muscles. It allows for a full range of motion to maximize muscle engagement.
HowTo: 1. Set the cables at a low position and stand in the middle. 2. Grasp the handles with your arms out to the sides. 3. Pull the cables together in front of you while keeping your elbows slightly bent. 4. Slowly return to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Chest Push (multiple response)
Desc: The Chest Push exercise focuses on building strength in the chest and arms. It can be performed with various equipment for versatility.
HowTo: 1. Position yourself on a bench or standing with weights. 2. Push the weights away from your chest until your arms are fully extended. 3. Slowly lower the weights back to the starting position. 4. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Medicine Ball Chest Pass
Desc: The medicine ball pass is a simple partner-based exercise that involves throwing a weighted ball back-and-forth. It can be part of a dynamic warm-up for lifting or athletics, but can also work as active rest or as a component of circuit training.
HowTo: 1. Stand facing your partner with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a medicine ball at chest level. 2. Squat slightly and then explosively extend your arms to throw the ball to your partner. 3. Catch the ball as it comes back and repeat the motion. 4. Ensure to engage your core throughout the exercise.

Title: Medicine ball sprawl to chest press
Desc: The medicine ball sprawl to chest press is a sequence of athletic movements using a medicine ball or other small weight. It involves performing a sprawl with the hands on the ball, followed by a standing chest press holding the ball. It is challenging to the cardiovascular system, but also the muscles of the core, shoulders, and upper back. It can be performed for reps or for time, usually in dedicated ab training or as part of a medicine ball and bodyweight circuit workout.
HowTo: 1. Start in a standing position with a medicine ball. 2. Bend down and place your hands on the ball, then kick your legs back into a sprawl position. 3. Return to standing while holding the ball, and press it overhead.

Title: Medicine ball push-up
Desc: The medicine ball push-up is a simple way to make a classic bodyweight exercise more difficult. It targets all the same muscles as the push-up: chest, triceps, shoulders, upper back, and core. The addition of the medicine ball adds a degree of difficulty and can increase chest and triceps activation.
Muscles: chest, triceps, shoulders, upper back, core
HowTo: 1. Place one hand on a medicine ball and the other on the floor. 2. Lower your body into a push-up, keeping your core tight. 3. Push back up to the starting position.

Title: Chest Push (single response)
Desc: The Chest Push exercise focuses on strengthening the upper body, particularly the chest and arms. It can be performed with various equipment or bodyweight.
HowTo: 1. Stand or sit with your back straight. 2. Push your arms forward, extending them fully in front of you. 3. Return to the starting position.

Title: Chest Push with Run Release
Desc: The Chest Push with Run Release combines upper body strength with cardiovascular elements. It enhances both muscle endurance and heart rate.
HowTo: 1. Start in a standing position. 2. Perform a chest push, then immediately run in place for a few seconds. 3. Repeat the sequence.

Title: Chest Push from 3 point stance
Desc: The Chest Push from 3 point stance is an exercise that targets the upper body while engaging the core. It is performed from a stable position to enhance strength.
HowTo: 1. Start in a three-point stance with one knee on the ground and the other foot planted. 2. Push your arms forward as if performing a chest push. 3. Return to the starting position.

Title: Dumbbell Bench Press
Desc: The dumbbell bench press is a mainstay of workout enthusiasts worldwide. Its a classic move for building a bigger, stronger chest. As such, its often placed first in mass-building chest workouts.
HowTo: 1. Lie back on a bench with a dumbbell in each hand. 2. Press the dumbbells up until your arms are fully extended, then lower them back down to chest level.

Title: Dumbbell Flyes
Desc: The dumbbell chest fly is a popular exercise that targets the pectoral or chest muscles. It attempts to isolate the chest muscles, stretching and contracting them while limiting involvement of the shoulders. Unlike a press, where the elbows bend and flex, flyes should keep a relatively consistent elbow angle. The motion is sometimes compared to "hugging a tree." Dumbbell flyes are usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of a chest or upper-body focused workout.
HowTo: 1. Lie on a flat bench holding dumbbells above your chest. 2. With a slight bend in your elbows, lower the dumbbells out to the sides until you feel a stretch in your chest, then bring them back together.

Title: Incline dumbbell bench press
Desc: The incline dumbbell bench press is a popular upper-body exercise targeting the upper pectoral muscles. While it can be a strength-focused movement, it is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of upper-body or chest-focused training.
HowTo: 1. Set an incline bench to a 30-45 degree angle and lie back with a dumbbell in each hand. 2. Press the dumbbells up above your chest, then lower them back down to the starting position.

Title: Decline Dumbbell Flyes
Desc: The decline dumbbell chest fly is an upper body isolation exercise targeting the lower chest. It will require less weight than a decline press, which makes it a great hypertrophy exercise with high reps.
