HowTo: 1. Lie on a decline bench holding dumbbells above your chest. 2. With a slight bend in your elbows, lower the dumbbells out to the sides until you feel a stretch in your chest, then bring them back together.

Title: Reverse-grip incline dumbbell bench press
Desc: The reverse-grip incline dumbbell bench press is an upper-body exercise targeting the pectoral muscles. Pressing with a reverse grip targets the upper chest in particular, especially when performed on an incline. This press variation is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of upper-body or chest-focused training.
HowTo: 1. Set an incline bench to a 30-45 degree angle and lie back with a dumbbell in each hand using a reverse grip. 2. Press the dumbbells up above your chest, then lower them back down to the starting position.

Title: Incline Dumbbell Flyes
Desc: The incline dumbbell chest fly is an upper body isolation exercise targeting the upper chest and is typically used with aesthetic goals in mind. It will require less weight than an incline press, which makes it a great hypertrophy exercise with high reps.
HowTo: 1. Lie on an incline bench with a dumbbell in each hand. 2. With a slight bend in your elbows, lower the dumbbells out to the sides until you feel a stretch in your chest, then bring them back together above your chest.

Title: Neutral-grip dumbbell bench press
Desc: The neutral-grip dumbbell bench press is a variation on a classic chest-building exercise where the palms face each other instead of forward. This shift puts the elbows closer to the sides, placing more emphasis on the triceps, and perhaps also the inner chest. The neutral-grip press can be performed in lower reps for strength or higher reps for muscle growth.
HowTo: 1. Lie on a flat bench with a dumbbell in each hand, palms facing each other. 2. Press the dumbbells up until your arms are fully extended, then lower them back down to your chest.

Title: Decline dumbbell bench press
Desc: The decline dumbbell bench press is a popular upper-body exercise targeting the lower pectoral muscles. While it can be a strength-focused movement, it is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of upper-body or chest-focused training.
HowTo: 1. Lie on a decline bench with a dumbbell in each hand. 2. Press the dumbbells up until your arms are fully extended, then lower them back down to your chest.

Title: Single-arm kettlebell row
Desc: The single-arm kettlebell row is a popular muscle- and strength-building exercise that works the muscles of the back and core simultaneously. It has all the same benefits as a single-arm dumbbell row, but some people find a kettlebell more comfortable to hold during the movement.
HowTo: 1. Place one knee and hand on a bench for support, holding a kettlebell in the opposite hand. 2. Pull the kettlebell towards your hip while keeping your elbow close to your body, then lower it back down.

Title: Hammer Grip Incline DB Bench Press
Desc: The Hammer Grip Incline DB Bench Press is a variation of the incline bench press that emphasizes the upper chest and triceps. It is performed with a neutral grip for a different angle of muscle engagement.
HowTo: 1. Lie on an incline bench with a dumbbell in each hand, palms facing each other. 2. Press the dumbbells up until your arms are fully extended, then lower them back down to your chest.

Title: Straight-arm dumbbell pull-over
Desc: The straight-arm dumbbell pull-over is an exercise that targets the muscles of the pecs, lats, and serratus anterior muscles. Performing this movement with straight arms makes it more difficult, increases the stretch on the serratus muscles and lats, and forces the core to work harder. Old-school bodybuilders would perform pull-overs with light weights for sets of 20 between sets of heavy 20-rep squats, but they are more popular today in moderate rep ranges, such as 8-12 reps per set, as part of an upper-body workout.
HowTo: 1. Lie on a bench with a dumbbell in each hand. 2. With arms straight, lower the dumbbells back over your head and then pull them back to the starting position, keeping your arms straight throughout the movement.

Title: Incline Dumbbell Bench With Palms Facing In
Desc: The incline dumbbell bench with palms facing in targets the upper chest and triceps. This variation helps to engage the shoulder muscles more effectively.
HowTo: 1. Sit on an incline bench with a dumbbell in each hand, palms facing each other. 2. Press the dumbbells up above your chest, then lower them back down to shoulder level.

Title: Incline Dumbbell Flyes - With A Twist
Desc: Incline dumbbell flyes with a twist are designed to target the upper chest while also engaging the shoulders. This exercise adds a twist to increase the range of motion and muscle activation.
HowTo: 1. Lie on an incline bench with a dumbbell in each hand, arms extended above your chest. 2. Lower the dumbbells out to the sides while twisting your wrists, then bring them back together above your chest.

Title: Bent-arm dumbbell pull-over
Desc: The bent-arm dumbbell pull-over was a staple exercise of the "Golden Era" of bodybuilding and a favorite of Arnold Schwarzenegger himself. Done properly, the exercise targets the pecs, lats, and serratus anterior muscles. Old-school bodybuilders would perform them with light weights for sets of 20 between sets of heavy 20-rep squats, but pull-overs are more popular today in moderate rep ranges, such as 8-12 reps per set, as part of an upper-body workout.
HowTo: 1. Lie on a bench with a dumbbell in each hand. 2. Bend your arms slightly and lower the dumbbells back over your head, then pull them back to the starting position.

Title: Close-grip dumbbell bench press
Desc: The close-grip dumbbell bench press is a popular variation of the dumbbell bench press in which the dumbbells are held closer than shoulder width. This places more emphasis on the triceps, and perhaps also the inner chest. The close-grip dumbbell bench press can be performed in lower reps for strength or higher reps for muscle growth.
HowTo: 1. Lie on a flat bench with a dumbbell in each hand, held close together above your chest. 2. Lower the dumbbells towards your chest while keeping your elbows close to your body, then press them back up to the starting position.

Title: Single-dumbbell push-up
Desc: The single-dumbbell push-up is a more difficult push-up variation where you balance your hands on the ends of a dumbbell. This simple change makes many muscle groups work harder, helping encourage muscle and strength gains across the upper body.
HowTo: 1. Start in a push-up position with one hand on a dumbbell. 2. Lower your body towards the ground while keeping your core tight, then push back up to the starting position.

Title: One-Arm Flat Bench Dumbbell Flye
Desc: The One-Arm Flat Bench Dumbbell Flye is an exercise that targets the chest muscles effectively.
HowTo: 1. Lie flat on a bench with a dumbbell in one hand. 2. Extend your arm above your chest, then lower the dumbbell out to the side in a controlled manner before returning to the starting position.

Title: Dumbbell Fix Dumbbell Floor Chest Fly
Desc: The Dumbbell Fix Dumbbell Floor Chest Fly is designed to target the chest while minimizing shoulder strain.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back on the floor with a dumbbell in each hand. 2. Extend your arms above your chest, then lower the dumbbells out to the sides before bringing them back together.

Title: Dumbbell Fix Traveling Push-Up
Desc: The Dumbbell Fix Traveling Push-Up is a variation that incorporates movement to increase difficulty.
HowTo: 1. Start in a push-up position with a dumbbell in each hand. 2. Perform a push-up, then move one hand and the corresponding foot to the side, repeating the movement in a lateral fashion.

Title: Incline dumbbell chest fly
Desc: The incline dumbbell chest fly is an upper-body exercise targeting the chest. Performing it at an incline helps to target the upper chest in particular, while limiting involvement of the shoulders. Fly variations are usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more.
HowTo: 1. Lie on an incline bench with a dumbbell in each hand. 2. Extend your arms above your chest, then lower the dumbbells out to the sides before bringing them back together.

Title: Paul Carter Dumbbell Shrug
Desc: The standing dumbbell shrug is a popular movement to build and strengthen the trapezius muscles. Its a often trained on a bodybuilding-style shoulder or back training day, but can also work well in full-body or strength-focused training.
HowTo: 1. Stand upright with a dumbbell in each hand at your sides. 2. Keeping your arms straight, lift your shoulders towards your ears while squeezing your traps. 3. Hold for a moment at the top, then lower back down.

Title: Dumbbell push-up row
Desc: The dumbbell push-up row combines pressing, rowing, and core stabilization into a single sequence. It's popular in time-efficient strength and muscle-building workouts.
HowTo: 1. Start in a push-up position with a dumbbell in each hand. 2. Perform a push-up, then row one dumbbell to your side while stabilizing your body. 3. Alternate sides with each rep.

Title: TBS Dumbbell Incline Press
Desc: The incline dumbbell bench press is an upper body exercise targeting the upper pectoral muscles.
HowTo: 1. Lie back on an incline bench with a dumbbell in each hand. 2. Press the dumbbells up above your chest, then lower them slowly to the sides of your chest. 3. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Incline Dumbbell Fly - Gethin Variation
Desc: The incline dumbbell chest fly is an upper body isolation exercise targeting the upper chest and is typically used with aesthetic goals in mind. It will require less weight than an incline press, which makes it a great hypertrophy exercise with high reps.
HowTo: 1. Lie back on an incline bench with a dumbbell in each hand, arms extended above your chest. 2. Lower the dumbbells out to the sides in a wide arc, keeping a slight bend in your elbows. 3. Bring the dumbbells back together above your chest.

Title: Dumbbell bench press-
Desc: The dumbbell bench press is a mainstay of lifters worldwide. It's a classic move for building a bigger, stronger chest and triceps. It's often placed first in mass-building chest workouts, but can also be utilized as an accessory movement for the barbell bench press in strength training. It can be performed in lower strength-focused rep ranges, or for higher reps to build muscle.
HowTo: 1. Lie back on a flat bench with a dumbbell in each hand, arms extended above your chest. 2. Lower the dumbbells to the sides of your chest, then press them back up to the starting position. 3. Keep your feet flat on the ground and your back pressed against the bench.

Title: Decline dumbbell fly and press
Desc: The decline dumbbell fly and press is a dumbbell complex that targets the chest muscles, particularly the lower pecs. By alternating the single-joint fly with the multijoint press, you get the benefits of both and put serious stress on the chest muscles even with relatively light weight. Because the fly will be the limiting factor in weight selection, this pairing is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of upper-body or chest-focused training.
HowTo: 1. Lie on a decline bench with a dumbbell in each hand. 2. Perform a fly motion by lowering the dumbbells out to the sides, then bring them back together while pressing them up.

Title: Incline dumbbell fly and press
Desc: The incline dumbbell fly and press is a dumbbell complex that targets the chest muscles, particularly the upper pecs. By alternating the single-joint fly with the multijoint press, you get the benefits of both and put serious stress on the chest muscles even with relatively light weight. Because the fly will be the limiting factor in weight selection, this pairing is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of upper-body or chest-focused training.
HowTo: 1. Lie on an incline bench with a dumbbell in each hand. 2. Perform a fly motion by lowering the dumbbells out to the sides, then bring them back together while pressing them up.

Title: Single-arm decline dumbbell bench press
Desc: The single-arm decline dumbbell bench press is an upper-body exercise targeting the pectoral muscles, particularly the lower pecs. Because balance can be an issue, this press variation is usually performed with lighter weight for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of upper-body or chest-focused training.
HowTo: 1. Lie on a decline bench with a dumbbell in one hand. 2. Press the dumbbell up while keeping your other arm at your side, then lower it back down.

Title: Single-arm incline dumbbell bench press
Desc: The single-arm incline dumbbell bench press is an upper-body exercise targeting the pectoral muscles. Because balance can be an issue, this press variation is usually performed with lighter weight for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of upper-body or chest-focused training.
HowTo: 1. Lie on an incline bench with a dumbbell in one hand. 2. Press the dumbbell up while keeping your other arm at your side, then lower it back down.

Title: Incline Dumbbell Press - Gethin Variation
Desc: The incline dumbbell bench press is an upper body exercise targeting the upper pectoral muscles.
HowTo: 1. Lie on an incline bench with a dumbbell in each hand. 2. Press the dumbbells up towards the ceiling, focusing on squeezing the upper pecs.

Title: Dumbbell Chest Press - Gethin Variation
Desc: The dumbbell bench press is a mainstay of workout enthusiasts worldwide. Its a classic move for building a bigger, stronger chest. As such, its often placed first in mass-building chest workouts.
HowTo: 1. Lie on a bench with a dumbbell in each hand, arms extended above your chest. 2. Lower the dumbbells to your chest, then press them back up to the starting position.

Title: Dumbbell Floor Press - Gethin Variation
Desc: The dumbbell floor press limits the range of motion you would achieve with a regular dumbbell bench press, but still targets the chest, triceps, and anterior delts. This allows you to build strength in the top portion of the lift and work on strengthening the shoulder stabilizers.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back on the floor with a dumbbell in each hand, arms extended above your chest. 2. Lower the dumbbells until your upper arms touch the floor, then press them back to the starting position.

Title: Decline Dumbbell Press - Gethin Variation
Desc: The decline dumbbell bench press is an upper body isolation exercise targeting the lower chest. Utilizing dumbbells instead of a barbell increases the difficulty of stabilizing the weight.
HowTo: 1. Lie on a decline bench with a dumbbell in each hand, arms extended above your chest. 2. Lower the dumbbells to the sides of your chest, then press them back up to the starting position.

Title: Dumbbell chest fly
Desc: The dumbbell chest fly is a popular exercise that targets the pectoral or chest muscles. It attempts to isolate the chest muscles, stretching and contracting them while limiting involvement of the shoulders. Unlike a press, where the elbows bend and flex, flyes should keep a relatively consistent elbow angle. The motion is sometimes compared to "hugging a tree." Dumbbell flyes are usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of a chest or upper-body focused workout.
HowTo: 1. Lie on a flat bench with a dumbbell in each hand, arms extended above your chest. 2. Open your arms wide to the sides while keeping a slight bend in your elbows, then bring them back together above your chest.

Title: Machine rear delt fly
Desc: The machine rear delt fly is an exercise targeting the rear head of the shoulder muscle or deltoids, as well as the muscles of the upper back. It's sort of the reverse of the machine chest fly, and is sometimes performed on the same machine, but facing the opposite direction. Because it targets such small muscles, this exercise is usually performed with light weight for high reps, such as 10-15 reps per set or more.
HowTo: 1. Sit at the machine with your back against the pad and grasp the handles. 2. Pull the handles back in a reverse fly motion, squeezing your shoulder blades together, then return to the starting position.

Title: AM Dumbbell Bench Press
Desc: The dumbbell bench press is a mainstay of workout enthusiasts worldwide. Its a classic move for building a bigger, stronger chest. As such, its often placed first in mass-building chest workouts.
HowTo: 1. Lie on a bench with a dumbbell in each hand. 2. Press the dumbbells up until your arms are fully extended. 3. Lower the dumbbells to your chest, then press them back up.

Title: UP Incline Dumbbell Press
Desc: The incline dumbbell bench press is an upper body exercise targeting the upper pectoral muscles.
HowTo: 1. Set an incline bench at a 30-45 degree angle. 2. Lie back on the bench with a dumbbell in each hand at shoulder level. 3. Press the dumbbells up until your arms are fully extended, then lower them back to the starting position.

Title: UP Incline Dumbbell Fly
Desc: The incline dumbbell chest fly is an upper body isolation exercise targeting the upper chest and is typically used with aesthetic goals in mind. It will require less weight than an incline press, which makes it a great hypertrophy exercise with high reps.
HowTo: 1. Lie on an incline bench with a dumbbell in each hand, arms extended above your chest. 2. With a slight bend in your elbows, lower the dumbbells out to the sides until you feel a stretch in your chest. 3. Bring the dumbbells back together above your chest.

Title: Holman Push-Up to Belly Touch
Desc: The Holman Push-Up to Belly Touch is a variation of the push-up that incorporates a touch to the belly.
HowTo: 1. Start in a push-up position with your hands shoulder-width apart. 2. Lower your body to the ground and push back up, then touch your belly with one hand. 3. Alternate sides with each repetition.

Title: Single-arm dumbbell floor press
Desc: The single-arm dumbbell floor press is a multijoint pressing exercise performed lying on the floor, either with the knees bent or straight. It has less range of motion than a regular dumbbell bench press, but still targets the chest, triceps, and anterior delts. By performing it with one arm, you can strengthen weakness on certain sides or simply use it as a way to challenge the core more during this exercise.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back on the floor with one dumbbell in one hand. 2. Press the dumbbell up until your arm is fully extended. 3. Lower the dumbbell back down to your chest, then repeat.

Title: Total Fitness Weighted Push-Up
Desc: The plate-weighted push-up is a simple way to make a classic bodyweight exercise more difficult. It targets all the same muscles as the push-up: chest, triceps, shoulders, upper back, and core. You can balance a plate on your upper back yourself, but it's easier and safer to have someone else put it there. If you stack a few plates up, be sure to have a spotter close at hand.
Muscles: Chest, Triceps, Shoulders, Upper Back, Core
HowTo: 1. Start in a push-up position with your hands shoulder-width apart. 2. Have a partner place a weight plate on your upper back. 3. Lower your body until your chest nearly touches the floor. 4. Push back up to the starting position.

Title: King Maker Standing Dumbbell Shoulder Press
Desc: The standing dumbbell shoulder press is a classic deltoid-builder (especially the front deltoids) thats ubiquitous in gyms around the world. Performing the move standing up as opposed to seated allows for more weight to be used.
HowTo: 1. Stand with a dumbbell in each hand at shoulder height. 2. Press the dumbbells overhead until your arms are fully extended. 3. Lower the dumbbells back to shoulder height and repeat.

Title: 30 Chest Incline Dumbbell Fly
Desc: The 30 Chest Incline Dumbbell Fly is an exercise that targets the chest muscles through a flying motion. It emphasizes the upper chest and helps in developing a fuller chest appearance.
HowTo: 1. Lie back on an incline bench with a dumbbell in each hand. 2. Start with the dumbbells above your chest, palms facing each other. 3. Lower the dumbbells out to the sides in a wide arc until you feel a stretch in your chest. 4. Bring the dumbbells back together above your chest.

Title: 30 Chest Incline Dumbbell Bench Press
Desc: The 30 Chest Incline Dumbbell Bench Press is designed to target the upper chest and build overall chest strength. This exercise is performed on an incline bench to emphasize the upper pectoral muscles.
HowTo: 1. Lie back on an incline bench with a dumbbell in each hand at shoulder height. 2. Press the dumbbells upward until your arms are fully extended. 3. Lower the dumbbells back to shoulder height and repeat.

Title: 30 Chest Dumbbells-Together Press
Desc: The 30 Chest Dumbbells-Together Press is an effective exercise for building strength in the chest and arms. It involves pressing dumbbells together, which increases the engagement of the chest muscles.
HowTo: 1. Lie on a flat bench with a dumbbell in each hand, held together above your chest. 2. Lower the dumbbells towards your chest while keeping them pressed together. 3. Press the dumbbells back up to the starting position.

Title: 30 Chest Dumbbells-Together Incline Bench Press
Desc: The incline bench press targets the upper chest muscles and helps build strength. It is performed using dumbbells while lying on an inclined bench.
HowTo: 1. Set an incline bench to a 30-degree angle. 2. Lie back on the bench with a dumbbell in each hand. 3. Press the dumbbells up above your chest, then lower them back down to the sides of your chest.

Title: 30 Chest Dumbbell Fly
Desc: The dumbbell fly is an isolation exercise that targets the chest muscles. It helps to stretch and strengthen the pectorals.
HowTo: 1. Lie on a flat bench holding a dumbbell in each hand above your chest. 2. With a slight bend in your elbows, lower the dumbbells out to the sides until you feel a stretch in your chest. 3. Bring the dumbbells back together above your chest.

Title: 30 Chest Dumbbell Bench Press
Desc: The dumbbell bench press is a fundamental exercise for building chest strength. It engages multiple muscle groups including the triceps and shoulders.
HowTo: 1. Lie on a flat bench with a dumbbell in each hand at chest level. 2. Press the dumbbells up until your arms are fully extended. 3. Lower the dumbbells back down to your chest.

Title: 30 Chest 30-Degree Incline Dumbbell Fly
Desc: The incline dumbbell fly focuses on the upper portion of the chest. It is effective for developing a fuller chest appearance.
HowTo: 1. Set an incline bench at a 30-degree angle and lie back with a dumbbell in each hand. 2. With elbows slightly bent, lower the dumbbells out to the sides. 3. Raise the dumbbells back to the starting position above your chest.

Title: FYR2 Single-Dumbbell Push-Up
Desc: The single-dumbbell push-up is a variation that increases the challenge on the chest and core. It helps improve stability and strength.
HowTo: 1. Get into a push-up position with one hand on a dumbbell. 2. Lower your body towards the ground while keeping your core tight. 3. Push back up to the starting position.

Title: Bodyweight Flyes
Desc: The double-bar roll-out chest fly is a chest exercise that utilizes two rotating barbells as "handles" for a chest fly. It targets the muscles of the chest, but is also an intense core workout. It's a tough movement that is usually performed in the chest-focused portion of a workout.
HowTo: 1. Set up two rotating barbells at shoulder height. 2. Grip the bars and lower your body into a fly position, then pull back to the starting position while engaging your core.

Title: Close-grip EZ-bar bench press
Desc: The close-grip EZ-bar bench press is an exercise targeting the chest, shoulders, and triceps. This move is more commonly done with a straight bar and is often only performed with an EZ-bar as part of a complex of movements such as pull-overs or skullcrushers.
HowTo: 1. Lie on a bench with an EZ-bar in your hands, arms extended above your chest. 2. Lower the bar towards your chest while keeping your elbows close to your body, then press back up to the starting position.

Title: Chest dip
Desc: The chest dip is a bodyweight exercise performed on parallel bars or on a pull-up and dip station. It targets the chest, triceps, and shoulders. Dips with a chest focus are usually performed with the torso leaning forward and the elbows angled out from the torso. Dips can be performed for low reps for strength or higher reps for muscle growth.
HowTo: 1. Position yourself on parallel bars with your arms straight. 2. Lower your body by bending your elbows while leaning forward, then push back up to the starting position.

Title: Drop Push
Desc: The drop push is a variation of the push-up that emphasizes explosive strength. It is performed by dropping from a height and pushing off the ground.
HowTo: 1. Start in a push-up position. 2. Drop your body down and push explosively off the ground to return to the starting position.

Title: Forward Drag with Press
Desc: The forward drag with press is a compound movement that engages multiple muscle groups. It combines a dragging motion with an overhead press.
HowTo: 1. Start with a weight in your hands at your side. 2. Drag the weight forward while simultaneously pressing it overhead.

Title: Chain Press
Desc: The Chain Press is a variation of the traditional bench press that incorporates chains for added resistance. This exercise helps to build strength and power in the upper body.
Muscles: chest, triceps, shoulders, upper back, core
HowTo: 1. Set up a bench press station with chains attached to the bar. 2. Lie back on the bench and grip the bar with your hands slightly wider than shoulder-width. 3. Lower the bar to your chest while keeping your elbows at a 45-degree angle. 4. Press the bar back up to the starting position, engaging your chest and triceps.

Title: Behind Head Chest Stretch
Desc: The Behind Head Chest Stretch is designed to improve flexibility in the shoulders and chest. It is beneficial for enhancing range of motion and relieving tension.
HowTo: 1. Stand or sit up straight with your arms at your sides. 2. Raise your arms overhead and bend your elbows to bring your hands behind your head. 3. Gently pull your elbows back to stretch your chest and shoulders. 4. Hold the stretch for 15-30 seconds, breathing deeply.

Title: Pass-through stretch with band
Desc: The pass-through stretch with band is a popular move to build and maintain mobility in the shoulder joint and to strengthen the muscles of the upper back and rotator cuff. It is common in CrossFit and Olympic lifting training and is usually performed as part of a warm-up or paired with movements in a workout. It can also be performed with a PVC pipe or dowel if a band isn't available.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and hold a resistance band with both hands, arms extended in front of you. 2. Keeping your arms straight, raise the band overhead and behind you until you feel a stretch in your shoulders. 3. Return to the starting position and repeat for several repetitions.

Title: Weighted Push-Up
Desc: The plate-weighted push-up is a simple way to make a classic bodyweight exercise more difficult. It targets all the same muscles as the push-up: chest, triceps, shoulders, upper back, and core. You can balance a plate on your upper back yourself, but it's easier and safer to have someone else put it there. If you stack a few plates up, be sure to have a spotter close at hand.
Muscles: chest, triceps, shoulders, upper back, core
HowTo: 1. Begin in a push-up position with your hands slightly wider than shoulder-width apart. 2. Have a weight plate placed on your upper back, ensuring it is stable. 3. Lower your body towards the ground while keeping your elbows at a 45-degree angle. 4. Push back up to the starting position, engaging your core and maintaining form.

Title: Heavy Bag Thrust
Desc: The Heavy Bag Thrust is a dynamic exercise that combines strength and cardio elements. It is effective for building endurance and power.
HowTo: 1. Stand in front of a heavy bag with your feet shoulder-width apart. 2. Bend your knees slightly and thrust your hips forward, striking the bag with your body. 3. Use your arms to help push the bag away while maintaining a strong core. 4. Repeat the thrusts for a set duration or number of repetitions.

Title: Decline Explosive Push-Up
Desc: The Decline Explosive Push-Up is a powerful variation of the standard push-up that emphasizes the upper chest and explosive strength. It is performed with the feet elevated, allowing for a more dynamic push-off from the ground.
HowTo: 1. Start in a decline push-up position with your feet elevated on a bench. 2. Lower your body towards the ground, then push explosively off the ground, allowing your hands to leave the floor briefly. 3. Land softly and immediately go into the next repetition.

Title: Suspended Chest Fly
Desc: The Suspended Chest Fly is an exercise that targets the chest muscles through a unique suspension system. It allows for a greater range of motion and engages stabilizing muscles.
HowTo: 1. Set up suspension straps at chest height. 2. Grab the handles and lean back, keeping your body straight. 3. With a slight bend in your elbows, open your arms wide to the sides, then bring them back together in front of you.

Title: Svend press
Desc: The Svend press is an exercise where the chest is targeted by performing presses while squeezing two weight plates together. It is usually performed for relatively high reps with light weights as an accessory movement to the bench press or as a burnout movement on chest day.
HowTo: 1. Stand upright holding two weight plates together at chest level. 2. Press the plates out in front of you while maintaining the squeeze. 3. Return to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Bar Push-Up Smith Machine
Desc: The hands-elevated push-up is a variation on the push-up, a body-weight standard. The hands are elevated, so that your body is aligned at an angle to the floor rather than parallel.
HowTo: 1. Set the bar on the Smith machine at an appropriate height. 2. Position yourself under the bar, gripping it with your hands shoulder-width apart. 3. Lower your body towards the bar, then push back up to the starting position.

Title: Plate-weighted push-up
Desc: The plate-weighted push-up is a simple way to make a classic bodyweight exercise more difficult. It targets all the same muscles as the push-up: chest, triceps, shoulders, upper back, and core. You can balance a plate on your upper back yourself, but it's easier and safer to have someone else put it there. If you stack a few plates up, be sure to have a spotter close at hand.
HowTo: 1. Position a weight plate on your upper back, ensuring it is stable. 2. Get into a push-up position with your hands slightly wider than shoulder-width. 3. Lower your body towards the ground, then push back up to the starting position.

Title: Double-bar roll-out chest fly
Desc: The double-bar roll-out chest fly is a chest exercise that utilizes two rotating barbells as "handles" for a chest fly. It targets the muscles of the chest, but is also an intense core workout. It's a tough movement that is usually performed in the chest-focused portion of a workout.
HowTo: 1. Start in a kneeling position with two rotating barbells in front of you. 2. Grip the handles and roll them forward while keeping your core engaged, then return to the starting position while performing a fly motion.

Title: Holman Plate Dynamo Push-Up
Desc: The Holman Plate Dynamo Push-Up is an intense variation of the traditional push-up that incorporates a plate for added resistance.
HowTo: 1. Place a weight plate on the ground. 2. Get into a push-up position with your hands on the plate. 3. Lower your body towards the plate and push back up, keeping your core tight.

Title: Holman Towel Drag Two Steps to Push-Up
Desc: The Holman Towel Drag Two Steps to Push-Up is a dynamic exercise that combines a towel drag with push-ups to engage multiple muscle groups.
HowTo: 1. Place a towel on the floor and get into a push-up position. 2. Drag the towel towards you with one hand, then perform a push-up. 3. Alternate hands and repeat.

Title: Taylor Val Slide Push-Up/Fly Combo
Desc: The Taylor Val Slide Push-Up/Fly Combo is a challenging exercise that combines push-ups with a fly motion to target the chest and shoulders.
HowTo: 1. Start in a push-up position with sliders under your hands. 2. Lower your body into a push-up, then slide your hands out to the sides as you return to the starting position. 3. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Exercise ball chest stretch
Desc: The exercise ball chest stretch is a simple stretch for the pectoral muscles that can be made more dynamic with help from a medicine ball. It can work in a dynamic warm-up, paired with movements in a workout, or as part of a cool-down or recovery strategy. If the stretch causes pain in the front of your shoulder, dial back the intensity or choose another chest stretch.
HowTo: 1. Sit on an exercise ball with your back against it. 2. Extend your arms out to the sides and gently lean back to stretch your chest. 3. Hold the stretch for 15-30 seconds.

Title: Bosu Ball Push-Up
Desc: The Bosu Ball Push-Up is a challenging variation of the standard push-up that incorporates instability to engage more muscles. It enhances upper body strength and stability.
HowTo: 1. Start in a push-up position with your hands on the Bosu ball and your feet on the ground. 2. Lower your body towards the ball by bending your elbows. 3. Push back up to the starting position while maintaining balance.

Title: Feet-elevated push-up on ball
Desc: The feet-elevated push-up on ball is a variation on the push-up, a bodyweight standard. The feet are elevated on a ball to align the body parallel to the floor and provide a greater stabilization challenge. This makes it more difficult than push-ups on the floor, but also puts more emphasis on the shoulder muscles. It can be a challenging non-gym substitute for incline presses, or as a burnout movement for a chest or shoulder workout.
HowTo: 1. Place your feet on a stability ball and your hands on the floor, shoulder-width apart. 2. Lower your body towards the floor by bending your elbows. 3. Push back up to the starting position, keeping your body straight.

Title: Standing alternating band speed row
Desc: The standing alternating band speed row is an explosive back exercise using exercise bands. It targets the muscles of the middle and upper back, including the lats (latissimus dorsi), rhomboids, and trapezius, as well as the biceps. It can be performed for time or reps either as part of a power or speed-focused portion of a workout or as a burnout at the end of a workout.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and hold the exercise band with both hands. 2. Pull one arm back while keeping the other arm extended. 3. Alternate arms quickly, focusing on explosive movement.

Title: Band roundhouse elbow
Desc: The band roundhouse elbow is an explosive rotational power exercise using exercise bands. It targets the muscles of the obliques and deep core, but also engrains full-body coordination and striking ability. It can work in an ab workout, in martial arts training, or in general strength and muscle training.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and hold the band with both hands. 2. Rotate your torso and pull the band across your body in a striking motion. 3. Return to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Palms-down wrist curl over bench
Desc: The palms-down wrist curl over bench is an exercise targeting the forearms. It is usually performed for high reps, such as 10-15 reps per set or more, as part of a grip or arm-focused workout.
HowTo: 1. Sit on a bench with your forearms resting on the bench and your wrists hanging off the edge. 2. Hold a weight in each hand with palms facing down. 3. Curl your wrists upwards, then lower them back down.

Title: Palms-up wrist curl over bench
Desc: The palms-up wrist curl over bench is an exercise targeting the forearms. It is usually performed for high reps, such as 10-15 reps per set or more, as part of a grip or arm-focused workout.
HowTo: 1. Sit on a bench with your forearms resting on the bench and your palms facing up. 2. Hold a dumbbell in each hand and curl your wrists upwards, then lower back down.

Title: Standing behind-the-back wrist curl
Desc: The standing behind-the-back wrist curl is a popular exercise to target the muscles in the forearms, wrists, and fingers. It is generally performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-15 reps per set, and can work as isolated forearm training or as part of an arms-focused workout.
HowTo: 1. Stand upright and hold a barbell behind your back with both hands. 2. Curl your wrists upwards, then lower back down to the starting position.

Title: Seated finger curl
Desc: The seated finger curl is an exercise targeting the muscles of the hands and forearms. It is popular with rock climbers and other athletes looking to build forearm size and strength. The range of motion is tiny, but done for moderate to high reps, these will definitely make the forearms burn.
HowTo: 1. Sit on a bench and hold a barbell with your palms facing up, resting your forearms on your thighs. 2. Curl your fingers to lift the barbell, then lower it back down.

Title: Seated palms-up wrist curl
Desc: The seated palms-up wrist curl is an exercise targeting the forearms. It is usually performed for high reps, such as 10-15 reps per set or more, as part of a grip or arm-focused workout.
HowTo: 1. Sit on a bench with your forearms resting on your thighs and your palms facing up. 2. Hold a dumbbell in each hand and curl your wrists upwards, then lower back down.

Title: Bottoms-Up Clean From The Hang Position
Desc: The Bottoms-Up Clean From The Hang Position is a dynamic exercise that targets multiple muscle groups, including the shoulders and legs. It is performed by lifting a kettlebell from a hang position to a racked position.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a kettlebell in one hand at your side. 2. Hinge at the hips and lower the kettlebell, then explosively pull it up to your shoulder while flipping it upside down.

Title: Seated One-Arm Dumbbell Palms-Up Wrist Curl
Desc: The Seated One-Arm Dumbbell Palms-Up Wrist Curl is a targeted exercise for the forearms. It helps in building grip strength and forearm muscle endurance.
HowTo: 1. Sit on a bench with your feet flat on the floor. 2. Hold a dumbbell in one hand with your palm facing up. 3. Rest your forearm on your thigh, allowing your wrist to hang off. 4. Curl the dumbbell upwards by flexing your wrist. 5. Lower the dumbbell back to the starting position. 6. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions before switching arms.

Title: Palms-Up Dumbbell Wrist Curl Over A Bench
Desc: The Palms-Up Dumbbell Wrist Curl Over A Bench is designed to strengthen the forearm muscles. This exercise is beneficial for improving grip strength and muscle definition.
HowTo: 1. Lie face down on a bench with your arms hanging off the edge. 2. Hold a dumbbell in each hand with your palms facing up. 3. Allow your wrists to extend downwards. 4. Curl the dumbbells upwards by flexing your wrists. 5. Slowly lower the dumbbells back to the starting position. 6. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Seated palms-down wrist curl
Desc: The seated palms-down wrist curl is an exercise targeting the forearms. It is usually performed for high reps, such as 10-15 reps per set or more, as part of a grip or arm-focused workout.
HowTo: 1. Sit on a bench with your feet flat on the floor. 2. Hold a dumbbell in each hand with your palms facing down. 3. Rest your forearms on your thighs, allowing your wrists to hang off. 4. Curl the dumbbells upwards by flexing your wrists. 5. Lower the dumbbells back to the starting position. 6. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Palms-Down Dumbbell Wrist Curl Over A Bench
Desc: The Palms-Down Dumbbell Wrist Curl Over A Bench is effective for strengthening the forearms. It enhances grip strength and muscle endurance in the wrists.
HowTo: 1. Lie face down on a bench with your arms hanging off the edge. 2. Hold a dumbbell in each hand with your palms facing down. 3. Allow your wrists to extend downwards. 4. Curl the dumbbells upwards by flexing your wrists. 5. Slowly lower the dumbbells back to the starting position. 6. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Seated One-Arm Dumbbell Palms-Down Wrist Curl
Desc: The Seated One-Arm Dumbbell Palms-Down Wrist Curl is a focused exercise for the forearms. It is great for enhancing grip strength and muscle definition.
HowTo: 1. Sit on a bench with your feet flat on the floor. 2. Hold a dumbbell in one hand with your palm facing down. 3. Rest your forearm on your thigh, allowing your wrist to hang off. 4. Curl the dumbbell upwards by flexing your wrist. 5. Lower the dumbbell back to the starting position. 6. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions before switching arms.

Title: Seated Dumbbell Palms-Up Wrist Curl
Desc: The Seated Dumbbell Palms-Up Wrist Curl is an exercise that targets the forearm muscles. It is performed while seated, focusing on wrist flexion with dumbbells.
HowTo: 1. Sit on a bench with your forearms resting on your thighs, holding a dumbbell in each hand with palms facing up. 2. Curl the dumbbells upward by flexing your wrists, then lower them back down to the starting position.

Title: Partner farmer's walk
Desc: The partner farmer's walk is a protocol for performing farmer's carries with dumbbells or other weights. One partner walks for a predetermined distance or time, then passes the weight to the other partner who walks for the same distance or time.
HowTo: 1. Each partner picks up a weight in one hand. 2. One partner walks a predetermined distance or time, then passes the weight to the other partner who continues for the same distance or time.

Title: Dumbbell suitcase carry
Desc: The dumbbell suitcase carry is similar to a dumbbell farmer's carry, but only uses one dumbbell rather than two. This simple change provides a significant challenge to the abdominal muscles. It can be a challenging finisher to any workout, or work well in fat-loss circuit training or as an accessory movement to heavy lifts like the deadlift.
HowTo: 1. Stand upright holding a dumbbell in one hand at your side. 2. Walk forward while keeping your core engaged and your body upright, then switch sides.

Title: Suitcase Dumbbell Carry
Desc: The dumbbell suitcase carry is similar to a dumbbell farmers carry, but only uses one dumbbell rather than two. This simple change provides a significant challenge to the abdominal muscles. It can be a challenging finisher to any workout, or work well in fat-loss circuit training or as an accessory movement to heavy lifts like the deadlift.
HowTo: 1. Stand upright with a dumbbell in one hand at your side. 2. Walk forward while maintaining an upright posture and engaging your core, then switch hands.

Title: Side plank with dumbbell external rotation
Desc: The side plank with dumbbell external rotation is a movement that combines an isometric side plank hold with a dumbbell rotation to target both the core and the rotator cuff muscles. You probably won't be able to use much weight without disrupting your balance, but even at light weight, this is a movement that can help address multiple muscle groups in a dynamic warm-up or as accessory work at the end of a workout.
HowTo: 1. Start in a side plank position with your body in a straight line and a dumbbell in your top hand. 2. Rotate the dumbbell towards your body while maintaining the side plank position, then return to the starting position.

Title: Rickshaw Carry
Desc: The Rickshaw Carry is a loaded carry exercise that challenges grip strength and overall stability. It engages multiple muscle groups and is effective for building functional strength.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart. 2. Hold the rickshaw handles with both hands. 3. Engage your core and lift the rickshaw off the ground. 4. Walk forward while maintaining good posture and control.

Title: Dumbbell farmer's walk
Desc: The dumbbell farmer's walk is an exercise with roots in competitive strongman training, but which is also popular in CrossFit and functional training. It can be a challenging finisher to any workout, or work well in fat-loss circuit training or as an accessory movement to heavy lifts like the deadlift.
HowTo: 1. Hold a dumbbell in each hand at your sides. 2. Stand tall with your shoulders back. 3. Walk forward for a set distance or time while maintaining good posture.

Title: Wrist Roller
Desc: The Wrist Roller is an exercise that primarily targets the forearm muscles. It is effective for building grip strength and forearm endurance.
HowTo: 1. Attach a weight to one end of a wrist roller. 2. Hold the roller with both hands at shoulder height. 3. Roll the weight up by twisting your wrists, then lower it back down.

Title: Standing Olympic Plate Hand Squeeze
Desc: The Standing Olympic Plate Hand Squeeze is an exercise that focuses on grip strength. It is often used to enhance forearm strength and endurance.
HowTo: 1. Stand upright holding an Olympic plate with both hands. 2. Squeeze the plate tightly while holding it at chest level. 3. Hold the squeeze for a set duration before releasing.

Title: Plate Pinch
Desc: The Plate Pinch is an exercise that targets the grip and forearm muscles. It is a simple yet effective way to improve grip strength.
HowTo: 1. Take two weight plates and pinch them together with your fingers. 2. Hold the plates at your sides. 3. Walk for a set distance while maintaining the pinch.

Title: Landmine Press and Catch
Desc: The single-arm linear jammer is an explosive pressing movement performed using an angled barbell anchored at floor level in a landmine device. It can also be performed by sticking a barbell in the corner of a room, preferably in a towel to protect the walls. The linear jammer involves pressing the weight into the air, then catching it with the other hand. The movement focuses primarily on the muscles of the shoulders or deltoids. It can be trained in traditional muscle and strength-focused rep ranges, for lower reps with a focus on explosive pressing power, or for higher reps.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and hold the barbell with one hand. 2. Press the barbell upward explosively and catch it with the other hand as it descends.

Title: Plate halo
Desc: The plate halo is an exercise targeting the shoulder complex. It's usually performed as part of a dynamic warm-up prior to an upper-body workout.
HowTo: 1. Hold a weight plate with both hands at chest level. 2. Move the plate in a circular motion around your head, keeping your arms extended.

Title: Bryant Wrist Curl
Desc: The Bryant Wrist Curl is a targeted exercise for strengthening the forearm muscles. It is typically performed with a barbell or dumbbells.
HowTo: 1. Sit on a bench with your forearms resting on your thighs and your wrists hanging off the edge. 2. Hold a barbell or dumbbells and curl your wrists upward, then lower them back down.

Title: Seated Two-Arm Palms-Up Low-Pulley Wrist Curl
Desc: The Seated Two-Arm Palms-Up Low-Pulley Wrist Curl is an exercise that targets the forearms and improves grip strength. It is performed using a low pulley machine.
HowTo: 1. Sit at a low pulley machine with your forearms resting on your thighs and palms facing up. 2. Grasp the handle and curl your wrists upward, then lower them back down.

Title: Cable Wrist Curl
Desc: The Cable Wrist Curl is an effective exercise for building forearm strength and muscle. It is performed using a cable machine.
HowTo: 1. Stand facing a cable machine with the pulley set at the lowest position. 2. Grasp the handle with an underhand grip and curl your wrist upward, then lower it back down.

Title: Single-arm cable push-down
Desc: The single-arm cable push-down is a single-joint isolation movement that develops the triceps muscle one arm at a time. Because the action is purely at the elbow joint, it is difficult to use any substantial weight. Reps are usually high, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, with a focus on strict form and feeling the mind-muscle connection.
HowTo: 1. Attach a single handle to a high pulley on a cable machine. 2. Stand facing the machine and grasp the handle with one hand. 3. Keep your elbow close to your body and push the handle down until your arm is fully extended. 4. Slowly return to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Wrist Circles
Desc: Wrist circles are a simple exercise to improve wrist mobility and flexibility. They help in warming up the wrists before workouts or relieving tension after long periods of use.
HowTo: 1. Stand or sit comfortably with your arms extended in front of you. 2. Make a fist with both hands. 3. Rotate your wrists in a circular motion, first clockwise for 10-15 seconds, then counterclockwise for the same duration.

Title: Kneeling Forearm Stretch
Desc: The kneeling forearm stretch is designed to improve flexibility in the shoulders and chest. It is particularly beneficial for those who spend long hours at a desk.
HowTo: 1. Kneel on the floor with your forearms resting on the ground in front of you. 2. Slowly lean forward, allowing your chest to sink towards the floor while keeping your forearms on the ground. 3. Hold the stretch for 15-30 seconds, breathing deeply.

Title: Hip Extension with Bands
Desc: Hip extension with bands is an effective exercise for targeting the glutes and hamstrings. It can be performed with resistance bands to increase difficulty.
HowTo: 1. Secure a resistance band around your ankles and stand with your feet hip-width apart. 2. Bend slightly at the knees and hinge at the hips to lean forward. 3. Extend one leg straight back behind you, keeping your knee straight. 4. Return to the starting position and switch legs.

Title: Hip Lift with Band
Desc: Hip lift with band is a great exercise for strengthening the glutes and core. It utilizes a resistance band for added intensity.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back with your knees bent and feet flat on the floor, placing a resistance band around your thighs just above your knees. 2. Press your feet into the ground and lift your hips towards the ceiling, squeezing your glutes at the top. 3. Lower your hips back down and repeat.

Title: HM Monster Walk
Desc: The HM Monster Walk is a mobility exercise that helps activate and strengthen the hip abductors and glutes. It is often used as a warm-up or activation drill.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and place a resistance band around your thighs. 2. Lower into a slight squat and step sideways, maintaining tension in the band. 3. Continue stepping sideways for a set distance, then return to the starting position.

Title: UNS Banded Glute Bridge
Desc: The UNS Banded Glute Bridge is an effective exercise for targeting the glutes and improving hip stability. It utilizes a resistance band to increase the intensity of the movement.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back with your knees bent and feet flat on the ground, placing a resistance band just above your knees. 2. Press through your heels and lift your hips towards the ceiling, squeezing your glutes at the top. 3. Lower your hips back down and repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: FYR2 Banded Glute Bridge
Desc: The FYR2 Banded Glute Bridge is designed to enhance glute activation and strength. It incorporates a resistance band to provide additional resistance during the bridge movement.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back with your knees bent and feet flat on the ground, placing a resistance band just above your knees. 2. Engage your core and press through your heels to lift your hips, squeezing your glutes at the top. 3. Hold for a moment before lowering back down and repeating.

Title: Piriformis SMR
Desc: Piriformis self-myofascial release (SMR) is a self-administered soft-tissue treatment for the lower body, usually using a foam roller, lacrosse ball, or other "trigger point" massage tool. By applying pressure strategically to the piriformis muscles in the upper gluteal region, some people find they can cause this often painful and tight muscle to relax or "release." Piriformis SMR is often accompanied by SMR on the iliotibial (IT) band or tensor fascia lata (TFL muscles), or by stretches that target the glutes and hips.
HowTo: 1. Sit on the floor with a foam roller or lacrosse ball under your glutes. 2. Lean to one side and roll over the ball or roller, focusing on tight areas. 3. Spend extra time on any particularly tight spots to release tension.

Title: Barbell glute bridge
Desc: The barbell glute bridge is a popular exercise targeting the muscles of the glutes and hamstrings. It can be done as a strength movement on its own, as an activation drill or warm-up for lower-body training, or as a burnout at the end of a lower-body workout.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back with your shoulders on a bench and a barbell resting on your hips. 2. Press through your heels and lift your hips towards the ceiling, squeezing your glutes at the top. 3. Lower your hips back down and repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Barbell Hip Thrust
Desc: The barbell hip thrust is an exercise that engages the posterior chain, particular the glutes. It involves fully extending your hips while holding a weighted barbell across the midsection.
HowTo: 1. Sit on the ground with your upper back against a bench. 2. Roll a barbell over your hips. 3. Plant your feet flat on the ground, shoulder-width apart. 4. Drive through your heels to lift your hips towards the ceiling. 5. Squeeze your glutes at the top and lower back down.

Title: Kneeling Squat
Desc: The kneeling squat is a variation of the squat that emphasizes strength and stability. It requires you to start from a kneeling position and then rise to a standing position.
HowTo: 1. Start in a kneeling position with your knees on the ground. 2. Engage your core and push through your feet to rise to a standing position. 3. Lower back down to the kneeling position with control.

Title: Kneeling Jump Squat
Desc: The kneeling jump squat is an explosive exercise that builds power in the legs. It involves jumping from a kneeling position to a standing position.
HowTo: 1. Start in a kneeling position with your knees on the ground. 2. Engage your core and explode upwards into a jump. 3. Land softly and return to the kneeling position.

Title: UN Rear Foot Elevated Split Squat
Desc: The UN rear foot elevated split squat is a unilateral exercise that targets the legs and improves balance. It involves elevating one foot behind you while squatting with the other leg.
HowTo: 1. Stand a few feet in front of a bench and place one foot on the bench behind you. 2. Lower your body into a squat with the front leg, keeping the back knee close to the ground. 3. Push through the front heel to return to the starting position.

Title: Kettlebell thruster
Desc: The kettlebell thruster is a popular kettlebell movement that combines a kettlebell front squat with a kettlebell press, while holding the bell in a goblet or bottoms-up grip. It is preceded by a clean at the start of each set, and you can perform a clean between each rep if you choose. It can be trained in traditional strength or muscle-building rep ranges, in circuit or fat-loss training, or as part of a larger kettlebell combination or complex.
HowTo: 1. Hold a kettlebell at chest height with both hands. 2. Squat down, keeping your chest up and knees out. 3. As you rise from the squat, press the kettlebell overhead. 4. Lower the kettlebell back to the chest and repeat.

Title: Taylor Kettlebell Swing
Desc: The Taylor Kettlebell Swing is a dynamic exercise that targets multiple muscle groups. It is great for building strength and endurance.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, holding a kettlebell with both hands. 2. Hinge at the hips, swinging the kettlebell back between your legs. 3. Thrust your hips forward to swing the kettlebell up to shoulder height. 4. Let the kettlebell swing back down and repeat.

Title: UN Goblet Squat
Desc: The UN Goblet Squat is a foundational lower body exercise that improves strength and stability. It is performed by holding a weight close to the chest while squatting.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, holding a dumbbell or kettlebell close to your chest. 2. Lower your body into a squat, keeping your chest up and back straight. 3. Push through your heels to return to the starting position.

Title: Single-arm triceps kick-back
Desc: The single-arm triceps kick-back is a popular movement to increase size and strength of the triceps. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps, at least 8-12 reps, as part of an upper-body or arm-focused workout.
HowTo: 1. Stand with one knee on a bench and the other foot on the floor. 2. Hold a dumbbell in the opposite hand, with your arm bent at 90 degrees. 3. Extend your arm back until it is straight, then return to the starting position.

Title: Holman Lateral High Knees to Quad Touch Jump
Desc: The Holman Lateral High Knees to Quad Touch Jump is a high-intensity exercise that combines cardio and agility. It improves coordination and leg strength.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet hip-width apart. 2. Drive your knees up towards your chest while moving laterally. 3. Touch your opposite foot with your hand, then jump explosively into the air. 4. Land softly and repeat.

Title: FYR2 Dumbbell Hip Thrust
Desc: The FYR2 Dumbbell Hip Thrust is an effective exercise for targeting the glutes and improving hip strength. It is performed with your upper back resting on a bench and feet flat on the ground.
HowTo: 1. Sit on the ground with your upper back against a bench, holding a dumbbell over your hips. 2. Plant your feet flat on the ground, shoulder-width apart. 3. Drive through your heels to lift your hips towards the ceiling, squeezing your glutes at the top. 4. Lower back down and repeat.

Title: FYR2 Glute Bridge Dumbbell Floor Press
Desc: The FYR2 Glute Bridge Dumbbell Floor Press is an effective exercise for targeting the glutes while also engaging the upper body. It combines a glute bridge with a dumbbell press to work multiple muscle groups.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back with your knees bent and feet flat on the floor. 2. Hold a dumbbell in each hand at chest level. 3. Lift your hips off the ground into a bridge position while pressing the dumbbells overhead. 4. Lower back down and repeat.

Title: Suspended Hip Thrust
Desc: The Suspended Hip Thrust is a powerful exercise that primarily targets the glutes. It involves lifting the hips while suspended, which increases the difficulty and engagement of the glute muscles.
HowTo: 1. Set up a suspension trainer at hip height. 2. Sit on the ground with your upper back against a bench and your feet in the straps. 3. Drive through your heels to lift your hips towards the ceiling. 4. Squeeze your glutes at the top and lower back down.

Title: Single-leg cable hip extension
Desc: The single-leg cable hip extension is an isolation exercise that targets the glutes, specifically the gluteus maximus. It is a common burnout movement on a lower-body focused day and is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more.
HowTo: 1. Attach a cable to a low pulley and adjust the weight. 2. Stand facing away from the machine and secure the ankle strap to one ankle. 3. Bend slightly at the waist and extend the leg back, squeezing the glute. 4. Return to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Pull Through
Desc: The Pull Through is an effective exercise for targeting the posterior chain, particularly the glutes and hamstrings. It emphasizes the hip hinge movement, which is essential for many athletic activities.
HowTo: 1. Stand facing away from a cable machine with the rope attachment set low. 2. Grab the rope between your legs and step forward to create tension. 3. Hinge at the hips and pull the rope through your legs while standing up straight. 4. Squeeze your glutes at the top and repeat.

Title: Cable rope pull-through deadlift
Desc: The cable rope pull-through deadlift is an exercise targeting the glutes and hamstrings using a proper hip-hinging motion.
HowTo: 1. Stand facing a cable machine with the rope attachment set low. 2. Grab the rope and step back to create tension. 3. Hinge at the hips while keeping your back straight, allowing the rope to pass between your legs. 4. Stand back up by driving through your heels and squeezing your glutes.

Title: UNS Cable Pull-Through
Desc: The UNS Cable Pull-Through is a lower-body exercise that primarily targets the glutes and hamstrings. It is performed using a cable machine for added resistance.
HowTo: 1. Stand facing away from the cable machine with the cable attached at the lowest setting. 2. Grab the handle with both hands and step forward to create tension in the cable. 3. Hinge at the hips, keeping your back straight, and pull the cable through your legs. 4. Squeeze your glutes to return to standing.

Title: 30 Legs Glute-Ham Raise
Desc: The 30 Legs Glute-Ham Raise is an exercise that targets the glutes and hamstrings. It is performed on a glute-ham developer machine.
HowTo: 1. Position yourself on the glute-ham developer with your feet secured. 2. Lower your upper body towards the ground while keeping your back straight. 3. Engage your hamstrings and glutes to raise your body back to the starting position.

Title: Glute bridge
Desc: The glute bridge is a popular lower-body bodyweight exercise that primarily targets the glutes, but also activates the lower back and hamstrings. It can be performed with body weight alone, or with added resistance such as barbells, dumbbells, or bands. It can be performed for time or reps and works perfectly in a dynamic warm-up for lower-body training, but can also be performed for glute activation anytime.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back with your knees bent and feet flat on the floor. 2. Push through your heels to lift your hips towards the ceiling, squeezing your glutes at the top. 3. Lower back down to the starting position.

Title: Single-leg glute bridge
Desc: The single-leg glute bridge is a lower-body exercise that targets the glutes, lower back, and hamstrings. It is performed one side at a time.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back with one knee bent and the other leg extended straight. 2. Push through the heel of the bent leg to lift your hips, keeping the extended leg in line with your body. 3. Lower back down and repeat on the other side.

Title: Step-up with knee raise
Desc: The step-up with knee raise is a lower-body exercise targeting the quads, glutes, and hamstrings. It differs from a traditional step-up in that at the top, you lift the trailing leg up to full hip flexion. This gives the exercise a greater range of motion and more of a focus on powerful hip extension in the working leg. When performed with body weight, these are usually performed for high reps as part of a dynamic warm-up, as cardio acceleration, or as part of the lower-body portion of a workout or circuit.
HowTo: 1. Stand in front of a sturdy bench or step. 2. Step up with one foot, pressing through the heel to lift your body. 3. At the top, raise your trailing knee towards your chest. 4. Step back down and repeat.

Title: Glute Kickback
Desc: The glute kickback is an exercise that targets the glute muscles. It is often performed to strengthen and tone the glutes.
HowTo: 1. Start on all fours with your hands under your shoulders and knees under your hips. 2. Keeping your knee bent, lift one leg towards the ceiling, squeezing your glutes at the top. 3. Lower back down and repeat for the desired number of reps before switching legs.

Title: Standing hip extension
Desc: The standing hip extension is a movement that activates the glutes and hamstrings. It is often performed either for time or reps as part of a dynamic warm-up.
HowTo: 1. Stand tall with your feet hip-width apart. 2. Keeping your knee straight, extend one leg back behind you while squeezing your glutes. 3. Return to the starting position and repeat for the desired number of reps before switching legs.

Title: Lying glute stretch
Desc: The lying glute stretch is a stretch to help increase flexibility in the glutes and hips. It involves rotating a single leg over the body while lying flat on the back, and reaching around the leg to facilitate a stretch. It is commonly included in dynamic warm-ups or cool-downs, but can also be performed as full-body mobility work anytime.
HowTo: 1. Lie flat on your back with your legs extended. 2. Bend one knee and cross it over your body towards the opposite side, keeping your shoulders on the ground. 3. Use your hand to gently pull the knee closer to the ground for a deeper stretch.

Title: Knee Across The Body
Desc: The knee across the body stretch helps to improve flexibility in the hips and lower back. It involves lying on your back and bringing one knee across your body to stretch the glutes and lower back.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back with your legs extended. 2. Bend one knee and bring it across your body towards the opposite side while keeping your shoulders on the ground. 3. Hold the stretch for a few seconds before returning to the starting position and switching sides.

Title: Seated Glute
Desc: The seated glute stretch is a great way to increase flexibility in the glutes and hips. It can be performed seated on the ground or on a bench.
HowTo: 1. Sit on the ground with your legs extended in front of you. 2. Bend one knee and place that foot on the opposite thigh. 3. Lean forward gently to deepen the stretch in the glutes and hold for a few seconds before switching sides.

Title: Lying Glute
Desc: The Lying Glute exercise helps in stretching and activating the glute muscles. It is beneficial for improving hip mobility and reducing tightness.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back with your knees bent and feet flat on the floor. 2. Cross one ankle over the opposite knee. 3. Gently pull the uncrossed leg towards your chest until you feel a stretch in the glute of the crossed leg. 4. Hold for 20-30 seconds and switch sides.

Title: One Knee To Chest
Desc: The One Knee To Chest exercise is designed to stretch the hip flexors and glutes. It helps improve flexibility and relieve tension in the lower back.
HowTo: 1. Start by lying on your back with your legs extended. 2. Bring one knee towards your chest, holding it with both hands. 3. Keep the other leg flat on the ground. 4. Hold the position for 20-30 seconds, then switch legs.

Title: Seated Glute Stretch
Desc: The Seated Glute Stretch targets the glutes and hamstrings, promoting flexibility and relaxation in the lower body. It is effective for relieving tightness after workouts.
HowTo: 1. Sit on the floor with your legs extended in front of you. 2. Bend one knee and place the foot on the outside of the opposite thigh. 3. Twist your torso towards the bent knee, using your opposite arm to push against the knee for a deeper stretch. 4. Hold for 20-30 seconds, then switch sides.

Title: Neck Bridge Supine
Desc: The Neck Bridge Supine is an exercise that strengthens the neck and upper back muscles. It can help improve posture and stability.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back with your knees bent and feet flat on the ground. 2. Lift your hips off the ground while pushing through your feet and shoulders. 3. Allow your head to rest on the ground, creating a bridge with your body. 4. Hold for a few seconds before lowering back down.

Title: Walking High Knee
Desc: The Walking High Knee exercise is a dynamic movement that increases heart rate and engages the lower body muscles. It is great for warming up and improving coordination.
HowTo: 1. Stand tall with your feet hip-width apart. 2. Begin walking forward, lifting your knees high towards your chest with each step. 3. Swing your arms in coordination with your legs to maintain balance. 4. Continue for 30 seconds to 1 minute.

Title: Walking Butt Kicks
Desc: Walking Butt Kicks is a dynamic exercise that helps improve cardiovascular fitness while engaging the lower body. It involves a rhythmic movement where you kick your heels towards your glutes as you walk.
HowTo: 1. Stand upright and start walking forward. 2. As you walk, lift your heels towards your glutes, alternating legs. 3. Keep a steady pace and maintain good posture.

Title: Walking Glute Stretch
Desc: The Walking Glute Stretch is designed to enhance flexibility and mobility in the hips and glutes. It involves a gentle stretch while moving, promoting better range of motion.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet hip-width apart. 2. Take a step forward with your right leg and place your right ankle over your left knee, creating a 'figure 4' position. 3. Lower your body into a slight squat to deepen the stretch, then alternate legs.

Title: Lunge kick
Desc: The lunge kick is a lower-body, cardio-based exercise performed at a high intensity. It includes a kick of the front leg to make the movement more powerful. It can be performed either for time or reps and is a great inclusion in a fat-loss or athleticism-focused circuit workout.
HowTo: 1. Start in a standing position. 2. Step forward into a lunge with your right leg, lowering your hips until both knees are bent at about a 90-degree angle. 3. Push off your right foot and kick your left leg forward, then return to the starting position and repeat on the other side.

Title: Curtsy lunge
Desc: The curtsy lunge is a lower-body bodyweight movement that targets the muscles of the hips and glutes. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps, at least 8-12 reps per leg.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet hip-width apart. 2. Step your right leg back and to the left, bending both knees to lower into a lunge. 3. Return to the starting position and repeat on the other side.

Title: Alternating standing glute stretch
Desc: The alternating standing glute stretch focuses on improving lower-body mobility and flexibility, particularly in the hips and glutes. It involves performing a partial squat in a "figure 4" position. It can be performed as part of a lower-body warm-up or done post-workout to help combat tightness and soreness.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet hip-width apart. 2. Lift your right ankle and place it over your left knee, forming a 'figure 4'. 3. Lower your body into a partial squat while keeping your back straight, then switch legs.

Title: Side-lying leg lift
Desc: The side-lying leg lift is a bodyweight exercise targeting the muscles of the hips and glutes. It can be a worthy addition to a dynamic warm-up on a lower-body or strength-focused training day, a component of a lower-body circuit or workout, or a glute activation drill to do anytime. Generally, leg lifts are done for high reps, such as 8-15 reps per leg or more.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your side with your legs straight. 2. Lift your top leg towards the ceiling while keeping it straight. 3. Lower it back down without letting it touch the bottom leg. 4. Repeat for the desired number of reps before switching sides.

Title: FYR Progressive High Knee
Desc: High knees is a full-body, cardio-based exercise with an emphasis on the lower body. It is often performed for reps or time as part of a dynamic warm-up.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet hip-width apart. 2. Quickly drive one knee up towards your chest while balancing on the other foot. 3. Switch legs rapidly, bringing the opposite knee up. 4. Continue alternating knees at a fast pace.

Title: Glute-Ham Raise - Gethin Variation
Desc: The glute ham raise is an exercise targeting the glutes and hamstrings on a GHD.
HowTo: 1. Position yourself on a glute-ham developer (GHD) with your feet secured. 2. Lower your upper body towards the ground while keeping your back straight. 3. Engage your glutes and hamstrings to raise your body back to the starting position.

Title: Lunge glute stretch
Desc: The lunge glute stretch is a lower-body stretch targeting the glutes, hips, and piriformis. It is influenced by the pigeon pose from yoga, but is performed with straight arms. It can be part of a dynamic warm-up or mobility work performed anytime.
HowTo: 1. Start in a lunge position with one foot forward and the other knee on the ground. 2. Keep your front knee over your ankle and push your hips forward. 3. Hold the stretch for a few seconds, then switch sides.

Title: Natural Glute Ham Raise - Gethin Variation
Desc: The glute ham raise is an exercise targeting the glutes and hamstrings on a GHD.
HowTo: 1. Position yourself on a glute-ham developer (GHD) with your feet secured. 2. Lower your upper body towards the ground while keeping your back straight. 3. Use your hamstrings to pull your body back up to the starting position.

Title: Groiner
Desc: The groiner is an explosive bodyweight exercise targeting the legs, shoulders, and core. It also includes a dynamic stretch of the hips. It can be performed for time or reps in any fat-loss or athleticism-focused circuit or workout.
HowTo: 1. Start in a plank position with your hands under your shoulders. 2. Jump your right foot forward to the outside of your right hand. 3. Return to the plank position and repeat on the left side. 4. Continue alternating sides for the desired number of reps or time.

Title: HM Alternating Donkey Kick
Desc: The HM Alternating Donkey Kick is a glute-focused exercise that targets the posterior chain. It can be performed on all fours, alternating legs to engage the glutes effectively.
HowTo: 1. Start on all fours with your hands under your shoulders and knees under your hips. 2. Keeping your knee bent, lift your right leg towards the ceiling. 3. Lower back to the starting position and repeat with the left leg. 4. Continue alternating legs for the desired number of reps.

Title: HM Alternating Slow Step-Down With Chair
Desc: The HM Alternating Slow Step-Down With Chair is a controlled exercise that targets the lower body. It emphasizes balance and strength by stepping down slowly from a chair.
HowTo: 1. Stand in front of a chair with your feet hip-width apart. 2. Step down with your right foot, lowering your body slowly until your left foot touches the ground. 3. Push through your right heel to return to the starting position. 4. Repeat on the left side, alternating for the desired number of reps.

Title: HM Right Side Iron Cross
Desc: The HM Right Side Iron Cross is an exercise that targets the core and improves stability. It involves a rotational movement that engages the obliques.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back with your arms extended to the sides and legs raised. 2. Rotate your hips to the right while lowering your legs towards the ground. 3. Return to the starting position and repeat on the left side. 4. Continue alternating sides for the desired number of reps.

Title: HM Single-Leg Bridge
Desc: The HM Single-Leg Bridge is an effective exercise for strengthening the glutes and hamstrings. It is performed by lifting one leg while bridging the hips.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back with your knees bent and feet flat on the ground. 2. Extend one leg straight up towards the ceiling. 3. Push through your heel on the grounded foot to lift your hips off the ground. 4. Hold for a moment at the top, then lower back down. 5. Repeat for the desired number of reps before switching legs.

Title: HM Hi-Low
Desc: The HM Hi-Low is an effective exercise targeting the upper body, focusing on the triceps and shoulders. It involves alternating between high and low positions to engage different muscle fibers.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. 2. Hold a weight in one hand and extend it overhead. 3. Lower the weight to the side of your body, then raise it back to the starting position. 4. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: HM Kick-Back
Desc: The HM Kick-Back is designed to strengthen the triceps and shoulders. This exercise involves extending the arm backward while maintaining a stable position.
HowTo: 1. Bend at the waist with a slight bend in your knees. 2. Hold a weight in one hand, keeping your elbow close to your body. 3. Extend your arm back until it is straight, then return to the starting position. 4. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: HM Left Side Iron Cross
Desc: The HM Left Side Iron Cross is a dynamic movement that enhances mobility and stability throughout the body. It engages the core while promoting flexibility in the shoulders and legs.
HowTo: 1. Start in a standing position with feet shoulder-width apart. 2. Raise your left arm overhead and extend your right leg out to the side. 3. Cross your left arm over your body while bringing your right leg back to the center. 4. Return to the starting position and repeat on the opposite side.

Title: HM Left Side-Kick
Desc: The HM Left Side-Kick is a lower body exercise that targets the legs and glutes. It helps improve strength and balance by focusing on lateral movement.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet together. 2. Shift your weight to your right leg and lift your left leg out to the side. 3. Keep your leg straight and hold for a moment before lowering it back down. 4. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions before switching sides.

Title: HM Leg Lifts
Desc: The HM Leg Lifts are a core strengthening exercise that targets the abdominal muscles and hip flexors. This movement helps improve core stability and strength.
HowTo: 1. Lie flat on your back with your legs extended. 2. Place your hands under your hips for support. 3. Keeping your legs straight, lift them towards the ceiling until your body forms a 90-degree angle. 4. Slowly lower your legs back to the starting position without touching the ground.

Title: Walking lunge
Desc: The walking lunge is a lower-body exercise that targets the glutes, quads, and hamstrings while challenging stability and balance. It can be performed for reps, time, or distance in the lower-body portion of any workout.
HowTo: 1. Stand upright with feet shoulder-width apart. 2. Step forward with one leg, lowering your hips until both knees are bent at about a 90-degree angle. 3. Push through the front heel to return to standing and repeat on the other side.

Title: High Plyometric Box Jump
Desc: The High Plyometric Box Jump is a dynamic exercise that improves explosive power and leg strength.
HowTo: 1. Stand in front of a sturdy box or platform. 2. Bend your knees slightly and swing your arms back. 3. Jump explosively onto the box, landing softly with your knees slightly bent. 4. Step back down and repeat.

Title: Barbell hip thrust-
Desc: The barbell hip thrust is a popular exercise that targets the posterior chain, particularly the glutes and hamstrings. It involves fully extending your hips while holding a weighted barbell across the front of the hips. It is a great movement to activate the glutes prior to other lower-body training, but can also be performed in the main part of a workout, or for high reps as a glute burnout.
HowTo: 1. Sit on the ground with your upper back against a bench and roll a barbell over your hips. 2. Plant your feet flat on the ground, shoulder-width apart. 3.
