Drive through your heels to lift your hips until your body forms a straight line from shoulders to knees. 4. Lower back down and repeat.

Title: UN Glute Bridge
Desc: The UN Glute Bridge is an effective exercise for targeting the glutes and hamstrings.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back with your knees bent and feet flat on the ground. 2. Push through your heels to lift your hips towards the ceiling, squeezing your glutes at the top. 3. Lower back down and repeat.

Title: Holman Donkey Kick
Desc: The Holman Donkey Kick is a targeted exercise for the glutes and hamstrings.
HowTo: 1. Start on all fours with your hands under your shoulders and knees under your hips. 2. Keeping your knee bent, lift one leg towards the ceiling, squeezing your glutes at the top. 3. Lower back down and repeat on the same side before switching.

Title: Holman Hip Raise with Alternating Kick
Desc: The Holman Hip Raise with Alternating Kick is an effective exercise for targeting the glutes and hamstrings. It involves raising the hips while alternating leg kicks to engage the core and improve stability.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back with your knees bent and feet flat on the floor. 2. Lift your hips towards the ceiling, squeezing your glutes. 3. While holding the hip raise, extend one leg straight out and then alternate with the other leg. 4. Lower your hips back down and repeat.

Title: Holman Left Leg Donkey Kick
Desc: The Holman Left Leg Donkey Kick primarily targets the glutes and hamstrings. This exercise helps to build strength and stability in the lower body.
HowTo: 1. Start on all fours with your hands under your shoulders and knees under your hips. 2. Keeping your knee bent, lift your left leg towards the ceiling, squeezing your glutes at the top. 3. Lower your leg back to the starting position and repeat. 4. Switch to the right leg after completing the set.

Title: Holman Diagonal Right Leg Step-Out to Right Knee-Up
Desc: The Holman Diagonal Right Leg Step-Out to Right Knee-Up is a dynamic exercise that engages the legs and core. It helps improve balance and coordination while strengthening the lower body.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet hip-width apart. 2. Step diagonally to the right with your right foot, bending your knee into a lunge. 3. Push off your right foot to bring your right knee up towards your chest. 4. Return to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Holman Right Leg Donkey Kick
Desc: The Holman Right Leg Donkey Kick is designed to strengthen the glutes and hamstrings. It is a great exercise for improving lower body strength and stability.
HowTo: 1. Start on all fours with your hands under your shoulders and knees under your hips. 2. Keeping your knee bent, lift your right leg towards the ceiling, squeezing your glutes at the top. 3. Lower your leg back to the starting position and repeat. 4. Switch to the left leg after completing the set.

Title: Holman Butt Tap to Jump
Desc: The Holman Butt Tap to Jump is a high-energy exercise that combines strength and cardio. It targets multiple muscle groups while improving cardiovascular fitness.
HowTo: 1. Start in a standing position with your feet shoulder-width apart. 2. Lower into a squat and tap your butt with your hands. 3. Explode upwards into a jump, reaching your arms overhead. 4. Land softly and immediately go into the next squat.

Title: Holman Butt Tap to Jump-Forward-Jump-Back
Desc: The Holman Butt Tap to Jump-Forward-Jump-Back is a dynamic exercise that combines cardio and agility. It engages multiple muscle groups while improving coordination and endurance.
HowTo: 1. Start in a standing position. 2. Jump forward, landing softly. 3. Tap your butt with one hand while balancing. 4. Jump back to the starting position. 5. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Holman Traveling High Knees to Squat Thrust
Desc: The Holman Traveling High Knees to Squat Thrust is a high-intensity exercise that combines high knees with squat thrusts. It effectively works the lower body while also engaging the core and shoulders.
HowTo: 1. Start by jogging in place, bringing your knees up high. 2. After a few seconds, drop into a squat and kick your feet back into a plank position. 3. Quickly return to the squat and then back to high knees. 4. Repeat the sequence for the desired duration.

Title: Holman Butt Kicker to High Knees
Desc: The Holman Butt Kicker to High Knees is a fast-paced exercise that alternates between butt kicks and high knees. It enhances cardiovascular fitness while targeting the legs and core.
HowTo: 1. Start jogging in place, alternating between kicking your heels to your glutes and lifting your knees high. 2. Maintain a quick pace, switching between the two movements. 3. Continue for the desired time, focusing on form.

Title: Holman Daisy Cutter
Desc: The Holman Daisy Cutter is an energetic exercise that combines explosive movements to enhance agility and coordination. It targets the legs and core while providing a cardiovascular workout.
HowTo: 1. Begin in a standing position with feet shoulder-width apart. 2. Lower into a squat and then jump explosively forward. 3. Land softly and immediately go into a squat again. 4. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Holman Frogger
Desc: The Holman Frogger is a dynamic exercise that combines a squat with a jump forward, enhancing both strength and cardiovascular fitness. It engages multiple muscle groups for a full-body workout.
HowTo: 1. Start in a squat position with your feet shoulder-width apart. 2. Jump forward explosively while extending your arms. 3. Land softly back into a squat. 4. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Holman Hip Raise with Chest Press
Desc: The Holman Hip Raise with Chest Press is an exercise that combines hip thrusting with a chest press. It effectively targets the glutes while also engaging the upper body.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back with your knees bent and feet flat on the floor. 2. Hold a weight or resistance band in both hands above your chest. 3. Lift your hips towards the ceiling while pressing the weight up. 4. Lower your hips and the weight back down to the starting position.

Title: Total Fitness Bear Crawl
Desc: The bear crawl is a popular bodyweight crawling exercise. While it looks simple, the bear crawl is an intense full-body movement that targets the cardiovascular system as well as a wide range of muscle groups, the shoulders, core, and legs in particular. It can be done as a full-body warm-up, in short bursts for power or circuit training, or for longer durations as cardiovascular conditioning.
HowTo: 1. Start on all fours with your hands under your shoulders and knees under your hips. 2. Lift your knees off the ground slightly. 3. Move your right hand and left foot forward simultaneously, then switch sides. 4. Continue crawling forward in a controlled manner.

Title: Pigeon stretch
Desc: The pigeon stretch is a lower-body stretch targeting the glutes, hips, and piriformis. It is similar to the pigeon pose from yoga, but is also popular as part of dynamic warm-ups or cool-downs in strength training. It can also be performed anytime to help combat training-related soreness.
HowTo: 1. Start in a plank position. 2. Bring your right knee forward and place it behind your right wrist. 3. Extend your left leg straight back behind you. 4. Lower your torso towards the ground for a deeper stretch.

Title: Levitating side kick-through
Desc: The levitating side kick-through is a full-body movement that starts in a bear crawl position and ends with a leg kicked out to the side. In between reps, you kick into the air in a partial handstand. It is commonly performed for reps or time in bodyweight circuits and animal-style flows, but can also work on its own or as part of a dynamic warm-up or mobility sequence.
HowTo: 1. Start in a bear crawl position. 2. Kick your right leg out to the side while lifting your hips and torso. 3. Return to the bear crawl position. 4. Alternate sides with each repetition.

Title: 30 Legs Hip Thrust
Desc: The 30 Legs Hip Thrust is an exercise focused on strengthening the glutes and hamstrings. It is performed by thrusting the hips upward while keeping the upper back on a bench.
HowTo: 1. Sit on the ground with your upper back against a bench and feet flat on the floor. 2. Roll a barbell or weight over your hips. 3. Drive through your heels and lift your hips towards the ceiling. 4. Lower your hips back down to the starting position.

Title: Dumbbell single-leg hip thrust
Desc: The dumbbell single-leg hip thrust is a single-sided exercise that targets the posterior chain, particularly the glutes and hamstrings. It involves balancing on one foot and fully extending your hips while holding a dumbbell across the front of your hip. It is a great movement to activate the glutes prior to other lower-body training, but can also be performed in the main part of a workout, or for high reps as a glute burnout.
HowTo: 1. Sit on the ground with your upper back against a bench or elevated surface. 2. Place a dumbbell across your hips. 3. Extend one leg straight out while keeping the other foot flat on the ground. 4. Drive through the heel of the grounded foot to lift your hips towards the ceiling. 5. Lower your hips back down and repeat.

Title: Medicine ball duck walk
Desc: The medicine ball duck walk is a dynamic medicine ball movement that challenges both the upper and lower body, while also elevating the heart rate. It's a great movement to include in medicine ball or bodyweight circuit training to increase fatigue and burn serious calories while hammering the muscles of the legs.
HowTo: 1. Hold a medicine ball at chest level. 2. Lower your body into a squat position. 3. Walk forward while staying low in the squat, taking small steps. 4. Keep your core engaged and maintain balance.

Title: Exercise ball hip thrust
Desc: The exercise ball hip thrust is a simple yet effective way to work the glutes and hamstrings. Proper form is essential to really feel the burn in the glutes, and the ball can help guide you into the right form better than a bench, which is the usual support for hip thrusts. Unlike the bench version, the ball hip thrust is best performed with body weight or bands as resistance for safety reasons. It can be an excellent component of a warm-up for lower-body training, or a glute activation drill performed anytime.
HowTo: 1. Sit on the ground with your upper back against an exercise ball. 2. Roll the ball so that your shoulder blades are resting on it and your feet are flat on the ground. 3. Drive through your heels and lift your hips towards the ceiling. 4. Squeeze your glutes at the top, then lower back down.

Title: Downward Facing Balance
Desc: The Downward Facing Balance is a balance and mobility exercise that helps improve stability and flexibility throughout the body. It engages multiple muscle groups while promoting body awareness.
HowTo: 1. Start in a standing position. 2. Bend forward at the hips and extend one leg back while keeping the other leg straight. 3. Reach your arms forward for balance. 4. Hold the position, then switch legs.

Title: Band Good Morning (Pull Through)
Desc: The Band Good Morning (Pull Through) is an effective exercise for strengthening the posterior chain, particularly the hamstrings and glutes. It utilizes a resistance band to provide tension throughout the movement.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and a resistance band anchored behind you. 2. Hold the band with both hands and hinge at the hips, keeping your back straight. 3. Lower your torso until it's parallel to the ground, then drive through your heels to return to standing. 4. Squeeze your glutes at the top.

Title: Standing Hamstring and Calf Stretch
Desc: The Standing Hamstring and Calf Stretch is designed to improve flexibility in the hamstrings and calves. It is essential for maintaining mobility and preventing injuries.
HowTo: 1. Stand upright with feet hip-width apart. 2. Bend at the hips and reach towards your toes while keeping your legs straight. 3. Hold the stretch for 15-30 seconds, feeling the stretch in your hamstrings and calves.

Title: Hamstring-SMR
Desc: Hamstring-SMR (Self-Myofascial Release) is a technique used to relieve tension in the hamstrings. This exercise helps improve flexibility and reduce muscle soreness.
HowTo: 1. Sit on the floor with your legs extended in front of you. 2. Place a foam roller under your hamstrings. 3. Roll back and forth slowly to massage the muscle for 1-2 minutes.

Title: Barbell Deadlift
Desc: The barbell deadlift is a compound exercise used to develop overall strength and size in the posterior chain. It is a competition lift in the sport of powerlifting, but is also considered a classic benchmark of overall strength. When performed with the hands outside the knees, it is often called a "conventional" deadlift. When the feet are wide and the hands are inside the knees, it is a sumo deadlift.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet hip-width apart, barbell over the midfoot. 2. Bend at the hips and knees to grip the barbell. 3. Keep your back straight and lift the bar by extending your hips and knees simultaneously. 4. Lower the bar back to the ground with control.

Title: Clean Deadlift
Desc: The Clean Deadlift is a variation of the deadlift that emphasizes proper lifting technique and strength development. It is often used to prepare for Olympic lifts.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and the barbell over your midfoot. 2. Bend at the hips and knees to grip the barbell. 3. Keep your chest up and back straight as you lift the barbell by extending your hips and knees. 4. Lower the barbell back to the ground with control.

Title: Sumo deadlift
Desc: The sumo deadlift is a compound movement in which the feet are set in a wide stance with toes pointed out and grip is placed inside of the legs. It is allowed to be performed instead of conventional deadlifts in most powerlifting competitions. The sumo deadlift targets the hamstrings, glutes, and upper back/traps, but also has a greater emphasis on stretching and strengthening the adductor and hip muscles due to the wide stance.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet wider than shoulder-width apart and toes pointed out. 2. Bend at the hips and knees to grip the barbell inside your legs. 3. Keep your chest up and back straight as you lift the barbell by extending your hips and knees. 4. Lower the barbell back to the ground with control.

Title: Romanian Deadlift from Deficit
Desc: The Romanian deadlift from deficit is a variation of the traditional deadlift that emphasizes the hamstrings and glutes. It is performed from a lower starting position, increasing the range of motion.
HowTo: 1. Stand on a platform or weight plate to create a deficit. 2. Hold a barbell with both hands in front of your thighs. 3. Hinge at your hips and lower the barbell while keeping your back straight. 4. Lower the barbell until you feel a stretch in your hamstrings. 5. Return to the starting position by driving through your heels and extending your hips.

Title: Power Snatch
Desc: The power snatch is a dynamic Olympic lift that involves lifting the barbell from the ground to overhead in one fluid motion. It requires strength, speed, and technique.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and the barbell over your midfoot. 2. Grip the barbell with a wide grip. 3. Initiate the lift by extending your legs and hips. 4. Pull the barbell upward, keeping it close to your body. 5. As the bar reaches your hips, explosively extend your hips and shrug your shoulders. 6. Pull yourself under the bar and catch it overhead with arms fully extended. 7. Stand up straight to complete the lift.

Title: Power Clean from Blocks
Desc: The power clean from blocks is a variation of the power clean that starts from an elevated position. This exercise focuses on explosive power and technique.
HowTo: 1. Set the barbell on blocks at knee height. 2. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and grip the barbell just outside your knees. 3. Initiate the lift by extending your legs and driving through your heels. 4. As the bar rises, pull it close to your body and extend your hips. 5. Quickly drop under the bar and catch it in the front rack position. 6. Stand up to complete the lift.

Title: Snatch Deadlift
Desc: The snatch deadlift is a variation of the deadlift that focuses on the starting position of the snatch. It helps to improve strength and technique for the snatch lift.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and the barbell over your midfoot. 2. Grip the barbell with a wide grip, similar to the snatch grip. 3. Lower your hips and keep your back straight. 4. Lift the barbell by extending your legs and hips simultaneously. 5. Keep the bar close to your body as you lift it to your hips. 6. Lower the bar back to the ground with control.

Title: Power clean
Desc: The power clean is a full-body movement in which the bar is pulled from the floor and caught in the front rack position in three pulls or phases. The bar is received in the "power" position, with the hips higher than a full-depth squat position. The power clean can be used as a component of the clean and press or clean and jerk, but is also a valuable lift to build explosive power and strength.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and the barbell over your midfoot. 2. Grip the barbell just outside your knees. 3. Initiate the lift by extending your legs and hips. 4. Pull the barbell upward, keeping it close to your body. 5. As the bar reaches your hips, explosively extend your hips and shrug your shoulders. 6. Pull yourself under the bar and catch it in the front rack position. 7. Stand up to complete the lift.

Title: Hang Snatch
Desc: The Hang Snatch is a dynamic Olympic weightlifting movement that develops explosive power and coordination. It involves lifting a barbell from a hanging position to overhead in one fluid motion.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, holding the barbell at thigh level. 2. Bend your knees slightly and hinge at the hips to lower the barbell. 3. Explosively extend your hips and knees while pulling the barbell upward. 4. Drop under the bar and catch it overhead with arms fully extended. 5. Stand up straight to complete the lift.

Title: Wide Stance Stiff Legs
Desc: Wide Stance Stiff Legs is a variation of the deadlift that emphasizes the hamstrings and glutes. It involves a wider stance to target the inner thighs and improve flexibility.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet wider than shoulder-width apart, holding a barbell in front of you. 2. Keep your back straight and hinge at the hips to lower the barbell while maintaining a slight bend in your knees. 3. Lower the barbell until you feel a stretch in your hamstrings. 4. Return to the starting position by driving through your heels and extending your hips.

Title: Clean
Desc: The Clean is a foundational Olympic lift that develops strength and power across multiple muscle groups. It involves lifting a barbell from the ground to the shoulders in one smooth motion.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet hip-width apart and the barbell over your mid-foot. 2. Grip the barbell with both hands just outside your knees. 3. Lift the barbell by extending your hips and knees simultaneously. 4. Once the bar reaches your thighs, explosively pull it upward while dropping into a squat position. 5. Catch the barbell on your shoulders and stand up.

Title: Good Morning
Desc: The barbell good morning is an exercise that targets glute, hamstring, and lower back development. It is often trained as an accessory movement to the deadlift, but also has value on its own. It is sometimes performed for reps in traditional strength-focused rep ranges such as 5-8 reps per set, but due to the risk posed to the lower back, is rarely treated as a max-effort single-rep lift.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and a barbell resting on your upper back. 2. Keep your back straight and hinge at the hips to lower your torso forward. 3. Lower until you feel a stretch in your hamstrings, keeping a slight bend in your knees. 4. Return to the starting position by driving your hips forward and standing tall.

Title: Barbell stiff-legged deadlift
Desc: The barbell stiff-legged deadlift targets the hamstrings, glutes, lower and upper back, as well as the core. It is a popular accessory movement for the deadlift, but also a muscle-building hamstring movement.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a barbell in front of your thighs. 2. Keep your legs straight (with a slight bend in the knees) and hinge at the hips to lower the barbell towards the ground. 3. Lower until you feel a stretch in your hamstrings, maintaining a flat back. 4. Return to the starting position by extending your hips and standing tall.

Title: Romanian Deadlift
Desc: The barbell stiff-legged deadlift targets the hamstrings, glutes, lower and upper back, as well as the core. It is a popular accessory movement for the deadlift, but also a muscle-building hamstring movement.
Muscles: Hamstrings, Glutes, Lower Back, Upper Back, Core
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a barbell in front of your thighs. 2. Keeping your back straight, hinge at the hips and lower the barbell down along your legs until you feel a stretch in your hamstrings. 3. Return to the starting position by driving through your heels and engaging your glutes.

Title: Sumo Deadlift with Chains
Desc: The sumo deadlift with chains is a variation that emphasizes the legs and glutes while providing accommodating resistance through the chains.
HowTo: 1. Set up a barbell with chains attached on either side. 2. Stand with a wide stance, toes pointed out, and grip the barbell with both hands. 3. Lower your hips and engage your core, then push through your heels to lift the barbell while keeping your back straight.

Title: Sumo Deadlift with Bands
Desc: The sumo deadlift with bands provides resistance that increases as you lift, targeting the legs and glutes effectively.
HowTo: 1. Attach resistance bands to a barbell and secure the other end to the floor. 2. Stand with a wide stance, grip the barbell, and lower your hips. 3. Engage your core and lift the barbell by pushing through your heels and extending your hips.

Title: Good Morning off Pins
Desc: The Good Morning off Pins is a variation that targets the posterior chain, focusing on the hamstrings and lower back.
HowTo: 1. Set a barbell on pins at shoulder height. 2. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and position the barbell on your upper back. 3. Hinge at the hips, lowering your torso while keeping your back straight, then return to the starting position.

Title: Stiff-Legged Deadlift
Desc: The barbell stiff-legged deadlift targets the hamstrings, glutes, lower and upper back, as well as the core. It is a popular accessory movement for the deadlift, but also a muscle-building hamstring movement.
Muscles: Hamstrings, Glutes, Lower Back, Upper Back, Core
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a barbell in front of your thighs. 2. Keeping your back straight, hinge at the hips and lower the barbell down along your legs until you feel a stretch in your hamstrings. 3. Return to the starting position by driving through your heels and engaging your glutes.

Title: Snatch Pull
Desc: The Snatch Pull is a powerful exercise that focuses on the explosive movement of the snatch. It helps develop strength and technique for Olympic lifting.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and grip the barbell with a wide grip. 2. Start with the barbell on the floor, then lift it to your hips while keeping it close to your body. 3. Extend your hips and knees explosively, pulling the barbell upwards. 4. Lower the barbell back to the starting position.

Title: Hanging Bar Good Morning
Desc: The Hanging Bar Good Morning is an effective exercise for strengthening the posterior chain. It emphasizes the hamstrings and lower back while improving flexibility.
HowTo: 1. Hang from a pull-up bar with your hands shoulder-width apart. 2. With your feet off the ground, hinge at the hips to lower your torso forward. 3. Keep your back straight and return to the starting position by engaging your hamstrings and glutes.

Title: Reverse Band Sumo Deadlift
Desc: The Reverse Band Sumo Deadlift is a variation of the deadlift that reduces the load at the bottom of the lift. It targets the legs and glutes while improving strength.
HowTo: 1. Set up a barbell on the floor with bands attached to the sides. 2. Stand with a wide stance, gripping the barbell with both hands. 3. Lower your hips and pull the barbell up while keeping your back straight. 4. Fully extend your hips and knees at the top before lowering the barbell back down.

Title: Muscle Snatch
Desc: The Muscle Snatch is a dynamic exercise that combines strength and speed. It is essential for developing power and coordination in Olympic lifting.
HowTo: 1. Start with the barbell on the floor and grip it with a wide grip. 2. Pull the barbell off the ground, extending your hips and knees. 3. As the barbell reaches your hips, pull it up explosively and drop under it to catch it overhead. 4. Stand up with the barbell locked out overhead.

Title: Split Snatch
Desc: The Split Snatch is a variation of the snatch that involves a split stance. It helps improve balance, coordination, and explosive strength.
HowTo: 1. Start with the barbell on the floor and grip it with a wide grip. 2. Pull the barbell up, extending your hips and knees. 3. As the barbell reaches its peak, split your legs into a lunge position, catching the barbell overhead. 4. Stand up with the barbell locked out overhead, then return to the starting position.

Title: Hang Snatch - Below Knees
Desc: The Hang Snatch - Below Knees is a dynamic Olympic weightlifting movement that focuses on explosive power and technique. It is performed from a hanging position below the knees, emphasizing strength and coordination.
HowTo: 1. Start in a standing position with the barbell at mid-shin level. 2. Grip the barbell with a wide grip. 3. Initiate the movement by driving through your legs and extending your hips. 4. Pull the barbell upward, keeping it close to your body. 5. Drop under the bar and catch it in a full squat position. 6. Stand up to complete the lift.

Title: 30 Legs Sumo Deadlift
Desc: The 30 Legs Sumo Deadlift is a variation of the traditional deadlift that emphasizes the inner thighs and glutes. It is performed with a wide stance to target different muscle groups effectively.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet wider than shoulder-width apart and toes pointed slightly outward. 2. Bend at the hips and knees to lower your body and grip the barbell. 3. Keep your back straight and chest up as you lift the barbell by extending your hips and knees. 4. Stand tall at the top of the movement, then lower the bar back to the ground.

Title: Kettlebell pass-through lunge
Desc: The kettlebell pass-through lunge is a dynamic leg and core exercise in which a lifter passes a weight under their front leg during lunges. It is a unique coordination challenge, but also challenging to the musculature of the abdomen, lower body, shoulders, and upper back. It is most commonly performed for higher reps, such as 10-15 reps per side, or for time. It can work in circuit-style workouts, or in lower-body or full-body time-efficient training.
HowTo: 1. Start in a standing position holding a kettlebell in one hand. 2. Step forward into a lunge with the opposite leg. 3. As you lunge, pass the kettlebell under your front leg to the other hand. 4. Push back to the starting position and repeat on the other side.

Title: Kettlebell One-Legged Deadlift
Desc: The kettlebell single-leg deadlift is a variation on the kettlebell deadlift where one foot stays planted on the ground while the other raises into the air at the bottom of the movement. It's popular in lower-body training for strength and muscle building, but also trains balance, grip, and the core muscles.
HowTo: 1. Stand on one leg while holding a kettlebell in the opposite hand. 2. Hinge at the hip, lowering the kettlebell towards the ground while extending the free leg behind you. 3. Keep your back straight and core engaged. 4. Return to the starting position by driving through the standing leg.

Title: Single-arm kettlebell clean
Desc: The single-arm kettlebell clean is an explosive kettlebell exercise where the lifter pulls the weight to shoulder level in a single movement. While the kettlebell clean is often used as a transitional movement into the press or front squat, it is also a valuable strength and power exercise in its own right. It can be performed in low rep ranges for strength or higher rep ranges for technique practice or muscle growth.
HowTo: 1. Start with a kettlebell on the ground between your feet. 2. Bend at the hips and knees to grip the kettlebell with one hand. 3. Drive through your legs and pull the kettlebell up to shoulder level in one smooth motion. 4. Rotate your wrist as you catch the kettlebell at shoulder height. 5. Lower the kettlebell back to the ground and repeat.

Title: Single-leg kettlebell deadlift
Desc: The kettlebell single-leg deadlift is a variation on the kettlebell deadlift where one foot stays planted on the ground while the other raises into the air at the bottom of the movement. It's popular in lower-body training for strength and muscle building, but also trains balance, grip, and the core muscles.
HowTo: 1. Stand on one leg while holding a kettlebell in the opposite hand. 2. Hinge at the hip, lowering the kettlebell towards the ground while keeping your back straight and the other leg extended behind you. 3. Return to the starting position by engaging your glutes and hamstrings.

Title: Romanian Deadlift with Kettlebell
Desc: The Romanian Deadlift with Kettlebell is a strength exercise that targets the posterior chain, focusing on the hamstrings and glutes.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet hip-width apart, holding a kettlebell in both hands. 2. Hinge at the hips, lowering the kettlebell down the front of your legs while keeping your back straight. 3. Return to the starting position by driving your hips forward.

Title: Single-arm kettlebell swing
Desc: The single-arm kettlebell swing is a popular exercise emphasizing the muscles of the hamstrings, glutes, and back. Because you are only swinging with one arm at a time, it is also uniquely challenging to the grip and core muscles. It is often used to train explosive power, for aerobic or cardiovascular conditioning, or in circuit training.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, holding a kettlebell in one hand. 2. Swing the kettlebell between your legs, then explosively drive your hips forward while swinging the kettlebell up to shoulder height. 3. Allow the kettlebell to swing back down and repeat.

Title: Kettlebell Dead Clean
Desc: The Kettlebell Dead Clean is a full-body exercise that focuses on lifting the kettlebell from the ground to the rack position, engaging multiple muscle groups.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, kettlebell on the ground between your feet. 2. Bend at the hips and knees to grasp the kettlebell with one hand. 3. Drive through your heels to lift the kettlebell to your shoulder, rotating your wrist to end in the rack position.

Title: Alternating Hang Clean
Desc: The Alternating Hang Clean is a dynamic exercise that targets multiple muscle groups while improving coordination and strength.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, holding a kettlebell in each hand. 2. Bend at the hips and knees to lower the kettlebells, then explosively pull one kettlebell up to your shoulder while dropping the other back down. 3. Alternate between sides with each repetition.

Title: One-Arm Open Palm Kettlebell Clean
Desc: The One-Arm Open Palm Kettlebell Clean is a dynamic exercise that engages multiple muscle groups. It helps improve grip strength and overall coordination.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and hold a kettlebell in one hand. 2. Bend your knees slightly and hinge at the hips to lower the kettlebell towards the ground. 3. Explosively extend your hips and pull the kettlebell upward, rotating your palm to face forward. 4. Catch the kettlebell at shoulder height with your elbow tucked in. 5. Lower the kettlebell back to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Open Palm Kettlebell Clean
Desc: The Open Palm Kettlebell Clean is an effective exercise for building strength and coordination. It targets the upper body and core while improving grip strength.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, holding a kettlebell with both hands. 2. Bend your knees slightly and hinge at the hips to lower the kettlebell. 3. Drive through your legs and pull the kettlebell upward, rotating your palms to face forward. 4. Catch the kettlebell at shoulder height. 5. Lower it back down and repeat.

Title: Kettlebell Hang Clean
Desc: The Kettlebell Hang Clean is a powerful exercise that engages multiple muscle groups for a full-body workout. It enhances strength, power, and coordination.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, holding a kettlebell with both hands at arm's length. 2. Hinge at the hips and lower the kettlebell between your legs. 3. Explosively extend your hips and pull the kettlebell upward, keeping it close to your body. 4. Rotate your palms to face forward and catch the kettlebell at shoulder height. 5. Lower it back down and repeat.

Title: Double Kettlebell Alternating Hang Clean
Desc: The Double Kettlebell Alternating Hang Clean is a challenging exercise that targets the entire body. It improves strength, coordination, and endurance.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, holding a kettlebell in each hand at arm's length. 2. Hinge at the hips and lower the kettlebells between your legs. 3. Explosively extend your hips and pull one kettlebell upward, alternating with the other. 4. Rotate your palms to face forward and catch the kettlebells at shoulder height. 5. Lower them back down and repeat, alternating sides.

Title: Romanian Deadlift With Dumbbells
Desc: The dumbbell stiff-legged deadlift targets the hamstrings, glutes, low and upper back, as well as the core. The purpose of the stiff-legged, as opposed to Romanian deadlift with slightly bent knees, is to engage the hamstrings and low back to an even greater degree.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet hip-width apart, holding a dumbbell in each hand at your sides. 2. Hinge at the hips and lower the dumbbells along your legs while keeping your back straight. 3. Lower until you feel a stretch in your hamstrings. 4. Drive through your heels to return to the starting position, squeezing your glutes at the top. 5. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Stiff-Legged Dumbbell Deadlift
Desc: The dumbbell stiff-legged deadlift targets the hamstrings, glutes, low and upper back, as well as the core. The purpose of the stiff-legged, as opposed to Romanian deadlift with slightly bent knees, is to engage the hamstrings and low back to an even greater degree.
Muscles: Hamstrings, Glutes, Lower Back, Upper Back, Core
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, holding a dumbbell in each hand. 2. Keep your back straight and hinge at the hips, lowering the dumbbells towards the ground while keeping your legs straight. 3. Lower until you feel a stretch in your hamstrings, then return to the starting position by driving your hips forward.

Title: Vertical Swing
Desc: The vertical swing is a dynamic exercise that engages multiple muscle groups and elevates heart rate. It involves swinging a weight vertically, focusing on explosive movement.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, holding a dumbbell with both hands. 2. Bend your knees slightly and hinge at the hips to swing the dumbbell between your legs. 3. Explosively extend your hips and knees to swing the dumbbell upward to shoulder height, then let it fall back down and repeat.

Title: Dumbbell Fix Dumbbell Swing
Desc: The Dumbbell Fix Dumbbell Swing is a full-body exercise that combines strength and coordination. It focuses on swinging a dumbbell in a controlled manner to engage various muscle groups.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, holding a dumbbell in one hand. 2. Bend your knees slightly and hinge at the hips to swing the dumbbell between your legs. 3. Use your hips to propel the dumbbell forward and upward, keeping your arm straight, then let it swing back down and repeat.

Title: Dumbbell Lying Hamstring Curl
Desc: The Dumbbell Lying Hamstring Curl is an isolation exercise that targets the hamstrings. It is performed while lying on your stomach and curling the dumbbells towards your glutes.
HowTo: 1. Lie face down on a bench with your legs hanging off the edge, holding a dumbbell between your feet. 2. Keeping your hips down, curl the dumbbell towards your glutes by bending your knees. 3. Lower the dumbbell back to the starting position and repeat.

Title: 30 Legs Dumbbell Stiff-Legged Deadlift
Desc: The 30 Legs Dumbbell Stiff-Legged Deadlift is a variation of the traditional stiff-legged deadlift that emphasizes the legs. It focuses on building strength in the hamstrings and glutes.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, holding a dumbbell in each hand. 2. Keep your back straight and hinge at the hips, lowering the dumbbells towards the ground while keeping your legs straight. 3. Lower until you feel a stretch in your hamstrings, then return to the starting position by driving your hips forward.

Title: Box jump
Desc: The box jump is an explosive exercise that strengthens the muscles of the lower body, including the quads, glutes, calves, and hamstrings. They also develop power in the lower body while revving the heart rate. Box jumps can be performed for low reps to focus on strength and power, or for higher reps for metabolic conditioning. Most coaches recommend stepping down rather than jumping down between reps.
HowTo: 1. Stand in front of a sturdy box or platform. 2. Bend your knees and swing your arms back. 3. Jump explosively onto the box, landing softly with your knees slightly bent. 4. Step back down and repeat.

Title: Box Jump (Multiple Response)
Desc: The box jump is a plyometric exercise that strengthens the muscles of the lower body, including the quads, glutes, calves and hamstrings. They also develop power in the lower-body while revving the heart rate.
HowTo: 1. Stand in front of a sturdy box or platform. 2. Bend your knees and swing your arms back. 3. Jump explosively onto the box, landing softly with your knees slightly bent. 4. Step back down and repeat.

Title: Sled push-
Desc: The sled push is a conditioning exercise that targets the cardiovascular system and the muscles of the lower body. It involves pushing a sled along turf or another flat surface either for time or distance. Depending on your type of equipment, you may be pushing handles or straps in front of the sled. It can be used as part of a dynamic warm-up or for power training, as a finisher, or as part of a conditioning workout or circuit.
HowTo: 1. Stand behind the sled with feet shoulder-width apart. 2. Grip the handles or straps firmly. 3. Push the sled forward using your legs and arms, maintaining a strong posture. 4. Continue pushing for the desired distance or time.

Title: Lying Hamstring
Desc: The lying hamstring exercise targets the hamstrings effectively. It is essential for strengthening the back of the legs.
HowTo: 1. Lie flat on your back on a mat. 2. Bend one knee and bring your heel towards your glutes. 3. Hold the position for a few seconds before switching legs. 4. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Chair Leg Extended Stretch
Desc: The Chair Leg Extended Stretch is a mobility exercise that helps stretch the legs. It improves flexibility and range of motion in the lower body.
HowTo: 1. Sit on the edge of a chair with your feet flat on the ground. 2. Extend one leg straight out in front of you, keeping it parallel to the floor. 3. Reach towards your toes while keeping your back straight. 4. Hold the stretch for 15-30 seconds and switch legs.

Title: Suspended Leg Curl
Desc: The Suspended Leg Curl is an exercise that targets the hamstrings using suspension training. It helps improve strength and stability in the lower body.
HowTo: 1. Attach your feet to the suspension straps. 2. Lie on your back with your arms at your sides. 3. Pull your heels towards your glutes by bending your knees, keeping your hips elevated. 4. Slowly return to the starting position.

Title: Box Skip
Desc: Box Skip is a dynamic exercise that combines cardio and strength training. It involves jumping onto and off a box, engaging the legs and improving coordination.
HowTo: 1. Stand in front of a sturdy box or platform. 2. Jump onto the box with both feet, landing softly. 3. Step or jump back down and repeat.

Title: Power Stairs
Desc: Power Stairs is a high-intensity exercise that targets the legs and improves cardiovascular fitness. It involves running or stepping up and down stairs quickly.
HowTo: 1. Find a set of stairs. 2. Start at the bottom and run up the stairs as quickly as possible. 3. Walk or jog back down and repeat for several sets.

Title: Seated Hamstring and Calf Stretch
Desc: The Seated Hamstring and Calf Stretch is a flexibility exercise that targets the hamstrings and calves. It helps improve mobility and reduce tightness in the lower body.
HowTo: 1. Sit on the floor with your legs extended in front of you. 2. Reach forward towards your toes, keeping your back straight. 3. Hold the stretch for 20-30 seconds.

Title: Hamstring slide
Desc: The hamstring slide is a bodyweight exercise targeting the hamstrings. Lying supine on a smooth surface, bend your knees to pull both heels toward you. The sliding action requires a pad, cloth, or furniture sliders under the heels. These are considered more difficult than exercise ball hamstring curls and are a great primer movement before heavy squats or deadlifts, or as an accessory movement later in a lower-body workout.
HowTo: 1. Lie supine on a smooth surface with your feet on a pad or sliders. 2. Bend your knees and pull your heels towards you, sliding them along the surface. 3. Extend your legs back out and repeat.

Title: Seated Band Hamstring Curl
Desc: The seated band hamstring curl is an effective exercise for targeting the hamstrings using resistance bands. It helps in building strength and muscle endurance in the posterior chain.
HowTo: 1. Sit on a bench with your back straight. 2. Anchor the band around your ankles. 3. Curl your legs back towards your glutes against the resistance of the band. 4. Slowly return to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Lying cable leg curl
Desc: The lying cable leg curl is a classic machine exercise for building greater muscle size and strength in the hamstrings. It's easy to learn, easy to master, and poses little in the way of injury risk. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps, at least 8-12 reps per set, as part of lower-body training.
HowTo: 1. Lie face down on the leg curl machine with your knees just off the edge. 2. Adjust the pad to rest against your ankles. 3. Curl your legs up towards your glutes, squeezing the hamstrings. 4. Lower back down slowly and repeat.

Title: Standing cable leg curl
Desc: The standing cable leg curl is an isolation exercise for the hamstrings. It is often used as a variation of leg curl machines and for working each side independently. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps, at least 8-12 reps per set, as part of lower-body training.
HowTo: 1. Stand facing the cable machine with an ankle strap attached to the low pulley. 2. Hook the strap around your ankle. 3. Curl your leg up towards your glutes while keeping your upper body stable. 4. Lower back down and repeat on both legs.

Title: Lying Leg Curls
Desc: The lying leg curl is a popular machine-based exercise for the legs, particularly the hamstrings. It is similar to the seated leg curl, but the open hip angle in the lying leg curl may incorporate more glute and calf activation. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of a leg pre-exhaust or as a muscle-building movement for lower-body training.
HowTo: 1. Lie face down on the leg curl machine with your knees just off the edge. 2. Adjust the pad to rest against your ankles. 3. Curl your legs up towards your glutes, squeezing the hamstrings and glutes. 4. Slowly lower back down and repeat.

Title: Glute Ham Raise
Desc: The glute ham raise is an exercise targeting the glutes and hamstrings on a GHD.
HowTo: 1. Position yourself on the glute ham raise machine with your feet secured. 2. Lower your body towards the ground while keeping your back straight. 3. Engage your hamstrings and glutes to raise your body back to the starting position. 4. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Reverse Hyperextension
Desc: The Reverse Hyperextension is an exercise that primarily targets the hamstrings and glutes while also engaging the lower back. It is often performed on a specialized machine that allows for a controlled movement.
HowTo: 1. Lie face down on the reverse hyperextension machine with your hips at the edge. 2. Grab the handles for support. 3. With your legs straight, lift them upward until they are parallel to the ground. 4. Lower your legs back down slowly to the starting position.

Title: Seated Leg Curl
Desc: The leg curl is a popular machine-based exercise for the legs, particularly the hamstrings. It comes in seated and lying varieties, but the seated leg curl machine is more common in commercial gyms. Leg curl variations are usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of a leg pre-exhaust or as a muscle-building movement for lower-body training.
HowTo: 1. Sit on the leg curl machine and adjust the pad to rest against your lower legs. 2. Grasp the handles and keep your back against the seat. 3. Curl your legs downwards by bending your knees, bringing your heels towards your glutes. 4. Slowly return to the starting position.

Title: Standing Leg Curl
Desc: The Standing Leg Curl is an effective exercise for targeting the hamstrings and glutes while also engaging the core for stability. It is often performed using a cable machine or a leg curl machine.
HowTo: 1. Stand facing the leg curl machine or cable machine with the ankle strap attached. 2. Lift one leg behind you by bending your knee, keeping your upper body straight. 3. Squeeze your hamstrings at the top of the movement. 4. Lower your leg back to the starting position.

Title: Smith machine stiff-legged deadlift
Desc: The Smith machine stiff-legged deadlift is a machine-based exercise targeting the muscles of the hamstrings, glutes, and upper back. The Smith machine mimics a barbell but provides more stability. This movement can be programmed like a traditional stiff-legged or Romanian deadlift, in low reps for strength or higher reps for muscle and strength endurance. It is often performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of a full-body or lower-body workout.
HowTo: 1. Set the Smith machine bar at thigh height and load it with weights. 2. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and grip the bar with both hands. 3. Keeping your legs straight, hinge at the hips to lower the bar down while maintaining a flat back. 4. Return to the starting position by driving through your hips.

Title: Lying Leg Curl - Gethin Variation
Desc: The lying leg curl is a popular machine-based exercise for the legs, particularly the hamstrings. It is similar to the seated leg curl, but the open hip angle in the lying leg curl may incorporate more glute and calf activation. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of a leg pre-exhaust or as a muscle-building movement for lower-body training.
HowTo: 1. Lie face down on the leg curl machine with your ankles under the padded lever. 2. Grasp the handles for support and keep your hips pressed against the bench. 3. Curl your legs upwards by bending your knees, bringing your heels towards your glutes. 4. Lower your legs back down slowly to the starting position.

Title: Paul Carter Leg Extension
Desc: The leg extension is an isolation exercise for the quads.
HowTo: 1. Sit on the leg extension machine with your back against the pad. 2. Adjust the pad so it rests on your lower legs just above your feet. 3. Extend your legs to lift the weight, then slowly lower back to the starting position.

Title: Lying leg curl
Desc: The lying leg curl is a popular machine-based exercise for the legs, particularly the hamstrings. It is similar to the seated leg curl, but the open hip angle in the lying leg curl may incorporate more glute and calf activation. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of a leg pre-exhaust or as a muscle-building movement for lower-body training.
HowTo: 1. Lie face down on the leg curl machine and position your legs under the pad. 2. Curl your legs up towards your glutes, then lower them back down slowly.

Title: Seated Hamstring Curl - Gethin Variation
Desc: The leg curl is a popular machine-based exercise for the legs, particularly the hamstrings. It comes in seated and lying varieties, but the seated leg curl machine is more common in commercial gyms. Leg curl variations are usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of a leg pre-exhaust or as a muscle-building movement for lower-body training.
HowTo: 1. Sit on the seated leg curl machine with your back against the pad. 2. Position your legs under the pad and curl your legs down towards the floor, then return to the starting position.

Title: Single-leg lying leg curl
Desc: The single-leg lying leg curl is a popular machine-based exercise for the legs, particularly the hamstrings. It is similar to the seated leg curl, but the open hip angle in the lying leg curl may incorporate more glute and calf activation. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of a leg pre-exhaust or as a muscle-building movement for lower-body training. Performing it one leg a time allows you to focus on the mind-muscle connection of each leg and address muscle imbalances.
HowTo: 1. Lie face down on the leg curl machine and position one leg under the pad. 2. Curl your leg up towards your glutes, then lower it back down slowly. 3. Repeat with the other leg.

Title: Leg curl
Desc: The leg curl is a popular machine-based exercise for the legs, particularly the hamstrings. It comes in seated and lying varieties, but the seated leg curl machine is more common in commercial gyms. Leg curl variations are usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of a leg pre-exhaust or as a muscle-building movement for lower-body training.
HowTo: 1. Sit on the leg curl machine with your back against the pad. 2. Position your legs under the pad and curl your legs down towards the floor, then return to the starting position.

Title: Leg Extension - Gethin Variation
Desc: The leg extension is an isolation exercise for the quads.
HowTo: 1. Sit on the leg extension machine with your back against the pad. 2. Adjust the pad so it rests on your lower legs just above your feet. 3. Extend your legs to lift the weight, then lower back down.

Title: Single-leg leg extension-
Desc: The single-leg leg extension is a popular machine-based exercise for the legs, particularly the quadriceps. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of a leg pre-exhaust or as a muscle-building movement for lower-body training. Performing it one leg a time allows you to focus on the mind-muscle connection of each leg and address muscle imbalances.
HowTo: 1. Sit on the leg extension machine and adjust the pad to your lower leg. 2. Extend one leg at a time, focusing on the contraction of the quadriceps. 3. Alternate legs for the desired number of reps.

Title: Lying Hamstring Curls - Gethin Variation
Desc: The lying leg curl is a popular machine-based exercise for the legs, particularly the hamstrings. It is similar to the seated leg curl, but the open hip angle in the lying leg curl may incorporate more glute and calf activation. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of a leg pre-exhaust or as a muscle-building movement for lower-body training.
HowTo: 1. Lie face down on the leg curl machine and adjust the pad to rest on your lower legs. 2. Curl your legs up towards your glutes, squeezing your hamstrings at the top. 3. Lower back down slowly to the starting position.

Title: AM Seated Hamstring Curl
Desc: The leg curl is a popular machine-based exercise for the legs, particularly the hamstrings. It comes in seated and lying varieties, but the seated leg curl machine is more common in commercial gyms. Leg curl variations are usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of a leg pre-exhaust or as a muscle-building movement for lower-body training.
HowTo: 1. Sit on the seated leg curl machine and adjust the pad to rest on your thighs. 2. Curl your legs down towards the floor, engaging your hamstrings. 3. Slowly return to the starting position.

Title: UP Hamstring Curl
Desc: The lying leg curl is a popular machine-based exercise for the legs, particularly the hamstrings. It is similar to the seated leg curl, but the open hip angle in the lying leg curl may incorporate more glute and calf activation. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of a leg pre-exhaust or as a muscle-building movement for lower-body training.
HowTo: 1. Lie face down on the leg curl machine and adjust the pad to rest on your lower legs. 2. Curl your legs up towards your glutes, squeezing your hamstrings at the top. 3. Lower back down slowly to the starting position.

Title: 30 Legs Leg Extension
Desc: The leg extension is a strength exercise that isolates the quadriceps muscles. It is performed on a machine that allows you to extend your legs against resistance.
HowTo: 1. Sit on the leg extension machine with your back against the pad. 2. Adjust the pad so it rests on your lower legs just above your ankles. 3. Select your desired weight. 4. Extend your legs fully while keeping your back pressed against the seat. 5. Slowly lower back to the starting position.

Title: 30 Legs Seated Leg Curl
Desc: The seated leg curl targets the hamstrings and is performed on a machine. It helps strengthen the back of the legs.
HowTo: 1. Sit on the leg curl machine with your back against the pad. 2. Adjust the pad so it rests on your lower legs just above your ankles. 3. Select your desired weight. 4. Curl your legs down towards the floor, squeezing your hamstrings. 5. Slowly return to the starting position.

Title: Natural Glute Ham Raise
Desc: The glute ham raise is an exercise targeting the glutes and hamstrings on a GHD.
HowTo: 1. Position yourself on the glute ham raise machine with your feet secured. 2. Start in a straight line from head to toe. 3. Lower your body by bending at the hips while keeping your back straight. 4. Once you reach a comfortable depth, raise your body back to the starting position using your hamstrings and glutes.

Title: Standing leg swing
Desc: The standing leg swing is a dynamic stretching exercise that involves moving one leg up in front of you, as if to punt an imaginary football. This is a classic move for warming up the body and stretching the hamstrings.
HowTo: 1. Stand upright and hold onto a wall or support for balance. 2. Swing one leg forward and backward in a controlled manner. 3. Keep your upper body still and focus on the leg movement. 4. Perform for a set number of repetitions before switching legs.

Title: Linear Acceleration Wall Drill
Desc: The linear acceleration wall drill is a cardio exercise that focuses on improving speed and acceleration. It involves sprinting against a wall to develop explosive power.
HowTo: 1. Stand facing a wall with your feet shoulder-width apart. 2. Lean into the wall at a 45-degree angle. 3. Drive your knees up towards your chest while pushing off the ground. 4. Focus on quick, explosive movements for a set time or distance.

Title: Knee Tuck Jump
Desc: The tuck jump is a vertical jump, an explosive lower-body exercise that is a common way to measure explosive hip and lower-body strength in athletes. The more explosive you are, the higher you'll be able to jump.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. 2. Bend your knees and lower your body into a quarter squat. 3. Jump explosively into the air, tucking your knees towards your chest. 4. Land softly and immediately go into the next jump.

Title: Leg-Up Hamstring Stretch
Desc: The leg-up hamstring stretch is designed to improve flexibility in the hamstrings and glutes. It is often used to alleviate tightness and enhance mobility in the lower body.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back with one leg extended straight up towards the ceiling. 2. Keep the other leg flat on the ground. 3. Gently pull the extended leg towards you while keeping it straight. 4. Hold the stretch for 15-30 seconds and switch legs.

Title: Inchworm
Desc: The inchworm is a popular bodyweight exercise that involves walking the hands on the floor from a bent-over toe-touch position into a straight-arm plank. It is usually performed as part of a dynamic warm-up to help raise core body temperature and limber up the body from head to toe.
HowTo: 1. Start in a standing position and bend at the hips to touch your toes. 2. Walk your hands forward to a plank position while keeping your legs straight. 3. Hold the plank for a moment, then walk your feet towards your hands. 4. Stand up and repeat.

Title: Moving Claw Series
Desc: The Moving Claw Series is a dynamic mobility exercise that targets the hips and legs, improving flexibility and range of motion. It is often used in warm-ups to prepare the body for more intense activity.
HowTo: 1. Start in a low lunge position with one foot forward and the other knee on the ground. 2. Move your hands forward and shift your weight into the front leg. 3. Alternate legs, moving smoothly from one lunge to the next. 4. Continue for a set number of repetitions or time.

Title: Lying groin stretch with band
Desc: The lying groin stretch with band is a simple way to stretch a chronically tight muscle group of the lower body. It is common in stretching and yoga classes but can also be performed individually as part of a warm-up, paired with movements in a workout, or as part of a cool-down or recovery strategy.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back with a resistance band looped around one foot. 2. Keep the other leg flat on the ground. 3. Gently pull the band to bring your leg out to the side, feeling a stretch in your groin. 4. Hold for 15-30 seconds and switch legs.

Title: 90/90 Hamstring
Desc: The 90/90 Hamstring stretch is designed to improve flexibility in the hamstrings and hip area. It is a great exercise for those looking to enhance their mobility and reduce tightness.
HowTo: 1. Sit on the floor with one leg bent at 90 degrees in front of you and the other leg bent at 90 degrees behind you. 2. Lean forward gently over the front leg while keeping your back straight. 3. Hold the stretch for 20-30 seconds and switch legs.

Title: World's greatest stretch
Desc: The world's greatest stretch is a popular movement that earned its name because it targets multiple parts of the body, including the hips, shoulders, and thoracic spine, in a single sequence. This makes it a great dynamic warm-up, post-workout stretch, or mobility work you can do anytime.
HowTo: 1. Start in a standing position and step forward into a lunge with your right leg. 2. Place your left hand on the ground inside your right foot and twist your torso to the right, reaching your right arm up. 3. Hold for a moment, then return to standing and repeat on the other side.

Title: The Straddle
Desc: The Straddle stretch is effective for improving flexibility in the inner thighs and hamstrings. It is commonly used in various fitness and dance routines.
HowTo: 1. Sit on the floor and spread your legs wide apart. 2. Keep your back straight and lean forward, reaching towards your toes or the floor. 3. Hold the position for 20-30 seconds.

Title: Prone Manual Hamstring
Desc: The Prone Manual Hamstring stretch is aimed at increasing flexibility in the hamstrings while lying down. It is especially beneficial for athletes and those with tight hamstrings.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your stomach with your legs extended. 2. Have a partner gently lift one leg while keeping the knee straight, until you feel a stretch in the hamstring. 3. Hold for 20-30 seconds and switch legs.

Title: Knee To Chest
Desc: The Knee To Chest stretch is a simple exercise that helps to stretch the lower back and hip area. It is often used to relieve tension and improve flexibility.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back with your legs extended. 2. Bring one knee towards your chest, holding it with both hands. 3. Hold the stretch for 20-30 seconds, then switch legs.

Title: Hurdle Hops
Desc: Hurdle hops are a plyometric exercise that enhances explosive power and agility. They involve jumping over hurdles or obstacles, which helps improve coordination and leg strength.
HowTo: 1. Set up hurdles or markers at a suitable height. 2. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart. 3. Bend your knees and jump over the first hurdle, landing softly. 4. Repeat for each hurdle, focusing on height and distance.

Title: Hip Stretch With Twist
Desc: The hip stretch with twist is designed to improve flexibility in the hips and lower back. It helps to release tension and increase range of motion.
HowTo: 1. Start in a seated position with legs extended. 2. Bend one knee and place the foot outside the opposite thigh. 3. Twist your torso towards the bent knee, using your opposite arm to deepen the stretch. 4. Hold for a few breaths and switch sides.

Title: Linear 3-Part Start Technique
Desc: The linear 3-part start technique is a foundational exercise for developing sprinting mechanics and overall body strength. It focuses on the initial acceleration phase of sprinting.
HowTo: 1. Start in a staggered stance with one foot forward. 2. Lean forward slightly, keeping your body straight. 3. Push off the front foot explosively while driving the back knee up. 4. Repeat for several repetitions, focusing on form.

Title: Alternating Leg Swing
Desc: Alternating leg swings are a dynamic stretching exercise that improves hip mobility and flexibility. They prepare the legs for activity by increasing blood flow and range of motion.
HowTo: 1. Stand next to a wall or support for balance. 2. Swing one leg forward and backward in a controlled manner. 3. Keep your upper body stable while swinging your leg. 4. Alternate legs and repeat for several swings.

Title: Single-leg balance and reach
Desc: The single-leg balance and reach is an exercise that focuses on lower-body strength and stability.
HowTo: 1. Stand on one leg with a slight bend in the knee. 2. Reach forward with the opposite leg while maintaining balance. 3. Return to the starting position and repeat. 4. Switch legs after several repetitions.

Title: High Kick
Desc: The High Kick is a dynamic stretching exercise that helps improve flexibility in the legs. It involves kicking one leg up towards the opposite hand while standing.
HowTo: 1. Stand tall with your feet hip-width apart. 2. Kick your right leg up towards your left hand while keeping your left leg straight. 3. Alternate legs and repeat for a set number of repetitions.

Title: Boss Everline 10-Yard Sprints
Desc: Boss Everline 10-Yard Sprints are high-intensity sprints that improve cardiovascular fitness and leg strength. This exercise is typically performed in short bursts over a distance of 10 yards.
HowTo: 1. Start at one end of a 10-yard distance. 2. Sprint as fast as you can to the other end. 3. Rest briefly and repeat for several sets.

Title: Standing hamstring stretch
Desc: The standing hamstring stretch is an exercise that stretches the hamstrings, the muscles that cover the back of the thighs. It involves looping a band around one foot and then pulling it, which produces an intense stretch in the hamstrings. It can be performed prior to training the lower body or playing sports, or as a restorative stretch anytime.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet hip-width apart. 2. Extend one leg straight in front of you with your heel on the ground. 3. Bend at the hips and reach towards your toes while keeping your back straight. 4. Hold the stretch for 15-30 seconds and switch legs.

Title: Reverse lunge
Desc: The reverse lunge is a lower-body exercise targeting the quads, glutes, and hamstrings. The reverse lunge places more emphasis on the glutes than other lunge variations.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. 2. Step back with your right foot into a lunge position, lowering your hips until both knees are at about 90 degrees. 3. Push through your left heel to return to the starting position. 4. Alternate legs and repeat.

Title: HM Alternating Cross Lunge
Desc: HM Alternating Cross Lunge is a variation of the lunge that targets the legs and improves balance. It involves lunging diagonally across the body.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. 2. Step your right leg diagonally back and to the left, lowering into a lunge. 3. Push back to the starting position and alternate with the left leg stepping diagonally back to the right. 4. Repeat for several repetitions.

Title: HM Alternating Front Kick
Desc: The HM Alternating Front Kick is a dynamic exercise that engages the lower body while improving cardiovascular fitness. It involves alternating kicks to the front, which also enhances balance and coordination.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet hip-width apart. 2. Lift your right leg and kick it forward, keeping your knee straight. 3. Lower your right leg and repeat with your left leg. 4. Continue alternating legs at a steady pace.

Title: HM World's Greatest Stretch
Desc: The HM World's Greatest Stretch is a comprehensive mobility exercise that targets multiple muscle groups. It helps improve flexibility and range of motion throughout the body.
HowTo: 1. Start in a standing position. 2. Step forward with your right foot into a lunge. 3. Place your left hand on the ground inside your right foot. 4. Rotate your torso to the right and reach your right arm up towards the ceiling. 5. Hold for a moment, then return to the starting position and switch sides.

Title: HM Alternating Sprawl Kick-Through
Desc: The HM Alternating Sprawl Kick-Through is an intense cardio exercise that engages the entire body. It combines elements of a sprawl and a kick-through to build strength and endurance.
HowTo: 1. Start in a standing position. 2. Drop into a squat and place your hands on the ground. 3. Jump your feet back into a plank position. 4. Perform a sprawl by lowering your hips and then kick one leg through to the side. 5. Return to plank and repeat on the other side.

Title: HM Alternating Step-Back
Desc: The HM Alternating Step-Back is a great exercise for building lower body strength and improving cardiovascular fitness. It involves stepping back alternately, which also helps with balance.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet hip-width apart. 2. Step back with your right foot into a lunge position. 3. Push through your left heel to return to standing. 4. Repeat with your left foot stepping back. 5. Continue alternating legs.

Title: HM Alternating Step-Up With Chair
Desc: The HM Alternating Step-Up With Chair is an effective strength exercise targeting the legs. It helps build muscle and improve stability by using a chair for elevation.
HowTo: 1. Stand in front of a sturdy chair with feet hip-width apart. 2. Step up onto the chair with your right foot, pressing through your heel. 3. Bring your left foot up to meet your right on the chair. 4. Step back down with your right foot, then your left. 5. Repeat, alternating the leading foot.

Title: HM Right Knee-Up
Desc: The HM Right Knee-Up is a mobility exercise that focuses on improving flexibility in the hip and leg muscles. It helps in enhancing range of motion and preparing the body for more intense workouts.
HowTo: 1. Stand tall with your feet hip-width apart. 2. Lift your right knee towards your chest while balancing on your left leg. 3. Hold for a moment, then lower your leg back down. 4. Repeat on the other side.

Title: HM Low Lunge With External Twist
Desc: The HM Low Lunge With External Twist is designed to improve flexibility and mobility in the hips and spine. It also engages the core and helps in stabilizing the body.
HowTo: 1. Start in a standing position. 2. Step forward with your right foot into a low lunge position. 3. Place your left hand on the ground and twist your torso to the right, reaching your right arm up. 4. Hold the position, then switch sides.

Title: HM Ninja Crawl
Desc: The HM Ninja Crawl is a dynamic mobility exercise that engages multiple muscle groups while improving coordination and flexibility. It mimics a crawling motion, which is beneficial for overall body movement.
HowTo: 1. Start in a tabletop position on your hands and knees. 2. Lift your knees slightly off the ground and move forward by alternating your hands and feet. 3. Keep your core engaged and move smoothly. 4. Continue crawling forward for a set distance.

Title: HM Pigeon Stretch
Desc: The HM Pigeon Stretch is a popular mobility exercise that targets the hips and glutes. It helps in relieving tension and improving flexibility in the lower body.
HowTo: 1. Start in a tabletop position. 2. Bring your right knee forward and place it behind your right wrist. 3. Extend your left leg straight back. 4. Lean forward over your right leg to deepen the stretch. 5. Hold, then switch sides.

Title: Single-Leg Deadlift Walk
Desc: The Single-Leg Deadlift Walk is a strength exercise that targets the posterior chain, enhancing balance and stability. It is effective for building strength in the legs and improving core engagement.
HowTo: 1. Stand on your right leg with your left leg slightly behind you. 2. Hinge at the hips and lower your torso while extending your left leg back. 3. Return to standing and take a step forward while maintaining balance. 4. Repeat for a set distance or number of steps.

Title: Total Fitness Hamstring Slide
Desc: The hamstring slide is a bodyweight exercise targeting the hamstrings. Lying supine on a smooth surface, you bend your knees to pull both heels toward you. The sliding action requires a pad, cloth, or furniture sliders under the heel. These are considered more difficult than exercise ball hamstring curls, and are a great primer movement before heavy squats or deadlifts, or as an accessory movement later in a lower-body workout.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back on a smooth surface with your knees bent. 2. Place a pad, cloth, or furniture sliders under your heels. 3. Pull your heels towards you by bending your knees, sliding your feet along the surface.

Title: 30 Legs Walking Lunge
Desc: The 30 Legs Walking Lunge is a dynamic exercise that targets the major muscle groups in the legs and improves lower body strength and stability.
HowTo: 1. Stand upright with your feet together. 2. Step forward with one leg into a lunge position, lowering your hips until both knees are bent at about a 90-degree angle. 3. Push off your front foot to bring your back leg forward into the next lunge.

Title: Glute ham raise-
Desc: The glute ham raise is an exercise targeting the glutes and hamstrings on a GHD, or glute ham developer bench. The unassisted version of the movement requires serious hamstring strength, so it is more common to see versions that use a band or PVC pipe for assistance. It is commonly performed as an accessory movement for heavy barbell lifts. While a single rep may be a struggle at first, with time, strong athletes can build up to doing them for 8-12 reps per set.
HowTo: 1. Position yourself on a GHD machine with your feet secured. 2. Lower your body towards the floor by bending at the hips while keeping your back straight. 3. Use your hamstrings and glutes to pull your body back up to the starting position.

Title: Lying hamstring stretch with band
Desc: The lying hamstring stretch with band is a simple way to stretch a chronically tight muscle group of the lower body. It is common in stretching and yoga classes but can also be performed individually as part of a warm-up, paired with movements in a workout, or as part of a cool-down or recovery strategy.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back with one leg extended on the ground. 2. Use a resistance band to pull the other leg up towards you while keeping it straight. 3. Hold the stretch for a few seconds, then switch legs.

Title: Upper Back-Leg Grab
Desc: The Upper Back-Leg Grab is a stretching exercise that targets the upper back and hamstrings, promoting flexibility and relaxation.
HowTo: 1. Stand upright and reach down to grab your legs while keeping your back straight. 2. Hold the stretch for a few seconds, feeling the stretch in your upper back and hamstrings.

Title: Seated Hamstring
Desc: The Seated Hamstring is a stretching exercise that helps improve flexibility in the hamstrings. It is often performed while seated on the ground, reaching towards the toes.
HowTo: 1. Sit on the ground with your legs extended in front of you. 2. Keeping your back straight, reach towards your toes while bending at the hips. 3. Hold the stretch for 15-30 seconds, feeling the stretch in your hamstrings.

Title: Alternating lunge jump
Desc: The alternating lunge jump is an explosive bodyweight exercise that targets the lower-body muscles, including the quads, glutes, and hamstrings. It can be performed for time or reps in power training, and is also effective in any fat-loss or athleticism-focused workout.
HowTo: 1. Start in a standing position. 2. Step forward into a lunge with one leg, lowering your hips until both knees are bent at about a 90-degree angle. 3. Jump explosively, switching legs in mid-air, and land in a lunge with the opposite leg forward. 4. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Runner's Stretch
Desc: The Runner's Stretch is a flexibility exercise that targets the hamstrings and helps improve range of motion. It is typically performed by stretching one leg while keeping the other bent.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet hip-width apart. 2. Extend one leg straight in front of you while bending the other knee. 3. Reach towards the toes of the extended leg, keeping your back straight. 4. Hold the stretch for 15-30 seconds, then switch legs.

Title: Exercise ball leg curl
Desc: The exercise ball leg curl is an exercise targeting the hamstrings. In particular, it targets the knee flexion function of the hamstrings, as opposed to deadlift variations, which target the other hamstring function, hip flexion. Many lifters opt for this exercise when they don't have access to a lying leg curl machine, but it is worth considering even if you already do machine curls.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back with your heels on top of an exercise ball. 2. Lift your hips off the ground, forming a straight line from your shoulders to your heels. 3. Bend your knees to roll the ball towards you, then extend your legs back out. 4. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Ball Hamstring Hat Trick
Desc: The exercise ball leg curl is an exercise targeting the hamstrings. In particular, it targets the knee flexion function of the hamstrings, as opposed to deadlift variations, which target the other hamstring function, hip flexion. Many lifters opt for this exercise when they dont have access to a lying leg curl machine, but it is worth considering even if you already do machine curls.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back with your heels on an exercise ball. 2. Lift your hips off the ground, keeping your body straight. 3. Pull the ball towards you by bending your knees, then roll it back out. 4. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Band-assisted pull-up
Desc: The band-assisted pull-up is a variation of the pull-up exercise in which the reps are performed with an elastic band looped around the feet or knees. This reduces weight and resistance at the bottom of the rep, while increasing it toward the top. Like other pull-up variations, it builds strength and muscle in the upper back, biceps, and core, and is often used as a way to help people boost their pull-up numbers or perform their first rep.
HowTo: 1. Loop a resistance band around a pull-up bar and place your feet or knees in the band. 2. Hang from the bar with your arms fully extended. 3. Pull yourself up towards the bar, engaging your upper back and biceps. 4. Lower yourself back down with control.

Title: Assisted Chin-Up
Desc: The reverse-grip chin-up is a variation of the pull-up exercise in which the reps are performed with the palms facing toward the body, in an underhand position, with a band looped around the feet or knees. This reduces weight and resistance at the bottom of the rep, while increasing it toward the top. Like other pull-up variations, it builds strength and muscle in the upper back, biceps, and core, but it utilizes the biceps slightly more than overhand band-assisted pull-ups.
HowTo: 1. Loop a resistance band around a pull-up bar and place your feet or knees in the band. 2. Grip the bar with palms facing you, arms fully extended. 3. Pull yourself up towards the bar while keeping your elbows close to your body. 4. Lower yourself back down with control.

Title: UN Band Assisted Pull-up Pronated
Desc: The UN Band Assisted Pull-up Pronated is a variation of the pull-up that uses a pronated (overhand) grip and a band for assistance. It targets the upper back and biceps while reducing the load.
HowTo: 1. Loop a resistance band around a pull-up bar and place your feet or knees in the band. 2. Grip the bar with palms facing away from you, arms fully extended. 3. Pull yourself up towards the bar, focusing on engaging your upper back. 4. Lower yourself back down with control.

Title: UN Band Assisted Pull-up Neutral
Desc: The UN Band Assisted Pull-up Neutral is a variation that uses a neutral grip and a band for assistance. It effectively targets the upper back and biceps.
HowTo: 1. Loop a resistance band around a pull-up bar and place your feet or knees in the band. 2. Grip the bar with palms facing each other, arms fully extended. 3. Pull yourself up towards the bar, engaging your upper back and biceps. 4. Lower yourself back down with control.

Title: UN Band Assisted Pull-up Supinated
Desc: The UN Band Assisted Pull-up Supinated is a variation that uses a supinated (underhand) grip and a band for assistance. It emphasizes the biceps while also working the upper back.
HowTo: 1. Loop a resistance band around a pull-up bar and place your feet or knees in the band. 2. Grip the bar with palms facing you, arms fully extended. 3. Pull yourself up towards the bar, focusing on your biceps and upper back. 4. Lower yourself back down with control.

Title: FYR2 Monster Band Face-Pull Hold
Desc: The FYR2 Monster Band Face-Pull Hold is an exercise that targets the upper back and shoulders. It helps improve shoulder stability and posture.
