HowTo: 1. Anchor a resistance band at upper chest height. 2. Stand facing the band, grasp it with both hands, and pull it towards your face while keeping your elbows high. 3. Hold the position for a few seconds before returning to the start.

Title: Single-arm band low row
Desc: The single-arm band low row is a single-arm row variation utilizing a band for resistance that is anchored low. It targets the muscles of the middle back, like the lats (latissimus dorsi) and rhomboids, but also the core. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps, at least 8-15 reps per set, in the later stages of a back or upper-body workout.
HowTo: 1. Anchor a resistance band low to the ground. 2. Stand facing the band and grasp it with one hand. 3. Pull the band towards your waist while keeping your elbow close to your body. 4. Slowly return to the starting position.

Title: Latissimus dorsi SMR
Desc: Latissimus dorsi self-myofascial release (SMR) is a self-administered soft-tissue treatment for the upper body, usually using a foam roller, lacrosse ball, or other "trigger point" massage tool. By applying pressure strategically to the lat muscles of the mid back, some people find they can cause this often painful and tight area to relax or "release." Latissimus dorsi SMR is often accompanied by SMR on the pectorals or rhomboids, or by stretches that target the lats.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your side with a foam roller positioned under your lat. 2. Roll slowly back and forth to apply pressure to the muscle. 3. Focus on tight areas for 20-30 seconds.

Title: Bent-arm barbell pull-over
Desc: The bent-arm barbell pull-over was a staple exercise of the "Golden Era" of bodybuilding and a favorite of Arnold Schwarzenegger himself. Done properly, the exercise targets the pecs, lats, and serratus anterior muscles. Old-school bodybuilders would perform them with light weights for sets of 20 between sets of heavy 20-rep squats, but pull-overs are more popular today in moderate rep ranges, such as 8-12 reps per set, as part of an upper-body workout.
HowTo: 1. Lie on a bench with a barbell held above your chest. 2. Bend your elbows and lower the barbell behind your head. 3. Pull the barbell back to the starting position while keeping your elbows bent.

Title: Barbell pull-over to press
Desc: The barbell pull-over to press is a complex that combines two popular exercises into one sequence that works much of the upper body, particularly the chest, triceps, and serratus anterior muscles. It is commonly performed with an EZ-bar, but can also be performed with a straight bar or neutral-grip bar. Because the pull-over will determine the amount of weight you can use, this movement is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of the upper-body portion of a workout.
HowTo: 1. Lie on a bench holding a barbell above your chest. 2. Lower the barbell behind your head into a pull-over. 3. Bring the barbell back over your chest and press it upwards. 4. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Single-arm barbell bent-over row
Desc: The single-arm barbell bent-over row is a barbell exercise focused on the muscles of the middle back, such as the lats (latissimus dorsi) and rhomboids. It also targets the biceps and grip. If the loose end of the barbell moves around, it can be secured by placing it in the corner of a room.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a barbell in one hand. 2. Bend at the hips and knees, keeping your back straight, and pull the barbell towards your hip while keeping your elbow close to your body.

Title: Reverse Barbell Row
Desc: The reverse barbell row is an effective exercise that targets the upper back and biceps. It involves pulling the barbell towards your chest while maintaining a bent-over position.
HowTo: 1. Stand bent over with your torso parallel to the ground, holding a barbell with both hands. 2. Pull the barbell towards your chest, squeezing your shoulder blades together, and then lower it back down.

Title: Side kick-through to kettlebell high pull
Desc: The side kick-through to kettlebell high pull is a combination of a popular bodyweight exercise and an explosive kettlebell movement. Between them, the pairing targets the traps, shoulders, core, hips, hamstrings, and glutes. This combination can be performed for time or for reps, often as circuit-style training for conditioning or fat loss.
Muscles: traps, shoulders, core, hips, hamstrings, glutes
HowTo: 1. Start in a plank position, then kick one leg through to the opposite side while reaching with the opposite arm. 2. Return to plank and perform a kettlebell high pull by pulling the kettlebell towards your chin with both hands.

Title: FYR2 Alternating Kettlebell Snatch
Desc: The FYR2 Alternating Kettlebell Snatch is a dynamic exercise that builds power and coordination. It involves lifting a kettlebell from the ground to overhead in a fluid motion.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a kettlebell in one hand. 2. Swing the kettlebell between your legs and then explosively lift it overhead, switching hands at the top.

Title: FYR2 Alternating Kettlebell Swing
Desc: The FYR2 Alternating Kettlebell Swing is a functional exercise that targets the posterior chain. It involves swinging a kettlebell between your legs and then up to shoulder height in an alternating fashion.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet hip-width apart, holding a kettlebell with both hands. 2. Hinge at the hips to swing the kettlebell back between your legs, then thrust your hips forward to swing it up to shoulder height, alternating hands with each swing.

Title: FYR2 American Kettlebell Swing
Desc: The American Kettlebell Swing is a dynamic exercise that targets multiple muscle groups, primarily focusing on the posterior chain. It involves swinging a kettlebell from between the legs to overhead, engaging the core and improving overall strength and power.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a kettlebell with both hands. 2. Hinge at the hips and lower the kettlebell between your legs. 3. Drive through your heels and extend your hips to swing the kettlebell up to shoulder height or overhead. 4. Control the descent and repeat.

Title: FYR2 Double-Kettlebell Standing Clean
Desc: The Double-Kettlebell Standing Clean is an effective full-body exercise that enhances strength and coordination. It involves lifting two kettlebells from the ground to the shoulders in a fluid motion.
HowTo: 1. Stand with a kettlebell in each hand on the ground. 2. Bend your knees and hinge at the hips to grasp the kettlebells. 3. Explode upwards, pulling the kettlebells to your shoulders while rotating your wrists. 4. Lower the kettlebells back to the ground and repeat.

Title: FYR2 Kettlebell Swing High Pull
Desc: The Kettlebell Swing High Pull combines the benefits of a swing with a high pull, targeting the upper body and core. This exercise improves explosive power and coordination.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a kettlebell with both hands. 2. Perform a kettlebell swing, driving through your hips. 3. As the kettlebell reaches chest height, pull it towards your chin, keeping your elbows high. 4. Lower the kettlebell and repeat.

Title: FYR2 Kettlebell Swing-Clean-Press Combo
Desc: The Kettlebell Swing-Clean-Press Combo is a comprehensive exercise that builds strength and endurance across multiple muscle groups. It combines swinging, cleaning, and pressing movements for a full-body workout.
HowTo: 1. Start with a kettlebell between your feet. 2. Perform a kettlebell swing to generate momentum. 3. Clean the kettlebell to your shoulder. 4. Press the kettlebell overhead. 5. Reverse the movements to return to the starting position and repeat.

Title: FYR2 Kettlebell Swing-Clean-Press-Row Combo
Desc: The Kettlebell Swing-Clean-Press-Row Combo is an advanced exercise that challenges strength, coordination, and endurance. It incorporates multiple movements to engage various muscle groups effectively.
HowTo: 1. Begin with a kettlebell on the ground. 2. Perform a kettlebell swing to generate momentum. 3. Clean the kettlebell to your shoulder. 4. Press the kettlebell overhead. 5. Lower the kettlebell and perform a row. 6. Return to the starting position and repeat.

Title: FYR2 Single-Arm Kettlebell Clean
Desc: The FYR2 Single-Arm Kettlebell Clean is a dynamic exercise that focuses on developing strength and coordination in the arms and shoulders. It involves lifting a kettlebell from the ground to a racked position at shoulder height using one arm.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, kettlebell on the ground between your feet. 2. Hinge at the hips and grasp the kettlebell with one hand. 3. Drive through your legs and pull the kettlebell up, rotating your wrist to catch it in the racked position. 4. Lower the kettlebell back to the ground and repeat.

Title: FYR2 Single-Arm Kettlebell Swing
Desc: The FYR2 Single-Arm Kettlebell Swing is an explosive movement that targets the shoulders and arms while also engaging the core. It involves swinging a kettlebell from between the legs to shoulder height using one arm.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, kettlebell on the ground between your feet. 2. Hinge at the hips and grasp the kettlebell with one hand. 3. Swing the kettlebell back between your legs, then thrust your hips forward to swing it up to shoulder height. 4. Allow the kettlebell to swing back down and repeat.

Title: PJR pull-over-
Desc: The PJR pull-over is a triceps-focused version of the pull-over exercise, usually performed on either a flat or slightly inclined bench. The low position of the movement stretches the tricepsparticularly the long head of the musclewhile the top position is a triceps press that contracts all three heads. It can be done in any type of strength or muscle-focused workout, in traditional muscle-building rep ranges, such as 8-12 reps, or for higher reps.
HowTo: 1. Lie on a flat or slightly inclined bench holding a dumbbell with both hands above your chest. 2. Lower the dumbbell back behind your head while keeping your elbows slightly bent. 3. Pull the dumbbell back to the starting position, focusing on contracting your triceps.

Title: Dumbbell seal row
Desc: The dumbbell seal row is a weighted exercise targeting the muscles of the middle back, including the lats (latissimus dorsi) and rhomboids. It can be performed on a special elevated bench, on a bench placed on top of boxes or benches, or on a bench with a slight incline. The higher the bench, the greater the range of motion and stretch at the bottom of the movement. It is usually performed as an assistance movement for back strength and muscle growth, in rep ranges of 8-12 reps per set or higher.
HowTo: 1. Lie face down on an elevated bench with a dumbbell in each hand. 2. Let your arms hang straight down, then pull the dumbbells towards your sides while squeezing your shoulder blades together. 3. Lower the weights back down and repeat.

Title: Incline Dumbbell Row - Gethin Variation
Desc: The incline dumbbell row is an upper body isolation exercise targeting the lower lats and upper back muscles.
HowTo: 1. Set an incline bench at about 30-45 degrees and lie face down with a dumbbell in each hand. 2. Pull the dumbbells towards your lower ribcage, keeping your elbows close to your body. 3. Squeeze your back muscles at the top, then lower the weights back down and repeat.

Title: FYR Bent-Over Dumbbell Row
Desc: The dumbbell bent-over row is a popular exercise to develop and strengthen the muscles of the upper and middle back, like the latissimus (lat), lower trapezius, and rear deltoids. It can work equally well in strength, muscle-building, or circuit-style fat-loss workouts.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, holding a dumbbell in each hand. 2. Bend your knees slightly and hinge at the hips, keeping your back straight. 3. Pull the dumbbells towards your hips, squeezing your shoulder blades together. 4. Lower the weights back to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Straight-Arm Dumbbell Pull-Over - Gethin Variation
Desc: The straight-arm dumbbell pull-overpull-over was a staple exercise of the Golden Era of bodybuilding and a favorite of Arnold Schwarzenegger himself. Done properly, the exercise hits the bottom of the pecs, the lats, the abs, and the triceps.
HowTo: 1. Lie on a bench with a dumbbell held above your chest with both hands. 2. Keeping your arms straight, lower the dumbbell back over your head until you feel a stretch in your lats. 3. Pull the dumbbell back to the starting position, engaging your chest and lats.

Title: Bent-Over Dumbbell Row - Gethin Variation
Desc: The dumbbell bent-over row is a popular exercise to develop and strengthen the muscles of the upper and middle back, like the latissimus (lat), lower trapezius, and rear deltoids. It can work equally well in strength, muscle-building, or circuit-style fat-loss workouts.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, holding a dumbbell in each hand. 2. Bend your knees slightly and hinge at the hips, keeping your back straight. 3. Pull the dumbbells towards your hips, squeezing your shoulder blades together. 4. Lower the weights back to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Bent-over dumbbell rear delt fly
Desc: The bent-over dumbbell rear delt fly is a popular upper-body exercise that targets the muscles on the back of the shoulder joint, specifically the rear head of the deltoid. Since pressing movements build the front and (to a lesser degree) side deltoid heads, this move is often done to promote balanced shoulder development. It is usually performed for high reps, such as 10-15 reps per set or more, as part of a shoulder or upper-body workout.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, holding a dumbbell in each hand. 2. Bend at the hips until your torso is nearly parallel to the ground. 3. With a slight bend in your elbows, raise the dumbbells out to the sides until they are level with your shoulders. 4. Lower the weights back to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Band Resisted Dumbbell Row
Desc: The band resisted dumbbell row is an effective exercise for targeting the back muscles while adding resistance through bands. It helps in building strength and stability in the upper body.
HowTo: 1. Secure a resistance band to a stable anchor point at waist height. 2. Hold a dumbbell in one hand and step back to create tension in the band. 3. Bend slightly at the knees and hinge at the hips. 4. Pull the dumbbell towards your hip while keeping the band taut, then lower it back down.

Title: Holman Right Arm Weighted Half Jack
Desc: The Holman Right Arm Weighted Half Jack is a unilateral exercise that targets the upper body and core. It involves a dynamic movement that engages multiple muscle groups while improving stability.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, holding a weight in your right hand. 2. Jump out to the side while raising your right arm overhead and bringing your left arm down to your side. 3. Return to the starting position and repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Holman Left Arm Weighted Half Jack
Desc: The Holman Left Arm Weighted Half Jack is similar to its right-arm counterpart, focusing on unilateral strength and stability. It helps to enhance coordination and balance while working the upper body.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, holding a weight in your left hand. 2. Jump out to the side while raising your left arm overhead and bringing your right arm down to your side. 3. Return to the starting position and repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Holman Renegade Row
Desc: The Holman Renegade Row is a compound exercise that targets the back and arms while engaging the core. It combines a rowing motion with a plank position for a full-body workout.
HowTo: 1. Start in a plank position with a weight in each hand. 2. Row one weight towards your hip while stabilizing your body with the other arm. 3. Alternate sides for the desired number of repetitions, keeping your core tight.

Title: Holman Renegade Row with Opposite Foot Step-Out
Desc: The Holman Renegade Row with Opposite Foot Step-Out adds a dynamic element to the traditional renegade row by incorporating a step-out movement. This exercise enhances coordination and engages more muscle groups.
HowTo: 1. Begin in a plank position with weights in each hand. 2. Perform a row with one arm while stepping out with the opposite foot to the side. 3. Return to the plank position and alternate sides for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Holman Renegade Row to Weighted Burpee
Desc: The Holman Renegade Row to Weighted Burpee combines strength and cardio elements for a challenging workout. It targets multiple muscle groups and improves overall fitness.
HowTo: 1. Start in a plank position with weights in each hand. 2. Perform a row with one arm, then jump your feet towards your hands. 3. Stand up and perform a burpee, then return to the plank position and repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Holman Weighted Double-Arm Cross Punch
Desc: The Holman Weighted Double-Arm Cross Punch is a dynamic exercise that targets the arms and shoulders. It involves punching movements with weights to build strength and endurance.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a weight in each hand. 2. Extend your arms out in front of you, then cross them over your body while punching forward. 3. Return to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Holman Standing Flat Back Row
Desc: The Holman Standing Flat Back Row is an effective exercise for targeting the upper back muscles. It helps improve posture and upper body strength.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and hinge at the hips to lean forward slightly. 2. Hold a weight in each hand with your arms extended down. 3. Pull the weights towards your torso, squeezing your shoulder blades together, then lower back down.

Title: Total Fitness Dumbbell Isometric Row Hold
Desc: The dumbbell bent-over row is a popular exercise to develop and strengthen the muscles of the upper and middle back, like the latissimus (lat), lower trapezius, and rear deltoids. It can work equally well in strength, muscle-building, or circuit-style fat-loss workouts.
HowTo: 1. Bend at the hips and knees to lower your torso, holding a dumbbell in each hand. 2. Pull the dumbbells towards your body and hold the position for a set time. 3. Keep your back straight and engage your core throughout.

Title: Dumbbell renegade row
Desc: The dumbbell renegade row combines rowing and core training into a single difficult movement. It's popular in time-efficient strength and muscle-building workouts, as well as in circuit-style training.
HowTo: 1. Start in a plank position with a dumbbell in each hand. 2. Row one dumbbell towards your hip while stabilizing your body with the other arm. 3. Alternate sides while maintaining a strong plank position.

Title: MetaBurn Bent-Over Row to Rear-Delt Raise
Desc: The MetaBurn Bent-Over Row to Rear-Delt Raise is a compound exercise that targets the back and shoulders. It helps in building muscle and improving upper body strength.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a dumbbell in each hand. 2. Bend at the hips and knees, lowering your torso while keeping your back straight. 3. Row the dumbbells towards your torso, then extend your arms out to the side for a rear-delt raise. 4. Lower back down and repeat.

Title: FYR2 Bent-Over Reverse Fly
Desc: The FYR2 Bent-Over Reverse Fly is an exercise that targets the upper back and shoulders. It is performed by bending over at the hips and raising weights out to the side.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and hold a dumbbell in each hand. 2. Bend at the hips until your torso is nearly parallel to the floor. 3. With a slight bend in your elbows, raise the weights out to the side until your arms are parallel to the floor. 4. Lower the weights back to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Weighted pull-up
Desc: The weighted pull-up is a more advanced variation of the pull-up exercise in which the lifter adds extra weight to their body. Options for adding weight include a dip belt, weighted vest, chains, a dumbbell placed between the feet or legs, or looping a kettlebell over the foot. Like other pull-up variations, the weighted pull-up builds strength and muscle in the upper back, biceps, and core.
HowTo: 1. Attach a weight to your body using a dip belt or other method. 2. Grip the pull-up bar with your palms facing away from you. 3. Hang with your arms fully extended. 4. Pull your body up until your chin is above the bar, then lower back down.

Title: Rocky Pull-Ups/Pulldowns
Desc: Rocky Pull-Ups/Pulldowns are exercises that target the upper back and biceps. They can be performed using a pull-up bar or a cable machine.
HowTo: 1. For pull-ups, grip the bar with palms facing away. 2. Pull your body up until your chin is above the bar. 3. For pulldowns, sit at a cable machine and grip the bar. 4. Pull the bar down to your chest, then return to the starting position.

Title: Gironda Sternum Chins
Desc: Gironda Sternum Chins are a variation of chin-ups that emphasize the upper back and chest. They require pulling the body up while keeping the chest forward.
HowTo: 1. Grip the pull-up bar with an underhand grip, hands shoulder-width apart. 2. Pull your body up while leading with your chest towards the bar. 3. Lower yourself back down and repeat.

Title: Floor rope climb
Desc: The floor rope climb is an exercise that involves performing partial rope climbs in a prone position with the feet on the floor. It can help prepare someone for full rope climbs, but also trains the muscles of the back, biceps, and grip. It can be done for time or reps.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your stomach with your feet on the floor and a rope in front of you. 2. Grip the rope with both hands. 3. Pull yourself up the rope using your arms while keeping your feet on the ground. 4. Lower yourself back down and repeat.

Title: Around-the-world pull-up
Desc: The around-the-world pull-up is a more advanced version of the classic pull-up. It focuses stress more directly on the individual arms or sides of the back, while also boosting the time under tension at the top of each rep. It can be used as a progression toward a one-arm pull-up, or simply as a way to increase the challenge and variety of your pull-up training.

Title: L-sit chin-up
Desc: The L-sit chin-up is an exercise targeting the back, biceps, core, and overall upper-body strength. It is considered significantly more difficult than standard chin-ups, and as such, is often performed for relatively low reps, such as 5-8 reps per set or less, with a focus on strength and form.

Title: Back Flyes - Gethin Variation
Desc: The incline dumbbell reverse fly is an upper-body exercise targeting the posterior or rear deltoids, as well as the postural muscles of the upper back. Because it targets such small muscles, this exercise is usually performed with light weight for high reps, such as 10-15 reps per set or more.

Title: Incline straight-arm pull-over
Desc: The incline straight-arm pull-over is an upper-body exercise targeting the chest and lats (latissimus dorsi). Performing it on an incline bench emphasizes the stretch on the chest in particular. If this movement causes pain in the front of the shoulders, perform it with a more limited range of motion or try pull-overs using a high cable stack instead. Pull-over variations are usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of chest or back-focused upper-body training.

Title: Machine high row
Desc: The machine high row is a machine-based exercise targeting the back muscles, including the lats, rhomboids, and middle and lower traps. It approximates the motion of a free-weight row, but uses a selectorized weight-stack or plate-loaded machine. Many such machines also allow you to choose between different grips and grip widths. Machine rows are often done for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of the upper-body or back-focused portion of a workout.
HowTo: 1. Sit at the machine and adjust the seat height. 2. Grasp the handles with your chosen grip. 3. Pull the handles towards your torso while keeping your elbows close to your body. 4. Slowly return to the starting position and repeat.

Title: AM T-Bar Row
Desc: The AM T-Bar Row is a compound exercise that targets the back and biceps. It involves rowing a barbell that is anchored at one end.
HowTo: 1. Stand over the T-Bar row machine with your feet shoulder-width apart. 2. Bend at the hips and knees to grasp the handles. 3. Pull the handles towards your chest while keeping your back straight. 4. Lower the weight back to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Assisted Single-Arm Pull-Up
Desc: The Assisted Single-Arm Pull-Up is a variation of the pull-up that provides assistance to help you perform the movement. It primarily targets the back and biceps.
HowTo: 1. Set the assistance level on the machine. 2. Grasp the pull-up bar with one hand. 3. Use the assistance to pull yourself up until your chin is above the bar. 4. Lower yourself back down and repeat.

Title: Assisted Single-Arm Chin-Up
Desc: The Assisted Single-Arm Chin-Up is a variation of the chin-up that provides assistance to help you perform the movement. It targets the biceps and back muscles.
HowTo: 1. Set the assistance level on the machine. 2. Grasp the chin-up bar with one hand, palms facing you. 3. Use the assistance to pull yourself up until your chin is above the bar. 4. Lower yourself back down and repeat.

Title: Holman Renegade Punch-Under
Desc: The Holman Renegade Punch-Under is a dynamic exercise that engages multiple muscle groups. It combines a plank position with a punching motion to enhance core stability and upper body strength.
HowTo: 1. Start in a plank position with a dumbbell in each hand. 2. Shift your weight to one side and punch the opposite arm forward. 3. Return to plank and repeat on the other side. 4. Continue alternating sides.

Title: Holman Renegade Row to Split Jump
Desc: The Holman Renegade Row to Split Jump combines upper body strength with explosive lower body movement. It targets multiple muscle groups for a comprehensive workout.
HowTo: 1. Start in a plank position with a dumbbell in each hand. 2. Perform a row with one dumbbell, bringing it to your side while stabilizing your body. 3. Place the dumbbell back down and jump your feet forward into a split stance. 4. Repeat on the other side.

Title: Holman Dirty Dog to Renegade Row
Desc: The Holman Dirty Dog to Renegade Row is a dynamic exercise that engages the core and upper body. It combines a hip opener with a rowing motion for a full-body workout.
HowTo: 1. Start on all fours with a dumbbell in one hand. 2. Lift the opposite leg while performing a row with the dumbbell. 3. Return to the starting position and switch sides.

Title: Holman Renegade Row to Side Punch to Forward Punch
Desc: The Holman Renegade Row to Side Punch to Forward Punch is an engaging full-body exercise. It incorporates strength and coordination by combining rowing and punching movements.
HowTo: 1. Begin in a plank position with a dumbbell in each hand. 2. Perform a row with one arm, then punch to the side with the same arm. 3. Return to plank and repeat with the other arm, punching forward.

Title: Standing dumbbell knee crunch
Desc: The standing dumbbell knee crunch is a great way to train the abs while standing up. Additionally, the deltoids are worked because the lifter holds a pair of dumbbells overhead throughout.
HowTo: 1. Stand with a dumbbell in each hand held overhead. 2. Raise one knee towards your chest while crunching your torso down. 3. Lower your leg and repeat on the other side.

Title: Close-grip pull-down
Desc: The close-grip pull-down is a variation on the lat pull-down that is performed with an overhand grip and the hands slightly closer than shoulder-width apart. This increases the range of motion beyond wider grips, and may increase the time under tension in each rep. This variation is usually performed for moderate to high reps as part of a back or upper-body workout.
HowTo: 1. Sit at a pull-down machine and grasp the bar with a close grip. 2. Pull the bar down towards your chest while keeping your elbows close to your body. 3. Slowly return to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Shotgun row
Desc: The shotgun row is a single-arm row variation utilizing a cable stack in a staggered stance. It targets the muscles of the middle back, like the lats (latissimus dorsi) and rhomboids, but also the core. It is usually performed for moderate to high-reps, at least 8-15 reps per set, in the later stages of a back or upper-body workout.
HowTo: 1. Stand in a staggered stance with one hand on the cable handle. 2. Pull the handle towards your torso while keeping your elbow close to your body, then slowly return to the starting position.

Title: Close-Grip Front Lat Pulldown
Desc: The close-grip pull-down is a variation on the lat pull-down, acable-based exercise machine thats ubiquitous in gyms around the world. This back builder is easy to learn and highly effective, allowing for variable resistance depending on where you place the pin in the stack.
HowTo: 1. Sit at the lat pulldown machine and grasp the close grip bar. 2. Pull the bar down towards your chest while keeping your elbows close to your body, then slowly release it back up.

Title: Straight-arm rope pull-down
Desc: The straight-arm rope pull-down is a variation of the straight-arm lat pull-down performed using a cable stack machine and a rope grip. It can either be performed in an athletic upright stance, or slightly bent over. It both stretches and contracts the muscles of the lats (latissimus dorsi) as well as providing additional activation to the other upper back muscles and the core. Because the triceps are also isometrically involved in the movement, it is usually performed for higher reps, such as 8-15 reps or more.
HowTo: 1. Stand in front of the cable machine and grasp the rope attachment. 2. With arms straight, pull the rope down towards your thighs while keeping your torso upright, then return to the starting position.

Title: Lat pull-down
Desc: The lat pull-down is a cable-based exercise that's ubiquitous in gyms around the world. This back builder is easy to learn and highly effective at building back size and strength. It's usually trained in moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set. If grip strength is a limitation, you can wear wrist straps.
HowTo: 1. Sit at the lat pulldown machine and grasp the bar with a wide grip. 2. Pull the bar down towards your chest while leaning back slightly, then slowly return it to the starting position.

Title: Straight-Arm Pulldown
Desc: The straight-arm bar pull-down is a variation of the straight-arm lat pull-down performed using a cable stack machine. It can either be performed in an athletic upright stance, or slightly bent-over. It both stretches and contracts the muscles of the lats (latissimus dorsi) as well as providing additional activation to the other upper back muscles and the core. Because the triceps are also isometrically involved in the movement, it is usually performed for higher reps, like 8-15 reps or above.
HowTo: 1. Stand in front of the cable machine and grasp the straight bar attachment. 2. With arms straight, pull the bar down towards your thighs while keeping your torso upright, then return to the starting position.

Title: Single-arm kneeling lat pull-down
Desc: The single-arm kneeling lat pull-down is a variation of the lat pull-down exercise performed one arm at a time, with the knees on the ground, rather than sitting on a bench or machine. It has all of the same benefits of a lat pull-down performed on a bench or machine, in addition to providing further activation to the core and lower body.
HowTo: 1. Kneel on the ground with one knee and the opposite hand on a bench for support. 2. Grasp the cable handle with the other hand. 3. Pull the handle down towards your shoulder while keeping your elbow close to your body. 4. Slowly return to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Elevated Cable Rows
Desc: The cable seated row is a popular exercise to train the muscles of the upper back, including the lats (latissimus dorsi), traps, rhomboids, and rear deltoids, using a cable stack. It also targets the biceps to a lesser degree. The cable row can work well in a variety of rep-ranges, but is most popular in muscle-building workouts or as an accessory movement for strength workouts.
Muscles: latissimus dorsi, traps, rhomboids, rear deltoids, biceps
HowTo: 1. Sit at a cable machine with your feet on the platform and knees slightly bent. 2. Grasp the handle with both hands. 3. Pull the handle towards your torso while keeping your back straight. 4. Slowly return to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Full Range-Of-Motion Lat Pulldown
Desc: The Full Range-Of-Motion Lat Pulldown is designed to engage the upper back muscles through a complete range of motion. It helps in building strength and muscle mass in the back.
HowTo: 1. Sit at a lat pulldown machine and grasp the bar with a wide grip. 2. Pull the bar down towards your chest while leaning back slightly. 3. Squeeze your shoulder blades together at the bottom of the movement. 4. Slowly return the bar to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Kneeling lat pull-down
Desc: The kneeling lat pull-down is a variation of the lat pull-down exercise performed with the knees on the ground rather than sitting on a bench or machine. It has all of the same benefits of a lat pull-down performed on a bench or machine, in addition to providing further activation to the core and lower body.
HowTo: 1. Kneel on the ground with one knee and the opposite hand on a bench for support. 2. Grasp the cable handle with the other hand. 3. Pull the handle down towards your shoulder while keeping your elbow close to your body. 4. Slowly return to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Behind-the-neck pull-down
Desc: The behind-the-neck pull-down is a cable exercise intended to target the muscles of the upper and middle back. If you have the requisite shoulder mobility, it can help you target the upper back muscles, including the trapezius and rhomboids, as well as the lats (latissimus dorsi). It is popular among elite bodybuilders and physique athletes, but some coaches consider it unsafe to the shoulder joint, particularly for people with existing shoulder problems.
HowTo: 1. Sit at a lat pulldown machine and grasp the bar with a wide grip behind your neck. 2. Pull the bar down towards the back of your neck while keeping your back straight. 3. Squeeze your shoulder blades together at the bottom of the movement. 4. Slowly return the bar to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Straight-arm cable pull-over
Desc: The straight-arm cable pull-over is an exercise that focuses on the muscles of the lats (latissimus dorsi) and chest using a cable stack and a flat bench. It is most commonly used for higher reps, such as 10-15 or more, in muscle-building workouts. It is also an effective substitute for dumbbell pull-overs or a pull-over machine, if you don't have access to them or they aggravate your shoulders.
HowTo: 1. Set the cable at a high position and attach a straight bar. 2. Stand facing the cable machine and grasp the bar with both hands. 3. Keeping your arms straight, pull the bar down towards your thighs while engaging your lats. 4. Return to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Cable Straight-Arm Pulldown - Gethin Variation
Desc: The straight-arm bar pull-down is a variation of the straight-arm lat pull-down performed using a cable stack machine. It can either be performed in an athletic upright stance, or slightly bent-over. It both stretches and contracts the muscles of the lats (latissimus dorsi) as well as providing additional activation to the other upper back muscles and the core. Because the triceps are also isometrically involved in the movement, it is usually performed for higher reps, like 8-15 reps or above.
Muscles: latissimus dorsi, upper back, core, triceps
HowTo: 1. Stand upright in front of a cable machine with the cable set at a high position. 2. Grasp the bar with both hands, keeping your arms straight. 3. Pull the bar down towards your thighs while engaging your lats and keeping your core tight. 4. Slowly return to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Rope Lat Pull-down - Gethin Variation
Desc: The close-grip pull-down is a variation on the lat pull-down, acable-based exercise machine thats ubiquitous in gyms around the world. This back builder is easy to learn and highly effective, allowing for variable resistance depending on where you place the pin in the stack.
HowTo: 1. Sit at a lat pull-down machine and adjust the knee pad. 2. Grasp the bar with a close grip, palms facing away. 3. Pull the bar down towards your chest while squeezing your shoulder blades together. 4. Slowly return to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Straight-Arm Pull-Down - Gethin Variation
Desc: The straight-arm bar pull-down is a variation of the straight-arm lat pull-down performed using a cable stack machine. It can either be performed in an athletic upright stance, or slightly bent-over. It both stretches and contracts the muscles of the lats (latissimus dorsi) as well as providing additional activation to the other upper back muscles and the core. Because the triceps are also isometrically involved in the movement, it is usually performed for higher reps, like 8-15 reps or above.
Muscles: latissimus dorsi, upper back, core, triceps
HowTo: 1. Stand in front of a cable machine with the cable set at a high position. 2. Grasp the bar with both hands, keeping your arms straight. 3. Pull the bar down towards your thighs while engaging your lats and keeping your core tight. 4. Slowly return to the starting position and repeat.

Title: High-cable standing row
Desc: The high-cable standing row is an exercise targeting the lats. The high position allows for more engagement of the upper back, as well, specifically the rhomboids and teres major.
HowTo: 1. Stand in front of a cable machine with the cable set at a high position. 2. Grasp the handle with both hands and step back slightly. 3. Pull the handle towards your torso while keeping your elbows close to your body. 4. Squeeze your shoulder blades together at the end of the movement, then return to the starting position.

Title: Lat Pull-down - Gethin Variation
Desc: The lat pull-down is a cable-based exercise machine thats ubiquitous in gyms around the world. This back builder is easy to learn and highly effective, allowing for variable resistance depending on where you place the pin in the stack.
HowTo: 1. Sit at a lat pull-down machine and adjust the knee pad. 2. Grasp the bar with a wide grip. 3. Pull the bar down towards your chest while keeping your back straight. 4. Slowly return to the starting position.

Title: Wide-Grip Lat Pull-Down - Gethin Variation
Desc: The lat pull-down is a cable-based exercise machine thats ubiquitous in gyms around the world. This back builder is easy to learn and highly effective, allowing for variable resistance depending on where you place the pin in the stack.
HowTo: 1. Sit at a lat pull-down machine and adjust the knee pad. 2. Grasp the bar with a wide grip. 3. Pull the bar down towards your chest while keeping your back straight. 4. Slowly return to the starting position.

Title: Behind-The-Neck Pull-Down - Gethin Variation
Desc: The behind-the-neck pull-down is a cable exercise intended to target the muscles of the upper and middle back. If you have the requisite shoulder mobility, it can help you targets the upper back muscles, including the trapezius and rhomboids, as well as the lats (latissimus dorsi). It is popular among elite bodybuilders and physique athletes, but some coaches consider it unsafe to the shoulder joint, in particular to people with existing shoulder problems.
HowTo: 1. Sit at a lat pull-down machine and adjust the knee pad. 2. Grasp the bar with a wide grip and pull it behind your neck. 3. Lower the bar to the upper back level while keeping your back straight. 4. Slowly return to the starting position.

Title: Single-Arm Cable Row - Gethin Variation
Desc: The single-arm cable seated row is a version of the cable row movement that train the muscles of the upper back one side at a time. It targets a wide range of muscles including the lats (latissimus dorsi), traps, rhomboids, and rear deltoids, as well as the biceps. The single-arm row can work well in a variety of rep-ranges, but is most popular in muscle-building workouts or as an accessory movement for strength workouts.
Muscles: latissimus dorsi, trapezius, rhomboids, rear deltoids, biceps
HowTo: 1. Sit at a cable row machine and adjust the seat. 2. Grasp the handle with one hand. 3. Pull the handle towards your torso while keeping your back straight. 4. Slowly return to the starting position.

Title: Scapular Rows
Desc: Scapular rows are a great exercise for strengthening the muscles around the shoulder blades. This exercise helps improve posture and shoulder stability.
HowTo: 1. Stand or sit with a cable machine or resistance band in front of you. 2. Grasp the handle or band with both hands. 3. Pull your shoulder blades together while keeping your arms straight. 4. Slowly return to the starting position.

Title: Standing V-Grip Cable Rows
Desc: Standing V-Grip Cable Rows are a strength exercise targeting the back muscles. This exercise helps to build upper body strength and improve posture.
HowTo: 1. Attach a V-grip handle to a low pulley on a cable machine. 2. Stand facing the machine, grasp the handle with both hands, and step back slightly. 3. Pull the handle towards your torso while keeping your elbows close to your body. 4. Squeeze your shoulder blades together at the end of the movement, then slowly return to the starting position.

Title: AM Close-Grip Pull-Down
Desc: The close-grip pull-down is a variation on the lat pull-down, acable-based exercise machine thats ubiquitous in gyms around the world. This back builder is easy to learn and highly effective, allowing for variable resistance depending on where you place the pin in the stack.
HowTo: 1. Sit at a cable machine with a close-grip bar attached to the high pulley. 2. Grasp the bar with both hands, palms facing you. 3. Pull the bar down towards your chest while leaning back slightly. 4. Slowly return the bar to the starting position, maintaining control throughout the movement.

Title: AM Wide-Grip Pull-Down
Desc: The lat pull-down is a cable-based exercise machine thats ubiquitous in gyms around the world. This back builder is easy to learn and highly effective, allowing for variable resistance depending on where you place the pin in the stack.
HowTo: 1. Sit at a lat pull-down machine and adjust the knee pad to fit snugly against your thighs. 2. Grasp the wide grip bar with an overhand grip. 3. Pull the bar down towards your chest while leaning back slightly. 4. Slowly return the bar to the starting position, controlling the weight.

Title: UP Lat Pull-Down
Desc: The lat pull-down is a cable-based exercise machine thats ubiquitous in gyms around the world. This back builder is easy to learn and highly effective, allowing for variable resistance depending on where you place the pin in the stack.
HowTo: 1. Sit at a lat pull-down machine and adjust the knee pad to fit snugly against your thighs. 2. Grasp the wide grip bar with an overhand grip. 3. Pull the bar down towards your chest while leaning back slightly. 4. Slowly return the bar to the starting position, controlling the weight.

Title: Reverse-grip lat pull-down
Desc: The reverse-grip lat pull-down is variation on the lat pull-down that targets the lower lats more than an overhand grip. Because the hands are relatively close together, it also increases the range of motion beyond wider-grip pull-down variations. It can be performed for low reps, such as 5-6 per set, for back strength, or for higher reps for size.
HowTo: 1. Sit at a lat pull-down machine and adjust the knee pad to fit snugly against your thighs. 2. Grasp the close-grip bar with an underhand grip. 3. Pull the bar down towards your chest while keeping your elbows close to your body. 4. Slowly return the bar to the starting position, maintaining control throughout the movement.

Title: Machine seated row
Desc: The machine seated row is a popular exercise targeting the back muscles, particularly the lats (latissimus dorsi), rhomboids, and middle and lower trapezius. There is a wide variety of seated row machines, but most of them approximate the motion of a free-weight row, but in an upright, forward-facing position. Machine row variations are often performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of an upper-body or back-focused portion of a workout.
HowTo: 1. Sit at the machine with your feet on the platform. 2. Grab the handles with both hands. 3. Pull the handles towards your torso while keeping your back straight. 4. Squeeze your shoulder blades together at the end of the movement. 5. Slowly return to the starting position.

Title: Machine-assisted pull-up
Desc: The machine-assisted pull-up takes a classic back-building exercise and adds assistance to make the movement easier than the bodyweight version. The amount of assistance can easily be changed by moving the pin in the stack. While some people use this variation as a substitute for pull-ups or as an assistance exercise for pull-ups, it is also effective as a way to perform the pull-up motion in traditional muscle-building ranges. This variation is often performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of upper-body or back-focused training.
HowTo: 1. Adjust the assistance weight on the machine. 2. Grab the pull-up handles with an overhand grip. 3. Step onto the platform and let your arms extend fully. 4. Pull yourself up until your chin is above the bar, using the assistance as needed. 5. Lower yourself back down slowly.

Title: Single-arm pull-down
Desc: The single-arm pull-down is a variation on the lat pull-down that is performed one arm at a time, usually with a D-shaped handle and a cable stack. Many lifters find they can feel the lat (latissimus dorsi) muscles working better with single-arm variations.
HowTo: 1. Attach a D-shaped handle to the cable stack. 2. Stand or kneel beside the machine and grab the handle with one hand. 3. Pull the handle down towards your shoulder while keeping your elbow close to your body. 4. Slowly return to the starting position. 5. Repeat for the desired number of reps before switching arms.

Title: Chest-Supported Smith Machine Row - Gethin Variation
Desc: The Chest-Supported Smith Machine Row - Gethin Variation is a rowing exercise that targets the back muscles while providing support to the chest. This helps to isolate the back muscles more effectively.
HowTo: 1. Set the Smith machine bar at an appropriate height. 2. Lie face down on the bench with your chest supported. 3. Grab the bar with an overhand grip. 4. Pull the bar towards your chest while squeezing your shoulder blades together. 5. Lower the bar back down slowly.

Title: Single-arm machine high row
Desc: The single-arm machine high row is a machine-based exercise targeting the back muscles, including the lats, rhomboids, and middle and lower traps. It approximates the motion of a free-weight row, but uses a selectorized weight-stack or plate-loaded machine. Many such machines also allow you to choose between different grips and grip widths. Machine-based rows are often done for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of the upper-body or back-focused portion of a workout.
HowTo: 1. Sit at the machine and adjust the seat height. 2. Grab the handle with one hand. 3. Pull the handle towards your torso while keeping your back straight. 4. Squeeze your shoulder blades together at the end of the movement. 5. Slowly return to the starting position.

Title: Machine Pull-Over - Gethin Variation
Desc: The Machine Pull-Over is designed to target the back muscles, particularly the lats. It helps in developing upper body strength and improving posture.
HowTo: 1. Sit on the machine with your back against the pad. 2. Grasp the handles with both hands. 3. Pull the handles down and back, engaging your lats. 4. Slowly return to the starting position.

Title: Seated Machine Row - Gethin Variation
Desc: The machine seated row is an exercise targeting the back muscles, emphasizing the mid- to upper-back.
HowTo: 1. Sit at the machine with your feet on the platform. 2. Grasp the handles with both hands. 3. Pull the handles towards your torso while keeping your back straight. 4. Slowly return to the starting position.

Title: Wide-Grip Machine Row
Desc: The Wide-Grip Machine Row targets the back muscles, focusing on the lats and upper back. It is beneficial for developing a wider back and improving overall strength.
HowTo: 1. Sit on the machine and adjust the seat height. 2. Grasp the wide grip handles. 3. Pull the handles towards your chest while squeezing your shoulder blades together. 4. Slowly return to the starting position.

Title: King Maker Lat Pull-Down
Desc: The lat pull-down is a cable-based exercise machine thats ubiquitous in gyms around the world. This back builder is easy to learn and highly effective, allowing for variable resistance depending on where you place the pin in the stack.
HowTo: 1. Sit at the lat pull-down machine and adjust the knee pad. 2. Grasp the bar with a wide grip. 3. Pull the bar down towards your chest while keeping your back straight. 4. Slowly return to the starting position.

Title: Robertson Half-Kneeling Landmine Press
Desc: The Robertson Half-Kneeling Landmine Press is an effective shoulder exercise that also engages the core. It helps in building shoulder strength and stability.
HowTo: 1. Kneel beside a landmine setup with one knee on the ground. 2. Hold the end of the barbell with one hand at shoulder height. 3. Press the barbell overhead while keeping your core engaged. 4. Lower the barbell back to shoulder height.

Title: Pullups
Desc: The pull-up is a multi-joint bodyweight exercise that builds strength and muscle in the upper back, biceps, and core. It is often used as a measurement tool in military or tactical fitness tests, and is an excellent gauge of relative strength which is strength in relation to bodyweight.
HowTo: 1. Hang from a pull-up bar with your palms facing away from you and hands shoulder-width apart. 2. Pull your body up until your chin is above the bar, then lower yourself back down.

Title: Pull-up
Desc: The pull-up is a multijoint bodyweight exercise that builds strength and muscle in the upper back, biceps, and core. It is often used as a measurement tool in military or tactical fitness tests, and is an excellent gauge of "relative strength" which is strength in relation to body weight.
HowTo: 1. Hang from a pull-up bar with your palms facing away from you and hands shoulder-width apart. 2. Pull your body up until your chin is above the bar, then lower yourself back down.

Title: Muscle Up
Desc: The muscle-up is a compound exercise that combines a pull-up with a dip, allowing the athlete to transition from hanging to above the bar. It is an advanced movement that requires significant upper body strength and coordination.
HowTo: 1. Start hanging from a bar with an overhand grip. 2. Pull yourself up explosively, leaning your chest towards the bar. 3. As you reach the top, rotate your wrists and push down to transition into a dip position. 4. Push your body above the bar and then lower back down.

Title: Rope climb
Desc: The rope climb is an exercise that is used commonly in CrossFit workouts and as a test of upper-body strength. It was even contested at the Olympics in the early 20th century. It targets a wide range of upper-body musculature, including the hands and forearms, shoulders, biceps, lats (latissimus dorsi), and core.
Muscles: hands, forearms, shoulders, biceps, lats, core
HowTo: 1. Grip the rope with both hands and hang from it. 2. Use your arms and legs to climb the rope by pulling with your arms and pushing with your legs. 3. Continue climbing until you reach the desired height, then lower yourself back down.

Title: Wide-Grip Rear Pull-Up
Desc: The wide-grip rear pull-up is a variation of the standard pull-up that emphasizes the upper back and rear deltoids. It is performed with a wider grip on the pull-up bar.
HowTo: 1. Grip the pull-up bar with a wide grip, palms facing away from you. 2. Pull your body up until your chin is above the bar, focusing on engaging your upper back. 3. Lower yourself back down to the starting position.

Title: Side To Side Chins
Desc: The Side To Side Chins is a variation of the chin-up that targets the upper body. It involves moving from side to side while performing the chin-up to engage different muscles.
HowTo: 1. Grab the pull-up bar with an underhand grip. 2. Pull yourself up while shifting your body to one side. 3. Lower yourself down and repeat on the other side.

Title: Neutral-grip pull-up
Desc: The neutral-grip pull-up is a multijoint bodyweight exercise in which the reps are performed with the palms facing one another. Like other pull-up variations, it builds strength and muscle in the upper back, biceps, and core. It can be used as a more shoulder-friendly alternative to straight-bar pull-ups, or to help perform more reps than you can perform overhand.
HowTo: 1. Grab the pull-up bar with a neutral grip (palms facing each other). 2. Hang with your arms fully extended. 3. Pull yourself up until your chin is above the bar. 4. Lower yourself back down with control.

Title: Kipping Muscle Up
Desc: The Kipping Muscle Up is a dynamic movement that combines a pull-up and a dip. It requires coordination and strength to transition from the pull-up to the dip position.
HowTo: 1. Start with a pull-up, generating momentum with your hips. 2. As you pull up, lean back and transition your chest over the bar. 3. Push down into a dip position once your chest is above the bar. 4. Finish by pressing up to full arm extension.

Title: One Arm Against Wall
Desc: The One Arm Against Wall exercise focuses on shoulder mobility and stability. It involves using a wall for support while engaging the shoulder muscles.
HowTo: 1. Stand next to a wall and place one hand against it at shoulder height. 2. Lean into the wall while keeping your body straight. 3. Hold the position to stretch and stabilize the shoulder.

Title: One Handed Hang
Desc: The single-arm hang is a static exercise that involves hanging from a bar by one hand. It is an advanced hanging exercise that demands above-average shoulder stability and grip strength, and may not be appropriate for some people. However, if someone is strong and stable enough to perform it, the movement can help build those same qualities.
HowTo: 1. Grab a pull-up bar with one hand. 2. Allow your body to hang freely. 3. Engage your shoulder and core to maintain stability. 4. Hold for as long as possible before switching hands.

Title: Standing side bend stretch
Desc: The standing side bend stretch is a stretching exercise targeting the obliques, the muscles that run along the side of the core. It is a common inclusion in dynamic warm-ups for the upper body, but can also be performed to help "limber up" for lifting or athletics anytime.
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. Raise one arm overhead and lean to the opposite side, feeling a stretch along your side.

Title: Burpee to pull-up
Desc: The burpee to pull-up is a variation of the bodyweight burpee in which the jump at the top of each rep leads into a jumping pull-up. It is popular in circuit-style and metcon workouts.
HowTo: Start in a standing position, drop into a squat, kick your feet back into a plank position, perform a push-up, jump your feet back to your hands, and jump up while reaching for the pull-up bar.

Title: Negative pull-up
Desc: The negative pull-up is a multijoint bodyweight exercise that focuses on just one half of the traditional pull-up: the lowering, eccentric, or "negative" portion. Because muscles are stronger eccentrically than they are concentrically, many people can perform negatives even if they can't perform full pull-ups. For this reason, it is a popular training tool to help people earn their first pull-up rep, or as a back-off exercise after doing full pull-ups.
HowTo: Start by hanging from a pull-up bar with your arms fully extended. Pull your body up towards the bar, then slowly lower yourself back down to the starting position.

Title: Chin-Up
Desc: The a chin-up is a variation of the pull-up exercise in which the reps are performed with the palms facing toward the body, in an underhand position, with a grip that is narrower than shoulder-width. Like other pull-up variations, it builds strength and muscle in the upper back, biceps, and core, but it utilizes the biceps slightly more than overhand pull-ups. It can be used as a more shoulder-friendly alternative to straight-bar pull-ups, or to help perform more reps than you can perform overhand.
HowTo: Hang from a bar with your palms facing you and your hands closer than shoulder-width apart. Pull yourself up until your chin is above the bar, then lower yourself back down.

Title: HM Superman Lat Pull
Desc: The HM Superman Lat Pull is an exercise targeting the upper back and lats, focusing on strength and stability.
HowTo: Lie face down on a bench or stability ball, extend your arms in front of you, and pull your elbows down towards your sides while squeezing your shoulder blades together.

Title: AM Pull-Up
Desc: The pull-up is a multi-joint bodyweight exercise that builds strength and muscle in the upper back, biceps, and core. It is often used as a measurement tool in military or tactical fitness tests, and is an excellent gauge of relative strength which is strength in relation to bodyweight.
HowTo: 1. Hang from a pull-up bar with an overhand grip, arms fully extended. 2. Pull your body up until your chin is above the bar, then lower back down.

Title: UP Chin-Up
Desc: The chin-up is a bodyweight exercise that primarily targets the upper body, focusing on the back and biceps.
HowTo: 1. Hang from a pull-up bar with an underhand grip, arms fully extended. 2. Pull your body up until your chin is above the bar, then lower back down.

Title: Holman Alternating Forward and Side Punch
Desc: The Holman Alternating Forward and Side Punch is a dynamic exercise that engages multiple muscle groups, focusing on the arms and shoulders.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart. 2. Alternate punching forward and to the side while maintaining a strong core.

Title: Jump to pull-up
Desc: The jump to pull-up is a bodyweight exercise that targets the muscles of the back, biceps, and, to a lesser degree, legs. It involves jumping up to a pull-up bar between reps. Similar to a push-press, the legs help power through the most difficult portion of the pull-up, allowing you to perform more reps. Jumping pull-ups are often performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as an accessory to other pulling or pull-up training, or as a full-body movement in a circuit or metcon.
HowTo: 1. Jump up to grab a pull-up bar with an overhand grip. 2. Use your legs to assist in pulling your chin above the bar, then lower back down.

Title: Bent-over scapular slide
Desc: The bent-over scapular slide is an upper-body exercise that helps with scapular and shoulder mobility. It is commonly performed for time or reps as part of a dynamic warm-up for the upper body.
HowTo: 1. Bend at the hips with a straight back, holding weights or no weights. 2. Slide your shoulder blades together and apart while maintaining the bent-over position.

Title: Iron cross stretch
Desc: The iron cross stretch is a bodyweight stretch that focuses on hip and thoracic spine mobility.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back with your arms extended out to the sides. 2. Bring one knee towards your chest and then let it fall across your body towards the opposite side, keeping your shoulders flat on the ground.

Title: Total Fitness Standing Lat Stretch
Desc: The Total Fitness Standing Lat Stretch helps to improve flexibility in the lats and shoulders.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. 2. Reach one arm overhead and lean to the opposite side, feeling a stretch along the side of your body.

Title: King Maker Pull-Up
Desc: The pull-up is a multi-joint bodyweight exercise that builds strength and muscle in the upper back, biceps, and core. It is often used as a measurement tool in military or tactical fitness tests, and is an excellent gauge of relative strength which is strength in relation to bodyweight.
HowTo: 1. Hang from a pull-up bar with your palms facing away from you. 2. Pull your body up until your chin is above the bar, then lower back down.

Title: Medicine ball slam
Desc: The medicine ball slam is an explosive exercise for developing power, strength, and speed. Muscles worked include the abdominals, legs, triceps, shoulders, and lats. The slams are usually done in rapid succession to complete one set. It can also be a component of a power or athleticism-focused circuit workout.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a medicine ball above your head. 2. Slam the ball down to the ground as hard as you can, bending at the knees and hips.

Title: Catch and Overhead Throw
Desc: The Catch and Overhead Throw is a dynamic exercise that enhances coordination and power.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and hold a medicine ball at chest level. 2. Throw the ball overhead and catch it as it comes back down, repeating the motion.

Title: FYR2 Bent-Over Medicine Ball Slam
Desc: The FYR2 Bent-Over Medicine Ball Slam is a dynamic exercise that combines strength and power. It engages multiple muscle groups while improving coordination and explosiveness.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a medicine ball. 2. Bend your knees slightly and hinge at the hips to lower your torso while keeping your back straight. 3. Swing the medicine ball overhead and slam it down to the ground as hard as you can. 4. Catch the ball on the rebound and repeat.

Title: Dynamic Back Stretch
Desc: The Dynamic Back Stretch is designed to improve flexibility and mobility in the back. It helps to relieve tension and enhance range of motion.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. 2. Reach both arms overhead and gently arch your back. 3. Lean to one side, holding the stretch for a few seconds, then switch to the other side. 4. Repeat several times.

Title: Chair Lower Back Stretch
Desc: The Chair Lower Back Stretch is a gentle stretch that targets the lower back and glutes. It helps to alleviate tightness and improve flexibility.
HowTo: 1. Sit on the edge of a chair with your feet flat on the floor. 2. Slowly lean forward, reaching your hands towards your feet. 3. Hold the stretch for 15-30 seconds, feeling the stretch in your lower back. 4. Return to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Side-Lying Floor Stretch
Desc: The Side-Lying Floor Stretch is an effective way to improve flexibility in the lower body. It targets multiple muscle groups and promotes relaxation.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your side with your legs stacked. 2. Bend the top leg and grab your ankle, pulling it towards your glutes. 3. Hold the stretch for 15-30 seconds. 4. Switch sides and repeat.

Title: Band good morning-
Desc: The band good morning is an exercise targeting the hamstrings and glutes. It is often performed in powerlifting-style training for high reps, or in the place of barbell good mornings.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, with a resistance band around your neck and under your feet. 2. Hinge at the hips, keeping your back straight, and lower your torso towards the ground. 3. Engage your hamstrings and glutes to return to the starting position. 4. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: FYR2 Monster Banded Good Morning
Desc: The FYR2 Monster Banded Good Morning is a strength exercise that primarily targets the hamstrings and glutes. It involves bending at the hips while maintaining a neutral spine.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart and a band around your shoulders. 2. Hinge at the hips, lowering your torso while keeping your back straight. 3. Return to the starting position by engaging your hamstrings and glutes.

Title: Band deadlift
Desc: The band deadlift is a lower-body exercise that mainly targets the hamstrings while also benefiting the glutes and lats using a proper hip-hinging motion.
HowTo: 1. Stand on the band with feet shoulder-width apart. 2. Bend at the hips and knees to grab the band. 3. Stand up by extending your hips and knees, keeping your back straight.

Title: Lower back SMR
Desc: Lower back self-myofascial release (SMR) is a self-administered soft-tissue treatment, usually using a foam roller, lacrosse ball, or other "trigger point" massage tool. By applying pressure strategically to the quadratus lumborum or spinal erector (erector spinae) muscles of the lower back, some people find they can cause this often painful and tight area to relax or "release." Lower back SMR is often accompanied by SMR on the glutes or piriformis muscles, or by stretches that target the piriformis or hips. However, some people find that SMR on the lower back can aggravate existing pain or injury, so be cautious when performing it.
HowTo: 1. Sit on the floor with a foam roller under your lower back. 2. Slowly roll back and forth, applying pressure to tight areas. 3. Adjust your body position to target different muscles as needed.

Title: Barbell deficit deadlift
Desc: The barbell deficit deadlift is a compound exercise targeting the posterior chain. It is commonly utilized in powerlifting training to build pulling strength off the floor, but is also an effective muscle-building movement for the glutes and hamstrings. It is usually performed with lighter weight, and perhaps for higher reps, than traditional deadlifts. If these make your back sore, decrease the deficit and/or wear a weightlifting belt.
HowTo: 1. Stand on a platform with a barbell on the floor in front of you. 2. Bend at the hips and knees to grip the barbell. 3. Stand up by extending your hips and knees, keeping your back straight.

Title: Deadlift with Bands
Desc: The deadlift with bands is a variation of the traditional deadlift that adds resistance through bands. It primarily targets the hamstrings and glutes while improving strength and stability.
HowTo: 1. Attach bands to a barbell and stand with feet shoulder-width apart. 2. Bend at the hips and knees to grip the barbell. 3. Stand up by extending your hips and knees, allowing the bands to provide resistance.

Title: Deadlift with Chains
Desc: The deadlift with chains adds variable resistance to the traditional deadlift, making it more challenging at the top of the lift. This exercise primarily targets the posterior chain.
Muscles: glutes, hamstrings, upper back, lower back, grip
HowTo: 1. Set up a barbell on the floor with chains hanging from it. 2. Stand with your feet hip-width apart and grip the barbell. 3. Keep your back straight and engage your core. 4. Lift the barbell by extending your hips and knees, pulling the chains off the ground. 5. Lower the barbell back down with control.

Title: Rack Pull with Bands
Desc: The rack pull with bands is a variation of the deadlift that uses bands for added resistance. It helps improve strength in the lockout phase of the deadlift.
Muscles: glutes, hamstrings, lower back, upper back, grip
HowTo: 1. Set up a barbell on a squat rack at knee height with resistance bands attached. 2. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and grip the barbell. 3. Keep your back straight and engage your core. 4. Lift the barbell by extending your hips and knees against the band resistance. 5. Lower the barbell back down with control.

Title: Rack pull
Desc: The rack pull is a variation of the deadlift performed from an elevated height, either using boxes, safety pins, or the safeties in a squat rack. It targets all the same muscles as the deadlift, including the glutes, hamstrings, upper back, lower back, and grip. It can be used to strengthen deadlift lockout, but also as a deadlift alternative for people who can't deadlift from the floor without pain.
Muscles: glutes, hamstrings, upper back, lower back, grip
HowTo: 1. Set the barbell on a squat rack or boxes at knee height. 2. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and grip the barbell. 3. Keep your back straight and engage your core. 4. Lift the barbell by extending your hips and knees. 5. Lower the barbell back down with control.

Title: Seated Good Mornings
Desc: Seated Good Mornings are a variation that targets the posterior chain while seated. This exercise helps improve hip hinge mechanics.
HowTo: 1. Sit on a bench with your feet flat on the floor. 2. Place a barbell across your upper back. 3. Keep your back straight and hinge at the hips to lower your torso. 4. Return to the starting position by engaging your glutes and hamstrings.

Title: Stiff Leg Barbell Good Morning
Desc: The Stiff Leg Barbell Good Morning targets the hamstrings and glutes while improving flexibility. It is performed with straight legs to emphasize the stretch.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and hold a barbell across your upper back. 2. Keep your legs straight and hinge at the hips to lower your torso. 3. Go as low as your flexibility allows while maintaining a straight back. 4. Return to the starting position by engaging your hamstrings and glutes.

Title: Reverse Band Deadlift
Desc: The Reverse Band Deadlift is a variation of the traditional deadlift that uses bands to assist in the lift. It allows for a greater range of motion and can help improve strength at the bottom of the lift.
HowTo: 1. Set up a barbell on the ground with bands attached to the bar and anchored above. 2. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, gripping the bar just outside your knees. 3. Hinge at the hips, lowering your torso while keeping your back straight. 4. Drive through your heels to lift the barbell, extending your hips and knees simultaneously. 5. Return to the starting position with control.

Title: Paul Carter Romanian Deadlift
Desc: The barbell stiff-legged deadlift targets the hamstrings, glutes, lower and upper back, as well as the core. It is a popular accessory movement for the deadlift, but also a muscle-building hamstring movement.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet hip-width apart, holding a barbell in front of your thighs. 2. Keep a slight bend in your knees and hinge at your hips, lowering the barbell while keeping it close to your body. 3. Lower until you feel a stretch in your hamstrings, then reverse the motion by driving your hips forward. 4. Return to the starting position, squeezing your glutes at the top.

Title: TBS Good Morning
Desc: The barbell good morning is an exercise that targets glute, hamstring, and lower back development. It is often trained as an accessory movement to the deadlift, but also has value on its own. It is sometimes performed for reps in traditional strength-focused rep ranges such as 5-8 reps per set, but due to the risk posed to the lower back, is rarely treated as a max-effort single-rep lift.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and a barbell resting on your upper back. 2. Keep your knees slightly bent and hinge at your hips, lowering your torso forward. 3. Maintain a straight back and lower until you feel a stretch in your hamstrings. 4. Reverse the motion by driving your hips forward to return to standing.

Title: TBS Romanian Deadlift
Desc: The barbell stiff-legged deadlift targets the hamstrings, glutes, lower and upper back, as well as the core. It is a popular accessory movement for the deadlift, but also a muscle-building hamstring movement.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet hip-width apart, holding a barbell in front of your thighs. 2. Keep a slight bend in your knees and hinge at your hips, lowering the barbell while keeping it close to your body. 3. Lower until you feel a stretch in your hamstrings, then reverse the motion by driving your hips forward. 4. Return to the starting position, keeping your back straight throughout.

Title: Barbell deadlift-
Desc: The barbell deadlift is a compound exercise used to develop overall strength and size in the posterior chain. It is a competition lift in the sport of powerlifting, but is also considered a classic benchmark of overall strength. When performed with the hands outside the knees, it is often called a "conventional" deadlift. When the feet are wide and the hands are inside the knees, it is a sumo deadlift.
Muscles: Hamstrings, Glutes, Lower Back, Core, Quads
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, barbell over the middle of your feet. 2. Bend at your hips and knees to grip the barbell just outside your knees. 3. Keep your chest up and back straight as you lift the bar by extending your hips and knees. 4. Stand up straight, then lower the bar back to the ground with control.

Title: Deadlift - Gethin Variation
Desc: The barbell deadlift is a compound exercise used to develop overall strength and size in the posterior chain. It is a competition lift in the sport of powerlifting, but is also considered a classic benchmark of overall strength. When performed with the hands outside the knees, it is often called a "conventional" deadlift. When the feet are wide and the hands are inside the knees, it is a sumo deadlift.
Muscles: Hamstrings, Glutes, Lower Back, Upper Back
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet hip-width apart, barbell over the mid-foot. 2. Bend at the hips and knees to grip the barbell. 3. Keep your back straight and chest up as you lift the bar by extending your hips and knees. 4. Lower the bar back to the ground by bending at the hips and knees.

Title: Barbell good morning
Desc: The barbell good morning is an exercise that targets glute, hamstring, and lower back development. It is often trained as an accessory movement to the deadlift, but also has value on its own. It is sometimes performed for reps in traditional strength-focused rep ranges such as 5-8 reps per set, but due to the risk posed to the lower back, is rarely treated as a max-effort single-rep lift.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and a barbell on your upper back. 2. Keep your back straight and hinge at the hips to lower your torso forward. 3. Lower until your torso is parallel to the ground, then return to the starting position by driving through your hips.

Title: UP Conventional Deadlift
Desc: The barbell deadlift is a compound exercise used to develop overall strength and size in the posterior chain. It is a competition lift in the sport of powerlifting, but is also considered a classic benchmark of overall strength. When performed with the hands outside the knees, it is often called a "conventional" deadlift. When the feet are wide and the hands are inside the knees, it is a sumo deadlift.
Muscles: Hamstrings, Glutes, Lower Back, Upper Back
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet hip-width apart, barbell over the mid-foot. 2. Bend at the hips and knees to grip the barbell. 3. Keep your back straight and chest up as you lift the bar by extending your hips and knees. 4. Lower the bar back to the ground by bending at the hips and knees.

Title: 30 Day Back Barbell Rack Pull
Desc: The 30 Day Back Barbell Rack Pull is designed to strengthen the back and posterior chain. It focuses on improving deadlift strength and overall back development.
HowTo: 1. Set a barbell on a rack at knee height. 2. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and grip the barbell. 3. Keep your back straight and lift the bar by extending your hips and knees. 4. Lower the bar back to the rack position.

Title: FYR Sumo Deadlift High Pull
Desc: The kettlebell sumo deadlift high pull is a dynamic kettlebell exercise that focuses on the muscles of the posterior chain, including the hamstrings, glutes, traps, rear delts, and upper back. It can be done in lower reps for power or strength, or higher reps for conditioning and fat loss. It can also be a component of a circuit-style kettlebell workout, either for time or reps.
Muscles: Hamstrings, Glutes, Traps, Rear Delts, Upper Back
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet wider than shoulder-width, kettlebell on the ground between your feet. 2. Bend at the hips and knees to grab the kettlebell. 3. Lift the kettlebell by extending your hips and pulling it up to your chin. 4. Lower the kettlebell back to the ground.

Title: Kettlebell deadlift
Desc: The kettlebell deadlift is a foundational movement in kettlebell training. It's often taught as a buildup or regression to the kettlebell swing, as well as to instruct the "hip hinge" motion in a more approachable manner than with a barbell.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, kettlebell between your feet. 2. Hinge at your hips, bending your knees slightly, and grip the kettlebell. 3. Keep your back straight and chest up as you lift the kettlebell by extending your hips and knees. 4. Lower the kettlebell back to the ground by hinging at the hips.

Title: HM Kettlebell Swing
Desc: The HM Kettlebell Swing is a dynamic exercise that targets the posterior chain and improves cardiovascular fitness. It is a powerful movement that builds strength and endurance.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, holding a kettlebell with both hands. 2. Hinge at your hips and swing the kettlebell between your legs. 3. Drive through your hips to swing the kettlebell up to shoulder height. 4. Allow the kettlebell to swing back down and repeat.

Title: KV Romanian Deadlift with Kettlebell
Desc: The KV Romanian Deadlift with Kettlebell focuses on the hamstrings and glutes while promoting proper hip hinge mechanics. It is an excellent exercise for building strength in the posterior chain.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet hip-width apart, holding a kettlebell in one hand. 2. Hinge at your hips, lowering the kettlebell towards the ground while keeping your back straight. 3. Lower until you feel a stretch in your hamstrings, then return to standing by driving through your hips.

Title: FYR2 Kettlebell Good Morning
Desc: The FYR2 Kettlebell Good Morning is a great exercise for strengthening the lower back and hamstrings. It emphasizes the hip hinge and helps improve posture.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, holding a kettlebell at chest level or resting on your shoulders. 2. Hinge at your hips, lowering your torso while keeping your back straight. 3. Lower until your torso is parallel to the ground, then return to standing.

Title: FYR2 Kettlebell Romanian Deadlift
Desc: The FYR2 Kettlebell Romanian Deadlift is an effective exercise for targeting the hamstrings and glutes. It helps develop strength and stability in the posterior chain.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet hip-width apart, holding a kettlebell in both hands. 2. Hinge at your hips, lowering the kettlebell towards the ground while keeping your back straight. 3. Lower until you feel a stretch in your hamstrings, then return to standing by driving through your hips.

Title: FYR2 Kettlebell Staggered-Stance Deadlift
