Desc: The FYR2 Kettlebell Staggered-Stance Deadlift is a variation of the deadlift that emphasizes the hamstrings and glutes. It is performed with a staggered stance to enhance stability and target the posterior chain.
HowTo: 1. Stand with one foot slightly in front of the other. 2. Hold a kettlebell in the hand opposite the front foot. 3. Hinge at the hips while keeping your back straight and lower the kettlebell towards the floor. 4. Engage your hamstrings and glutes to return to the starting position.

Title: Dumbbell Fix Dumbbell Deadlift
Desc: The Dumbbell Fix Dumbbell Deadlift is a fundamental strength exercise that targets the posterior chain. It focuses on building strength in the hamstrings and glutes while also engaging the lower back.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet hip-width apart, holding a dumbbell in each hand. 2. Hinge at the hips and lower the dumbbells towards the ground while keeping your back straight. 3. Engage your glutes and hamstrings to lift back to the starting position.

Title: Dumbbell skier
Desc: As the name suggests, the dumbbell skier takes the motion of skiing and replaces the poles with dumbbells. The hip and torso motion are similar to a kettlebell swing, as are the muscles it targets, including the hamstrings, glutes, upper back, and grip. However, unlike the traditional kettlebell swing, the arms are outside of the knees. This movement can be performed for time or for reps, but is usually performed for relatively high reps, such as 8-12 sets per rep or more, as part of a fat-loss or athleticism-focused circuit or workout.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, holding a dumbbell in each hand. 2. Bend at the hips and knees, lowering your torso while keeping your arms straight outside your knees. 3. Drive through your heels to return to standing, engaging your glutes and hamstrings.

Title: TBS Dumbbell Romanian Deadlift
Desc: The dumbbell stiff-legged deadlift targets the hamstrings, glutes, low and upper back, as well as the core. The purpose of the stiff-legged, as opposed to Romanian deadlift with slightly bent knees, is to engage the hamstrings and low back to an even greater degree.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet hip-width apart, holding a dumbbell in each hand. 2. Keep your knees slightly bent and hinge at the hips to lower the dumbbells towards the floor. 3. Maintain a straight back and engage your hamstrings and glutes to lift back to standing.

Title: Stiff-Legged Dumbbell Deadlift - Gethin Variation
Desc: The dumbbell stiff-legged deadlift targets the hamstrings, glutes, low and upper back, as well as the core. The purpose of the stiff-legged, as opposed to Romanian deadlift with slightly bent knees, is to engage the hamstrings and low back to an even greater degree.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet hip-width apart, holding a dumbbell in each hand. 2. With a slight bend in the knees, hinge at the hips to lower the dumbbells while keeping your back straight. 3. Engage your hamstrings and glutes to return to the starting position.

Title: UNS Dumbbell Romanian Deadlift
Desc: The Dumbbell Romanian Deadlift primarily targets the hamstrings and glutes. It is an effective exercise for building strength in the posterior chain.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet hip-width apart, holding a dumbbell in each hand. 2. Keep your back straight and hinge at the hips to lower the dumbbells along your legs. 3. Lower until you feel a stretch in your hamstrings, then return to standing by driving your hips forward.

Title: Holman Slow Deadlift
Desc: The Holman Slow Deadlift focuses on building strength and control in the deadlift movement. It emphasizes slow, controlled lifting to enhance muscle engagement.
Muscles: Hamstrings, Glutes, Lower Back, Upper Back
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, barbell over mid-foot. 2. Bend at the hips and knees to grip the barbell. 3. Keep your back flat and engage your core as you lift the bar slowly, extending your hips and knees simultaneously. 4. Lower the bar back to the ground with control.

Title: Holman Deadlift to Overhead Press
Desc: The Holman Deadlift to Overhead Press combines a deadlift with an overhead press for a full-body workout. This exercise builds strength and coordination.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, gripping the barbell. 2. Perform a deadlift to lift the barbell to hip level. 3. Once at hip level, press the barbell overhead by extending your arms. 4. Lower the barbell back to the ground and repeat.

Title: Holman Staggered-Stance Deadlift
Desc: The Holman Staggered-Stance Deadlift targets the legs and improves balance. It focuses on one leg at a time for enhanced muscle engagement.
HowTo: 1. Stand in a staggered stance with one foot slightly behind the other. 2. Grip the barbell with both hands, keeping your back flat. 3. Lower the barbell by hinging at the hips, then return to standing by driving through the front heel.

Title: Holman Deadlift to Front Raise
Desc: The Holman Deadlift to Front Raise combines a deadlift with a front raise to target both the lower body and shoulders. This exercise enhances strength and stability.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, gripping the barbell. 2. Perform a deadlift to lift the barbell to hip level. 3. From hip level, raise the barbell in front of you to shoulder height. 4. Lower the barbell back to the ground and repeat.

Title: Holman Deadlift to Chest Press
Desc: The Holman Deadlift to Chest Press combines a deadlift with a chest press, targeting multiple muscle groups. It is effective for building strength and coordination.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, holding weights in both hands. 2. Perform a deadlift by bending at the hips and knees, lowering the weights towards the ground. 3. Once you reach the bottom position, engage your glutes and hamstrings to lift back up. 4. As you stand, press the weights overhead into a chest press position. 5. Lower the weights back to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Holman Deadlift to Squat Thrust
Desc: The Holman Deadlift to Squat Thrust combines a deadlift with a squat thrust, engaging multiple muscle groups for a full-body workout. This exercise enhances strength and cardiovascular endurance.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet hip-width apart, holding weights in both hands. 2. Perform a deadlift by lowering the weights towards the ground while keeping your back straight. 3. Once you reach the bottom, thrust your legs back into a plank position. 4. Quickly return to a squat position and then stand up, lifting the weights overhead. 5. Repeat the sequence for the desired number of reps.

Title: Holman Deadlift to Biceps Curl
Desc: The Holman Deadlift to Biceps Curl is a compound exercise that targets the lower body and arms. It combines a deadlift with a biceps curl for a comprehensive workout.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, holding weights in both hands. 2. Perform a deadlift by bending at the hips and knees, lowering the weights towards the ground. 3. As you return to standing, curl the weights up towards your shoulders. 4. Lower the weights back to the starting position and repeat the sequence.

Title: Dumbbell kickstand deadlift
Desc: The dumbbell kickstand deadlift is a movement targeting the muscles of the hamstrings, glutes, and back. The kickstand position can help focus the stretch and contraction on each individual leg, similar to a single-leg Romanian deadlift, while presenting less of a balance challenge. It can be performed in low reps, such as 5-8 reps per set, for strengthening the posterior chain, or for higher reps for muscle growth.
HowTo: 1. Stand with one foot slightly behind you, resting on the toes (kickstand position). 2. Hold a dumbbell in one hand and hinge at the hips to lower the weight towards the ground. 3. Keep your back straight and engage your core. 4. Return to standing by engaging your glutes and hamstrings. 5. Switch sides after completing the desired reps.

Title: Single-leg stiff-legged deadlift to row
Desc: The single-leg stiff-legged deadlift to row takes two popular strength moves and combines them into one full-body blaster. Between the deadlift and the row, you'll target the glutes, hamstrings, quads, back, and biceps. Because balance can be a challenge, this movement is usually done with relatively light weights for high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more.
HowTo: 1. Stand on one leg, holding a dumbbell in the opposite hand. 2. Hinge at the hips to lower the dumbbell towards the ground while extending the free leg behind you. 3. Once you reach the bottom position, pull the dumbbell towards your ribcage in a rowing motion. 4. Return to the starting position and repeat for the desired number of reps. 5. Switch legs and repeat.

Title: FYR2 Dumbbell Deadlift
Desc: The FYR2 Dumbbell Deadlift is a strength exercise that targets the lower body and back. It involves lifting dumbbells from the ground to a standing position, engaging multiple muscle groups.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, holding a dumbbell in each hand. 2. Bend at the hips and knees to lower the dumbbells to the ground. 3. Keep your back straight and chest up. 4. Push through your heels to lift the dumbbells back to standing.

Title: FYR2 Dumbbell Deadlift to Dumbbell Upright Row
Desc: The FYR2 Dumbbell Deadlift to Dumbbell Upright Row combines two exercises into one, targeting the legs and shoulders. It helps build strength and coordination.
HowTo: 1. Start with a dumbbell in each hand, feet shoulder-width apart. 2. Perform a deadlift by lowering the dumbbells to the ground. 3. As you stand up, pull the dumbbells up to your chest, leading with your elbows. 4. Lower the dumbbells back down and repeat.

Title: Atlas Stones
Desc: Atlas Stones are a classic strength training exercise that involves lifting heavy stones from the ground to a platform. This exercise builds overall body strength and power.
HowTo: 1. Stand over the stone with feet shoulder-width apart. 2. Bend at the hips and knees to grip the stone. 3. Lift the stone by extending your hips and knees, bringing it to your chest. 4. Load the stone onto a platform or over a bar.

Title: Axle Deadlift
Desc: The Axle Deadlift is a variation of the traditional deadlift that uses a thicker bar, increasing grip strength requirements. It primarily targets the lower body and back muscles.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet hip-width apart, gripping the axle bar with both hands. 2. Keep your back straight and chest up as you lower your hips. 3. Push through your heels to lift the bar off the ground, extending your hips and knees. 4. Lower the bar back to the ground with control.

Title: Atlas Stone Trainer
Desc: The Atlas Stone Trainer is designed to help individuals practice lifting Atlas stones safely and effectively. It builds strength and technique for stone lifting.
HowTo: 1. Stand with the stone in front of you, feet shoulder-width apart. 2. Bend at the hips and knees to grip the stone. 3. Lift the stone to your chest, keeping your back straight. 4. Practice loading the stone onto a platform or over a bar.

Title: Partner Flat-Bench Back Extension
Desc: The partner bench back extensionis a clever way to perform this exercise, which works the spinal erectors in the lower back. There are machines and angled apparatus that allow this exercise to performed solo; but, lacking those, all you need is a bench and a workout partner.
HowTo: 1. Lie face down on a flat bench with your hips at the edge. 2. Have your partner hold your feet down. 3. Lower your upper body towards the ground, then raise it back up to engage the lower back.

Title: Keg Load
Desc: The Keg Load is a strength exercise that involves lifting a keg or similar object. It primarily targets the lower body muscles.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. 2. Bend at the knees and hips to lower your body down to grab the keg. 3. Lift the keg by extending your hips and knees, keeping your back straight.

Title: Partner bench back extension
Desc: The partner bench back extension is a clever way to target the glutes and spinal erector muscles. There are machines and angled benches that allow this exercise to be performed solo, but, lacking those, all you need is a bench and a workout partner. It is usually performed for high reps as a burnout or accessory movement for lower-body training.
HowTo: 1. Lie face down on a bench with your hips at the edge. 2. Have a partner hold your feet down. 3. Lower your upper body towards the ground, then raise it back up to engage the glutes and lower back.

Title: Rack Pull - Gethin Variation
Desc: The rack pull is a variation of the deadlift performed from an elevated height, either using boxes, safety pins, or the safeties in a squat rack. It targets all the same muscles as the deadlift, including the glutes, hamstrings, upper back, lower back, and grip. It can e used to strengthen deadlift lockout, but also as a deadlift alternative for people who cant deadlift from the floor without pain.
Muscles: glutes, hamstrings, upper back, lower back
HowTo: 1. Set up a barbell on safety pins or boxes at knee height. 2. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, gripping the bar. 3. Lift the bar by extending your hips and knees, keeping your back straight.

Title: Hex Bar Deadlift - Gethin Variation
Desc: The hex bar deadlift is a variety of deadlift performed in a hexagonal barbell also known as a trap bar. The bar is held with a parallel (palms in) grip outside of the legs. It is biomechanically different from a barbell deadlift in that it lines up with a lifters center of gravity, rather than placing it in front of their body. The trap bar deadlift can be trained in traditional strength and muscle-focused rep range, or for higher reps. It activates all of the same muscle groups as conventional or sumo deadlifts, including the glutes, quads, hamstring, lower back, lats, upper back, and grip.
Muscles: glutes, quads, hamstrings, lower back, lats, upper back
HowTo: 1. Stand inside the hex bar with your feet shoulder-width apart. 2. Bend at the knees and hips to grip the handles. 3. Lift the bar by extending your hips and knees, keeping your back straight.

Title: Holman Deadlift
Desc: The Holman Deadlift is a strength exercise that primarily targets the lower body. It is performed by lifting a barbell from the ground while maintaining proper form to engage the glutes and hamstrings.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, barbell over the mid-foot. 2. Bend at the hips and knees to grip the barbell with both hands. 3. Keep your back straight and chest up. 4. Drive through your heels to lift the barbell, extending your hips and knees simultaneously. 5. Lower the barbell back to the ground with control.

Title: ACFT Low-handle trap bar deadlift
Desc: The low-handle trap bar deadlift is a variety of deadlift performed in a hexagonal barbell also known as a trap bar. This specific exercise is part of the new Army Combat Fitness Test or ACFT. The bar is held with a parallel (palms in) grip outside of the legs. It is biomechanically different from a barbell deadlift in that it lines up with a lifter's center of gravity, rather than placing the weight in front of their body. It activates all of the same muscle groups as conventional or sumo deadlifts, including the glutes, quads, hamstrings, lower back, lats, upper back, and grip.
Muscles: glutes, quads, hamstrings, lower back, lats, upper back, grip
HowTo: 1. Stand inside the trap bar with feet shoulder-width apart. 2. Bend at the hips and knees to grasp the handles with a neutral grip. 3. Keep your back straight and chest up. 4. Push through your heels to lift the trap bar, extending your hips and knees. 5. Lower the trap bar back to the ground with control.

Title: Neutral-grip lat pull-down
Desc: The neutral-grip lat pull-down is a variation on the lat pull-down that uses a handle with a neutral (palms facing in) grip. This arrangement helps to build lat width and target the upper lats. This movement is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 per set or higher, as part of an upper-body or back-focused workout.
HowTo: 1. Sit at the lat pull-down machine and grasp the neutral grip handles. 2. Adjust the knee pad to secure your legs. 3. Pull the handles down towards your chest while keeping your elbows close to your body. 4. Slowly return to the starting position, fully extending your arms.

Title: Seated cable deadlift
Desc: The seated cable deadlift is a version of the deadlift or hip hinge movement that is performed on a seated cable row machine. Similar to a stiff-legged deadlift or 45-degree back extension, it targets the muscles of the lower back, as well as the glutes and upper back to a lesser degree. It is usually utilized in higher rep ranges, at least 8-12 reps per set, on a back-focused muscle-building day, or as a deadlift accessory lift to strengthen the lower back.
HowTo: 1. Sit on the cable row machine with feet on the platform and knees slightly bent. 2. Grasp the handle with both hands, keeping your back straight. 3. Hinge at the hips to pull the handle towards your body, engaging your lower back and glutes. 4. Slowly return to the starting position, maintaining control.

Title: Cable stiff-legged deadlift
Desc: The cable stiff-legged deadlift is a lower-body exercise that mainly targets the hamstrings, while also benefiting the glutes using a proper hip-hinging motion.
HowTo: 1. Stand facing a cable machine with the pulley set at the lowest position. 2. Attach a straight bar to the cable and grasp it with both hands. 3. Keep your knees slightly bent and hinge at the hips to lower the bar towards the ground. 4. Engage your hamstrings and glutes to return to the starting position.

Title: Single-leg cable stiff-legged deadlift
Desc: The single-leg cable stiff-legged deadlift is a lower-body exercise that mainly targets the hamstrings, while also benefiting the glutes using a proper hip-hinging motion. Training one leg at a time allows for working out imbalances.
HowTo: 1. Attach a cable to the low pulley and adjust the weight. 2. Stand on one leg with the other leg extended behind you. 3. Hinge at the hips while keeping your back straight and lower the weight towards the ground. 4. Return to the starting position by engaging your hamstrings and glutes.

Title: UNS Banded Dumbbell Romanian Deadlift
Desc: The UNS Banded Dumbbell Romanian Deadlift is a lower-body exercise that primarily targets the hamstrings and glutes while also engaging the lower back.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet hip-width apart holding a dumbbell in each hand. 2. Loop a resistance band around your thighs just above the knees. 3. Hinge at the hips, lowering the dumbbells while keeping your back straight. 4. Return to standing by driving through your heels and engaging your glutes.

Title: Seated Back Extension
Desc: The Seated Back Extension is an exercise that targets the lower back and helps improve spinal stability and strength.
HowTo: 1. Sit on the back extension machine with your legs secured. 2. Adjust the pad so it rests on your lower back. 3. Lean forward at the hips and then extend your back to return to the starting position. 4. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Back extension
Desc: The back extension is an exercise used to build lower back strength that also targets the hamstrings and glutes. It is often performed on a 45-degree bench with the feet anchored. Unweighted back extensions are often performed for high reps, such as 15-20 reps or more, but the movement can also be performed with added weight in lower rep ranges, such as 8-12 reps per set.
HowTo: 1. Position yourself on a 45-degree bench with your feet secured. 2. Lower your upper body towards the ground while keeping your back straight. 3. Raise your upper body back to the starting position by engaging your lower back and glutes. 4. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Hyperextensions With No Hyperextension Bench
Desc: Hyperextensions without a hyperextension bench can be performed on the floor or a stability ball to strengthen the lower back.
HowTo: 1. Lie face down on a stability ball or the floor with your feet anchored. 2. Keep your hands behind your head or crossed over your chest. 3. Raise your upper body off the ground by extending your back. 4. Lower back down and repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Superman
Desc: The Superman is a bodyweight exercise that consists of isometric holds in an extended spine position. It targets the muscles of the posterior chain, including the muscles of the glutes, spinal erectors, and upper back. It can be performed as part of a dynamic warm-up, or for muscle activation or mobility anytime.
HowTo: 1. Lie face down on the floor with your arms extended in front of you and legs straight. 2. Simultaneously lift your arms, chest, and legs off the ground, holding the position for a few seconds before lowering back down.

Title: Hug A Ball
Desc: Hug A Ball is an exercise that promotes flexibility and relaxation. It is often used in warm-up routines.
HowTo: 1. Sit on the ground with your legs extended. 2. Hold a stability ball close to your chest and gently roll back and forth to stretch your back and hips.

Title: Child's pose
Desc: Childs pose is a traditional yoga pose that is also popular in fitness and strength training. It targets mobility of the thoracic spine and control of the vertebral column. It can be performed for time or reps as part of a dynamic warm-up or as a mobility or restorative exercise anytime. It can also work as part of a yoga or bodyweight sequence with other poses.
HowTo: 1. Start on your hands and knees. 2. Sit back on your heels, extending your arms forward and lowering your forehead to the ground.

Title: Pelvic Tilt Into Bridge
Desc: Pelvic Tilt Into Bridge is an exercise that strengthens the glutes and core. It focuses on pelvic stability and lower back strength.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back with your knees bent and feet flat on the floor. 2. Tilt your pelvis up, engaging your glutes, and lift your hips towards the ceiling, then lower back down.

Title: Hug Knees To Chest
Desc: Hug Knees To Chest is a gentle stretch that promotes relaxation and flexibility. It is often used to relieve tension in the lower back.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back and pull your knees towards your chest. 2. Hold the position for several breaths, gently rocking side to side if desired.

Title: Pyramid
Desc: The Pyramid exercise is a strength training method that involves increasing and then decreasing the weight for each set while performing a specific number of repetitions. This technique helps build muscle endurance and strength.
HowTo: 1. Start with a light weight and perform 12-15 reps. 2. Gradually increase the weight while decreasing the reps for each subsequent set until you reach your maximum weight. 3. Then, decrease the weight and increase the reps back to the starting point.

Title: Partner Superman with alternating high-five
Desc: The partner Superman with alternating high-five is an exercise in which both partners perform isometric holds for reps, high-fiving each other in between. It targets the muscles of the posterior chain, including the muscles of the glutes, spinal erectors, and upper back. It can be performed as part of a dynamic warm-up, or as part of a core or back-focused workout or finisher.
HowTo: 1. Both partners lie face down on the floor with arms extended. 2. Lift your arms and legs off the ground simultaneously, holding the position. 3. Alternate high-fiving each other while maintaining the hold.

Title: Yoga plex
Desc: The yoga plex is a stretch that combines elements of the downward facing dog yoga pose with the worlds greatest stretch. It is most commonly performed as part of a dynamic warm-up, to limber up muscles from head to toe, raise the bodys core temperature, and mobilize the hips, upper back, and shoulders.
HowTo: 1. Start in a downward facing dog position. 2. Step one foot forward into a lunge, rotating your torso towards the front leg. 3. Switch sides and repeat, flowing between the two positions.

Title: TBS Back Extension
Desc: The back extension is an exercise used to build lower back strength that also targets the hamstrings and glutes. It is often performed on a 45-degree bench with the feet anchored. Unweighted back extensions are often performed for high reps, such as 15-20 reps or more, but the movement can also be performed with added weight in lower rep ranges, such as 8-12 reps per set.
HowTo: 1. Position yourself on a 45-degree bench with your feet anchored. 2. Lower your upper body towards the ground while keeping your back straight. 3. Raise your upper body back to the starting position, squeezing your lower back muscles.

Title: Lower Back Stretch - Yates Variation
Desc: The lying cross-over lower back stretch is a simple bodyweight stretch targeting the lower back, hips, and torso. It involves rotating the legs while lying flat on the back. It is commonly included in dynamic warm-ups, but can also be performed as full-body mobility work anytime.
HowTo: 1. Lie flat on your back with your arms extended to the sides. 2. Rotate your legs to one side while keeping your shoulders on the ground. 3. Hold the stretch for a few seconds, then switch to the other side.

Title: Hyperextension - Gethin Variation
Desc: The back extension is an exercise used to build lower back strength that also targets the hamstrings and glutes. It is often performed on a 45-degree bench with the feet anchored. Unweighted back extensions are often performed for high reps, such as 15-20 reps or more, but the movement can also be performed with added weight in lower rep ranges, such as 8-12 reps per set.
HowTo: 1. Position yourself on a 45-degree bench with your feet secured. 2. Lower your upper body towards the ground while keeping your back straight. 3. Raise your upper body back to the starting position by engaging your lower back, hamstrings, and glutes.

Title: Back Extension - Gethin Variation
Desc: The back extension is an exercise used to build lower back strength that also targets the hamstrings and glutes. It is often performed on a 45-degree bench with the feet anchored. Unweighted back extensions are often performed for high reps, such as 15-20 reps or more, but the movement can also be performed with added weight in lower rep ranges, such as 8-12 reps per set.
HowTo: 1. Position yourself on a 45-degree bench with your feet secured. 2. Lower your upper body towards the ground while keeping your back straight. 3. Raise your upper body back to the starting position by engaging your lower back, hamstrings, and glutes.

Title: HM Banana Stretch
Desc: The HM Banana Stretch is a flexibility exercise that targets the entire body, focusing on the lateral muscles. It helps improve mobility and stretches the hip flexors and lower back.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back with your arms and legs extended. 2. Reach your arms and legs to one side, creating a banana shape with your body. 3. Hold the stretch for 15-30 seconds, then switch sides.

Title: HM T-Spine Stretch on Wall
Desc: The HM T-Spine Stretch on Wall is designed to improve thoracic spine mobility and shoulder flexibility. This exercise helps alleviate tension in the upper back.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your back against a wall and feet shoulder-width apart. 2. Raise your arms to shoulder height and press your elbows against the wall. 3. Gently rotate your upper body away from the wall while keeping your lower body stable. 4. Hold for a few seconds, then return to the starting position.

Title: HM Child's Pose
Desc: The HM Child's Pose is a restorative stretch that promotes relaxation and flexibility in the back and hips. It is commonly used to relieve tension and stress.
HowTo: 1. Kneel on the floor with your big toes touching and knees apart. 2. Sit back on your heels and extend your arms forward on the floor. 3. Lower your torso between your thighs and relax your neck. 4. Hold the position for 30 seconds to a minute.

Title: HM Cobra
Desc: The HM Cobra is a stretching exercise that helps improve flexibility in the spine and opens up the chest. It is often used in yoga practices to enhance mobility.
HowTo: 1. Start in a prone position on the floor. 2. Place your hands under your shoulders and gently push up, arching your back. 3. Keep your hips on the ground and look up towards the ceiling. 4. Hold the position for a few breaths before releasing.

Title: HM Cobra With Arm Retraction
Desc: The HM Cobra With Arm Retraction enhances the stretch of the HM Cobra by incorporating arm movement, improving shoulder mobility and back flexibility. This exercise is beneficial for posture and spinal health.
HowTo: 1. Begin in the HM Cobra position. 2. As you hold the position, retract your arms back, squeezing your shoulder blades together. 3. Hold for a few seconds, then return to the starting position. 4. Repeat several times.

Title: HM Dive-Bomber
Desc: The HM Dive-Bomber is a dynamic movement that combines elements of a push-up and a yoga pose, promoting flexibility and strength. It engages multiple muscle groups while improving overall body coordination.
HowTo: 1. Start in a downward dog position. 2. Lower your chest towards the ground while arching your back and moving forward. 3. Transition into an upward position, then reverse the movement back to downward dog. 4. Repeat for several repetitions.

Title: HM Downward-Facing Dog Pose
Desc: The HM Downward-Facing Dog Pose is a foundational yoga pose that stretches the entire body, focusing on the back, hamstrings, and shoulders. It helps to relieve tension and improve overall flexibility.
HowTo: 1. Start on your hands and knees. 2. Tuck your toes and lift your hips up and back, straightening your legs and arms. 3. Press your heels towards the ground and relax your head between your arms. 4. Hold the position and breathe deeply.

Title: HM Downward Dog To Left Leg Extension To Warrior Pose
Desc: The HM Downward Dog To Left Leg Extension To Warrior Pose is a flow that transitions from a stretch into a strength pose, enhancing flexibility and stability. It engages the core and lower body while promoting balance.
HowTo: 1. Start in downward dog position. 2. Lift your left leg towards the ceiling, keeping your hips square. 3. Transition into Warrior Pose by stepping your left foot forward and bending your knee. 4. Raise your arms overhead and hold the position.

Title: HM Downward Dog To Right Leg Extension To Warrior Pose
Desc: The Downward Dog is a foundational yoga pose that stretches the entire body. The transition to Warrior Pose engages the legs and core while promoting balance.
HowTo: 1. Start in a downward-facing dog position with your hands and feet on the ground. 2. Lift your right leg towards the ceiling, keeping your hips square. 3. Step your right foot forward between your hands, transitioning into Warrior Pose. 4. Bend your right knee and extend your arms overhead, gazing forward.

Title: HM Spine Twist
Desc: The Spine Twist is a great exercise for improving spinal mobility and flexibility. It helps to release tension in the back and promotes better posture.
HowTo: 1. Sit on the floor with your legs extended. 2. Bend your right knee and place your foot on the outside of your left thigh. 3. Place your left elbow on the outside of your right knee and twist your torso to the right. 4. Hold the position, then switch sides.

Title: HM Good Morning
Desc: The Good Morning exercise targets the posterior chain, primarily the hamstrings and lower back. It is effective for building strength and stability.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and a barbell across your upper back. 2. Keeping your back straight, hinge at the hips and lower your torso forward. 3. Go down until your torso is parallel to the ground, then return to the starting position.

Title: HM Rag Doll
Desc: Rag Doll is a relaxing stretch that helps to relieve tension in the back and hamstrings. It promotes flexibility and relaxation.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet hip-width apart. 2. Bend forward at the hips, letting your arms hang towards the ground. 3. Relax your neck and shoulders, and hold the position for several breaths. 4. Slowly roll back up to standing.

Title: HM Upward-Facing Dog Pose
Desc: The Upward-Facing Dog Pose is a powerful stretch for the front of the body. It opens the chest and strengthens the back.
HowTo: 1. Lie face down on the floor with your hands under your shoulders. 2. Press into your hands to lift your chest and thighs off the ground, keeping your legs straight. 3. Open your chest and look up, engaging your back muscles. 4. Hold the position while breathing deeply.

Title: Superman-
Desc: The Superman is a bodyweight exercise that consists of isometric holds in an extended spine position. It targets the muscles of the posterior chain, including the muscles of the glutes, spinal erectors, and upper back. It can be performed as part of a dynamic warm-up, or for muscle activation or mobility anytime.
HowTo: Lie face down on the ground with your arms extended in front of you. Simultaneously lift your arms, chest, and legs off the ground, holding the position for a few seconds before lowering back down.

Title: Weighted back extension
Desc: The weighted back extension is an exercise targeting the spinal erectors, as well as the glutes and hamstrings. Back extensions are often done for high reps without weight, but when done with weight, they can be an excellent accessory movement for deadlift strength as well as an overall posterior-chain strength builder. Because your back is the limiting factor, it's still an exercise that is usually done for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or higher. You can weight it with a plate or by holding a dumbbell or other weight in your hands.
HowTo: Position yourself on a back extension bench with your hips against the pad. Lower your upper body towards the ground, then raise it back up until your body is in a straight line, squeezing your glutes at the top.

Title: MetaBurn Alternating Superman
Desc: The MetaBurn Alternating Superman is a variation of the Superman exercise that focuses on alternating arm and leg lifts to enhance core stability and coordination.
HowTo: Start in a prone position with arms extended. Lift your right arm and left leg simultaneously, hold for a moment, then switch to your left arm and right leg.

Title: MetaBurn Swimmer
Desc: The MetaBurn Swimmer is a dynamic exercise that mimics the motion of swimming, targeting multiple muscle groups for mobility and coordination.
HowTo: Lie face down with arms extended in front of you. Alternate lifting your right arm and left leg, then your left arm and right leg, as if you are swimming.

Title: Dancer's Stretch
Desc: The Dancer's Stretch is a flexibility exercise that targets the legs and hips, promoting overall mobility.
HowTo: Stand on one leg and pull the other leg behind you, holding your ankle. Keep your knees close together and push your hips forward to feel the stretch in your quadriceps.

Title: Cat Stretch
Desc: The Cat Stretch is a gentle stretch that helps improve flexibility in the spine and relieve tension in the back. It is often used in yoga and can be beneficial for overall mobility.
HowTo: 1. Start on your hands and knees in a tabletop position. 2. Inhale as you arch your back, dropping your belly towards the floor and lifting your head and tailbone. 3. Exhale as you round your back, tucking your chin to your chest and pulling your belly button towards your spine. 4. Repeat for several cycles of breath.

Title: Crossover Reverse Lunge
Desc: The Crossover Reverse Lunge is an effective lower-body exercise that targets the legs and glutes while improving balance and coordination. It involves stepping back diagonally to engage multiple muscle groups.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet hip-width apart. 2. Step back with your right foot and cross it behind your left leg, lowering into a lunge. 3. Push through your left heel to return to standing. 4. Repeat on the other side.

Title: Standing Pelvic Tilt
Desc: The Standing Pelvic Tilt is a simple exercise that helps strengthen the abdominal muscles and improve posture. It is particularly useful for those looking to enhance core stability.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. 2. Tighten your abdominal muscles and tilt your pelvis slightly forward. 3. Hold for a few seconds, then relax. 4. Repeat several times.

Title: Exercise ball weighted hyperextension
Desc: The exercise ball weighted hyperextension is an exercise that strengthens the lower back. If balance is an issue, have someone hold your feet.
HowTo: 1. Lie face down on an exercise ball with your feet anchored. 2. Hold a weight plate or dumbbell against your chest. 3. Lift your upper body by extending your back, squeezing your glutes at the top. 4. Lower back down and repeat.

Title: Exercise ball rear delt fly
Desc: The exercise ball rear delt fly is a dumbbell exercise targeting the rear heads of the shoulders, as well as the muscles of the upper-middle back. Lying prone on an exercise ball offers support to perform the movement. It is generally performed for moderate to high reps as a part of upper body or shoulder training.
HowTo: 1. Lie face down on an exercise ball with your feet firmly on the ground. 2. Hold a dumbbell in each hand with your arms hanging down. 3. Raise your arms out to the sides, squeezing your shoulder blades together. 4. Lower back down and repeat.

Title: Lying rear delt Y
Desc: The lying rear delt Y works the shoulders, specifically the rear heads, as well as the lower trapezius muscles. At the top of the motion, the arms and torso form a Yhence the name. Shoulder Y variations are usually performed with light weights as a warm-up or prehab movement for upper-body training, or as a burnout on shoulder day.
HowTo: 1. Lie face down on a bench or mat with your arms extended in front of you. 2. Lift your arms and torso to form a 'Y' shape, squeezing your shoulder blades together.

Title: Partner Facing Feet-Elevated Side Plank With Band Row
Desc: The partner facing feet-elevated side plank with band row engages the core while providing resistance through the band row.
HowTo: 1. One partner assumes a side plank position with feet elevated. 2. The other partner stands facing them, holding a resistance band anchored to the elevated partner, and performs a row while maintaining the plank.

Title: Partner side plank band row
Desc: The partner side plank band row is an abdominal exercise where two partners perform side planks while pulling on the opposite ends of an exercise band. This technique can be done for time or reps in any ab-focused workout.
HowTo: 1. Both partners get into a side plank position facing each other. 2. Each partner grabs the ends of an exercise band and performs a rowing motion while maintaining the plank position.

Title: Band-assisted chin-up
Desc: The band-assisted chin-up is a variation of the pull-up exercise in which the reps are performed with the palms facing toward the body in an underhand position, with a band looped around the feet or knees. This reduces weight and resistance at the bottom of the rep, while increasing it toward the top. Like other pull-up variations, it builds strength and muscle in the upper back, biceps, and core, but it utilizes the biceps slightly more than overhand band-assisted pull-ups.
HowTo: 1. Loop a resistance band around your feet or knees. 2. Grip the bar with palms facing you and pull yourself up while using the band for assistance.

Title: 30 Back Band-Assisted Pull-Up
Desc: The 30 back band-assisted pull-up is a variation that helps build strength in the upper body while reducing resistance.
HowTo: 1. Set up a resistance band around the bar and loop it under your knees or feet. 2. Grip the bar with palms facing you and pull yourself up, using the band to assist you.

Title: 30 Back Reverse-Grip Band-Assisted Pull-Up
Desc: The 30 Back Reverse-Grip Band-Assisted Pull-Up is an effective exercise for building upper body strength. It primarily targets the back muscles while also engaging the biceps.
Muscles: latissimus dorsi, lower trapezius, rear deltoids, biceps
HowTo: 1. Attach a resistance band to a pull-up bar. 2. Place one foot or knee in the band for assistance. 3. Grip the bar with an underhand grip. 4. Pull your body up towards the bar while keeping your elbows close to your body. 5. Lower yourself back down and repeat.

Title: Band bent-over row
Desc: The band bent-over row is an exercise to develop and strengthen the muscles of the upper and middle back, like the latissimus (lat), lower trapezius, and rear deltoids. Bands provide dynamic resistance and can work equally well in strength, muscle-building, or circuit-style fat-loss workouts.
Muscles: latissimus dorsi, lower trapezius, rear deltoids, biceps
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, holding the band with both hands. 2. Bend at the hips and knees, keeping your back straight. 3. Pull the band towards your torso, squeezing your shoulder blades together. 4. Slowly return to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Heavy band bent-over row
Desc: The heavy band bent-over row is a variation of the popular barbell exercise to develop and strengthen the muscles of the upper and middle back, like the latissimus (lats), lower trapezius, and rear deltoids. It can work equally well in strength, muscle-building, or circuit-style fat-loss workouts.
Muscles: latissimus dorsi, lower trapezius, rear deltoids, biceps
HowTo: 1. Stand on the band with feet shoulder-width apart, holding the ends of the band. 2. Bend at the hips and knees, keeping your back straight. 3. Pull the band towards your torso, squeezing your shoulder blades together. 4. Slowly return to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Reverse-grip bent-over row
Desc: The reverse-grip bent-over row is a compound exercise used to build strength and size in both the lower and upper back. It targets nearly all of the muscles in the back, but particularly the lats, rhomboids, and lower back. It is thought to target the biceps and lats a bit more directly than overhand barbell rows. Because it can be loaded heavily, it is a popular movement in strength and muscle-focused upper-body workouts.
Muscles: latissimus dorsi, rhomboids, lower back, biceps
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, holding a barbell with an underhand grip. 2. Bend at the hips and knees, keeping your back straight. 3. Pull the barbell towards your torso, focusing on squeezing your back muscles. 4. Lower the barbell back down and repeat.

Title: One-Arm Long Bar Row
Desc: The single-arm landmine bent-over row is a barbell exercise focused on the muscles of the middle back, such as the lats (latissimus dorsi) and rhomboids. It also targets the biceps and grip. It utilizes a landmine device which anchors one end of the barbell near the ground, but could also be approximated by placing the barbell in the corner of a room.
HowTo: 1. Set up a landmine device with one end of the barbell anchored. 2. Stand next to the barbell, holding it with one hand. 3. Bend at the hips and knees, keeping your back straight. 4. Pull the barbell towards your torso, focusing on your back muscles. 5. Lower the barbell back down and repeat.

Title: Bent Over Barbell Row
Desc: The barbell bent-over row is a compound exercise used to build strength and size in both the lower and upper back. It targets nearly all of the muscles in the back, but particularly the lats, rhomboids, and lower back. It is commonly utilized as an accessory movement for the deadlift in powerlifting, but is also popular in strength and muscle-focused upper-body workouts.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a barbell with both hands. 2. Bend at the hips and knees, keeping your back straight, until your torso is nearly parallel to the ground. 3. Pull the barbell towards your lower rib cage, squeezing your shoulder blades together. 4. Lower the barbell back to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Yates Row Reverse Grip
Desc: The Yates row is a variation of the bent-over row that emphasizes the upper back and lats. It is performed with a reverse grip, allowing for a different angle of pull.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a barbell with a reverse grip (palms facing you). 2. Bend at the hips and knees, keeping your back straight, until your torso is at a 45-degree angle. 3. Pull the barbell towards your abdomen, keeping your elbows close to your body. 4. Lower the barbell back to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Pendlay Row
Desc: The Pendlay row, named after the well-known strength coach Glenn Pendlay, is a bent-over row variation where each rep starts with the barbell resting on the ground. This eliminates the stretch reflex and forces the lifter to pull with power and a bent-over spine. The Pendlay row can be performed heavy for low reps, but is usually performed for moderate reps, such as 5-8 per set.
HowTo: 1. Stand over a barbell with your feet shoulder-width apart. 2. Bend at the hips and knees to grasp the barbell with an overhand grip. 3. Keep your back straight and pull the barbell explosively towards your lower chest. 4. Lower the barbell back to the ground and repeat.

Title: Straight Bar Bench Mid Rows
Desc: Straight Bar Bench Mid Rows are performed on a bench and target the middle back muscles. This exercise allows for a controlled range of motion and emphasizes back strength.
HowTo: 1. Lie face down on a bench with your chest supported and feet on the ground. 2. Hold a barbell with both hands, arms extended towards the floor. 3. Pull the barbell towards your lower chest, squeezing your shoulder blades together. 4. Lower the barbell back to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Barbell seal row
Desc: The barbell seal row is a weighted exercise targeting the muscles of the middle back, including the lats (latissimus dorsi) and rhomboids. It can be performed on a special elevated bench, on a bench placed on top of boxes or benches, or on a bench with a slight incline. The higher the bench, the greater the range of motion and stretch at the bottom of the movement. It is usually performed as an assistance movement for back strength and muscle growth, in rep ranges of 8-12 reps per set or higher.
HowTo: 1. Lie face down on an elevated bench with your arms hanging down, holding a barbell. 2. Pull the barbell towards your chest, keeping your elbows close to your body. 3. Squeeze your shoulder blades together at the top of the movement. 4. Lower the barbell back to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Yates Row
Desc: The Yates Row is a bent-over rowing exercise that targets the upper back and biceps. It is performed with a barbell, focusing on pulling the weight towards the lower chest.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a barbell with an underhand grip. 2. Bend your knees slightly and hinge at the hips to lower your torso until it's almost parallel to the ground. 3. Pull the barbell towards your lower chest, squeezing your shoulder blades together. 4. Lower the barbell back to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Plate Row
Desc: The Plate Row is a rowing exercise that targets the upper back and arms. It is performed with a weight plate, focusing on pulling the plate towards the body.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a weight plate with both hands. 2. Bend your knees slightly and hinge at the hips to lower your torso. 3. Pull the plate towards your abdomen, keeping your elbows close to your body. 4. Lower the plate back to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Barbell Deadlift Bent Row Complex
Desc: The barbell deadlift bent-over row complex combines two movements to target the posterior chain. It requires using a lighter weight than you could handle for heavy deadlifts alone, but doubles down on activation in the upper back, lower back, and glutes.
Muscles: Latissimus Dorsi, Rhomboids, Trapezius, Glutes, Hamstrings
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet hip-width apart, barbell on the floor in front of you. 2. Bend at the hips and knees to grip the barbell with an overhand grip. 3. Lift the barbell by extending your hips and knees until you are standing. 4. Hinge at the hips to lower your torso and pull the barbell towards your lower chest. 5. Return the barbell to the floor and repeat.

Title: Single-Arm Landmine Row
Desc: The Single-Arm Landmine Row is a unilateral exercise that targets the upper back and biceps. It is performed using a landmine attachment for stability and focus.
HowTo: 1. Set one end of a barbell into a landmine attachment. 2. Stand facing the barbell, holding the free end with one hand. 3. Bend your knees slightly and hinge at the hips. 4. Pull the barbell towards your torso, keeping your elbow close to your body. 5. Lower the barbell back to the starting position and repeat.

Title: TBS T-Bar Row
Desc: The TBS T-Bar Row is a compound exercise that targets the upper back and arms. It is performed using a T-Bar row machine or a barbell with a landmine attachment.
HowTo: 1. Stand over the T-Bar row machine or landmine setup, feet shoulder-width apart. 2. Bend your knees slightly and hinge at the hips to grip the handles or bar. 3. Pull the weight towards your chest, squeezing your shoulder blades together. 4. Lower the weight back to the starting position and repeat.

Title: TBS Deficit Deadlift
Desc: The barbell deficit deadlift is a compound exercise targeting the posterior chain.
HowTo: 1. Stand on a platform with a barbell on the floor. 2. Bend at the hips and knees to grasp the barbell with both hands. 3. Keep your back straight and chest up as you lift the barbell by extending your hips and knees. 4. Lower the barbell back to the floor with control.

Title: Bent-Over Barbell Row - Gethin Variation
Desc: The barbell bent-over row is a compound exercise used to build strength and size in both the lower and upper back. It targets nearly all of the muscles in the back, but particularly the lats, rhomboids, and lower back. It is commonly utilized as an accessory movement for the deadlift in powerlifting, but is also popular in strength and muscle-focused upper-body workouts.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and hold a barbell with both hands. 2. Bend your knees slightly and hinge at the hips to lower your torso until it's nearly parallel to the floor. 3. Pull the barbell towards your lower ribcage, squeezing your shoulder blades together. 4. Lower the barbell back to the starting position with control.

Title: Barbell bent-over row
Desc: The barbell bent-over row is a compound exercise used to build strength and size in both the lower and upper back. It targets nearly all of the muscles in the back, but particularly the lats, rhomboids, and lower back. It is commonly utilized as an accessory movement for the deadlift in powerlifting, but is also popular in strength and muscle-focused upper-body workouts.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and hold a barbell with both hands. 2. Bend your knees slightly and hinge at the hips to lower your torso until it's nearly parallel to the floor. 3. Pull the barbell towards your lower ribcage, squeezing your shoulder blades together. 4. Lower the barbell back to the starting position with control.

Title: UN Barbell Rack Pull
Desc: The barbell rack pull is a compound exercise that primarily targets the posterior chain, similar to the deadlift but with the bar elevated. It focuses on building strength in the hamstrings, glutes, and lower back.
HowTo: 1. Set a barbell on a squat rack at knee height. 2. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and grasp the barbell with both hands. 3. Keep your back straight and chest up as you lift the barbell by extending your hips and knees. 4. Lower the barbell back to the rack with control.

Title: UN Barbell Scrape The Rack
Desc: The barbell scrape the rack is an exercise that targets the posterior chain, focusing on the hamstrings and glutes. It is performed by pulling the barbell along the body to emphasize proper form and control.
HowTo: 1. Stand with a barbell in front of you at hip height. 2. Grasp the barbell with both hands and lift it while keeping it close to your body. 3. Pull the barbell up along your torso, maintaining a straight back. 4. Lower the barbell back to the starting position with control.

Title: Barbell deadlift bent-over row complex
Desc: The barbell deadlift bent-over row complex combines two movements to target the posterior chain. It requires using a lighter weight than you could handle for heavy deadlifts alone, but doubles down on activation in the upper back, lower back, and glutes.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, holding a barbell. 2. Bend at the hips and knees to lower your torso while keeping your back straight. 3. Perform a deadlift by lifting the barbell while engaging your glutes and hamstrings. 4. Transition into a bent-over row by pulling the barbell towards your torso, squeezing your shoulder blades together. 5. Lower the barbell back down and repeat.

Title: 30 Back Barbell Deadlift
Desc: The 30 Back Barbell Deadlift is a fundamental exercise that targets the posterior chain, focusing on the hamstrings and glutes. It is essential for building strength in the lower body and improving overall lifting performance.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet hip-width apart and grip the barbell with both hands. 2. Keep your back straight and push your hips back as you lower the barbell down your legs. 3. Drive through your heels to lift the barbell back to the starting position, engaging your glutes and hamstrings.

Title: 30 Back Bent-Over Barbell Row
Desc: The 30 Back Bent-Over Barbell Row is an effective exercise for strengthening the upper back and improving posture. It helps develop the lats and rhomboids, contributing to a well-rounded back workout.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a barbell with an overhand grip. 2. Bend at the hips and knees, keeping your back straight. 3. Pull the barbell towards your lower ribcage, squeezing your shoulder blades together. 4. Lower the barbell back down and repeat.

Title: 30 Back T-Bar Row
Desc: The 30 Back T-Bar Row is a great exercise for targeting the middle of the back and building overall back thickness. It emphasizes the lats and traps, making it a staple in back training routines.
HowTo: 1. Stand over a T-bar row machine or a barbell set in a corner. 2. Bend at the hips and knees, grasping the handles or barbell. 3. Pull the weight towards your chest while keeping your elbows close to your body. 4. Lower the weight back down and repeat.

Title: 30 Back Underhand Bent-Over Barbell Row
Desc: The 30 Back Underhand Bent-Over Barbell Row is an effective variation that targets the upper back and biceps. This exercise helps improve grip strength and overall back development.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a barbell with an underhand grip. 2. Bend at the hips and knees, keeping your back straight. 3. Pull the barbell towards your abdomen, focusing on squeezing your back muscles. 4. Lower the barbell back down and repeat.

Title: Kettlebell alternating renegade row
Desc: The kettlebell alternating renegade row combines rowing and core training into a single difficult movement. It's popular in time-efficient strength and muscle-building workouts, as well as in circuit-style training.
HowTo: 1. Start in a plank position with a kettlebell in each hand. 2. Row one kettlebell towards your hip while stabilizing your body with the other arm. 3. Alternate sides while maintaining a strong plank position.

Title: Alternating Kettlebell Row
Desc: The Alternating Kettlebell Row is a rowing exercise that targets the upper back and biceps. It helps improve strength and stability in the back muscles.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, holding a kettlebell in each hand. 2. Bend slightly at the hips and knees, keeping your back straight. 3. Row one kettlebell towards your hip while keeping the other arm extended. 4. Alternate sides.

Title: Two-Arm Kettlebell Row
Desc: The Two-Arm Kettlebell Row is a compound exercise that targets the upper back and arms. It is effective for building strength and muscle in the back.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, holding a kettlebell in each hand. 2. Bend at the hips and knees, keeping your back straight. 3. Pull both kettlebells towards your hips simultaneously, squeezing your shoulder blades together. 4. Lower the kettlebells back to the starting position.

Title: Kettlebell bent-over row to clean
Desc: The kettlebell bent-over row to clean is a combination kettlebell exercise that targets many of the muscles of the upper body including the lats (latissimus dorsi), biceps, shoulders, and core. It also strengthens and trains power output of the lower body. It can be done for reps or for time as a strength or muscle-focused complex, or in circuit-style training for conditioning or fat loss.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, holding a kettlebell in each hand. 2. Bend at the hips and knees, keeping your back straight. 3. Row the kettlebells towards your hips, then transition into a clean by bringing them to shoulder height. 4. Lower back to the starting position and repeat.

Title: UP Deficit Kettlebell Stiff-Legged Deadlift
Desc: The kettlebell deficit deadlift is a more advanced version of the kettlebell deadlift movement that is performed standing on steps or boxes. It can be done to build strength or hip mobility for squats or deadlifts, in high reps or in more traditional strength and muscle-focused rep ranges.
HowTo: 1. Stand on a step or box with a kettlebell between your feet. 2. Hinge at the hips and lower your body to grab the kettlebell. 3. Engage your hamstrings and glutes to lift the kettlebell back to standing. 4. Lower the kettlebell back to the ground and repeat.

Title: FYR2 Dagger-Grip Double-Kettlebell Gorilla Row
Desc: The FYR2 Dagger-Grip Double-Kettlebell Gorilla Row is a strength exercise that targets the back muscles. It involves rowing two kettlebells while maintaining a stable position.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, holding a kettlebell in each hand. 2. Bend at the hips and knees to lower your torso while keeping your back straight. 3. Row the kettlebells towards your hips, squeezing your shoulder blades together. 4. Lower the kettlebells back to the starting position and repeat.

Title: FYR2 Double-Kettlebell Swing Clean
Desc: The FYR2 Double-Kettlebell Swing Clean is a dynamic exercise that combines a swing and a clean motion. It effectively targets the lower body and improves power.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet hip-width apart, holding a kettlebell in each hand. 2. Hinge at the hips to swing the kettlebells back between your legs. 3. Drive through your heels to swing the kettlebells forward and up, catching them at shoulder height. 4. Lower back down and repeat.

Title: Single-arm kettlebell row-
Desc: The single-arm kettlebell row is a popular muscle- and strength-building exercise that works the muscles of the back and core simultaneously. It has all the same benefits as a single-arm dumbbell row, but some people find a kettlebell more comfortable to hold during the movement.
HowTo: 1. Place one knee and hand on a bench for support, with the other foot on the ground. 2. Hold a kettlebell in the opposite hand, letting it hang straight down. 3. Pull the kettlebell towards your hip, keeping your elbow close to your body. 4. Lower the kettlebell back down and repeat.

Title: FYR2 Ascending-Rep Swing-Squat Complex
Desc: The FYR2 Ascending-Rep Swing-Squat Complex is a compound exercise that combines swinging and squatting movements. It effectively targets the legs and enhances overall strength.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, holding a kettlebell. 2. Perform a kettlebell swing, driving through your hips. 3. After the swing, transition directly into a squat position. 4. Repeat the swing and squat for the desired number of reps.

Title: One-Arm Dumbbell Row
Desc: The single-arm bench dumbbell row is a popular exercise for building the latissimus dorsi, or lat, muscles of the back. The bench is used for support during the rowing motion.
HowTo: 1. Place one knee and hand on a bench for support, with the other foot on the ground. 2. Hold a dumbbell in the opposite hand, letting it hang straight down. 3. Pull the dumbbell towards your hip, keeping your elbow close to your body. 4. Lower the dumbbell back down and repeat.

Title: Incline dumbbell row
Desc: The incline dumbbell row is an upper-body exercise targeting the lats (latissimus dorsi) and upper-back muscles, as well as the biceps. Performing it on an incline bench helps target the lower lats in particular. Dumbbell row variations are usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of the upper-body or back-focused portion of a workout.
HowTo: 1. Lie face down on an incline bench with a dumbbell in each hand. 2. Pull the dumbbells towards your lower rib cage while keeping your elbows close to your body, then lower them back down.

Title: Bent Over Two-Dumbbell Row With Palms In
Desc: The Bent Over Two-Dumbbell Row with Palms In is an effective exercise for targeting the back muscles while also engaging the biceps. This exercise can be performed with a moderate weight for multiple repetitions.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, holding a dumbbell in each hand with palms facing in. 2. Bend at the hips and knees, keeping your back straight, and row the dumbbells towards your hips, squeezing your shoulder blades together at the top.

Title: Man-maker
Desc: The man-maker is a sequence of exercises combining a dumbbell front squat, military press, renegade row, and sprawl. Between these movements it challenges muscles across the body, along with the cardiovascular system. It can be performed for rounds or for time as a single full-body exercise or as part of a fat-loss or athleticism-focused workout.
HowTo: 1. Start in a standing position with a dumbbell in each hand. 2. Perform a squat, then press the dumbbells overhead, followed by a renegade row, and finish with a sprawl to return to the standing position.

Title: Dumbbell bent-over row
Desc: The dumbbell bent-over row is a popular exercise to develop and strengthen the muscles of the upper and middle back, like the latissimus (lat), lower trapezius, and rear deltoids. It can work equally well in strength, muscle-building, or circuit-style fat-loss workouts.
Muscles: latissimus dorsi, lower trapezius, rear deltoids
HowTo: 1. Stand with a dumbbell in each hand, bend at the hips until your torso is nearly parallel to the ground. 2. Pull the dumbbells towards your waist, squeezing your shoulder blades together, then lower them back down.

Title: Middle Back Shrug
Desc: The Middle Back Shrug focuses on strengthening the upper back and shoulders. It can be performed with dumbbells or a barbell for added resistance.
HowTo: 1. Stand upright holding a dumbbell in each hand at your sides. 2. Raise your shoulders towards your ears, squeezing the shoulder blades together, then lower back down.

Title: Dumbbell pull-over to skullcrusher
Desc: The dumbbell pull-over to skullcrusher is a complex that combines two popular exercises into one sequence that works much of the upper body, particularly the chest, triceps, and serratus anterior muscles. Because the pull-over will determine the amount of weight you can use, this movement is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of the upper-body portion of a workout.
HowTo: 1. Lie on a bench with a dumbbell in both hands above your chest. 2. Lower the dumbbell behind your head in a pull-over motion. 3. Bring the dumbbell back over your chest, then lower it to your forehead for the skullcrusher. 4. Extend your arms back to the starting position.

Title: Dumbbell Fix Single-Arm Dumbbell Row
Desc: The Dumbbell Fix Single-Arm Dumbbell Row is an effective exercise for targeting the back muscles. It involves pulling a dumbbell towards your hip while stabilizing your body with the opposite arm.
HowTo: 1. Place one knee and hand on a bench for support. 2. Hold a dumbbell in the opposite hand, arm extended towards the floor. 3. Pull the dumbbell towards your hip, keeping your elbow close to your body. 4. Lower the dumbbell back to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Dumbbell Fix Bent-Over Dumbbell Row
Desc: The Dumbbell Fix Bent-Over Dumbbell Row is a compound exercise that targets the upper back muscles. It involves bending forward and rowing dumbbells towards your torso.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, holding a dumbbell in each hand. 2. Bend at the hips and knees, keeping your back straight. 3. Pull the dumbbells towards your waist, squeezing your shoulder blades together. 4. Lower the dumbbells back to the starting position.

Title: Dumbbell Seal Row - Gethin Variation
Desc: The dumbbell seal row is a weighted exercise targeting the muscles of the middle back, including the lats (latissimus dorsi) and rhomboids. It can be performed on a special elevated bench, on a bench placed on top of boxes or benches, or on a bench with a slight incline. The higher the bench, the greater the range of motion and stretch at the bottom of the movement. It is usually performed as an assistance movement for back strength and muscle growth, in rep ranges of 8-12 reps per set or higher.
HowTo: 1. Lie face down on a bench with your arms hanging down, holding a dumbbell in each hand. 2. Pull the dumbbells towards your chest, keeping your elbows close to your body. 3. Squeeze your shoulder blades together at the top of the movement. 4. Lower the dumbbells back to the starting position.

Title: Decline dumbbell chest fly
Desc: The decline dumbbell chest fly is an upper-body exercise targeting the muscles of the chest, particularly the lower chest. It will require less weight than a decline press, which makes it a great hypertrophy exercise with high reps. Fly variations are usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more.
HowTo: 1. Lie on a decline bench holding a dumbbell in each hand above your chest. 2. Lower the dumbbells out to the sides in a wide arc, keeping a slight bend in your elbows. 3. Bring the dumbbells back together above your chest, squeezing your chest muscles. 4. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: TBS Bent-Over Dumbbell Row
Desc: The dumbbell bent-over row is a popular exercise to develop and strengthen the muscles of the upper and middle back, like the latissimus (lat), lower trapezius, and rear deltoids. It can work equally well in strength, muscle-building, or circuit-style fat-loss workouts.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a dumbbell in each hand. 2. Bend your knees slightly and hinge at your hips to lower your torso until it's almost parallel to the floor. 3. Pull the dumbbells towards your hips, squeezing your shoulder blades together. 4. Lower the weights back to the starting position and repeat.

Title: HM Alternating Bent-Over Quick Row
Desc: The alternating bent-over quick row is an effective exercise for targeting the back muscles while also improving coordination and stability.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet hip-width apart, holding a dumbbell in each hand. 2. Bend your knees slightly and hinge at your hips to lower your torso. 3. Row one dumbbell towards your hip while keeping the other arm extended. 4. Alternate sides with each repetition.

Title: HM Bent-Over Dumbbell Row
Desc: The bent-over dumbbell row is a classic exercise for strengthening the back and improving posture.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and hold a dumbbell in each hand. 2. Bend your knees slightly and hinge at your hips to lower your torso. 3. Pull the dumbbells towards your hips, keeping your elbows close to your body. 4. Lower the weights back down and repeat.

Title: AM Single Arm Row
Desc: The single-arm bench dumbbell row is a popular exercise for building the latissimus dorsi, or lat, muscles of the back. The bench is used for support during the rowing motion.
HowTo: 1. Position yourself on a bench with one knee and hand for support. 2. Hold a dumbbell in the opposite hand and let it hang straight down. 3. Pull the dumbbell towards your hip while keeping your elbow close to your body. 4. Lower the dumbbell back to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Dumbbell stiff-legged deadlift
Desc: The dumbbell stiff-legged deadlift is a dumbbell exercise that targets the hamstrings, glutes, lower and upper back, and core. The difference between a stiff-legged deadlift and a Romanian deadlift is primarily the amount of knee bend. The knees are only slightly bent in a stiff-legged deadlift, while they bend more in a Romanian deadlift. Stiff-legged deadlifts are generally performed for low to moderate reps, such as 8-10 reps per set, with a focus on maximizing the hamstring stretch rather than moving heavy weight. Feel free to wear a weight belt to protect your lower back.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a dumbbell in each hand. 2. Keep your legs straight with a slight bend in the knees. 3. Hinge at your hips and lower the dumbbells towards the ground while keeping your back straight. 4. Return to standing by engaging your hamstrings and glutes.

Title: Single-arm bench dumbbell row
Desc: The single-arm bench dumbbell row is a popular exercise for building the latissimus dorsi, or lat, muscles of the back. The bench is used for support during the rowing motion.
HowTo: 1. Place one knee and one hand on a bench for support. 2. Hold a dumbbell in the opposite hand, letting it hang straight down. 3. Pull the dumbbell towards your hip while keeping your elbow close to your body. 4. Lower the dumbbell back to the starting position and repeat.

Title: UN Bent-Over Dumbbell Row
Desc: The UN Bent-Over Dumbbell Row is an effective exercise for targeting the upper back and improving posture. It involves bending over while holding dumbbells and pulling them towards your torso.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, holding a dumbbell in each hand. 2. Bend at the hips and knees, keeping your back straight. 3. Pull the dumbbells towards your waist, squeezing your shoulder blades together. 4. Lower the dumbbells back to the starting position and repeat.

Title: UN Dumbbell RDL
Desc: The UN Dumbbell RDL (Romanian Deadlift) focuses on the posterior chain, particularly the hamstrings and glutes. It is performed by hinging at the hips while holding dumbbells.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet hip-width apart, holding a dumbbell in each hand in front of your thighs. 2. Keeping your knees slightly bent, hinge at the hips to lower the dumbbells along your legs. 3. Lower until you feel a stretch in your hamstrings, then return to standing by driving your hips forward.

Title: UN Chest Supported Row
Desc: The UN Chest Supported Row is designed to isolate the back muscles while minimizing strain on the lower back. It is performed on a bench with your chest supported.
HowTo: 1. Lie face down on a bench with your chest supported and feet on the ground. 2. Hold a dumbbell in each hand, arms extended towards the floor. 3. Pull the dumbbells towards your chest, squeezing your shoulder blades together. 4. Lower the dumbbells back to the starting position and repeat.

Title: MetaBurn Bent-Over Renegade Row
Desc: The MetaBurn Bent-Over Renegade Row is a compound exercise that targets multiple muscle groups, including the back and core. It combines a plank position with a rowing motion.
HowTo: 1. Start in a plank position with a dumbbell in each hand. 2. Keeping your body straight, row one dumbbell towards your hip while stabilizing with the other arm. 3. Lower the dumbbell back down and repeat on the other side. 4. Alternate sides for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: 30 Back Bent-Over Dumbbell Row
Desc: The Bent-Over Dumbbell Row targets the upper back and helps improve posture. It is effective for building strength in the back muscles.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a dumbbell in each hand. 2. Bend your knees slightly and hinge at the hips to lean forward, keeping your back straight. 3. Pull the dumbbells towards your hips, squeezing your shoulder blades together. 4. Lower the weights back down and repeat.

Title: 30 Back Dumbbell Pull-Over
Desc: The Dumbbell Pull-Over is great for expanding the chest and strengthening the back. It works multiple muscle groups simultaneously.
HowTo: 1. Lie on a bench with your upper back supported and feet flat on the ground. 2. Hold a dumbbell with both hands above your chest. 3. Lower the dumbbell back and over your head while keeping your arms slightly bent. 4. Bring the dumbbell back to the starting position and repeat.

Title: 30 Back Incline Dumbbell Row
Desc: The Incline Dumbbell Row targets the upper back and rear deltoids. It helps improve muscle definition and strength.
HowTo: 1. Set an incline bench to about 30-45 degrees and lie face down with a dumbbell in each hand. 2. Pull the dumbbells towards your sides, keeping your elbows close to your body. 3. Squeeze your shoulder blades together at the top of the movement. 4. Lower the weights back down and repeat.

Title: 30 Back Single-Arm Dumbbell Row
Desc: The Single-Arm Dumbbell Row is effective for isolating each side of the back. It helps improve muscle imbalances.
HowTo: 1. Place one knee and hand on a bench for support, with the other foot on the ground. 2. Hold a dumbbell in the free hand, letting it hang straight down. 3. Pull the dumbbell towards your hip, keeping your elbow close to your body. 4. Lower the dumbbell back down and repeat before switching sides.

Title: 30 Back Single-Arm Dumbbell Swing Row
Desc: The Single-Arm Dumbbell Swing Row combines a rowing motion with a swinging action for dynamic strength training. It targets the back and engages the core.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a dumbbell in one hand. 2. Bend slightly at the knees and hinge at the hips, letting the dumbbell swing down between your legs. 3. Row the dumbbell up towards your hip while keeping your back straight. 4. Lower the dumbbell back down and repeat before switching sides.

Title: T-Bar Row with Handle
Desc: The T-Bar Row with Handle is a strength exercise that primarily targets the upper back. It is performed using a T-Bar row machine or a barbell with a handle attachment.
Muscles: lats, traps, rhomboids, rear deltoids, biceps
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. 2. Bend at the hips and knees to grasp the handle with both hands. 3. Pull the handle towards your chest while keeping your elbows close to your body. 4. Lower the handle back to the starting position and repeat.

Title: T-Bar Row
Desc: The T-Bar Row is a strength training exercise that targets the upper back muscles. It is effective for building muscle mass and strength in the back.
Muscles: lats, traps, rhomboids, rear deltoids, biceps
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and grasp the T-Bar handle. 2. Bend at the hips and knees, keeping your back straight. 3. Pull the handle towards your torso, squeezing your shoulder blades together. 4. Lower the handle back down and repeat.

Title: Alternating sit-through with crunch
Desc: The alternating sit-through with crunch is a full-body movement that starts in a bear crawl position and ends with a leg kicked out to the side. In between reps, you perform a crunch. It is commonly performed for reps or time in bodyweight circuits and animal-style flows, but can also work on its own or as part of a dynamic warm-up or mobility sequence.
HowTo: 1. Start in a bear crawl position with your hands under your shoulders and knees under your hips. 2. Lift your right hand and left foot, bringing your knee towards your chest while performing a crunch. 3. Extend your leg out to the side and return to the starting position. 4. Alternate sides and repeat.

Title: Seated Cable Rows
Desc: The cable seated row is a popular exercise to train the muscles of the upper back, including the lats (latissimus dorsi), traps, rhomboids, and rear deltoids, using a cable stack. It also targets the biceps to a lesser degree. The cable row can work well in a variety of rep-ranges, but is most popular in muscle-building workouts or as an accessory movement for strength workouts.
Muscles: lats, traps, rhomboids, rear deltoids, biceps
HowTo: 1. Sit at a cable row machine with your feet on the platform. 2. Grasp the handle with both hands, keeping your back straight. 3. Pull the handle towards your abdomen, squeezing your shoulder blades together. 4. Slowly return to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Upside-down pull-up
Desc: The upside-down pull-up is an advanced bodyweight exercise that is normally performed on a pair of gymnastic rings. It involves pulling the body toward the ceiling in an inverted position. It targets the same muscles as traditional pull-ups, including the lats (latissimus dorsi), biceps, and core. However, the pulling angle is more akin to a bent-over row or upright row, depending on the angle of your hips.
HowTo: 1. Set up gymnastic rings at a height where you can hang from them. 2. Grip the rings and pull your body up towards the ceiling while keeping your body straight. 3. Lower yourself back down to the starting position and repeat. 4. Maintain control throughout the movement.

Title: Smith machine inverted row
Desc: The Smith machine inverted row is a bodyweight exercise targeting the muscles of the lats (latissimus dorsi) and upper back, using the bar of the Smith machine to hang and pull from. You can change the bar height to customize the difficulty level and desired angle of the row. This variation is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more.
HowTo: 1. Set the bar on the Smith machine at a height that allows you to hang underneath it. 2. Grip the bar with an overhand grip, and hang with your body straight. 3. Pull your chest towards the bar while keeping your body straight, then lower back down.

Title: Lying T-Bar Row
Desc: The Lying T-Bar Row is a strength exercise that targets the back muscles. It involves pulling a weighted bar towards your torso while lying face down.
HowTo: 1. Stand over a T-Bar row machine and place one end of the bar into the corner. 2. Load the other end with weights. 3. Straddle the bar and bend at the hips, grabbing the handles. 4. Pull the bar towards your chest while keeping your elbows close to your body, then lower it back down.

Title: Suspended row
Desc: The suspended row is a bodyweight pulling exercise that focuses on the muscles of the middle and upper back, as well as the biceps. It can be trained in traditional muscle-building rep ranges or for higher reps. It can also work as part of a dynamic warm-up for a pressing or pulling-focused workout.
HowTo: 1. Set up suspension straps at waist height. 2. Grip the handles and lean back, keeping your body straight. 3. Pull your chest towards the handles while keeping your elbows close to your body, then lower back down.

Title: Inverted Row with Straps
Desc: The Inverted Row with Straps is a variation of the traditional inverted row that uses straps for added instability. It targets the upper back and biceps.
