HowTo: 1. Set the straps at a suitable height and adjust them to your preferred length. 2. Grip the handles and hang with your body straight. 3. Pull your chest towards the handles while keeping your body straight, then lower back down.

Title: One Arm Chin-Up
Desc: The One Arm Chin-Up is an advanced bodyweight exercise that primarily targets the lats and biceps. It requires significant strength and control.
HowTo: 1. Hang from a pull-up bar with one arm while the other arm is at your side. 2. Engage your core and pull your body up towards the bar using the strength of your pulling arm. 3. Lower yourself back down under control.

Title: Sled Row
Desc: The sled row is a strength exercise that targets the upper back and arms. It involves pulling a sled towards your body using a rowing motion.
Muscles: lats, traps, rhomboids, rear deltoids, biceps
HowTo: 1. Stand facing the sled with feet shoulder-width apart. 2. Grip the handles firmly. 3. Lean back slightly and pull the sled towards you while keeping your elbows close to your body. 4. Slowly return to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Paul Carter T-Bar Row
Desc: The Paul Carter T-Bar Row is a compound exercise that primarily targets the upper back. It helps to build strength and mass in the back muscles.
Muscles: lats, traps, rhomboids, rear deltoids, biceps
HowTo: 1. Stand over the T-Bar row machine and place your feet shoulder-width apart. 2. Bend at the hips and knees to grasp the handles. 3. Pull the handles towards your chest while keeping your elbows close to your body. 4. Lower the weight back down and repeat.

Title: Single-Arm Bent-Over Rear Delt Raise - Gethin Variation
Desc: The single-arm bent-over rear delt fly or rear delt raise is a popular upper-body exercise that targets the muscles on the back of the shoulder joint, specifically the rear head of the deltoid. Since pressing movements build the front and (to a lesser degree) side deltoid heads, this move is often done to promote balanced shoulder development. It is usually performed for high reps, such as 10-15 reps per set or more, as part of a shoulder or upper-body workout.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and hinge at the hips to bend forward. 2. Hold a dumbbell in one hand and let it hang straight down. 3. Raise the dumbbell out to the side until your arm is parallel to the ground. 4. Lower it back down and repeat, then switch arms.

Title: 30 Back Plate Hyperextension
Desc: The 30 Back Plate Hyperextension is an exercise that targets the lower back and hamstrings. It helps to strengthen the posterior chain.
HowTo: 1. Position yourself on a hyperextension bench with your hips against the pad. 2. Hold a weight plate against your chest. 3. Lower your upper body towards the ground while keeping your back straight. 4. Raise your upper body back to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Seated Cable Rows
Desc: The cable seated row is a popular exercise to train the muscles of the upper back, including the lats (latissimus dorsi), traps, rhomboids, and rear deltoids, using a cable stack. It also targets the biceps to a lesser degree. The cable row can work well in a variety of rep-ranges, but is most popular in muscle-building workouts or as an accessory movement for strength workouts.
Muscles: lats, traps, rhomboids, rear deltoids, biceps
HowTo: 1. Sit at a cable row machine with your feet on the platform and knees slightly bent. 2. Grasp the handle with both hands. 3. Pull the handle towards your torso while keeping your back straight and elbows close to your body. 4. Slowly extend your arms back to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Single-arm cable seated row
Desc: The single-arm cable seated row is a version of the cable row movement that trains the muscles of the upper back one side at a time. It targets a wide range of muscles including the lats (latissimus dorsi), traps, rhomboids, and rear deltoids. It also targets the biceps to a lesser degree. The single-arm row can work well in a variety of rep ranges but is most popular in muscle-building workouts or as an accessory movement for strength workouts.
Muscles: lats, traps, rhomboids, rear deltoids, biceps
HowTo: 1. Sit at the cable machine and adjust the pulley to a low position. 2. Grasp the handle with one hand, keeping your back straight. 3. Pull the handle towards your torso while squeezing your shoulder blades together. 4. Slowly return to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Paul Carter Lat Pull-Down
Desc: The lat pull-down is a cable-based exercise machine thats ubiquitous in gyms around the world. This back builder is easy to learn and highly effective, allowing for variable resistance depending on where you place the pin in the stack.
HowTo: 1. Sit at the lat pull-down machine and adjust the knee pad. 2. Grasp the bar with a wide grip. 3. Pull the bar down towards your chest while leaning back slightly. 4. Slowly return the bar to the starting position and repeat.

Title: TBS Lat Pull-Down
Desc: The TBS Lat Pull-Down is a cable exercise targeting the back muscles, particularly the lats. It is effective for building strength and size in the upper body.
HowTo: 1. Sit at the lat pull-down machine and adjust the knee pad. 2. Grasp the bar with a wide grip. 3. Pull the bar down towards your chest while leaning back slightly. 4. Slowly return the bar to the starting position and repeat.

Title: One-Arm Cable Read Delt Fly - Gethin Variation
Desc: The single-arm bent-over cable rear delt fly is an exercise targeting the rear deltoids. It is a great way to isolate this area of the shoulder and attack each side independently. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps, at least 8-12 reps per set, as part of an upper-body or shoulder-focused workout.
HowTo: 1. Stand next to a cable machine and adjust the pulley to a low position. 2. Grasp the handle with one hand and bend forward slightly. 3. Pull the handle out to the side, keeping your elbow slightly bent. 4. Slowly return to the starting position and repeat.

Title: UP Seated Cable Row
Desc: The cable seated row is a popular exercise to train the muscles of the upper back, including the lats (latissimus dorsi), traps, rhomboids, and rear deltoids, using a cable stack. It also targets the biceps to a lesser degree. The cable row can work well in a variety of rep-ranges, but is most popular in muscle-building workouts or as an accessory movement for strength workouts.
Muscles: lats, traps, rhomboids, rear deltoids, biceps
HowTo: 1. Sit at the cable machine and adjust the pulley to a low position. 2. Grasp the handle with both hands, keeping your back straight. 3. Pull the handle towards your torso while squeezing your shoulder blades together. 4. Slowly return to the starting position and repeat.

Title: UP Cable Straight-Arm Pull-Down
Desc: The straight-arm rope pull-down is a variation of the straight-arm lat pull-down performed using a cable stack machine and a rope grip. It can either be performed in an athletic upright stance, or slightly bent-over. It both stretches and contracts the muscles of the lats (latissimus dorsi) as well as providing additional activation to the other upper back muscles and the core. Because the triceps are also isometrically involved in the movement, it is usually performed for higher reps, like 8-15 reps or above.
Muscles: Latissimus Dorsi, Triceps, Upper Back, Core
HowTo: 1. Attach a rope handle to the high pulley of a cable machine. 2. Stand facing the machine with feet shoulder-width apart. 3. Grasp the rope with both hands, palms facing down. 4. Pull the rope down in a straight line while keeping your arms straight, engaging your lats and upper back. 5. Slowly return to the starting position and repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: UN Cable Pull-Through
Desc: The cable pull-through is an effective exercise for targeting the posterior chain, specifically the hamstrings and glutes. It involves pulling a cable from behind the body while hinging at the hips.
HowTo: 1. Attach a rope handle to the low pulley of a cable machine. 2. Stand facing away from the machine with feet shoulder-width apart. 3. Grasp the rope between your legs with both hands. 4. Hinge at the hips, allowing the cable to pull your torso forward while keeping your back straight. 5. Drive through your heels to return to the starting position, squeezing your glutes at the top.

Title: 30 Back Close-Grip Seated Cable Row
Desc: The seated cable row is a great exercise for building back strength and muscle. It involves pulling a cable towards your torso while seated.
HowTo: 1. Sit on a cable row machine with your feet on the platform. 2. Grasp the handle with both hands, keeping your arms extended. 3. Pull the handle towards your torso, squeezing your shoulder blades together. 4. Slowly extend your arms back to the starting position and repeat.

Title: 30 Back Incline Face-Up Cable Pull-Down
Desc: The incline face-up cable pull-down targets the upper back and lats while allowing for a greater range of motion. This exercise is performed on an incline bench to enhance muscle engagement.
HowTo: 1. Set an incline bench at a 30-degree angle and position it in front of a cable machine. 2. Attach a straight bar to the high pulley. 3. Lie face-up on the bench and grasp the bar with both hands. 4. Pull the bar down towards your chest, engaging your back muscles. 5. Slowly return to the starting position and repeat.

Title: 30 Back Kneeling High Cable Pull-Down
Desc: The kneeling high cable pull-down is an effective exercise for targeting the upper back and lats while in a kneeling position. This position helps to isolate the back muscles.
HowTo: 1. Kneel in front of a cable machine with a high pulley. 2. Attach a straight bar to the pulley and grasp it with both hands. 3. Pull the bar down towards your chest while keeping your elbows close to your body. 4. Slowly return to the starting position and repeat.

Title: 30 Back Leaning V-Bar Pull-Down
Desc: The V-Bar Pull-Down primarily targets the back muscles, particularly the lats. It helps in building upper body strength and improving posture.
HowTo: 1. Sit at a pull-down machine and grasp the V-bar attachment. 2. Pull the bar down towards your chest while keeping your elbows close to your body. 3. Slowly return to the starting position and repeat.

Title: 30 Back Reverse-Grip Pull-Down
Desc: The Reverse-Grip Pull-Down is effective for targeting the upper back and biceps. It emphasizes the lower lats and helps in developing a well-rounded back.
HowTo: 1. Sit at a pull-down machine and grasp the bar with an underhand grip. 2. Pull the bar down towards your chest while leaning back slightly. 3. Slowly return to the starting position and repeat.

Title: 30 Back Standing Low Cable Bar Row
Desc: The Standing Low Cable Bar Row is a great exercise for building back thickness and strength. It engages multiple muscle groups in the upper body.
HowTo: 1. Stand facing a low cable machine with a bar attachment. 2. Grasp the bar with both hands and pull it towards your torso while keeping your elbows close. 3. Slowly extend your arms back to the starting position and repeat.

Title: 30 Back Standing Low Cable Rope Row
Desc: The Standing Low Cable Rope Row targets the back and biceps effectively. It allows for a greater range of motion and better muscle engagement.
HowTo: 1. Stand facing a low cable machine with a rope attachment. 2. Pull the rope towards your body while keeping your elbows close and squeezing your shoulder blades together. 3. Slowly return to the starting position and repeat.

Title: 30 Back Straight-Arm Bar Pull-Down
Desc: The Straight-Arm Bar Pull-Down is an excellent exercise for isolating the lats. It helps in developing upper body strength and improving muscle definition.
HowTo: 1. Stand at a pull-down machine and grasp the bar with both hands, arms extended. 2. Pull the bar down towards your thighs while keeping your arms straight. 3. Slowly return to the starting position and repeat.

Title: 30 Back Straight-Arm Rope Pull-Down
Desc: The 30 Back Straight-Arm Rope Pull-Down is an effective exercise for targeting the upper back and shoulders. It helps in building strength and muscle definition in the back region.
HowTo: 1. Stand in front of a cable machine with a rope attachment. 2. Grasp the rope with both hands, palms facing down. 3. Pull the rope down while keeping your arms straight, engaging your back muscles. 4. Return to the starting position and repeat.

Title: 30 Back Wide-Grip Behind-The-Head Pull-Down
Desc: The 30 Back Wide-Grip Behind-The-Head Pull-Down is designed to target the upper back and shoulders effectively. This exercise helps in developing width and strength in the back.
HowTo: 1. Sit at a pull-down machine and grasp the bar with a wide grip. 2. Pull the bar down behind your head, keeping your elbows pointed down. 3. Slowly return to the starting position and repeat.

Title: 30 Back Wide-Grip Pull-Down
Desc: The 30 Back Wide-Grip Pull-Down focuses on building strength in the upper back and lats. It is a fundamental exercise for developing back width.
HowTo: 1. Sit at a pull-down machine and grip the bar with a wide grip. 2. Pull the bar down towards your chest, squeezing your shoulder blades together. 3. Slowly return to the starting position and repeat.

Title: 30 back Wide-Grip Seated Cable Row
Desc: The 30 Back Wide-Grip Seated Cable Row is excellent for targeting the back and biceps. It helps in building overall upper body strength.
HowTo: 1. Sit at a cable row machine with your feet on the platform. 2. Grasp the wide grip handle with both hands. 3. Pull the handle towards your torso while keeping your back straight. 4. Slowly return to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Rower
Desc: The rower is a popular gym machine that is serious cardiovascular work, but also targets the legs, back, and arm muscles. It's a great way build overall aerobic and muscular fitness. It is popular in CrossFit-style workouts, but is also a staple in all types of gyms. It can be equally effective for HIIT-style interval workouts or for longer-duration endurance work.
HowTo: 1. Sit on the rower and strap your feet in. 2. Start with your knees bent and arms extended. 3. Push back with your legs while pulling the handle towards your chest. 4. Extend your arms and bend your knees to return to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Seated Cable Rows
Desc: The cable seated row is a popular exercise to train the muscles of the upper back, including the lats (latissimus dorsi), traps, rhomboids, and rear deltoids, using a cable stack. It also targets the biceps to a lesser degree. The cable row can work well in a variety of rep-ranges, but is most popular in muscle-building workouts or as an accessory movement for strength workouts.
Muscles: lats, traps, rhomboids, rear deltoids, biceps
HowTo: 1. Sit at the cable row machine with your feet on the platform. 2. Grab the handle with both hands, keeping your back straight. 3. Pull the handle towards your torso, squeezing your shoulder blades together. 4. Slowly return to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Smith machine bent-over row
Desc: The Smith machine bent-over row is an upper-body exercise targeting the muscles of the back, particularly the lats (latissimus dorsi). This movement can be programmed in low reps for strength or higher reps for muscle and strength endurance. It is often performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of an upper-body or back-focused workout.
HowTo: 1. Set the Smith machine bar to a comfortable height. 2. Bend at the hips and knees, keeping your back straight, and grasp the bar with an overhand grip. 3. Pull the bar towards your torso while squeezing your shoulder blades together. 4. Lower the bar back to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Leverage High Row
Desc: The machine high row is an exercise targeting the lats and works the back overall.
HowTo: 1. Sit at the leverage high row machine and adjust the seat height if necessary. 2. Grab the handles with both hands, keeping your back straight. 3. Pull the handles towards your chest while squeezing your shoulder blades. 4. Slowly return to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Machine Low Row
Desc: The machine low row is an exercise targeting the back muscles.
HowTo: 1. Sit at the low row machine and adjust the seat height if necessary. 2. Grab the handle with both hands, keeping your back straight. 3. Pull the handle towards your torso, engaging your back muscles. 4. Slowly return to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Standing lat pull-down
Desc: The standing lat pull-down is a variation of the lat pull-down performed standing next to a cable stack rather than sitting on a bench or machine. It has all of the same benefits of a lat pull-down performed on a bench or machine, in addition to providing further activation to the core and lower body. If you are too tall to perform this movement, a kneeling lat pull-down provides all of the same benefits.
HowTo: 1. Stand next to the cable stack and grab the lat pull-down bar with an overhand grip. 2. Lean slightly back and pull the bar down towards your chest while engaging your core. 3. Slowly return the bar to the starting position and repeat.

Title: 30 Back Machine Seated Row
Desc: The Seated Row is a strength exercise targeting the back muscles. It involves pulling a weighted handle towards your torso while seated.
HowTo: 1. Sit on the machine with your feet on the platform. 2. Grab the handle with both hands. 3. Pull the handle towards your torso while keeping your back straight. 4. Slowly return to the starting position.

Title: 30 Back Smith Machine Push-Up
Desc: The Smith Machine Push-Up is a variation of the push-up that utilizes a Smith machine for support. It primarily targets the chest and triceps.
HowTo: 1. Set the Smith machine bar at an appropriate height. 2. Position yourself under the bar and grip it with both hands. 3. Lower your body towards the bar, then push back up to the starting position.

Title: Mixed Grip Chin
Desc: The Mixed Grip Chin is a pull-up variation that targets the back and biceps. It involves using a different grip for each hand.
HowTo: 1. Hang from a pull-up bar with one hand in an underhand grip and the other in an overhand grip. 2. Pull your body up until your chin is above the bar. 3. Lower yourself back down and repeat.

Title: Rhomboids SMR
Desc: Rhomboids self-myofascial release (SMR) is a self-administered soft-tissue treatment for the upper body, usually using a foam roller, lacrosse ball, or other "trigger point" massage tool. By applying pressure strategically to the rhomboid muscles of the mid back, some people find they can cause this often painful and tight area to relax or "release." Rhomboids SMR is often accompanied by SMR on the lats, or by stretches that target the rhomboids or lats.
HowTo: 1. Position a foam roller or lacrosse ball on the floor. 2. Lie on your back with the roller/ball under your upper back. 3. Gently roll back and forth to apply pressure to the rhomboids.

Title: Spinal Stretch
Desc: The Spinal Stretch is a mobility exercise that helps improve flexibility in the spine. It targets the muscles along the back.
HowTo: 1. Sit on the floor with your legs extended in front of you. 2. Reach your arms overhead and gently lean forward, reaching towards your toes. 3. Hold the stretch for a few seconds before returning to the starting position.

Title: Upper Back Stretch
Desc: The Upper Back Stretch helps improve flexibility and relieve tension in the upper back muscles. It is beneficial for those who spend long hours sitting or working at a desk.
HowTo: 1. Stand or sit comfortably. 2. Interlace your fingers and extend your arms in front of you. 3. Round your upper back and push your hands away from your body. 4. Hold the stretch for 15-30 seconds.

Title: Middle Back Stretch
Desc: The Middle Back Stretch targets the mid-back area to enhance flexibility and reduce stiffness. It is particularly useful for counteracting the effects of poor posture.
HowTo: 1. Stand or sit up straight. 2. Reach both arms overhead and clasp your hands together. 3. Lean to one side, feeling the stretch along your side and middle back. 4. Hold for 15-30 seconds and switch sides.

Title: TBS Pull-Up
Desc: The TBS Pull-Up is an effective upper body exercise that primarily targets the back and arms. It builds strength and muscle endurance.
HowTo: 1. Grab the pull-up bar with an overhand grip, hands slightly wider than shoulder-width apart. 2. Hang with your arms fully extended. 3. Pull your body up until your chin is above the bar. 4. Lower yourself back down to the starting position. 5. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: HM Angel Stretch
Desc: The HM Angel Stretch is designed to improve shoulder mobility and flexibility. It helps relieve tension in the shoulders and upper back.
HowTo: 1. Stand against a wall with your back flat against it. 2. Raise your arms to form a 'W' shape, keeping your elbows and wrists against the wall. 3. Slowly slide your arms up into a 'Y' shape while keeping contact with the wall. 4. Hold for 15-30 seconds.

Title: UNS Foam Roll Upper Back
Desc: The UNS Foam Roll Upper Back exercise helps release tension and improve mobility in the upper back. It is particularly effective for muscle recovery.
HowTo: 1. Sit on the floor and place a foam roller behind your upper back. 2. Lean back onto the roller, supporting your head with your hands. 3. Roll back and forth slowly, allowing the roller to massage your upper back. 4. Spend 1-2 minutes on this area.

Title: 30 Back Neutral-Grip Pull-Down
Desc: The 30 Back Neutral-Grip Pull-Down is an effective exercise for building back strength. It primarily targets the upper back and biceps.
HowTo: 1. Sit at a pull-down machine and grasp the neutral grip bar. 2. Pull the bar down towards your chest while keeping your back straight. 3. Slowly return to the starting position and repeat.

Title: 30 Back Pull-Up
Desc: The 30 Back Pull-Up is a challenging exercise that builds upper body strength. It primarily targets the back and biceps.
HowTo: 1. Hang from a pull-up bar with an overhand grip. 2. Pull your body up until your chin is above the bar. 3. Lower yourself back down and repeat.

Title: 30 Back Reverse-Grip Pull-Up
Desc: The 30 Back Reverse-Grip Pull-Up is a variation that emphasizes the lower lats and biceps. It is a great exercise for building upper body strength.
HowTo: 1. Hang from a pull-up bar with an underhand grip. 2. Pull your body up until your chin is above the bar. 3. Lower yourself back down and repeat.

Title: ACFT Medicine ball overhead power throw
Desc: The medicine ball overhead power throw is an explosive exercise targeting the abdominals and hips. This specific exercise is part of the new Army Combat Fitness Test or ACFT. It can be performed for lower reps with a focus on power or for higher reps with a focus on fat loss and conditioning. It begins in a semi-squat position holding a medicine ball, which then gets "scooped" up and thrown overhead in one continuous movement.
HowTo: 1. Start in a semi-squat position holding a medicine ball. 2. Scoop the ball up and throw it overhead in one continuous motion. 3. Follow through with your arms and return to the starting position.

Title: Upright Row - With Bands
Desc: The Upright Row with Bands is an effective exercise for shoulder development. It targets the deltoids and upper back.
HowTo: 1. Stand on a resistance band with both feet and hold the handles. 2. Pull the band upwards towards your chin, keeping your elbows higher than your wrists. 3. Lower the band back down and repeat.

Title: Band seated row
Desc: The band seated row is a band alternative to the popular cable exercise and trains the muscles of the upper back, including the lats (latissimus dorsi), traps, rhomboids, and rear deltoids. It also targets the biceps to a lesser degree. The band row can work well in a variety of rep ranges, requiring a heavier band for muscle-building and strength workouts and a lighter band for weight-loss work and as an accessory movement.
Muscles: lats, traps, rhomboids, rear deltoids, biceps
HowTo: 1. Sit on the floor with your legs extended. 2. Loop a resistance band around your feet and hold the ends with both hands. 3. Pull the band towards your torso while keeping your elbows close to your body. 4. Squeeze your shoulder blades together at the end of the movement. 5. Slowly return to the starting position.

Title: Barbell shrug
Desc: The barbell shrug is an exercise targeting the traps (trapezius muscles). It is popular in strength and muscle-focused upper-body training, and is often trained on a shoulder day. With the assistance of straps, it can be loaded heavily, but it is still usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-10 reps per set.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and hold a barbell in front of your thighs with an overhand grip. 2. Keep your arms straight and lift your shoulders towards your ears. 3. Hold for a moment at the top, then lower your shoulders back down.

Title: Barbell behind-the-back shrug
Desc: The barbell behind-the-back shrug is an exercise targeting the traps. Having the bar behind you helps keep your shoulders pulled up and back, rather than rounded forward. It is popular in strength and muscle-focused upper-body training, and is often trained on a shoulder day. With the assistance of straps, it can be loaded heavily, but it is still usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-10 reps per set.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and hold a barbell behind your back with an overhand grip. 2. Keep your arms straight and lift your shoulders towards your ears. 3. Hold for a moment at the top, then lower your shoulders back down.

Title: Clean Shrug
Desc: The clean shrug is a strength exercise that primarily targets the traps. It is often performed as part of Olympic lifting training.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and hold a barbell at hip level. 2. Clean the barbell to your shoulders. 3. With the barbell at your shoulders, shrug your shoulders upwards. 4. Hold for a moment, then lower your shoulders back down.

Title: Snatch Shrug
Desc: The snatch shrug is a strength exercise that primarily targets the traps. It is often performed as part of Olympic lifting training.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and hold a barbell at hip level. 2. Snatch the barbell overhead. 3. With the barbell overhead, shrug your shoulders upwards. 4. Hold for a moment, then lower your shoulders back down.

Title: Single-arm inverted row
Desc: The single-arm inverted row is a bodyweight exercise targeting the muscles of the lats (latissimus dorsi) and upper back, using the bar of the Smith machine to hang and pull from. You can change the bar height to customize the difficulty level and desired angle of the row.
HowTo: 1. Set the bar of the Smith machine at a height that allows you to hang underneath it. 2. Grab the bar with one hand and pull your body up towards it, keeping your body straight.

Title: Kettlebell sumo deadlift high pull
Desc: The kettlebell sumo deadlift high pull is a dynamic kettlebell exercise that focuses on the muscles of the posterior chain, including the hamstrings, glutes, traps, rear delts, and upper back. It can be done in lower reps for power or strength, or higher reps for conditioning and fat loss. It can also be a component of a circuit-style kettlebell workout, either for time or reps.
Muscles: hamstrings, glutes, traps, rear delts, upper back
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet in a wide stance, holding a kettlebell between your legs. 2. Perform a deadlift to lift the kettlebell, then pull it up towards your chin in one fluid motion.

Title: Standing dumbbell shrug
Desc: The standing dumbbell shrug is a popular movement to build and strengthen the trapezius muscles. It's often trained on a bodybuilding-style shoulder or back training day, but can also work well in full-body or strength-focused training.
HowTo: 1. Stand upright holding a dumbbell in each hand at your sides. 2. Raise your shoulders towards your ears, squeezing the traps at the top, then lower back down.

Title: Standing dumbbell upright row
Desc: The standing dumbbell upright row is a popular movement for building stronger and bigger traps and shoulders. Many lifters combine this move with either their back or shoulder workout, since it involves both body parts. It is generally performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more.
HowTo: 1. Stand with a dumbbell in each hand at your sides. 2. Pull the dumbbells up towards your chin, keeping them close to your body, then lower them back down.

Title: Dumbbell pull-over
Desc: The dumbbell pull-over is a popular muscle and strength-building exercise that targets the muscles of the chest, upper back, lats, and the serratus anterior. It was a favorite of old-school bodybuilders, who believed high-rep pull-overs helped build a V-taper shape in the torso.
Muscles: chest, upper back, lats, serratus anterior
HowTo: 1. Lie on a bench holding a dumbbell with both hands above your chest. 2. Lower the dumbbell back over your head in an arc, then pull it back to the starting position.

Title: Standing Dumbbell Shrug - Gethin Variation
Desc: The standing dumbbell shrug is a popular movement to build and strengthen the trapezius muscles. Its a often trained on a bodybuilding-style shoulder or back training day, but can also work well in full-body or strength-focused training.
HowTo: Stand upright with a dumbbell in each hand at your sides. Raise your shoulders towards your ears while keeping your arms straight, then lower back down.

Title: Single-arm dumbbell row
Desc: The single-arm dumbbell row is a popular exercise for building the latissimus dorsi, or lat, muscles of the back. It is most often performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per arm or more, as part of a muscle-building upper-body or back-focused portion of a workout.
HowTo: Place one knee and hand on a bench for support, holding a dumbbell in the opposite hand. Pull the dumbbell towards your hip while keeping your elbow close to your body, then lower it back down.

Title: Lying Face Down Plate Neck Resistance
Desc: The lying face down plate neck resistance exercise targets the neck muscles for strength and stability. It is typically performed on a bench with a weight plate.
HowTo: Lie face down on a bench with your head hanging off the edge. Place a weight plate on the back of your head and lift your head up towards the ceiling, then lower it back down.

Title: Lying Face Up Plate Neck Resistance
Desc: The lying face up plate neck resistance exercise focuses on strengthening the neck muscles. It is performed while lying on your back with a weight plate.
HowTo: Lie face up on a bench with your head hanging off the edge. Place a weight plate on your forehead and lift your head towards your chest, then lower it back down.

Title: Seated Head Harness Neck Resistance
Desc: The seated head harness neck resistance exercise is designed to strengthen the neck muscles. It is performed using a head harness attached to weights.
HowTo: Sit on a bench and wear a head harness attached to weights. Slowly nod your head forward and backward, controlling the movement with your neck muscles.

Title: Cable straight-bar upright row
Desc: The cable straight-bar upright row is an isolation exercise for the traps and the medial deltoids. It may not be appropriate for all lifters depending on their shoulder health and injury history. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of an upper-body or shoulder-focused workout.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and grasp the cable straight bar with both hands. 2. Pull the bar straight up towards your chin, keeping your elbows higher than your wrists, then lower it back down.

Title: Cable shrug
Desc: The cable shrug is an exercise targeting the traps, as well as hitting the shoulders and upper back. Cables allow for lighter loading which is beneficial for higher-rep sets.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and grasp the cable handle with both hands. 2. Lift your shoulders towards your ears while keeping your arms straight, then lower them back down.

Title: Smith machine shrug
Desc: The Smith machine shrug is an upper-body exercise targeting the traps (trapezius muscles). It is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of shoulder or trap-focused training.
HowTo: 1. Position yourself under the Smith machine bar with your feet shoulder-width apart. 2. Grasp the bar with both hands and lift your shoulders towards your ears while keeping your arms straight, then lower back down.

Title: Leverage Shrug
Desc: The Leverage Shrug is an exercise targeting the trapezius muscles. It is performed similarly to other shrug variations, focusing on raising the shoulders.
HowTo: 1. Stand in the leverage shrug machine with your back against the pad. 2. Grasp the handles and lift your shoulders towards your ears, then lower them back down.

Title: Calf-Machine Shoulder Shrug
Desc: The Calf-Machine Shoulder Shrug is an exercise that targets the trapezius muscles. It utilizes a calf machine to perform shoulder shrugs effectively.
HowTo: 1. Position yourself in the calf machine with your shoulders under the pads. 2. Lift your shoulders towards your ears while keeping your arms straight, then lower them back down.

Title: Smith machine behind-the-back shrug
Desc: The Smith machine behind-the-back shrug is an upper-body exercise targeting the traps (trapezius muscles). It is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of shoulder or trap-focused training.
HowTo: 1. Stand facing away from the Smith machine with the bar positioned at your back. 2. Grasp the bar with both hands, shoulder-width apart. 3. Lift your shoulders towards your ears while keeping your arms straight. 4. Lower your shoulders back down to the starting position. 5. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Smith machine upright row
Desc: The Smith machine upright row is an upper-body exercise targeting the muscles of the traps and shoulders. This movement is often performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of an upper-body or shoulder-focused workout.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and grasp the Smith machine bar with an overhand grip. 2. Pull the bar straight up towards your chin, keeping it close to your body. 3. Raise your elbows above your shoulders while keeping your wrists straight. 4. Lower the bar back down to the starting position. 5. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Machine low row-
Desc: The machine low row is a popular exercise targeting the back muscles, particularly the lats (latissimus dorsi), rhomboids, and middle and lower trapezius. Machine row variations are often performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of an upper-body or back-focused portion of a workout.
HowTo: 1. Sit at the low row machine with your feet on the platform and knees slightly bent. 2. Grasp the handles with both hands, keeping your back straight. 3. Pull the handles towards your torso, squeezing your shoulder blades together. 4. Slowly return to the starting position. 5. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Machine Shrug - Gethin Variation
Desc: The Machine Shrug - Gethin Variation is a strength exercise that focuses on the trapezius muscles. It is typically performed for moderate to high reps, targeting the upper traps effectively.
HowTo: 1. Sit on the machine with your back against the pad and your feet flat on the ground. 2. Grasp the handles or bar with both hands. 3. Lift your shoulders towards your ears while keeping your arms straight. 4. Hold at the top for a moment, then lower back down. 5. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Smith machine single-arm shrug
Desc: The Smith machine single-arm shrug is an upper-body exercise targeting the traps (trapezius muscles). It is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of shoulder or trap-focused training.
HowTo: 1. Stand next to the Smith machine with one side facing it. 2. Grasp the bar with one hand, positioned at your side. 3. Lift your shoulder towards your ear while keeping your arm straight. 4. Lower your shoulder back down to the starting position. 5. Repeat for the desired number of reps, then switch sides.

Title: Isometric Neck Exercise - Sides
Desc: This exercise focuses on improving flexibility and mobility in the neck. It helps relieve tension and increase range of motion.
HowTo: 1. Sit or stand comfortably with your back straight. 2. Tilt your head to one side, bringing your ear towards your shoulder. 3. Hold the position for a few seconds, then return to the starting position. 4. Repeat on the other side.

Title: Isometric Neck Exercise - Front And Back
Desc: This exercise targets the neck muscles to enhance flexibility and strength. It is beneficial for posture and reducing neck pain.
HowTo: 1. Stand or sit with a straight back. 2. Gently push your head forward and backward, holding each position for a few seconds. 3. Repeat the movement several times, ensuring a controlled motion.

Title: Neck Bridge Prone
Desc: The neck bridge is a strength exercise that targets the neck and upper back. It helps build stability and strength in the cervical region.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back with your knees bent and feet flat on the ground. 2. Lift your hips off the ground, supporting your weight on your head and feet. 3. Hold the position for a few seconds, then lower back down.

Title: Side Neck Stretch
Desc: The side neck stretch helps to alleviate tension and improve flexibility in the neck. It is a gentle exercise that can be performed anywhere.
HowTo: 1. Sit or stand with your back straight. 2. Slowly tilt your head to one side, bringing your ear towards your shoulder. 3. Hold for a few seconds and then switch to the other side.

Title: Neck-SMR
Desc: Neck-SMR (Self-Myofascial Release) helps to release tension in the neck muscles. It can improve blood flow and flexibility.
HowTo: 1. Sit comfortably and use a foam roller or massage ball on the neck area. 2. Apply gentle pressure and roll over the tight areas for 1-2 minutes. 3. Focus on areas that feel tense or sore.

Title: Scapular Pull-Up
Desc: The scapular pull-up is an exercise that focuses on the muscles of the upper back. It helps in strengthening the scapular stabilizers and improving shoulder mobility.
HowTo: 1. Hang from a pull-up bar with your arms fully extended. 2. Without bending your elbows, pull your shoulder blades down and together. 3. Hold for a moment and then return to the starting position.

Title: Single-leg depth squat
Desc: The single-leg depth squat is an exercise targeting the muscles of the lower body, including the quads, glutes, and hamstrings. It is sometimes used as a substitute for the pistol squat, since it doesn't demand the same level of flexibility to perform. It is usually performed for low to moderate reps with a focus on proper form and control.
HowTo: 1. Stand on one leg with the other leg extended in front of you. 2. Lower your body into a squat position while keeping the extended leg off the ground. 3. Push through your heel to return to the starting position.

Title: Squats - With Bands
Desc: Squats with bands add resistance to the traditional squat, enhancing muscle engagement. This exercise is effective for building strength and stability in the lower body.
HowTo: 1. Place a resistance band around your thighs, just above your knees. 2. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. 3. Lower into a squat while pushing your knees outward against the band. 4. Return to standing position.

Title: Hip Flexion with Band
Desc: Hip flexion with a band helps improve flexibility and strength in the hip flexors. It is beneficial for athletes and individuals looking to enhance their mobility.
HowTo: 1. Attach a resistance band to a low anchor point and loop it around your ankle. 2. Stand tall and lift your knee towards your chest against the resistance of the band. 3. Lower your leg back down and repeat.

Title: Forward Band Walk
Desc: The forward band walk is an exercise that targets the glutes and hip abductors while improving lateral movement. It is often used in warm-ups and rehabilitation.
HowTo: 1. Place a resistance band around your legs, just above your knees. 2. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. 3. Take small steps forward while keeping tension on the band. 4. Maintain a slight squat position throughout the movement.

Title: Boss Everline Resistance-Band Pull Sprint
Desc: The Boss Everline Resistance-Band Pull Sprint is an explosive exercise designed to enhance speed and power in the lower body. It utilizes resistance bands to increase the challenge and muscle activation during sprints.
HowTo: 1. Attach a resistance band around your waist and secure the other end to a stationary object. 2. Stand in a sprinting position with your knees slightly bent. 3. Sprint forward against the resistance of the band, driving your knees up and pumping your arms. 4. Maintain a strong core and focus on explosive movements.

Title: Banded jump squat
Desc: The banded jump squat is an explosive bodyweight squat variation performed with a band around the thighs just above the knees. This increases muscle activation in the hips and glutes, while the squat targets the quads, hamstrings, and glutes. The banded jump squat can be performed for low reps as a power-focused exercise, or for higher reps to build muscle in the lower body, challenge conditioning, and burn fat.
HowTo: 1. Place a resistance band around your thighs just above your knees. 2. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. 3. Lower into a squat, keeping your chest up and knees aligned with your toes. 4. Explode upwards into a jump, landing softly back into the squat position.

Title: Speed Box Squat
Desc: The banded barbell box squat is a strength and power exercise targeting the lower body. It is popular in powerlifting training, either performed with light weights as a power and speed exercise, or heavier for strength. It is usually performed to a box of a height that demands the squatter to decent to around parallel.
HowTo: 1. Set a box at a height that allows you to squat to parallel. 2. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and a barbell on your back. 3. Lower yourself onto the box, keeping your back straight and core engaged. 4. Push through your heels to stand back up explosively.

Title: HM Banded Squat Toe Tap
Desc: The HM Banded Squat Toe Tap is a lower body exercise that focuses on strength and stability. It incorporates a band to enhance resistance and muscle engagement during the squat.
HowTo: 1. Place a resistance band around your thighs just above your knees. 2. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. 3. Lower into a squat while tapping one foot out to the side. 4. Return to the starting position and repeat on the other side.

Title: UP Band Abducted Squat
Desc: The UP Band Abducted Squat is designed to enhance lower body strength and stability. It utilizes a resistance band to increase the challenge during the squat movement.
HowTo: 1. Place a resistance band around your thighs just above your knees. 2. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. 3. Lower into a squat while pushing your knees outward against the band. 4. Hold the squat position briefly before returning to standing.

Title: FYR2 Lateral Band Walk
Desc: The FYR2 Lateral Band Walk is an exercise that targets the lower body, particularly the glutes and outer thighs. It is often used for strengthening and activating the hip muscles.
HowTo: 1. Place a resistance band around your legs, just above your knees. 2. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and slightly bend your knees. 3. Step to the side with one foot, followed by the other, maintaining tension in the band. 4. Continue stepping sideways for a set distance or number of steps.

Title: FYR2 Banded Squat Hold-Pulse-Jump Complex
Desc: The FYR2 Banded Squat Hold-Pulse-Jump Complex is designed to enhance lower body strength and power. It combines a squat hold with pulsing and jumping movements to increase intensity.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart and place a band around your thighs. 2. Lower into a squat position, holding it at parallel. 3. Perform small pulses in the squat for a set number of reps. 4. From the squat, explode upward into a jump, landing softly back into the squat position.

Title: Band split squat
Desc: The band split squat is a band movement targeting the quads, glutes, and hamstrings. It can be performed either for time or reps, and is often included as part of a fat-loss or athleticism-focused circuit workout. Leaning back places more emphasis on the glutes and hamstrings, while standing straight up targets the quads.
HowTo: 1. Stand with one foot forward and the other foot back, with a band under the front foot and held at shoulder height. 2. Lower your back knee towards the ground while keeping your front knee over your ankle. 3. Push through the front heel to return to the starting position. 4. Repeat for the desired number of reps before switching legs.

Title: Band front squat
Desc: The band front squat is a popular exercise for targeting the muscles of the lower body, including the quadriceps, glutes, and hamstrings. Holding band in the racked position also works the core and upper-back muscles to maintain posture while the lower body moves. Because the tension of the band changes as it stretches, the resistance more closely matches the natural strength curve of the squat. This movement is usually performed for moderate to high reps, at least 8-12 reps per set or more. If this movement hurts your knees, try performing it with a wider stance.
Muscles: quads, glutes, hamstrings, core, upper back
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and hold a band in the racked position at your shoulders. 2. Lower your body into a squat while keeping your chest up and back straight. 3. Push through your heels to return to the starting position. 4. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Squat hold with band pull-apart
Desc: The squat hold with band pull-apart is a combination of the squat hold and band pull-apart. It involves holding the squat position with the thighs at or below parallel to the ground while performing a band pull-apart. The band pull-apart is an exercise targeting the upper back muscles, including the trapezius, rear delts, and rhomboids. The squat hold band pull-apart can be performed for mobility purposes or to increase time under tension on lower-body muscles including the quads, glutes, and hamstrings.
HowTo: 1. Get into a squat position with your thighs parallel to the ground and hold it. 2. While in the squat, hold a band with both hands in front of you. 3. Pull the band apart by extending your arms out to the sides, squeezing your shoulder blades together. 4. Hold for a few seconds before returning to the starting position.

Title: Banded squat toe tap
Desc: The banded squat toe tap is a banded variation on the classic bodyweight squat, but with a lateral toe tap to add extra focus to the stabilizer muscles around the hips. It can be performed for time or for reps as part of a dynamic warm-up for the lower body, or in any lower-body portion of a workout.
HowTo: 1. Start in a standing position with a resistance band around your thighs. 2. Lower into a squat while tapping one foot out to the side, alternating sides.

Title: Band overhead squat
Desc: The band overhead squat is a full-body, functional movement that works to build full-body strength and stability. It is a variation of the classic barbell exercise and can be used to train core strength and stability for Olympic weightlifting or CrossFit.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and a band overhead. 2. Lower into a squat while keeping the band extended overhead, then return to standing.

Title: Quadriceps SMR
Desc: Quadriceps self-myofascial release (SMR) is a self-administered soft-tissue treatment for the lower body, usually using a foam roller, lacrosse ball, or other "trigger point" massage tool. By applying pressure strategically to the quad muscles of the upper leg, some people find they can cause this often painful and tight muscle group to relax or "release." Quadriceps SMR is often accompanied by SMR on the calf, glute, or hip muscles, or by stretches that target the calves or quads.
HowTo: 1. Sit on the floor with a foam roller under your thighs. 2. Roll back and forth over the roller to apply pressure to the quads.

Title: Clean from Blocks
Desc: The clean from blocks is a weightlifting exercise that focuses on the explosive movement of lifting a barbell from a raised position. It develops strength and power in the legs and back.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and a barbell on blocks in front of you. 2. Bend at the hips and knees to grip the bar, then explosively lift it to your shoulders.

Title: Barbell Full Squat
Desc: The barbell back squat is a popular compound movement that emphasizes building the lower-body muscle groups and overall strength. It's the classic way to start a leg day, and is a worthy centerpiece to a lower-body training program. The squat is a competitive lift in the sport of powerlifting, but is also a classic measurement of lower-body strength. With the barbell racked on the traps or upper back, the emphasis is placed on the posterior chain but the entire body gets worked. The back squat can be trained in everything from heavy singles to sets of 20 reps or higher.
HowTo: 1. Position a barbell on your upper back and stand with feet shoulder-width apart. 2. Lower your body into a squat, keeping your chest up and back straight, then push through your heels to return to standing.

Title: Barbell back squat to box
Desc: The barbell back squat to box is a popular version of a classic lower-body exercise that utilizes a box at the bottom position of the movement. This allows the lifter to customize the depth of the squat, as well as limit the stretch reflex at the bottom of the squat. The movement targets the quadriceps, glutes, and hamstrings. The squat to box can be performed for low reps to build strength or power, or for higher reps to build muscle.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and a barbell on your upper back. 2. Sit back into your hips and lower your body until your thighs are parallel to the box, then push through your heels to return to standing.

Title: Push-press
Desc: The push-press is an overhead press variation in which the barbell is pushed upward with assistance from the lower body. This "push" helps the weight travel through the sticking point of a strict press. The push-press is commonly performed as part of barbell complexes, power training for all types of athletics, or as a powerful shoulder exercise.
HowTo: 1. Start with the barbell at shoulder height, feet shoulder-width apart. 2. Dip slightly by bending your knees, then explosively extend your legs while pressing the barbell overhead.

Title: Power snatch-
Desc: The power snatch is a full-body lift in which the bar is pulled from the floor with a wide grip to the overhead position in one movement. The bar is received in the "power" position, with the hips higher than a full-depth squat position. The power snatch can be used as a learning tool for the full snatch, or to train muscular power and strength on its own. It is usually performed for low reps, focusing on power and movement quality.
HowTo: 1. Start with the barbell on the floor, feet hip-width apart, and grip the bar with a wide grip. 2. Pull the bar explosively from the floor to your hips, then drive it overhead in one fluid motion.

Title: Hang Clean
Desc: The hang clean is a dynamic full-body exercise that focuses on pulling the barbell from the hang position to the shoulders. It develops power, strength, and coordination.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and the barbell at your thighs. 2. Dip slightly at the knees, then explosively extend your hips and pull the barbell to your shoulders.

Title: Barbell walking lunge
Desc: The barbell walking lunge tests your ability to maintain balance while challenging the quads, glutes, and hamstrings as well as the core muscles. Using a barbell allows you to overload the exercise. It can be performed for moderate reps, such as 8-15 per set or across the gym, or for higher reps as a conditioning and mental toughness challenge.
HowTo: 1. Stand upright with a barbell resting on your shoulders. 2. Step forward into a lunge, lowering your back knee toward the ground, then push back to the starting position.

Title: Olympic Squat
Desc: The Olympic squat is a fundamental strength exercise that primarily targets the lower body. It is performed with a barbell on the shoulders and involves squatting down to a depth where the hips are below the knees.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and the barbell resting on your upper back. 2. Keep your chest up and core engaged. 3. Lower your body by bending at the knees and hips, keeping your back straight. 4. Go down until your thighs are at least parallel to the ground. 5. Push through your heels to return to the starting position.

Title: Narrow-stance squat
Desc: The narrow-stance squat is an exercise that targets the lower body with an emphasis on the quads. Many people will find they can't go as deep in a narrow-stance squat as with a wider squat, which is normal. The narrow-stance squat can be performed for time or reps in any workout.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet closer together than shoulder-width. 2. Keep your chest up and core tight. 3. Lower your body by bending your knees and hips, keeping your back straight. 4. Go down until your thighs are at least parallel to the ground. 5. Push through your heels to return to the starting position.

Title: Box Squat with Bands
Desc: The Box Squat with Bands is a variation of the squat that adds resistance through bands. This exercise helps improve strength and power in the lower body.
HowTo: 1. Set up a box behind you at an appropriate height. 2. Attach resistance bands to a barbell and place the barbell on your upper back. 3. Stand in front of the box with your feet shoulder-width apart. 4. Lower your body by bending your knees and hips until you sit on the box. 5. Pause briefly, then push through your heels to stand back up.

Title: Weighted Jump Squat
Desc: The Weighted Jump Squat is an explosive exercise that combines strength and power training. It targets the lower body while improving overall athletic performance.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a dumbbell or kettlebell at chest level. 2. Lower into a squat position. 3. Explode upward, jumping as high as you can. 4. Land softly and immediately go into the next squat.

Title: Squat with Chains
Desc: The Squat with Chains is a variation that adds accommodating resistance to the squat. This exercise helps build strength and power in the lower body.
HowTo: 1. Set up a barbell on your upper back with chains hanging down. 2. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. 3. Lower your body into a squat, keeping your back straight. 4. Go down until your thighs are at least parallel to the ground. 5. Push through your heels to return to the starting position, allowing the chains to lift off the ground.

Title: Barbell Squat
Desc: The barbell back squat is a popular compound movement that emphasizes building the lower-body muscle groups and overall strength. It's the classic way to start a leg day, and is a worthy centerpiece to a lower-body training program. The squat is a competitive lift in the sport of powerlifting, but is also a classic measurement of lower-body strength. With the barbell racked on the traps or upper back, the emphasis is placed on the posterior chain but the entire body gets worked. The back squat can be trained in everything from heavy singles to sets of 20 reps or higher.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, barbell racked on your upper back. 2. Lower your body by bending your knees and hips, keeping your chest up and back straight. 3. Go down until your thighs are parallel to the ground, then push through your heels to return to the starting position.

Title: Barbell front squat
Desc: The barbell front squat is a compound movement that emphasizes building the lower-body muscle groups. With the barbell racked in front of the body on the anterior delts, the front squat emphasizes the quads and glutes, but also upper back and core strength to remain upright. Front squats can be trained as an alternative to back squats, as an accessory movement for either squats or deadlifts, or for strength and muscle on their own. Many lifters and athletes prefer them to back squats, although they can be uncomfortable and difficult to learn at first.
Muscles: quads, glutes, hamstrings, core, upper back
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, barbell racked on your front shoulders. 2. Lower your body by bending your knees and hips, keeping your chest upright. 3. Go down until your thighs are parallel to the ground, then push through your heels to return to the starting position.

Title: Barbell forward lunge
Desc: The barbell forward lunge is a popular lower-body exercise targeting the quads, glutes, and hamstrings. Using a barbell allows you to overload the exercise beyond body weight and perform the movement in strength or muscle-focused rep ranges. The forward lunge can be performed as part of a barbell complex, in a circuit, or on its own in the lower-body portion of any workout.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet together, holding a barbell across your shoulders. 2. Step forward with one leg, lowering your hips until both knees are bent at about a 90-degree angle. 3. Push back to the starting position and repeat on the other leg.

Title: Smith machine box squat
Desc: The Smith machine box squat is a machine-based exercise targeting the quads, glutes, and hamstrings. The Smith machine mimics a barbell but provides more stability. This movement can be programmed in low reps for strength or power or higher reps for muscle and strength endurance. It is often performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of a full-body or lower-body workout.
HowTo: 1. Position a box behind you and set the Smith machine bar at shoulder height. 2. Stand in front of the box with your feet shoulder-width apart, barbell on your shoulders. 3. Lower your body to sit back onto the box, then push through your heels to return to standing.

Title: Barbell step-up
Desc: The barbell step-up is a great exercise for building lower-body strength and power. It targets all the same muscles as bodyweight step-ups, such as the quads, glutes, and hamstrings, but allows for greater muscular overload.
HowTo: 1. Stand in front of a bench or step with a barbell across your shoulders. 2. Step up onto the bench with one foot, pushing through your heel to lift your body up. 3. Step back down and repeat on the other leg.

Title: Barbell Bulgarian split squat
Desc: The barbell Bulgarian split squat is a single-leg exercise targeting the quads, glutes, and hamstrings. It is easier to overload with the barbell than when using dumbbells. If balance is an issue, consider using a Smith machine or holding dumbbells at your side instead.
HowTo: 1. Stand a few feet in front of a bench with a barbell resting on your shoulders. 2. Step one foot back onto the bench, lowering your body until your front thigh is parallel to the ground. 3. Push through your front heel to return to the starting position.

Title: Hang Clean - Below the Knees
Desc: The hang clean - below the knees is a dynamic exercise that focuses on building explosive power and strength throughout the body, particularly in the legs and shoulders.
HowTo: 1. Start with the barbell just below your knees, feet shoulder-width apart. 2. Engage your core and pull the barbell up explosively, extending your hips and knees. 3. As the bar reaches your chest, rotate your elbows under the bar and catch it in a front rack position.

Title: Barbell hack squat
Desc: The barbell hack squat is a variety of deadlift performed with the barbell behind the legs. This forces the lifter into a body position similar to a squat and targets the quads and glutes. It is named after famed strongman George Hackenschmidt, who performed it as an overall leg-building exercise. The barbell hack squat can be used as a substitute for the machine hack squat, or as a lower-body strength and size movement on its own.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and the barbell positioned behind your legs. 2. Bend at your hips and knees to lower your body while keeping your back straight. 3. Drive through your heels to lift the barbell back to the starting position.

Title: Hack Squat
Desc: The hack squat is a machine-based exercise that targets the muscles of the legs, particularly the quadriceps. It is often used as an accessory for squats, but can also be the main lower-body movement in a workout. It is often performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more.
HowTo: 1. Position yourself on the hack squat machine with your back against the pad and feet shoulder-width apart on the platform. 2. Lower your body by bending your knees until your thighs are parallel to the ground. 3. Push through your heels to return to the starting position.

Title: Barbell thruster
Desc: The barbell thruster is a full-body exercise that incorporates both squatting and pressing in one functional movement. It's especially common in contemporary CrossFit workouts, but also in general strength training. The barbell is usually cleaned into place first, but it could be performed taken from a squat rack in a front-rack position. The thruster can be performed in traditional strength-focused rep ranges to build strength in the press, or in higher reps for full-body conditioning.
HowTo: 1. Start with the barbell at shoulder height, feet shoulder-width apart. 2. Lower into a squat while keeping the barbell in the front rack position. 3. As you rise from the squat, press the barbell overhead until your arms are fully extended.

Title: Split Jerk
Desc: The Split Jerk is a dynamic weightlifting movement that requires coordination and strength. It is performed by driving the barbell overhead while splitting the legs into a lunge position.
HowTo: 1. Start with the barbell in the front rack position. 2. Dip down slightly by bending your knees. 3. Explode upwards, pushing the barbell overhead. 4. Split your legs into a lunge position as you catch the bar overhead. 5. Stand up straight to complete the lift.

Title: Push-jerk
Desc: The push-jerk is a movement in which the barbell is pushed from the front rack position to overhead with help from the legs. It differs from the push-press in that the lifter dips under the bar rather than simply pushing it up. It is popular in CrossFit workouts and Olympic weightlifting, as well as power training for athletics. It is usually performed for low reps, focusing on power and movement quality.
HowTo: 1. Start with the barbell in the front rack position. 2. Dip down slightly by bending your knees. 3. Explode upwards and push the barbell overhead. 4. Dip under the bar to catch it overhead. 5. Stand up straight to complete the lift.

Title: Barbell back squat
Desc: The barbell back squat is a popular compound movement that emphasizes building the lower-body muscle groups and overall strength. It's the classic way to start a leg day, and is a worthy centerpiece to a lower-body training program. The squat is a competitive lift in the sport of powerlifting, but is also a classic measurement of lower-body strength. With the barbell racked on the traps or upper back, the emphasis is placed on the posterior chain but the entire body gets worked. The back squat can be trained in everything from heavy singles to sets of 20 reps or higher.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and the barbell on your upper back. 2. Lower your body by bending your knees and hips, keeping your chest up. 3. Go down until your thighs are at least parallel to the ground. 4. Push through your heels to return to the starting position.

Title: Zercher squat
Desc: The Zercher squat is a barbell exercise in which the bar is placed in the crease of your elbows as you perform a normal squat. This movement can be awkward at first but is extremely effective in building both size and strength.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and the barbell in the crease of your elbows. 2. Lower your body by bending your knees and hips, keeping your chest up. 3. Go down until your thighs are at least parallel to the ground. 4. Push through your heels to return to the starting position.

Title: Jefferson Squats
Desc: Jefferson Squats are a unique squat variation that targets the lower body while also engaging the core. They can help improve flexibility and strength in the legs.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and the barbell positioned between your legs. 2. Squat down to grab the bar with one hand on each side. 3. Keep your chest up and back straight as you lift the bar. 4. Stand up straight, then lower back down to complete the rep.

Title: Jerk Dip Squat
Desc: The Jerk Dip Squat is a dynamic movement that combines a dip and a squat to enhance strength and power in the lower body. It is often used in Olympic weightlifting training.
HowTo: 1. Start with the barbell on your shoulders. 2. Perform a dip by bending your knees slightly. 3. As you dip, squat down into a full squat position. 4. Drive through your heels to return to standing.

Title: Barbell side split squat
Desc: The barbell side split squat is a variation of the split squat that targets the lower body, specifically the quads, and requires good hip mobility.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet wider than shoulder-width apart. 2. Hold a barbell across your upper back. 3. Shift your weight to one side and squat down while keeping the other leg straight. 4. Push through your heel to return to the starting position.

Title: Frankenstein Squat
Desc: The Frankenstein Squat is a front-loaded squat that emphasizes core stability and leg strength. It is named for the arm position, which resembles that of Frankenstein's monster.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and hold a barbell across your shoulders with your arms extended forward. 2. Squat down by bending your knees and pushing your hips back. 3. Keep your chest up and core tight. 4. Return to standing by pushing through your heels.

Title: Barbell speed squat
Desc: The barbell speed squat targets the lower-body muscle groups using lighter weights to perform fast-paced back squats. Speed squats are popular in certain powerlifting training methodologies as a way to engrain form and lifting speed that can carry over to max-effort lifts. In this approach, they are usually performed in numerous sets of 3-5 reps with adequate rest in between. Speed squats are also sometimes performed with bands or chains adding extra resistance to the top half of the lift.
HowTo: 1. Set up a barbell on your upper back and stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. 2. Lower into a squat quickly while maintaining form. 3. Drive up explosively through your heels to return to standing. 4. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Single-arm side deadlift
Desc: The single-arm side deadlift is a compound exercise that strengthens the glutes, quads, hamstrings, back, and core. It has more of a core stability and anti-rotational component than other deadlift variations. The side deadlift is usually done for low to moderate reps, such as 5-8 reps per side, with a focus on posture and movement quality.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and hold a dumbbell in one hand. 2. Shift your weight to the opposite leg and hinge at the hips to lower the dumbbell towards the ground. 3. Keep your back straight and core engaged. 4. Return to standing by driving through your heel.

Title: Barbell Squat To A Bench
Desc: The barbell back squat to box takes a classic compound exercise for developing the lower body and adds the box element. Muscles worked include the quads, hips, glutes, and upper hamstrings.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and the barbell on your back. 2. Lower your body by bending your knees and hips until your thighs are parallel to the ground or until you touch the box. 3. Push through your heels to return to the starting position.

Title: Clean Pull
Desc: The clean pull is a powerful movement that focuses on developing strength and explosiveness in the posterior chain.
HowTo: 1. Start with your feet hip-width apart and the barbell over your mid-foot. 2. Bend at the hips and knees to grip the barbell. 3. Pull the barbell up while extending your hips and knees, keeping it close to your body. 4. Finish with your shoulders over the bar and your hips extended.

Title: Front Barbell Squat To A Bench
Desc: The front barbell squat to a bench is a variation of the squat that emphasizes the quads and requires good mobility.
HowTo: 1. Position the barbell on your front shoulders and stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. 2. Lower your body by bending your knees and hips until your thighs are parallel to the ground or until you touch the bench. 3. Push through your heels to return to the starting position.

Title: Barbell reverse lunge
Desc: The barbell reverse lunge is a popular lower-body exercise targeting the quads, glutes, and hamstrings. Using a barbell allows you to overload the exercise beyond body weight and perform the movement in strength or muscle-focused rep ranges. The reverse lunge can be performed as part of a barbell complex, in a circuit, or on its own in the lower-body portion of any workout.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and hold a barbell across your upper back. 2. Step back with one leg and lower your body until your front thigh is parallel to the ground. 3. Push through your front heel to return to the starting position and switch legs.

Title: Split Clean
Desc: The split clean is an explosive movement that combines a clean and a split position, targeting multiple muscle groups.
HowTo: 1. Start with your feet hip-width apart and the barbell over your mid-foot. 2. Pull the barbell up while extending your hips and knees, then drop into a split stance as you catch the barbell on your shoulders. 3. Stand up from the split position to complete the lift.

Title: Close-stance dumbbell front squat
Desc: The close-stance dumbbell front squat is a popular exercise for targeting the muscles of the lower body, the quadriceps in particular. Holding dumbbells in the racked position also works the core and upper-back muscles to maintain posture while the lower body moves. Because the amount of weight you can use will be limited by what you can clean to the rack position, this movement is usually performed for moderate to high reps, at least 8-12 reps per set or more. If this movement hurts your knees, try performing it with a wider stance.
Muscles: Quadriceps, Hamstrings, Glutes, Core, Upper Back
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet close together, holding dumbbells in the racked position. 2. Squat down by bending your knees and hips, keeping your chest up and back straight. 3. Lower until your thighs are parallel to the ground, then push through your heels to return to standing.

Title: Front Squat (Clean Grip)
Desc: The front squat (clean grip) is a variation of the squat that emphasizes the quadriceps and core stability. It requires a clean grip on the barbell, which helps improve upper body posture and strength.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, holding a barbell in the clean grip position across your shoulders. 2. Keep your elbows high and chest up as you squat down, pushing your knees out. 3. Lower until your thighs are parallel to the ground, then push through your heels to return to standing.

Title: Barbell front squat to back squat
Desc: The barbell front squat to back squat is a complex that combines two fundamental barbell squat movements with a press in between to build overall strength, coordination, and endurance. This combo hits every muscle in the lower body, but also seriously challenges the upper-body musculature to control and transition the weight.
HowTo: 1. Begin with a barbell on your shoulders in a front squat position. 2. Perform a front squat, then transition to a back squat by shifting the barbell to your back. 3. Complete the back squat and return the barbell to the front position for the next rep.

Title: Squat Jerk
Desc: The squat jerk is a dynamic movement that combines a squat with an overhead press. It requires explosive strength and coordination to lift the barbell from a squat position to overhead.
HowTo: 1. Start with the barbell on your shoulders in a front rack position. 2. Perform a squat while simultaneously pressing the barbell overhead. 3. Stand up from the squat while keeping the barbell locked out overhead.

Title: Barbell Front-To-Back Squat
Desc: The barbell front squat to back squat is a complex that combines two fundamental barbell squat movements with a press in between to build overall strength, coordination, and endurance. This combo hits every muscle in the lower body, but also seriously challenges the upper-body musculature to control and transition the weight.
HowTo: 1. Begin with a barbell on your shoulders in a front squat position. 2. Perform a front squat, then transition to a back squat by shifting the barbell to your back. 3. Complete the back squat and return the barbell to the front position for the next rep.

Title: Box Squat with Chains
Desc: The Box Squat with Chains is a variation of the squat that incorporates chains to add resistance. This exercise primarily targets the lower body while also engaging the core for stability.
HowTo: 1. Set up a box at the appropriate height behind you. 2. Attach chains to the barbell to provide variable resistance. 3. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and the barbell on your back. 4. Lower yourself to sit on the box, keeping your chest up and back straight. 5. Push through your heels to stand back up, engaging your glutes and quads.

Title: Snatch from Blocks
Desc: The Snatch from Blocks is a dynamic Olympic weightlifting movement that develops explosive strength and power. It requires coordination and technique to lift the barbell from a stationary position.
HowTo: 1. Set the barbell on blocks at knee height. 2. Stand with your feet hip-width apart and grip the barbell with a wide grip. 3. Initiate the lift by extending your hips and knees while pulling the barbell upward. 4. As the bar reaches your hips, explosively extend your body and pull yourself under the bar. 5. Catch the bar overhead with arms fully extended, then stand up.

Title: Power Snatch from Blocks
Desc: The Power Snatch from Blocks is similar to the Snatch but focuses on generating maximum power from a stationary position. This exercise is crucial for developing explosive strength.
HowTo: 1. Position the barbell on blocks at knee height. 2. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart and grip the bar with a wide grip. 3. Start the lift by driving through your legs and extending your hips. 4. Pull the barbell upward explosively, keeping it close to your body. 5. Drop under the bar and catch it overhead with arms extended, then stand.

Title: Front Squat (Bodybuilder)
Desc: The barbell front squat is a compound movement that emphasizes building the lower-body muscle groups. With the barbell racked in front of the body on the anterior delts, the front squat emphasizes the quads and glutes, but also upper back and core strength to remain upright. Front squats can be trained as an alternative to back squats, as an accessory movement for either squats or deadlifts, or for strength and muscle on their own. Many lifters and athletes prefer them to back squats, although they can be uncomfortable and difficult to learn at first.
Muscles: Quads, Glutes, Hamstrings, Core, Upper Back
HowTo: 1. Rack the barbell on your anterior deltoids with your elbows high. 2. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. 3. Lower your body by bending your knees and hips, keeping your chest up and back straight. 4. Go down until your thighs are parallel to the ground. 5. Push through your heels to return to the starting position.

Title: Barbell step-down reverse lunge
Desc: The barbell step-down reverse lunge is an exercise targeting the lower body, particularly the glutes and hamstrings. The front foot is slightly elevated during this movement, making the subsequent step-down more pronounced and difficult. These are usually performed for time or for relatively high reps, such as 10 reps or more per set.
HowTo: 1. Stand on an elevated surface with a barbell on your back. 2. Step back with one leg, lowering your body into a lunge. 3. Ensure your front knee does not go past your toes. 4. Push through your front heel to return to the starting position. 5. Alternate legs and repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Squat with Bands
Desc: The squat with bands adds resistance to the traditional squat, enhancing strength and stability. It targets the lower body while also engaging the core.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart and place a resistance band under your feet and over your shoulders. 2. Lower your body into a squat by bending your knees and pushing your hips back. 3. Keep your chest up and back straight. 4. Push through your heels to return to the starting position.

Title: Heaving Snatch Balance
Desc: The heaving snatch balance is a dynamic movement that combines a snatch and a squat. It improves strength, coordination, and stability.
HowTo: 1. Start with the barbell on your shoulders, feet hip-width apart. 2. Dip slightly by bending your knees and then explosively extend your hips while pushing the bar overhead. 3. As the bar moves up, drop into a squat position to catch it. 4. Stand up to complete the lift.

Title: Snatch Balance
Desc: The snatch balance is a weightlifting exercise that develops speed and coordination. It is essential for improving the overhead squat position.
HowTo: 1. Begin with the barbell on your shoulders, feet shoulder-width apart. 2. Dip slightly and then explosively extend your hips while pushing the bar overhead. 3. As the bar travels upward, drop into a squat to catch it. 4. Stand up to finish the movement.

Title: Reverse Band Power Squat
Desc: The reverse band power squat reduces the weight at the bottom of the squat, allowing for greater depth and strength development. It is useful for building strength in the squat pattern.
HowTo: 1. Set up a barbell on your back and attach bands to the bar and the floor. 2. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart and lower into a squat. 3. The bands will assist you at the bottom, allowing you to push back up. 4. Focus on maintaining good form throughout the movement.

Title: Paul Carter Back Squat
Desc: The barbell back squat is a popular compound movement that emphasizes building the lower-body muscle groups and overall strength. It's the classic way to start a leg day, and is a worthy centerpiece to a lower-body training program.
