The squat is a competitive lift in the sport of powerlifting, but is also a classic measurement of lower-body strength. With the barbell racked on the traps or upper back, the emphasis is placed on the posterior chain but the entire body gets worked. The back squat can be trained in everything from heavy singles to sets of 20 reps or higher.
HowTo: 1. Position the barbell on your upper back and stand with feet shoulder-width apart. 2. Lower your body by bending your knees and pushing your hips back. 3. Keep your chest up and back straight as you descend. 4. Push through your heels to return to the starting position.

Title: Paul Carter Barbell Split Squat
Desc: The barbell Bulgarian split squat is a single-leg, full-body exercise targeting the quads, glutes, and hamstrings. It is easier to overload with the barbell as opposed to using dumbbells.
HowTo: 1. Stand with a barbell on your back, feet shoulder-width apart. 2. Step back into a split stance, lower your back knee towards the ground while keeping your front knee aligned over your ankle, then push through your front heel to return to standing.

Title: TBS High-Bar Back Squat
Desc: The barbell back squat is a popular compound movement that emphasizes building the lower-body muscle groups and overall strength. It's the classic way to start a leg day, and is a worthy centerpiece to a lower-body training program. The squat is a competitive lift in the sport of powerlifting, but is also a classic measurement of lower-body strength. With the barbell racked on the traps or upper back, the emphasis is placed on the posterior chain but the entire body gets worked. The back squat can be trained in everything from heavy singles to sets of 20 reps or higher.
HowTo: 1. Stand with a barbell racked on your upper back. 2. Lower your body by bending your knees and hips until your thighs are at least parallel to the ground, then push through your heels to return to standing.

Title: TBS Barbell Front Squat
Desc: The barbell front squat is a compound movement that emphasizes building the lower-body muscle groups. With the barbell racked in front of the body on the anterior delts, the front squat emphasizes the quads and glutes, but also upper back and core strength to remain upright. Front squats can be trained as an alternative to back squats, as an accessory movement for either squats or deadlifts, or for strength and muscle on their own. Many lifters and athletes prefer them to back squats, although they can be uncomfortable and difficult to learn at first.
HowTo: 1. Stand with a barbell racked on your front shoulders. 2. Lower your body by bending your knees and hips, keeping your torso upright, then push through your heels to return to standing.

Title: Squat - Gethin Variation
Desc: The barbell back squat is a popular compound movement that emphasizes building the lower-body muscle groups and overall strength. It's the classic way to start a leg day, and is a worthy centerpiece to a lower-body training program. The squat is a competitive lift in the sport of powerlifting, but is also a classic measurement of lower-body strength. With the barbell racked on the traps or upper back, the emphasis is placed on the posterior chain but the entire body gets worked. The back squat can be trained in everything from heavy singles to sets of 20 reps or higher.
HowTo: 1. Stand with a barbell racked on your upper back. 2. Lower your body by bending your knees and hips until your thighs are at least parallel to the ground, then push through your heels to return to standing.

Title: Front-To-Back Barbell Squat
Desc: The front-to-back barbell squat is a variation that targets the lower body while also engaging the core for stability. It combines elements of both front and back squats for a comprehensive leg workout.
HowTo: 1. Start with a barbell on your upper back, feet shoulder-width apart. 2. Perform a squat, then transition into a front squat position by moving the barbell to the front, and continue squatting, alternating between the two positions.

Title: Barbell Lunge - Gethin Variation
Desc: The barbell forward lunge is a popular lower-body exercise targeting the quads, glutes, and hamstrings. Using a barbell allows you to overload the exercise beyond body weight and perform the movement in strength or muscle-focused rep ranges. The forward lunge can be performed as part of a barbell complex, in a circuit, or on its own in the lower-body portion of any workout.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a barbell across your upper back. 2. Step forward with one leg, lowering your body until your front thigh is parallel to the ground. 3. Push through your front heel to return to the starting position. 4. Alternate legs for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Rack Deadlift - Gethin Variation
Desc: The rack pull is a variation of the deadlift performed from an elevated height, either using boxes, safety pins, or the safeties in a squat rack. It targets all the same muscles as the deadlift, including the glutes, hamstrings, upper back, lower back, and grip. It can e used to strengthen deadlift lockout, but also as a deadlift alternative for people who cant deadlift from the floor without pain.
Muscles: Glutes, Hamstrings, Upper Back, Lower Back
HowTo: 1. Set the barbell on safety pins or boxes at knee height. 2. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, gripping the barbell with both hands. 3. Lift the barbell by extending your hips and knees until you are standing upright. 4. Lower the barbell back to the starting position with control.

Title: Barbell Squat - Gethin Variation
Desc: The barbell back squat is a popular compound movement that emphasizes building the lower-body muscle groups and overall strength. It's the classic way to start a leg day, and is a worthy centerpiece to a lower-body training program. The squat is a competitive lift in the sport of powerlifting, but is also a classic measurement of lower-body strength. With the barbell racked on the traps or upper back, the emphasis is placed on the posterior chain but the entire body gets worked. The back squat can be trained in everything from heavy singles to sets of 20 reps or higher.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, barbell resting on your upper back. 2. Lower your body by bending your knees and hips, keeping your chest up and back straight. 3. Go down until your thighs are at least parallel to the ground. 4. Push through your heels to return to the starting position.

Title: Barbell Good Morning - Gethin Variation
Desc: The barbell good morning is an exercise that targets glute, hamstring, and lower back development. It is often trained as an accessory movement to the deadlift, but also has value on its own. It is sometimes performed for reps in traditional strength-focused rep ranges such as 5-8 reps per set, but due to the risk posed to the lower back, is rarely treated as a max-effort single-rep lift.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a barbell across your upper back. 2. Hinge at your hips, bending slightly at the knees, and lower your torso until it's nearly parallel to the ground. 3. Keep your back straight and core engaged. 4. Return to the starting position by driving your hips forward.

Title: AM Barbell Squat
Desc: The barbell back squat is a popular compound movement that emphasizes building the lower-body muscle groups and overall strength. It's the classic way to start a leg day, and is a worthy centerpiece to a lower-body training program. The squat is a competitive lift in the sport of powerlifting, but is also a classic measurement of lower-body strength. With the barbell racked on the traps or upper back, the emphasis is placed on the posterior chain but the entire body gets worked. The back squat can be trained in everything from heavy singles to sets of 20 reps or higher.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, barbell resting on your upper back. 2. Lower your body by bending your knees and hips, keeping your chest up and back straight. 3. Go down until your thighs are at least parallel to the ground. 4. Push through your heels to return to the starting position.

Title: Plyometric Power Clean
Desc: The Plyometric Power Clean is a dynamic exercise that combines strength and speed, focusing on explosive power development. It is commonly used in athletic training to enhance performance in sports.
HowTo: 1. Start with the barbell on the ground. 2. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. 3. Bend at the hips and knees to grip the barbell. 4. Explosively extend your hips and knees, pulling the barbell upward. 5. As the bar reaches your chest, drop under it and catch it in a front squat position. 6. Stand up to complete the lift.

Title: Banded Split Jerk
Desc: The Banded Split Jerk is a variation of the split jerk that incorporates resistance bands to enhance strength and stability. It is effective for developing explosive power in the legs and shoulders.
HowTo: 1. Set up a barbell at shoulder height with resistance bands attached. 2. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and grip the barbell. 3. Dip slightly by bending your knees. 4. Explode upward, driving the barbell overhead while splitting your legs. 5. Lock your arms and stabilize the position. 6. Return to the starting position.

Title: UP Squat
Desc: The barbell back squat is a popular compound movement that emphasizes building the lower-body muscle groups and overall strength. It's the classic way to start a leg day, and is a worthy centerpiece to a lower-body training program. The squat is a competitive lift in the sport of powerlifting, but is also a classic measurement of lower-body strength. With the barbell racked on the traps or upper back, the emphasis is placed on the posterior chain but the entire body gets worked. The back squat can be trained in everything from heavy singles to sets of 20 reps or higher.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and the barbell on your upper back. 2. Lower your body by bending your knees and pushing your hips back. 3. Keep your chest up and back straight. 4. Go down until your thighs are parallel to the ground. 5. Push through your heels to return to the starting position.

Title: UN Barbell Back Squat
Desc: The UN Barbell Back Squat is a classic strength exercise that builds muscle and strength in the lower body. It is a staple in many strength training programs.
HowTo: 1. Position the barbell on your upper back and stand with feet shoulder-width apart. 2. Lower your body by bending your knees and hips. 3. Keep your back straight and chest up. 4. Go down until your thighs are parallel to the ground. 5. Push through your heels to return to the starting position.

Title: UN Barbell Box Squat
Desc: The UN Barbell Box Squat is a variation of the squat that emphasizes proper form and depth control. It is beneficial for developing strength and power in the legs.
HowTo: 1. Set a box behind you at an appropriate height. 2. Position the barbell on your upper back. 3. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. 4. Lower your body by bending your knees and hips until you sit back onto the box. 5. Pause briefly, then push through your heels to stand back up.

Title: UN Barbell Front Squat
Desc: The UN Barbell Front Squat is a variation of the squat that targets the front of the legs and requires good core stability. It is performed with the barbell resting on the front shoulders.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and the barbell on your front shoulders. 2. Keep your elbows high and chest up. 3. Lower your body by bending your knees and hips, keeping your back straight. 4. Push through your heels to return to the starting position.

Title: KV Bulgarian Split Squat
Desc: The KV Bulgarian Split Squat is a single-leg exercise that targets the legs and improves balance and stability. It is performed with one foot elevated behind you.
HowTo: 1. Stand a few feet in front of a bench with your back to it. 2. Place one foot on the bench behind you. 3. Lower your body until your front thigh is parallel to the ground. 4. Push through your front heel to return to the starting position.

Title: King Maker Barbell Back Squat
Desc: The barbell back squat is a popular compound movement that emphasizes building the lower-body muscle groups and overall strength. It's the classic way to start a leg day, and is a worthy centerpiece to a lower-body training program. The squat is a competitive lift in the sport of powerlifting, but is also a classic measurement of lower-body strength. With the barbell racked on the traps or upper back, the emphasis is placed on the posterior chain but the entire body gets worked. The back squat can be trained in everything from heavy singles to sets of 20 reps or higher.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and the barbell on your upper back. 2. Keep your chest up and core tight. 3. Lower your body by bending your knees and hips, keeping your back straight. 4. Push through your heels to return to the starting position.

Title: King Maker Barbell Deadlift
Desc: The barbell deadlift is a compound exercise used to develop overall strength and size in the posterior chain. It is a competition lift in the sport of powerlifting, but is also considered a classic benchmark of overall strength. When performed with the hands outside the knees, it is often called a "conventional" deadlift. When the feet are wide and the hands are inside the knees, it is a sumo deadlift.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet hip-width apart and the barbell over your mid-foot. 2. Bend at your hips and knees to grip the bar with both hands. 3. Keep your back straight and chest up as you lift the bar by extending your hips and knees. 4. Lower the bar back to the ground with control.

Title: 30 Legs Barbell Back Squat
Desc: The 30 Legs Barbell Back Squat is a variation of the back squat that focuses on building leg strength and endurance. It is performed with a barbell on the upper back.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and the barbell on your upper back. 2. Keep your chest up and core tight. 3. Lower your body by bending your knees and hips, keeping your back straight. 4. Push through your heels to return to the starting position.

Title: 30 Legs Barbell Front Squat
Desc: The barbell front squat is a compound exercise that primarily targets the legs and core. It involves holding a barbell across the front of your shoulders while squatting down.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and the barbell resting on your front shoulders. 2. Keep your elbows high and chest up. 3. Lower your body into a squat, keeping your weight on your heels. 4. Push through your heels to return to the starting position.

Title: Barbell Back Squats
Desc: Barbell back squats are a fundamental strength exercise that targets the lower body. They involve squatting down with a barbell placed across your upper back.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and the barbell resting on your upper back. 2. Keep your chest up and back straight. 3. Lower your body into a squat, keeping your knees aligned with your toes. 4. Push through your heels to return to the starting position.

Title: Front Squats With Two Kettlebells
Desc: Front squats with two kettlebells are a variation that emphasizes the quads and core stability. They require holding a kettlebell in each hand at shoulder height while squatting.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a kettlebell in each hand at shoulder height. 2. Keep your elbows high and chest up. 3. Lower your body into a squat, keeping your weight on your heels. 4. Push through your heels to return to the starting position.

Title: Kettlebell Pistol Squat
Desc: The kettlebell pistol squat is an advanced single-leg exercise that challenges balance and strength. It requires lowering your body on one leg while keeping the other leg extended forward.
HowTo: 1. Stand on one leg with the other leg extended in front of you. 2. Hold a kettlebell in front of your chest. 3. Lower your body into a squat on the standing leg while keeping the extended leg off the ground. 4. Push through your heel to return to the starting position.

Title: Goblet Squat
Desc: The goblet squat is a popular lower-body exercise where you hold a kettlebell or dumbbell in front of your chest as if you are supporting a heavy cup or goblet. It can help lifters of all levels improve their squat technique and hip mobility, but can also work as a muscle-building or strength accessory movement for experienced athletes. It also works well in combinations, complexes, and flows with other kettlebell movements like swings, presses, and cleans.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a kettlebell or dumbbell at chest height. 2. Keep your elbows inside your knees as you squat down. 3. Lower your body until your thighs are parallel to the ground. 4. Push through your heels to return to the starting position.

Title: Kettlebell Curtsy Lunge
Desc: The kettlebell curtsy lunge is a lower-body exercise that targets the glutes, quads, and hamstrings. It involves stepping back into a curtsy position, which engages the inner thighs and improves balance.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet hip-width apart, holding a kettlebell in one hand. 2. Step one leg back diagonally into a curtsy position, lowering your body until the front thigh is parallel to the ground. 3. Push through the front heel to return to the starting position. 4. Repeat on the other side.

Title: Single-arm kettlebell overhead squat
Desc: The single-arm kettlebell overhead squat is a popular kettlebell movement performed while holding a single kettlebell in a locked-out overhead position. It targets the muscles of the lower body dynamically, while also challenging and building shoulder stability and upper-back mobility. It can be trained in traditional strength or muscle-building rep ranges, in circuit or fat-loss training, or as part of a kettlebell combination or complex.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, holding a kettlebell in one hand overhead. 2. Engage your core and squat down, keeping the kettlebell locked out above you. 3. Push through your heels to return to standing while maintaining the overhead position.

Title: Kettlebell side squat
Desc: The kettlebell side squat is a popular movement to build mobility and lateral strength in the hips. It can be performed for time or for reps, either on its own or as part of a kettlebell circuit, complex, or flow.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet wider than shoulder-width apart, holding a kettlebell at chest height. 2. Shift your weight to one side and squat down, keeping the other leg straight. 3. Push through the heel of the squatting leg to return to standing. 4. Repeat on the other side.

Title: Kettlebell sumo squat
Desc: The kettlebell sumo squat is a lower-body movement emphasizing the muscles of the hips, glutes, and quads. It shares attributes with both the kettlebell deadlift and the goblet squat, but is usually performed with a wider stance and the feet pointed more outward, similar to a sumo deadlift. Its unique stance helps the lifter keep an upright torso, as well as emphasize stretching the hips and adductor muscles.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet wider than shoulder-width apart and toes pointed outward, holding a kettlebell with both hands. 2. Lower your body into a squat, keeping your chest up and back straight. 3. Push through your heels to return to standing.

Title: Kettlebell thruster progression
Desc: The kettlebell thruster progression is a kettlebell combination movement that includes a squat, curl, press, and overhead extension in a single sequence. It can work well with a light or moderate weight either for time or reps, in circuit-style training, or as a single kettlebell "flow."
HowTo: 1. Start standing with feet shoulder-width apart, holding a kettlebell at chest height. 2. Perform a squat, then curl the kettlebell to your shoulders. 3. As you stand up, press the kettlebell overhead. 4. Lower the kettlebell back to your chest and repeat.

Title: Kettlebell power clean
Desc: The kettlebell power clean is an explosive kettlebell exercise where the lifter pulls the weight to shoulder level with a slight swing between the legs. It is often used as a drill to teach kettlebell clean technique, but is also a valuable power exercise in its own right. It can be performed in low rep ranges for strength or higher rep ranges for technique practice or muscle growth.
HowTo: 1. Start with the kettlebell on the floor between your feet. 2. Hinge at the hips and grasp the kettlebell with one hand. 3. Swing the kettlebell between your legs, then explosively pull it up to shoulder level, keeping your elbow close to your body. 4. Lower the kettlebell back to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Kettlebell fire feet
Desc: Kettlebell fire feet is a dynamic movement that works most of the major muscle groups in the body simultaneously, while also elevating the heart rate. It's a great movement to include in kettlebell or bodyweight circuit training to increase fatigue and burn serious calories.
HowTo: 1. Start in a standing position with a kettlebell in each hand. 2. Quickly alternate lifting your feet off the ground while maintaining a slight bend in your knees. 3. Swing the kettlebells in a controlled manner as you move your feet rapidly. 4. Continue for the desired duration.

Title: Single Arm Overhead Kettlebell Squat
Desc: The single-arm kettlebell overhead squat is a popular kettlebell movement performed while holding a single kettlebell in a locked-out overhead position. It targets the muscles of the lower body dynamically, while also challenging and building shoulder stability and upper-back mobility. It can be trained in traditional strength or muscle-building rep ranges, in circuit or fat-loss training, or as part of a kettlebell combination or complex.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and hold a kettlebell in one hand overhead. 2. Lower your body into a squat while keeping the kettlebell locked out overhead. 3. Push through your heels to return to the starting position. 4. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Pulsing goblet squat
Desc: The pulsing goblet squat is a simple way to make a popular squat variation more taxing for the lower body and cardiovascular system. They can be done for time or reps, allowing you to get a significant training effect from a light weight in circuit-style training.
HowTo: 1. Hold a kettlebell close to your chest with both hands. 2. Lower your body into a squat position, keeping your chest up and back straight. 3. Pulse at the bottom of the squat by slightly rising and lowering your body. 4. Stand back up to complete one repetition.

Title: Double-kettlebell alternating lunge to clean
Desc: The double-kettlebell alternating lunge to clean is a combination of kettlebell moves in a single sequence. This combination can be performed for time or for reps, often as circuit-style training for conditioning or fat loss, or in a kettlebell complex or flow.
HowTo: 1. Start in a standing position with a kettlebell in each hand. 2. Step forward into a lunge with one leg while lowering the kettlebell to the floor. 3. Push off the front foot to return to standing and clean the kettlebell to shoulder level. 4. Alternate legs and repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: FYR Goblet Squat
Desc: The goblet squat is a popular lower-body exercise where you hold a kettlebell or dumbbell in front of your chest as if you are supporting a heavy cup or goblet. It can help lifters of all levels improve their squat technique and hip mobility, but can also work as a muscle-building or strength accessory movement for experienced athletes. It also works well in combinations, complexes, and flows with other kettlebell movements like swings, presses, and cleans.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, holding a kettlebell or dumbbell close to your chest. 2. Lower your body into a squat by bending your knees and pushing your hips back, keeping your chest up and back straight. 3. Push through your heels to return to the starting position.

Title: FYR Kettlebell Sumo Squat
Desc: The kettlebell sumo squat is a lower-body movement emphasizing the muscles of the hips, glutes, and quads. It shares attributes with both the kettlebell deadlift and the goblet squat, but is usually performed with a wider stance and the feet pointed more outward, similar to a sumo deadlift. Its unique stance helps the lifter keep an upright torso, as well as emphasize stretching the hips and adductor muscles.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet wider than shoulder-width apart and hold a kettlebell with both hands in front of you. 2. Lower into a squat, keeping your torso upright and pushing your knees outward. 3. Return to the starting position by pushing through your heels.

Title: Double-kettlebell front squat
Desc: The double-kettlebell front squat is a popular kettlebell movement performed while holding two kettlebells in the front-racked position. It targets the muscles of the lower body dynamically, and the muscles of the upper back and core isometrically. It can be trained in traditional strength or muscle-building rep ranges, in circuit or fat-loss training, or as part of a larger kettlebell combination or complex.
Muscles: Quads, Hamstrings, Glutes, Core, Upper Back
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, holding two kettlebells in the front-racked position. 2. Lower your body into a squat, keeping your elbows close to your body and your chest up. 3. Push through your heels to return to the starting position.

Title: FYR Kettlebell Squat Clean
Desc: The kettlebell squat clean is an explosive kettlebell exercise where the lifter pulls the weight to shoulder level with a slight swing between the legs. It is often used as a drill to teach kettlebell clean technique, but is also a valuable power exercise in its own right. It can be performed in low rep ranges for strength or higher rep ranges for technique practice or muscle growth.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, holding a kettlebell between your legs. 2. Swing the kettlebell back between your legs, then explosively pull it up to shoulder level while squatting down. 3. Stand up straight, bringing the kettlebell to shoulder height and then return to the starting position.

Title: Single-arm kettlebell front squat
Desc: The single-arm kettlebell front squat is a popular kettlebell movement performed while holding a single kettlebell in the front-racked position. It targets the muscles of the lower body dynamically, and the muscles of the upper back and core isometrically. It can be trained in traditional strength or muscle-building rep ranges, in circuit or fat-loss training, or as part of a kettlebell combination or complex.
Muscles: Quads, Hamstrings, Glutes, Core, Upper Back
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, holding a single kettlebell in the front-racked position. 2. Lower your body into a squat, keeping your elbows close to your body and your chest up. 3. Push through your heels to return to the starting position.

Title: Kettlebell front rack lunge
Desc: The kettlebell front rack lunge is a dynamic leg and core exercise in which a lifter performs lunges while holding a single kettlebell in the front-racked position. It is a unique coordination challenge, but also challenging to the musculature of the abdomen, lower body, shoulders, and upper back. It is most commonly performed for higher reps, such as 10-15 reps per side, or for time. It can work in circuit-style workouts, as well as in muscle or strength-focused workouts.
Muscles: Quadriceps, Hamstrings, Glutes, Core, Shoulders, Upper Back
HowTo: 1. Stand upright holding a kettlebell in the front rack position. 2. Step forward with one leg into a lunge, keeping your torso upright. 3. Push back to the starting position and repeat on the other side.

Title: HM Turkish Get-Up
Desc: The Turkish Get-Up is a complex movement that involves transitioning from lying down to standing while holding a weight overhead. It engages multiple muscle groups and improves stability and mobility.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back holding a kettlebell in one hand. 2. Roll to your side and push yourself up onto your elbow. 3. Move to a sitting position, then to a kneeling position. 4. Stand up while keeping the kettlebell overhead. 5. Reverse the steps to return to the starting position.

Title: HM Single-Leg Romanian Deadlift
Desc: The Single-Leg Romanian Deadlift is an effective exercise for targeting the hamstrings and glutes while improving balance. It requires stability and strength in the lower body.
HowTo: 1. Stand on one leg while holding a kettlebell in the opposite hand. 2. Hinge at the hips and lower the kettlebell towards the ground while extending the free leg behind you. 3. Return to standing by engaging the glutes and hamstrings.

Title: Taylor Single-Arm Kettlebell Front Squat
Desc: The Single-Arm Kettlebell Front Squat is a variation of the squat that challenges the core and lower body while requiring stability. It focuses on strength and balance.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart holding a kettlebell in one hand at chest height. 2. Lower into a squat while keeping the kettlebell close to your body. 3. Push through your heels to return to standing.

Title: Taylor Kettlebell Goblet Squat
Desc: The Kettlebell Goblet Squat is a fundamental exercise that targets the lower body while promoting proper squat mechanics. It is great for building strength and endurance.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart holding a kettlebell by the handles close to your chest. 2. Lower your body into a squat, keeping your chest up and elbows inside your knees. 3. Push through your heels to return to standing.

Title: Goblet squat-
Desc: The goblet squat is a popular lower-body exercise where you hold a kettlebell or dumbbell in front of your chest as if you are supporting a heavy cup or goblet. It can help lifters of all levels improve their squat technique and hip mobility, but can also work as a muscle-building or strength accessory movement for experienced athletes. It also works well in combinations, complexes, and flows with other kettlebell movements like swings, presses, and cleans.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. 2. Hold a kettlebell or dumbbell close to your chest with both hands. 3. Squat down by bending your knees and pushing your hips back, keeping your chest up. 4. Go as low as you can while maintaining good form, then push through your heels to return to standing.

Title: Holman Kettlebell Squat Clean
Desc: The Holman Kettlebell Squat Clean is a dynamic exercise that combines a squat and a clean movement. It helps develop strength and coordination in the lower body.
HowTo: 1. Start with a kettlebell on the ground between your feet. 2. Bend at your hips and knees to grab the kettlebell with one hand. 3. In one motion, lift the kettlebell to your shoulder while squatting down. 4. Stand up while bringing the kettlebell to a racked position at your shoulder.

Title: Holman Kettlebell Swing
Desc: The Holman Kettlebell Swing is a powerful exercise that targets the posterior chain and improves cardiovascular conditioning. It is performed by swinging a kettlebell between the legs and then up to shoulder height.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a kettlebell with both hands. 2. Bend your knees slightly and hinge at your hips to swing the kettlebell back between your legs. 3. Drive your hips forward to swing the kettlebell up to shoulder height. 4. Let the kettlebell swing back down and repeat.

Title: Holman Kettlebell Swing Transfer
Desc: The Holman Kettlebell Swing Transfer is an advanced variation of the kettlebell swing that involves transferring the kettlebell from one hand to the other. This exercise enhances grip strength and coordination.
HowTo: 1. Start in the same position as the kettlebell swing. 2. Swing the kettlebell back between your legs. 3. As you swing it forward, transfer it from one hand to the other at the top of the swing. 4. Continue swinging with the transferred hand.

Title: Dumbbell goblet squat-
Desc: The goblet squat is a popular lower-body exercise in which a dumbbell or kettlebell is held in front of the chest with two hands, approximating how you might hold a heavy goblet. It is used as a teaching tool to help instruct and develop proper squat form, but is also effective for building size in the quads, glutes, and hamstrings. It can be performed for low reps to build strength, or for higher reps to build muscle and conditioning.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a dumbbell close to your chest with both hands. 2. Squat down by bending your knees and pushing your hips back, keeping your chest up. 3. Go as low as you can while maintaining good form, then push through your heels to return to standing.

Title: Robertson Kettlebell Jump
Desc: The Robertson Kettlebell Jump is a dynamic exercise that combines strength and explosive power. It targets the lower body while improving coordination and agility.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, holding a kettlebell in each hand. 2. Lower into a squat, then explosively jump upward, swinging the kettlebells overhead. 3. Land softly and return to the squat position.

Title: FYR2 Alternating Kettlebell Squat Clean
Desc: The FYR2 Alternating Kettlebell Squat Clean is a compound movement that works multiple muscle groups. It enhances strength and coordination while focusing on the legs and shoulders.
HowTo: 1. Start in a standing position with a kettlebell in each hand. 2. Perform a squat while bringing the kettlebells to the floor. 3. Clean one kettlebell to the shoulder while standing up, then alternate to the other side.

Title: FYR2 Banded Double-Kettlebell Squat Pulse
Desc: The FYR2 Banded Double-Kettlebell Squat Pulse is an effective exercise for building leg strength and endurance. It incorporates resistance bands for added intensity.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, holding a kettlebell in each hand. 2. Lower into a squat and pulse up and down for a few inches. 3. Maintain tension and keep the kettlebells close to your body.

Title: FYR2 Double-Kettlebell Ballin' Lunge
Desc: The FYR2 Double-Kettlebell Ballin' Lunge is a powerful lower body exercise that builds strength and stability. It challenges balance and coordination while targeting the legs.
HowTo: 1. Stand upright with a kettlebell in each hand at your sides. 2. Step forward into a lunge position, lowering your back knee toward the ground. 3. Push back to the starting position and repeat on the other leg.

Title: FYR2 Double-Kettlebell Front Rack Lunge
Desc: The FYR2 Double-Kettlebell Front Rack Lunge is an excellent exercise for developing leg strength and core stability. It emphasizes proper posture and control during movement.
HowTo: 1. Hold two kettlebells in the front rack position at shoulder height. 2. Step forward into a lunge, keeping your torso upright. 3. Push back to the starting position and alternate legs.

Title: FYR2 Double-Kettlebell Front Squat
Desc: The Double-Kettlebell Front Squat is a compound exercise that targets the lower body and core. It helps improve strength and stability while engaging multiple muscle groups.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, holding a kettlebell in each hand at shoulder level. 2. Lower your body into a squat by bending your knees and pushing your hips back. 3. Keep your chest up and back straight. 4. Push through your heels to return to the starting position.

Title: FYR2 Explosive Kettlebell Jump Squat
Desc: The Explosive Kettlebell Jump Squat is a dynamic exercise that combines strength and power training. It enhances explosive leg strength and improves athletic performance.
HowTo: 1. Start in a squat position with a kettlebell held at chest level. 2. Explode upwards into a jump, extending your legs and arms. 3. Land softly back into the squat position and repeat.

Title: FYR2 Kettlebell Goblet Squat
Desc: The Kettlebell Goblet Squat is a fundamental lower body exercise that emphasizes proper squat form. It helps build strength and mobility in the legs and core.
HowTo: 1. Hold a kettlebell close to your chest with both hands. 2. Stand with feet slightly wider than shoulder-width apart. 3. Lower your body into a squat, keeping the kettlebell close to your chest. 4. Push through your heels to return to standing.

Title: FYR2 Kettlebell Reverse Lunge Switch Grip
Desc: The Kettlebell Reverse Lunge Switch Grip is an effective exercise for building leg strength and stability. It also improves coordination and balance.
HowTo: 1. Stand upright holding a kettlebell in one hand. 2. Step back into a lunge with the opposite leg, switching the kettlebell to the other hand. 3. Push through the front heel to return to standing and repeat on the other side.

Title: FYR2 Kettlebell Reverse Lunge to Kneeling Press
Desc: The Kettlebell Reverse Lunge to Kneeling Press combines lower body strength with upper body pressing. It is excellent for building functional strength and stability.
HowTo: 1. Start standing with a kettlebell in one hand. 2. Step back into a reverse lunge while bringing the kettlebell down to your shoulder. 3. As you stand back up, press the kettlebell overhead. 4. Repeat on the other side.

Title: FYR2 Kettlebell Sumo Squat Pulse
Desc: The Kettlebell Sumo Squat Pulse targets the lower body, focusing on the legs and glutes. It involves a wide stance squat with a pulsing motion at the bottom.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet wider than shoulder-width apart, holding a kettlebell with both hands. 2. Lower into a squat, keeping your chest up and back straight. 3. Pulse at the bottom of the squat for a few seconds before returning to standing.

Title: FYR2 Reverse Lunge to Single-Leg Kettlebell Deadlift
Desc: The Reverse Lunge to Single-Leg Kettlebell Deadlift combines lower body strength with balance and stability. It engages multiple muscle groups while improving coordination.
HowTo: 1. Stand upright holding a kettlebell in one hand. 2. Step back into a reverse lunge with the opposite leg. 3. Push through the front heel to return to standing, then hinge at the hips to lower the kettlebell towards the ground on the same side as the lunging leg. 4. Return to standing and repeat.

Title: FYR2 Kettlebell Goblet-Squat-Deadlift Complex
Desc: The Kettlebell Goblet-Squat-Deadlift Complex is a full-body exercise that builds strength and endurance. It combines squats and deadlifts into one fluid movement.
HowTo: 1. Hold a kettlebell close to your chest with both hands. 2. Perform a squat by lowering your hips back and down. 3. Stand up and immediately hinge at the hips to perform a deadlift, lowering the kettlebell to the ground. 4. Repeat the sequence.

Title: FYR2 Kettlebell Squat-Press-Deadlift Complex
Desc: The Kettlebell Squat-Press-Deadlift Complex is a dynamic exercise that works multiple muscle groups. It enhances strength and coordination throughout the body.
HowTo: 1. Hold a kettlebell at shoulder height. 2. Perform a squat, then stand up and press the kettlebell overhead. 3. Lower the kettlebell back to shoulder height and perform a deadlift. 4. Repeat the sequence.

Title: Goblet Squats
Desc: Goblet Squats are a foundational exercise that targets the lower body and improves squat mechanics. They are great for building strength and stability.
HowTo: 1. Hold a kettlebell close to your chest with both hands. 2. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart. 3. Lower your body into a squat, keeping the kettlebell close to your chest. 4. Push through your heels to return to standing.

Title: Dumbbell Goblet Squat
Desc: The goblet squat is a common exercise used in the early stages of learning to squat, or as a movement in general training programs for building size to the quads, glutes, and hamstrings.
HowTo: 1. Hold a dumbbell close to your chest with both hands. 2. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. 3. Lower your body into a squat by bending your knees and pushing your hips back. 4. Keep your chest up and back straight. 5. Push through your heels to return to the starting position.

Title: Dumbbell squat
Desc: The dumbbell squat is a classic lower-body exercise that targets the quadriceps, hamstrings, and glutes. While this variation is usually performed with relatively light weights for high reps, it can also be used as a substitute for squats or the trap-bar deadlift in any workout.
HowTo: 1. Stand with a dumbbell in each hand at your sides. 2. Lower your body by bending your knees, keeping your back straight. 3. Go down until your thighs are parallel to the ground. 4. Push through your heels to return to standing.

Title: Dumbbell Lunges
Desc: The dumbbell split squat is a popular lower-body exercise to build strength and muscle one leg at a time. It can be used to teach proper lunge form, but is also valuable on its own when trained in traditional strength-focused rep ranges, such as 5-8 reps per set, or for higher reps to build muscle or for conditioning.
HowTo: 1. Stand upright with a dumbbell in each hand at your sides. 2. Step forward with one leg and lower your body until both knees are bent at about a 90-degree angle. 3. Push back to the starting position and repeat on the other leg.

Title: Dumbbell reverse lunge
Desc: The dumbbell reverse lunge is a popular lower-body movement that targets the muscles of the quads, glutes, hamstrings, and hips. It also works the core and upper-back muscles to maintain posture while the lower body moves. Lunge variations are often performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per leg or more, as part of the lower-body portion of a workout. If this movement hurts your knees, try performing split squats instead.
Muscles: quadriceps, glutes, hamstrings, core, upper back
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet hip-width apart, holding a dumbbell in each hand. 2. Step back with one leg into a lunge position, lowering your hips until both knees are bent at about a 90-degree angle. 3. Keep your torso upright and push through the front heel to return to standing.

Title: Split Squat with Dumbbells
Desc: The dumbbell Bulgaria split squat is a single-leg exercise targeting the quads, glutes, and hamstrings.
HowTo: 1. Stand a few feet in front of a bench or elevated surface, holding dumbbells at your sides. 2. Place one foot on the bench behind you. 3. Lower your body into a squat on the standing leg, keeping your chest up. 4. Push through your front heel to return to the starting position.

Title: Dumbbell sumo squat
Desc: The dumbbell sumo squat is a popular lower-body movement using a single dumbbell held in front of the legs. It is performed with a wider than shoulder-width stance, which increases the demand on the glutes, hamstrings, and adductors while still benefiting the quads, core, and upper body. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps, at least 8-12 reps per set, as part of the lower-body portion of a workout.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet wider than shoulder-width apart, holding a dumbbell in front of your legs. 2. Lower your body into a squat, keeping your chest up and pushing your hips back, then return to standing.

Title: Dumbbell seated box jump
Desc: The dumbbell seated box jump is an explosive exercise that builds the quadriceps as well as overall lower-body strength and explosiveness. All you need is a box, a bench, and a light dumbbell. Performing it from a seated position eliminates the stretch reflex in the lower body, forcing you to generate more power. This is an advanced move, so consider starting off with box jumps or squat jumps before progressing to this.
HowTo: 1. Sit on a bench with a dumbbell in hand. 2. Explode upwards, jumping onto the box while driving through your legs, landing softly.

Title: Dumbbell step-up
Desc: The dumbbell step-up is a great exercise for building lower-body strength and power. It targets all the same muscles as bodyweight step-ups, such as the quads, glutes, and hamstrings, but allows for greater muscular overload.
HowTo: 1. Stand in front of a bench or platform with a dumbbell in each hand. 2. Step up onto the bench with one foot, driving through your heel, and then step back down.

Title: Dumbbell Walking Lunge
Desc: The dumbbell walking lunge tests your ability to maintain balance while challenging the quads, glutes, and hamstrings as well as core muscles.
HowTo: 1. Stand upright with a dumbbell in each hand. 2. Step forward into a lunge, lowering your back knee toward the ground, then push back to the starting position.

Title: Dumbbell Squat To A Bench
Desc: The dumbbell squat to a bench is a controlled movement that helps to build lower-body strength. It involves squatting down to a bench and standing back up.
HowTo: 1. Stand in front of a bench with a dumbbell in each hand. 2. Lower your body into a squat until your glutes touch the bench, then stand back up.

Title: Dumbbell thruster
Desc: The dumbbell thruster, which begins with a squat and ends with an overhead press, works the entire body at once in a single fluid motion. This exercise is often performed with kettlebells, but dumbbells are also a great option.
Muscles: quadriceps, glutes, hamstrings, core, upper back
HowTo: 1. Start in a standing position holding dumbbells at shoulder height. 2. Lower into a squat, keeping your chest up and knees over your toes. 3. Push through your heels to return to standing while pressing the dumbbells overhead. 4. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Dumbbell front squat
Desc: The dumbbell front squat is a popular exercise for targeting the muscles of the lower body, including the quadriceps, glutes, and hamstrings. Holding dumbbells in the racked position also works the core and upper-back muscles to maintain posture while the lower body moves. Because the amount of weight you can use will be limited by what you can clean to the rack position, this movement is usually performed for moderate to high reps, at least 8-12 reps per set or more. If this movement hurts your knees, try performing it with a wider stance.
Muscles: quadriceps, glutes, hamstrings, core, upper back
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, holding dumbbells in the racked position at shoulder height. 2. Lower into a squat, keeping your chest up and elbows high. 3. Push through your heels to return to standing. 4. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Single-Arm Dumbbell Overhead Squat
Desc: The Single-Arm Dumbbell Overhead Squat is a challenging exercise that tests balance and strength. It engages multiple muscle groups, particularly in the legs and core.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, holding a dumbbell in one hand overhead. 2. Lower into a squat while keeping the dumbbell overhead and your core engaged. 3. Push through your heels to return to standing. 4. Switch arms and repeat.

Title: Dumbbell lateral hop
Desc: The dumbbell lateral hop is an explosive exercise that targets the muscles of the hips and legs. Adding dumbbells adds a challenge to the core, as well. Because balance can be a challenge, it is usually performed with relatively light weights, often as a component of fat-loss or athletic training.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet together, holding a dumbbell in each hand. 2. Jump laterally to one side, landing softly on the opposite foot while keeping the other foot off the ground. 3. Immediately jump back to the starting position. 4. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Dumbbell lunge with biceps curl
Desc: The dumbbell lunge with biceps curl combines an isometric hold at the bottom of a lunge with a dumbbell biceps curl. The two exercises combine to target the legs, core, and biceps. The curl will determine the amount of weight you can use, but even a light weight will make the lunge hold seriously challenging.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet together, holding dumbbells at your sides. 2. Step forward into a lunge position while simultaneously curling the dumbbells towards your shoulders. 3. Push back to the starting position and repeat on the other leg. 4. Continue alternating legs for the desired number of reps.

Title: Dumbbell Pistol Squat
Desc: The Dumbbell Pistol Squat is a challenging single-leg squat that builds strength and balance. It requires significant leg strength and stability.
HowTo: 1. Stand on one leg while holding a dumbbell in the opposite hand. 2. Lower your body into a squat while extending the other leg forward. 3. Push through your heel to return to the starting position.

Title: Dumbbell Squat Snatch
Desc: The Dumbbell Squat Snatch is a dynamic movement that combines a squat with an explosive overhead lift. It develops power and coordination.
HowTo: 1. Start with a dumbbell on the ground between your feet. 2. Squat down and grip the dumbbell with one hand. 3. Explode upward, pulling the dumbbell up and dropping into a squat as you lift it overhead. 4. Stand up to complete the lift.

Title: Dumbbell Alternating Lunge
Desc: The Dumbbell Alternating Lunge is a great exercise for building leg strength and stability. It targets the major muscles in the legs while improving balance.
HowTo: 1. Stand upright with a dumbbell in each hand. 2. Step forward with one leg into a lunge position, lowering your back knee toward the ground. 3. Push back to the starting position and repeat with the other leg.

Title: Dumbbell jump squat
Desc: The dumbbell jump squat is a popular movement combining an explosive lower-body movement with extra upper-body loading in the form of dumbbells held in the hands. Done with heavier weights, it can be trained for low reps with a power focus. With light weights, it is often done for higher reps for fat-loss and conditioning.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, holding a dumbbell in each hand. 2. Lower into a squat position. 3. Explode upward into a jump, landing softly and immediately going into the next squat.

Title: Dumbbell Side Lunge
Desc: The Dumbbell Side Lunge targets the inner and outer thighs while improving lateral movement. It is effective for building leg strength and flexibility.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet hip-width apart, holding a dumbbell in each hand. 2. Step to the side with one leg, bending that knee while keeping the other leg straight. 3. Push back to the starting position and repeat on the other side.

Title: Boss Everline Dumbbell Lunge Jump
Desc: The Boss Everline Dumbbell Lunge Jump is an explosive lower body exercise that combines a lunge with a jump. It targets the legs and helps improve strength and power.
HowTo: 1. Start in a standing position with a dumbbell in each hand. 2. Step forward into a lunge position, lowering your back knee toward the ground. 3. Push off your front foot and jump up explosively, switching legs in mid-air. 4. Land softly and immediately go into the next lunge.

Title: Dumbbell Fix Dumbbell Split Squat
Desc: The Dumbbell Fix Dumbbell Split Squat is a lower body exercise that targets the quads, hamstrings, and glutes. It is performed by lowering the body into a split stance while holding dumbbells.
HowTo: 1. Stand with one foot forward and one foot back in a split stance, holding a dumbbell in each hand. 2. Lower your body by bending both knees until your back knee nearly touches the ground. 3. Push through your front heel to return to the starting position. 4. Repeat for the desired number of reps before switching legs.

Title: Single-leg dumbbell Romanian deadlift
Desc: The single-leg dumbbell Romanian deadlift is a movement targeting the muscles of the hamstrings, glutes, and back. The difference between a Romanian deadlift and a stiff-legged deadlift is the amount of knee bend. The knees are only slightly bent in a stiff-legged deadlift, while they bend more in a Romanian deadlift. Single-leg deadlifts are generally performed for low to moderate reps, such as 8-10 reps per set, with a focus on maximizing the hamstring stretch rather than moving heavy weight. If balance is a challenge, this movement is still very effective if performed while holding on to a stable object for support.
HowTo: 1. Stand on one leg while holding a dumbbell in the opposite hand. 2. Keeping a slight bend in the standing knee, hinge at the hips to lower the dumbbell toward the ground while extending the free leg behind you. 3. Lower until you feel a stretch in the hamstring, then return to the starting position by driving through the standing heel. 4. Repeat for the desired number of reps before switching legs.

Title: Dumbbell Fix Dumbbell Alternating Reverse Lunge
Desc: The Dumbbell Fix Dumbbell Alternating Reverse Lunge is a dynamic exercise that targets the lower body, focusing on the quads and glutes. It involves stepping back into a lunge and alternating legs.
HowTo: 1. Stand upright with a dumbbell in each hand at your sides. 2. Step back with one leg into a reverse lunge, lowering your hips until both knees are bent at about 90 degrees. 3. Push through the front heel to return to standing. 4. Alternate legs and repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Dumbbell Fix Turkish Get-Up
Desc: The Dumbbell Fix Turkish Get-Up is a full-body exercise that enhances mobility and stability. It requires coordination and strength to transition from lying down to standing while holding a dumbbell.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back with a dumbbell in one hand, arm extended. 2. Bend the knee on the same side and keep the opposite leg straight. 3. Push through your elbow to sit up, keeping the dumbbell overhead. 4. Rise to a standing position while maintaining control of the dumbbell, then reverse the steps to return to the starting position.

Title: Seesaw lunge
Desc: The seesaw lunge is a bodyweight exercise that combines both the forward and the reverse lunge. It can also be performed holding dumbbells or other weights. It can be performed for time or reps in the lower-body portion of any workout.
HowTo: 1. Stand upright with feet shoulder-width apart. 2. Step forward with one leg into a lunge position, then push back to the starting position. 3. Immediately step back with the same leg into a reverse lunge. 4. Return to the starting position and repeat with the other leg.

Title: FYR Dumbbell Front Squat
Desc: The dumbbell front squat targets the quads, glutes, and hamstrings, as well as the upper body and challenging core stability for building total body strength.
Muscles: quads, glutes, hamstrings, core, upper body
HowTo: 1. Hold a dumbbell in each hand at shoulder height. 2. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart. 3. Lower your body into a squat, keeping your chest up and elbows high. 4. Push through your heels to return to the starting position.

Title: Dumbbell split squat
Desc: The dumbbell split squat is a popular lower-body exercise to build strength and muscle one leg at a time. It can be used to teach proper lunge form, but is also valuable on its own when trained in traditional strength-focused rep ranges, such as 5-8 reps per set, or for higher reps to build muscle or for conditioning.
HowTo: 1. Stand in a staggered stance with one foot forward and one foot back. 2. Lower your body by bending your front knee, keeping your back knee close to the ground. 3. Push through your front heel to return to the starting position. 4. Repeat for the desired number of reps before switching legs.

Title: Dumbbell deadlift
Desc: The dumbbell deadlift is a movement that targets the hamstrings, glutes, and back muscles. While it can be performed all the way from the ground, in the style of a barbell deadlift, it is more often performed from the top down as a Romanian deadlift. The dumbbell deadlift can be performed in low rep ranges to build posterior strength, or for moderate to high reps to build muscle and endurance.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet hip-width apart, holding a dumbbell in each hand in front of your thighs. 2. Hinge at your hips and lower the dumbbells towards the ground while keeping your back straight. 3. Engage your glutes and hamstrings to return to the starting position.

Title: Single-arm stiff-legged deadlift
Desc: The single-arm stiff-legged deadlift is a dumbbell exercise that targets the hamstrings, glutes, lower and upper back, and core. The difference between a stiff-legged deadlift and a Romanian deadlift is primarily the amount of knee bend. The knees are only slightly bent in a stiff-legged deadlift, while they bend more in a Romanian deadlift. Stiff-legged deadlifts are generally performed for low to moderate reps, such as 8-10 reps per set, with a focus on maximizing the hamstring stretch rather than moving heavy weight. Feel free to wear a weight belt to protect your lower back.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet hip-width apart, holding a dumbbell in one hand. 2. Slightly bend your knee and hinge at your hips to lower the dumbbell towards the ground. 3. Keep your back straight and engage your hamstrings as you return to the starting position. 4. Repeat for the desired number of reps before switching arms.

Title: HM Dumbbell Overhead Squat
Desc: The HM Dumbbell Overhead Squat is a compound exercise that targets the legs and core while improving stability and strength. It involves squatting while holding a dumbbell overhead, engaging multiple muscle groups.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a dumbbell overhead with both hands. 2. Lower your body into a squat while keeping the dumbbell above your head. 3. Push through your heels to return to the starting position.

Title: HM Dumbbell Squat
Desc: The HM Dumbbell Squat is an effective lower body exercise that builds strength in the legs and glutes. It involves holding a dumbbell at your chest while performing a squat.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a dumbbell close to your chest. 2. Lower your body into a squat, keeping your chest up and back straight. 3. Return to the starting position by pushing through your heels.

Title: UNS Dumbbell Goblet Squat
Desc: The UNS Dumbbell Goblet Squat is a lower body exercise that emphasizes the quads and glutes while also engaging the core. It is performed by holding a dumbbell in front of your chest and squatting down.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a dumbbell vertically at your chest. 2. Lower your body into a squat, keeping the dumbbell close to your body. 3. Push through your heels to return to the starting position.

Title: Single-Arm Dumbbell Snatch
Desc: The Single-Arm Dumbbell Snatch is a dynamic full-body exercise that develops power and explosiveness. It involves lifting a dumbbell from the ground to overhead in one fluid motion.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, with a dumbbell on the ground between your feet. 2. Bend at the hips and knees to grasp the dumbbell with one hand. 3. In one motion, lift the dumbbell explosively overhead while standing up. 4. Lower the dumbbell back to the ground and repeat.

Title: KV Dumbbell Lunges
Desc: KV Dumbbell Lunges are a lower body exercise that targets the legs and glutes while improving balance and coordination. This exercise involves stepping forward into a lunge position while holding dumbbells.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet together, holding a dumbbell in each hand at your sides. 2. Step forward with one leg and lower your body into a lunge, keeping your front knee over your ankle. 3. Push back to the starting position and switch legs.

Title: Holman Squat to Biceps Curl
Desc: The Holman Squat to Biceps Curl combines a squat with a biceps curl to target both the lower and upper body. This exercise promotes strength and coordination.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, holding weights in both hands. 2. Lower into a squat while keeping your back straight. 3. As you rise, curl the weights up towards your shoulders. 4. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Holman Burpee to Biceps Curl
Desc: The Holman Burpee to Biceps Curl is a full-body exercise that combines a burpee with a biceps curl. It enhances cardiovascular fitness while building strength.
HowTo: 1. Start in a standing position with weights in hand. 2. Drop into a squat, place weights down, and kick your feet back into a plank. 3. Perform a push-up, return to squat, and stand up while curling the weights. 4. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Holman Slow Weighted Reverse Lunge
Desc: The Holman Slow Weighted Reverse Lunge targets the legs and glutes while improving balance and coordination. This exercise emphasizes strength through controlled movement.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet hip-width apart, holding weights at your sides. 2. Step back with one leg into a lunge, keeping your front knee over your ankle. 3. Push through the front heel to return to standing. 4. Alternate legs for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Holman Slow Weighted Plie Squat
Desc: The Holman Slow Weighted Plie Squat focuses on the inner thighs and glutes while promoting strength and stability. This controlled movement enhances muscle engagement.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet wider than shoulder-width apart, toes turned out, holding weights. 2. Lower into a squat, keeping your back straight and chest up. 3. Push through your heels to return to standing. 4. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Holman Weighted Lunge Jump with Biceps Curl
Desc: The Holman Weighted Lunge Jump with Biceps Curl is a dynamic exercise that builds power and strength in the legs and arms. It combines explosive movement with resistance training.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet hip-width apart, holding weights in both hands. 2. Step forward into a lunge, then jump up explosively, switching legs in the air. 3. As you land, perform a biceps curl. 4. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Holman Left Reverse Lunge Chest Press to Left Knee-Up Chest Press
Desc: The Holman Left Reverse Lunge Chest Press combines a lower body lunge with an upper body chest press. This exercise targets both the legs and the chest, providing a full-body workout.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, holding weights at chest level. 2. Step back with your left leg into a lunge position. 3. As you lower into the lunge, press the weights forward. 4. Return to standing and lift your left knee up while pressing the weights overhead. 5. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Holman Weighted Lunge Jump with Chest Press
Desc: The Holman Weighted Lunge Jump with Chest Press is a dynamic exercise that combines explosive movement with upper body strength. It targets the legs and chest, enhancing power and endurance.
HowTo: 1. Start in a standing position with weights at your chest. 2. Step forward into a lunge, then explosively jump up, switching legs in mid-air. 3. As you land, press the weights forward. 4. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Holman Weighted Half Jack to Biceps Curl
Desc: The Holman Weighted Half Jack to Biceps Curl is an exercise that targets the upper body while incorporating a cardio element. It focuses on building strength in the arms and shoulders.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, holding weights at your sides. 2. Jump out to the side while raising your arms overhead (half jack). 3. Immediately lower your arms and perform a biceps curl. 4. Return to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Holman Weighted Half Jack to Chest Press
Desc: The Holman Weighted Half Jack to Chest Press is a combination of a cardio move and strength training for the upper body. This exercise effectively targets the chest and shoulders.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, holding weights at your sides. 2. Jump out to the side while raising your arms overhead (half jack). 3. Lower the weights to chest level and press them forward. 4. Return to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Holman 180 Jump to Renegade Side Raise
Desc: The Holman 180 Jump to Renegade Side Raise is a high-intensity exercise that engages multiple muscle groups. It combines explosive jumps with strength training for a full-body workout.
HowTo: 1. Start in a plank position with weights in each hand. 2. Jump 180 degrees to land facing the opposite direction. 3. As you land, perform a renegade row by pulling one weight towards your side. 4. Alternate sides and repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Holman Right Reverse Lunge Biceps Curl to Right Knee-Up Biceps Curl
Desc: The Holman Right Reverse Lunge Biceps Curl to Right Knee-Up Biceps Curl combines a reverse lunge with a biceps curl and a knee-up. This exercise targets the legs and arms while improving balance and coordination.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, holding dumbbells at your sides. 2. Step back with your right leg into a reverse lunge. 3. As you lunge, curl the dumbbells up towards your shoulders. 4. Push through your left heel to return to standing while bringing your right knee up. 5. Lower your right leg and repeat.

Title: Holman Roll-Back to Squat Thrust to Renegade Row
Desc: The Holman Roll-Back to Squat Thrust to Renegade Row is a dynamic exercise that engages multiple muscle groups. It combines a roll-back with a squat thrust and a renegade row for a full-body workout.
HowTo: 1. Start in a seated position, roll back onto your back. 2. Quickly roll back up and jump into a squat position. 3. From the squat, place your hands on the ground and jump back into a plank position. 4. Perform a renegade row by pulling one dumbbell towards your hip while stabilizing your body. 5. Alternate sides and repeat.

Title: Holman Roll-Back to Squat Thrust to Renegade Triceps Press
Desc: The Holman Roll-Back to Squat Thrust to Renegade Triceps Press focuses on building arm strength and stability. This exercise combines a roll-back with a squat thrust and a triceps press.
HowTo: 1. Begin in a seated position, roll back onto your back. 2. Roll back up and transition into a squat position. 3. Place your hands on the ground and jump back into a plank. 4. Perform a triceps press by lowering your body towards the ground and pushing back up. 5. Return to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Holman Weighted Narrow Squat Jump
Desc: The Holman Weighted Narrow Squat Jump is an explosive exercise that targets the lower body. It helps to build power and strength in the legs.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet together, holding a weight close to your chest. 2. Lower into a narrow squat, keeping your knees aligned with your toes. 3. Explode upward into a jump, reaching your arms overhead. 4. Land softly and immediately lower back into the squat. 5. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Holman Diagonal Deadlift
Desc: The Holman Diagonal Deadlift is a strength exercise that focuses on the posterior chain. It helps improve stability and strength in the back and legs.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet hip-width apart, holding a dumbbell in one hand. 2. Hinge at the hips, lowering the dumbbell diagonally towards the opposite foot. 3. Keep your back straight and engage your core. 4. Return to standing by driving through your heels and squeezing your glutes. 5. Switch sides and repeat.

Title: Holman Weighted Burpee to Triceps Press
Desc: The Holman Weighted Burpee to Triceps Press is a full-body exercise that combines a burpee with a triceps press. It helps improve cardiovascular endurance and upper body strength.
HowTo: 1. Start in a standing position. 2. Drop into a squat and place your hands on the ground. 3. Jump your feet back into a plank position. 4. Perform a push-up. 5. Jump your feet back to the squat position. 6. Stand up and press a weight overhead while engaging your triceps.

Title: Holman Squat Thrust Overhead Press
Desc: The Holman Squat Thrust Overhead Press is a dynamic exercise that targets multiple muscle groups. It combines a squat thrust with an overhead press to build strength and endurance.
HowTo: 1. Begin in a standing position with weights at shoulder height. 2. Drop into a squat and place your hands on the ground. 3. Jump your feet back into a plank position. 4. Jump your feet back to the squat position. 5. Stand up and press the weights overhead.

Title: Holman Weighted Burpee to Chest Press
Desc: The Holman Weighted Burpee to Chest Press is an intense exercise that engages the entire body. It combines a burpee with a chest press to enhance strength and cardiovascular fitness.
HowTo: 1. Start in a standing position with weights. 2. Drop into a squat and place your hands on the ground. 3. Jump your feet back into a plank position. 4. Perform a push-up. 5. Jump your feet back to the squat position. 6. Stand up and press the weights to your chest.

Title: Holman Squat to Right-Arm Overhead Press
Desc: The Holman Squat to Right-Arm Overhead Press is a compound movement that works the lower and upper body. It focuses on building strength and stability through the legs and shoulders.
HowTo: 1. Start in a standing position with a weight in your right hand. 2. Lower into a squat while keeping the weight at shoulder height. 3. Stand up and press the weight overhead with your right arm.

Title: Holman Right Lunge Jump with Right Overhead Press
Desc: The Holman Right Lunge Jump with Right Overhead Press is a powerful exercise that enhances explosive strength and coordination. It targets the legs and shoulders while improving agility.
HowTo: 1. Start in a standing position with a weight in your right hand. 2. Step back into a lunge with your right leg while lowering the weight to shoulder height. 3. Jump up explosively and press the weight overhead as you return to the starting position.

Title: Holman Left Lunge Jump with Left Overhead Press
Desc: The Holman Left Lunge Jump with Left Overhead Press is a dynamic exercise that combines a lunge jump with an overhead press. It targets the legs and shoulders while improving coordination and balance.
HowTo: 1. Start in a standing position. 2. Step forward with your left leg into a lunge position. 3. Jump up explosively while pushing your left arm overhead. 4. Land softly back into the lunge position. 5. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Holman Heavy Hip Drive
Desc: The Holman Heavy Hip Drive is an effective exercise for building strength in the lower body. It focuses on the glutes and hamstrings while enhancing overall power.
HowTo: 1. Sit on the ground with your upper back against a bench. 2. Roll a barbell over your hips. 3. Plant your feet flat on the ground, shoulder-width apart. 4. Drive through your heels to lift your hips towards the ceiling. 5. Squeeze your glutes at the top, then lower back down.

Title: Holman Squat to Left-Arm Overhead Press
Desc: The Holman Squat to Left-Arm Overhead Press combines a squat with an overhead press, targeting the shoulders and core. It helps improve strength and stability.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a dumbbell in your left hand. 2. Lower into a squat while keeping the dumbbell at shoulder height. 3. As you rise from the squat, press the dumbbell overhead with your left arm. 4. Lower the dumbbell back to shoulder height and repeat.

Title: Holman Weighted Lunge Jump to Floor Lunge Jump
Desc: The Holman Weighted Lunge Jump to Floor Lunge Jump is a high-intensity exercise that targets the legs and improves explosive power. It combines weighted lunges with jumps for added difficulty.
HowTo: 1. Start in a standing position holding weights. 2. Step forward into a lunge, then jump explosively from the lunge position. 3. Land softly and immediately step back into a lunge. 4. Alternate legs with each jump.

Title: Holman Alternating Weighted Lunge Jump to Chest Press
Desc: The Holman Alternating Weighted Lunge Jump to Chest Press combines lunges with a chest press, targeting the chest and legs. It enhances strength and coordination.
HowTo: 1. Stand with weights in both hands at chest level. 2. Step forward into a lunge while pressing the weights forward. 3. Jump up and switch legs in the air, landing in a lunge with the opposite leg. 4. Repeat the movement, alternating legs.

Title: Holman Weighted Burpee to Overhead Alternating Reverse Lunge
Desc: The Holman Weighted Burpee to Overhead Alternating Reverse Lunge is a dynamic full-body exercise that combines a burpee with lunges. It helps improve cardiovascular fitness while strengthening multiple muscle groups.
HowTo: 1. Start in a standing position. 2. Drop into a squat and place your hands on the ground. 3. Jump your feet back into a plank position. 4. Perform a push-up. 5. Jump your feet back to your hands. 6. Stand up and lift a weight overhead. 7. Step back into a reverse lunge with one leg, alternating sides.

Title: Holman Weighted 180 Jump to Chest Press
Desc: The Holman Weighted 180 Jump to Chest Press is a powerful exercise that engages the upper body while incorporating explosive movements. It enhances strength and coordination.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart holding weights at chest level. 2. Jump 180 degrees to one side while pressing the weights overhead. 3. Land softly and immediately jump back to the starting position. 4. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Holman Alternating Side Squat Overhead Press
Desc: The Holman Alternating Side Squat Overhead Press targets the shoulders and legs, promoting strength and stability. It combines a squat with an overhead press for a comprehensive workout.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart holding weights at shoulder height. 2. Step to the side into a squat position with one leg while pressing the weights overhead. 3. Return to the starting position and repeat on the other side.

Title: Holman Right Lunge with Right Biceps Curl
Desc: The Holman Right Lunge with Right Biceps Curl is an effective exercise for building arm strength while engaging the lower body. It focuses on the biceps and legs simultaneously.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet together holding a weight in your right hand. 2. Step forward with your right leg into a lunge while curling the weight towards your shoulder. 3. Push back to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Holman Left Lunge with Left Biceps Curl
Desc: The Holman Left Lunge with Left Biceps Curl is similar to the right lunge, focusing on the left side of the body. It effectively builds strength in the arms and legs.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet together holding a weight in your left hand. 2. Step forward with your left leg into a lunge while curling the weight towards your shoulder. 3. Push back to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Holman Squat Thrust to Alternating Front Raise
Desc: The Holman Squat Thrust to Alternating Front Raise is a dynamic exercise that combines a squat thrust with a front raise to engage multiple muscle groups. It is effective for building strength and endurance.
HowTo: 1. Start in a standing position with a dumbbell in each hand. 2. Drop into a squat and place the dumbbells on the ground. 3. Jump your feet back into a plank position. 4. Perform a push-up if desired. 5. Jump your feet back towards your hands. 6. Stand up and raise one dumbbell in front of you, alternating arms with each repetition.

Title: Dumbbell racked reverse lunge
Desc: The dumbbell racked reverse lunge is a popular lower-body movement that targets the muscles of the quads, glutes, hamstrings, and hips. Holding dumbbells in the racked position further challenges the core and upper-back muscles to maintain posture while the lower body moves. Lunge variations are often performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per leg or more, as part of the lower-body portion of a workout. If this movement hurts your knees, try performing split squats instead.
Muscles: quads, glutes, hamstrings, core, upper back
HowTo: 1. Stand with a dumbbell racked on each shoulder. 2. Step back with one leg into a lunge position. 3. Lower your back knee towards the ground while keeping your front knee over your ankle. 4. Push through your front heel to return to the starting position. 5. Alternate legs with each repetition.

Title: Total Fitness Dumbbell Reverse Lunge
Desc: The dumbbell reverse lunge is a great single-leg movement that strengthens and builds the quads, hamstrings, and glutes.
HowTo: 1. Stand with a dumbbell in each hand at your sides. 2. Step back with one leg into a lunge position. 3. Lower your back knee towards the ground while keeping your front knee over your ankle. 4. Push through your front heel to return to the starting position. 5. Alternate legs with each repetition.

Title: Single-arm dumbbell snatch-
Desc: The single-arm dumbbell snatch is an explosive exercise that builds full-body power and targets the muscles of the hips, back, and shoulders. It involves lifting a dumbbell from the ground to overhead in a single movement. It can be performed for low reps with a focus on power and speed, or for higher reps to build muscle or as part of a metabolic conditioning circuit.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and a dumbbell on the ground between your feet. 2. Bend at your hips and knees to grasp the dumbbell with one hand. 3. Explosively extend your hips and legs while pulling the dumbbell up. 4. As the dumbbell rises, drop under it and catch it overhead with your arm extended. 5. Lower the dumbbell back to the ground and repeat.

Title: Total Fitness Dumbbell Step-Up
Desc: The dumbbell step-up is a great exercise for building lower-body strength and power. The dumbbell version is better for intermediate and advanced lifters than beginners, who should begin by performing these unweighted.
HowTo: 1. Stand in front of a sturdy bench or step with a dumbbell in each hand. 2. Step up onto the bench with one foot, pressing through your heel. 3. Bring your other foot up to meet the first on the bench. 4. Step back down with the same foot and then the other. 5. Alternate the leading foot with each repetition.

Title: Single-arm dumbbell front squat
Desc: The single-arm dumbbell front squat is an exercise that targets the quads, glutes, and hamstrings, as well as the upper body. It also challenges oblique strength due to the offset loading. It can be performed in strength and muscle-focused workouts, in circuit training, or as part of a larger dumbbell complex with movements like single-arm dumbbell clean and presses.
HowTo: 1. Stand with a dumbbell in one hand at shoulder height. 2. Squat down by bending your knees and hips, keeping your chest up and back straight. 3. Push through your heels to return to standing, maintaining balance.

Title: King Maker Weighted Jump Squat
Desc: The dumbbell jump squat takes a classic bodybuilding move, the squat, and adds a plyometric element, the jump. It builds not only lower-body strength but also explosiveness.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart. 2. Lower into a squat, then explosively jump upward. 3. Land softly and immediately go into the next squat.

Title: 3D dumbbell lunge
Desc: The 3D dumbbell lunge is a sequence of lower-body exercises that target the muscles of the glutes, quads, and hamstrings from a variety of angles. It consists of one curtsy lunge with each leg, followed by one reverse lunge with each leg. This lunge variation is most commonly performed for multiple rounds as part of a lower-body circuit or workout.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet hip-width apart, holding dumbbells at your sides. 2. Step back into a curtsy lunge, alternating legs, then follow with a reverse lunge. 3. Return to standing and repeat for multiple rounds.

Title: MetaBurn Dumbbell Burpee
