Desc: The MetaBurn Dumbbell Burpee is a full-body exercise that combines a burpee with dumbbell movements to enhance cardiovascular fitness and strength.
HowTo: 1. Start in a standing position with dumbbells in hand. 2. Drop into a squat and place the dumbbells on the floor, then kick your feet back into a plank position. 3. Perform a push-up, return to the squat position, and jump up explosively.

Title: Dumbbell jump squat with rotation
Desc: The dumbbell jump squat with rotation is a popular movement combining an explosive lower-body movement with extra upper-body loading in the form of dumbbells held in the hands. Each jump ends with the body turned 90 degrees, adding a rotational power component to the lift. It is usually performed with light weights for high reps in fat-loss and conditioning workouts.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, holding dumbbells at your sides. 2. Lower into a squat, then jump explosively while rotating your body 90 degrees. 3. Land softly and return to the squat position, repeating the movement.

Title: MetaBurn Dumbbell Wide Squat to Rack
Desc: The MetaBurn Dumbbell Wide Squat to Rack is a lower body exercise that targets the legs and glutes. It combines a wide squat with a racking motion to engage multiple muscle groups.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet wider than shoulder-width apart, holding a dumbbell in each hand. 2. Lower into a squat, keeping your chest up and knees over your toes. 3. Push through your heels to return to standing while racking the dumbbells at shoulder height.

Title: MetaBurn Reverse Lunge To High Pull
Desc: The MetaBurn Reverse Lunge To High Pull is a dynamic exercise that works the legs while also engaging the shoulders. It combines a reverse lunge with a high pull movement to enhance strength and coordination.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet hip-width apart, holding a dumbbell in each hand. 2. Step back into a lunge, lowering your back knee toward the ground. 3. As you return to standing, pull the dumbbells up towards your chin in a high pull motion.

Title: MetaBurn Reverse Lunge With Overhead Raise
Desc: The MetaBurn Reverse Lunge With Overhead Raise targets the legs while also working the shoulders. This exercise combines a reverse lunge with an overhead raise to promote strength and stability.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet hip-width apart, holding a dumbbell in each hand at shoulder height. 2. Step back into a lunge, lowering your back knee toward the floor. 3. As you push back to standing, raise the dumbbells overhead.

Title: MetaBurn Squat to Triceps Extension
Desc: The MetaBurn Squat to Triceps Extension is a compound exercise that targets the arms and legs. It combines a squat with a triceps extension to enhance upper body strength while working the lower body.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, holding a dumbbell with both hands above your head. 2. Lower into a squat while keeping the dumbbell overhead. 3. As you rise from the squat, lower the dumbbell behind your head and extend your arms back up.

Title: 30 Legs Dumbbell Goblet Squat
Desc: The 30 Legs Dumbbell Goblet Squat is a lower body exercise that focuses on building strength in the legs. This squat variation engages the core and improves overall stability.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, holding a dumbbell close to your chest with both hands. 2. Lower into a squat, keeping your chest up and elbows inside your knees. 3. Push through your heels to return to standing.

Title: 30 Legs Dumbbell Squat
Desc: The 30 Legs Dumbbell Squat is a lower body exercise that primarily targets the legs. It involves squatting while holding dumbbells to increase resistance.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a dumbbell in each hand at your sides. 2. Lower your body into a squat position by bending your knees and pushing your hips back, keeping your chest up. 3. Go as low as you can while maintaining good form, then push through your heels to return to the starting position.

Title: Dumbbell step-down reverse lunge
Desc: The dumbbell step-down reverse lunge is an exercise targeting the lower body, particularly the glutes and hamstrings. The front foot is slightly elevated during this movement, making the subsequent step-down more pronounced and difficult. These are usually performed for time or for relatively high reps, such as 10 reps or more per side.
HowTo: 1. Stand with a dumbbell in each hand at your sides. 2. Step back with one foot into a lunge position, lowering your back knee toward the ground. 3. Push through your front heel to return to the starting position, then repeat on the other side.

Title: Tire flip
Desc: The tire flip is an exercise that works the entire body, starting from a deadlift position and ending with a giant tire being flipped over. Each flip moves the tire farther in one direction until a set has been completed. It can be performed for time or reps as part of a functional fitness or athleticism-focused workout.
HowTo: 1. Stand in front of the tire with your feet shoulder-width apart. 2. Bend at your hips and knees to grip the bottom of the tire. 3. Lift the tire by extending your hips and knees, then push it forward and flip it over.

Title: Single Leg Push-off
Desc: The Single Leg Push-off is an exercise that targets the legs and improves balance. It involves pushing off the ground with one leg while maintaining stability.
HowTo: 1. Stand on one leg with the other leg slightly bent behind you. 2. Bend your standing knee and lower your body slightly. 3. Push off the ground with your standing leg to return to the starting position.

Title: Bear crawl sled drag
Desc: The bear crawl sled drag is an advanced variation of the bear crawl exercise involving added resistance from a sled or other weight. If no sled is available, other viable options include dragging chain, a barbell plate, or a tire. The bear crawl sled drag is an intense full-body movement that targets the cardiovascular system as well as a wide range of muscle groups, particularly the shoulders, core, and legs. It can be done in short bursts for power or circuit training, or for longer durations as cardiovascular conditioning.
HowTo: 1. Start in a bear crawl position with your hands and feet on the ground. 2. Attach a sled to your waist or hold onto it. 3. Crawl forward while dragging the sled, keeping your core engaged and maintaining a steady pace.

Title: Bicycling
Desc: Bicycling is a cardiovascular exercise that primarily engages the legs. It can be performed outdoors on a bike or indoors on a stationary bike.
HowTo: 1. Adjust the seat height for comfort. 2. Start pedaling at a moderate pace. 3. Increase resistance or speed as you become more comfortable.

Title: Hex-bar deadlift
Desc: The hex bar deadlift is a variety of deadlift performed in a hexagonal barbell also known as a trap bar. The bar is held with a parallel (palms in) grip outside of the legs. It is biomechanically different from a barbell deadlift in that it lines up with a lifter's center of gravity, rather than placing the weight in front of their body. It activates all of the same muscle groups as conventional or sumo deadlifts, including the glutes, quads, hamstrings, lower back, lats, upper back, and grip.
Muscles: glutes, quads, hamstrings, lower back, lats, upper back, grip
HowTo: 1. Stand in the center of the hex bar with feet shoulder-width apart. 2. Bend at the hips and knees to grip the handles. 3. Keep your back straight and lift the bar by extending your hips and knees simultaneously. 4. Lower the bar back to the ground with control.

Title: Skating
Desc: Skating is a dynamic cardiovascular exercise that engages the legs and core. It can be performed on ice or on roller skates.
HowTo: 1. Start by gliding on one foot while pushing off with the other. 2. Alternate feet in a smooth motion while maintaining balance. 3. Use your arms for balance and propulsion.

Title: Weighted sissy squat
Desc: The weighted sissy squat is an exercise primarily targeting the quadriceps. In sissy squats, the knees travel over the toes, placing the quads under a fairly extreme stretch. They are usually performed for moderate to high reps as part of a lower-body training session.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and hold weights at your sides. 2. Lower your body by bending your knees and keeping your torso upright. 3. Ensure your knees go over your toes while maintaining balance. 4. Push through your heels to return to the starting position.

Title: Dumbbell step-up
Desc: The dumbbell step-up is a great exercise for building lower-body strength and power. It targets all the same muscles as bodyweight step-ups, such as the quads, glutes, and hamstrings, but allows for greater muscular overload.
HowTo: 1. Stand in front of a sturdy bench or step with a dumbbell in each hand. 2. Step up onto the bench with one foot, pressing through your heel. 3. Bring the other foot up to meet it on the bench. 4. Step back down one foot at a time and repeat.

Title: Yoke Walk
Desc: The Yoke Walk is a strength training exercise that involves carrying a yoke across the shoulders while walking. It engages the entire body, particularly the legs and core, and is great for building overall strength and stability.
HowTo: 1. Position the yoke across your shoulders. 2. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. 3. Engage your core and lift the yoke off the ground. 4. Walk forward, maintaining a strong posture.

Title: Front Cone Hops (or hurdle hops)
Desc: Front Cone Hops are a dynamic exercise that improves agility and cardiovascular endurance. They involve hopping over cones or hurdles, which enhances lower body strength and coordination.
HowTo: 1. Set up cones or hurdles in a straight line. 2. Stand in front of the first cone. 3. Jump over the cone, landing softly on the other side. 4. Repeat for each cone in succession.

Title: Weighted Squat
Desc: The Weighted Squat is a fundamental strength exercise that targets the lower body. It involves squatting while holding weights, which increases resistance and builds muscle strength.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, holding weights at your sides or on your shoulders. 2. Lower your body by bending your knees and hips, keeping your back straight. 3. Go as low as comfortable, then push through your heels to return to standing.

Title: Bench skip
Desc: The bench skip is an explosive lower-body exercise that involves alternating the position of the feet on top of a bench. It primarily targets the muscles of the lower body, but is also a serious cardiovascular challenge. It is often performed for high reps or for time as part of a fat-loss or athleticism-focused workout or circuit.
HowTo: 1. Stand in front of a bench with feet shoulder-width apart. 2. Jump onto the bench with one foot, bringing the other knee up towards your chest. 3. Alternate feet quickly, skipping from one foot to the other.

Title: Backward Drag
Desc: The Backward Drag is a strength exercise that targets the posterior chain, including the hamstrings and glutes. It involves dragging a weight backward, which helps improve strength and stability.
HowTo: 1. Attach a weight to a sled or use a resistance band. 2. Stand facing away from the weight, feet shoulder-width apart. 3. Bend your knees slightly and lean forward. 4. Begin to walk backward, dragging the weight behind you.

Title: Sled Push
Desc: The sled push is a conditioning exercise that targets the cardiovascular system and the muscles of the lower body. It involves pushing a sled along a turf or other flat surface either for time or distance. Depending on your type of equipment, you may be pushing handles or straps in front of the sled. It can be used as part of a dynamic warm-up or for power training, as a finisher, or as part of a conditioning workout or circuit.
HowTo: 1. Stand behind the sled with feet shoulder-width apart. 2. Grip the handles or straps firmly. 3. Lean forward slightly and push the sled forward using your legs and arms. 4. Continue pushing for the desired distance or time.

Title: Barbell squat with plate slide
Desc: The barbell squat with plate slide is an exercise targeting the quadriceps, with the plate slide also working the adductors and abductors. It can help you get more total-leg and hip development out of squats, but is probably not the sort of thing you want to do with a seriously heavy load on your back.
HowTo: 1. Set up a barbell on your upper back. 2. Stand on a plate slide machine with your feet shoulder-width apart. 3. Lower your body into a squat while sliding the plate. 4. Push through your heels to return to standing.

Title: Suspended split squat
Desc: The suspended split squat is a single-leg squat variation performed with the rear leg in a suspension strap system. This allows the rear leg to move slightly more naturally than it would be able to on a bench. The exercise targets the quads, hamstring, and glute muscles on the front leg, but also taxes and stretches the quads on the rear leg.
HowTo: 1. Attach your rear foot to a suspension strap. 2. Stand with your front foot forward and lower your body into a squat. 3. Keep your chest up and core engaged. 4. Push through your front heel to return to standing.

Title: Intermediate Hip Flexor and Quad Stretch
Desc: The Intermediate Hip Flexor and Quad Stretch is designed to improve flexibility in the hip flexors and quadriceps. It is beneficial for recovery and mobility.
HowTo: 1. Kneel on one knee with the other foot in front, creating a 90-degree angle. 2. Push your hips forward while keeping your back straight. 3. Hold the stretch for 20-30 seconds, then switch sides.

Title: Sled Drag - Harness
Desc: The sled drag is a conditioning exercise that involves pulling a sled behind you, which targets the lower body and cardiovascular system. It can be used for strength and endurance training.
HowTo: 1. Attach a harness to your body and connect it to the sled. 2. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. 3. Lean slightly forward and begin walking or running backward to drag the sled. 4. Maintain a steady pace for the desired distance.

Title: Burpee over barbell
Desc: The burpee over barbell is an exercise that takes the burpee, a popular functional fitness move, and separates each rep with a lateral jump across the barbell. It works the cardiovascular system, but also the chest, quads, glutes, hamstrings, and abs. This exercise is a favorite of many athletes, including obstacle race participants.
HowTo: 1. Start in a standing position. 2. Drop into a squat position and place your hands on the ground. 3. Kick your feet back into a plank position. 4. Perform a push-up. 5. Jump your feet back to the squat position. 6. Jump laterally over the barbell. 7. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Dumbbell walking lunge-
Desc: The dumbbell walking lunge is a popular lower-body movement that targets the muscles of the quads, glutes, hamstrings, and hips. It also works the core and upper-back muscles to maintain posture while the lower body moves. The dumbbell walking lunge is often performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per leg or more, as part of the lower-body portion of a workout. If this movement hurts your knees, try performing reverse lunges or split squats instead.
Muscles: quads, glutes, hamstrings, hips, core, upper back
HowTo: 1. Stand upright holding dumbbells at your sides. 2. Step forward with one leg and lower your hips until both knees are bent at about a 90-degree angle. 3. Push through the front heel to return to the starting position. 4. Alternate legs and repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Single-Leg Box Jump
Desc: The Single-Leg Box Jump is an explosive exercise that develops power and balance. It primarily targets the lower body, particularly the quads and hamstrings.
HowTo: 1. Stand on one leg in front of a sturdy box or platform. 2. Bend your knee slightly and swing your arms back. 3. Explosively jump onto the box using the leg you are standing on. 4. Land softly with your knee slightly bent. 5. Step back down and repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Conan's Wheel
Desc: Conan's Wheel is a dynamic exercise that engages the entire body, focusing on core stability and strength. It is particularly effective for building functional strength and endurance.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a weight or a barbell in front of you. 2. Rotate your torso to one side while keeping your hips facing forward. 3. Move the weight in a circular motion around your body, engaging your core throughout. 4. Complete the circle and return to the starting position. 5. Repeat in the opposite direction.

Title: Single-Leg Hop Progression
Desc: The Single-Leg Hop Progression is a mobility and stability exercise that enhances balance and coordination. It focuses on strengthening the lower body while improving joint stability.
HowTo: 1. Stand on one leg with your knee slightly bent. 2. Hop forward on the same leg, landing softly. 3. Continue hopping forward for a set distance or number of hops. 4. Switch legs and repeat. 5. Progress by increasing distance or adding lateral hops.

Title: Rickshaw Deadlift
Desc: The Rickshaw Deadlift is a variation of the traditional deadlift that emphasizes the posterior chain. It is performed using a rickshaw or similar implement to lift heavy weights off the ground.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, with the rickshaw in front of you. 2. Bend at the hips and knees to grip the handles. 3. Keep your back straight and engage your core. 4. Lift the rickshaw by extending your hips and knees until you are standing upright. 5. Lower the rickshaw back to the ground with control.

Title: Single-cone sprint drill
Desc: The single-cone sprint drill is an agility drill that involves moving quickly around a single cone. It demands that an athlete start, stop, and change directions all in a short period of time and a small space. It can be beneficial for football players and other athletes where quick changes of direction are important.
HowTo: 1. Set up a cone in an open area. 2. Start at a designated point a few meters away from the cone. 3. Sprint towards the cone, touch it, and quickly change direction to sprint back. 4. Repeat the drill for a set amount of time or repetitions.

Title: Single-Leg Stride Jump
Desc: The Single-Leg Stride Jump is a plyometric exercise that develops explosive power in the legs. It involves jumping forward off one leg and landing on the same leg.
HowTo: 1. Stand on one leg with your knee slightly bent. 2. Swing your arms back and prepare to jump. 3. Jump forward explosively off your standing leg. 4. Land softly on the same leg, absorbing the impact with your knee slightly bent.

Title: Trap Bar Jump
Desc: The Trap Bar Jump is a dynamic exercise that focuses on developing lower body power. It is performed using a trap bar to facilitate jumping movements.
HowTo: 1. Stand inside the trap bar with your feet shoulder-width apart. 2. Grip the handles and lower your body into a squat position. 3. Explode upward, jumping as high as you can while holding the trap bar. 4. Land softly and reset for the next jump.

Title: Single-Leg Lateral Hop
Desc: The Single-Leg Lateral Hop is a mobility and stability exercise that helps improve balance and coordination. It involves hopping side to side on one leg.
HowTo: 1. Stand on one leg with your knee slightly bent. 2. Hop laterally to one side, landing softly on the same leg. 3. Immediately hop back to the starting position. 4. Repeat for a set number of hops.

Title: Burpee Box-Jumps
Desc: Burpee Box-Jumps combine a burpee with a box jump, providing a full-body workout that enhances cardiovascular endurance and strength. This exercise is great for building explosive power and agility.
HowTo: 1. Start in a standing position. 2. Drop into a squat and place your hands on the ground. 3. Kick your feet back into a plank position. 4. Perform a push-up (optional). 5. Jump your feet back towards your hands. 6. Explode upwards into a jump onto the box.

Title: Sandbag Load
Desc: The Sandbag Load is a functional strength exercise that mimics the movement of lifting and loading heavy objects. It engages multiple muscle groups and improves overall strength and stability.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and a sandbag in front of you. 2. Bend at the hips and knees to lower your body. 3. Grip the sandbag and lift it by extending your hips and knees. 4. Load the sandbag onto your shoulder or designated area.

Title: Single-leg knee-tap squat
Desc: The single-leg knee-tap squat is a single-leg squat variation that involves floating the back leg over the ground on the descent until touching just the knee to the ground or a pad. It is similar to a lunge, but without touching the back foot to the ground. It is an intense strength and coordination challenge that can work in any strength- or athleticism-focused workout.
HowTo: 1. Stand on one leg with the other leg extended behind you. 2. Lower your body into a squat while reaching down to tap your knee with your opposite hand. 3. Keep your back straight and core engaged. 4. Return to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Car Deadlift
Desc: The Car Deadlift is a unique strength exercise that mimics the action of lifting a heavy object from the ground. It targets the posterior chain and improves overall strength.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and a barbell or heavy object in front of you. 2. Bend at the hips and knees to grip the object. 3. Keep your back straight as you lift the object by extending your hips and knees. 4. Lower it back down with control.

Title: Barbell Squat To A Box
Desc: The Barbell Squat To A Box is a strength exercise that helps improve squat depth and form. It builds strength in the lower body and engages the core for stability.
HowTo: 1. Set a box at a height that allows you to squat down to it. 2. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and a barbell on your back. 3. Lower your body into a squat until you lightly touch the box. 4. Push through your heels to return to standing.

Title: Double Under
Desc: The Double Under is a high-intensity jump rope exercise that enhances cardiovascular fitness and coordination. It involves swinging the rope twice under the feet for each jump.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and hold the jump rope handles. 2. Start swinging the rope overhead and jump off the ground. 3. As you jump, flick your wrists to swing the rope twice under your feet before landing.

Title: Plate push
Desc: The plate push is a conditioning exercise that targets the cardiovascular system and the muscles of the lower body. It involves pushing a plate along turf or another flat surface either for time or distance. It can be used as part of a dynamic warm-up or for power training, as a finisher, or as part of a conditioning workout or circuit.
HowTo: 1. Stand behind a weight plate on a flat surface. 2. Bend your knees and grip the plate with both hands. 3. Push the plate forward using your legs and body weight, keeping your back straight. 4. Continue pushing for the desired distance or time.

Title: Hybrid deadlift
Desc: The hybrid deadlift is a version of the barbell deadlift in which the lifter's stance is wider than a conventional position, but narrower than a wide sumo deadlift. The feet are just outside the shoulders and grip placement is just inside of the legs. Many non-competitive lifters find this position to be more spine friendly and strong than either of the other traditional stances. This variation of the deadlift has all the same benefits as the others, and is capable of building serious full-body and posterior chain strength.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet slightly wider than shoulder-width apart and a barbell on the ground in front of you. 2. Bend at the hips and knees to grip the barbell just inside your legs. 3. Keep your chest up and back straight as you lift the barbell by extending your hips and knees simultaneously. 4. Lower the barbell back to the ground with control.

Title: Boss Everline Suspension Side Run
Desc: The Boss Everline Suspension Side Run is a dynamic exercise that engages multiple muscle groups while improving cardiovascular endurance. It involves running sideways using suspension straps for added resistance.
HowTo: 1. Attach suspension straps to a sturdy anchor point. 2. Stand facing the anchor point and hold the straps with both hands. 3. Lean back slightly and run sideways, pulling on the straps for resistance. 4. Alternate sides for the desired duration.

Title: Boss Everline Lunge Sled Push
Desc: The Boss Everline Lunge Sled Push is an effective lower body exercise that enhances strength and power. It involves pushing a sled while performing lunges, targeting the legs and core.
HowTo: 1. Stand behind a sled with your feet shoulder-width apart. 2. Grip the sled handles and step forward into a lunge position. 3. Push the sled forward with your front leg while maintaining a strong core. 4. Alternate legs and continue pushing for the desired distance.

Title: Squat Bottom Position Hold
Desc: The squat bottom position hold is an isometric exercise that focuses on building strength and stability in the squat position. It is beneficial for improving squat depth and overall leg strength.
HowTo: 1. Lower into a squat position until your thighs are parallel to the ground. 2. Hold this position for a specified duration, keeping your chest up and core engaged.

Title: TRX Squat Jump
Desc: The TRX squat jump is a dynamic exercise that combines strength and cardio, targeting the lower body while improving explosive power. It is performed using TRX straps for support.
HowTo: 1. Stand facing the TRX straps, holding them with both hands. 2. Lower into a squat, then jump explosively upward while using the straps for balance. 3. Land softly and immediately go into the next squat jump.

Title: Landmine squat
Desc: The landmine squat is a lower-body exercise that uses an angled barbell anchored at floor level in a landmine device. It can also be performed by sticking a barbell in the corner of a room, preferably in a towel to protect the walls. The landmine squat is similar in many ways to a goblet squat, but with slight differences due to the angle of the barbell. It can be trained in traditional muscle and strength-focused rep ranges or for higher reps.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, facing the landmine bar. 2. Hold the end of the barbell with both hands at chest level. 3. Squat down by bending your knees and pushing your hips back, keeping your chest up. 4. Return to standing by pushing through your heels.

Title: Dumbbell Bulgarian split squat
Desc: The dumbbell Bulgarian split squat is a single-leg exercise targeting the quads, glutes, and hamstrings. Overloading the movement with dumbbells usually presents less of a balance challenge than putting a barbell on the back. Dumbbell split squats are usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per leg, but they are also effective done with heavier weights in lower rep ranges.
HowTo: 1. Stand a few feet in front of a bench or elevated surface. 2. Place one foot behind you on the bench. 3. Lower your body into a squat on the standing leg, keeping your chest up and core engaged. 4. Push through your heel to return to the starting position.

Title: Holman Towel Alternating Prisoner Reverse Lunge
Desc: The Holman towel alternating prisoner reverse lunge is a unique variation of the reverse lunge that incorporates a towel for added challenge. It targets the lower body while also engaging the core for stability.
HowTo: 1. Stand upright with a towel held behind your head, elbows bent. 2. Step back with one leg into a lunge position, lowering your hips until both knees are bent at about 90 degrees. 3. Push through the front heel to return to standing and alternate legs.

Title: Holman Weighted Burpee to Belly Touch
Desc: The Holman Weighted Burpee to Belly Touch is a high-intensity exercise that combines a burpee with a belly touch for added core engagement. It helps improve cardiovascular fitness and overall body strength.
HowTo: 1. Start in a standing position. 2. Drop into a squat and place your hands on the ground. 3. Jump your feet back into a plank position. 4. Perform a belly touch by lowering your body to the ground. 5. Push back up to the plank position. 6. Jump your feet back towards your hands and explode up into a jump.

Title: Holman Weighted Burpee to Front Punch
Desc: The Holman Weighted Burpee to Front Punch is a dynamic exercise that combines a burpee with a front punch, enhancing both strength and cardio. This exercise targets multiple muscle groups while improving coordination.
HowTo: 1. Begin in a standing position. 2. Drop into a squat and place your hands on the floor. 3. Jump back into a plank position. 4. Perform a push-up (optional). 5. Jump back to the squat position and throw a front punch with your right arm. 6. Jump up explosively, raising your arms overhead.

Title: Holman Weighted Low Squat Punch
Desc: The Holman Weighted Low Squat Punch is a strength exercise that targets the lower body while incorporating an upper body punch for coordination. It helps build strength in the legs and core stability.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, holding weights. 2. Lower into a squat position, keeping your back straight. 3. From the squat, punch forward with your right arm. 4. Return to the squat position and repeat with the left arm. 5. Stand back up to the starting position.

Title: Holman Weighted Hook Punch to Squat Thrust
Desc: The Holman Weighted Hook Punch to Squat Thrust is a full-body exercise that combines strength training with explosive movements. It enhances muscle endurance and coordination.
HowTo: 1. Start in a standing position with weights. 2. Perform a squat thrust by placing your hands on the ground and jumping your feet back. 3. From the plank position, perform a hook punch with your right arm. 4. Jump your feet back towards your hands and stand up, repeating the movement.

Title: Holman Towel Alternating Side Lunge Squat
Desc: The Holman Towel Alternating Side Lunge Squat is a lower body exercise that targets the legs and improves flexibility. It incorporates a towel for added resistance and balance.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet hip-width apart, holding a towel in both hands. 2. Step to the right into a side lunge, keeping the towel extended in front. 3. Push back to the center and repeat on the left side. 4. Alternate between sides for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Holman Weighted Burpee to Renegade Side Punch
Desc: The Holman Weighted Burpee to Renegade Side Punch is a high-intensity exercise that combines a burpee with a renegade row and a punch. It engages multiple muscle groups and improves cardiovascular fitness.
HowTo: 1. Start in a standing position with weights in your hands. 2. Drop into a squat and place the weights on the ground. 3. Jump your feet back into a plank position. 4. Perform a renegade row by pulling one weight to your side while stabilizing your body. 5. Return to plank, jump your feet back to your hands, and stand up. 6. Finish with a side punch to one side, then repeat.

Title: Holman Weighted Reverse Lunge to Knee-Up Overhead Press
Desc: The Holman Weighted Reverse Lunge to Knee-Up Overhead Press is a compound exercise that targets the legs and shoulders. It combines a reverse lunge with an overhead press, enhancing strength and stability.
HowTo: 1. Stand with weights at shoulder height. 2. Step back into a reverse lunge with your right leg. 3. Push through your left heel to return to standing while lifting your right knee up. 4. Press the weights overhead as you lift your knee. 5. Repeat on the other side.

Title: Holman Lunge Jump with Overhead Press
Desc: The Holman Lunge Jump with Overhead Press is a dynamic exercise that builds explosive power in the legs while engaging the shoulders. It combines a jump lunge with an overhead press for a full-body workout.
HowTo: 1. Stand with weights at shoulder height. 2. Step forward into a lunge with your right leg. 3. Jump explosively from the lunge position, switching legs in mid-air. 4. As you land, press the weights overhead. 5. Repeat the movement, alternating legs.

Title: Holman Weighted Burpee to Belly Touch to Standing T
Desc: The Holman Weighted Burpee to Belly Touch to Standing T is a challenging full-body exercise that enhances strength and endurance. It incorporates a burpee with a belly touch and a standing T position for balance.
HowTo: 1. Start in a standing position with weights. 2. Drop into a squat and place the weights on the ground. 3. Jump back into a plank position. 4. Perform a belly touch by lowering your body to the ground. 5. Push back up to plank, jump your feet forward, and stand up. 6. Extend your arms out to the side in a T position.

Title: Holman Weighted Squat Jump
Desc: The Holman Weighted Squat Jump is an explosive exercise that builds strength and power in the lower body. It combines a squat with a jump, engaging multiple muscle groups.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, holding weights at your sides. 2. Lower into a squat, keeping your chest up and back straight. 3. Explode upward into a jump, driving your arms up for momentum. 4. Land softly and immediately lower back into the squat for the next repetition.

Title: Holman Weighted Plie Squat
Desc: The Holman Weighted Plie Squat is a lower body exercise that targets the legs and glutes. It involves a wide stance squat with added weight for increased resistance.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet wider than shoulder-width apart and toes pointed out. 2. Hold a weight in both hands at chest level. 3. Lower your body into a squat, keeping your back straight and chest up. 4. Push through your heels to return to the starting position.

Title: Holman Heels-Elevated Sissy Squat
Desc: The Holman Heels-Elevated Sissy Squat focuses on the quadriceps and improves lower body strength. Elevating the heels increases the range of motion and emphasizes the front of the legs.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your heels elevated on a platform or weight plate. 2. Keep your torso upright and lower your body by bending your knees. 3. Go as low as you can while maintaining balance. 4. Push through your heels to return to the starting position.

Title: Holman Squat Jump to Overhead Press
Desc: The Holman Squat Jump to Overhead Press is a dynamic exercise that combines a squat jump with an overhead press. It builds explosive power and engages multiple muscle groups.
HowTo: 1. Start in a standing position with feet shoulder-width apart and a weight in each hand. 2. Perform a squat, then jump explosively upwards. 3. As you land, press the weights overhead. 4. Return to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Holman 180 Jump to Overhead Press
Desc: The Holman 180 Jump to Overhead Press is a high-intensity exercise that enhances agility and strength. It combines a jump with a rotational movement and an overhead press.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, holding weights at shoulder height. 2. Jump 180 degrees while rotating your body. 3. As you land, press the weights overhead. 4. Return to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Holman Weighted Burpee to Row
Desc: The Holman Weighted Burpee to Row is a full-body exercise that combines cardio and strength training. It involves a burpee followed by a rowing motion with weights.
HowTo: 1. Start in a standing position with weights in hand. 2. Drop into a squat and place the weights on the ground. 3. Kick your feet back into a plank position. 4. Perform a row with each weight, then jump back to the squat position. 5. Stand up and repeat.

Title: Holman Weighted Burpee to 180 Jump
Desc: The Holman Weighted Burpee to 180 Jump is a high-intensity exercise that combines a burpee with a jump. It engages multiple muscle groups while improving cardiovascular fitness.
HowTo: 1. Start in a standing position. 2. Drop into a squat and place your hands on the ground. 3. Kick your feet back into a plank position. 4. Perform a push-up. 5. Jump your feet back to your hands. 6. Explode upwards into a 180-degree jump.

Title: Holman Weighted 180 Jump
Desc: The Holman Weighted 180 Jump is an explosive movement that develops power and agility. It focuses on jumping mechanics while incorporating weight for added resistance.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and hold a weight. 2. Bend your knees and lower into a quarter squat. 3. Swing your arms back and then explosively jump 180 degrees. 4. Land softly and reset for the next jump.

Title: Holman Weighted Narrow-Mid-Wide Hop
Desc: The Holman Weighted Narrow-Mid-Wide Hop is a dynamic exercise that enhances coordination and cardiovascular endurance. It involves hopping in different foot positions while maintaining balance.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet together. 2. Hop forward into a narrow stance, then return to the starting position. 3. Next, hop into a mid stance, and then back. 4. Finally, hop into a wide stance and return.

Title: Holman Alternating Weighted Diagonal Burpee
Desc: The Holman Alternating Weighted Diagonal Burpee is a challenging exercise that combines burpees with diagonal movements. It targets multiple muscle groups and improves overall fitness.
HowTo: 1. Start in a standing position holding a weight. 2. Drop into a squat and place your hands on the ground. 3. Kick your feet back into a plank position. 4. Perform a push-up. 5. Jump your feet back to your hands. 6. Lift one weight diagonally overhead as you jump up.

Title: Holman Towel Burpee to Push-Up
Desc: The Holman Towel Burpee to Push-Up is a full-body exercise that incorporates a towel for added resistance. It builds strength and endurance through a combination of burpees and push-ups.
HowTo: 1. Start in a standing position with a towel in both hands. 2. Drop into a squat and place the towel on the ground. 3. Kick your feet back into a plank position. 4. Perform a push-up while holding the towel. 5. Jump your feet back to your hands. 6. Stand up and repeat.

Title: Holman Towel Right Side Squat
Desc: The Holman Towel Right Side Squat is a lower body exercise that targets the legs and improves balance. It involves squatting while holding a towel for resistance, engaging various leg muscles.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a towel in your right hand. 2. Lower your body into a squat position while extending your right leg to the side. 3. Push through your left heel to return to the starting position. 4. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions, then switch sides.

Title: ACFT Sprint-drag-carry
Desc: The sprint-drag-carry is a strength and endurance relay that is part of the new Army Combat Fitness Test or ACFT. It combines sprinting, reverse sled drag, side shuffle, and a farmer's carry to test overall strength and athletic conditioning. Practicing this relay as a drill is great for developing strenght, speed, endurance, and power, and can also be great conditioning work for lifters and athletes of all ability levels.
HowTo: 1. Start with a sprint to the sled and perform a reverse drag. 2. After dragging the sled, perform a side shuffle to the next station. 3. Complete the farmer's carry with weights, then sprint back to the starting point. 4. Repeat as necessary for conditioning.

Title: Cable Hip Adduction
Desc: Cable Hip Adduction is an exercise that targets the hip adductor muscles, helping to strengthen the inner thighs. It is performed using a cable machine for resistance.
HowTo: 1. Attach an ankle strap to the low pulley of a cable machine. 2. Stand next to the machine and attach the strap to the ankle farthest from the machine. 3. Keeping your leg straight, pull the cable across your body towards the machine. 4. Slowly return to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Cable Deadlifts
Desc: Cable Deadlifts are a variation of traditional deadlifts that utilize a cable machine for resistance. This exercise focuses on the posterior chain, enhancing strength and stability.
HowTo: 1. Set the cable machine to a low position and attach a bar or handle. 2. Stand facing the machine with feet shoulder-width apart, grasping the handle. 3. With a flat back, hinge at the hips to lower the weight while keeping your knees slightly bent. 4. Drive through your heels to return to the standing position.

Title: KV Cable Squat
Desc: KV Cable Squat is a strength exercise that targets the lower body using a cable machine for added resistance. It helps improve leg strength and stability.
HowTo: 1. Attach a cable handle to the low pulley of a cable machine. 2. Stand facing the machine, holding the handle with both hands. 3. Lower your body into a squat while keeping tension on the cable. 4. Push through your heels to return to the starting position.

Title: Single-Leg Press
Desc: The single-leg leg press is an exercise targeting the quadriceps one leg at a time. Many lifters prefer the leg press to squatting for several reasons, including the perception that its safer for the spine.
HowTo: 1. Sit on the leg press machine with your back against the pad. 2. Place one foot on the platform and the other foot off the platform. 3. Push the platform away by extending your leg, then slowly return to the starting position.

Title: Stair climber
Desc: The stair climber is a popular cardio machine found in most commercial gyms. Along with burning a ton of calories, the stair climber also helps build strength in the lower body, especially the glutes. It can work well at higher speeds for interval-style conditioning training, but also works well at slower paces for steady-state cardio.
HowTo: 1. Step onto the stair climber and adjust the settings. 2. Begin stepping in a controlled manner, alternating legs, and maintain a steady pace or increase speed for intervals.

Title: Leg Press
Desc: The leg press is a machine exercise targeting the quadriceps. Its favorite among lifters who prefer the seated position to standing with a load on the spine.
HowTo: 1. Sit on the leg press machine with your feet shoulder-width apart on the platform. 2. Push the platform away by extending your legs, then slowly lower it back down by bending your knees.

Title: Elliptical trainer
Desc: The elliptical trainer is a popular machine for cardiovascular training without the significant impact on your joints of running. On many machines, you can adjust the resistance level to make the movement more difficult for all four limbs. The elliptical is a mainstay in most commercial gyms, and can be equally effective for HIIT-style interval workouts or for longer-duration endurance work.
HowTo: 1. Step onto the elliptical trainer and select your desired resistance and incline. 2. Begin moving your legs and arms in a coordinated manner, maintaining a steady pace or adjusting for intervals.

Title: Narrow-stance leg press
Desc: The narrow-stance leg press is a machine-based exercise that targets the muscles of the legs. It emphasizes the quads, particularly the muscles of the outer quads and hips. It is often used as an accessory for squats, or as a muscle-building movement during lower-body training when it is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more.
HowTo: 1. Sit on the narrow-stance leg press machine with your feet positioned close together on the platform. 2. Push the platform away by extending your legs, focusing on using your quads, then return to the starting position.

Title: Narrow Stance Hack Squats
Desc: Narrow stance hack squats primarily target the quadriceps while also engaging the glutes and hamstrings. This variation emphasizes the quads more than traditional squats due to the narrower foot placement.
HowTo: 1. Stand on the hack squat machine with your back against the pad. 2. Position your feet shoulder-width apart or closer on the platform. 3. Lower your body by bending your knees and hips until your thighs are parallel to the ground. 4. Push through your heels to return to the starting position.

Title: Stairmaster
Desc: The stair climber is a popular cardio machine found in most commercial gyms. Along with burning a ton of calories, the stair climber also helps build strength in the lower body, especially the glutes. It can work well at higher speeds for interval-style conditioning training, but also works well at slower paces for steady-state cardio.
HowTo: 1. Step onto the stair climber and adjust the settings if necessary. 2. Start climbing by placing one foot on a step and then the other. 3. Maintain a steady pace or increase speed for intervals. 4. Keep your posture upright and engage your core.

Title: Machine Squat
Desc: Machine squats are a controlled way to perform squats using a machine that guides your movement. They are beneficial for isolating the lower body muscles while providing stability.
HowTo: 1. Sit on the machine with your back against the pad and feet on the platform. 2. Adjust the machine to fit your body size. 3. Lower the weight by bending your knees until your thighs are parallel to the ground. 4. Push through your heels to return to the starting position.

Title: Smith machine back squat
Desc: The Smith machine back squat is a machine-based exercise targeting the muscles of the lower body. The Smith machine mimics a barbell but provides more stability. This movement can be programmed in low reps for strength or higher reps for muscle and strength endurance. It is often performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of a full-body or lower-body workout.
HowTo: 1. Set the Smith machine bar at shoulder height and load it with an appropriate weight. 2. Position yourself under the bar, resting it on your upper back. 3. Stand up to lift the bar off the rack and step back. 4. Lower your body by bending your knees and hips, then push back up to the starting position.

Title: Leg Extensions
Desc: The leg extension is an isolation exercise for the quads.
HowTo: 1. Sit on the leg extension machine with your back against the pad and feet under the padded bar. 2. Adjust the machine to fit your leg length. 3. Extend your legs by straightening your knees until they are fully extended. 4. Slowly lower the weight back to the starting position.

Title: Treadmill running
Desc: Treadmill running is a popular cardiovascular exercise performed on a machine that is available in most gyms. Performing this exercise on a treadmill allows you to adjust the speed of your running and, depending on the machine, perform it on an adjustable incline. Many machines also have built-in heart rate monitors and timers to help you track your progress.
HowTo: 1. Start by adjusting the treadmill to your desired speed and incline. 2. Begin running at a steady pace, maintaining good form and posture throughout the exercise.

Title: Stationary bike
Desc: The stationary bike is a popular cardio machine found in most commercial gyms. Along with burning a ton of calories, the stationary bike also helps develop the lower body. Stationary bikes come in multiple variations, ranging from ones that resemble riding a bike, to recumbent bikes, to fan bikes that work both the arms and the legs. No matter the variation, a stationary bike can work well at higher speeds for interval-style conditioning training, but also works well at slower paces for steady-state cardio.
HowTo: 1. Adjust the seat height and resistance on the stationary bike. 2. Begin pedaling at a comfortable pace, gradually increasing speed or resistance as desired.

Title: Treadmill jogging
Desc: Treadmill jogging is a popular cardiovascular exercise performed on a machine that is available in most gyms. Performing this exercise on a treadmill allows you to adjust the speed of your jogging and, depending on the machine, perform it on an adjustable incline. Many machines also have built-in heart rate monitors and timers to help you track your progress.
HowTo: 1. Set the treadmill to a comfortable jogging speed and incline. 2. Jog steadily while maintaining proper running form and breathing.

Title: Recumbent Bike
Desc: The recumbent bike is a low-impact cardiovascular exercise machine that allows you to sit back while pedaling, making it easier on the joints. It targets the lower body effectively while providing a comfortable workout experience.
HowTo: 1. Adjust the seat to ensure your feet can comfortably reach the pedals. 2. Start pedaling at a moderate pace, adjusting resistance as needed.

Title: Smith machine leg press
Desc: The Smith machine leg press is a machine-based movement that targets the quads, glutes, and hamstrings. It can serve as a substitute for the leg press or be programmed similarly to the leg press. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of lower-body training. If your Smith machine has safety bars, set them at a height that allows you a full range of motion while giving adequate protection from the weight potentially falling.
HowTo: 1. Position yourself on the Smith machine with your back against the pad and feet shoulder-width apart on the platform. 2. Lower the weight by bending your knees, then push through your heels to return to the starting position.

Title: Lying Machine Squat
Desc: The Lying Machine Squat is a lower body exercise that primarily targets the quadriceps and glutes. It is performed using a machine that provides support and stability.
HowTo: 1. Adjust the machine to fit your body size. 2. Sit down with your back against the pad and feet on the platform. 3. Push through your heels to extend your legs while keeping your back pressed against the pad. 4. Slowly lower back to the starting position.

Title: Seated Leg Press
Desc: The seated leg press is a lower body exercise that targets the quads, adductors, glutes, and hamstrings.
HowTo: 1. Sit on the leg press machine with your back against the pad. 2. Place your feet shoulder-width apart on the platform. 3. Push the platform away by extending your legs while keeping a slight bend in your knees. 4. Slowly return to the starting position.

Title: Smith machine pistol squat
Desc: The Smith machine pistol squat is a machine-based exercise that targets the quads, glutes, and hamstrings. It is similar in form to a pistol squat but is performed with a bar on the shoulders. This adds extra resistance, but also eliminates some of the balance challenge of single-leg squats. This squat variation can be performed in low reps for strength or for higher reps for muscle gain.
HowTo: 1. Set the Smith machine bar at shoulder height. 2. Stand with one leg extended forward and the other leg on the ground. 3. Lower your body by bending the knee of the standing leg while keeping the other leg straight. 4. Push through the heel to return to standing.

Title: Leverage Deadlift
Desc: The Leverage Deadlift is a strength exercise that targets the posterior chain, including the hamstrings, glutes, and lower back. It is performed using a leverage machine that allows for a safer lifting position.
HowTo: 1. Stand on the platform of the leverage machine with your feet shoulder-width apart. 2. Grip the handles or bar with both hands. 3. Push through your heels to lift the weight while keeping your back straight. 4. Lower the weight back to the starting position with control.

Title: Leg press-
Desc: The leg press is a machine exercise targeting the leg muscles, including the quads, glutes, and hamstrings. It's a favorite among lifters who prefer the seated position to standing with a load on the spine. The leg press is often used as an accessory for squats or deadlifts, but can also be the main lower-body movement in a workout. It is often performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more.
HowTo: 1. Sit on the leg press machine with your back against the pad. 2. Place your feet on the platform shoulder-width apart. 3. Push the platform away by extending your legs. 4. Slowly lower the platform back to the starting position.

Title: TBS Hack Squat
Desc: The hack squat is a machine-based exercise that targets the muscles of the legs, particularly the quadriceps. It is often used as an accessory for squats, but can also be the main lower-body movement in a workout. It is often performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more.
HowTo: 1. Position yourself on the hack squat machine with your back against the pad. 2. Place your feet shoulder-width apart on the platform. 3. Lower your body by bending your knees until your thighs are parallel to the ground. 4. Push through your heels to return to the starting position.

Title: Leg Extensions - Gethin Variation
Desc: The leg extension is an isolation exercise for the quads.
HowTo: 1. Sit on the leg extension machine with your back against the pad. 2. Adjust the pad so it rests on your lower legs just above your ankles. 3. Extend your legs to lift the weight, squeezing your quads at the top. 4. Slowly lower back to the starting position.

Title: Seated leg press-
Desc: The seated leg press is a machine-based exercise that targets the quads, glutes, and hamstrings. It is similar in many ways to larger leg press machines, but often utilizes a selectorized weight stack rather than plate loading. Leg press variations are often used as an accessory for squats or deadlifts, but can also be the main lower-body movement in a workout. This movement is often performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more.
HowTo: 1. Sit on the leg press machine with your back against the pad and feet on the platform. 2. Adjust the seat so your knees are at a 90-degree angle. 3. Push the platform away by extending your legs, keeping your feet flat. 4. Slowly return to the starting position.

Title: Smith machine front squat
Desc: The Smith machine front squat is a machine-based exercise targeting the muscles of the lower body. The Smith machine mimics a barbell but provides more stability. This movement can be programmed in low reps for strength or higher reps for muscle and strength endurance. It is often performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of a full-body or lower-body workout.
HowTo: 1. Position the bar on the Smith machine at shoulder height. 2. Stand under the bar, resting it on your shoulders, and grip it with both hands. 3. Lower your body into a squat by bending your knees and hips. 4. Push through your heels to return to the starting position.

Title: Machine Deadlift - Gethin Variation
Desc: The Machine Deadlift - Gethin Variation is a variation of the deadlift performed on a machine, targeting the posterior chain.
HowTo: 1. Set the machine to the appropriate weight and adjust the foot placement. 2. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and grip the handles. 3. Keeping your back straight, hinge at the hips to lower the weight. 4. Drive through your heels to lift the weight back to the starting position.

Title: Single-leg hack squat
Desc: The single-leg hack squat is a lower-body exercise mainly targeting the quads, performed one side at a time per set. It is often used as an accessory for squats, or as a muscle-building movement during lower-body training, and is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more.
HowTo: 1. Stand with one foot on the platform and the other foot off the edge. 2. Lower your body by bending the knee of the standing leg until the thigh is parallel to the ground, then push back up to the starting position.

Title: Narrow-stance hack squat
Desc: The narrow-stance hack squat is a machine-based exercise that targets the muscles of the legs, particularly the quadriceps. It is often used as an accessory for squats, or as a muscle-building movement during lower-body training, and is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more.
HowTo: 1. Position yourself in the hack squat machine with a narrow stance. 2. Lower your body by bending your knees while keeping your back against the pad, then push through your heels to return to the starting position.

Title: Alternating Single-Leg Curl - Gethin Variation
Desc: The alternating single-leg curl is a variation that focuses on the hamstrings and glutes, performed one leg at a time to enhance muscle engagement.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet hip-width apart and hold a weight in one hand. 2. Bend one knee and curl your heel towards your glutes while balancing on the opposite leg, then lower and switch legs.

Title: Stiff-Legged Deadlift - Gethin Variation
Desc: The barbell stiff-legged deadlift targets the hamstrings, glutes, lower and upper back, as well as the core. It is a popular accessory movement for the deadlift, but also a muscle-building hamstring movement.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a barbell in front of your thighs. 2. Keeping your back straight, hinge at the hips to lower the barbell towards the ground while maintaining a slight bend in your knees, then return to standing.

Title: Single-Leg Press - Gethin Variation
Desc: The single-leg leg press is an exercise targeting the quadriceps one leg at a time. Many lifters prefer the leg press to squatting for several reasons, including the perception that its safer for the spine.
HowTo: 1. Sit on the leg press machine and place one foot on the platform. 2. Lower the platform by bending your knee, then push through your heel to extend your leg back to the starting position.

Title: Hack squat-
Desc: The hack squat is a machine-based exercise that targets the muscles of the legs, particularly the quadriceps. It is often used as an accessory for squats, but can also be the main lower-body movement in a workout. It is often performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more.
HowTo: 1. Position yourself on the hack squat machine with your back against the pad. 2. Place your feet shoulder-width apart on the platform. 3. Lower your body by bending your knees until your thighs are parallel to the ground. 4. Push through your heels to return to the starting position.

Title: Smith machine lunge squat
Desc: The Smith machine lunge squat is an exercise targeting the quads, glutes, and hamstrings. Using added weight allows you to overload the exercise beyond body weight and perform the movement in strength ranges. The Smith machine mimics a barbell but provides more stability.
HowTo: 1. Set the Smith machine bar at shoulder height and load it with appropriate weights. 2. Stand under the bar, positioning it across your upper back. 3. Step back and position your feet shoulder-width apart. 4. Lower your body into a lunge while keeping your front knee over your ankle. 5. Push back to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Hack Squat - Gethin Variation
Desc: The hack squat is a machine-based exercise that targets the muscles of the legs, particularly the quadriceps. It is often used as an accessory for squats, but can also be the main lower-body movement in a workout. It is often performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more.
HowTo: 1. Position yourself on the hack squat machine with your back against the pad. 2. Place your feet shoulder-width apart on the platform. 3. Lower your body by bending your knees until your thighs are parallel to the ground. 4. Push through your heels to return to the starting position.

Title: Leg Press - Gethin Variation
Desc: The leg press is a machine exercise targeting the quadriceps. Its favorite among lifters who prefer the seated position to standing with a load on the spine.
HowTo: 1. Sit on the leg press machine with your back against the pad. 2. Place your feet shoulder-width apart on the platform. 3. Lower the platform by bending your knees until they are at a 90-degree angle. 4. Push through your heels to return to the starting position.

Title: AM Leg Press
Desc: The leg press is a machine exercise targeting the quadriceps. Its favorite among lifters who prefer the seated position to standing with a load on the spine.
HowTo: 1. Sit on the leg press machine with your back against the pad. 2. Place your feet shoulder-width apart on the platform. 3. Lower the platform by bending your knees until they are at a 90-degree angle. 4. Push through your heels to return to the starting position.

Title: Leg extension
Desc: The leg extension is a popular machine-based exercise for the legs, particularly the quadriceps. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of a leg pre-exhaust or as a muscle-building movement for lower-body training.
HowTo: 1. Sit on the leg extension machine with your back against the pad. 2. Adjust the pad so it rests on your lower legs just above your feet. 3. Extend your legs to lift the weight, then slowly lower back to the starting position.

Title: UP Quad Extension
Desc: The leg extension is an isolation exercise for the quads.
HowTo: 1. Sit on the leg extension machine with your back against the pad. 2. Adjust the pad so it rests on your lower legs just above your feet. 3. Extend your legs to lift the weight, then slowly lower back to the starting position.

Title: UP Single-Leg Press
Desc: The single-leg leg press is an exercise targeting the quadriceps one leg at a time. Many lifters prefer the leg press to squatting for several reasons, including the perception that its safer for the spine.
HowTo: 1. Sit on the leg press machine and place one foot on the platform. 2. Lower the platform by bending your knee, then push back up to the starting position using your leg.

Title: UP Leg Press
Desc: The leg press is a machine exercise targeting the quadriceps. Its favorite among lifters who prefer the seated position to standing with a load on the spine.
HowTo: 1. Sit on the leg press machine with your feet shoulder-width apart on the platform. 2. Lower the platform by bending your knees, then push back up to the starting position.

Title: Pop Squat On Leg Press
Desc: The Pop Squat on Leg Press is a dynamic exercise that targets the legs and glutes. It combines a squat movement with the leg press machine for added resistance.
HowTo: 1. Sit on the leg press machine with your feet on the platform. 2. Perform a squat motion by lowering your body while pushing against the platform, then explosively push back up.

Title: King Maker Leg Press
Desc: The leg press is a machine exercise targeting the quadriceps. Its favorite among lifters who prefer the seated position to standing with a load on the spine.
HowTo: 1. Sit on the leg press machine with your back against the pad. 2. Place your feet shoulder-width apart on the platform. 3. Lower the platform by bending your knees until your thighs are parallel to the ground. 4. Push the platform back up to the starting position.

Title: Single-leg leg press
Desc: The single-leg leg press is a machine exercise targeting the leg muscles, including the quads, glutes, and hamstrings. The leg press is often used as an accessory for squats or deadlifts, but can also be the main lower-body movement in a workout. It is often performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more.
HowTo: 1. Sit on the leg press machine and place one foot on the platform. 2. Keep the other foot off the platform. 3. Lower the platform by bending the knee of the foot on the platform. 4. Push the platform back up to the starting position.

Title: King Maker Hack Squat
Desc: The hack squat is a machine-based exercise that targets the muscles of the legs, particularly the quadriceps. It is often used as an accessory for squats, but can also be the main lower-body movement in a workout. It is often performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more.
HowTo: 1. Stand on the hack squat machine with your back against the pad. 2. Place your feet shoulder-width apart on the platform. 3. Lower your body by bending your knees until your thighs are parallel to the ground. 4. Push back up to the starting position.

Title: 30 Legs Feet-High Leg Press
Desc: The 30 Legs Feet-High Leg Press is a variation of the leg press that emphasizes the lower part of the legs. It targets the quadriceps and glutes while providing a unique angle of resistance.
HowTo: 1. Sit on the leg press machine with your feet placed high on the platform. 2. Lower the platform by bending your knees. 3. Push the platform back up to the starting position.

Title: 30 Legs Leg Press
Desc: The 30 Legs Leg Press is a standard leg press exercise that targets the major muscles of the legs. It is commonly used in strength training routines.
HowTo: 1. Sit on the leg press machine with your feet placed shoulder-width apart on the platform. 2. Lower the platform by bending your knees until your thighs are parallel to the ground. 3. Push the platform back up to the starting position.

Title: 30 Legs Leg Press Calf Raise
Desc: The Leg Press Calf Raise targets the calves and helps in building lower leg strength. It is performed using a leg press machine, focusing on the calf muscles.
HowTo: 1. Sit on the leg press machine with your feet on the platform. 2. Push the platform away using your toes while keeping your heels off the platform. 3. Lower your heels back down to the starting position and repeat.

Title: 30 Legs Lying Leg Curl
Desc: The Lying Leg Curl primarily targets the hamstrings and is essential for balanced leg development. This exercise is performed on a lying leg curl machine.
HowTo: 1. Lie face down on the leg curl machine and position your legs under the padded lever. 2. Curl your legs up towards your glutes while keeping your hips down. 3. Slowly lower your legs back to the starting position and repeat.

Title: 30 Legs Machine Hack Squat
Desc: The Machine Hack Squat is an effective exercise for building overall leg strength and size. It targets the quadriceps while also engaging the hamstrings and glutes.
HowTo: 1. Position yourself on the hack squat machine with your shoulders under the pads. 2. Lower your body by bending your knees while keeping your back against the pad. 3. Push through your heels to return to the starting position.

Title: 30 Legs Single-Leg Leg Extension
Desc: The Single-Leg Leg Extension isolates the quadriceps and helps improve muscle imbalances. This exercise is performed on a leg extension machine, focusing on one leg at a time.
HowTo: 1. Sit on the leg extension machine and adjust the pad to rest on your lower leg. 2. Extend one leg upwards while keeping the other leg on the ground. 3. Lower the leg back down and repeat before switching legs.

Title: 30 Legs Single-Leg Leg Press
Desc: The Single-Leg Leg Press is a compound exercise that targets the entire leg, focusing on the quadriceps and glutes. It helps in improving balance and strength in each leg individually.
HowTo: 1. Sit on the leg press machine and place one foot on the platform. 2. Push the platform away using your foot while keeping your other leg off the platform. 3. Slowly return to the starting position and repeat before switching legs.

Title: 30 Legs Single-Leg Lying Leg Curl
Desc: The single-leg lying leg curl is an isolation exercise that primarily targets the hamstrings. It helps improve strength and balance in the legs.
HowTo: 1. Lie face down on a leg curl machine with your knees just off the edge. 2. Curl one leg up towards your glutes while keeping the other leg straight. 3. Lower the leg back down slowly and repeat for the desired number of reps before switching legs.

Title: 30 Legs Smith Machine Split Squat
Desc: The Smith Machine Split Squat is a variation of the squat that targets the lower body muscles. It is effective for building strength and stability in the legs.
HowTo: 1. Stand in a split stance with one foot forward and the other foot back, resting the barbell on your shoulders. 2. Lower your body by bending your front knee while keeping your back leg straight. 3. Push through your front heel to return to the starting position and repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: 30 Legs Smith Machine Squat
Desc: The Smith Machine Squat is a compound exercise that targets multiple muscles in the lower body. It is great for building overall leg strength.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart under the Smith machine bar. 2. Unrack the bar and lower your body into a squat by bending your knees and pushing your hips back. 3. Keep your chest up and back straight as you squat down, then push through your heels to return to standing.

Title: Jumping rope
Desc: Jumping rope is a classic conditioning exercise that is popular with everyone from children to boxers to CrossFit athletes. It targets many different muscles, including the calves, glutes, shoulders, and upper back, and is great for everything from fat loss to improving overall athletic performance.
HowTo: 1. Hold the rope handles in each hand and stand with the rope behind your heels. 2. Swing the rope over your head and jump as it comes down in front of you. 3. Continue jumping at a steady rhythm, keeping your elbows close to your sides.

Title: Forward lunge
Desc: The forward lunge is a lower-body bodyweight exercise targeting the quads, glutes, and hamstrings. It can also be performed holding dumbbells or other weights. The forward lunge places more emphasis on the quads than other lunge variations. It can be performed for time or reps in the lower-body portion of any workout.
HowTo: 1. Stand upright with your feet shoulder-width apart. 2. Step forward with one leg, lowering your hips until both knees are bent at about a 90-degree angle. 3. Push back to the starting position and repeat with the other leg.

Title: Side-to-side box skip
Desc: The side-to-side box skip is an explosive lower-body exercise that involves jumping laterally over a bench or box, landing with one foot on top of the surface, and then switching positions. It primarily targets the muscles of the lower body, but is also a serious cardiovascular challenge. It is often performed for high reps or for time as part of a fat-loss or athleticism-focused workout or circuit.
HowTo: 1. Stand next to a box or bench. 2. Jump laterally over the box, landing with one foot on top. 3. Quickly switch feet and jump back to the starting position. 4. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Bodyweight squat
Desc: The bodyweight squat is a fundamental exercise that strengthens the quads, glutes, and hamstrings. It can be performed as part of a dynamic warm-up, for time or reps during a workout, or for hip and spine mobility any time.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. 2. Lower your body by bending your knees and pushing your hips back. 3. Keep your chest up and back straight. 4. Go down until your thighs are parallel to the ground, then push through your heels to return to standing.

Title: Broad jump
Desc: The broad jump is an explosive lower-body exercise. It is a common way to measure explosive hip and lower-body strength in athletes. The more explosive you are, the farther you'll be able to jump.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. 2. Bend your knees and swing your arms back. 3. Explode forward, jumping as far as you can. 4. Land softly with your knees slightly bent.

Title: Burpee
Desc: The burpee is a high-intensity exercise that recruits the entire body to build strength and aerobic capacity. It is common in CrossFit workouts and group fitness classes, but can also be performed for time or reps in any fat-loss or athleticism-focused circuit or workout.
HowTo: 1. Start in a standing position. 2. Drop into a squat and place your hands on the ground. 3. Jump your feet back into a plank position. 4. Perform a push-up (optional). 5. Jump your feet back to the squat position and explode up into a jump.

Title: Trail Running/Walking
Desc: Trail running/walking is a great way to engage in cardiovascular exercise while enjoying nature. It involves running or walking on trails, which can vary in difficulty and terrain.
HowTo: 1. Choose a suitable trail for your fitness level. 2. Wear appropriate footwear for traction. 3. Start at a comfortable pace, focusing on your footing. 4. Adjust your speed and intensity according to the trail's difficulty.

Title: Scissors Jump
Desc: The alternating lunge jump is an explosive bodyweight exercise that targets the lower-body muscles, including the quads, glutes, and hamstrings. It can be performed for time or reps in power training, and is also effective in any fat-loss or athleticism-focused workout.
HowTo: 1. Start in a standing position. 2. Jump into a lunge position, alternating legs with each jump. 3. Land softly and repeat for the desired number of reps or time.

Title: Jumping jack-
Desc: The jumping jack is a classic calisthenics exercise to improve overall conditioning. Its one the most recognizable exercises on the planet, and its almost synonymous with training for military recruits. It can be done for time or reps, often in dynamic warm-ups or to mobilize the hips and shoulders.
HowTo: 1. Stand upright with your feet together and arms at your sides. 2. Jump up while spreading your legs shoulder-width apart and raising your arms above your head. 3. Jump back to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Arms-crossed jump squat
Desc: The arms-crossed jump squat is an explosive version of the jump squat. Crossing your arms eliminates any extra power that could come from swinging your arms, making the movement extra strict and challenging for the lower body. It can be performed for time or reps and is especially effective in a fat-loss or athleticism-focused circuit or workout.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and cross your arms over your chest. 2. Squat down and then jump explosively upward. 3. Land softly and repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Bodyweight Reverse Lunge
Desc: The reverse lunge is a lower-body exercise targeting the quads, glutes, and hamstrings. The reverse lunge places more emphasis on the glutes than other lunge variations.
HowTo: 1. Stand upright with feet hip-width apart. 2. Step back with one leg into a lunge position, lowering your hips until both knees are bent at about a 90-degree angle. 3. Push through the front heel to return to the starting position and repeat on the other side.

Title: Alien Squat
Desc: The Alien Squat is a lower-body exercise that targets the legs and glutes. It is effective for building strength and stability.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. 2. Squat down by bending your knees and pushing your hips back, keeping your chest up. 3. Return to standing by pushing through your heels.

Title: Treadmill walking
Desc: Treadmill walking is a popular cardiovascular exercise performed on a machine that is available in most gyms. Performing this exercise on a treadmill allows you to adjust the speed of your walking and, depending on the machine, perform it on an adjustable incline. Many machines also have built-in heart rate monitors and timers to help you track your progress.
HowTo: 1. Step onto the treadmill and select your desired speed and incline. 2. Begin walking at a comfortable pace, maintaining good posture and engaging your core.

Title: Rocket Jump
Desc: The Rocket Jump is a powerful plyometric exercise that involves jumping explosively into the air. It helps improve vertical jump and overall leg strength.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. 2. Bend your knees and swing your arms back. 3. Explode upwards, jumping as high as you can while swinging your arms forward. 4. Land softly and repeat.

Title: Depth jump box jump
Desc: The depth jump box jump is a plyometric exercise that entails jumping off one box, dropping into a squat, and then jumping up onto another box. These are all performed fluidly to complete one rep. Depth jumps have been a staple of high-level athletic programming for decades. They are usually performed for low reps with a focus on power and technique. If they hurt your knees or back, consider performing box jumps or squat jumps instead.
HowTo: 1. Start by standing on one box. 2. Jump off the box, landing softly in a squat position. 3. Immediately jump onto the second box, using your arms for momentum. 4. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Bodyweight Walking Lunge
Desc: The walking lunge is a lower-body exercise that targets the glutes, quads, and hamstrings while challenging stability and balance. It can be performed for reps, time, or distance in the lower-body portion of any workout.
HowTo: 1. Stand upright with your feet together. 2. Step forward with one leg and lower your body until both knees are bent at about a 90-degree angle. 3. Push back to the starting position and repeat with the other leg.

Title: Walking High Knees
Desc: Walking High Knees is a dynamic exercise that elevates your heart rate while engaging your core and legs. It is great for warming up or as part of a cardio workout.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet hip-width apart. 2. Begin walking in place, lifting your knees high towards your chest with each step. 3. Swing your arms to help maintain balance and increase intensity.

Title: Lateral lunge
Desc: The lateral lunge is a lower-body bodyweight movement that works the quads, glutes, and hamstrings. It can also be performed holding dumbbells or other weights. It is often performed for reps as part of a dynamic warm-up or mobility routine but can also work in a circuit or other workouts.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. 2. Step to the side with one leg, bending that knee while keeping the other leg straight, then return to the starting position.

Title: Jump Squat
Desc: The jump squat is an explosive bodyweight exercise targeting the quads, hamstrings, and glutes. It is also a serious cardiovascular challenge when done for reps. It can be performed as a power exercise to build jumping power, or in any fat-loss or athleticism-focused workout.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. 2. Lower into a squat, then explode upward into a jump, landing softly back into the squat position.

Title: Over bench jump
Desc: The over bench jump is a plyometric exercise requiring only a weight bench to perform. It improves jumping ability and athleticism while burning a lot of calories.
HowTo: 1. Stand in front of a weight bench. 2. Jump over the bench, landing softly on the other side, and immediately jump back over.

Title: Split Jump
Desc: The alternating lunge jump is an explosive bodyweight exercise that targets the lower-body muscles, including the quads, glutes, and hamstrings. It can be performed for time or reps in power training, and is also effective in any fat-loss or athleticism-focused workout.
HowTo: 1. Start in a lunge position with one foot forward. 2. Jump explosively, switching your legs in mid-air to land in a lunge with the opposite leg forward.

Title: 90-degree jump squat
Desc: The 90-degree jump squat is an explosive bodyweight exercise that targets the muscles of the lower body, including the quads, glutes, and hamstrings, as well as the cardiovascular system. It can be performed for time or reps, usually in a fat-loss or athleticism-focused circuit workout.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. 2. Lower into a squat, then jump up 90 degrees, landing softly back into the squat position.

Title: Skip
Desc: The skip is an exercise that builds power and explosiveness in the legs. It's commonly performed by children and in gym classes, but is also great for working the legs and hip flexors, making it a favorite warm-up for athletes who need to explode vertically.
