HowTo: 1. Stand upright with your feet together. 2. Jump and click your heels together while raising your arms overhead. 3. Land softly and immediately bend at the waist to touch the ground with your hands. 4. Repeat the jumping and reaching sequence.

Title: Holman Burpee to 180 Jump
Desc: The Holman Burpee to 180 Jump is a high-intensity exercise that combines a burpee with a jump turn, targeting the entire body. It improves strength, agility, and cardiovascular fitness.
HowTo: 1. Start in a standing position. 2. Drop into a squat and place your hands on the ground. 3. Kick your feet back into a plank position. 4. Perform a push-up (optional). 5. Jump your feet back to your hands and explode into a jump, turning 180 degrees. 6. Land softly and repeat.

Title: Holman Traveling Low Jack to Belly Touch
Desc: The Holman Traveling Low Jack to Belly Touch is a dynamic exercise that combines lateral movement with core engagement. It enhances agility and coordination while providing a cardio workout.
HowTo: 1. Start in a low squat position with your hands on the ground. 2. Jump your feet out to the sides while keeping your body low (like a jumping jack). 3. After the jump, touch your belly with your hands. 4. Repeat the movement, traveling sideways.

Title: Holman Flying Squat Thrust to Shoulder Tap
Desc: The Holman Flying Squat Thrust to Shoulder Tap is a strength-building exercise that combines squats with shoulder taps. It targets the legs and core while improving stability and balance.
HowTo: 1. Start in a standing position. 2. Squat down and place your hands on the ground. 3. Jump your feet back into a plank position. 4. Perform a shoulder tap by touching your left shoulder with your right hand. 5. Jump your feet back to the squat position and repeat.

Title: Holman Squat Jump to Alternating Side Lunge Jump
Desc: The Holman Squat Jump to Alternating Side Lunge Jump is an explosive exercise that targets the lower body while enhancing power and agility. It combines squat jumps with lateral lunges for a comprehensive workout.
HowTo: 1. Start in a standing position. 2. Perform a squat jump, exploding upward. 3. Land softly and immediately step to the right into a side lunge. 4. Push off the right foot and jump to the left into a side lunge. 5. Repeat the sequence.

Title: Holman Low Squat with Low Diagonal Dumbbell Punch
Desc: The Holman Low Squat with Low Diagonal Dumbbell Punch is a compound exercise that targets the lower body while incorporating upper body movement. It helps improve strength and coordination.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, holding a dumbbell in one hand. 2. Lower into a squat position while extending the opposite arm diagonally forward. 3. Push through your heels to return to standing while bringing the dumbbell back to your side. 4. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions, then switch sides.

Title: Holman Right Leg Hop to Right Reverse Lunge
Desc: The Holman Right Leg Hop to Right Reverse Lunge is a dynamic exercise that enhances lower body strength and balance. It combines a hop and a lunge to engage multiple muscle groups.
HowTo: 1. Start standing on your right leg. 2. Hop forward on your right leg and land softly. 3. Immediately lower into a reverse lunge with your left leg. 4. Push back to standing and repeat the hop and lunge for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Holman Left Leg Hop to Left Reverse Lunge
Desc: The Holman Left Leg Hop to Left Reverse Lunge is similar to its right-side counterpart, focusing on lower body strength and coordination. It challenges balance and stability.
HowTo: 1. Start standing on your left leg. 2. Hop forward on your left leg and land softly. 3. Immediately lower into a reverse lunge with your right leg. 4. Push back to standing and repeat the hop and lunge for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Holman Burpee to Open Stance
Desc: The Holman Burpee to Open Stance is a high-intensity exercise that works the entire body while improving cardiovascular fitness. It combines a squat, push-up, and jump.
HowTo: 1. Start in a standing position. 2. Drop into a squat and place your hands on the ground. 3. Jump your feet back into a plank position and perform a push-up. 4. Jump your feet back to the squat position and explode upward into a jump with arms raised. 5. Land softly and repeat.

Title: Holman Diagonal Squat Thrust to Renegade Forward Punch
Desc: The Holman Diagonal Squat Thrust to Renegade Forward Punch is a full-body exercise that combines strength and stability. It targets multiple muscle groups while enhancing coordination.
HowTo: 1. Start in a standing position with feet shoulder-width apart. 2. Lower into a squat and place your hands on the ground. 3. Jump your feet back into a plank position. 4. Perform a renegade row by pulling one dumbbell towards your hip while stabilizing your body. 5. Return to the plank and jump your feet back to the squat position, then punch forward with the opposite arm. 6. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Holman Bear Crawl
Desc: The Holman Bear Crawl is a dynamic movement that engages multiple muscle groups while improving mobility and stability. It mimics the crawling motion of a bear, promoting coordination and strength.
HowTo: 1. Start on all fours with your hands directly under your shoulders and knees under your hips. 2. Lift your knees slightly off the ground and crawl forward by moving opposite hand and foot together. 3. Keep your core engaged and maintain a flat back as you move.

Title: Holman Bear Crawl to Donkey Kick
Desc: The Holman Bear Crawl to Donkey Kick combines a bear crawl with a donkey kick, targeting the glutes and core. This exercise enhances mobility while also building strength in the lower body.
HowTo: 1. Begin in the bear crawl position. 2. As you crawl forward, lift one leg and kick it back towards the ceiling in a donkey kick motion. 3. Alternate legs as you continue to crawl forward.

Title: Holman Bear Crawl to Froggy Push-Up
Desc: The Holman Bear Crawl to Froggy Push-Up is a compound exercise that combines crawling with a push-up. It builds upper body strength while engaging the core and lower body.
HowTo: 1. Start in the bear crawl position. 2. Move forward and lower your body into a push-up position, performing a push-up. 3. Return to the bear crawl position and repeat.

Title: Holman Bear Crawl to Shoulder Tap
Desc: The Holman Bear Crawl to Shoulder Tap is an exercise that enhances stability and coordination. It challenges the core while engaging the upper body.
HowTo: 1. Start in the bear crawl position. 2. While maintaining your balance, lift one hand to tap the opposite shoulder. 3. Alternate sides while keeping your hips stable.

Title: Holman Burpee to Tuck Jump
Desc: The Holman Burpee to Tuck Jump is a high-intensity exercise that combines a burpee with a tuck jump. It is great for building cardiovascular endurance and explosive power.
HowTo: 1. Start standing, then drop into a squat and place your hands on the ground. 2. Kick your feet back into a plank position and perform a push-up. 3. Jump your feet back to your hands, then explosively jump up, bringing your knees to your chest in a tuck jump.

Title: Holman Burpee to Flying Squat Thrust to Tuck Jump
Desc: The Holman Burpee to Flying Squat Thrust to Tuck Jump is a high-intensity exercise that combines multiple movements to elevate your heart rate and engage various muscle groups. It is effective for building endurance and strength.
HowTo: 1. Start in a standing position. 2. Drop into a squat and place your hands on the ground. 3. Jump your feet back into a plank position. 4. Perform a push-up. 5. Jump your feet back towards your hands. 6. Jump explosively into the air, tucking your knees towards your chest. 7. Land softly and repeat.

Title: Holman Forward Lunge to Reverse Lunge
Desc: The Holman Forward Lunge to Reverse Lunge is a compound exercise that targets the lower body, improving strength and stability. It engages the major muscle groups in the legs and enhances balance.
HowTo: 1. Stand upright with feet hip-width apart. 2. Step forward with your right leg into a lunge, lowering your hips until both knees are bent at about a 90-degree angle. 3. Push back to the starting position. 4. Step back with your right leg into a reverse lunge, lowering your hips again. 5. Return to the starting position and repeat with the left leg.

Title: Holman Renegade Lunge Jump
Desc: The Holman Renegade Lunge Jump is a dynamic exercise that combines lunges with explosive jumps, providing a full-body workout. It helps improve cardiovascular fitness and muscular endurance.
HowTo: 1. Start in a plank position with your hands under your shoulders. 2. Jump your right foot forward into a lunge position. 3. Jump back to the plank position. 4. Repeat on the left side. 5. Continue alternating sides while maintaining a strong core.

Title: Holman Squat Jump to Lunge Jump
Desc: The Holman Squat Jump to Lunge Jump is an explosive exercise that targets multiple muscle groups and boosts cardiovascular endurance. It is great for building power and agility.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart. 2. Perform a squat jump, landing softly. 3. Immediately step back into a lunge with your right leg. 4. Return to standing and repeat the squat jump. 5. Alternate with the left leg for the lunge.

Title: Holman Prisoner Reverse Lunge
Desc: The Holman Prisoner Reverse Lunge is a strength exercise that focuses on the lower body while also engaging the core. It helps improve leg strength and stability.
HowTo: 1. Stand tall with your hands behind your head. 2. Step back with your right leg into a reverse lunge, keeping your torso upright. 3. Lower your hips until both knees are bent at about a 90-degree angle. 4. Push through your front heel to return to standing. 5. Repeat on the left side.

Title: Holman Wide-to-Narrow Squat Jump
Desc: The Holman Wide-to-Narrow Squat Jump is an explosive exercise that targets the lower body. It helps improve strength and power in the legs while enhancing agility.
HowTo: 1. Start in a wide squat position with feet wider than shoulder-width apart. 2. Lower into a squat, then jump explosively, bringing your feet together mid-air. 3. Land softly in a narrow squat position and repeat.

Title: Holman Donkey Run
Desc: The Holman Donkey Run is a dynamic exercise that combines running with a donkey kick motion. It engages multiple muscle groups while providing a cardiovascular workout.
HowTo: 1. Start in a high plank position. 2. Quickly bring one knee towards your chest while kicking the opposite leg back. 3. Alternate legs rapidly as if running.

Title: Holman Weighted Wide-to-Narrow Squat Jump
Desc: The Holman Weighted Wide-to-Narrow Squat Jump adds resistance to the explosive squat jump. This variation increases strength and power in the lower body.
HowTo: 1. Hold a weight (dumbbell or kettlebell) at chest level. 2. Start in a wide squat position, then jump explosively while bringing your feet together. 3. Land softly in a narrow squat and repeat.

Title: Holman Wide-to-Narrow Donkey Kick
Desc: The Holman Wide-to-Narrow Donkey Kick is an effective exercise for targeting the glutes and hamstrings. It helps improve lower body strength and stability.
HowTo: 1. Start on all fours with hands under shoulders and knees under hips. 2. Extend one leg back and up while keeping the knee bent. 3. Return to the starting position and alternate legs.

Title: Holman Mule Kick
Desc: The Holman Mule Kick is a great exercise for strengthening the glutes and hamstrings. It also engages the core for stability.
HowTo: 1. Start on all fours with hands under shoulders and knees under hips. 2. Kick one leg back and up while keeping the knee straight. 3. Return to the starting position and switch legs.

Title: Holman Goal Post to Squat
Desc: The Holman Goal Post to Squat is a dynamic exercise that improves flexibility and mobility in the lower body. It combines a goal post arm position with a deep squat to enhance range of motion.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart and arms bent at 90 degrees, palms facing forward. 2. Lower into a squat while keeping your arms in the goal post position. 3. Return to standing while maintaining the arm position. 4. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Holman Frogger Squat to Heel Click
Desc: The Holman Frogger Squat to Heel Click is a high-energy exercise that combines squatting and jumping to elevate your heart rate. It engages multiple muscle groups while improving coordination and agility.
HowTo: 1. Start in a squat position with feet shoulder-width apart. 2. Jump forward into a squat, landing softly. 3. Click your heels together while in the squat position. 4. Stand up and repeat the sequence.

Title: Holman Stair Sprint
Desc: The Holman Stair Sprint is a high-intensity cardio exercise that targets the entire body while focusing on leg strength and endurance. It is an effective way to improve cardiovascular fitness and leg power.
HowTo: 1. Find a set of stairs. 2. Stand at the bottom and sprint up the stairs as fast as you can. 3. Walk or jog back down to recover. 4. Repeat for several rounds.

Title: Holman Stair Bear Crawl
Desc: The Holman Stair Bear Crawl is a full-body exercise that engages multiple muscle groups while enhancing strength and stability. It mimics animal movement patterns for functional fitness.
HowTo: 1. Start at the bottom of the stairs on all fours. 2. Crawl up the stairs using opposite hand and foot (right hand with left foot, and vice versa). 3. Keep your core engaged and back flat. 4. Reach the top and crawl back down.

Title: Holman Burpee to Flying Squat Thrust
Desc: The Holman Burpee to Flying Squat Thrust is a challenging exercise that combines strength and cardio. It targets multiple muscle groups and improves overall fitness.
HowTo: 1. Start in a standing position. 2. Drop into a squat and place your hands on the ground. 3. Kick your feet back into a plank position. 4. Perform a push-up if desired. 5. Jump your feet back to your hands and explode into a squat thrust. 6. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Holman Flying Squat Thrust to Push-Up
Desc: The Holman Flying Squat Thrust to Push-Up is a dynamic exercise that combines a squat thrust with a push-up to build strength and endurance. It targets multiple muscle groups while enhancing coordination and stability.
HowTo: 1. Start in a standing position. 2. Drop into a squat and place your hands on the ground. 3. Jump your feet back into a plank position. 4. Perform a push-up. 5. Jump your feet back towards your hands and return to standing. 6. Repeat the movement.

Title: Holman Foot-Elevated Step-To-Lunge
Desc: The Holman Foot-Elevated Step-To-Lunge is an effective lower body exercise that targets the legs and glutes. Elevating the foot increases the range of motion and intensity of the lunge.
HowTo: 1. Stand in front of a bench or elevated surface. 2. Place one foot on the bench behind you. 3. Lower your body into a lunge with the front knee over the ankle. 4. Push through the front heel to return to standing. 5. Repeat on the other side.

Title: Holman Split Lunge
Desc: The Holman Split Lunge is a powerful exercise that focuses on the lower body, particularly the legs and glutes. It improves balance and strength while engaging the core.
HowTo: 1. Start in a standing position. 2. Step one foot back into a lunge position, keeping the front knee over the ankle. 3. Lower your body until the back knee nearly touches the ground. 4. Push through the front heel to return to standing. 5. Switch legs and repeat.

Title: Holman Stair Climb
Desc: The Holman Stair Climb is a cardiovascular exercise that engages multiple muscle groups while improving endurance. It's a great way to elevate your heart rate and strengthen the legs.
HowTo: 1. Find a set of stairs. 2. Start at the bottom and step up with one foot, followed by the other. 3. Continue climbing the stairs at a steady pace. 4. Focus on using your legs and maintaining good posture.

Title: Holman Burpee to Flying Jack
Desc: The Holman Burpee to Flying Jack is a high-intensity exercise that combines a burpee with a jumping jack. It effectively works the entire body while boosting cardiovascular fitness.
HowTo: 1. Start in a standing position. 2. Drop into a squat and place your hands on the ground. 3. Jump your feet back into a plank position and perform a push-up. 4. Jump your feet back towards your hands. 5. Jump up and spread your legs while raising your arms overhead (jumping jack). 6. Return to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Holman Right Reverse Lunge
Desc: The Holman Right Reverse Lunge is a lower body exercise that targets the legs and glutes. It involves stepping back into a lunge position, which helps improve strength and stability.
HowTo: 1. Stand upright with your feet shoulder-width apart. 2. Step back with your right leg, lowering your hips until both knees are bent at about a 90-degree angle. 3. Push through your left heel to return to the starting position. 4. Repeat for the desired number of reps before switching legs.

Title: Holman Left Reverse Lunge
Desc: The Holman Left Reverse Lunge is similar to the right lunge but focuses on the left leg. It helps build strength and balance in the lower body.
HowTo: 1. Stand upright with your feet shoulder-width apart. 2. Step back with your left leg, lowering your hips until both knees are bent at about a 90-degree angle. 3. Push through your right heel to return to the starting position. 4. Repeat for the desired number of reps before switching legs.

Title: Holman Squat Tap to Hop
Desc: The Holman Squat Tap to Hop is a dynamic exercise that combines a squat with a hop, targeting the legs and improving explosive strength. It is effective for building muscle and enhancing cardiovascular fitness.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. 2. Lower into a squat, tapping the ground with your hands. 3. Explode upwards into a hop, landing softly back into the squat position. 4. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Holman Squat Tap to Jump-Forward-Jump-Back
Desc: The Holman Squat Tap to Jump-Forward-Jump-Back is an advanced exercise that combines squats with jumps, enhancing leg strength and agility. It challenges both muscle endurance and cardiovascular fitness.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. 2. Lower into a squat and tap the ground. 3. Jump forward explosively, then immediately jump back to the starting position. 4. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Holman Squat Hip Drive
Desc: The Holman Squat Hip Drive is a strength exercise focusing on the hips and legs. It helps in building muscle and improving overall lower body strength.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. 2. Lower into a squat position, keeping your chest up. 3. Drive through your heels to return to standing, focusing on squeezing your glutes at the top. 4. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Holman Alternating Double Lunge Hop
Desc: The Holman Alternating Double Lunge Hop is a dynamic exercise that targets the lower body while improving cardiovascular endurance. It involves alternating lunges with a hop to engage multiple muscle groups.
HowTo: 1. Start in a standing position with feet hip-width apart. 2. Step forward into a lunge with your right leg, lowering your hips until both knees are bent at about a 90-degree angle. 3. Push off your right foot and hop up, switching legs in mid-air. 4. Land softly in a lunge position with your left leg forward. 5. Repeat the movement, alternating legs.

Title: Holman Right Reverse Lunge to Front Kick
Desc: The Holman Right Reverse Lunge to Front Kick is a functional exercise that combines strength and balance. It works the legs and core while enhancing coordination.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet together. 2. Step back with your right leg into a reverse lunge, keeping your left knee over your ankle. 3. Push through your left heel to return to standing. 4. Immediately kick your right leg forward, keeping your core engaged. 5. Repeat the movement on the same leg or alternate.

Title: Holman Right Leg Forward Lunge Hop
Desc: The Holman Right Leg Forward Lunge Hop is an explosive exercise that targets the lower body while enhancing cardiovascular fitness. It incorporates lunging and hopping to build strength and agility.
HowTo: 1. Begin in a standing position with feet shoulder-width apart. 2. Step forward with your right leg into a lunge, lowering your hips. 3. Push off your right foot and hop up, switching legs in mid-air. 4. Land softly in a lunge position with your left leg forward. 5. Continue alternating legs with each rep.

Title: Holman Right Squat Thrust
Desc: The Holman Right Squat Thrust is a full-body exercise that combines strength and cardio. It is effective for building endurance and strength in multiple muscle groups.
HowTo: 1. Start in a standing position. 2. Bend your knees and place your hands on the ground, jumping your feet back into a plank position. 3. Perform a push-up if desired. 4. Jump your feet back towards your hands. 5. Stand up and jump into the air, reaching your arms overhead. 6. Repeat the sequence.

Title: Holman Left Reverse Lunge to Front Kick
Desc: The Holman Left Reverse Lunge to Front Kick is a great exercise for building strength and balance in the legs. It challenges coordination and engages the core.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet together. 2. Step back with your left leg into a reverse lunge, keeping your right knee over your ankle. 3. Push through your right heel to return to standing. 4. Immediately kick your left leg forward, keeping your core engaged. 5. Repeat the movement on the same leg or alternate.

Title: Holman Left Leg Forward Lunge Hop
Desc: The Holman Left Leg Forward Lunge Hop is a dynamic lower body exercise that targets the legs and enhances balance. It combines a lunge with a hop, engaging multiple muscle groups.
HowTo: 1. Start in a standing position. 2. Step forward with your left leg into a lunge position, lowering your hips until both knees are bent at about a 90-degree angle. 3. Push through your left heel to hop up, bringing your right knee towards your chest. 4. Land softly back into the lunge position and repeat.

Title: Holman Left Side Diagonal Burpee
Desc: The Holman Left Side Diagonal Burpee is a high-intensity exercise that combines a burpee with a lateral movement. It works the entire body and improves cardiovascular fitness.
HowTo: 1. Start in a standing position. 2. Drop into a squat and place your hands on the ground. 3. Jump your feet back into a plank position. 4. Perform a push-up, then jump your feet back towards your hands. 5. Jump to the left side, reaching your arms overhead. 6. Repeat.

Title: Holman Left Squat Thrust
Desc: The Holman Left Squat Thrust is a full-body exercise that builds strength and endurance. It emphasizes explosive movement and engages multiple muscle groups.
HowTo: 1. Start in a standing position. 2. Lower into a squat and place your hands on the ground. 3. Jump your feet back into a plank position. 4. Quickly return to the squat position and jump up explosively. 5. Land softly and repeat.

Title: Holman Wide Squat Thrust
Desc: The Holman Wide Squat Thrust is a variation of the squat thrust that targets the legs and core. It helps improve strength and stability.
HowTo: 1. Start in a standing position with feet wider than shoulder-width. 2. Lower into a wide squat and place your hands on the ground. 3. Jump your feet back into a plank position. 4. Quickly return to the squat position and jump up. 5. Land softly and repeat.

Title: Holman Alternating Single-Leg Hop to Squat to 180 Jump
Desc: The Holman Alternating Single-Leg Hop to Squat to 180 Jump is a powerful exercise that enhances explosive strength and agility. It targets the legs while improving coordination.
HowTo: 1. Start in a standing position on your right leg. 2. Hop forward on your right leg and land softly. 3. Lower into a squat position. 4. Jump 180 degrees to your left, landing on your left leg. 5. Repeat the sequence, alternating legs.

Title: Holman Right Lunge Hop to Chest Press
Desc: The Holman Right Lunge Hop to Chest Press is a dynamic exercise that combines a lunge with a chest press. It targets the lower body while also engaging the upper body for a full-body workout.
HowTo: 1. Start in a standing position holding weights at chest level. 2. Step forward with your right leg into a lunge position. 3. As you lunge, press the weights forward. 4. Push back to the starting position and repeat, alternating legs.

Title: Holman Left Lunge Hop to Overhead Press
Desc: The Holman Left Lunge Hop to Overhead Press is a powerful exercise that works the legs and shoulders simultaneously. It improves strength and coordination while providing a cardiovascular challenge.
HowTo: 1. Stand with weights at shoulder height. 2. Step forward with your left leg into a lunge position. 3. As you lunge, press the weights overhead. 4. Return to the starting position and alternate legs.

Title: Holman 180 Jump Hop Forward Hop Back
Desc: The Holman 180 Jump Hop Forward Hop Back is a high-intensity exercise that engages multiple muscle groups. It enhances agility and cardiovascular endurance.
HowTo: 1. Start in a standing position. 2. Jump forward while rotating 180 degrees. 3. Land softly and immediately jump back to the starting position. 4. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Holman Right Split Squat
Desc: The Holman Right Split Squat is an effective lower body exercise that focuses on strength and stability. It primarily targets the quadriceps and glutes.
HowTo: 1. Stand in a staggered stance with your right foot forward. 2. Lower your body into a squat position, keeping your front knee over your ankle. 3. Push through your front heel to return to the starting position. 4. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Holman Left Split Squat
Desc: The Holman Left Split Squat is similar to the right split squat but focuses on the left leg. It builds strength and balance in the lower body.
HowTo: 1. Stand in a staggered stance with your left foot forward. 2. Lower your body into a squat position, ensuring your front knee stays over your ankle. 3. Push through your front heel to return to the starting position. 4. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Holman Double Squat Pulse to 180 Jump
Desc: The Holman Double Squat Pulse to 180 Jump is a dynamic exercise that targets the lower body while enhancing explosive power. It combines squats with a jump to engage multiple muscle groups.
HowTo: 1. Start in a squat position with feet shoulder-width apart. 2. Perform a double pulse in the squat, then explode upwards into a 180-degree jump. 3. Land softly and return to the squat position to repeat.

Title: Holman Towel Left Side Squat
Desc: The Holman Towel Left Side Squat is a unilateral exercise that focuses on strengthening the legs and improving balance. Using a towel adds resistance and stability challenges.
HowTo: 1. Stand with a towel in your left hand, feet hip-width apart. 2. Shift your weight to your right leg and squat down while extending your left leg to the side. 3. Return to standing and repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Holman Alternating Lunge Jump
Desc: The Holman Alternating Lunge Jump is an explosive exercise that targets the legs and enhances cardiovascular fitness. It combines lunges with jumps for a high-intensity workout.
HowTo: 1. Start in a standing position. 2. Step forward into a lunge with your right leg, then jump up explosively and switch legs in mid-air. 3. Land in a lunge with your left leg forward and repeat.

Title: Holman Lunge Jump to Squat Jump
Desc: The Holman Lunge Jump to Squat Jump is a high-intensity exercise that builds strength and power in the lower body. It combines lunges and squat jumps for a comprehensive workout.
HowTo: 1. Begin in a standing position. 2. Lunge forward with your right leg, then jump up explosively and land in a squat position. 3. From the squat, jump back up and repeat the sequence.

Title: Holman Burpee with Belly Touch
Desc: The Holman Burpee with Belly Touch is a full-body exercise that combines strength and cardio. It engages multiple muscle groups and improves overall fitness.
HowTo: 1. Start in a standing position. 2. Drop into a squat and place your hands on the ground, then kick your feet back into a plank position. 3. Perform a push-up, then jump your feet back to your hands and jump up while touching your belly. 4. Repeat.

Title: Bootstrapper squat
Desc: The bootstrapper squat is a movement that improves mobility, muscular strength, and flexibility in the hips and hamstrings. It is usually performed as part of a dynamic warm-up for the lower body to mobilize the hips and improve squat form.
HowTo: Start in a standing position with feet shoulder-width apart. Squat down while keeping your chest up, then place your hands on the ground and push your hips back, allowing your knees to track over your toes. Hold the position briefly and then return to standing.

Title: Total Fitness Broad Jump
Desc: The broad jump is an explosive lower-body exercise. It is a common way to measure explosive hip and lower-body strength in athletes. The more explosive you are, the farther you'll be able to jump.
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. Bend your knees and swing your arms back, then explosively jump forward as far as you can, landing softly on your feet.

Title: Total Fitness Lateral Lunge
Desc: The lateral lunge is a lower-body bodyweight movement that works the quads, glutes, and hamstrings. It can also be performed holding dumbbells or other weights. It is often performed for reps as part of a dynamic warm-up or mobility routine but can also work in a circuit or other workouts.
HowTo: Stand with your feet together. Step to the side with one leg, bending that knee while keeping the other leg straight. Push back to the starting position and repeat on the other side.

Title: Lateral shuffle
Desc: The lateral shuffle is a common exercise in sports training and gym classes. It involves taking steps to one side and then steps to the other side. It can be performed as part of a circuit for athletes of any level, but is also a great movement for beginners.
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. Bend your knees slightly and shuffle to one side, then quickly shuffle back to the starting position. Repeat for a set distance or time.

Title: Total Fitness Skip
Desc: The skip is an exercise that builds power and explosiveness in the legs. It's commonly performed by children and in gym classes, but is also great for working the legs and hip flexors, making it a favorite warm-up for athletes who need to explode vertically.
HowTo: Start by standing tall with your feet together. Begin to skip forward by driving one knee up while pushing off the opposite foot, alternating legs in a rhythmic motion.

Title: Total Fitness Spider Lunge
Desc: The spider lunge stretch is a lower-body stretch targeting the hips, groin, and quads. It can be part of a dynamic warm-up or mobility work performed anytime.
HowTo: 1. Start in a standing position. 2. Step forward into a lunge while keeping your back leg straight and your front knee over your ankle. 3. Lower your hips towards the ground while keeping your chest upright. 4. Hold the position for a moment, then return to standing and repeat on the other side.

Title: Spider lunge stretch
Desc: The spider lunge stretch is a lower-body stretch targeting the hips, groin, and quads. It can be part of a dynamic warm-up or mobility work performed anytime.
HowTo: 1. Start in a standing position. 2. Step forward into a lunge while keeping your back leg straight and your front knee over your ankle. 3. Lower your hips towards the ground while keeping your chest upright. 4. Hold the position for a moment, then return to standing and repeat on the other side.

Title: Spider lunge with T-rotation
Desc: The spider lunge with T-rotation is an exercise that produces a deep stretch in the glutes and hamstrings while also rotating and mobilizing the thoracic spine region. It is a great movement to include in a dynamic warm-up, or as mobility work anytime.
HowTo: 1. Begin in a lunge position with one foot forward and the other back. 2. Place your opposite hand on the ground inside your front foot. 3. Rotate your torso towards your front leg and reach your other arm up towards the ceiling. 4. Hold the position for a moment, then return to the starting position and switch sides.

Title: Standing quad stretch
Desc: The standing quad stretch is a simple exercise designed to stretch the quadriceps, the big muscles that cover most of the thighs. This is a static stretch, meaning its usually performed by holding the stretched position for a certain length of time.
HowTo: 1. Stand upright and hold onto a wall or chair for balance if needed. 2. Bend one knee and bring your heel towards your buttocks. 3. Grasp your ankle with your hand and gently pull it closer to your body. 4. Keep your knees together and hold the stretch for 15-30 seconds, then switch legs.

Title: Vertical jump
Desc: The vertical jump is an explosive lower-body exercise that is a common way to measure explosive hip and lower-body strength in athletes. The more explosive you are, the higher you'll be able to jump.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. 2. Bend your knees and lower your body into a squat position. 3. Explode upwards, jumping as high as you can while swinging your arms upward. 4. Land softly on your feet and immediately go into the next jump.

Title: King Maker Burpee
Desc: The burpee is a high-intensity exercise that recruits the entire body to build strength and aerobic capacity. It is common in CrossFit workouts and group fitness classes, but can also be performed for time or reps in any fat-loss or athleticism-focused circuit or workout.
HowTo: 1. Start in a standing position. 2. Drop into a squat and place your hands on the ground. 3. Kick your feet back into a plank position. 4. Perform a push-up. 5. Jump your feet back to the squat position. 6. Explode up into a jump.

Title: King Maker Explosive High Jump
Desc: The tuck jump is a vertical jump, an explosive lower-body exercise that is a common way to measure explosive hip and lower-body strength in athletes. The more explosive you are, the higher you'll be able to jump.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. 2. Bend your knees and lower your body slightly. 3. Jump upward explosively, bringing your knees toward your chest. 4. Land softly and repeat.

Title: Muscle Beach Skip
Desc: Muscle Beach Skip is a dynamic exercise that involves skipping to improve cardiovascular fitness and coordination. It engages the lower body muscles while providing a fun way to get your heart rate up.
HowTo: 1. Stand tall with your feet together. 2. Begin skipping by lifting one knee high while pushing off the opposite foot. 3. Alternate legs in a rhythmic motion, using your arms to help propel you forward.

Title: Muscle Beach Broad Jump
Desc: The broad jump is a powerful lower-body exercise that focuses on explosiveness and distance. It helps develop strength in the legs and is often used in athletic training.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. 2. Bend your knees and swing your arms back. 3. Jump forward as far as you can, swinging your arms forward for momentum. 4. Land softly with your knees slightly bent.

Title: Muscle Beach Sprint
Desc: Muscle Beach Sprint is a high-intensity exercise that focuses on speed and cardiovascular endurance. It engages the lower body and improves overall fitness levels.
HowTo: 1. Start in a standing position with your feet hip-width apart. 2. Bend your knees slightly and lean forward. 3. Sprint forward at maximum effort for a short distance. 4. Focus on quick, powerful strides.

Title: Muscle Beach Front Kick
Desc: The Muscle Beach Front Kick is a dynamic exercise that focuses on improving hip mobility and leg strength. It involves kicking forward to engage the muscles of the legs and core.
HowTo: 1. Stand upright with your feet shoulder-width apart. 2. Lift one leg and kick it forward, keeping your knee straight. 3. Return to the starting position and repeat with the other leg.

Title: Muscle Beach Side Kick
Desc: The Muscle Beach Side Kick enhances lateral movement and flexibility in the legs. This exercise targets the inner and outer thigh muscles while improving balance.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet together. 2. Lift one leg out to the side, keeping it straight. 3. Lower it back down and repeat on the other side.

Title: Muscle Beach Spin Kick
Desc: The Muscle Beach Spin Kick is a dynamic movement that combines balance and coordination. It engages the core and leg muscles while enhancing agility.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. 2. Pivot on one foot while spinning your body and kicking with the opposite leg. 3. Return to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Muscle Beach Freestyle Kick
Desc: The Muscle Beach Freestyle Kick is a versatile exercise that promotes flexibility and strength in the legs. It can be performed in various directions to target different muscle groups.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. 2. Kick one leg forward, then to the side, and finally backward in a fluid motion. 3. Repeat with the other leg.

Title: MetaBurn Alternating Curtsy Lunge To Squat
Desc: The MetaBurn Alternating Curtsy Lunge To Squat is a compound exercise that targets the lower body and improves overall strength. It combines lunges and squats for a comprehensive workout.
HowTo: 1. Start in a standing position. 2. Step one leg back into a curtsy lunge, then return to standing. 3. Immediately go into a squat, then return to standing and repeat on the other side.

Title: MetaBurn Alternating Curtsy Lunge With High Knee
Desc: The MetaBurn Alternating Curtsy Lunge With High Knee is a dynamic lower body exercise that targets the legs and glutes. It combines a curtsy lunge with a high knee lift to enhance balance and strength.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet hip-width apart. 2. Step your right leg back and to the left into a curtsy lunge. 3. Push through your left heel to return to standing while lifting your right knee towards your chest. 4. Alternate sides.

Title: MetaBurn Alternating Diagonal Sprawl
Desc: The MetaBurn Alternating Diagonal Sprawl is a high-intensity exercise that engages multiple muscle groups while improving cardiovascular endurance. It involves quick movements that mimic a sprawl, enhancing agility and coordination.
HowTo: 1. Start in a standing position. 2. Quickly drop into a squat and place your hands on the ground. 3. Jump your feet back into a plank position. 4. Jump your feet back towards your hands and return to standing, alternating diagonal movements.

Title: MetaBurn Alternating Lateral Sprawl
Desc: The MetaBurn Alternating Lateral Sprawl is a fast-paced exercise that works the entire body and boosts heart rate. It focuses on lateral movements to improve coordination and agility.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. 2. Drop into a squat and place your hands on the ground. 3. Jump your feet out to the side into a plank position. 4. Jump back to the squat and alternate sides.

Title: MetaBurn Curtsy Lunge
Desc: The MetaBurn Curtsy Lunge is a strength exercise that targets the legs and glutes while improving balance. It involves a curtsy motion that engages the inner thighs and stabilizing muscles.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet hip-width apart. 2. Step your right leg back and to the left, bending both knees into a curtsy lunge. 3. Push through your front heel to return to standing. 4. Alternate legs.

Title: MetaBurn Frogger
Desc: The MetaBurn Frogger is a dynamic exercise that combines strength and cardio, engaging multiple muscle groups. It mimics a frog-like movement to enhance agility and power.
HowTo: 1. Start in a standing position. 2. Squat down and place your hands on the ground. 3. Jump your feet forward towards your hands, landing in a squat. 4. Jump back to the starting position and repeat.

Title: MetaBurn High Knee Rotation
Desc: The MetaBurn High Knee Rotation is a dynamic exercise that engages multiple muscle groups while improving cardiovascular fitness. It involves high knees and rotational movements to enhance agility and coordination.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet hip-width apart. 2. Lift your right knee towards your chest while rotating your torso to the right. 3. Lower your right leg and repeat on the left side, alternating sides at a quick pace.

Title: MetaBurn Side-To-Side Lunge
Desc: The MetaBurn Side-To-Side Lunge is an effective lower body exercise that targets the legs and glutes. It improves strength and stability while engaging the core.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. 2. Step to the right with your right foot, bending your right knee into a lunge while keeping your left leg straight. 3. Push off your right foot to return to the starting position and repeat on the left side.

Title: MetaBurn Star Jump
Desc: The MetaBurn Star Jump is a high-energy exercise that combines jumping and coordination. It helps to improve cardiovascular endurance and overall body strength.
HowTo: 1. Start in a standing position with your feet together. 2. Jump up while spreading your legs and arms out into a star shape. 3. Land softly and return to the starting position, repeating the jump.

Title: MetaBurn Tuck Jump With Knee Slap
Desc: The MetaBurn Tuck Jump With Knee Slap is a plyometric exercise that enhances explosive power and coordination. It targets the legs and core while improving agility.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. 2. Jump up, bringing your knees towards your chest while slapping your knees with your hands. 3. Land softly and repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: MetaBurn Lateral Bounding Hop
Desc: The MetaBurn Lateral Bounding Hop is a dynamic exercise that improves lateral movement and leg strength. It engages the legs and core while enhancing balance and coordination.
HowTo: 1. Stand on your right leg with your left leg slightly lifted. 2. Push off your right leg to jump laterally to the left, landing softly on your left leg. 3. Repeat the movement, alternating sides.

Title: MetaBurn Double Lunge
Desc: The MetaBurn Double Lunge is a lower body exercise that targets the legs and improves balance and coordination. It involves alternating lunges to engage multiple muscle groups effectively.
HowTo: 1. Stand upright with feet hip-width apart. 2. Step forward with one leg into a lunge position, keeping the knee over the ankle. 3. Push back to the starting position and repeat with the other leg. 4. Continue alternating legs for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Robertson Sprinter Step-Up
Desc: The Robertson Sprinter Step-Up is a dynamic exercise that targets the lower body while also improving cardiovascular fitness. It mimics the motion of sprinting and helps develop explosive power.
HowTo: 1. Stand in front of a sturdy bench or step. 2. Place one foot on the bench and push through the heel to step up, bringing the opposite knee up towards your chest. 3. Step back down and repeat with the other leg. 4. Continue alternating legs for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: FYR2 Front Kick-Through
Desc: The FYR2 Front Kick-Through is a mobility exercise that enhances flexibility and core stability. It involves a dynamic movement pattern that engages multiple muscle groups.
HowTo: 1. Start in a plank position with hands under shoulders. 2. Bring one knee towards your chest, then kick it through to the side while rotating your hips. 3. Return to plank and repeat on the other side. 4. Continue alternating sides for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Lunge high-knee clap
Desc: The lunge high-knee clap is a full-body, cardio-based exercise with emphasis on the lower body. It includes a clap under the front leg to make the movement more powerful and strict. It can be performed either for time or reps and is a great inclusion in a fat-loss or athleticism-focused circuit workout.
HowTo: 1. Start in a standing position. 2. Step forward into a lunge while raising the opposite knee and clapping your hands under the lifted leg. 3. Return to standing and repeat with the other leg. 4. Continue alternating legs for the desired duration.

Title: FYR2 Plyo Split Squat
Desc: The FYR2 Plyo Split Squat is an explosive exercise that targets the legs and enhances power and agility. It involves a jumping motion that engages multiple muscle groups.
HowTo: 1. Start in a split squat position with one foot forward and one foot back. 2. Lower your body into a squat, then explosively jump up, switching your legs mid-air. 3. Land softly in the split squat position with the opposite leg forward. 4. Continue alternating legs for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: FYR2 Reverse Burpee
Desc: The FYR2 Reverse Burpee is a dynamic exercise that combines a squat and a backward roll into a standing position. It engages multiple muscle groups and improves coordination and cardiovascular fitness.
HowTo: 1. Start in a standing position. 2. Squat down and place your hands on the ground. 3. Roll backward onto your back, then roll forward to return to a standing position.

Title: FYR2 Reverse Burpee to Regular Burpee
Desc: The FYR2 Reverse Burpee to Regular Burpee combines two effective exercises for a full-body workout. This movement enhances strength, endurance, and agility.
HowTo: 1. Start in a standing position. 2. Perform a reverse burpee as described above. 3. From the standing position, drop into a squat and kick your feet back into a plank position. 4. Perform a push-up if desired, then jump your feet back to the squat and explode up into a jump.

Title: FYR2 Reverse Burpee Tuck Jump
Desc: The FYR2 Reverse Burpee Tuck Jump is a high-intensity exercise that combines a reverse burpee with a tuck jump. It challenges your cardiovascular system and builds explosive power.
HowTo: 1. Start in a standing position. 2. Perform a reverse burpee to roll back. 3. As you come up, jump explosively and tuck your knees to your chest. 4. Land softly and return to the starting position.

Title: FYR2 Sprawlee
Desc: The FYR2 Sprawlee is a dynamic movement that engages the entire body while improving agility and coordination. It's an excellent way to elevate your heart rate.
HowTo: 1. Start in a standing position. 2. Drop into a squat and place your hands on the ground. 3. Jump your feet back into a plank position. 4. Quickly return your feet to the squat and jump up explosively.

Title: FYR2 Squat Hold
Desc: The FYR2 Squat Hold is an isometric exercise that targets the lower body muscles, particularly the legs and glutes. It helps build endurance and strength in the squat position.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. 2. Lower into a squat position, keeping your back straight and chest up. 3. Hold the squat position for a specified duration, ensuring your knees do not go past your toes.

Title: FYR2 Squat Jump
Desc: The FYR2 Squat Jump is a plyometric exercise that helps develop explosive power in the legs. It involves jumping from a squat position to maximize height and power output.
HowTo: 1. Start in a squat position with your feet shoulder-width apart. 2. Explode upward, jumping as high as you can. 3. Land softly back into the squat position and repeat.

Title: FYR2 Squat Pulse
Desc: The FYR2 Squat Pulse is a variation of the squat that emphasizes endurance and strength in the legs. It involves performing small pulses at the bottom of the squat position to increase time under tension.
HowTo: 1. Begin in a squat position with your thighs parallel to the ground. 2. Pulse up and down in the squat position without fully standing up. 3. Maintain tension in your legs and repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Sprinter burpee
Desc: The sprinter burpee is an explosive version of the burpee exercise that adds a sprinter jump to the top of each rep. It can be performed for time or reps in any fat-loss or athleticism-focused circuit or workout.
HowTo: 1. Start in a standing position. 2. Drop into a squat and place your hands on the ground. 3. Kick your feet back into a plank position. 4. Perform a push-up (optional). 5. Jump your feet back to your hands and explode upwards into a sprinter jump.

Title: Shuttle run training
Desc: Shuttle run training is an athletic conditioning drill thats great for developing speed and power, as well as changing direction. Its a favorite of football and basketball players, but it can also be great conditioning work for lifters and athletes of all ability levels.
HowTo: 1. Set up two markers about 10-20 meters apart. 2. Start at one marker and sprint to the other. 3. Touch the ground at the marker and sprint back. 4. Repeat for the desired duration or number of reps.

Title: Medicine ball ninja
Desc: The medicine ball ninja is a dynamic medicine ball movement that challenges both the upper and lower body, while also elevating the heart rate. It's a great movement to include in medicine ball or bodyweight circuit training to increase fatigue and burn serious calories while hammering the muscles of the legs.
HowTo: 1. Start in a standing position holding a medicine ball. 2. Squat down and place the ball on the ground. 3. Jump your feet back into a plank position. 4. Jump your feet back to your hands and explosively jump up, raising the ball overhead.

Title: FYR Air Ball Plus Medicine Ball Jumping Sprawl
Desc: The medicine ball air ball to jumping sprawl is a series of bodyweight and medicine ball movement strung together into a single sequence. They collectively target virtually every muscle in the body, as well as seriously challenging the cardiovascular system. It can be a single-movement workout if done for high reps, or part of a larger circuit workout.
HowTo: 1. Start in a standing position holding a medicine ball. 2. Perform a squat and place the ball on the ground. 3. Jump your feet back into a plank position. 4. Jump your feet back towards your hands. 5. Jump up explosively while raising the medicine ball overhead.

Title: Medicine ball cowboy squat
Desc: The medicine ball cowboy squat is an explosive exercise targeting the lower body, although several upper-body muscles play important supporting roles. The move involves performing jumping squats while holding a medicine ball overhead. It's commonly performed as part of a bodyweight and medicine ball circuit focused on fat loss or athleticism.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a medicine ball overhead. 2. Lower into a squat position while keeping the ball raised. 3. Explode upwards into a jump, extending your legs fully. 4. Land softly and immediately go into the next squat.

Title: Medicine ball jumping jill
Desc: The medicine ball jumping jill is an explosive medicine ball exercise that is similar to a jumping jack but performed holding a medicine ball between the hands. It can be performed for time or reps in a dynamic warm-up or fat-loss or conditioning circuit, usually paired with other bodyweight or medicine ball movements.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet together, holding a medicine ball in both hands at chest level. 2. Jump your feet out to the sides while raising the ball overhead. 3. Jump back to the starting position while lowering the ball back to chest level. 4. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Alternate Leg Diagonal Bound
Desc: The Alternate Leg Diagonal Bound is a dynamic exercise that focuses on explosive leg movement and coordination. It targets the lower body while also engaging the core for stability.
HowTo: 1. Stand on one leg with the other leg slightly bent behind you. 2. Push off the standing leg and jump diagonally forward, landing on the opposite leg. 3. Use your arms to help propel your body and maintain balance. 4. Alternate legs with each jump.

Title: Sit Squats
Desc: Sit squats are a foundational exercise that targets the lower body, focusing on building strength and stability. They are performed by sitting back into a squat position as if sitting on an invisible chair.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. 2. Push your hips back and bend your knees to lower your body into a squat. 3. Keep your chest up and back straight as you lower down. 4. Hold the squat position for a moment before standing back up.

Title: Frog Hops
Desc: Frog hops are a plyometric exercise that targets the lower body, particularly the legs. They involve jumping forward in a frog-like motion, which helps improve explosive strength and agility.
HowTo: 1. Start in a squat position with your feet shoulder-width apart. 2. Jump forward explosively, landing softly and immediately going into the next hop.

Title: Dumbbell lateral hop to sprint
Desc: The dumbbell lateral hop to sprint is a multi-part explosive exercise combining weighted hops with weighted sprinting. Adding dumbbells adds a challenge to the core and shoulders. Because balance can be a challenge, it is usually performed with relatively light weights, often as a component of fat-loss or athletic training.
HowTo: 1. Hold a dumbbell in each hand and stand with your feet together. 2. Jump laterally to one side, landing softly, then immediately sprint forward for a few steps. 3. Repeat on the other side.

Title: Smith machine lunge sprint
Desc: The Smith machine lunge sprint is a lower-body power exercise performed with the bar of a Smith machine on the back. It is similar to an alternating jump lunge or "scissor lunge," but with added weight. The contained bar of the Smith machine makes it safer and less of a balance challenge than using a free weight.
HowTo: 1. Position the bar on your back and stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. 2. Step forward into a lunge, then explosively push off the front foot to return to standing. 3. Alternate legs and repeat.

Title: Sissy squat
Desc: The sissy squat is a bodyweight squat variation that involves letting the knees travel far over the toes, placing an extreme stretch on the quads. This movement targets the quad muscles directly and can be performed in partial or full ranges of motion based on knee health and pain.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. 2. Lean back while bending your knees, allowing them to travel forward over your toes. 3. Lower your body as far as comfortable, then return to standing.

Title: Wall ball toss
Desc: The wall ball toss is an explosive full-body exercise utilizing a medicine ball. It involves squatting down, then explosively pressing a weighted ball into the air and catching it on a bounce off of a vertical surface. It is common in CrossFit workouts and can be performed for time or reps.
HowTo: 1. Hold a medicine ball at chest level and stand facing a wall. 2. Perform a squat, then explosively stand up while throwing the ball against the wall. 3. Catch the ball on the rebound and repeat.

Title: Bosu Ball Squat
Desc: The Bosu Ball Squat is a variation of the traditional squat that incorporates balance training. It helps improve leg strength while also engaging core stability.
HowTo: 1. Stand on the flat side of a Bosu ball with your feet shoulder-width apart. 2. Lower your body into a squat position, keeping your chest up and knees behind your toes. 3. Push through your heels to return to the starting position.

Title: Exercise ball Bulgarian split squat
Desc: The exercise ball Bulgarian split squat is an exercise that builds the quads, hamstrings, and glutes one leg at a time. The exercise ball is used to support the trailing shin and foot. Due to the balance challenge, this version of the split squat is usually performed for moderate to high reps with body weight only or light weights in the hands. If balance is a problem, you can stick the ball in the corner of a room while performing the exercise.
HowTo: 1. Stand a few feet in front of an exercise ball. 2. Place one foot on the ball behind you. 3. Lower your body into a lunge, keeping your front knee aligned with your ankle. 4. Push back up to the starting position.

Title: Internal Rotation with Band
Desc: Internal rotation with a band is an exercise that focuses on improving shoulder mobility and stability. It targets the rotator cuff muscles, which are crucial for shoulder health.
HowTo: 1. Attach a resistance band at elbow height. 2. Stand with your side to the band and hold it with the hand closest to it. 3. Keep your elbow at your side and rotate your arm inward, pulling the band towards your body. 4. Slowly return to the starting position.

Title: Band Pull Apart
Desc: The band pull-apart is an exercise targeting the upper back muscles, including the trapezius, rear delts, and rhomboids. The band creates dynamic tension, allowing you to really focus on contracting these muscles, making it a great activation drill prior to upper-body lifting.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and hold a resistance band with both hands in front of you at shoulder height. 2. Pull the band apart by moving your arms out to the sides, keeping your elbows slightly bent. 3. Squeeze your shoulder blades together at the end of the movement. 4. Slowly return to the starting position.

Title: Back Flyes - With Bands
Desc: Back Flyes with bands are an effective exercise for targeting the upper back and improving posture. They help strengthen the muscles that support the shoulder girdle.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and hold a resistance band with both hands in front of you. 2. Bend slightly at the waist and extend your arms in front of you. 3. Pull the band apart while keeping your arms slightly bent, squeezing your shoulder blades together. 4. Return to the starting position.

Title: Lateral Raise - With Bands
Desc: The lateral raise with bands targets the shoulder muscles, particularly the deltoids. This exercise helps in building shoulder strength and stability.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, holding a resistance band in both hands. 2. Raise your arms to the side until they are parallel to the ground, keeping a slight bend in the elbows. 3. Slowly lower back to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Shoulder Press - With Bands
Desc: The shoulder press with bands is an effective exercise for strengthening the shoulder muscles. It also engages the triceps and upper chest.
HowTo: 1. Stand on the resistance band with feet shoulder-width apart, holding the ends at shoulder height. 2. Press the bands overhead until your arms are fully extended. 3. Lower back to shoulder height and repeat.

Title: External Rotation with Band
Desc: External rotation with a band is designed to strengthen the rotator cuff muscles. This exercise promotes shoulder stability and mobility.
HowTo: 1. Attach a resistance band to a stable object at waist height. 2. Stand sideways to the band, holding it with the hand farthest from the anchor. 3. Keeping your elbow at your side, rotate your arm outward away from your body. 4. Return to the starting position and repeat.

Title: FYR Band Pull-Apart
Desc: The FYR band pull-apart focuses on the upper back and rear shoulder muscles. It helps improve posture and upper body strength.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, holding a resistance band with both hands in front of you at shoulder height. 2. Pull the band apart by moving your arms out to the sides while keeping them straight. 3. Squeeze your shoulder blades together at the end of the movement, then return to the starting position.

Title: HM Lateral Raise
Desc: The HM lateral raise is a variation of the lateral raise that focuses on the shoulder muscles. It enhances shoulder definition and strength.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, holding weights or resistance bands at your sides. 2. Raise your arms out to the sides until they are parallel to the ground, keeping a slight bend in your elbows. 3. Lower your arms back to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Rusin Banded Over-And-Back
Desc: The Rusin Banded Over-And-Back is a mobility exercise designed to improve shoulder flexibility and stability. It involves using a resistance band to perform a controlled movement that stretches and strengthens the shoulder muscles.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and hold a resistance band with both hands. 2. Raise the band overhead and slowly bring it behind your back while keeping your arms straight. 3. Reverse the motion to return to the starting position.

Title: Rusin Banded Face Pull
Desc: The Rusin Banded Face Pull is an effective exercise for targeting the upper back and shoulder muscles. It helps improve posture and shoulder stability by engaging the rear deltoids and upper back.
HowTo: 1. Attach a resistance band to a stable anchor at shoulder height. 2. Stand facing the anchor and grasp the band with both hands, palms facing down. 3. Pull the band towards your face while keeping your elbows high and squeezing your shoulder blades together. 4. Slowly return to the starting position.

Title: UP Band Pull-Apart
Desc: The UP Band Pull-Apart is a simple yet effective exercise for strengthening the shoulder and upper back muscles. It focuses on improving shoulder stability and posture.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and hold a resistance band with both hands in front of you at shoulder height. 2. Keeping your arms straight, pull the band apart by moving your hands outward. 3. Squeeze your shoulder blades together at the end of the movement, then return to the starting position.

Title: Jordan Shallow Band-Resisted Thread the Needle
Desc: The Jordan Shallow Band-Resisted Thread the Needle is a mobility exercise that enhances thoracic spine rotation and shoulder flexibility. It is particularly beneficial for improving posture and reducing tension in the upper back.
HowTo: 1. Start in a tabletop position on your hands and knees with a resistance band anchored to one side. 2. Reach one arm under your body and thread it through the band while rotating your torso. 3. Return to the starting position and repeat on the other side.

Title: 30 Shoulders Seated Banded Barbell Shoulder Press
Desc: The 30 Shoulders Seated Banded Barbell Shoulder Press is a strength exercise that targets the shoulder muscles while also engaging the triceps and upper chest. It is performed seated to enhance stability and focus on shoulder strength.
HowTo: 1. Sit on a bench with back support and hold a resistance band or barbell at shoulder height. 2. Press the band or barbell overhead until your arms are fully extended. 3. Lower it back to the starting position with control.

Title: Band shoulder press
Desc: The band shoulder press is a deltoid exercise and an alternative to the classic dumbbell shoulder press. The dynamic tension of the band forces the core to stabilize the body and more closely matches the strength curve of the shoulder press. It can be performed in low reps, such as 5-8 reps per set, to build shoulder strength, or for higher reps to build muscle and for conditioning. It can work as the main focus of a shoulder day but is also popular as an accessory movement to the bench press or barbell military press.
HowTo: 1. Stand on the band with feet shoulder-width apart. 2. Hold the band handles at shoulder height with palms facing forward. 3. Press the band overhead until arms are fully extended. 4. Lower back to the starting position.

Title: Band lateral raise
Desc: The band lateral raise is a shoulder exercise that targets the medial or middle head of the deltoid muscle. It's a variation of the dumbbell lateral raise, a staple strength-training move. The band lateral raise is a great option for warm-up or accessory work on upper-body training days. The dynamic tension of the band provides constant tension and matches the strength curve of the movement. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps, at least 8-12 reps, as part of the upper-body or shoulder-focused portion of a workout.
HowTo: 1. Stand on the band with feet shoulder-width apart. 2. Hold the band handles at your sides. 3. Raise your arms out to the sides until they are parallel to the ground. 4. Lower back to the starting position.

Title: Band upright row
Desc: The band upright row is a popular movement for building stronger and bigger traps and shoulders and similar to the dumbbell upright row. Many lifters combine this move with either their back or shoulder workout, since it involves both body parts. Using the band provides dynamic resistance and is easier on the shoulder than using a barbell. It is generally performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more.
HowTo: 1. Stand on the band with feet shoulder-width apart. 2. Hold the band handles with palms facing your body. 3. Pull the band up towards your chin, keeping elbows higher than wrists. 4. Lower back to the starting position.

Title: Staggered-stance band shoulder press
Desc: The staggered-stance band shoulder press is a deltoid exercise and a variation of the band shoulder press. The dynamic tension of the band forces the core to stabilize the body, and the staggered-stance provides more stability and relieves tension on the back. It can be performed in low reps, such as 5-8 reps per set, to build shoulder strength, or for higher reps to build muscle and for conditioning. It can work as the main focus of a shoulder day but is also popular as an accessory movement to the bench press or barbell military press.
HowTo: 1. Stand with one foot forward and the other back, on the band with feet shoulder-width apart. 2. Hold the band handles at shoulder height with palms facing forward. 3. Press the band overhead until arms are fully extended. 4. Lower back to the starting position.

Title: Single-arm banded landmine press
Desc: The single-arm banded landmine press is an upper-body exercise that uses an angled barbell anchored at floor level in a landmine device. It can also be performed by sticking a barbell in the corner of a room, preferably in a towel to protect the walls. The band adds constant tension and dynamic resistance to the exercise. The movement focuses primarily on the muscles of the shoulders or deltoids and can be trained in traditional muscle and strength-focused rep ranges or for higher reps.
HowTo: 1. Set up a barbell in a landmine attachment or corner. 2. Attach a band to the barbell and hold it with one hand. 3. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart. 4. Press the banded barbell upward until your arm is fully extended. 5. Lower back to the starting position.

Title: Band front raise rear fly row combo
Desc: The band front raise rear fly row combo is a combination of three different shoulder exercises to build and strengthen the anterior, middle deltoids, and posterior portions of the shoulders. It requires a continuous loop band to provide constant, dynamic tension throughout the movement. In addition to the front and rear delts, this exercise works the arms, chest, back, and core, making it a great time-efficient shoulder burnout or accessory movement on an upper-body day.
Muscles: anterior deltoids, middle deltoids, posterior deltoids, arms, chest, back, core
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, holding the band with both hands. 2. Raise the band in front of you to shoulder height (front raise). 3. Open your arms to the side to perform a rear fly. 4. Pull the band towards your chest to complete the row. 5. Repeat the sequence for the desired number of reps.

Title: Jordan Shallow Foam Roller Thoracic Extension
Desc: The Jordan Shallow Foam Roller Thoracic Extension is designed to improve mobility in the thoracic spine. This exercise helps to alleviate tension and improve posture.
HowTo: 1. Sit on the floor with your legs extended in front of you. 2. Place a foam roller horizontally behind your upper back. 3. Lean back over the foam roller, allowing your thoracic spine to extend. 4. Hold the position for a few seconds, then return to the starting position. 5. Repeat for several reps.

Title: Jordan Shallow Thread the Needle (with Foam Roller)
Desc: The Jordan Shallow Thread the Needle (with Foam Roller) is a mobility exercise that targets the thoracic spine and shoulders. It helps to improve flexibility and relieve tension in the upper body.
HowTo: 1. Start on all fours with a foam roller placed under one arm. 2. Reach the opposite arm up towards the ceiling. 3. Thread the arm under your body and reach towards the opposite side. 4. Hold the stretch for a few seconds, then return to the starting position. 5. Repeat on both sides.

Title: Clean and press
Desc: The clean and press is a full-body lift comprised of two movements: the clean, where the bar is pulled from the floor and caught in the front rack position in three pulls or phases, followed by the overhead press. Decades ago, it was contested in the Olympics. Today, it remains a worthy centerpiece of a power and strength training program, and has full-body benefits when done for low reps as well as moderate to high reps.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, barbell on the floor. 2. Bend at the hips and knees to grip the bar. 3. Pull the bar up to your shoulders (clean). 4. Press the bar overhead (press). 5. Lower the bar back to the floor and repeat.

Title: Clean and jerk
Desc: The clean and jerk is a full-body lift that is one of two contested lifts in Olympic weightlifting competitions. It is comprised of two movements: the clean, where the bar is pulled from the floor and caught in the front rack position in three pulls or phases, followed by the jerk overhead. The clean and jerk hits every muscle from head to toe and can be the centerpiece of a lifting program. It is also popular in CrossFit and athletic training programs. It is usually performed in low rep ranges, focusing on power and movement quality.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, barbell on the floor. 2. Grip the bar and pull it up to your shoulders (clean). 3. Dip slightly and drive the bar overhead (jerk). 4. Lower the bar back to the floor and repeat. 5. Focus on form and movement quality throughout.

Title: Military press
Desc: The military press is a compound movement used to build size and strength in the shoulders. It was once contested as a fourth powerlift, but is rarely competed anymore. However, being able to press a significant weight overhead remains a popular marker of upper-body strength. The military press can be trained as a strength lift or in traditional muscle-building rep ranges as part of full-body, shoulder-focused, or upper-body training.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. 2. Grip the barbell with both hands slightly wider than shoulder-width. 3. Press the barbell overhead until your arms are fully extended. 4. Lower the barbell back to shoulder level and repeat.

Title: Seated barbell shoulder press
Desc: The seated barbell shoulder press is a classic exercise for building muscle and strength in the shoulders. The triceps also play a significant role in pressing the barbell overhead. Performing the movement seated reduces help from the lower body and decreases the risk of overextending the lumbar spine during the movement. This press variation can be the primary pressing movement on an upper-body or shoulder day, or an effective accessory movement later in a workout.
HowTo: 1. Sit on a bench with back support. 2. Grip the barbell with both hands shoulder-width apart. 3. Press the barbell overhead until your arms are fully extended. 4. Lower the barbell back to shoulder level and repeat.

Title: Snatch-Grip Behind-The-Neck Overhead Press
Desc: The Snatch-Grip Behind-The-Neck Overhead Press is a variation of the overhead press that emphasizes shoulder mobility and strength. It requires a wider grip on the barbell, which can enhance the range of motion.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and grip the barbell with a wide grip. 2. Lift the barbell overhead from behind your neck until your arms are fully extended. 3. Lower the barbell back to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Standing Bradford press
Desc: The standing Bradford press is an obscure yet effective shoulder exercise that alternates front presses with behind-the-neck presses. It can be used as a warm-up for other press variations on a shoulder day, or as a muscle-building movement on its own in a shoulder or upper-body focused workout. It is usually performed for relatively high reps, such as 8-15 reps per set or higher, or just to the point of fatigue.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. 2. Grip the barbell with both hands shoulder-width apart. 3. Press the barbell overhead, alternating between front and behind-the-neck positions. 4. Lower the barbell back to shoulder level and repeat.

Title: Barbell Shoulder Press
Desc: The seated barbell shoulder pressis a classic exercise for building muscle and strengthening the shoulders, particularly but not exclusively the front heads. The triceps also play a significant roles in pressing the barbell overhead.
HowTo: 1. Sit on a bench with back support. 2. Grip the barbell with both hands shoulder-width apart. 3. Press the barbell overhead until your arms are fully extended. 4. Lower the barbell back to shoulder level and repeat.

Title: Barbell rear delt bent-over row
Desc: The barbell rear delt bent-over row is a movement used to target the shoulders as well as the upper-back muscles. It is performed with lighter weights than a traditional barbell bent-over row, and is usually performed for higher reps, such as 8-15 reps per set, as part of a back or upper-body workout.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and hold a barbell with both hands. 2. Bend at the hips and knees, keeping your back straight, and lower your torso until it's nearly parallel to the ground. 3. Pull the barbell towards your chest, squeezing your shoulder blades together. 4. Lower the barbell back to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Barbell upright row
Desc: The barbell upright row is a barbell exercise that builds stronger and bigger traps. Many lifters combine this move with either their back or shoulder workout since it involves both body parts.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a barbell with an overhand grip. 2. Pull the barbell straight up towards your chin, keeping it close to your body. 3. Raise your elbows above your shoulders at the top of the movement. 4. Lower the barbell back to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Bradford/Rocky Presses
Desc: Bradford/Rocky Presses are a shoulder exercise that targets the deltoids and triceps. This exercise involves pressing the barbell overhead in a unique manner to enhance shoulder stability and strength.
HowTo: 1. Sit or stand with a barbell at shoulder height. 2. Press the barbell overhead, then lower it back to the front of your shoulders. 3. Immediately press it back overhead again, alternating the movement. 4. Continue this pattern for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Lying rear delt fly
Desc: The lying rear delt fly is an upper-body exercise that targets the rear deltoid of the shoulder. By performing the movement lying face down on a bench, it eliminates momentum from the rest of the body. This movement is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of the upper-body or shoulder-focused portion of a workout.
HowTo: 1. Lie face down on a bench with your arms hanging down holding dumbbells. 2. Keep a slight bend in your elbows and raise the dumbbells out to the sides. 3. Squeeze your shoulder blades together at the top of the movement. 4. Lower the dumbbells back to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Machine Shoulder (Military) Press
Desc: The machine shoulder press is an upper body exercise targeting the deltoids.
HowTo: 1. Sit at the machine with your back against the pad and feet flat on the floor. 2. Adjust the seat height so that the handles are at shoulder level. 3. Grip the handles and press them upward until your arms are fully extended. 4. Slowly lower the handles back to shoulder level and repeat.

Title: Standing Barbell Press Behind Neck
Desc: The standing behind-the-head press is a classic shoulder exercise that was used widely during bodybuilding's professed Golden Era. In addition to the deltoids, it also works the trapezius and triceps muscles. It may not be a good choice for some people's shoulders, depending on their injury history. It can be trained in strength-focused rep ranges, but is more commonly trained in moderate to high reps, such as 8-15 reps per set.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and grip the barbell behind your neck. 2. Press the barbell overhead while keeping your core engaged and back straight.

Title: Barbell front raise
Desc: The barbell front raise is an upper-body isolation exercise that targets the shoulders. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps or higher, as part of the shoulder-focused part of any workout.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and hold a barbell in front of your thighs. 2. Raise the barbell in front of you to shoulder height, keeping your arms straight.

Title: Overhead bar front raise
Desc: The overhead bar front raise is an exercise targeting the muscles of the traps (trapezius), especially the upper traps, as well as the front or anterior shoulders. It can also be performed with a weight plate or dumbbell, providing a neutral grip that may be more shoulder-friendly for some lifters. Overhead raises are most common for high reps (at least 8-12 reps per set or higher) on a shoulder, trap, or other upper-body-focused muscle-building day.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and hold a barbell at shoulder height. 2. Raise the barbell overhead while engaging your traps and shoulders.

Title: Incline barbell shoulder protraction
Desc: The incline barbell shoulder protraction is an upper-body movement that targets strength and mobility in the scapula or shoulder blades. This can help increase pressing strength and prevent injury. It also helps develop the serratus anterior, an often-neglected muscle around the ribcage that can aid in shoulder health and upper-body muscle definition. Because it targets such small muscles, this exercise is usually performed with light weight for high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more.
HowTo: 1. Lie on an incline bench with a barbell in your hands. 2. Protract your shoulders by pushing the barbell forward while keeping your elbows straight.

Title: Behind-the-head push-press
Desc: The behind-the-head push-press is an overhead press variation in which the barbell starts in the back rack position and is pushed overhead with assistance from the lower body. It is most often seen in training for Olympic weightlifting. It can be part of a barbell complex or performed for low reps focusing on power and movement quality.
HowTo: 1. Start with the barbell in the back rack position at shoulder height. 2. Use your legs to assist in pushing the barbell overhead explosively.

Title: Rack Delivery
Desc: The Rack Delivery is a compound exercise that engages multiple muscle groups. It is often used in Olympic weightlifting to develop strength and power.
HowTo: 1. Start with the barbell in a rack position at shoulder height. 2. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. 3. Lift the barbell off the rack and stabilize it at shoulder level. 4.
