Perform a front squat, then drive through your heels to stand up. 5. Lower the barbell back to the rack position.

Title: Smith Incline Shoulder Raise
Desc: The Smith Incline Shoulder Raise targets the shoulder muscles, particularly the deltoids. It is performed on an incline to isolate the upper part of the shoulders.
HowTo: 1. Set the Smith machine bar to an appropriate height. 2. Adjust the bench to an incline position. 3. Sit on the bench with your back against it and grasp the bar with an overhand grip. 4. Raise the bar above your head until your arms are fully extended. 5. Lower the bar back to shoulder level and repeat.

Title: Tall Muscle Snatch
Desc: The Tall Muscle Snatch is a dynamic exercise that focuses on explosive power and full-body coordination. It is commonly used in Olympic weightlifting training.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and hold the barbell at hip level. 2. Bend your knees slightly and hinge at the hips. 3. In one explosive motion, extend your hips and pull the barbell upward. 4. As the bar reaches chest height, drop under it and catch it overhead in a squat position. 5. Stand up to complete the lift.

Title: Axle Clean And Press
Desc: The Axle Clean And Press is a compound exercise that builds strength and power in the upper and lower body. It involves lifting a thick barbell from the ground to an overhead position.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, with the axle bar on the ground in front of you. 2. Bend at the hips and knees to grip the bar with both hands. 3. Lift the bar to your shoulders in one motion (the clean). 4. Once at shoulder level, press the bar overhead until your arms are fully extended. 5. Lower the bar back to your shoulders and then to the ground.

Title: Jerk Balance
Desc: The Jerk Balance is a technique-focused exercise that helps improve your jerk lift in Olympic weightlifting. It emphasizes balance and stability while holding a barbell overhead.
HowTo: 1. Start with the barbell at shoulder height. 2. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. 3. Dip slightly by bending your knees, then explosively drive through your legs to push the bar overhead. 4. As you press the bar up, split your legs into a lunge position for stability. 5. Hold the position briefly before returning to a standing position.

Title: Seated EZ-bar shrug
Desc: The seated EZ-bar shrug is an exercise targeting the trapezius muscle, that V-shaped muscle that forms a triangle where the shoulders meet the neck. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps during an upper-body or shoulders and traps-focused workout.
HowTo: 1. Sit on a bench with an EZ-bar in your hands. 2. Keep your elbows slightly bent and lift your shoulders towards your ears, squeezing the traps at the top of the movement.

Title: Paul Carter Barbell Seated Military Press
Desc: The seated barbell shoulder pressis a classic exercise for building muscle and strengthening the shoulders, particularly but not exclusively the front heads. The triceps also play a significant roles in pressing the barbell overhead.
HowTo: 1. Sit on a bench with a barbell at shoulder height. 2. Grip the barbell with both hands, press it overhead until your arms are fully extended, and then lower it back to shoulder height.

Title: TBS Barbell Military Press
Desc: The military press is a compound movement used to build size and strength in the shoulders. It was once contested as a fourth powerlift, but is rarely competed anymore. However, being able to press a significant weight overhead remains a popular marker of upper-body strength. The military press can be trained as a strength lift or in traditional muscle-building rep ranges as part of full-body, shoulder-focused, or upper-body training.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and hold a barbell at shoulder height. 2. Press the barbell overhead until your arms are fully extended, then lower it back to the starting position.

Title: Incline Front Barbell Raise - Gethin Variation
Desc: The incline face-down bar front raise is an upper-body exercise targeting the shoulders. Because it is performed face down on an angled bench, it has a greater range of motion than standing or upright-seated raises and hits the shoulders from a different angle. Raise variations are usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of upper-body or shoulder-focused training.
HowTo: 1. Lie face down on an inclined bench with a barbell in your hands. 2. Raise the barbell in front of you to shoulder height, then lower it back down with control.

Title: Barbell Front Raise - Gethin Variation
Desc: The barbell front raise is an upper-body isolation exercise that targets the shoulders. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps or higher, as part of the shoulder-focused part of any workout.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and hold a barbell in front of your thighs. 2. Raise the barbell in front of you to shoulder height, keeping your arms straight, then lower it back down.

Title: Single-arm barbell lateral raise
Desc: The single-arm barbell lateral raise is an isolation exercise targeting the shoulders. It is more challenging than using a dumbbell and has an instability component that may make the deltoid muscles work harder. It is generally performed one side at a time for moderate to high reps, such as 8-15 reps per set, as part of a shoulder-focused workout.
HowTo: Stand with a barbell in one hand at your side. Raise the barbell laterally until your arm is parallel to the ground, then lower it back down.

Title: AM Upright Row
Desc: The barbell upright row is a barbell exercise that builds stronger and bigger traps. Many lifters combine this move with either their back or shoulder workout since it involves both body parts.
HowTo: Stand with a barbell held in front of you at hip level. Pull the barbell up towards your chin, keeping your elbows higher than your wrists, then lower it back down.

Title: AM Barbell Shoulder Press
Desc: The standing barbell shoulder press is a compound movement used to build size and strength in the shoulders. The shoulder press can be trained as a strength lift or in traditional muscle-building rep ranges as part of full-body, shoulder-focused, or upper-body training.
HowTo: Stand with a barbell at shoulder height, grip it with both hands. Press the barbell overhead until your arms are fully extended, then lower it back to shoulder height.

Title: Standing barbell shoulder press
Desc: The standing barbell shoulder press is a compound movement used to build size and strength in the shoulders. The shoulder press can be trained as a strength lift or in traditional muscle-building rep ranges as part of full-body, shoulder-focused, or upper-body training.
HowTo: Stand with a barbell at shoulder height, grip it with both hands. Press the barbell overhead until your arms are fully extended, then lower it back to shoulder height.

Title: King Maker Barbell Thruster
Desc: The barbell thruster is a full-body exercise that incorporates both squatting and pressing in one functional movement. It's especially common in contemporary CrossFit workouts, but also in general strength training. The barbell is usually cleaned into place first, but it could be performed taken from a squat rack in a front-rack position. The thruster can be performed in traditional strength-focused rep ranges to build strength in the press, or in higher reps for full-body conditioning.
HowTo: Start in a standing position with the barbell in a front-rack position. Squat down and then explosively press the barbell overhead as you stand up.

Title: Single-arm incline cable cross-over
Desc: The single-arm incline cable cross-over is an isolation movement that uses a cable stack and a bench to target the upper part of the pectoral muscles. Working the chest one side at a time allows you to focus on balance between the sides of your chest and really feel the chest muscles contracting. It is common in upper-body and chest-focused muscle-building workouts, often in combination with other presses or flyes to target the chest from different angles.
HowTo: 1. Set the cable at a low position and adjust the bench to an incline. 2. Stand beside the cable machine and grasp the handle with one hand. 3. Step back and lean slightly forward. 4. Pull the cable across your body, keeping your elbow slightly bent, until your hand is at shoulder height. 5. Slowly return to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Barbell bear complex
Desc: The barbell bear complex is a series of barbell lifts that run together in a single sequence: a barbell power clean, front squat, push-press, back squat, and another push-press from behind the neck. It trains the entire body for both building strength and improving conditioning. It is often performed for rounds, either with or without rest between rounds.
HowTo: 1. Start with the barbell on the ground. 2. Perform a power clean to bring the barbell to your shoulders. 3. Execute a front squat. 4. Perform a push-press to lift the barbell overhead. 5. Lower the barbell to your upper back and perform a back squat. 6. Finish with another push-press from behind the neck.

Title: 30 Shoulders Barbell Shrug
Desc: The 30 Shoulders Barbell Shrug targets the trapezius muscles and helps build shoulder strength. It is commonly used in shoulder workouts to enhance upper back and neck strength.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a barbell at your thighs. 2. Keep your arms straight and lift your shoulders towards your ears. 3. Squeeze at the top for a moment, then lower your shoulders back down.

Title: 30 Shoulders Incline Face-Up Straight-Bar Front Raise
Desc: The 30 Shoulders Incline Face-Up Straight-Bar Front Raise primarily targets the front deltoids. This exercise is effective for building shoulder strength and stability.
HowTo: 1. Lie face-up on an incline bench, holding a straight barbell with both hands. 2. With your arms straight, raise the barbell in front of you to shoulder height. 3. Lower the barbell back down slowly to the starting position.

Title: 30 Shoulders Seated Dumbbell Shoulder Press
Desc: The 30 Shoulders Seated Dumbbell Shoulder Press is an effective exercise for building shoulder strength and mass. It targets the deltoids and triceps while promoting stability.
HowTo: 1. Sit on a bench with back support, holding a dumbbell in each hand at shoulder height. 2. Press the dumbbells overhead until your arms are fully extended. 3. Lower the dumbbells back to shoulder height and repeat.

Title: 30 Shoulders Standing Behind-The-Head Shoulder Press
Desc: The 30 Shoulders Standing Behind-The-Head Shoulder Press is a strength exercise targeting the shoulder muscles. It involves pressing a weight overhead while standing.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. 2. Hold a barbell behind your head with both hands. 3. Press the barbell overhead until your arms are fully extended. 4. Lower the barbell back to the starting position.

Title: 30 Shoulders Standing Barbell Press
Desc: The 30 Shoulders Standing Barbell Press is a classic strength exercise for building shoulder muscle. It requires pressing a barbell overhead while standing.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. 2. Hold a barbell at shoulder height with both hands. 3. Press the barbell overhead until your arms are fully extended. 4. Lower the barbell back to shoulder height.

Title: FYR2 Wide Overhead Press
Desc: The FYR2 Wide Overhead Press is a shoulder exercise designed to enhance strength and stability. It focuses on pressing a weight overhead with a wide grip.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. 2. Hold a barbell or dumbbells with a wide grip at shoulder height. 3. Press the weight overhead until your arms are fully extended. 4. Lower the weight back to shoulder height.

Title: Single-arm kettlebell push-press
Desc: The single-arm kettlebell push-press is a popular kettlebell movement that involves performing a press with help from the muscles of the lower body. It is preceded by a clean at the start of each set, and optionally you can perform a clean between each rep. It can be trained in traditional strength or muscle-building rep ranges, in circuit or fat-loss training, or as part of a larger kettlebell combination or complex.
HowTo: 1. Start by cleaning the kettlebell to shoulder height. 2. Slightly bend your knees and use your legs to help drive the kettlebell overhead. 3. Press the kettlebell overhead until your arm is fully extended. 4. Lower the kettlebell back to the starting position.

Title: Two-Arm Kettlebell Military Press
Desc: The Two-Arm Kettlebell Military Press is a strength exercise targeting the shoulders and arms. It involves pressing two kettlebells overhead simultaneously.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a kettlebell in each hand at shoulder height. 2. Press both kettlebells overhead until your arms are fully extended. 3. Lower the kettlebells back to shoulder height. 4. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Alternating Kettlebell Press
Desc: The Alternating Kettlebell Press is a shoulder exercise that involves pressing a kettlebell overhead while alternating arms. It helps improve shoulder stability and strength.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, holding a kettlebell in one hand at shoulder height. 2. Press the kettlebell overhead until your arm is fully extended. 3. Lower the kettlebell back to shoulder height and switch to the other arm. 4. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Single-arm kettlebell snatch
Desc: The single-arm kettlebell snatch is a kettlebell exercise that involves lifting a kettlebell overhead in a single motion. It is popular as a full-body strength and conditioning movement, but it's also competed for reps in Russian-style girevoy sport. A "snatch test" of max reps in 5 or 10 minutes is also a common measurement of conditioning in kettlebell training. It can be performed from the ground or with a swing
HowTo: 1. Start with the kettlebell on the ground between your feet. 2. Hinge at the hips and grab the kettlebell with one hand. 3. In one motion, lift the kettlebell up and overhead while standing up. 4. Lower it back down and repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Single-arm kettlebell clean and jerk
Desc: The single-arm kettlebell clean and jerk is a popular kettlebell movement that is performed both in an exercise setting and competitively as a part of Russian-style girevoy sport. It differs from a clean and push-press in that the lifter "dips" under the weight rather than simply using the legs to help push the weight up. Each rep of a clean and jerk is preceded by a clean at the start of each set. It can be trained in traditional strength or muscle-building rep ranges, in circuit or fat-loss training, or as part of a larger kettlebell combination or complex.
HowTo: 1. Start with the kettlebell on the ground between your feet. 2. Hinge at the hips and grab the kettlebell with one hand. 3. Clean the kettlebell to shoulder height. 4. Dip slightly and press the kettlebell overhead. 5. Lower it back down and repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Kettlebell pirate ship
Desc: The kettlebell pirate ship is a rotational shoulder and core-focused kettlebell movement. It demands the lifter raise the kettlebell to the side in both directions, emphasizing core strength in the transverse abdominis and obliques in particular. It is best learned with a light weight, using controlled movements in both directions.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, holding a kettlebell in one hand. 2. Raise the kettlebell to the side while rotating your torso. 3. Lower the kettlebell back to the starting position and repeat on the opposite side. 4. Continue alternating sides for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Two-Arm Kettlebell Clean
Desc: The Two-Arm Kettlebell Clean is a foundational kettlebell exercise that targets multiple muscle groups. It is effective for building strength and coordination.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, holding a kettlebell in each hand. 2. Hinge at the hips and lower the kettlebells to the ground. 3. In one motion, clean the kettlebells to shoulder height. 4. Lower them back down and repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Double Kettlebell Push Press
Desc: The double-kettlebell push-press is a popular kettlebell movement that involves performing a press with help from the muscles of the lower body. It is preceded by a double clean at the start of each set, and optionally you can perform a clean between each rep. It can be trained in traditional strength or muscle-building rep ranges, in circuit or fat-loss training, or as part of a larger kettlebell combination or complex.
HowTo: 1. Start with two kettlebells at shoulder height. 2. Dip slightly by bending your knees. 3. Explode upward, pressing the kettlebells overhead. 4. Lock out your arms at the top and lower back to shoulder height.

Title: Kettlebell Seated Press
Desc: The kettlebell seated press is a strength exercise that targets the shoulders and triceps. It is performed while seated, providing stability and focus on the upper body.
HowTo: 1. Sit on a bench with a kettlebell in each hand at shoulder height. 2. Press the kettlebells overhead until your arms are fully extended. 3. Lower the kettlebells back to shoulder height and repeat.

Title: Double Kettlebell Jerk
Desc: The double kettlebell jerk is a dynamic exercise that combines strength and power, focusing on the shoulders and legs. It is performed by using a dip and drive motion to propel the kettlebells overhead.
HowTo: 1. Start with two kettlebells at shoulder height. 2. Dip down slightly by bending your knees. 3. Drive upward, extending your legs and pressing the kettlebells overhead. 4. Lock out your arms and lower back to shoulder height.

Title: Kettlebell Arnold Press
Desc: The kettlebell Arnold press is a variation of the overhead press that targets the shoulders and upper chest. It involves a rotation of the wrists during the press.
HowTo: 1. Start with a kettlebell in each hand at shoulder height, palms facing you. 2. As you press the kettlebells overhead, rotate your wrists so your palms face forward. 3. Lower the kettlebells back to the starting position, rotating your wrists back towards you.

Title: Double-kettlebell windmill
Desc: The double-kettlebell windmill is an advanced kettlebell exercise emphasizing core strength and shoulder and hip mobility and stability. Because it involves holding one weight overhead while holding another under the torso, it builds strength across the core and stability in the shoulders. It doesn't work well in a metcon or conditioning setting, and shouldn't be performed under intense fatigue.
HowTo: 1. Stand with a kettlebell in one hand overhead and the other hand down by your side. 2. Hinge at your hips and lower your torso towards the ground while keeping the kettlebell overhead. 3. Return to standing while maintaining the kettlebell position.

Title: One-Arm Kettlebell Split Snatch
Desc: The One-Arm Kettlebell Split Snatch is a dynamic exercise that targets the shoulders and core. It involves a powerful movement that combines a snatch with a split stance.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a kettlebell in one hand. 2. Lower the kettlebell between your legs while bending your knees slightly. 3. Explode upwards, extending your hips and knees, and pull the kettlebell up towards your shoulder. 4. As the kettlebell reaches shoulder height, split your legs into a lunge position. 5. Lock out your arm overhead, keeping your core engaged. 6. Return to the starting position and repeat.

Title: One-Arm Kettlebell Para Press
Desc: The One-Arm Kettlebell Para Press is an effective shoulder exercise that also engages the core. It involves pressing the kettlebell overhead while maintaining stability.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a kettlebell in one hand at shoulder height. 2. Engage your core and press the kettlebell overhead until your arm is fully extended. 3. Lower the kettlebell back to shoulder height with control. 4. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions before switching arms.

Title: One-Arm Kettlebell Split Jerk
Desc: The One-Arm Kettlebell Split Jerk is a powerful exercise that develops shoulder strength and explosiveness. It combines a jerk motion with a split stance for stability.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a kettlebell in one hand at shoulder height. 2. Dip slightly by bending your knees, then explosively drive the kettlebell overhead while splitting your legs into a lunge position. 3. Lock out your arm overhead, ensuring your body is stable. 4. Return to the starting position and repeat.

Title: One-Arm Kettlebell Military Press To The Side
Desc: The One-Arm Kettlebell Military Press To The Side is a variation that targets the shoulders and engages the core. This exercise emphasizes stability and control.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a kettlebell in one hand at shoulder height. 2. Press the kettlebell overhead while keeping your body straight. 3. As you press, lean slightly to the side to engage the lateral muscles. 4. Lower the kettlebell back to shoulder height and repeat.

Title: One-Arm Kettlebell Jerk
Desc: The One-Arm Kettlebell Jerk is a dynamic exercise that builds shoulder strength and power. It requires coordination and explosive movement.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a kettlebell in one hand at shoulder height. 2. Dip slightly by bending your knees, then explosively drive the kettlebell overhead. 3. As you press, split your legs for stability. 4. Lock out your arm overhead and return to the starting position.

Title: Double Kettlebell Snatch
Desc: The Double Kettlebell Snatch is a dynamic exercise that requires explosive power and coordination. It involves lifting two kettlebells from the ground to an overhead position in one fluid motion.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, kettlebells on the ground between your feet. 2. Hinge at the hips and grip the kettlebells. 3. In one motion, extend your hips and knees while pulling the kettlebells upward. 4. As the kettlebells reach chest height, rotate your wrists and punch them overhead. 5. Lock out your arms overhead and stabilize before lowering back down.

Title: Two-Arm Kettlebell Jerk
Desc: The Two-Arm Kettlebell Jerk is a powerful movement that helps develop explosive strength and coordination. It involves driving the kettlebells overhead using a dip and drive motion.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, kettlebells at shoulder height. 2. Bend your knees slightly and dip down. 3. Explosively drive through your legs while pressing the kettlebells overhead. 4. Lock out your arms and stabilize the kettlebells overhead. 5. Lower the kettlebells back to shoulder height and repeat.

Title: FYR Kettlebell Power Clean
Desc: The kettlebell power clean is an explosive kettlebell exercise where the lifter pulls the weight to shoulder level with a slight swing between the legs. It is often used as a drill to teach kettlebell clean technique, but is also a valuable power exercise in its own right. It can be performed in low rep ranges for strength or higher rep ranges for technique practice or muscle growth.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, kettlebell on the ground between your feet. 2. Hinge at the hips and grip the kettlebell. 3. Pull the kettlebell up explosively, swinging it between your legs. 4. As it rises, rotate your wrist and catch it at shoulder height. 5. Lower it back down and repeat.

Title: Kettlebell upright row
Desc: The kettlebell upright row is an exercise targeting the muscles of the traps (trapezius), as well as the posterior muscles of the shoulders or deltoid muscles. It is common as a light- or moderate-weight accessory movement in upper-body or shoulder training, usually in rep ranges of 8-12 or more. It may not be appropriate for some people, depending on their shoulder health.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, holding a kettlebell in each hand at your thighs. 2. Pull the kettlebells up towards your chin, keeping them close to your body. 3. Squeeze your shoulders at the top of the movement. 4. Lower the kettlebells back to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Kettlebell upright row and press
Desc: The kettlebell upright row and press is a combination of two popular kettlebell movements in a single sequence. This combination can be performed for time or for reps, often as circuit-style training for conditioning or fat loss, or in a kettlebell complex or flow.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, holding a kettlebell in each hand. 2. Perform an upright row by pulling the kettlebells to your chin. 3. Transition into a press by pushing the kettlebells overhead. 4. Lower the kettlebells back to the starting position and repeat the sequence.

Title: Single-arm kettlebell thruster
Desc: The single-arm kettlebell thruster is a popular kettlebell movement that combines a kettlebell front squat with a kettlebell press. It is preceded by a clean at the start of each set, and you can perform a clean between each rep if you choose. It can be trained in traditional strength or muscle-building rep ranges, in circuit or fat-loss training, or as part of a kettlebell combination or complex.
HowTo: 1. Start with the kettlebell in one hand at shoulder height. 2. Perform a squat while keeping the kettlebell stable. 3. As you rise from the squat, press the kettlebell overhead. 4. Lower the kettlebell back to shoulder height and repeat.

Title: Double-kettlebell shoulder press
Desc: The double-kettlebell shoulder press is a popular movement in strength and muscle-focused kettlebell workouts. Each set is started by cleaning the weights up to the rack position. The weights can optionally be re-cleaned between each rep, which is known as a clean and press. The double press can be trained in traditional strength or muscle-growth rep ranges (e.g., 5x5 or 8-12 reps per set), or in circuit-style fat-loss training or kettlebell complexes.
HowTo: 1. Clean the kettlebells to shoulder height. 2. Press both kettlebells overhead until your arms are fully extended. 3. Lower the kettlebells back to the rack position and repeat.

Title: Double-kettlebell push-press
Desc: The double-kettlebell push-press is a popular kettlebell movement that involves performing a press with help from the muscles of the lower body. It is preceded by a double clean at the start of each set, and optionally you can perform a clean between each rep. It can be trained in traditional strength or muscle-building rep ranges, in circuit or fat-loss training, or as part of a larger kettlebell combination or complex.
HowTo: 1. Clean the kettlebells to shoulder height. 2. Bend your knees slightly and use your legs to help push the kettlebells overhead. 3. Lower the kettlebells back to shoulder height and repeat.

Title: HM Kettlebell Windmill
Desc: The HM Kettlebell Windmill is an exercise that engages the core and improves mobility. It involves a unique movement pattern that challenges balance and stability.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, holding a kettlebell overhead with one arm. 2. Hinge at the hips and lower your torso towards the ground while keeping the kettlebell overhead. 3. Return to standing and repeat.

Title: HM Kettlebell Z-Press
Desc: The HM Kettlebell Z-Press is a seated overhead press that targets the shoulders and core. It requires stability and strength to perform correctly.
HowTo: 1. Sit on the floor with your legs extended in front of you, holding a kettlebell in one hand. 2. Press the kettlebell overhead while keeping your back straight. 3. Lower the kettlebell back to shoulder height and repeat.

Title: Taylor Half-Kneeling Kettlebell Halo
Desc: The Taylor Half-Kneeling Kettlebell Halo is a dynamic shoulder exercise that improves stability and mobility. It involves moving a kettlebell around your head while in a half-kneeling position.
HowTo: 1. Start in a half-kneeling position with one knee on the ground and the opposite foot flat on the floor. 2. Hold a kettlebell with both hands at chest level. 3. Move the kettlebell around your head in a circular motion while maintaining your posture. 4. Switch sides after completing the desired repetitions.

Title: Taylor Towel Kettlebell Farmer's Walk
Desc: The Taylor Towel Kettlebell Farmer's Walk is a grip-strengthening exercise that also engages the core and legs. It involves carrying kettlebells while holding onto a towel to enhance grip challenge.
HowTo: 1. Wrap a towel around the handle of a kettlebell. 2. Stand upright and lift the kettlebell off the ground. 3. Walk a specified distance while maintaining a strong grip on the towel. 4. Keep your core engaged and posture upright.

Title: FYR2 Double-Kettlebell Alternating Press
Desc: The FYR2 Double-Kettlebell Alternating Press is a shoulder exercise that builds strength and stability. It involves pressing two kettlebells overhead in an alternating fashion.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and hold a kettlebell in each hand at shoulder height. 2. Press one kettlebell overhead while keeping the other at shoulder level. 3. Lower the pressed kettlebell back to shoulder height and press the other kettlebell. 4. Continue alternating for the desired repetitions.

Title: FYR2 Double-Kettlebell Thruster
Desc: The FYR2 Double-Kettlebell Thruster is a full-body exercise that combines a squat and an overhead press. It is effective for building strength and power.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a kettlebell in each hand at shoulder height. 2. Perform a squat by lowering your hips back and down. 3. As you stand up, press both kettlebells overhead. 4. Lower the kettlebells back to shoulder height and repeat.

Title: FYR2 Half-Kneeling Kettlebell Clean
Desc: The FYR2 Half-Kneeling Kettlebell Clean is a powerful movement that builds strength and coordination. It involves lifting a kettlebell from the ground to a racked position.
HowTo: 1. Start in a half-kneeling position with one knee on the ground and the opposite foot flat on the floor. 2. Place a kettlebell on the ground beside your knee. 3. Reach down and grab the kettlebell with the opposite hand. 4. In one motion, pull the kettlebell up and rotate it into the racked position at your shoulder. 5. Lower the kettlebell back to the ground and repeat.

Title: FYR2 Kettlebell Clean and Press
Desc: The Kettlebell Clean and Press is a compound exercise that targets the shoulders and upper body. It involves lifting a kettlebell from the ground to shoulder height and then pressing it overhead.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and a kettlebell on the floor between your feet. 2. Bend at the hips and knees to grasp the kettlebell with one hand. 3. Swing the kettlebell back between your legs. 4. In one motion, pull the kettlebell up to your shoulder while rotating your wrist. 5. Press the kettlebell overhead until your arm is fully extended. 6. Lower the kettlebell back to the starting position and repeat.

Title: FYR2 Kettlebell High Pull to Overhead Press
Desc: The Kettlebell High Pull to Overhead Press combines a high pull movement with an overhead press, targeting the shoulders and upper back. This exercise enhances strength and coordination.
HowTo: 1. Start with a kettlebell on the floor between your feet. 2. Bend your knees and grasp the kettlebell with one hand. 3. Swing the kettlebell back between your legs. 4. Pull the kettlebell up to your chin, keeping your elbow high. 5. As the kettlebell reaches your chin, press it overhead until your arm is straight. 6. Lower the kettlebell back to the starting position and repeat.

Title: FYR2 Kettlebell Swing Clean and Press
Desc: The Kettlebell Swing Clean and Press is a dynamic exercise that works multiple muscle groups, including the legs and shoulders. It combines a swing with a clean and press for a full-body workout.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and a kettlebell on the floor. 2. Bend at the hips and knees to grasp the kettlebell. 3. Swing the kettlebell back between your legs. 4. Drive your hips forward to swing the kettlebell up to shoulder height. 5. Clean the kettlebell to your shoulder and press it overhead. 6. Lower the kettlebell back to the starting position and repeat.

Title: FYR2 Single-Arm Kettlebell Press
Desc: The Single-Arm Kettlebell Press focuses on building shoulder strength and stability. It isolates one arm at a time, enhancing muscle engagement.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a kettlebell in one hand at shoulder height. 2. Engage your core and press the kettlebell overhead until your arm is fully extended. 3. Lower the kettlebell back to shoulder height. 4. Repeat for the desired number of reps before switching arms.

Title: FYR2 Ascending-Rep High-Pull-Press Complex
Desc: The Ascending-Rep High-Pull-Press Complex is a challenging exercise that builds strength and endurance across multiple muscle groups. It involves a series of high pulls and presses with increasing repetitions.
HowTo: 1. Start with a kettlebell on the floor between your feet. 2. Perform a high pull by swinging the kettlebell up to your chin. 3. Immediately transition into an overhead press. 4. Repeat the high pull and press for the desired number of reps, increasing the count each set. 5. Maintain good form throughout the exercise.

Title: Dumbbell front raise to lateral raise
Desc: The dumbbell front raise to lateral raise is a dumbbell complex that combines two exercises that build and strengthen the middle deltoids and the anterior deltoids of the shoulders. It is usually performed one rep of each movement at a time, although you could perform more reps of each, or increase the reps in successive rounds (e.g., 1 rep in round 1, 2 reps in round 2, etc.). No matter how you perform it, it targets both the anterior and medial deltoids, making it a great time-efficient shoulder burnout or accessory movement on an upper-body day.
HowTo: 1. Stand with a dumbbell in each hand at your sides. 2. Raise one dumbbell in front of you to shoulder height, then lower it back down. 3. Immediately raise the other dumbbell to the side to shoulder height, then lower it back down. 4. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Single-arm palm-in dumbbell shoulder press
Desc: The single-arm palm-in dumbbell shoulder press builds the shoulder muscles but with two major differences from the standard dumbbell shoulder press. It's done one arm at a time and the wrist stays neutral throughout the movement. It can be performed standing or seated. A single dumbbell press can be pursued as a strength goal, or trained in traditional muscle-building rep ranges such as 8-15 reps per set or more.
HowTo: 1. Stand or sit with a dumbbell in one hand at shoulder height, palm facing in. 2. Press the dumbbell overhead until your arm is fully extended. 3. Lower the dumbbell back to the starting position. 4. Repeat for the desired number of reps, then switch arms.

Title: Standing palms-in shoulder press
Desc: The standing palms-in shoulder press is a dumbbell exercise targeting the shoulders. It can be performed in strength-focused rep ranges, such as 5-8 reps per set, or for higher reps to build muscle or for conditioning.
HowTo: 1. Stand with a dumbbell in each hand at shoulder height, palms facing in. 2. Press both dumbbells overhead until your arms are fully extended. 3. Lower the dumbbells back to shoulder height. 4. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Seated Dumbbell Press
Desc: The seated dumbbell shoulder pressis an exercise for building muscle and strengthening the shoulders, particularly but not exclusively the front heads. The triceps also assist. Some lifters feel that using dumbbells versus a barbell reduced injury risk.
HowTo: 1. Sit on a bench with a dumbbell in each hand at shoulder height. 2. Press the dumbbells overhead until your arms are fully extended. 3. Lower the dumbbells back to shoulder height. 4. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Standing dumbbell shoulder press
Desc: The standing dumbbell shoulder press is a classic deltoid-building exercise that is common in gyms around the world. Performing the move standing up as opposed to seated allows more weight to be used and taxes the core more than seated presses. The standing press is worthy of being the main movement in a muscle-building shoulder workout, but is also a great strength movement and accessory for the bench press.
HowTo: 1. Stand with a dumbbell in each hand at shoulder height. 2. Press the dumbbells overhead until your arms are fully extended. 3. Lower the dumbbells back to shoulder height. 4. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Single-arm lateral raise
Desc: The single-arm lateral raise is a shoulder exercise that targets the medial or middle head of the deltoid muscle. It's a staple strength-training move and is a great option for accessory work on upper-body training days. Hold on to a post for balance, or do it free-standing to challenge core strength and stability. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps, at least 8-12 reps per side, as part of the upper-body or shoulder-focused portion of a workout.
HowTo: Stand with a dumbbell in one hand at your side. Raise the dumbbell to the side until your arm is parallel to the ground, then lower it back down.

Title: Power Partials
Desc: Power Partials are a dynamic exercise that focuses on explosive strength and power development. They can be performed with various equipment such as barbells or kettlebells.
HowTo: Start in a standing position with your feet shoulder-width apart. Bend your knees slightly and lower your body into a quarter squat, then explosively extend your hips and knees to jump or lift the weight.

Title: Incline dumbbell reverse fly
Desc: The incline dumbbell reverse fly is an upper-body exercise targeting the posterior or rear deltoids, as well as the postural muscles of the upper back. Because it targets such small muscles, this exercise is usually performed with light weight for high reps, such as 10-15 reps per set or more.
HowTo: Lie face down on an incline bench with a dumbbell in each hand. With a slight bend in your elbows, lift the dumbbells out to the side until your arms are parallel to the ground, then lower them back down.

Title: Overhead dumbbell front raise
Desc: The overhead dumbbell front raise takes the dumbbell front raise one step further, extending the motion all the way above the head. In addition to the shoulders, it activates and strengthens the muscles of the traps and upper back. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-15 reps or more. It can be part of a dynamic upper-body warm-up, performed as a muscle-building upper-body movement, or as a burnout movement on shoulder day.
HowTo: Stand with a dumbbell in each hand at thigh level. Raise the dumbbells in front of you to shoulder height, then extend them overhead before lowering them back down.

Title: Seated dumbbell shoulder press
Desc: The seated dumbbell shoulder press is a popular exercise for building muscle and strength in the shoulders. The triceps also work hard in this lift. Many lifters find using dumbbells to be more comfortable and shoulder-friendly for this press variation than a barbell. This can be the primary pressing movement on an upper-body or shoulder day, or an effective accessory movement later in a workout.
HowTo: Sit on a bench with a dumbbell in each hand at shoulder height. Press the dumbbells overhead until your arms are fully extended, then lower them back to the starting position.

Title: Alternating standing shoulder press
Desc: The alternating standing shoulder press is a popular dumbbell exercise targeting the shoulders. It can be performed in strength-focused rep ranges, such as 5-8 reps per set, or for higher reps to build muscle or for conditioning.
HowTo: 1. Stand with a dumbbell in each hand at shoulder height. 2. Press the dumbbells overhead, alternating arms, while keeping your core engaged.

Title: Single-arm incline rear delt raise
Desc: The single-arm incline rear delt raise is an upper-body exercise targeting the posterior deltoids or shoulder muscles, as well as the postural muscles of the upper back. Training each side independently can help correct imbalances in size, strength, and shoulder stability. Because it targets such small muscles, this exercise is usually performed with light weight for high reps, such as 10-15 reps per set or more.
HowTo: 1. Lie face down on an incline bench with a dumbbell in one hand. 2. Raise the dumbbell towards the ceiling, focusing on squeezing the shoulder blade at the top of the movement.

Title: Alternating dumbbell front raise
Desc: The alternating dumbbell front raise is a single-joint exercise targeting the shoulder muscles, particularly the front or anterior deltoids. Performing the movement one shoulder at a time gives a momentary rest to each side while the other is working, potentially allowing you to do more reps during each set. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps, at least 8-12 reps per set, as part of an upper-body or shoulder-focused workout.
HowTo: 1. Stand with a dumbbell in each hand at your sides. 2. Raise one dumbbell in front of you to shoulder height, then lower it and repeat with the other arm.

Title: Alternating Deltoid Raise
Desc: The dumbbell front raise to lateral raise combines two exercises that build and strengthen the middle deltoids and the anterior deltoids of the shoulders.
HowTo: 1. Stand with a dumbbell in each hand at your sides. 2. Raise one dumbbell in front of you and then transition to a lateral raise, lifting the dumbbell to the side.

Title: Single-dumbbell front raise
Desc: The single-dumbbell front raise is an isolation movement that targets the shoulders. In particular, it focuses on the anterior or front head of the deltoid muscles. By performing it with one dumbbell at a time, you can focus on each shoulder muscle independently and try to address muscular imbalances between shoulders. This movement is usually performed for moderate to high reps, at least 8-12 reps per set, as part of an upper-body or shoulder-focused workout.
HowTo: 1. Stand with a dumbbell in one hand at your side. 2. Raise the dumbbell in front of you to shoulder height, keeping your arm straight.

Title: Arnold press
Desc: Named after the iconic bodybuilder and movie star, the Arnold press adds rotation to a classic shoulder press. It allows the hands to rotate naturally, while also hitting all three heads of the deltoids in one motion. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps or more, as part of the upper-body or shoulder-focused portion of a workout.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, holding a dumbbell in each hand. 2. Start with the dumbbells at shoulder height, palms facing you, and press them overhead while rotating your palms forward.

Title: Single-arm standing shoulder press
Desc: The single-arm standing shoulder press is a popular exercise to build size and strength the shoulders and triceps. Most lifters find they can go heavier (per arm) on this movement than if they are pressing two dumbbells simultaneously, making it an effective strength movement as well as a muscle-building movement in higher reps.
HowTo: 1. Stand with a dumbbell in one hand at shoulder height. 2. Press the dumbbell overhead until your arm is fully extended, then lower it back to the starting position.

Title: Dumbbell front raise
Desc: The dumbbell front raise is a single-joint exercise targeting the shoulder muscles, particularly the front or anterior deltoids. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps, at least 8-12 reps per set, as part of an upper-body or shoulder-focused workout.
HowTo: 1. Stand with a dumbbell in each hand at your sides. 2. Raise the dumbbells in front of you to shoulder height, keeping your arms straight, then lower them back down.

Title: Bent-over dumbbell rear delt row
Desc: The bent-over dumbbell rear delt row is a popular upper-body exercise that targets the muscles on the backside of the shoulder joint, specifically the medial and rear heads of the deltoid. Since pressing movements build the front and (to a lesser degree) side deltoid heads, this move is often done to promote balanced shoulder development. It is usually performed for high reps, such as 10-15 reps per set or more, as part of a shoulder or upper-body workout.
HowTo: 1. Bend at the hips and knees, holding a dumbbell in each hand. 2. Pull the dumbbells towards your chest while keeping your elbows high, then lower them back down.

Title: Incline dumbbell front raise
Desc: The incline dumbbell front raise is an upper-body exercise targeting the shoulders. Because it is performed face down on an angled bench, it has a greater range of motion than standing or upright-seated raises and hits the shoulders from a different angle. Raise variations are usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of upper-body or shoulder-focused training.
HowTo: 1. Lie face down on an incline bench with a dumbbell in each hand. 2. Raise the dumbbells in front of you to shoulder height, then lower them back down.

Title: Side Lateral Raise
Desc: The dumbbell lateral raise is an upper body isolation exercise for building shoulder strength and muscle. It's a staple strength training move and is a great option for accessory work on upper body training days. This exercise particularly focuses on the lateral or medial head of the deltoid, making them appear wider and more developed.
HowTo: 1. Stand with a dumbbell in each hand at your sides. 2. Raise the dumbbells out to the side until they are at shoulder height, keeping a slight bend in your elbows. 3. Lower the dumbbells back to the starting position.

Title: Dumbbell external shoulder rotation
Desc: The dumbbell external shoulder rotation is a lightweight dumbbell exercise intended to maintain the health of the shoulder joints, including the rotator cuffs. It is often used as a warm-up or prehab for a shoulder or chest-focused workout with lots of pressing.
HowTo: 1. Sit or stand with a dumbbell in one hand, elbow bent at 90 degrees and close to your body. 2. Rotate your arm outward, keeping your elbow fixed, until the dumbbell is at shoulder height. 3. Return to the starting position.

Title: Single-arm incline lateral raise
Desc: The single-arm incline lateral raise is an exercise targeting the lateral or medial head of the shoulder muscles. It is performed lying sideways on an incline bench set to around 45 degrees, which helps to increase the range of motion in the lift and enforce strict form. Because it targets such small muscles, this exercise is usually performed with light weight for high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more.
HowTo: 1. Lie sideways on an incline bench with a dumbbell in the upper hand. 2. Raise the dumbbell straight up to shoulder height, keeping your elbow slightly bent. 3. Lower the dumbbell back to the starting position.

Title: Seated rear delt fly
Desc: The seated rear delt fly is an upper-body exercise that targets the real deltoid of the shoulder. By performing the movement seated, it eliminates momentum from the rest of the body. This movement is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of the upper-body or shoulder-focused portion of a workout.
HowTo: 1. Sit on a bench with a dumbbell in each hand, leaning forward slightly. 2. With a slight bend in your elbows, raise the dumbbells out to the side until they are level with your shoulders. 3. Lower the dumbbells back to the starting position.

Title: Dumbbell Raise
Desc: The Dumbbell Raise is a versatile exercise that can target the shoulder muscles effectively. It can be performed in various ways to enhance shoulder strength and stability.
HowTo: 1. Stand with a dumbbell in each hand at your sides. 2. Raise the dumbbells in front of you to shoulder height, keeping a slight bend in your elbows. 3. Lower the dumbbells back to the starting position.

Title: Seated Side Lateral Raise
Desc: The seated dumbbell lateral raiseis an iconic exercise for developing the shoulders. If youve ever worked out with weights, chances are youve done this move at some point. Proper execution is paramount to avoid injury.
HowTo: 1. Sit on a bench with a dumbbell in each hand at your sides. 2. Raise the dumbbells out to the side until your arms are parallel to the ground, keeping a slight bend in your elbows. 3. Lower the dumbbells back to the starting position.

Title: Dumbbell Lying Rear Lateral Raise
Desc: The incline dumbbell reverse fly is an upper-body exercise targeting the posterior or rear deltoids, as well as the postural muscles of the upper back. Because it targets such small muscles, this exercise is usually performed with light weight for high reps, such as 10-15 reps per set or more.
HowTo: 1. Lie face down on an incline bench with a dumbbell in each hand. 2. With a slight bend in your elbows, raise the dumbbells out to the sides until they are parallel to the ground. 3. Lower the dumbbells back to the starting position.

Title: Head-on-bench dumbbell rear delt raise
Desc: The head-on-bench dumbbell rear delt raise is an exercise targeting the posterior shoulder muscles, or rear deltoids. This variation of the bent-over rear delt raise often helps to better isolate this area of the shoulder. Because it targets such small muscles, this exercise is usually performed with light weight for high reps, such as 10-15 reps per set or more.
HowTo: 1. Lie face down on a bench with a dumbbell in each hand. 2. With your arms hanging down, raise the dumbbells out to the sides until they are parallel to the ground. 3. Lower the dumbbells back to the starting position.

Title: Cuban press
Desc: The Cuban press is an exercise that targets the muscles of the shoulders, rotator cuff, and upper back. It combines a shoulder external rotation with a dumbbell press, training multiple muscles and motions in a single sequence. It can be performed standing, or as a more difficult variation face-down on an incline bench. It is usually performed with relatively light weight as part of a dynamic warm-up for upper-body lifting.
HowTo: 1. Stand with a dumbbell in each hand at shoulder height, palms facing you. 2. Rotate your arms outward and press the dumbbells overhead. 3. Lower the dumbbells back to shoulder height and rotate back to the starting position.

Title: Reverse Flyes With External Rotation
Desc: Reverse Flyes With External Rotation is an exercise that targets the shoulder muscles. It combines reverse fly movements with external rotation.
HowTo: 1. Stand or sit with a dumbbell in each hand, arms at your sides. 2. Bend slightly at the hips and raise the dumbbells out to the sides while rotating your arms externally. 3. Lower the dumbbells back to the starting position.

Title: Single-arm side lying rear fly
Desc: The single-arm side lying rear fly is an upper-body exercise that targets the rear deltoid of the shoulder. By performing the movement lying on a bench, it eliminates momentum from the rest of the body. This movement is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of the upper-body or shoulder-focused portion of a workout.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your side on a bench with one arm hanging down. 2. With the other arm, lift the dumbbell out to the side, keeping your elbow slightly bent, and then lower it back down.

Title: Single-arm dumbbell upright row
Desc: The single-arm dumbbell upright row is a popular movement for building stronger and bigger traps and shoulders. Many lifters combine this move with either their back or shoulder workout, since it involves both body parts. It is generally performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more.
HowTo: 1. Stand with a dumbbell in one hand, arm at your side. 2. Pull the dumbbell up towards your chin, keeping your elbow higher than your wrist, then lower it back down.

Title: Dumbbell Scaption
Desc: The dumbbell scaption is an exercise that targets the shoulder muscles, particularly the deltoids and supraspinatus. It is performed by lifting the dumbbells at a 30-degree angle from the body.
HowTo: 1. Stand with a dumbbell in each hand at your sides. 2. Raise the dumbbells in a 'V' shape at a 30-degree angle from your body until they reach shoulder height, then lower them back down.

Title: See-Saw Press (Alternating Side Press)
Desc: The See-Saw Press is an alternating shoulder press that engages the deltoids and triceps. It involves pressing one dumbbell overhead while lowering the other.
HowTo: 1. Stand with a dumbbell in each hand at shoulder height. 2. Press one dumbbell overhead while lowering the other to shoulder level, then alternate.

Title: Dumbbell Incline Shoulder Raise
Desc: The Dumbbell Incline Shoulder Raise targets the shoulder muscles, particularly the deltoids. It is performed by raising the dumbbells while seated on an incline bench.
HowTo: 1. Sit on an incline bench with a dumbbell in each hand at your sides. 2. Raise the dumbbells out to the side until they reach shoulder height, then lower them back down.

Title: Single-arm half-kneeling shoulder press
Desc: The single-arm half-kneeling shoulder press is a popular exercise to target the deltoid muscles while also developing strength and stability in the core and hips. Balance can be a challenge, which is one reason why this movement is generally trained lighter than standing single-arm shoulder presses. The half-kneeling press can be used as an accessory lift for the shoulder press or bench press, or simply as a technique to make shoulder presses stricter and more athletic.
HowTo: 1. Start in a half-kneeling position with one knee on the ground and the opposite foot in front. 2. Hold a dumbbell in one hand at shoulder height. 3. Press the dumbbell overhead while maintaining core stability. 4. Lower the dumbbell back to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Dumbbell Clean And Jerk
Desc: The dumbbell clean and jerk is a dynamic full-body exercise that combines a clean and an overhead press. It effectively builds strength and power in multiple muscle groups.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, holding a dumbbell in each hand. 2. Bend your knees and lower your hips to initiate the clean. 3. Explosively extend your hips and knees to lift the dumbbells to shoulder height. 4. Press the dumbbells overhead and then lower them back to the starting position.

Title: Dumbbell shoulder press with body rotation
Desc: The dumbbell shoulder press with body rotation is a twist on the traditional dumbbell shoulder press. Rather than pressing straight overhead, you twist your torso and hips to the side during each rep. It hits the deltoid muscles just like a shoulder press, but adds a challenge to the core, hips, and back muscles. Due to the potential balance challenge of twisting and pressing at the same time, it is commonly performed with light to moderate weights.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, holding a dumbbell in each hand at shoulder height. 2. Rotate your torso to one side as you press the dumbbells overhead. 3. Return to the starting position and repeat, alternating sides.

Title: Dumbbell Fix Dumbbell Military Press
Desc: The dumbbell military press is a classic strength exercise that targets the shoulders and triceps. It is performed standing or seated and focuses on pressing weights overhead.
HowTo: 1. Stand or sit with a dumbbell in each hand at shoulder height. 2. Press the dumbbells overhead until your arms are fully extended. 3. Lower the dumbbells back to shoulder height and repeat.

Title: Dumbbell Fix Standing Dumbbell Arnold Press
Desc: The standing dumbbell Arnold press is a variation of the shoulder press that incorporates rotation, targeting the deltoids and enhancing shoulder stability. It is named after Arnold Schwarzenegger, who popularized this movement.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, holding dumbbells in front of you with palms facing your body. 2. As you press the dumbbells overhead, rotate your palms to face forward. 3. Lower the dumbbells back to the starting position while rotating your palms back towards you.

Title: Dumbbell Fix Dumbbell Single-Arm Snatch
Desc: The Dumbbell Single-Arm Snatch is a dynamic exercise that targets the shoulders and engages the core. It involves lifting a dumbbell from the ground to overhead in one fluid motion.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and a dumbbell on the floor between your feet. 2. Bend at your hips and knees to grasp the dumbbell with one hand. 3. In one motion, explosively lift the dumbbell off the ground, extending your legs and driving your elbow up. 4. As the dumbbell rises, rotate your wrist and press it overhead. 5. Lower the dumbbell back to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Paul Carter Rear-Delt Fly
Desc: The seated rear delt fly is an upper-body exercise that targets the real deltoid of the shoulder. By performing the movement seated, it eliminates momentum from the rest of the body. This movement is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of the upper-body or shoulder-focused portion of a workout.
HowTo: 1. Sit on a bench with your feet flat on the floor and lean forward slightly. 2. Hold a dumbbell in each hand with your arms hanging down. 3. Keeping a slight bend in your elbows, raise the dumbbells out to the sides until they are level with your shoulders. 4. Slowly lower the dumbbells back to the starting position.

Title: FYR Dumbbell Shoulder Press
Desc: The standing dumbbell shoulder press is a classic deltoid-builder (especially the front deltoids) thats ubiquitous in gyms around the world. Performing the move standing up as opposed to seated allows for more weight to be used.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a dumbbell in each hand at shoulder height. 2. Press the dumbbells overhead until your arms are fully extended. 3. Lower the dumbbells back to shoulder height and repeat.

Title: FYR Single-Arm Dumbbell Press
Desc: The single-arm standing shoulder press builds shoulder muscle but with two major differences from the standard seated dumbbell shoulder press. Its done one arm at a time, as well as standing, which may allow more weight to be used.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and hold a dumbbell in one hand at shoulder height. 2. Press the dumbbell overhead until your arm is fully extended. 3. Lower the dumbbell back to shoulder height and repeat. 4. Switch arms and repeat.

Title: FYR Dumbbell Tempo L-Raise
Desc: The dumbbell lateral raise is an upper body isolation exercise for building shoulder strength and muscle. It's a staple strength training move and is a great option for accessory work on upper body training days. This exercise particularly focuses on the lateral or medial head of the deltoid, making them appear wider and more developed.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a dumbbell in each hand at your sides. 2. Keeping a slight bend in your elbows, raise the dumbbells out to the sides until they are level with your shoulders. 3. Slowly lower the dumbbells back to the starting position.

Title: Dumbbell seesaw shoulder press
Desc: The dumbbell seesaw shoulder press is an exercise targeting the deltoids and triceps. The difference between this movement and the alternating shoulder press is that both dumbbells keep moving throughout each rep, rather than having one weight be stationary while the other moves. This piston-style pressing increases time under tension and may allow you to complete more total reps than with alternating reps.
HowTo: 1. Stand with a dumbbell in each hand at shoulder height. 2. Press both dumbbells overhead while keeping them moving in a seesaw motion, alternating their positions without pausing.

Title: FYR Dumbbell front raise to lateral raise
Desc: The dumbbell front raise to lateral raise combines two exercises that build and strengthen the middle deltoids and the anterior deltoids of the shoulders.
HowTo: 1. Stand with a dumbbell in each hand, arms extended in front of you. 2. Raise one dumbbell to shoulder height while simultaneously raising the other dumbbell to the side, then lower them back down.

Title: FYR Dumbbell Arnold Press
Desc: Named after the iconic bodybuilder/movie star, the Arnold press adds rotation to a classic shoulder press, hitting all three heads of the deltoids in one motion.
HowTo: 1. Start with a dumbbell in each hand at shoulder height, palms facing you. 2. Rotate your palms outward as you press the dumbbells overhead, then lower them back to the starting position.

Title: FYR Dumbbell Military Press to Dumbbell High Pull to V-up
Desc: The FYR Dumbbell Military Press to Dumbbell High Pull to V-up combines multiple movements to engage various muscle groups.
HowTo: 1. Start with a dumbbell in each hand at shoulder height. 2. Press the dumbbells overhead, then lower them and perform a high pull, followed by a V-up on the floor.

Title: FYR Dumbbell Thruster
Desc: The dumbbell thruster, which begins with a squat and ends with an overhead press, works the entire body at once in a single fluid motion. This exercise is often performed with kettlebells, but dumbbells work great, too.
HowTo: 1. Begin in a squat position holding dumbbells at shoulder height. 2. Push through your heels to stand up while pressing the dumbbells overhead in one fluid motion.

Title: Dumbbell hang snatch
Desc: The dumbbell hang snatch is an explosive exercise that builds full-body power and targets the muscles of the hips, back, and shoulders. Performing the movement from the hang position, rather than from the ground, emphasizes explosive hip and upper-body power. It can be performed for low reps with a focus on power and speed, or for higher reps to build muscle or as part of a metabolic conditioning circuit.
HowTo: 1. Start in a standing position with a dumbbell in each hand. 2. Lower the dumbbells to the hang position, then explosively extend your hips and pull the dumbbells upward, catching them overhead.

Title: Surfer sprawl
Desc: The surfer sprawl is an explosive bodyweight exercise that targets multiple muscle groups across the upper and lower body. It is similar to a burpee, but instead of jumping at the top, you end in a "surfer position," alternating sides with each rep. It can be performed for time or reps in any fat-loss or athleticism-focused circuit or workout. The surfer position offers a unique way to challenge the body by staying in a low position rather than standing up after the plank.
HowTo: 1. Begin in a standing position, then drop into a plank position. 2. From the plank, perform a push-up, then jump your feet towards your hands and explode into a 'surfer position' on one side.

Title: Dumbbell clean and press
Desc: The dumbbell clean and press is a full-body movement that targets both the lower and upper body. The clean utilizes the muscles of the hips, legs, glutes, back, and biceps, while the press utilizes the shoulders and triceps. It can be trained in low to moderate reps for strength, or for higher reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, for muscle building or metabolic conditioning.
Muscles: hips, legs, glutes, back, biceps, shoulders, triceps
HowTo: 1. Start with a dumbbell on the floor between your feet. 2. Perform a clean by lifting the dumbbell to your shoulder, then press it overhead.

Title: Standing One-Arm Shoulder Press - Gethin Variation
Desc: The single-arm standing shoulder press builds shoulder muscle but with two major differences from the standard seated dumbbell shoulder press. Its done one arm at a time, as well as standing, which may allow more weight to be used.
HowTo: 1. Stand with a dumbbell in one hand at shoulder height. 2. Press the dumbbell overhead until your arm is fully extended, then lower it back to the starting position.

Title: Incline Front Dumbbell Raise - Gethin Variation
Desc: The incline dumbbell front raise is an isolation exercise targeting the shoulders
HowTo: 1. Lie back on an incline bench with a dumbbell in each hand. 2. Raise the dumbbells in front of you to shoulder height, then lower them back down.

Title: Dumbbell lateral raise
Desc: The dumbbell lateral raise is a shoulder exercise that targets the medial or middle head of the deltoid muscle. It's a staple strength-training move and is a great option for accessory work on upper-body training days. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps, at least 8-12 reps, as part of the upper-body or shoulder-focused portion of a workout.
HowTo: Stand with a dumbbell in each hand at your sides. Raise the dumbbells out to the side until they are parallel to the ground, then lower them back down.

Title: Incline Rear-Delt Fly - Gethin Variation
Desc: The incline dumbbell reverse fly is an upper-body exercise targeting the posterior or rear deltoids, as well as the postural muscles of the upper back. Because it targets such small muscles, this exercise is usually performed with light weight for high reps, such as 10-15 reps per set or more.
HowTo: Lie face down on an incline bench with a dumbbell in each hand. With your arms hanging down, lift the dumbbells out to the side until they are parallel to the ground, then lower them back down.

Title: Incline Bench Rear Dumbbell Fly - Gethin Variation
Desc: The incline dumbbell reverse fly is an upper-body exercise targeting the posterior or rear deltoids, as well as the postural muscles of the upper back. Because it targets such small muscles, this exercise is usually performed with light weight for high reps, such as 10-15 reps per set or more.
HowTo: Lie face down on an incline bench with a dumbbell in each hand. With your arms hanging down, lift the dumbbells out to the side until they are parallel to the ground, then lower them back down.

Title: Dumbbell front raise and press
Desc: The dumbbell front raise and press combines two upper-body moves into one challenging sequence targeting the deltoid muscles. It's a simple way to boost your heart rate while getting a good upper-body pump, and is a natural fit in time-efficient upper-body or circuit training.
HowTo: Stand with a dumbbell in each hand at your thighs. Raise the dumbbells in front of you to shoulder height, then press them overhead before lowering them back down.

Title: Rotator cuff warm-up
Desc: The rotator cuff warm-up is a simple exercise targeting the rotator cuffs through weighted shoulder external rotation. It's a classic way to warm up the shoulder prior to sports or training, as well as a common rehab movement. The rotator cuffs are a notorious injury-prone structure in the shoulders of Major League pitchers and other athletes. This is a movement most commonly done for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps or more per set.
HowTo: Stand or sit with a light dumbbell in one hand. Keep your elbow close to your body and rotate your arm outward, then return to the starting position.

Title: Seated Lateral Raise - Gethin Variation
Desc: The seated dumbbell lateral raiseis an iconic exercise for developing the shoulders. If youve ever worked out with weights, chances are youve done this move at some point. Proper execution is paramount to avoid injury.
HowTo: 1. Sit on a bench with a back support, holding a dumbbell in each hand at shoulder height. 2. Raise the dumbbells out to the sides until your arms are parallel to the ground, then lower them back to the starting position.

Title: Single-arm dumbbell arc row
Desc: The single-arm dumbbell arc row is an exercise for building the latissimus dorsi, or lat, muscles of the back. This variation has more of an arcing shape than the traditional single-arm dumbbell row, which may increase the mind-muscle connection and hit the back from a different angle. You probably won't be able to go as heavy on this as on a traditional row.
HowTo: 1. Stand with a dumbbell in one hand and hinge at the hips, keeping your back straight. 2. Pull the dumbbell in an arcing motion towards your hip while keeping your elbow close to your body, then lower it back down.

Title: Incline Rear Delt Raises - Gethin Variation
Desc: The incline dumbbell reverse fly is an upper-body exercise targeting the posterior or rear deltoids, as well as the postural muscles of the upper back. Because it targets such small muscles, this exercise is usually performed with light weight for high reps, such as 10-15 reps per set or more.
HowTo: 1. Lie face down on an incline bench with a dumbbell in each hand. 2. Raise the dumbbells out to the sides in a reverse fly motion, squeezing your shoulder blades together at the top, then lower them back down.

Title: Incline Dumbbell Y Raise
Desc: The incline dumbbell Y raise is an exercise that targets the shoulders and upper back. It helps improve shoulder stability and strength.
HowTo: 1. Lie face down on an incline bench with a dumbbell in each hand. 2. Raise the dumbbells in a Y shape above your head, keeping your arms straight, then lower them back down.

Title: HM Bent-Over Rear-Delt Fly
Desc: The bent-over rear-delt fly targets the rear deltoids and upper back muscles. It is effective for improving posture and shoulder strength.
HowTo: 1. Bend at the hips with a dumbbell in each hand, keeping your back straight. 2. Raise the dumbbells out to the sides, squeezing your shoulder blades together, then lower them back down.

Title: HM Dumbbell Shoulder Press
Desc: The HM Dumbbell Shoulder Press is an effective exercise for building shoulder strength. It primarily targets the deltoid muscles while also engaging the triceps.
HowTo: 1. Sit on a bench with back support holding a dumbbell in each hand at shoulder height. 2. Press the dumbbells overhead until your arms are fully extended. 3. Lower the weights back to the starting position.

Title: HM Single-Leg Overhead Dumbbell Press
Desc: The HM Single-Leg Overhead Dumbbell Press challenges balance while strengthening the shoulders. It engages the core for stability as you press the weights overhead.
HowTo: 1. Stand on one leg with a dumbbell in one hand at shoulder height. 2. Press the dumbbell overhead while maintaining balance on the standing leg. 3. Lower the dumbbell back to shoulder height and repeat.

Title: 6 Way Shoulder Raise
Desc: The 6 Way Shoulder Raise is a comprehensive exercise targeting all heads of the deltoids. It involves multiple movements to fully engage the shoulder muscles.
HowTo: 1. Stand with a dumbbell in each hand at your sides. 2. Raise the dumbbells in six different directions: front raise, lateral raise, bent-over lateral raise, upright row, and two variations of diagonal raises. 3. Perform each movement with controlled form.

Title: Seated dumbbell lateral raise
Desc: The seated dumbbell lateral raise is an exercise that targets the shoulder muscles, particularly the medial or middle head of the deltoids. Performing it on a bench helps enforce strict form and eliminate swinging or using momentum to move the weights. Lateral raise variations are usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of the upper-body or shoulder-focused portion of a workout.
HowTo: 1. Sit on a bench with a dumbbell in each hand at your sides. 2. Raise the dumbbells out to the sides until they are parallel to the ground. 3. Lower the weights back to the starting position.

Title: AM Dumbbell Shoulder Press
Desc: The seated dumbbell shoulder pressis an exercise for building muscle and strengthening the shoulders, particularly but not exclusively the front heads. The triceps also assist. Some lifters feel that using dumbbells versus a barbell reduced injury risk.
HowTo: 1. Sit on a bench with back support, holding a dumbbell in each hand at shoulder height. 2. Press the dumbbells overhead until your arms are fully extended. 3. Slowly lower the dumbbells back to shoulder height.

Title: AM Dumbbell Side Raise
Desc: The dumbbell lateral raise is an upper body isolation exercise for building shoulder strength and muscle. It's a staple strength training move and is a great option for accessory work on upper body training days. This exercise particularly focuses on the lateral or medial head of the deltoid, making them appear wider and more developed.
HowTo: Stand with a dumbbell in each hand at your sides. Raise the dumbbells to the side until they reach shoulder height, then lower them back down.

Title: AM Front Raise
Desc: The alternating dumbbell front raise is an isolation movement that targets the shoulders. By using one arm at a time, you can use more weight than when you use both arms at once. Bodybuilders use this exercise to zero in on the front shoulders, but the simple movement also makes it great for people new to lifting weights.
HowTo: Stand with a dumbbell in one hand at your side. Raise the dumbbell in front of you to shoulder height, then lower it back down before switching arms.

Title: UP Dumbbell Lateral Raise
Desc: The dumbbell lateral raise is an upper body isolation exercise for building shoulder strength and muscle. It's a staple strength training move and is a great option for accessory work on upper body training days. This exercise particularly focuses on the lateral or medial head of the deltoid, making them appear wider and more developed.
HowTo: Stand with a dumbbell in each hand at your sides. Raise the dumbbells to the side until they reach shoulder height, then lower them back down.

Title: UP Seated Dumbbell Overhead Press
Desc: The seated dumbbell shoulder pressis an exercise for building muscle and strengthening the shoulders, particularly but not exclusively the front heads. The triceps also assist. Some lifters feel that using dumbbells versus a barbell reduced injury risk.
HowTo: Sit on a bench with a dumbbell in each hand at shoulder height. Press the dumbbells overhead until your arms are fully extended, then lower them back to the starting position.

Title: AA Incline Bench Dumbbell Reverse Fly
Desc: The incline bench dumbbell reverse fly targets the upper back and shoulders, promoting better posture and shoulder stability.
HowTo: Lie face down on an incline bench with a dumbbell in each hand. With a slight bend in your elbows, lift the dumbbells out to the side until they are parallel to the ground, then lower them back down.

Title: CM Forward Shoulder Press
Desc: The CM Forward Shoulder Press is a compound exercise that primarily targets the shoulder muscles. It helps in building strength and stability in the upper body.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a dumbbell in each hand at shoulder height. 2. Press the dumbbells overhead until your arms are fully extended. 3. Lower the dumbbells back to shoulder height and repeat.

Title: Dumbbell Halo
Desc: The Dumbbell Halo is an exercise that engages the shoulders and core while improving shoulder mobility. It involves moving a dumbbell around the head in a circular motion.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a dumbbell with both hands. 2. Raise the dumbbell to eye level and move it around your head in a circular motion. 3. Reverse the direction after completing the set.

Title: Standing Dumbbell Scap Raise
Desc: The Standing Dumbbell Scap Raise targets the upper back and shoulders, helping to improve posture and shoulder stability. This exercise is great for strengthening the muscles around the scapula.
HowTo: 1. Stand with a dumbbell in each hand, arms at your sides. 2. Raise your arms straight out to the sides until they are parallel to the ground. 3. Lower your arms back down and repeat.

Title: Holman Overhead Press
Desc: The Holman Overhead Press is a powerful exercise that targets the shoulder muscles and helps in building upper body strength. It is performed standing to engage the core as well.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a barbell or dumbbells at shoulder height. 2. Press the weight overhead until your arms are fully extended. 3. Lower the weight back to shoulder height and repeat.

Title: Holman Slow Weighted Half Jack to Overhead Press
Desc: The Holman Slow Weighted Half Jack to Overhead Press combines a jumping jack with an overhead press, engaging multiple muscle groups. It is effective for building strength and coordination.
HowTo: 1. Start in a standing position with weights in each hand. 2. Perform a half jumping jack by moving your legs out while raising the weights overhead. 3. Return to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Holman Slow Arnold Press
Desc: The Holman Slow Arnold Press is a variation of the traditional Arnold press that focuses on controlled movement. It emphasizes shoulder stability and strength.
HowTo: 1. Stand or sit with a dumbbell in each hand at shoulder height, palms facing you. 2. Rotate your palms outward as you press the weights overhead, fully extending your arms. 3. Slowly lower the weights back to the starting position while rotating your palms back towards you.

Title: Holman Boat Arnold Press with Feet Push-Out
Desc: The Holman Boat Arnold Press with Feet Push-Out engages the core while incorporating shoulder strength. It combines a boat pose with an overhead press for a full-body challenge.
HowTo: 1. Sit in a boat position with your knees bent and feet off the ground. 2. Hold a dumbbell in each hand at shoulder height. 3. Press the weights overhead while extending your legs out, then return to the starting position.

Title: Holman Dumbbell Hip Drive to Overhead Press
Desc: The Holman Dumbbell Hip Drive to Overhead Press combines lower body and shoulder strength. It is effective for building power and stability.
HowTo: 1. Start in a standing position with dumbbells at your sides. 2. Perform a hip drive by bending your knees and pushing your hips forward while pressing the weights overhead. 3. Return to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Holman Squat Thrust to Alternating Renegade Triceps Press
Desc: The Holman Squat Thrust to Alternating Renegade Triceps Press is a dynamic exercise that targets multiple muscle groups. It combines a squat thrust with a triceps press for a full-body workout.
HowTo: 1. Start in a standing position, then drop into a squat and kick your feet back into a plank. 2. Perform a renegade row by pulling one dumbbell towards your hip while stabilizing your body. 3. Return to the squat position and repeat on the other side.

Title: Holman Cheer Press
Desc: The Holman Cheer Press is a shoulder exercise that mimics the motion of a cheerleading cheer. It focuses on shoulder strength and stability.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a dumbbell in each hand at shoulder height. 2. Press the weights overhead while extending your arms fully. 3. Lower the weights back to shoulder height and repeat.

Title: Holman Left Arm Press with Right Arm Hold
Desc: The Holman Left Arm Press with Right Arm Hold is a unilateral shoulder exercise that targets the deltoids and stabilizing muscles. It helps improve shoulder strength and stability.
