HowTo: 1. Stand or sit with your left arm holding a weight above your head. 2. Keep your right arm extended out to the side at shoulder height. 3. Press the weight overhead with your left arm while maintaining the right arm's position. 4. Lower the weight back to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Holman Right Arm Press with Left Arm Hold
Desc: The Holman Right Arm Press with Left Arm Hold is a unilateral shoulder exercise that focuses on building strength in the deltoids. It also enhances stability and coordination.
HowTo: 1. Stand or sit with your right arm holding a weight above your head. 2. Keep your left arm extended out to the side at shoulder height. 3. Press the weight overhead with your right arm while maintaining the left arm's position. 4. Lower the weight back to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Holman Left Front Raise with Right Hold
Desc: The Holman Left Front Raise with Right Hold is a shoulder exercise that targets the front deltoids while engaging stabilizing muscles. It promotes shoulder strength and endurance.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a weight in your left hand. 2. Extend your right arm out to the side at shoulder height. 3. Raise the weight in your left hand straight in front of you to shoulder height. 4. Lower the weight back down and repeat.

Title: Holman Right Front Raise with Left Hold
Desc: The Holman Right Front Raise with Left Hold is a unilateral exercise that targets the front deltoids and improves shoulder stability. It is effective for building shoulder strength.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a weight in your right hand. 2. Extend your left arm out to the side at shoulder height. 3. Raise the weight in your right hand straight in front of you to shoulder height. 4. Lower the weight back down and repeat.

Title: Holman Alternating Front Raise to Side Raise
Desc: The Holman Alternating Front Raise to Side Raise is a dynamic shoulder exercise that targets the deltoids and enhances shoulder mobility. It combines two movements for comprehensive shoulder training.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a weight in each hand. 2. Raise one weight in front of you to shoulder height while keeping the other arm at your side. 3. Lower the front weight and raise the other weight to the side to shoulder height. 4. Alternate between the front and side raises.

Title: Holman Heavy Right Arm Overhead Press
Desc: The Holman Heavy Right Arm Overhead Press is a strength exercise targeting the shoulder muscles. It involves pressing a weight overhead with one arm, engaging the core for stability.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a dumbbell in your right hand at shoulder height. 2. Press the dumbbell overhead until your arm is fully extended. 3. Lower the dumbbell back to shoulder height and repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Holman Heavy Left Arm Overhead Press
Desc: The Holman Heavy Left Arm Overhead Press is a unilateral strength exercise focusing on the left shoulder. It helps improve strength and stability in the shoulder joint.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a dumbbell in your left hand at shoulder height. 2. Press the dumbbell overhead until your arm is fully extended. 3. Lower the dumbbell back to shoulder height and repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Holman Right Arm Heavy Overhead Press
Desc: The Holman Right Arm Heavy Overhead Press is a strength exercise that targets the right shoulder. It enhances shoulder strength and stability.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a dumbbell in your right hand at shoulder height. 2. Press the dumbbell overhead until your arm is fully extended. 3. Lower the dumbbell back to shoulder height and repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Holman Right Diagonal Lunge to Overhead Press
Desc: The Holman Right Diagonal Lunge to Overhead Press is a compound exercise that combines a lunge with an overhead press. It targets the legs and shoulders, enhancing overall strength and coordination.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet hip-width apart, holding a dumbbell in each hand. 2. Step diagonally forward with your right leg into a lunge while pressing the dumbbells overhead. 3. Push through your front heel to return to the starting position and repeat on the other side.

Title: Holman Left Arm Heavy Overhead Press
Desc: The Holman Left Arm Heavy Overhead Press is a unilateral exercise focusing on the left shoulder. It is effective for building shoulder strength and stability.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a dumbbell in your left hand at shoulder height. 2. Press the dumbbell overhead until your arm is fully extended. 3. Lower the dumbbell back to shoulder height and repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Holman Weighted Palms-In Overhead Press
Desc: No description provided.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, holding dumbbells at shoulder height with palms facing in. 2. Press the dumbbells overhead until arms are fully extended, then lower back to the starting position.

Title: Dumbbell racked carry
Desc: The dumbbell racked carry involves carrying dumbbells for time or distance, while holding them close to the shoulders in a front-racked position. Similar to a dumbbell farmer's carry, it can be a challenging finisher to any workout, or work well in fat-loss circuit training or as an accessory movement to heavy lifts like the deadlift.
HowTo: 1. Hold a dumbbell in each hand at shoulder height with elbows tucked in. 2. Walk forward for a specified distance or time while maintaining a strong posture.

Title: Dumbbell clean and push-press
Desc: The dumbbell clean and push-press is a full-body movement that targets both the lower and upper body. The clean utilizes the muscles of the hips, legs, glutes, back, and biceps, while the push-press utilizes the shoulders and triceps. It differs from the clean and press in that the push-press allows you to use lower-body momentum to power through the most difficult part of the press. It can be trained in low to moderate reps for strength, or for higher reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, for muscle building or metabolic conditioning.
HowTo: 1. Start with dumbbells on the ground. 2. Clean the dumbbells to shoulder height, then dip slightly and press them overhead. 3. Lower back to shoulder height and repeat.

Title: Total Fitness Dumbbell Farmer's Carry
Desc: The dumbbell farmer's walk or carry is an exercise with roots in competitive strongman training, but which is also popular in CrossFit and functional training. It can be a challenging finisher to any workout, or work well in fat-loss circuit training or as an accessory movement to heavy lifts like the deadlift.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, holding a dumbbell in each hand at your sides. 2. Walk forward for a specified distance while keeping your back straight and shoulders back.

Title: Single-arm dumbbell racked carry
Desc: The single-arm dumbbell racked carry involves carrying a single dumbbell for time or distance, while holding it close to the shoulders in a front-racked position. Similar to a dumbbell farmer's carry, it can be a challenging finisher to any workout, or work well in fat-loss circuit training or as an accessory movement to heavy lifts like the deadlift.
HowTo: 1. Hold a dumbbell in one hand at shoulder height with your elbow tucked in. 2. Walk forward for a specified distance or time while maintaining a strong posture.

Title: Jordan Shallow Dumbbell Pull-Over
Desc: The Jordan Shallow Dumbbell Pull-Over is a strength exercise that targets the chest and back. It helps to improve upper body strength and flexibility.
HowTo: 1. Lie on a bench with your upper back and shoulders supported. 2. Hold a dumbbell with both hands above your chest, arms slightly bent. 3. Slowly lower the dumbbell back over your head, keeping your arms straight. 4. Pull the dumbbell back to the starting position, engaging your chest and lats.

Title: King Maker Dumbbell Lateral Raise
Desc: The dumbbell lateral raise is an upper body isolation exercise for building shoulder strength and muscle. It's a staple strength training move and is a great option for accessory work on upper body training days. This exercise particularly focuses on the lateral or medial head of the deltoid, making them appear wider and more developed.
HowTo: 1. Stand with a dumbbell in each hand at your sides. 2. Keep your elbows slightly bent and raise the dumbbells out to the sides until they are at shoulder height. 3. Lower the dumbbells back to the starting position slowly.

Title: Dumbbell shadow boxing
Desc: Dumbbell shadow boxing is a more advanced version of a popular conditioning exercise. By adding a pair of lightweight dumbbells, you can greatly increase the challenge to both the shoulders and cardiovascular system.
HowTo: 1. Stand with a dumbbell in each hand, feet shoulder-width apart. 2. Begin throwing punches in the air while maintaining a light bounce on your feet. 3. Engage your core and keep your movements quick and controlled.

Title: King Maker Dumbbell Farmer's Carry
Desc: The dumbbell farmer's walk or carry is an exercise with roots in competitive strongman training, but which is also popular in CrossFit and functional training. It can be a challenging finisher to any workout, or work well in fat-loss circuit training or as an accessory movement to heavy lifts like the deadlift.
HowTo: 1. Stand upright while holding a heavy dumbbell in each hand at your sides. 2. Keep your shoulders back and core engaged. 3. Walk forward for a specified distance or time, maintaining good posture.

Title: King Maker Dumbbell Shrug
Desc: The standing dumbbell shrug is a popular movement to build and strengthen the trapezius muscles. Its a often trained on a bodybuilding-style shoulder or back training day, but can also work well in full-body or strength-focused training.
HowTo: 1. Stand with a dumbbell in each hand at your sides. 2. Raise your shoulders towards your ears while keeping your arms straight. 3. Lower your shoulders back down to the starting position.

Title: 30 Shoulders Alternating Dumbbell Front Raise
Desc: The Alternating Dumbbell Front Raise targets the shoulders, focusing on the front deltoids. It helps in building shoulder strength and stability.
HowTo: 1. Stand with a dumbbell in each hand at your sides. 2. Raise one dumbbell in front of you to shoulder height while keeping the other arm at your side. 3. Lower the dumbbell back to the starting position and repeat with the other arm. 4. Alternate arms for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: 30 Shoulders Bent-Over Dumbbell Reverse Fly
Desc: The Bent-Over Dumbbell Reverse Fly primarily targets the rear deltoids and upper back. It is effective for improving shoulder stability and posture.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and bend at the hips, keeping your back straight. 2. Hold a dumbbell in each hand with your arms hanging down. 3. Raise the dumbbells out to the sides until they are level with your shoulders. 4. Lower the dumbbells back to the starting position.

Title: 30 Shoulders Dumbbell Front Raise
Desc: The Dumbbell Front Raise is an effective exercise for isolating the front deltoids. It helps in building shoulder strength and improving muscle definition.
HowTo: 1. Stand with a dumbbell in each hand at your sides. 2. Raise both dumbbells in front of you to shoulder height, keeping your arms straight. 3. Lower the dumbbells back to the starting position.

Title: 30 Shoulders Dumbbell Lateral Raise
Desc: The Dumbbell Lateral Raise targets the lateral deltoids, contributing to shoulder width and strength. It is a key exercise for shoulder development.
HowTo: 1. Stand with a dumbbell in each hand at your sides. 2. Raise both dumbbells out to the sides until they reach shoulder height. 3. Lower the dumbbells back to the starting position.

Title: 30 Shoulders Dumbbell Shrug
Desc: The Dumbbell Shrug primarily targets the trapezius muscles, helping to build upper back strength. It is essential for improving posture and shoulder stability.
HowTo: 1. Stand with a dumbbell in each hand at your sides. 2. Raise your shoulders towards your ears while keeping your arms straight. 3. Lower your shoulders back to the starting position.

Title: 30 Shoulders Incline Face-Down Dumbbell Reverse Fly
Desc: The incline face-down dumbbell reverse fly primarily targets the rear deltoids and upper back. It helps improve shoulder stability and posture.
HowTo: 1. Lie face down on an incline bench with a dumbbell in each hand. 2. Keep your arms slightly bent and lift the dumbbells out to the side until they are parallel to the ground. 3. Squeeze your shoulder blades together at the top of the movement, then lower the weights back down.

Title: 30 Shoulders Seated Dumbbell Front Raise
Desc: The seated dumbbell front raise focuses on the anterior deltoids. It is effective for building shoulder strength and stability.
HowTo: 1. Sit on a bench with a dumbbell in each hand resting on your thighs. 2. Raise the dumbbells in front of you to shoulder height, keeping your arms straight but not locked. 3. Lower the weights back down to the starting position.

Title: 30 Shoulders Seated Dumbbell Side Raise
Desc: The seated dumbbell side raise targets the lateral deltoids, helping to build width in the shoulders. It is a great exercise for shoulder aesthetics.
HowTo: 1. Sit on a bench with a dumbbell in each hand at your sides. 2. Raise the dumbbells out to the side until they reach shoulder height. 3. Slowly lower the weights back down to the starting position.

Title: 30 Shoulders Neutral-Grip Arnold Press
Desc: The neutral-grip Arnold press is a variation of the shoulder press that targets all three heads of the deltoids. It promotes shoulder stability and strength.
HowTo: 1. Sit on a bench with back support, holding dumbbells at shoulder height with palms facing you. 2. Rotate your palms away from you as you press the weights overhead. 3. Reverse the motion to return to the starting position.

Title: 30 Shoulders Standing Dumbbell Upright Row
Desc: The standing dumbbell upright row primarily targets the shoulders and upper back. It helps in developing shoulder width and strength.
HowTo: 1. Stand with a dumbbell in each hand at your thighs, palms facing your body. 2. Pull the dumbbells straight up towards your chin, keeping them close to your body. 3. Lower the weights back down to the starting position.

Title: MetaBurn 3-Way Shoulder Raise
Desc: The MetaBurn 3-Way Shoulder Raise targets the shoulder muscles through three different angles. It helps in building shoulder strength and stability.
HowTo: 1. Stand with a dumbbell in each hand at your sides. 2. Raise the dumbbells laterally to shoulder height. 3. Lower them back down and then raise them forward to shoulder height. 4. Finally, raise them in front of you at a 45-degree angle. 5. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: MetaBurn Dumbbell Overhead Press
Desc: The MetaBurn Dumbbell Overhead Press is an effective exercise for building shoulder strength. It primarily targets the deltoids and helps improve overall upper body strength.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and hold a dumbbell in each hand at shoulder height. 2. Press the dumbbells overhead until your arms are fully extended. 3. Lower the dumbbells back to shoulder height. 4. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: MetaBurn Single-Leg Arnold Press
Desc: The MetaBurn Single-Leg Arnold Press combines balance and strength training for the shoulders. It engages the core while focusing on the deltoids.
HowTo: 1. Stand on one leg while holding a dumbbell in each hand at chest level with palms facing you. 2. As you press the dumbbells overhead, rotate your palms to face forward. 3. Lower the dumbbells back to the starting position while rotating your palms back towards you. 4. Switch legs after completing the desired reps.

Title: RG Forward-Leaning Dumbbell Upright Row
Desc: The RG Forward-Leaning Dumbbell Upright Row is designed to strengthen the shoulder and upper back muscles. It promotes good posture and shoulder stability.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and lean slightly forward at the hips. 2. Hold a dumbbell in each hand with your arms hanging down. 3. Pull the dumbbells up towards your chin, keeping your elbows higher than your wrists. 4. Lower the dumbbells back down to the starting position. 5. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: RG Alternating Seated Dumbbell Lateral Raise
Desc: The RG Alternating Seated Dumbbell Lateral Raise focuses on the lateral deltoids for shoulder development. It helps in achieving a well-rounded shoulder appearance.
HowTo: 1. Sit on a bench with a dumbbell in each hand at your sides. 2. Raise one dumbbell out to the side until it reaches shoulder height. 3. Lower it back down and repeat with the other arm. 4. Continue alternating arms for the desired number of reps.

Title: RG Seated Dumbbell Shoulder Press
Desc: The seated dumbbell shoulder press is an effective exercise for building shoulder strength and stability. It primarily targets the deltoid muscles while also engaging the triceps and upper back.
HowTo: 1. Sit on a bench with back support and hold a dumbbell in each hand at shoulder height. 2. Press the dumbbells upward until your arms are fully extended overhead. 3. Lower the dumbbells back to shoulder height and repeat.

Title: FYR2 Dumbbell Clean and Jerk
Desc: The dumbbell clean and jerk is a full-body exercise that combines strength and explosive power. It targets multiple muscle groups, including the legs, shoulders, and core.
HowTo: 1. Start with the dumbbells on the floor in front of you. 2. Bend your knees and grab the dumbbells, then lift them to your shoulders in one motion. 3. From this position, press the dumbbells overhead while standing up. 4. Lower the dumbbells back to the starting position and repeat.

Title: FYR2 Dumbbell Cross-Body Front Raise
Desc: The cross-body front raise is an isolation exercise that targets the front deltoid muscles. It helps improve shoulder stability and strength.
HowTo: 1. Stand with a dumbbell in one hand at your side. 2. Raise the dumbbell across your body to shoulder height while keeping your arm straight. 3. Lower the dumbbell back to the starting position and repeat on the other side.

Title: FYR2 Dumbbell Front Raise
Desc: The dumbbell front raise is a great exercise for targeting the front deltoid muscles. It helps to build shoulder strength and improve muscle definition.
HowTo: 1. Stand with a dumbbell in each hand at your thighs. 2. Raise the dumbbells in front of you to shoulder height with your arms straight. 3. Lower the dumbbells back to the starting position and repeat.

Title: FYR2 Dumbbell Lateral Raise
Desc: The dumbbell lateral raise is an effective exercise for isolating the lateral deltoid muscles. It helps to build width in the shoulders and improve overall shoulder aesthetics.
HowTo: 1. Stand with a dumbbell in each hand at your sides. 2. Raise the dumbbells out to the sides until they are at shoulder height. 3. Lower the dumbbells back to the starting position and repeat.

Title: FYR2 Lateral Raise Hold
Desc: No description provided.
HowTo: Stand with a weight plate held in front of you at chest height. Twist your torso to the left and then to the right, mimicking the motion of turning a steering wheel.

Title: FYR2 Seesaw Dumbbell Military Press
Desc: No description provided.
HowTo: Stand or sit with a dumbbell in each hand at shoulder height. Press the dumbbells overhead until your arms are fully extended, then lower them back to the starting position.

Title: FYR2 Single-Dumbbell Halo
Desc: No description provided.
HowTo: Hold a single dumbbell with both hands above your head. Move the dumbbell in a circular motion around your head, keeping your arms slightly bent.

Title: FYR2 Single-Dumbbell Overhead Press
Desc: No description provided.
HowTo: Stand or sit with a dumbbell in one hand at shoulder height. Press the dumbbell overhead until your arm is fully extended, then lower it back to the starting position.

Title: Car driver
Desc: The car driver is a variation of the plate front raise exercise where the lifter holds a weight plate in front of them and twists it from side to side, similar to a steering wheel. It targets the muscles of the shoulders, the front or anterior deltoids in particular, but is also challenging to the core and upper-back muscles. It can provide variety in a shoulder-focused muscle-building workout or as part of an upper-body or full-body circuit.
HowTo: Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, holding a weight plate in front of you. Rotate your torso to the left and right, engaging your core and maintaining control of the plate.

Title: Arnold press
Desc: Named after the iconic bodybuilder and movie star, the Arnold press adds rotation to a classic shoulder press. It allows the hands to rotate naturally, while also hitting all three heads of the deltoids in one motion. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps or more, as part of the upper-body or shoulder-focused portion of a workout.
HowTo: 1. Sit on a bench with back support. 2. Hold a dumbbell in each hand at shoulder height with palms facing you. 3. Press the weights overhead while rotating your palms to face forward. 4. Lower the weights back to the starting position while rotating your palms back to face you.

Title: Front Plate Raise
Desc: The plate front raise is a variation of the dumbbell front raise where the lifter holds a weight plate between two hands, rather than using a dumbbell, barbell, or other weight. It can provide variety in a shoulder-focused muscle-building workout, or as part of an upper body or full-body circuit.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart holding a weight plate with both hands at hip level. 2. Raise the plate in front of you to shoulder height, keeping your arms straight. 3. Lower the plate back to the starting position.

Title: Battle ropes
Desc: Battle ropes are an explosive training tool that involves moving the rope in waves with the other end of the rope anchored at ground level. There are many different types of waves, but the most common is alternating waves with the left and right hands. The battle ropes can be performed for short bursts as power training, for longer durations as cardiovascular training, or as a component of a conditioning or fat-loss circuit.
HowTo: 1. Anchor one end of the rope and hold the other end in each hand. 2. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. 3. Move your arms up and down alternately to create waves in the rope. 4. Continue for a set duration or number of reps.

Title: Seated rear delt fly
Desc: The seated rear delt fly is an upper-body exercise that targets the real deltoid of the shoulder. By performing the movement seated, it eliminates momentum from the rest of the body. This movement is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of the upper-body or shoulder-focused portion of a workout.
HowTo: 1. Sit on a bench with your chest against the pad, holding dumbbells in each hand. 2. With a slight bend in your elbows, lift the weights out to the sides until your arms are parallel to the ground. 3. Lower the weights back to the starting position.

Title: Circus Bell
Desc: The Circus Bell is a unique exercise that combines strength and balance. It typically involves lifting a weighted bell in a controlled manner, engaging multiple muscle groups.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and the Circus Bell on the ground between your feet. 2. Bend at your knees and hips to grasp the bell with both hands. 3. Lift the bell by extending your legs and standing up straight, keeping your core engaged. 4. Lower the bell back to the ground in a controlled manner.

Title: Landmine Linear Jammer
Desc: The linear jammer is an explosive pressing movement performed using an angled barbell anchored at floor level in a landmine device. It can also be performed by sticking a barbell in the corner of a room, preferably in a towel to protect the walls. The linear jammer involves pressing the weight into the air, then catching it with the other hand. The movement focuses primarily on the muscles of the shoulders or deltoids. It can be trained in traditional muscle and strength-focused rep ranges, for lower reps with a focus on explosive pressing power, or for higher reps.
HowTo: 1. Set up a barbell in a landmine device or in the corner of a room. 2. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and grasp the barbell with one hand. 3. Press the barbell upward explosively, then catch it with the other hand as it comes down.

Title: Crucifix
Desc: No description provided.
HowTo: 1. Stand or sit with a barbell or similar object held in both hands. 2. Extend your arms overhead and slowly lower the bar behind your head, keeping your arms straight. 3. Hold the stretch for a few seconds, then return to the starting position.

Title: Bar shoulder extension stretch
Desc: The bar shoulder extension stretch is a technique to increase overhead mobility (known as shoulder flexion) and thoracic extension with the help of a bar or other stable object. It is often used as part of a warm-up before upper-body training.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and hold a barbell or similar object with both hands. 2. Raise the bar overhead and slowly lower it behind your head while keeping your arms straight. 3. Hold the position for a few seconds, then return to the starting position.

Title: Chair Upper Body Stretch
Desc: No description provided.
HowTo: 1. Sit on a chair or stand with your arms extended in front of you. 2. Slowly raise your arms overhead and then back, stretching your upper body. 3. Hold the stretch for a few seconds before returning to the starting position.

Title: Sled Reverse Flye
Desc: No description provided.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and hold a weight in each hand. 2. Bend slightly at the hips and pull the weights out to the side, squeezing your shoulder blades together. 3. Return to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Plate shoulder circle big to small
Desc: The plate shoulder circle big to small is an exercise targeting the shoulder complex. Typically, this is considered a warm-up move rather than a working exercise. It warms up the shoulder joint and works small and hard-to-attack muscles such as the rotator cuff group.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart holding a weight plate. 2. Extend your arms out to the sides and make large circles with the plate, gradually making the circles smaller.

Title: Sled Overhead Backward Walk
Desc: The Sled Overhead Backward Walk is a strength exercise that involves walking backward while pushing a sled overhead. It engages multiple muscle groups and improves strength and stability.
HowTo: 1. Stand facing away from the sled with the sled positioned behind you. 2. Grip the handles of the sled overhead, keeping your arms straight. 3. Walk backward, maintaining a strong core and steady pace.

Title: Log Lift
Desc: The Log Lift is a strength exercise that involves lifting a log or similar object from the ground to shoulder height. It targets multiple muscle groups and is great for functional strength.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and the log in front of you. 2. Bend at the hips and knees to grip the log. 3. Lift the log to your chest and then press it overhead, extending your arms fully.

Title: Standing suspended rear delt fly
Desc: The standing suspended rear delt fly is a bodyweight movement targeting the shoulders and upper back using a suspension strap system or gymnastic rings. It can be performed for time or reps as part of a dynamic warm-up for an upper-body strength workout, or in the workout itself either in traditional muscle-building rep ranges or for higher reps.
HowTo: 1. Set up a suspension strap or gymnastic rings at shoulder height. 2. Grab the straps and lean back, keeping your body straight. 3. Pull your body towards the straps while keeping your elbows slightly bent, focusing on squeezing your shoulder blades together.

Title: Waiter's carry
Desc: The waiter's carry is a type of loaded carry that targets the core, shoulders, and upper back. A weight is raised overhead with a single arm before the lifter begins walking in that position. It resembles a waiter carrying a tray overheadhence the name. It can be performed for time or distance.
HowTo: 1. Stand upright holding a weight overhead with one arm. 2. Engage your core and walk forward while keeping the weight stable overhead. 3. Maintain a straight posture and avoid leaning to one side.

Title: Towel dumbbell front raise
Desc: The towel dumbbell front raise is a variation of the dumbbell front raise that involves hanging a dumbbell from a towel held in the hands. It could also be performed with a kettlebell or weight plate. It can provide variety in a shoulder-focused muscle-building workout or as part of an upper-body or full-body circuit.
HowTo: 1. Hold a towel with both hands, with a dumbbell hanging from the center. 2. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart and raise the dumbbell in front of you to shoulder height, keeping your arms straight. 3. Lower the dumbbell back to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Reach-roll-lift combo
Desc: The reach-roll-lift combo is a mobility drill for the upper back and shoulders. It can be part of a dynamic warm-up for upper-body workouts, or as postural training anytime.
HowTo: 1. Start in a seated position with your legs extended. 2. Reach forward to touch your toes, then roll back onto your back. 3. Lift your arms overhead and return to the seated position, engaging your core throughout.

Title: Upright Row - Gethin Variation
Desc: The barbell upright row is a barbell exercise that builds stronger and bigger traps. Many lifters combine this move with either their back or shoulder workout since it involves both body parts.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a barbell with an overhand grip. 2. Pull the barbell up towards your chin, keeping it close to your body. 3. Lower the barbell back down and repeat.

Title: Squat Press Shoulder Press - Gethin Variation
Desc: The Squat Press Shoulder Press - Gethin Variation is a compound exercise that combines a squat with a shoulder press. It targets multiple muscle groups, providing a full-body workout.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, holding dumbbells at shoulder height. 2. Perform a squat by bending your knees and lowering your hips. 3. As you rise from the squat, press the dumbbells overhead until your arms are fully extended.

Title: Plate lateral raise
Desc: The plate lateral raise is an exercise targeting the side heads of the shoulder muscles or deltoids. It closely resembles the more popular dumbbell lateral raise, but is performed with light plates, making the movement slightly more difficult. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps as part of a shoulder or upper-body workout.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, holding a plate in each hand at your sides. 2. Raise the plates out to the sides until your arms are parallel to the floor. 3. Lower the plates back to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Standing Military Press - Gethin Variation
Desc: The military press is a compound movement used to build size and strength in the shoulders. It was once contested as a fourth powerlift, but is rarely competed anymore. However, being able to press a significant weight overhead remains a popular marker of upper-body strength. The military press can be trained as a strength lift or in traditional muscle-building rep ranges as part of full-body, shoulder-focused, or upper-body training.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. 2. Grip the barbell slightly wider than shoulder-width and lift it to shoulder height. 3. Press the barbell overhead until your arms are fully extended. 4. Lower the barbell back to shoulder height and repeat.

Title: Bent-over plate rear delt raise
Desc: The bent-over plate rear delt raise is an exercise targeting the rear heads of the shoulders, or deltoids. You can also use dumbbells or other light weights for a similar effect. This movement is usually performed as part of a dynamic warm-up or as a high-rep burnout movement on a shoulder or back day.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and hold a weight plate with both hands. 2. Bend at the hips until your torso is nearly parallel to the ground. 3. Raise the plate out to the side until your arms are parallel to the ground. 4. Lower the plate back down and repeat.

Title: Single-arm landmine press
Desc: The single-arm landmine press is an upper-body exercise that uses an angled barbell anchored at floor level in a landmine device. It can also be performed by sticking a barbell in the corner of a room, preferably in a towel to protect the walls. The angle of a landmine press is usually somewhere between an incline press and a military press, and the movement focuses primarily on the muscles of the shoulders or deltoids. It can be trained in traditional muscle and strength-focused rep ranges or for higher reps.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and hold the end of a barbell anchored in a landmine device. 2. Press the barbell upward with one arm until it is fully extended. 3. Lower the barbell back to shoulder height and repeat. 4. Switch arms after completing the set.

Title: Plate front raise
Desc: The plate front raise is a variation of the front raise where the lifter holds a weight plate between two hands, rather than using a dumbbell, barbell, or other weight. It can provide variety in a shoulder-focused muscle-building workout or as part of an upper-body or full-body circuit.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and hold a weight plate with both hands in front of your thighs. 2. Raise the plate straight up in front of you until your arms are parallel to the ground. 3. Lower the plate back down to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Holman Slow Overhead Press
Desc: The Holman Slow Overhead Press is a shoulder exercise that emphasizes control and strength. It focuses on building shoulder stability and strength through a slow and deliberate movement.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and hold a barbell at shoulder height. 2. Press the barbell overhead slowly, focusing on maintaining control. 3. Lower the barbell back to shoulder height slowly. 4. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: 30 Shoulders Plate Front Raise
Desc: The 30 Shoulders Plate Front Raise is a shoulder exercise that primarily targets the deltoid muscles. It involves raising a weight plate in front of you to shoulder height to build strength and stability.
HowTo: 1. Stand upright holding a weight plate with both hands in front of your thighs. 2. Keeping your arms straight, lift the plate in front of you to shoulder height. 3. Slowly lower it back to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Single-arm landmine push-press
Desc: The single-arm landmine push-press is an explosive upper-body exercise that uses an angled barbell anchored at floor level in a landmine device. It can also be performed by sticking a barbell in the corner of a room, preferably in a towel to protect the walls. The angle of a landmine press is usually somewhere between an incline press and a military press, and the movement focuses primarily on the muscles of the shoulders or deltoids. It can be trained in traditional muscle and strength-focused rep ranges or for higher reps.
HowTo: 1. Stand with a landmine barbell anchored at the floor. 2. Grip the end of the barbell with one hand and position it at shoulder height. 3. Dip slightly into your legs and explosively press the bar overhead using your shoulder and arm. 4. Lower back to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Single-arm cable front raise
Desc: The single-arm cable front raise is an isolation exercise targeting the anterior and medial deltoids or shoulder muscles. The single-arm version of this movement allows you to focus on each side independently. Because grip will be a limitation, it is usually performed for moderate to high reps, at least 8-12 reps per set, as part of an upper-body or shoulder-focused workout.
HowTo: 1. Stand next to a cable machine with the cable set at the lowest position. 2. Grab the handle with one hand and stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. 3. Keeping your arm straight, raise the handle in front of you to shoulder height. 4. Lower it back down and repeat before switching sides.

Title: Cable Internal Rotation
Desc: Cable Internal Rotation is an exercise that targets the rotator cuff and deltoid muscles. It helps improve shoulder stability and strength.
HowTo: 1. Attach a handle to a low pulley on a cable machine. 2. Stand with your side to the machine, holding the handle with the hand closest to the machine. 3. Keep your elbow at a 90-degree angle and rotate your arm inward towards your body. 4. Slowly return to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Seated face pull
Desc: The seated face pull is a cable exercise targeting the shoulder muscles, particularly the rear delts, and the muscles of the upper back. This can help build healthier shoulders and posture, and increase shoulder stability. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps as part of a dynamic warm-up for an upper-body workout or in the main part of a shoulder-focused workout.
HowTo: 1. Sit at a cable machine with the pulley set at upper chest height. 2. Grab the rope attachment with both hands and pull it towards your face, keeping your elbows high. 3. Squeeze your shoulder blades together at the end of the movement. 4. Slowly return to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Single-arm bent-over cable rear delt fly
Desc: The single-arm bent-over cable rear delt fly is an exercise targeting the rear deltoids. It is a great way to isolate this area of the shoulder and attack each side independently. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps, at least 8-12 reps per set, as part of an upper-body or shoulder-focused workout.
HowTo: 1. Stand bent over with one arm holding the cable. 2. Pull the cable out to the side, focusing on squeezing the rear deltoid at the top of the movement.

Title: Seated cable shoulder press
Desc: The seated cable shoulder press is a multijoint machine-based exercise that focuses on the deltoid or shoulder muscles, as well as the triceps. It's most common in muscle-building workouts and rep ranges, usually 8-12 reps or more.
HowTo: 1. Sit on the cable machine with the handles at shoulder height. 2. Press the handles upward until your arms are fully extended, then lower back to the starting position.

Title: Standing face pull
Desc: The standing face pull is an isolation exercise primarily targeting the rear deltoids, traps, and upper back. It is most often performed with a rope attachment.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding the rope attachment with both hands. 2. Pull the rope towards your face, keeping your elbows high and squeezing your shoulder blades together.

Title: Standing cable rear delt row
Desc: The standing cable rear delt row primarily targets the rear deltoids. This movement also hits the traps, rhomboids, and biceps. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps, at least 8-12 reps per set, as part of an upper-body or shoulder-focused workout.
HowTo: 1. Stand with a cable in each hand, arms extended in front of you. 2. Pull the cables towards your body, focusing on squeezing your shoulder blades together.

Title: Standing Low-Pulley Deltoid Raise
Desc: The single-arm cable lateral raise is an isolation exercise targeting the shoulders, specifically the medial deltoid. This movement also hits the traps and upper back, and allows you to focus on each side independently. Because grip is a limitation, it is usually performed for moderate to high reps, like at least 8-12 reps per set, as part of an upper body or shoulders-focused workout.
HowTo: 1. Stand with a cable in one hand, arm at your side. 2. Raise the cable out to the side until your arm is parallel to the ground, then lower back down.

Title: Standing crossed-cable rear delt fly
Desc: The standing crossed-cable rear delt fly is an isolation exercise for the rear deltoids. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps, at least 8-12 reps per set, as part of an upper-body or shoulder-focused workout.
HowTo: 1. Stand between two cable machines with the cables set at a low position. 2. Grab the cables with your hands crossed over each other. 3. With a slight bend in your elbows, pull the cables out to the sides until your arms are parallel to the ground. 4. Slowly return to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Cable Shoulder Press
Desc: The Cable Shoulder Press is a compound exercise that targets the shoulder muscles. It involves pressing a cable overhead to build strength and muscle size.
HowTo: 1. Stand facing away from the cable machine with the cables set at shoulder height. 2. Grab the handles with both hands and bring them to shoulder level. 3. Press the handles upward until your arms are fully extended. 4. Lower back to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Alternating Cable Shoulder Press
Desc: The Alternating Cable Shoulder Press is a variation of the shoulder press that allows for unilateral training. This exercise helps to improve shoulder stability and strength.
HowTo: 1. Stand facing away from the cable machine with the cables set at shoulder height. 2. Grab the handles with each hand at shoulder level. 3. Press one handle overhead while keeping the other at shoulder height. 4. Alternate arms with each repetition.

Title: Cable Seated Lateral Raise
Desc: The Cable Seated Lateral Raise is an isolation exercise that targets the lateral deltoids. It is performed seated to reduce momentum and focus on muscle contraction.
HowTo: 1. Sit on a bench with a cable machine on each side. 2. Grab the handles with your arms at your sides. 3. Raise the cables out to the sides until your arms are parallel to the ground. 4. Slowly lower back to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Single-arm lying cable front raise
Desc: The single-arm lying cable front raise is an isolation exercise for the shoulders, performed lying on the back, either on a bench or the ground, and lifting the cable over the torso one arm at a time. This movement is usually performed for moderate to high reps for a burn and pump as part of a shoulder-focused workout.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back on a bench or the ground with a cable machine beside you. 2. Grab the cable handle with one hand, keeping your arm straight. 3. Raise the cable straight up over your torso. 4. Lower back to the starting position and repeat before switching arms.

Title: Lying cable front raise
Desc: The lying cable front raise is an isolation exercise for the shoulders, particularly the front deltoids. It is performed lying on the back, either on a bench or the ground, with the cable lifted over the torso. This movement is usually performed for moderate to high reps for a burn and pump as part of a shoulder-focused workout.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back on a bench or the ground. 2. Hold the cable with both hands and lift it over your torso, raising it to shoulder height.

Title: Cable Rear Delt Fly - Gethin Variation
Desc: The standing crossed-cable rear delt fly is an isolation exercise for the rear deltoids. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps, at least 8-12 reps per set, as part of an upper-body or shoulder-focused workout.
HowTo: 1. Stand between two cable machines and grasp the cables with your hands crossed. 2. Pull the cables outward and back, squeezing your shoulder blades together.

Title: One-Arm Cable Side Raise - Gethin Variation
Desc: The single-arm cable lateral raise is an isolation exercise targeting the shoulders, specifically the medial deltoid. This movement also hits the traps and upper back, and allows you to focus on each side independently. Because grip is a limitation, it is usually performed for moderate to high reps, like at least 8-12 reps per set, as part of an upper body or shoulders-focused workout.
HowTo: 1. Stand with a cable in one hand at your side. 2. Raise the cable out to the side, keeping your arm straight until it reaches shoulder height.

Title: Rope Face Pull - Gethin Variation
Desc: The standing face pull is an isolation exercise primarily targeting the rear deltoids, traps, and upper back. It is most often performed with a rope attachment.
HowTo: 1. Stand facing a cable machine with the rope attachment at upper chest height. 2. Pull the rope towards your face, keeping your elbows high and squeezing your shoulder blades together.

Title: Lying cable lateral raise
Desc: The lying cable lateral raise is an isolation exercise that targets the medial or middle deltoid muscle of the shoulders. It is most common in muscle-building shoulder or upper-body workouts, usually in higher rep ranges of at least 8-12 reps per set.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your side on a bench or the ground with a cable in the top hand. 2. Raise the cable straight up to shoulder height, keeping your elbow slightly bent.

Title: Cable seated row
Desc: The cable seated row is a popular exercise to train the muscles of the upper back, including the lats (latissimus dorsi), traps, rhomboids, and rear deltoids, using a cable stack. It also targets the biceps to a lesser degree. The cable row can work well in a variety of rep ranges but is most popular in muscle-building workouts or as an accessory movement for strength workouts.
Muscles: latissimus dorsi, traps, rhomboids, rear deltoids, biceps
HowTo: 1. Sit at a cable row machine with your feet on the platform. 2. Grab the handle with both hands, keeping your back straight. 3. Pull the handle towards your torso while squeezing your shoulder blades together. 4. Slowly return to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Single-arm cable lateral raise
Desc: The single-arm cable lateral raise is an isolation exercise targeting the shoulders, specifically the medial deltoid. This movement also hits the traps and upper back and allows you to focus on each side independently. Because grip is a limitation, it is usually performed for moderate to high reps, at least 8-12 reps per set, as part of an upper-body or shoulder-focused workout.
HowTo: 1. Stand next to a cable machine with the pulley set at the lowest position. 2. Grab the handle with one hand and stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. 3. Raise your arm to the side until it is parallel to the ground, keeping a slight bend in your elbow. 4. Lower it back down slowly and repeat.

Title: UP Cable Face Pull
Desc: The standing face pull is an isolation exercise primarily targeting the rear deltoids, traps, and upper back. It is most often performed with a rope attachment.
HowTo: 1. Stand facing a cable machine with the pulley at upper chest height. 2. Grab the rope attachment with both hands and step back to create tension. 3. Pull the rope towards your face, keeping your elbows high and squeezing your shoulder blades together. 4. Slowly return to the starting position and repeat.

Title: AA Cable Leaning Side Raise
Desc: The AA Cable Leaning Side Raise is an exercise targeting the shoulders. It focuses on the medial deltoid while also engaging the traps.
HowTo: 1. Stand next to a cable machine and grab the handle with the hand farthest from the machine. 2. Lean away from the machine to create tension in the cable. 3. Raise your arm to the side until it is parallel to the ground. 4. Lower it back down slowly and repeat.

Title: 30 Shoulders Bent-Over Low Cable Reverse Fly
Desc: The 30 Shoulders Bent-Over Low Cable Reverse Fly is an exercise that targets the rear deltoids. It also engages the traps for upper back development.
HowTo: 1. Stand facing a low cable machine and grab the handles with both hands. 2. Bend at the hips and keep your back straight. 3. Pull the cables out to the side, squeezing your shoulder blades together. 4. Slowly return to the starting position and repeat.

Title: 30 Shoulders Cable Rope Face Pull
Desc: The cable rope face pull is an excellent exercise for targeting the rear deltoids and upper back. It helps improve shoulder stability and posture.
HowTo: 1. Attach a rope handle to a cable pulley at upper chest height. 2. Stand facing the cable machine and grasp the rope with both hands, palms facing each other. 3. Step back to create tension in the cable. 4. Pull the rope towards your face, keeping your elbows high and squeezing your shoulder blades together. 5. Slowly return to the starting position and repeat.

Title: 30 Shoulders Cable Straight-Bar Front Raise
Desc: The straight-bar front raise primarily targets the anterior deltoids. It is a great exercise for building shoulder strength and size.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and hold a straight barbell in front of your thighs with an overhand grip. 2. Keeping your arms straight, raise the barbell in front of you to shoulder height. 3. Pause at the top, then slowly lower the barbell back to the starting position.

Title: 30 Shoulders Cable Straight-Bar Upright Row
Desc: The upright row is a compound exercise that targets the shoulders and upper back. It helps to develop strength and muscle mass in the deltoids.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and hold a straight barbell with an overhand grip, arms extended in front of you. 2. Pull the barbell straight up towards your chin, keeping it close to your body. 3. Raise your elbows to shoulder height, then lower the barbell back to the starting position.

Title: 30 Shoulders High Cable Reverse Fly
Desc: The high cable reverse fly is an effective exercise for targeting the rear deltoids and upper back. It promotes shoulder stability and helps improve posture.
HowTo: 1. Set the pulleys on a cable machine to the highest setting. 2. Stand in the center, grasping the handles with your arms extended in front of you. 3. With a slight bend in your elbows, pull the handles out to the sides until your arms are parallel to the ground. 4. Squeeze your shoulder blades together at the top, then return to the starting position.

Title: 30 Shoulders Single-Arm Bent-Over Cable Reverse Fly
Desc: The single-arm bent-over cable reverse fly targets the rear deltoids and upper back muscles. It is a great exercise for improving shoulder strength and stability.
HowTo: 1. Attach a handle to a low pulley on a cable machine. 2. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding the handle in one hand. 3. Bend at the hips and keep your back flat, letting your arm hang straight down. 4. Raise your arm out to the side, keeping a slight bend in your elbow, until it is parallel to the ground. 5. Lower back to the starting position and repeat.

Title: 30 Shoulders Single-Arm Cable Front Raise
Desc: The 30 Shoulders Single-Arm Cable Front Raise is an isolation exercise that targets the front deltoid muscle. It helps in building shoulder strength and stability.
HowTo: 1. Attach a cable to a low pulley. 2. Stand facing away from the machine and grasp the handle with one hand. 3. Raise the handle in front of you to shoulder height while keeping your arm straight. 4. Lower the handle back to the starting position and repeat.

Title: 30 Shoulders Single-Arm Leaning Cable Lateral Raise
Desc: The 30 Shoulders Single-Arm Leaning Cable Lateral Raise targets the lateral deltoid muscles for shoulder development. This exercise enhances shoulder width and stability.
HowTo: 1. Set the cable at the lowest position and stand to the side of the machine. 2. Grasp the handle with the hand furthest from the machine. 3. Lean away from the machine and raise the handle laterally to shoulder height. 4. Slowly lower the handle back to the starting position.

Title: RG 3-Way Single-Arm Rear Delt Cable Fly
Desc: The RG 3-Way Single-Arm Rear Delt Cable Fly is designed to target the rear deltoids and upper back muscles. It improves shoulder stability and posture.
HowTo: 1. Attach a cable to a high pulley and stand facing the machine. 2. Grasp the handle with one hand and pull it back in a fly motion. 3. Perform the movement in three directions: straight back, diagonal up, and diagonal down. 4. Return to the starting position after each rep.

Title: RG Single-Arm Cross-Body Cable Front Raise
Desc: The RG Single-Arm Cross-Body Cable Front Raise targets the front deltoid while also engaging the core for stability. It is effective for shoulder strength and coordination.
HowTo: 1. Attach a cable to a low pulley and stand sideways to the machine. 2. Grasp the handle with the hand closest to the machine. 3. Raise the handle across your body to shoulder height. 4. Lower the handle back to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Smith machine shoulder press
Desc: The Smith machine shoulder press is a machine-based exercise targeting the deltoid muscles. The Smith machine mimics a barbell but provides more stability. This movement can be programmed in low reps for strength or higher reps for muscle and strength endurance. It is often performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of a shoulder or upper-body focused workout.
HowTo: 1. Set the Smith machine bar at shoulder height. 2. Sit on the bench with your back against the support. 3. Grasp the bar with an overhand grip slightly wider than shoulder-width. 4. Press the bar overhead until your arms are fully extended, then lower it back to shoulder height.

Title: Machine shoulder press
Desc: The machine shoulder press is a machine-based exercise targeting the deltoid muscles. It approximates the motion of a free-weight shoulder press, but uses a selectorized weight-stack or plate-loaded machine. Many such machines also allow you to choose between different grips and grip widths. Machine shoulder presses are often done for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of the upper-body or shoulder-focused portion of a workout.
HowTo: 1. Adjust the seat height so that the handles are at shoulder level. 2. Sit down and grasp the handles with an overhand grip. 3. Press the handles upward until your arms are fully extended. 4. Slowly lower the handles back to the starting position.

Title: Reverse Machine Flyes
Desc: The machine rear delt fly is an exercise targeting the rear head of the shoulder muscle or deltoids, as well as the muscles of the upper back. It's sort of the reverse of the machine chest fly, and is sometimes performed on the same machine, but facing the opposite direction. Because it targets such small muscles, this exercise is usually performed with light weight for high reps, such as 10-15 reps per set or more.
HowTo: 1. Adjust the seat height and grip handles. 2. Sit facing the machine with your chest against the pad. 3. Grasp the handles and pull them outward, squeezing your shoulder blades together. 4. Slowly return to the starting position.

Title: Single-arm Smith machine upright row
Desc: The single-arm Smith machine upright row is an upper-body exercise targeting the muscles of the traps and shoulders. This movement is often performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of an upper-body or shoulder-focused workout.
HowTo: 1. Set the Smith machine bar to a low position. 2. Stand next to the bar and grasp it with one hand. 3. Pull the bar up towards your chin, keeping your elbow higher than your wrist. 4. Lower the bar back to the starting position.

Title: Machine Lateral Raise
Desc: The machine lateral raise is an exercise that targets the lateral deltoids. It is performed on a machine designed to isolate the shoulder muscles.
HowTo: 1. Adjust the seat height and arm pads. 2. Sit down and grasp the handles with your arms at your sides. 3. Raise the handles out to the side until your arms are parallel to the ground. 4. Slowly lower the handles back to the starting position.

Title: Smith machine behind-the-neck press
Desc: The Smith machine behind-the-neck press is a machine-based exercise targeting the deltoids. The Smith machine mimics a barbell but provides more stability. This movement can be programmed in low reps for strength or higher reps for muscle and strength endurance. It is often performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of a shoulder or upper-body focused workout.
HowTo: 1. Set the Smith machine bar to shoulder height. 2. Stand with your back to the bar and grasp it with an overhand grip. 3. Press the bar upward until your arms are fully extended. 4. Lower the bar back to the starting position behind your neck.

Title: Smith Machine Behind-The-Neck Press - Gethin Variation
Desc: The Smith machine behind-the-neck press is a machine-based exercise targeting the deltoids. The Smith machine mimics a barbell but provides more stability. This movement can be programmed in low reps for strength or higher reps for muscle and strength endurance. It is often performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of a shoulder or upper-body focused workout.
HowTo: 1. Set the Smith machine bar at shoulder height. 2. Sit on the bench with your back straight and feet flat on the ground. 3. Grip the bar with a wide grip and lower it behind your neck. 4. Press the bar back up to the starting position.

Title: 30 Shoulders Leg Press Shoulder Press
Desc: The 30 Shoulders Leg Press Shoulder Press is a compound exercise that combines leg and shoulder movements. It effectively targets the shoulder muscles while engaging the legs.
HowTo: 1. Sit on the leg press machine with your back against the pad. 2. Place your feet on the platform shoulder-width apart. 3. Grip the handles and press the platform away while simultaneously pressing the weights overhead. 4. Return to the starting position.

Title: 30 Shoulders Machine Shoulder Press
Desc: The 30 Shoulders Machine Shoulder Press is designed to isolate and strengthen the shoulder muscles. It allows for controlled movement and stability.
HowTo: 1. Adjust the seat height so that the handles are at shoulder level. 2. Sit down and grip the handles. 3. Press the handles upward until your arms are fully extended. 4. Lower the handles back to shoulder level.

Title: 30 Shoulders Pec-Deck Reverse Fly
Desc: The 30 Shoulders Pec-Deck Reverse Fly targets the rear deltoids and upper back. It is an effective exercise for improving shoulder stability and posture.
HowTo: 1. Sit on the Pec-Deck machine facing the pads. 2. Adjust the seat height so that your arms are at shoulder level. 3. Grip the handles and pull them back in a reverse fly motion. 4. Return to the starting position.

Title: 30 Shoulders Smith Machine Behind-The-Head Press
Desc: The 30 Shoulders Smith Machine Behind-The-Head Press is a variation that targets the shoulders effectively. It allows for a controlled range of motion.
HowTo: 1. Set the Smith machine bar at shoulder height. 2. Sit on a bench with your back straight. 3. Grip the bar with a wide grip and lower it behind your head. 4. Press the bar back up to the starting position.

Title: 30 Shoulders Smith Machine Shoulder Press
Desc: The Smith Machine Shoulder Press is a strength training exercise that primarily targets the shoulders. It can also engage the triceps and upper chest during the pressing movement.
HowTo: 1. Set the Smith machine bar at shoulder height. 2. Stand under the bar and grasp it with an overhand grip. 3. Lift the bar off the rack and press it overhead until your arms are fully extended. 4. Lower the bar back to shoulder height and repeat.

Title: Handstand push-up
Desc: The handstand push-up is an exercise targeting the shoulders, although other muscles assist in the completion of the reps. It is common in both CrossFit workouts and advanced bodyweight or calisthenics training. Given the degree of difficulty, beginners will need to progress to this move.
HowTo: 1. Kick up into a handstand against a wall for support. 2. Lower your body by bending your elbows until your head nearly touches the ground. 3. Push back up to the starting position.

Title: Upward Stretch
Desc: The Upward Stretch is a mobility exercise that helps improve flexibility and range of motion in the shoulders. It can be beneficial for warming up before workouts or for recovery.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. 2. Raise your arms overhead and stretch upwards while keeping your shoulders relaxed. 3. Hold the stretch for a few seconds, then release.

Title: Shoulder Circles
Desc: Shoulder Circles are a simple mobility exercise that helps to warm up the shoulder joints and improve flexibility. They can be performed as part of a dynamic warm-up routine.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and arms at your sides. 2. Raise your arms out to the sides and make small circles in the air. 3. Gradually increase the size of the circles, then reverse the direction.

Title: Cross-body shoulder stretch
Desc: The cross-body shoulder stretch targets increased flexibility in the shoulders. It is a common inclusion in upper-body dynamic warm-ups prior to training or sports, but can also be performed anytime to "limber up" the upper body.
HowTo: 1. Stand or sit comfortably. 2. Bring one arm across your body at shoulder height. 3. Use your opposite hand to gently pull the arm closer to your chest. 4. Hold the stretch for 15-30 seconds, then switch arms.

Title: Arm circle
Desc: The arm circle is a non-weighted exercise targeting the shoulders. It involves extending your arms to the sides and drawing small circles in the air with your hands. It is common in warm-ups for both training and athletics, and is often performed simply until someone feels a burn, rather than for a set amount of reps.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. 2. Extend your arms out to the sides at shoulder height. 3. Draw small circles in the air with your hands, gradually increasing the size of the circles.

Title: Seated Front Deltoid
Desc: The Seated Front Deltoid exercise primarily targets the shoulder muscles. It is performed while seated to isolate the deltoids effectively.
HowTo: 1. Sit on a bench with back support. 2. Hold a dumbbell in each hand at shoulder height. 3. Press the weights upward until your arms are fully extended, then lower them back to the starting position.

Title: Shoulder Raise
Desc: The Shoulder Raise is an exercise that targets the shoulder muscles. It can be performed with dumbbells or resistance bands.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a dumbbell in each hand at your sides. 2. Raise your arms out to the sides until they are parallel to the ground, then lower them back down.

Title: Hand Stand Push-Up
Desc: The handstand push-up is an exercise targeting the shoulders, although other muscles assist in the completion of the reps. It is common in both CrossFit workouts and advanced bodyweight or calisthenics training. Given the degree of difficulty, beginners will want to progress to this move.
HowTo: 1. Kick up into a handstand against a wall. 2. Lower your body by bending your elbows until your head nearly touches the ground. 3. Push back up to the starting position.

Title: Wall walk
Desc: The wall walk is a challenging exercise that works the entire body. From a push-up position, the hands walk back as the feet walk up the wall, then the whole movement is reversed. This is not for beginners, who will need to progress to this exercise.
HowTo: 1. Start in a push-up position with your feet against a wall. 2. Walk your hands back towards the wall while simultaneously walking your feet up the wall. 3. Reverse the movement to return to the starting position.

Title: Return Push from Stance
Desc: The Return Push from Stance is a shoulder-focused exercise that helps build strength and stability. It can be performed as part of a strength training routine.
HowTo: 1. Start in a standing position with feet shoulder-width apart. 2. Bend your knees slightly and hinge at the hips to lower your torso. 3. Push through your hands to return to a standing position while engaging your shoulders.

Title: Wall shoulder tap
Desc: The wall shoulder tap is a bodyweight shoulder exercise that is a popular movement for gymnasts, cheerleaders, and other athletes who need to spend a lot of time in dynamic handstand movements. Beginning in a handstand position with toes touching the wall, one hand is raised to touch the opposing shoulder. This continues in alternating fashion for the duration of the set.
HowTo: 1. Begin in a handstand position with your toes touching the wall. 2. Raise one hand to touch the opposite shoulder, then alternate hands for the duration of the set.

Title: Bear crawl shoulder tap
Desc: The bear crawl shoulder tap is a variation of the bear crawl that involves touching the opposing shoulder while in a static bear crawl hold. It adds an extra coordination and core challenge to an already intense full-body movement that targets the cardiovascular system as well as a wide range of muscle groups. It can be done as a full-body warm-up, or as part of a bodyweight circuit or flow.
HowTo: 1. Start in a bear crawl position with your hands under your shoulders and knees under your hips. 2. Lift one hand to tap the opposite shoulder while maintaining a stable core, then alternate sides.

Title: Shadow boxing
Desc: Shadow boxing is an exercise typically used in combat sports and fighting. However, it can also make a great cardio session for anyone to implement in a fast-paced circuit or as active rest. It is usually performed for time or rounds.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and fists up. 2. Throw punches in the air while moving around, incorporating footwork and head movement.

Title: Bear crawl fire feet
Desc: Bear crawl fire feet is a variation of the bear crawl that involves running in place while in a static bear crawl hold. It adds an extra coordination and full-body challenge to an already intense full-body movement that targets the cardiovascular system as well as a wide range of muscle groups. It can be done as a full-body warm-up, or as part of a bodyweight circuit or flow.
HowTo: 1. Start in a bear crawl position with your hands and feet on the ground. 2. While holding the position, run in place by alternating your knees towards your chest.

Title: Wall sprawl
Desc: The wall sprawl is a bodyweight exercise targeting the shoulders, although numerous other muscles are recruited to complete the exercise. From an all-fours position, you kick up onto the wall, then back down. It's a serious cardiovascular challenge that is usually performed as part of a fat-loss or athleticism-focused workout.
HowTo: 1. Start in an all-fours position. 2. Kick your feet up onto the wall while pushing your body forward. 3. Return to the starting position by kicking your feet back down.

Title: Bent Over Shoulder Y
Desc: The lying rear delt Y works the shoulders, specifically the rear heads. The range of motion differs from the lying rear delt fly. At the midpoint, the arms and torso form a Yhence the name.
HowTo: 1. Lie face down on a bench with your arms hanging down. 2. Raise your arms to form a Y shape while keeping your elbows slightly bent. 3. Lower back to the starting position.

Title: Shoulder L
Desc: The bent-over shoulder rotation is an upper-body exercise that helps strengthen the muscles around the rotator cuff for a stable shoulder joint. It is usually performed as part of a dynamic warm-up for the shoulders. It can be performed with body weight, light dumbbells or weight plates, or bands.
HowTo: 1. Stand bent over with a slight bend in your knees, holding light weights or bands. 2. Rotate your arms outward while keeping your elbows close to your body. 3. Return to the starting position.

Title: Shoulder Dislocation Stretch-Dowel
Desc: The Shoulder Dislocation Stretch-Dowel is an effective mobility exercise for improving shoulder flexibility. It helps to increase the range of motion in the shoulder joint.
HowTo: 1. Hold a dowel or stick with a wide grip in front of you. 2. Raise the dowel overhead and behind your back while keeping your arms straight. 3. Return to the starting position.

Title: TBS Inverted Row
Desc: The Smith machine inverted row is a bodyweight exercise targeting the muscles of the lats (latissimus dorsi) and upper back, using the bar of the Smith machine to hang and pull from. You can change the bar height to customize the difficulty level and desired angle of the row. This variation is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more.
HowTo: 1. Set the bar of the Smith machine at waist height. 2. Hang from the bar with an overhand grip, feet on the ground or elevated. 3. Pull your chest towards the bar, then lower back down.

Title: PVC Shoulder Stretch
Desc: The PVC Shoulder Stretch is designed to improve shoulder mobility and flexibility. It helps to open up the shoulder joint and stretch the surrounding muscles.
HowTo: 1. Hold a PVC pipe or a similar object with both hands, wider than shoulder-width apart. 2. Raise the pipe overhead and gently pull it back behind your head, keeping your arms straight, until you feel a stretch in your shoulders.

Title: Shoulder T
Desc: The bent-over plate rear delt raise is an exercise targeting the rear heads of the shoulders, aka deltoids. You can also use dumbbells or other light weights for a similar effect. This movement is usually performed as part of a dynamic warm-up, or as a high-rep burnout movement on a shoulder or back day.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a plate or dumbbells. 2. Bend forward at the hips, keeping your back straight, and raise the weights out to the sides to form a 'T' shape with your arms. 3. Lower the weights back down and repeat.

Title: HM Arm Circle
Desc: The HM Arm Circle is a dynamic stretching exercise that enhances shoulder mobility. It helps to warm up the shoulder joints and improve range of motion.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and extend your arms out to the sides at shoulder height. 2. Make small circles with your arms, gradually increasing the size of the circles, then reverse the direction after a set time.

Title: HM Shoulder Stretch
Desc: The HM Shoulder Stretch is aimed at increasing flexibility in the shoulder region. It helps relieve tension and improve overall shoulder health.
HowTo: 1. Stand or sit comfortably and reach one arm across your body. 2. Use the opposite arm to gently pull the extended arm closer to your chest, feeling a stretch in the shoulder.

Title: HM Shoulder Stretch on Floor
Desc: The HM Shoulder Stretch on Floor is a variation that focuses on shoulder flexibility while lying down. It is particularly useful for those with limited mobility.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back with your arms extended out to the sides. 2. Slowly lower one arm towards the floor while keeping the other arm extended, feeling a stretch across your chest and shoulder.

Title: HM Shoulder Tap
Desc: The HM Shoulder Tap is a mobility exercise that helps improve shoulder stability and flexibility. It involves tapping your shoulder while maintaining a plank position.
HowTo: 1. Start in a plank position with your hands directly under your shoulders. 2. Keeping your core tight, lift one hand to tap the opposite shoulder. 3. Return to plank and repeat with the other hand.

Title: HM Hand-On-Wall Stretch
Desc: The HM Hand-On-Wall Stretch is a stretching exercise that targets the shoulders and chest. It helps improve flexibility and range of motion in the upper body.
HowTo: 1. Stand facing a wall and place your hand on it at shoulder height. 2. Slowly lean into the wall to stretch your shoulder and chest. 3. Hold the stretch for 15-30 seconds and switch sides.

Title: HM Jumping Arm Circle
Desc: The HM Jumping Arm Circle is a dynamic mobility exercise that warms up the shoulders. It combines jumping with arm circles to enhance shoulder mobility and coordination.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. 2. Jump while making large circles with your arms, first forward and then backward. 3. Repeat for 30 seconds.

Title: Kipping Clapping Pull-Up
Desc: The Kipping Clapping Pull-Up is an advanced strength exercise that combines a pull-up with a clap at the top. It builds upper body strength and explosive power.
HowTo: 1. Start from a hanging position on the pull-up bar. 2. Use a kipping motion to propel your body upward. 3. At the top of the pull-up, clap your hands before lowering back down.

Title: Holman Kneeling Overhead Press to Donkey Kick
Desc: The Holman Kneeling Overhead Press to Donkey Kick is a compound exercise that targets the shoulders and glutes. It combines an overhead press with a donkey kick for a full-body workout.
HowTo: 1. Start in a kneeling position with a weight in one hand. 2. Press the weight overhead while extending the opposite leg back into a donkey kick. 3. Return to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Floor angel
Desc: The floor angel is a stretch targeting shoulder mobility and activation of the shoulder stabilizer muscles. It also targets a range of postural muscles in the upper back.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back with your arms at a 90-degree angle. 2. Slowly slide your arms up and down while keeping your elbows and wrists in contact with the ground.

Title: Shoulder extension stretch
Desc: The shoulder extension stretch is focused on bringing more flexibility to the shoulder joint. It increases range of motion in shoulder extension, or moving the arms behind the back. It can be performed as part of a warm-up or mobility and flexibility work post-workout or anytime.
HowTo: 1. Stand or sit up straight. 2. Extend your arms behind you, keeping them straight, and hold the stretch for 15-30 seconds.

Title: Backward Medicine Ball Throw
Desc: The backward medicine ball throw is a dynamic exercise that enhances explosive power and coordination. It engages multiple muscle groups for a full-body workout.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a medicine ball. 2. Rotate your torso and throw the ball backward over your head, using your legs and core for power.

Title: Medicine ball scoop throw
Desc: The medicine ball scoop throw is an explosive exercise targeting the abdominals and hips. It can be performed for lower reps with a focus on power or for higher reps with a focus on fat loss and conditioning. It begins in a semi-squat position holding a medicine ball, which then gets "scooped" up and thrown overhead in one continuous movement.
HowTo: 1. Start in a semi-squat position holding a medicine ball. 2. Scoop the ball up and throw it overhead in one continuous movement.

Title: Standing Two-Arm Overhead Throw
Desc: The standing two-arm overhead throw is a powerful movement that develops upper body strength and coordination. It engages the core and legs for a full-body workout.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a medicine ball at chest level. 2. Use your legs and core to propel the ball overhead, extending your arms fully.

Title: Incline face-down bar front raise
Desc: The incline face-down bar front raise is an upper-body exercise targeting the shoulders. Because it is performed face down on an angled bench, it has a greater range of motion than standing or upright-seated raises and hits the shoulders from a different angle. Raise variations are usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of upper-body or shoulder-focused training.
HowTo: 1. Lie face down on an incline bench. 2. Hold a barbell with both hands, arms extended down. 3. Raise the barbell in front of you until your arms are parallel to the ground. 4. Lower the barbell back to the starting position.

Title: Incline anti-gravity shoulder press
Desc: The incline anti-gravity shoulder press is an upper-body exercise targeting the shoulders and upper back. It works the rear delts and upper-back muscles isometrically to hold the weight up, while dynamically training the lateral and front delts. Because of the challenge of holding the weight up, this press variation is usually performed with relatively light weights for moderate reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of upper-body or shoulder training.
HowTo: 1. Sit on an incline bench with a dumbbell in each hand. 2. Hold the dumbbells at shoulder height with palms facing forward. 3. Press the dumbbells overhead until your arms are fully extended. 4. Lower the dumbbells back to shoulder height.

Title: 30 Shoulders EZ-Bar Front Raise
Desc: The 30 Shoulders EZ-Bar Front Raise is an exercise that targets the shoulders, specifically the front deltoids. It involves raising an EZ-bar in front of the body to strengthen and develop shoulder muscles.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding an EZ-bar with both hands. 2. Keep your arms straight and raise the bar in front of you to shoulder height. 3. Lower the bar back to the starting position.

Title: Side Wrist Pull
Desc: The Side Wrist Pull is a mobility exercise that targets the forearms and improves wrist flexibility. It helps to stretch and strengthen the muscles in the forearm.
HowTo: 1. Extend one arm in front of you with your palm facing up. 2. Use the other hand to gently pull back on the fingers of the extended arm. 3. Hold the stretch for a few seconds and switch arms.

Title: Elbow Circles
Desc: Elbow Circles are a mobility exercise that helps improve shoulder and elbow joint flexibility. This exercise is beneficial for warming up the shoulder joints before more intense workouts.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your arms bent at 90 degrees. 2. Rotate your elbows in a circular motion, making small circles. 3. Perform circles in one direction for a set amount of time, then switch to the opposite direction.

Title: Kneeling Arm Drill
Desc: The Kneeling Arm Drill is a mobility exercise designed to enhance shoulder stability and flexibility. It involves dynamic movements that engage the shoulder joints and surrounding muscles.
HowTo: 1. Start in a kneeling position with your arms at your sides. 2. Raise one arm overhead while keeping the other arm at your side. 3. Alternate arms while maintaining a stable core and proper posture.

Title: Bent-over shoulder rotation
Desc: The bent-over shoulder rotation is an upper-body exercise that helps strengthen the muscles around the rotator cuff for a stable shoulder joint. It is usually performed as part of a dynamic warm-up for the shoulders. It can be performed with body weight, light dumbbells or weight plates, or bands.
HowTo: 1. Stand bent over at the waist with a slight bend in your knees. 2. Hold light dumbbells in each hand with your arms hanging down. 3. Rotate your arms outward, keeping your elbows bent at 90 degrees, then return to the starting position.

Title: Band overhead triceps press
Desc: The band overhead triceps press is a dynamic arm exercise utilizing a looped exercise band. It could also be performed with an exercise band with handles. It targets the triceps muscles and can be performed for time or reps, either in traditional muscle-building rep ranges such as 12-15 reps per set, or higher rep ranges such as 30, 50, or more.
