HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and hold the band overhead with both hands. 2. Lower the band behind your head by bending your elbows, then press back up to the starting position.

Title: Band overhead triceps extension
Desc: The band overhead triceps extension is a single-joint exercise focused on the triceps that uses the dynamic resistance of the band. The overhead position of the arms targets the long head of the triceps. Many lifters save this move for last in their triceps workout, performing it for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps or more per set.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and hold the band overhead with both hands. 2. Keeping your elbows close to your head, lower the band behind your neck and then extend your arms back to the starting position.

Title: Band straight-arm pull-down
Desc: The band straight-arm pull-down is a non-gym or at home variation of the straight-arm lat pull-down performed using a cable stack machine. It can either be performed in an athletic upright stance, or slightly bent over. It both stretches and contracts the muscles of the lats (latissimus dorsi) as well as providing additional activation to the other upper back muscles and the core. Because the triceps are also isometrically involved in the movement, it is usually performed for higher reps, such as 8-15 reps or more.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and hold the band with both hands above your head. 2. Keeping your arms straight, pull the band down towards your thighs while engaging your lats, then return to the starting position.

Title: Band skullcrusher
Desc: The band skullcrusher is a variation of the popular bench exercise targeting the triceps muscles. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps as part of an upper-body or arm-focused workout.
HowTo: 1. Lie on a decline bench with a barbell in hand, arms extended above your chest. 2. Lower the barbell to your forehead by bending your elbows, keeping your upper arms stationary. 3. Press the barbell back to the starting position by extending your elbows.

Title: Single-arm band kick-back
Desc: The single-arm band kick-back is an isolation exercise that targets the triceps. This is a common burnout move performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of an upper-body or arm-focused workout.
HowTo: 1. Lie flat on a bench with your feet planted on the ground. 2. Grip the barbell slightly wider than shoulder-width apart. 3. Lower the barbell to your chest, then press it back up to the starting position.

Title: Incline EZ-bar skullcrusher
Desc: The incline EZ-bar skullcrusher is a popular exercise targeting the triceps muscles. The incline angle helps to target the long head of the triceps in particular. This exercise is usually performed for moderate to high reps as part of an upper-body or arm-focused workout.
HowTo: 1. Anchor a resistance band overhead. 2. Grasp the band with both hands and extend your arms above your head. 3. Bend your elbows to lower your hands towards your forehead, then extend back to the starting position.

Title: Decline Close-Grip Bench To Skull Crusher
Desc: The single-arm band kick-back is an isolation exercise that targets the triceps. This is a common burnout move performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of an upper-body or arm-focused workout.
HowTo: 1. Anchor a resistance band at a low point. 2. Stand facing the anchor and grab the band with one hand. 3. Bend forward slightly and extend your arm straight back, squeezing the triceps at the top of the movement.

Title: Bench Press - Powerlifting
Desc: The incline EZ-bar skullcrusher is a popular exercise targeting the triceps muscles. The incline angle helps to target the long head of the triceps in particular.
HowTo: 1. Lie on an incline bench with an EZ-bar held above your chest. 2. Lower the bar towards your forehead by bending your elbows. 3. Extend your arms back to the starting position, focusing on squeezing the triceps.

Title: Behind-the-head skullcrusher
Desc: The behind-the-head skullcrusher is a variation on a triceps exercise that has been a staple of bodybuilders for decades. In this version, instead of the bar coming down lightly to the forehead, the bar tracks over the top of the head without touching it. Skullcrushers are usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of an upper-body or arm-focused workout. If a straight bar is uncomfortable for your wrists or elbows, try using an angled EZ-bar.
HowTo: 1. Lie on a bench with a barbell. 2. Hold the barbell with an overhand grip and lower it behind your head. 3. Extend your arms back to the starting position.

Title: Standing barbell overhead triceps extension
Desc: The standing barbell overhead triceps extension is an isolation movement targeting the triceps. The overhead position targets the long head of the triceps in particular. This movement is generally performed for moderate to high reps as part of the arms-focused portion of a workout. If holding a straight bar bothers the wrists or elbows, it can alternately be performed with an EZ-bar or neutral-grip bar.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and hold a barbell overhead. 2. Lower the barbell behind your head while keeping your elbows close to your ears. 3. Extend your arms back to the starting position.

Title: Reverse-grip bench press
Desc: The reverse-grip bench press is a popular barbell exercise targeting the chest, triceps, and forearms. The main difference between this exercise and the standard bench press is that the grip is underhand, not overhand. This helps target both the upper chest and the triceps. This lift can feel awkward at first, so go light and don't be afraid to use a spotter.
HowTo: 1. Lie on a bench and grasp the barbell with an underhand grip. 2. Lower the barbell to your chest. 3. Press the barbell back to the starting position.

Title: Bench Press with Chains
Desc: The Bench Press with Chains is a variation of the traditional bench press that incorporates chains for added resistance. This exercise helps improve strength and stability in the chest and triceps.
HowTo: 1. Set up a bench press station with a barbell and chains attached. 2. Lie on the bench and grip the barbell. 3. Lower the barbell to your chest and press it back up, allowing the chains to add resistance.

Title: Floor Press
Desc: The Floor Press is a strength exercise that targets the chest and triceps. It is performed lying on the floor, which limits the range of motion and emphasizes the lockout phase of the press.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back on the floor with a barbell or dumbbells in hand. 2. Press the weights up until your arms are fully extended. 3. Lower the weights back down until your elbows touch the floor.

Title: One Arm Floor Press
Desc: The One Arm Floor Press is a unilateral exercise that targets the chest and triceps. It helps improve strength and stability in the upper body.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back on the floor with one arm holding a dumbbell above your chest. 2. Lower the dumbbell to your chest while keeping your elbow close to your body. 3. Press the dumbbell back up to the starting position. 4. Repeat for the desired number of reps and switch arms.

Title: Pin Presses
Desc: Pin Presses are a great way to build shoulder strength and stability. This exercise focuses on the pressing movement from a fixed position.
HowTo: 1. Set a barbell on a squat rack at about chest height. 2. Lie under the bar and grip it with your hands slightly wider than shoulder-width. 3. Press the barbell straight up until your arms are fully extended. 4. Lower the bar back to the starting position and repeat.

Title: JM Press With Bands
Desc: The JM Press with Bands combines elements of a tricep extension and a bench press. It effectively targets the triceps while also engaging the shoulders.
HowTo: 1. Lie on a bench with a barbell and bands attached to the ends. 2. Start with the barbell above your chest, arms extended. 3. Lower the barbell towards your forehead while keeping your elbows tucked. 4. Press the bar back up to the starting position.

Title: JM Press
Desc: The JM Press is an effective exercise for targeting the triceps and improving overall pressing strength. It combines elements of a skull crusher and a bench press.
HowTo: 1. Lie on a bench with a barbell. 2. Grip the barbell with a close grip and start with it above your chest. 3. Lower the bar towards your forehead while keeping your elbows tucked in. 4. Press the bar back to the starting position.

Title: Floor Press with Chains
Desc: The Floor Press with Chains is a variation of the traditional floor press that adds accommodating resistance. It helps to develop strength in the chest and triceps.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back on the floor with a barbell and chains. 2. Hold the barbell above your chest with arms extended. 3. Lower the barbell to your chest while keeping your elbows close to your body. 4. Press the barbell back up to the starting position, allowing the chains to lift off the ground.

Title: Reverse Band Bench Press
Desc: The Reverse Band Bench Press is a variation of the traditional bench press that uses bands to reduce the weight at the bottom of the lift. This allows for a greater range of motion and can help improve strength and technique.
HowTo: 1. Set up a bench press station with bands attached to the barbell. 2. Lie back on the bench and grip the barbell with hands slightly wider than shoulder-width. 3. Unrack the bar and lower it to your chest while keeping your elbows at a 45-degree angle. 4. Press the bar back up to the starting position, engaging your chest and triceps.

Title: Decline Barbell Triceps Extension - Gethin Variation
Desc: The decline EZ-bar skullcrusher is an upper body isolation exercise targeting the triceps.
HowTo: 1. Lie on a decline bench and hold an EZ-bar with an overhand grip. 2. Extend your arms straight up above your chest. 3. Lower the bar towards your forehead by bending your elbows while keeping your upper arms stationary. 4. Extend your arms back to the starting position.

Title: AM Skullcrusher
Desc: The EZ-bar skullcrusher is a popular exercise targeting the triceps muscles. The EZ-bar is used more often than a straight bar. As for the name, thats worst-case scenario. The bar should actually come down behind the head. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps as part of an upper body or arms-focused workout. No need to chase a 1RM on this move!
HowTo: 1. Lie on a flat bench with an EZ-bar held above your chest. 2. Bend your elbows to lower the bar behind your head. 3. Keep your upper arms stationary and focus on using your triceps to lift the bar back to the starting position.

Title: 30 Arms Close-Grip Bench Press
Desc: The 30 Arms Close-Grip Bench Press is a variation that emphasizes the triceps while also engaging the chest muscles. It is performed with a narrower grip to target the triceps more effectively.
HowTo: 1. Lie on a flat bench and grip the barbell with your hands close together. 2. Lower the bar to your chest while keeping your elbows close to your body. 3. Press the bar back up to the starting position, focusing on using your triceps.

Title: 30 Arms Barbell Skullcrusher
Desc: The 30 Arms Barbell Skullcrusher is an effective exercise for isolating the triceps. It is performed with a barbell and focuses on the extension of the arms.
HowTo: 1. Lie on a flat bench with a barbell held above your chest. 2. Bend your elbows to lower the bar towards your forehead. 3. Extend your arms back to the starting position, ensuring your elbows remain stationary.

Title: FYR2 Sprawl Over Kettlebell
Desc: The FYR2 Sprawl Over Kettlebell is a dynamic exercise that combines elements of strength and mobility. It engages multiple muscle groups while improving overall coordination and stability.
HowTo: 1. Start in a standing position holding a kettlebell. 2. Drop into a squat position while placing the kettlebell on the ground. 3. Kick your legs back into a plank position. 4. Perform a sprawl by bringing your legs back to the squat position. 5. Stand up and repeat.

Title: Dumbbell floor press
Desc: The dumbbell floor press is a multijoint pressing exercise performed lying on the floor. It can be performed either with the knees bent or flat. The floor press limits the range of motion you would achieve with a regular dumbbell bench press, but still targets the chest, triceps, and anterior delts. This allows you to press more weight than in a dumbbell bench press, and perhaps put less stress on the shoulders.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back on the floor with a dumbbell in each hand. 2. Press the dumbbells up above your chest with your arms extended. 3. Lower the dumbbells until your elbows touch the floor. 4. Press the dumbbells back up to the starting position.

Title: Seated triceps press
Desc: The seated triceps press is a popular arm-building exercise that targets the triceps with a single dumbbell held by both hands, extending it up behind your head. While you can go surprisingly heavy on this movement, it is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of the upper-body or arm-focused portion of a workout. If you're going heavy, having someone help get the weight into position is a good idea.
HowTo: 1. Sit on a bench with a dumbbell held by both hands. 2. Raise the dumbbell above your head with arms extended. 3. Lower the dumbbell behind your head by bending your elbows. 4. Extend your arms back to the starting position.

Title: Tricep Dumbbell Kickback
Desc: The single-arm triceps kick-back is an isolation move from a bent-over position used to increase size and strength of the triceps.
HowTo: 1. Bend over at the waist while holding a dumbbell in one hand. 2. Keep your upper arm close to your body and extend your elbow to lift the dumbbell back. 3. Lower the dumbbell back to the starting position. 4. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions before switching arms.

Title: Standing Dumbbell Triceps Extension
Desc: The standing dumbbell triceps extension is an effective exercise for targeting the triceps. It involves lifting a dumbbell overhead and lowering it behind your head.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and hold a dumbbell with both hands above your head. 2. Keeping your elbows close to your ears, lower the dumbbell behind your head. 3. Extend your arms back to the starting position. 4. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Double-arm triceps kick-back
Desc: The double-arm triceps kick-back is a popular movement to increase size and strength of the triceps. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps, at least 8-12 reps, as part of an upper-body or arm-focused workout.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a dumbbell in each hand. 2. Bend your knees slightly and lean forward at the hips, keeping your back straight. 3. With your elbows bent at 90 degrees, extend your arms back until they are straight, squeezing your triceps at the top. 4. Return to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Single-arm dumbbell triceps extension
Desc: The single-arm dumbbell triceps extension is a popular exercise targeting the triceps one side at a time. It targets all three heads of the triceps, but when performed with the arm overhead, it can be especially effective at building the long head of the triceps. This exercise is usually performed for moderate to high reps, at least 8-12 reps per set, as part of the upper-body or arm-focused portion of a workout.
HowTo: 1. Stand or sit with a dumbbell in one hand. 2. Raise the dumbbell overhead, fully extending your arm. 3. Lower the dumbbell behind your head by bending your elbow, keeping your upper arm stationary. 4. Extend your arm back to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Decline Dumbbell Triceps Extension
Desc: The decline dumbbell triceps extension is an effective exercise for targeting the triceps while in a decline position. This position emphasizes the long head of the triceps, providing a unique angle for muscle growth.
HowTo: 1. Lie on a decline bench with a dumbbell in each hand. 2. Extend your arms straight above your chest. 3. Lower the dumbbells behind your head by bending your elbows, keeping your upper arms stationary. 4. Extend your arms back to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Dumbbell skullcrusher
Desc: The dumbbell skullcrusher is a triceps exercise that has been a staple of bodybuilders for decades. Skullcrushers are usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of an upper-body or arm-focused workout.
HowTo: 1. Lie on a flat bench with a dumbbell in each hand, arms extended above your chest. 2. Keeping your elbows close to your head, lower the dumbbells towards your forehead by bending your elbows. 3. Extend your arms back to the starting position and repeat.

Title: One Arm Pronated Dumbbell Triceps Extension
Desc: The One Arm Pronated Dumbbell Triceps Extension is an effective exercise for isolating the triceps. It allows for a greater range of motion and can help in building strength and size in the triceps.
HowTo: 1. Stand or sit with a dumbbell in one hand, palm facing down. 2. Raise the dumbbell overhead, fully extending your arm. 3. Lower the dumbbell behind your head by bending your elbow, keeping your upper arm stationary. 4. Extend your arm back to the starting position and repeat.

Title: One Arm Supinated Dumbbell Triceps Extension
Desc: The One Arm Supinated Dumbbell Triceps Extension is an effective exercise for isolating the triceps muscle. It helps to build strength and size in the arms.
HowTo: 1. Stand or sit with a dumbbell in one hand. 2. Extend your arm overhead, keeping your elbow close to your head. 3. Lower the dumbbell behind your head by bending your elbow. 4. Raise the dumbbell back to the starting position.

Title: Seated Bent-Over Two-Arm Dumbbell Triceps Extension
Desc: The Seated Bent-Over Two-Arm Dumbbell Triceps Extension targets the triceps muscles effectively. It is a great way to build strength in the arms.
HowTo: 1. Sit on a bench with a dumbbell in each hand. 2. Lean forward slightly, keeping your back straight. 3. Extend your arms overhead, then lower the dumbbells behind your head by bending your elbows. 4. Raise the dumbbells back to the starting position.

Title: Tate Press
Desc: The Tate Press is a unique exercise that targets the triceps. It helps in building strength and definition in the arms.
HowTo: 1. Lie on a bench with a dumbbell in each hand, arms extended above your chest. 2. Keep your elbows tucked in and lower the dumbbells towards your chest. 3. Press the dumbbells back up to the starting position.

Title: Standing Bent-Over One-Arm Dumbbell Triceps Extension
Desc: The single-arm triceps kick-back is an isolation move from a bent-over position used to increase size and strength of the triceps.
HowTo: 1. Stand with a dumbbell in one hand and bend forward at the hips. 2. Extend your arm back, keeping your elbow close to your body. 3. Lower the dumbbell towards the floor by bending your elbow. 4. Raise the dumbbell back to the starting position.

Title: Seated Bent-Over One-Arm Dumbbell Triceps Extension
Desc: The Seated Bent-Over One-Arm Dumbbell Triceps Extension is an excellent exercise for isolating the triceps. It is effective for building strength in the arms.
HowTo: 1. Sit on a bench with a dumbbell in one hand. 2. Lean forward slightly, keeping your back straight. 3. Extend your arm overhead, then lower the dumbbell behind your head by bending your elbow. 4. Raise the dumbbell back to the starting position.

Title: Dumbbell Tricep Extension -Pronated Grip
Desc: The Dumbbell Tricep Extension is an effective exercise for targeting the triceps muscles. It can be performed with various grips to emphasize different parts of the triceps.
HowTo: 1. Stand or sit with a dumbbell in both hands, arms extended overhead. 2. Lower the dumbbell behind your head by bending your elbows. 3. Extend your arms back to the starting position.

Title: V-sit with overhead triceps extension
Desc: The V-sit with overhead triceps extension is a hybrid movement that trains the abdominal and triceps muscles simultaneously. It can address multiple muscle groups in a time-efficient muscle-building or circuit-style workout, while also providing a cardiovascular challenge.
HowTo: 1. Sit on the floor with your legs extended and lean back slightly. 2. Hold a dumbbell overhead with both hands. 3. Perform a triceps extension while maintaining the V-sit position.

Title: PJR Pull-Over
Desc: The PJR Pull-Over is a compound exercise that targets the chest and back muscles. It helps in developing upper body strength and flexibility.
HowTo: 1. Lie on a bench with your upper back supported and feet flat on the floor. 2. Hold a dumbbell with both hands above your chest. 3. Lower the dumbbell back over your head in a controlled manner, then pull it back to the starting position.

Title: Paul Carter Dumbbell Kick-Back
Desc: The single-arm triceps kick-back is an isolation move from a bent-over position used to increase size and strength of the triceps.
HowTo: 1. Bend forward at the hips with a dumbbell in one hand. 2. Keep your upper arm close to your body and extend your elbow to lift the dumbbell behind you. 3. Lower the dumbbell back to the starting position.

Title: Single-arm dumbbell skullcrusher
Desc: The single-arm dumbbell skullcrusher is a triceps exercise that has been a staple of bodybuilders for decades. Skullcrushers are usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of an upper-body or arms-focused workout.
HowTo: 1. Lie on a bench with a dumbbell in one hand, arm extended above your chest. 2. Lower the dumbbell towards your forehead by bending your elbow. 3. Extend your arm back to the starting position.

Title: Dumbbells-together incline bench press
Desc: The dumbbells-together incline bench press is an exercise targeting the pectoral muscles, particularly the upper pecs. Squeezing the dumbbells together forces the chest muscles to work hard during the entire press. This press variation is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of upper-body or chest-focused training.
HowTo: 1. Lie back on an incline bench with a dumbbell in each hand. 2. Press the dumbbells together above your chest, then lower them slowly to the sides before pressing back up.

Title: Incline dumbbell overhead triceps extension
Desc: The incline dumbbell overhead triceps extension is a popular exercise targeting the triceps muscles. The incline angle helps to target the long head of the triceps in particular. This exercise is usually performed for moderate to high reps as part of an upper-body or arm-focused workout.
HowTo: 1. Sit on an incline bench with a dumbbell in each hand. 2. Extend the dumbbells overhead, then lower them behind your head while keeping your elbows close to your ears.

Title: Dumbbell Crush Press
Desc: The Dumbbell Crush Press is an effective exercise for targeting the chest and triceps. It emphasizes the inner chest by squeezing the dumbbells together during the press.
HowTo: 1. Lie on a flat bench holding two dumbbells together above your chest. 2. Lower the dumbbells to your chest while squeezing them together, then press back up.

Title: Holman Hovering Renegade Triceps Press
Desc: The Holman Hovering Renegade Triceps Press is a challenging exercise that targets the triceps while engaging the core. It combines a plank position with a pressing motion to enhance stability and strength.
HowTo: 1. Start in a plank position with a dumbbell in each hand. 2. Lower one dumbbell towards your chest while stabilizing your body, then press it back up and alternate sides.

Title: Holman Heavy Triceps Press to Overhead Press
Desc: The Holman Heavy Triceps Press to Overhead Press is an effective compound exercise that targets the triceps and shoulders. It builds strength and stability in the upper body.
HowTo: 1. Start with dumbbells at shoulder height. 2. Press the dumbbells overhead, then lower them back to shoulder height, focusing on the triceps.

Title: Total Fitness Close-Grip Dumbbell Press
Desc: The close-grip dumbbell bench press puts a spin on a mainstay of workout enthusiasts worldwide. Its a classic move for building a bigger, stronger chest. The difference here is that the dumbbells are held closer together.
HowTo: 1. Lie on a bench with a dumbbell in each hand, palms facing each other. 2. Lower the dumbbells to your chest while keeping them close together, then press them back up to the starting position.

Title: Dumbbell row to triceps kick-back
Desc: The dumbbell row to triceps kick-back is a dumbbell complex that combines two movements that collectively target the muscles of the lats (latissimus dorsi), upper back, and triceps. It also isometrically targets the core, hamstrings, and glutes. It is usually performed one rep of each movement at a time, although you could perform more reps of each, or increase the reps in successive rounds (e.g., 1 rep in round 1, 2 reps in round 2, etc.). No matter how you structure the sets and reps, it is a time-efficient way to hit two crucial upper-body muscles in any workout.
HowTo: 1. Start in a bent-over position with a dumbbell in each hand. 2. Perform a row by pulling the dumbbells towards your torso, then extend your arms back for the triceps kick-back.

Title: Rolling triceps press
Desc: The rolling triceps press is a dynamic triceps exercise that is popular as a bench press accessory movement among powerlifters. It can be done in traditional muscle-building rep ranges, such as 8-12 reps per set, or for very high reps of 50-100 reps per set to boost triceps size and strength. It can be performed on a bench or on the floor if a bench is unavailable.
HowTo: 1. Lie on a bench with a dumbbell in each hand, arms extended above your chest. 2. Bend your elbows to lower the dumbbells towards your forehead, then press back up to the starting position.

Title: MetaBurn Skullcrusher to Ab Crunch
Desc: The MetaBurn Skullcrusher to Ab Crunch combines a triceps exercise with an abdominal movement for a full upper body workout.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back with a dumbbell in each hand, arms extended above your head. 2. Perform a skullcrusher by bending your elbows, then engage your core to perform an ab crunch.

Title: FYR2 Single-Dumbbell Triceps Extension
Desc: The FYR2 Single-Dumbbell Triceps Extension is an effective exercise for targeting the triceps muscles.
HowTo: 1. Stand or sit with a dumbbell held overhead with both hands. 2. Lower the dumbbell behind your head by bending your elbows, then extend back to the starting position.

Title: 30 Arms Overhead Dumbbell Triceps Extension
Desc: The 30 Arms Overhead Dumbbell Triceps Extension is an effective exercise for targeting the triceps. It helps in building strength and definition in the upper arms.
HowTo: 1. Stand or sit with a dumbbell held overhead with both hands. 2. Lower the dumbbell behind your head by bending your elbows. 3. Extend your arms back to the starting position.

Title: 30 Arms Dumbbell Skullcrusher
Desc: The 30 Arms Dumbbell Skullcrusher is a popular exercise for isolating the triceps. It is effective for building muscle mass and strength in the upper arms.
HowTo: 1. Lie on a bench with a dumbbell in each hand, arms extended above your chest. 2. Bend your elbows to lower the dumbbells towards your forehead. 3. Extend your arms back to the starting position.

Title: 30 Arms Dumbbell Kick-Back
Desc: The 30 Arms Dumbbell Kick-Back is an excellent exercise for targeting the triceps. It helps in developing strength and definition in the back of the arms.
HowTo: 1. Bend forward at the hips with a dumbbell in each hand, arms bent at 90 degrees. 2. Extend your arms back until they are straight. 3. Return to the starting position by bending your elbows.

Title: 30 Arms BFR Dumbbell Kick-Back
Desc: The 30 Arms BFR Dumbbell Kick-Back is a variation that utilizes blood flow restriction for enhanced muscle growth. It is effective for building strength and size in the triceps.
HowTo: 1. Secure a blood flow restriction band around your upper arms. 2. Bend forward with a dumbbell in each hand, arms bent at 90 degrees. 3. Extend your arms back until they are straight, then return to the starting position.

Title: Dumbbell saw triceps skullcrusher
Desc: The dumbbell saw triceps skullcrusher is a variation of the classic skullcrusher triceps exercise that has been a staple of bodybuilders for decades. It combines a dumbbell skullcrusher with a dumbbell shoulder press. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of an upper-body or arm-focused workout.
HowTo: 1. Lie on a bench with a dumbbell in each hand, arms extended above your chest. 2. Lower the dumbbells in a saw motion towards your forehead while keeping your elbows stationary. 3. Extend your arms back to the starting position.

Title: Chain Handle Extension
Desc: The Chain Handle Extension is a triceps exercise that focuses on building strength in the arms. It typically involves using a cable machine with chain handles to extend the arms downward.
HowTo: 1. Attach chain handles to a cable machine at a high position. 2. Stand facing the machine and grasp the handles with both hands. 3. Step back slightly and keep your elbows close to your body. 4. Extend your arms downward, squeezing your triceps at the bottom. 5. Slowly return to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Sled Overhead Triceps Extension
Desc: The Sled Overhead Triceps Extension is a triceps-focused exercise performed using a sled. It targets the triceps while also engaging the shoulders and core for stability.
HowTo: 1. Set up a sled with appropriate weight. 2. Stand behind the sled and grasp the handles overhead. 3. Keep your elbows close to your head and lower the sled behind your head. 4. Extend your arms back to the starting position, focusing on your triceps. 5. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Body Triceps Press Using Flat Bench
Desc: The bodyweight triceps press is an arm movement that involves performing overhead presses in a face-down position on a Smith machine or other raised bar. It is a surprisingly difficult movement that hammers all three heads of the triceps and can easily be scaled upward or downward in difficulty by moving the bar.
HowTo: 1. Lie face down on a flat bench with a barbell positioned above your head. 2. Grasp the barbell with a narrow grip. 3. Lower the barbell behind your head by bending your elbows. 4. Press the barbell back to the starting position, focusing on your triceps. 5. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Suspended Triceps Press
Desc: The Suspended Triceps Press is an advanced triceps exercise that utilizes suspension straps. It challenges stability and strength in the triceps and shoulders.
HowTo: 1. Adjust the suspension straps to a suitable height. 2. Grasp the handles and lean back, keeping your body straight. 3. Lower your body by bending your elbows, keeping them close to your sides. 4. Press back up to the starting position, engaging your triceps. 5. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Seated triceps push-down
Desc: The seated triceps push-down is a triceps exercise that is performed with a rope attachment. The seated position helps eliminate the use of momentum. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps as part of the arm-focused portion of a workout.
HowTo: 1. Sit at a cable machine with a rope attachment set at a high position. 2. Grasp the rope with both hands and pull it down to your chest. 3. Keep your elbows close to your body and extend your arms downwards. 4. Squeeze your triceps at the bottom, then return to the starting position. 5. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Machine triceps extension-
Desc: The machine triceps extension is a popular exercise to build size and strength in the triceps muscles. It approximates the motion of a free-weight skullcrusher, but uses a selectorized weight-stack or plate-loaded machine. Machine triceps extensions are often done for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of the upper-body or arm-focused portion of a workout.
HowTo: 1. Adjust the seat height so that the handles are at chest level. 2. Grasp the handles with both hands and keep your elbows close to your body. 3. Extend your arms downward until your elbows are fully extended. 4. Slowly return to the starting position.

Title: Holman Overhead Weighted Triceps Press
Desc: The Holman Overhead Weighted Triceps Press is an effective exercise for targeting the triceps. It involves pressing a weight overhead to engage the triceps fully.
HowTo: 1. Stand or sit with a weight held overhead. 2. Lower the weight behind your head while keeping your elbows close to your ears. 3. Press the weight back up to the starting position.

Title: 30 Arms Weighted Triceps Dip
Desc: The 30 Arms Weighted Triceps Dip is a challenging exercise that targets the triceps and can be performed using parallel bars. It emphasizes the triceps through a dipping motion.
HowTo: 1. Position yourself on parallel bars with your arms straight and legs hanging. 2. Lower your body by bending your elbows until your upper arms are parallel to the ground. 3. Push back up to the starting position.

Title: Cable V-bar push-down
Desc: The cable V-bar push-down is a popular gym exercise for targeting the triceps. It utilizes an angled bar, which can allow you to move heavier weights more comfortably than a straight bar or rope. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps or more per set, as part of an upper-body or arm-focused workout.
HowTo: 1. Stand facing a cable machine with a V-bar attached. 2. Grasp the V-bar with both hands and pull it down to your thighs. 3. Slowly return to the starting position while maintaining control.

Title: Reverse Grip Triceps Pushdown
Desc: The reverse-grip cable straight-bar push-down is a twist on the popular cable straight-bar push-down. The difference has to do with how the hands are positioned holding the bar: the palms facing up rather than down. Because grip will be a limiting factor, this movement is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or higher.
HowTo: 1. Stand facing a cable machine with a straight bar attached. 2. Grasp the bar with an underhand grip and pull it down to your thighs. 3. Slowly return to the starting position while keeping your elbows close to your body.

Title: Kneeling cable triceps extension
Desc: The kneeling cable triceps extension is a single-joint exercise meant to isolate the triceps muscles using a high pully on a cable stack and a bench. It can also be performed in a tall-kneeling stance from a low pully. It is most commonly used in muscle-building triceps or arm workouts.
HowTo: 1. Kneel in front of a cable machine with a high pulley. 2. Grasp the handle with both hands and pull it down to your forehead, keeping your elbows close to your head. 3. Extend your arms back to the starting position, focusing on squeezing the triceps.

Title: Single-arm cable triceps extension
Desc: The single-arm cable triceps extension is a single-joint isolation exercise for building the triceps. It involves driving a handle attached to a cable stack overhead to full extension. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of an upper-body or arm-focused workout.
HowTo: 1. Stand next to a cable machine with a low pulley. 2. Grasp the handle with one hand and pull it overhead. 3. Extend your arm fully, then lower it back to the starting position.

Title: Dip Machine
Desc: The dip machine is a machine exercise that mimics a triceps dip, a bodyweight exercise performed on parallel bars or on a pull-up and dip station. It targets the triceps first, but also stretches and strengthens the chest and shoulders. Dips with a triceps focus are usually performed with an upright torso, the knees bent and crossed, and the arms close to the body. Dips can be performed for low reps for strength or higher reps for muscle growth.
HowTo: 1. Sit on the dip machine with your back against the pad. 2. Grasp the handles and lower your body by bending your elbows. 3. Push back up to the starting position, focusing on using your triceps.

Title: Triceps Pushdown
Desc: The cable V-bar push-down is a popular gym exercise for targeting the triceps. It utilizes an angled bar, which can allow you to move heavier weights more comfortably than a straight bar or rope. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps or more per set, as part of an upper-body or arm-focused workout.
HowTo: 1. Stand in front of a cable machine with a V-bar attachment. 2. Grasp the bar with both hands and pull it down towards your thighs. 3. Extend your arms fully, then return to the starting position.

Title: Low cable overhead triceps extension
Desc: The low cable overhead triceps extension is a single-joint isolation exercise for building the triceps. It involves lying on a bench and then driving the rope handle to full extension. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of an upper-body or arm-focused workout.
HowTo: 1. Lie on a bench with a low cable pulley above your head. 2. Grasp the rope handle and pull it down towards your forehead. 3. Extend your arms back to the starting position, focusing on the triceps.

Title: Lying cable triceps extension
Desc: The lying cable triceps extension is an isolation exercise performed lying on either a bench or the floor. This movement is usually performed for moderate to high reps for a burn and pump as part of an arm-focused workout.
HowTo: 1. Lie on a bench or the floor with a cable pulley above your head. 2. Grasp the cable handle with both hands and lower it towards your forehead while keeping your elbows stationary. 3. Extend your arms back to the starting position.

Title: Low Cable Triceps Extension
Desc: The low cable triceps extension is an isolation exercise targeting the triceps. It is typically performed for moderate to high repetitions to build muscle endurance.
HowTo: 1. Stand facing a low cable pulley with a handle attached. 2. Grasp the handle with one hand and pull it down while keeping your elbow close to your body. 3. Extend your arm fully and then return to the starting position.

Title: Cable overhead triceps extension
Desc: The cable overhead triceps extension is a cable exercise performed in a seated position, targeting the triceps muscles. While it hits all three heads of the triceps, the overhead position helps to target the long head in particular. The seated position helps eliminate the use of momentum. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps as part of the arm-focused portion of a workout.
HowTo: 1. Sit on a bench with a cable pulley above your head. 2. Grasp the cable handle with both hands and lower it behind your head. 3. Extend your arms back to the starting position while keeping your elbows stationary.

Title: Single-arm low cable triceps extension
Desc: The single-arm low cable triceps extension is a single-joint isolation exercise for building the triceps. It involves driving a handle attached to a cable stack overhead to full extension. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of an upper-body or arm-focused workout.
HowTo: 1. Stand next to a low cable pulley with a handle attached. 2. Grasp the handle with one hand and pull it down while keeping your elbow close to your body. 3. Extend your arm fully and return to the starting position.

Title: Incline cable straight-bar triceps extension
Desc: The incline cable straight-bar triceps extension is a single-joint arm exercise performed on an incline bench. This incline position offers a great stretch and range of motion, potentially targeting the long head of the triceps more than some other triceps exercises. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps as part of the arm-focused portion of a workout.
HowTo: 1. Set an incline bench at a 30-45 degree angle and attach a straight bar to a low cable pulley. 2. Lie back on the bench and grasp the bar with both hands. 3. Lower the bar towards your forehead and then extend your arms back to the starting position.

Title: Paul Carter Overhead Rope Triceps Extension
Desc: The rope overhead triceps extension is a single-joint exercise focused on the triceps and using a cable stack with a rope handle. The overhead position targets the long head of the triceps in particular. Many lifters save this move for last in their triceps workout, performing it for moderate to high reps, like at least 8-12 reps or higher.
HowTo: 1. Attach a rope handle to a cable stack. 2. Stand facing away from the cable stack and grasp the rope with both hands. 3. Extend your arms overhead, keeping your elbows close to your head. 4. Slowly lower the rope behind your head by bending your elbows. 5. Extend your arms back to the starting position.

Title: TBS Rope Cable Push-Down
Desc: The cable rope push-down is a popular exercise targeting the triceps muscles. It's easy to learn and perform, making it a favorite for everyone from beginners to advanced lifters. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps or more per set, as part of an upper-body or arm-focused workout.
HowTo: 1. Attach a rope handle to a cable stack. 2. Stand facing the cable stack and grasp the rope with both hands. 3. Keep your elbows close to your body and push down the rope until your arms are fully extended. 4. Slowly return to the starting position.

Title: Single-arm cable triceps kick-back
Desc: The single-arm cable triceps kick-back is an isolation exercise that targets the triceps. This is a common burnout move performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of an upper-body or arm-focused workout.
HowTo: 1. Attach a single handle to a cable stack. 2. Stand beside the cable stack and grasp the handle with one hand. 3. Bend forward slightly and extend your arm back, keeping your elbow close to your body. 4. Slowly return to the starting position.

Title: Incline cable rope triceps extension
Desc: The incline cable rope triceps extension is a single-joint arm exercise performed on an incline bench. This incline position offers a great stretch and range of motion, potentially targeting the long head of the triceps more than some other triceps exercises. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps as part of the arm-focused portion of a workout.
HowTo: 1. Set an incline bench at a comfortable angle. 2. Attach a rope handle to a cable stack above the bench. 3. Lie back on the incline bench and grasp the rope with both hands. 4. Extend your arms overhead, then lower the rope behind your head. 5. Extend your arms back to the starting position.

Title: Reverse-grip cable straight-bar push-down
Desc: The reverse-grip cable straight-bar push-down is a twist on the popular cable straight-bar push-down. The difference has to do with how the hands are positioned holding the bar: the palms facing up rather than down. Because grip will be a limiting factor, this movement is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or higher.
HowTo: 1. Attach a straight bar to a cable stack. 2. Stand facing the cable stack and grasp the bar with an underhand grip. 3. Keep your elbows close to your body and push down the bar until your arms are fully extended. 4. Slowly return to the starting position.

Title: Kneeling Cable Triceps Extension - Gethin Variation
Desc: The kneeling cable triceps extension is an single-joint exercise meant to isolate the triceps muscles, using a high pully on a cable stack and a bench. It can also be performed in a tall-kneeling stance from a low pully. It is most commonly used in muscle-building triceps or overall arms workouts.
HowTo: 1. Kneel in front of a cable machine with a high pulley. 2. Grasp the cable attachment with both hands and extend your arms to push the cable down, isolating the triceps.

Title: Cable Overhead Triceps Extension - Gethin Variation
Desc: The overhead triceps extension is an isolation exercise that is performed with a cable. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps as part of the arm-focused portion of a workout.
HowTo: 1. Stand or sit with a cable machine set to a low pulley. 2. Grasp the cable attachment with both hands and extend your arms overhead, lowering the cable behind your head to target the triceps.

Title: Reverse-Grip Cable Triceps Pushdown - Gethin Variation
Desc: The reverse-grip cable straight-bar push-down is a twist on the popular cable straight-bar push-down. The difference has to do with how the hands are positioned holding the bar: the palms facing up rather than down. Because grip will be a limiting factor, this movement is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or higher.
HowTo: 1. Stand in front of a cable machine with a straight bar attachment at a high pulley. 2. Grip the bar with palms facing up and push it down while keeping your elbows close to your body.

Title: Cable Triceps Extension - Gethin Variation
Desc: The cable rope push-down is a popular exercise targeting the triceps muscles. It's easy to learn and perform, making it a favorite for everyone from beginners to advanced lifters. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps or more per set, as part of an upper-body or arm-focused workout.The cable rope push-down is a popular exercise targeting the triceps muscles. It's easy to learn and perform, making it a favorite for everyone from beginners to advanced lifters. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps or more per set, as part of an upper-body or arm-focused workout.
HowTo: 1. Stand in front of a cable machine with a rope attachment at a high pulley. 2. Grip the rope with both hands and push down, spreading the rope at the bottom to fully engage the triceps.

Title: Single-arm incline triceps extension
Desc: The single-arm incline triceps extension is a dumbbell exercise targeting the triceps. The incline angle helps to target the long head of the triceps in particular. This exercise is usually performed for moderate to high reps as part of an upper-body or arm-focused workout.
HowTo: 1. Lie back on an incline bench with a dumbbell in one hand. 2. Extend your arm upwards and then lower the dumbbell behind your head, focusing on the triceps as you lift it back to the starting position.

Title: Triceps Overhead Extension with Rope - Gethin Variation
Desc: The overhead triceps extension is an isolation exercise that is performed with a cable. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps as part of the arm-focused portion of a workout.
HowTo: 1. Attach a rope to the high pulley of a cable machine. 2. Stand facing the machine and grasp the rope with both hands. 3. Keep your elbows close to your head and extend your arms upward, then slowly return to the starting position.

Title: Cable rope push-down
Desc: The cable rope push-down is a popular exercise targeting the triceps muscles. It's easy to learn and perform, making it a favorite for everyone from beginners to advanced lifters. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps or more per set, as part of an upper-body or arm-focused workout.
HowTo: 1. Attach a rope to the high pulley of a cable machine. 2. Stand facing the machine and grasp the rope with both hands. 3. Keep your elbows close to your body and push the rope down until your arms are fully extended, then return to the starting position.

Title: Cable straight-bar push-down
Desc: The cable straight-bar push-down is a popular gym exercise for targeting the triceps. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps or more per set, as part of an upper-body or arm-focused workout.
HowTo: 1. Attach a straight bar to the high pulley of a cable machine. 2. Stand facing the machine and grasp the bar with both hands. 3. Keep your elbows close to your body and push the bar down until your arms are fully extended, then return to the starting position.

Title: Straight-arm bar pull-down
Desc: The straight-arm bar pull-down is a variation of the straight-arm lat pull-down performed using a cable stack machine. It can either be performed in an athletic upright stance, or slightly bent over. It both stretches and contracts the muscles of the lats (latissimus dorsi) as well as providing additional activation to the other upper back muscles and the core. Because the triceps are also isometrically involved in the movement, it is usually performed for higher reps, such as 8-15 reps or more.
HowTo: 1. Attach a straight bar to the high pulley of a cable machine. 2. Stand facing the machine and grasp the bar with both hands. 3. With your arms extended, pull the bar down in front of you while keeping your arms straight, then return to the starting position.

Title: AM Rope Triceps Pushdown
Desc: The cable rope push-down is a popular exercise targeting the triceps muscles. It's easy to learn and perform, making it a favorite for everyone from beginners to advanced lifters. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps or more per set, as part of an upper-body or arm-focused workout.
HowTo: 1. Attach a rope to the high pulley of a cable machine. 2. Stand facing the machine and grasp the rope with both hands. 3. Keep your elbows close to your body and push the rope down until your arms are fully extended, then return to the starting position.

Title: AM Bar Triceps Push-Down
Desc: The cable straight-bar push-down is a popular gym exercise for targeting the triceps. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps or more per set, as part of an upper-body or arm-focused workout.
HowTo: 1. Attach a straight bar to a high pulley on a cable machine. 2. Stand facing the machine and grasp the bar with both hands, palms facing down. 3. Keep your elbows close to your body and push the bar down until your arms are fully extended. 4. Slowly return to the starting position.

Title: Rope overhead triceps extension
Desc: The rope overhead triceps extension is a single-joint exercise focused on the triceps that uses a cable stack with a rope handle. The overhead position targets the long head of the triceps in particular. Many lifters save this move for last in their triceps workout, performing it for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps or more per set.
HowTo: 1. Attach a rope handle to a high pulley on a cable machine. 2. Stand with your back to the machine and grasp the rope with both hands. 3. Extend your arms overhead, keeping your elbows close to your head. 4. Lower the rope behind your head by bending your elbows, then return to the starting position.

Title: UP Rope Push-down
Desc: The cable rope push-down is a popular exercise targeting the triceps muscles. It's easy to learn and perform, making it a favorite for everyone from beginners to advanced lifters. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps or more per set, as part of an upper-body or arm-focused workout.
HowTo: 1. Attach a rope handle to a high pulley on a cable machine. 2. Stand facing the machine and grasp the rope with both hands. 3. Keep your elbows close to your body and push the rope down until your arms are fully extended. 4. Slowly return to the starting position.

Title: UP Triceps Extension Straight-Bar Push-Down
Desc: The cable straight-bar push-down is a popular gym exercise for targeting the triceps. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps or more per set, as part of an upper-body or arm-focused workout.
HowTo: 1. Attach a straight bar to a high pulley on a cable machine. 2. Stand facing the machine and grasp the bar with both hands, palms facing down. 3. Keep your elbows close to your body and push the bar down until your arms are fully extended. 4. Slowly return to the starting position.

Title: LD Cable One-Arm Upright Row
Desc: The LD Cable One-Arm Upright Row is an exercise that targets the shoulders and upper back. It is performed using a cable machine, focusing on lifting the weight with one arm at a time.
HowTo: 1. Attach a single handle to a low pulley on a cable machine. 2. Stand next to the machine and grasp the handle with one hand. 3. Pull the handle up towards your chin, keeping your elbow higher than your wrist. 4. Lower the handle back to the starting position.

Title: 30 Arms Underhand Cable Straight-Bar Push-Down
Desc: The underhand cable push-down primarily targets the triceps muscles. It is an effective exercise for building arm strength and definition.
HowTo: 1. Attach a straight bar to a high pulley on a cable machine. 2. Stand facing the machine and grasp the bar with an underhand grip, hands shoulder-width apart. 3. Keep your elbows close to your body and push the bar down until your arms are fully extended. 4. Slowly return to the starting position and repeat.

Title: 30 Arms Single-Arm Reverse-Grip Cable Push-Down
Desc: The single-arm reverse-grip cable push-down focuses on the triceps while allowing for unilateral training. This helps to correct muscle imbalances and improve overall arm strength.
HowTo: 1. Attach a single handle to a high pulley on a cable machine. 2. Stand facing the machine and grasp the handle with a reverse grip (palm facing you). 3. Keep your elbow close to your side and push the handle down until your arm is fully extended. 4. Slowly return to the starting position and repeat for the desired number of reps before switching arms.

Title: 30 Arms Cable V-Bar Push-Down
Desc: The cable V-bar push-down is a variation that targets the triceps effectively. It allows for a different grip and angle, enhancing muscle engagement.
HowTo: 1. Attach a V-bar to a high pulley on a cable machine. 2. Stand facing the machine and grasp the V-bar with both hands. 3. Keep your elbows close to your body and push the bar down until your arms are fully extended. 4. Slowly return to the starting position and repeat.

Title: 30 Arms Cable Straight-Bar Push-Down
Desc: The cable straight-bar push-down is a classic exercise for building tricep strength. It is simple to perform and highly effective for muscle development.
HowTo: 1. Attach a straight bar to a high pulley on a cable machine. 2. Stand facing the machine and grasp the bar with an overhand grip. 3. Keep your elbows tucked in and push the bar down until your arms are fully extended. 4. Slowly return to the starting position and repeat.

Title: 30 Arms Cable Rope Push-Down
Desc: The cable rope push-down is an excellent exercise for isolating the triceps. The rope allows for a greater range of motion and better muscle contraction.
HowTo: 1. Attach a rope handle to a high pulley on a cable machine. 2. Stand facing the machine and grasp the rope with both hands, palms facing each other. 3. Keep your elbows close to your body and push the rope down, spreading the ends apart at the bottom. 4. Slowly return to the starting position and repeat.

Title: 30 Arms Cable Rope Overhead Triceps Extension
Desc: The 30 Arms Cable Rope Overhead Triceps Extension is an effective exercise for targeting the triceps. It involves using a cable machine to perform an overhead extension with a rope attachment.
HowTo: 1. Attach a rope to the high pulley of a cable machine. 2. Stand facing away from the machine and grasp the rope with both hands. 3. Step forward to create tension in the cable. 4. Extend your arms overhead, keeping your elbows close to your head. 5. Slowly lower the rope behind your head, then return to the starting position.

Title: BFR underhand straight-bar push-down
Desc: The blood flow restriction (BFR) underhand straight-bar push-down is an arm movement that builds triceps size and strength using a cable stack, straight-bar grip, and blood flow restriction bands. It is popular in high-rep "pump"-style arm workouts. The bands should be placed as high as possible on your arms, at a tightness of no greater than 8 on a scale of 10. Most BFR workouts recommend using a far lighter weight than usual, perhaps as low as 25-50 percent of a normal working weight.
HowTo: 1. Attach a straight bar to a high pulley on a cable machine. 2. Stand facing the machine and grasp the bar with an underhand grip. 3. Step back to create tension in the cable. 4. Push the bar down towards your thighs, fully extending your arms. 5. Slowly return to the starting position.

Title: BFR overhand straight-bar push-down
Desc: The blood flow restriction (BFR) overhand straight-bar push-down is an arm movement that builds triceps size and strength using a cable stack, straight-bar grip, and blood flow restriction bands. It is popular in high-rep "pump"-style arm workouts. The bands should be placed as high as possible on your arms, at a tightness of no greater than 8 on a scale of 10. Most BFR workouts recommend using a far lighter weight than usual, perhaps as low as 25-50 percent of a normal working weight.
HowTo: 1. Attach a straight bar to a high pulley on a cable machine. 2. Stand facing the machine and grasp the bar with an overhand grip. 3. Step back to create tension in the cable. 4. Push the bar down towards your thighs, fully extending your arms. 5. Slowly return to the starting position.

Title: BFR cable rope push-down
Desc: The blood flow restriction (BFR) cable rope push-down is an arm movement that builds triceps size and strength using a cable stack, rope grip, and blood flow restriction bands. It is popular in high-rep "pump"-style arm workouts. The bands should be placed as high as possible on your arms, at a tightness of no greater than 8 on a scale of 10. Most BFR workouts recommend using a far lighter weight than usual, perhaps as low as 25-50 percent of a normal working weight.
HowTo: 1. Attach a rope to a high pulley on a cable machine. 2. Stand facing the machine and grasp the rope with both hands. 3. Step back to create tension in the cable. 4. Push the rope down towards your thighs, fully extending your arms. 5. Slowly return to the starting position.

Title: Triceps Pressdown
Desc: The Triceps Pressdown is a classic exercise for targeting the triceps. It involves using a cable machine to push down a bar or rope attachment.
HowTo: 1. Attach a bar or rope to a high pulley on a cable machine. 2. Stand facing the machine and grasp the attachment with both hands. 3. Step back to create tension in the cable. 4. Push the attachment down towards your thighs, fully extending your arms. 5. Slowly return to the starting position.

Title: Machine Triceps Extension
Desc: The machine triceps extension is an isolation exercise targeting the tricep muscles.
HowTo: 1. Sit on the machine with your back against the pad. 2. Adjust the seat height so that the handles are at chest level. 3. Grasp the handles with both hands and extend your arms downwards. 4. Slowly return to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Smith machine end-grip shoulder press
Desc: The Smith machine end-grip shoulder press is a machine-based exercise targeting the shoulder muscles. It is performed holding the end of the bar in the Smith machine on the outside of the rack. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of an upper-body or shoulder-focused workout.
HowTo: 1. Position yourself under the bar of the Smith machine with your feet shoulder-width apart. 2. Grip the bar with your hands slightly wider than shoulder-width. 3. Press the bar overhead until your arms are fully extended. 4. Lower the bar back to shoulder level and repeat.

Title: Assist machine triceps push-down
Desc: The assist machine triceps push-down is a triceps-focused exercise that is performed on an assisted pull-up or dip station. It is performed by pressing downward on the knee pad of the machine, against the resistance of the weight. It approximates the motion of a triceps cable rope push-down, but with open hands. This variation is often performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of upper-body or arm-focused training.
HowTo: 1. Adjust the machine to your height and sit down. 2. Grip the handles and position your elbows close to your body. 3. Push the handles down until your arms are fully extended. 4. Slowly return to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Smith machine close-grip bench press-
Desc: The Smith machine close-grip bench press is a machine-based movement targeting the chest and triceps. The Smith machine mimics a barbell but provides more stability. This movement can be programmed in low reps for strength or higher reps for muscle and strength endurance. It is often performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of a chest, arms, or upper-body focused workout.
HowTo: 1. Lie on the bench of the Smith machine with your feet flat on the floor. 2. Grip the bar with your hands shoulder-width apart. 3. Lower the bar to your chest while keeping your elbows close to your body. 4. Press the bar back up to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Machine Triceps Extension - Gethin Variation
Desc: The machine triceps extension is an isolation exercise targeting the tricep muscles.
HowTo: 1. Sit on the machine with your back against the pad. 2. Adjust the seat height so that the handles are at chest level. 3. Grasp the handles with both hands and extend your arms downwards. 4. Slowly return to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Overhead Machine Triceps Extension - Gethin Variation
Desc: The machine triceps extension is an isolation exercise targeting the tricep muscles.
HowTo: 1. Sit at the machine with your back against the pad. 2. Grasp the handles and extend your arms downward, keeping your elbows close to your body. 3. Slowly return to the starting position and repeat.

Title: 30 Arms Machine Triceps Dip
Desc: The 30 Arms Machine Triceps Dip is a strength exercise targeting the triceps.
HowTo: 1. Sit on the machine and place your hands on the dip handles. 2. Lower your body by bending your elbows until your arms are at a 90-degree angle. 3. Push back up to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Triceps dip
Desc: The triceps dip is a bodyweight exercise performed on parallel bars or on a pull-up and dip station. It targets the triceps first, but also stretches and strengthens the chest and shoulders. Dips with a triceps focus are usually performed with an upright torso, the knees bent and crossed, and the arms close to the body. Dips can be performed for low reps for strength or higher reps for muscle growth.
HowTo: 1. Position yourself on parallel bars with your arms straight. 2. Lower your body by bending your elbows until your upper arms are parallel to the ground. 3. Push back up to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Weighted bench dip
Desc: The weighted bench dip is a highly effective exercise for building the triceps. The resistance comes from a combination of body weight and added weightusually a weight plate.
HowTo: 1. Sit on the edge of a bench with your hands beside you. 2. Slide your buttocks off the bench and lower your body by bending your elbows. 3. Push back up to the starting position, adding weight if desired.

Title: Push-Ups - Close Triceps Position
Desc: The close push-up is an upper-body exercise that targets the chest, triceps, and shoulders. The close hand position places more emphasis on the triceps.
HowTo: 1. Start in a plank position with your hands close together. 2. Lower your body towards the ground while keeping your elbows close to your sides. 3. Push back up to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Parallel Bar Dip
Desc: The triceps dip is a bodyweight exercise performed on parallel bars or on a pull-up and dip station. It targets the triceps first, but also stretches and strengthens the chest and shoulders. Dips with a triceps focus are usually performed with an upright torso, the knees bent and crossed, and the arms close to the body. Dips can be performed for low reps for strength or higher reps for muscle growth.
HowTo: 1. Position yourself on the parallel bars with your arms straight and your body upright. 2. Lower your body by bending your elbows until your upper arms are parallel to the ground. 3. Push yourself back up to the starting position.

Title: Ring dip
Desc: The ring dip is an upper-body strength exercise performed on gymnastic rings. It targets the muscles of the chest, triceps, and shoulders, but is also quite taxing to the core. It is generally considered to be more difficult than dips performed on parallel bars. It is common in gymnastics training and CrossFit workouts, but is also a simple way to make dips more challenging for any strength athlete.
HowTo: 1. Grip the rings and lift your body off the ground. 2. Lower your body by bending your elbows while keeping your torso upright. 3. Push back up to the starting position.

Title: Feet-elevated bench dip
Desc: The feet-elevated bench dip is a popular bodyweight exercise for building the triceps, chest, and shoulders. Elevating the feet brings more chest and shoulder into the movement, but also allows for extra weight on the hips. If these bother your shoulders, try performing them between two benches or chairs rather than on a single bench.
HowTo: 1. Sit on the edge of a bench with your hands beside your hips. 2. Place your feet on another bench behind you. 3. Lower your body by bending your elbows, then push back up to the starting position.

Title: Bodyweight triceps press
Desc: The bodyweight triceps press is an arm movement that involves performing overhead presses in a face-down position on a Smith machine or other raised bar. It is a surprisingly difficult movement that hammers all three heads of the triceps and the difficulty can easily be scaled up or down by moving the bar.
HowTo: 1. Position yourself face down on a raised bar or Smith machine. 2. Grip the bar with your hands shoulder-width apart. 3. Press the bar overhead by extending your arms.

Title: Standing Towel Triceps Extension
Desc: The Standing Towel Triceps Extension is a bodyweight exercise that focuses on the triceps. It can be performed using a towel for resistance.
HowTo: 1. Stand upright and hold a towel with both hands above your head. 2. Bend your elbows to lower the towel behind your head. 3. Extend your arms back to the starting position.

Title: Tricep Side Stretch
Desc: The Tricep Side Stretch helps improve flexibility in the triceps and shoulders. It is a simple stretch that can be performed anywhere.
HowTo: 1. Stand or sit comfortably. 2. Raise one arm overhead and bend the elbow, reaching down your back. 3. Use the opposite hand to gently pull the elbow for a deeper stretch. 4. Hold for 15-30 seconds, then switch sides.

Title: Triceps Stretch
Desc: The Triceps Stretch is designed to enhance flexibility in the triceps and shoulders. It is beneficial for relieving tension in the upper body.
HowTo: 1. Stand or sit comfortably. 2. Raise one arm overhead, bend the elbow, and reach down your back. 3. Use the opposite hand to gently push the elbow for a deeper stretch. 4. Hold for 15-30 seconds, then switch sides.

Title: Overhead Triceps
Desc: Overhead Triceps is an effective exercise for building strength in the triceps. It also engages the shoulders and core for stability.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, holding a dumbbell with both hands. 2. Raise the dumbbell overhead, arms straight. 3. Lower the dumbbell behind your head by bending your elbows. 4. Extend your arms back to the starting position. 5. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Russian Bar Dip
Desc: The Russian dip is a chest-and-triceps building exercise that resembles the chest dip, albeit with a twist that makes it even harder and more taxing.
HowTo: 1. Position yourself on parallel bars with your arms straight. 2. Lean forward slightly and lower your body by bending your elbows. 3. Keep your elbows close to your body as you descend. 4. Push back up to the starting position. 5. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Straight-arm plank with kick-back
Desc: The straight-arm plank with kick-back is a hybrid movement that trains the abdominal and triceps muscles simultaneously. It can address multiple muscle groups in a time-efficient muscle-building or circuit-style workout, while also providing an additional cardiovascular challenge.
HowTo: 1. Start in a plank position with arms straight and feet hip-width apart. 2. Engage your core and maintain a straight line from head to heels. 3. Lift one arm straight back, squeezing the triceps, then return to plank. 4. Alternate arms for the desired number of reps.

Title: TBS Dip
Desc: The triceps dip is a machine version of an exercise that many lifters perform using parallel bars or two parallel benches. The machine is found in many gyms.
HowTo: 1. Adjust the machine to your height. 2. Sit on the machine and grasp the handles. 3. Lower your body by bending your elbows until your arms are at a 90-degree angle. 4. Push back up to the starting position.

Title: Bench Dips - Gethin Variation
Desc: The bench dip is a highly effective exercise for building the triceps. The resistance comes from the body itself, rather than weight.
HowTo: 1. Sit on the edge of a bench with your hands next to your thighs. 2. Move your body forward off the bench, supporting your weight with your arms. 3. Lower your body by bending your elbows until they are at a 90-degree angle. 4. Push back up to the starting position.

Title: Banded dip
Desc: The banded dip is a bodyweight exercise targeting the chest, triceps, and shoulders. This variation utilizes an exercise band to help support the lifter in the bottom part of the movement. This makes pushing out of the hole easier, and may combat the shoulder pain that some lifters feel when they perform dips. The top of the movement receives less help from the band, putting more stress on the triceps.
HowTo: 1. Attach a resistance band to a sturdy overhead anchor. 2. Place the band around your shoulders. 3. Grasp the dip bars and lower your body by bending your elbows. 4. Push back up to the starting position, using the band for assistance.

Title: Bench Dip - Gethin Variation
Desc: The bench dip is a highly effective exercise for building the triceps. The resistance comes from the body itself, rather than weight.
HowTo: 1. Sit on the edge of a bench with your hands next to your thighs. 2. Move your body forward off the bench, supporting your weight with your arms. 3. Lower your body by bending your elbows until they are at a 90-degree angle. 4. Push back up to the starting position.

Title: HM Chair Dip
Desc: The HM Chair Dip is a variation of the dip exercise that targets the triceps and chest. It can be performed using a chair or a bench.
HowTo: 1. Sit on the edge of a chair with your hands next to your thighs. 2. Move your body forward off the chair, supporting your weight with your arms. 3. Lower your body by bending your elbows until they are at a 90-degree angle. 4. Push back up to the starting position.

Title: Bench dip
Desc: The bench dip is a highly effective exercise for building the triceps. The resistance comes from the body itself, rather than added weight.
HowTo: 1. Sit on the edge of a bench with your hands next to your thighs. 2. Slide your buttocks off the bench, supporting your weight with your arms. 3. Lower your body by bending your elbows until they are at about a 90-degree angle. 4. Push back up to the starting position.

Title: Holman Step Triceps Dip
Desc: The Holman Step Triceps Dip is a variation of the traditional dip that targets the triceps effectively. It involves using a step or platform to increase the range of motion.
HowTo: 1. Stand in front of a step or platform. 2. Place your hands on the edge of the step, fingers facing forward. 3. Extend your legs out in front of you. 4. Lower your body by bending your elbows, then push back up to the starting position.

Title: Holman Chair Triceps Dip
Desc: The Holman Chair Triceps Dip is performed using a chair for support and focuses on building triceps strength. It is a bodyweight exercise that can be done anywhere.
HowTo: 1. Sit on the edge of a chair with your hands beside your hips. 2. Move your hips forward off the chair. 3. Lower your body by bending your elbows, then push back up.

Title: Bodyweight Triceps Rope Press
Desc: The Bodyweight Triceps Rope Press is an exercise that targets the triceps using body weight. It can be performed with a rope attachment in a cable machine or using a resistance band.
HowTo: 1. Stand facing the cable machine with a rope attachment at shoulder height. 2. Grab the rope with both hands and step back. 3. Press the rope down by extending your arms while keeping your elbows close to your body. 4. Return to the starting position.

Title: Holman Heavy Triceps Overhead Press
Desc: The Holman Heavy Triceps Overhead Press is a compound exercise that targets the triceps and shoulders. It involves pressing a weight overhead to build strength.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and hold a weight overhead. 2. Lower the weight behind your head by bending your elbows. 3. Press the weight back up to the starting position.

Title: Holman Couch Triceps Dip
Desc: The Holman Couch Triceps Dip is an effective exercise for targeting the triceps. It involves using a stable surface to perform dips that primarily engage the arm muscles.
HowTo: 1. Sit on the edge of a couch or bench with your hands beside you, fingers facing forward. 2. Move your hips forward off the edge and lower your body by bending your elbows. 3. Push back up to the starting position by straightening your arms.

Title: FYR2 Triceps Push-Up
Desc: The FYR2 Triceps Push-Up is a variation of the traditional push-up that emphasizes the triceps. This exercise not only strengthens the arms but also engages the chest and shoulders.
HowTo: 1. Start in a push-up position with your hands placed closer than shoulder-width apart. 2. Lower your body while keeping your elbows close to your sides. 3. Push back up to the starting position.

Title: 30 Arms Triceps Dip
Desc: The 30 Arms Triceps Dip is designed to build strength in the triceps and shoulders. It is performed using a stable surface to support the body weight.
HowTo: 1. Position yourself on a bench or chair with your hands beside you. 2. Lower your body by bending your elbows while keeping your back close to the bench. 3. Push back up to the starting position using your triceps.

Title: 30 Arms Close-Grip Push-Up
Desc: The 30 Arms Close-Grip Push-Up focuses on the triceps while also engaging the chest and shoulders. This variation of the push-up is excellent for building upper body strength.
HowTo: 1. Begin in a push-up position with your hands close together under your chest. 2. Lower your body while keeping your elbows tucked in. 3. Push back up to the starting position.

Title: 30 Arms BFR Close-Grip Push-Up
Desc: The 30 Arms BFR Close-Grip Push-Up incorporates blood flow restriction to enhance muscle growth in the triceps and upper body. This exercise is effective for those looking to increase strength and hypertrophy.
HowTo: 1. Wrap a blood flow restriction band around your upper arms. 2. Get into a close-grip push-up position. 3. Lower your body while keeping your elbows close to your sides, then push back up.

Title: Supine Chest Throw
Desc: The Supine Chest Throw is an explosive exercise that targets the chest and triceps. It is performed lying on your back, throwing a medicine ball or similar object upwards.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back on a flat surface with your knees bent. 2. Hold a medicine ball at chest level. 3. Explosively throw the ball upwards while extending your arms. 4. Catch the ball as it comes down and repeat.

Title: Decline EZ-bar skullcrusher
Desc: The decline EZ-bar skullcrusher is a popular exercise targeting the triceps muscles. The angle of the bench creates a greater range of motion than flat bench skullcrushers, as well as targeting the lateral head of the muscle. This exercise is usually performed for moderate to high reps as part of an upper-body or arm-focused workout.
HowTo: 1. Lie on a decline bench and hold an EZ-bar with a close grip. 2. Lower the bar towards your forehead while keeping your elbows stationary. 3. Extend your arms back to the starting position.

Title: EZ-Bar Skullcrusher
Desc: The EZ-bar skullcrusher is a popular exercise targeting the triceps muscles. The EZ-bar is used more often than a straight bar. As for the name, thats worst-case scenario. The bar should actually come down behind the head. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps as part of an upper body or arms-focused workout. No need to chase a 1RM on this move!
HowTo: 1. Lie on a flat bench and hold an EZ-bar with a close grip. 2. Lower the bar behind your head while keeping your elbows stationary. 3. Extend your arms back to the starting position.

Title: EZ-bar skullcrusher-
Desc: The EZ-bar skullcrusher is a popular exercise targeting the triceps muscles. Contrary to what the name implies, the bar should actually come down behind the head. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps as part of an upper-body or arms-focused workout.

Title: Lying Close-Grip Barbell Triceps Press To Chin
Desc: The Lying Close-Grip Barbell Triceps Press To Chin is an effective exercise for targeting the triceps and shoulders.
HowTo: 1. Lie on a flat bench and hold a barbell with a close grip. 2. Lower the barbell towards your chin while keeping your elbows close to your body. 3. Press the barbell back to the starting position.

Title: EZ-Bar Skullcrusher - Gethin Variation
Desc: The EZ-bar skullcrusher is a popular exercise targeting the triceps muscles. The EZ-bar is used more often than a straight bar. As for the name, thats worst-case scenario. The bar should actually come down behind the head. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps as part of an upper body or arms-focused workout. No need to chase a 1RM on this move!
HowTo: 1. Lie on a bench with an EZ-bar held above your chest. 2. Lower the bar behind your head by bending your elbows. 3. Extend your arms back to the starting position.
